entry.ety: L. temerarius. See Temerity
entry.def: Unreasonably adventurous; despising danger; rash; headstrong; audacious; reckless; heedless.
entry.q: I spake against temerarious judgment.

entry.ety: L. temerare to defile
entry.def: Temerity.

entry.usage: Temerity Rashness. These words are closely allied in sense, but have a slight difference in their use and application. Temerity is Latin, and rashness is Anglo-Saxon. As in many such cases, the Latin term is more select and dignified; the Anglo-Saxon more familiar and energetic. We show temerity in hasty decisions, and the conduct to which they lead. We show rashness in particular actions, as dictated by sudden impulse. It is an exhibition of temerity to approach the verge of a precipice; it is an act of rashness to jump into a river without being able to swim. Temerity, then, is an unreasonable contempt of danger; rashness is a rushing into danger from thoughtlessness or excited feeling.
entry.ety: L. temeritas, from temere by chance, rashly; perhaps akin to Skr. tamas darkness: cf. F. témérité
entry.def: Unreasonable contempt of danger; extreme venturesomeness; rashness; as, the temerity of a commander in war.
entry.q: It is notorious temerity to pass sentence upon grounds uncapable of evidence.
Her rush hand in evil hour Forth reaching to the fruit, she plucked, she eat.

entry.def: Temerarious.
Of or pertaining to Temple, a valley in Thessaly, celebrated by Greek poets on account of its beautiful scenery; resembling Temple; hence, beautiful; delightful; charming.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tempered; p. pr. & vb. n. Tempering
entry.ety: AS. temprian or OF. temper, F. tempérer, and (in sense 3temper, L. temperare, akin to tempus time. Cf. Temporal Distemper Tamper

sn.def: To mingle in due proportion; to prepare by combining; to modify, as by adding some new element; to qualify, as by an ingredient; hence, to soften; to mollify; to assuage; to soothe; to calm.
sn.q: Puritan austerity was so tempered by Dutch indifference, that mercy itself could not have dictated a milder system.
Woman! lovely woman! nature made thee To temper man: we had been brutes without you.
But thy fire Shall be more tempered, and thy hope far higher.
She [the Goddess of Justice] threw darkness and clouds about her, that tempered the light into a thousand beautiful shades and colors.

sn.def: To fit together; to adjust; to accomodate.
sn.q: Thy sustenance . . . serving to the appetite of the eater, tempered itself to every man's liking.

sn.def: To bring to a proper degree of hardness; as, to temper iron or steel.
sn.q: The tempered metals clash, and yield a silver sound.

sn.def: To govern; to manage.
sn.q: With which the damned ghosts he governeth, And furies rules, and Tartare tempereth.

sn.def: To moisten to a proper consistency and stir thoroughly, as clay for making brick, loam for molding, etc.
To adjust, as the mathematical scale to the actual scale, or to that in actual use.
sn.syn: To soften; mollify; assuage; soothe; calm.

cs.cd: in deep well boring, an adjusting screw connecting the working beam with the rope carrying the tools, for lowering the tools as the drilling progresses.

sn.def: The state of any compound substance which results from the mixture of various ingredients; due mixture of different qualities; just combination; as, the temper of mortar.
Constitution of body; temperament; in old writers, the mixture or relative proportion of the four humors, blood, choler, phlegm, and melancholy.
sn.q: The exquisiteness of his [Christ's] bodily temper increased the exquisiteness of his torment.

sn.def: Disposition of mind; the constitution of the mind, particularly with regard to the passions and affections; as, a calm temper; a hasty temper; a fretful temper.
sn.q: Remember with what mild And gracious temper he both heared and judged.
The consequents of a certain ethical temper.

sn.def: Calmness of mind; moderation; equanimity; composure; as, to keep one's temper .
sn.q: To fall with dignity, with temper rise.
Restore yourselves to your tempers, fathers.

sn.def: Heat of mind or passion; irritation; proneness to anger; -- in a reproachful sense.
The state of a metal or other substance, especially as to its hardness, produced by some process of heating or cooling; as, the temper of iron or steel.
Middle state or course; mean; medium.
sn.q: The perfect lawgiver is a just temper between the mere man of theory, who can see nothing but general principles, and the mere man of business, who can see nothing but particular circumstances.

sn.def: Milk of lime, or other substance, employed in the process formerly used to clarify sugar.
sn.syn: Disposition; temperament; frame; humor; mood. See Disposition.

sn.def: To accord; to agree; to act and think in conformity.
To have or get a proper or desired state or quality; to grow soft and pliable.
sn.q: I have him already tempering between my finger and my thumb, and shortly will I seal with him.

entry.note: ☞ The term is applied especially to early Italian painting, common vehicles of which were yolk of egg, yolk and white of egg mixed together, the white juice of the fig tree, and the like.
entry.ety: It
entry.def: A mode or process of painting; distemper.
Capable of being tempered.
entry.q: The fusible, hard, and temperable texture of metals.

cs.cd: that in which the variations from mathematically true pitch are distributed among all the keys alike.
that in which the variations are thrown into the keys least used.

entry.ety: L. temperamentum a mixing in due proportion, proper measure, temperament: cf. F. tempérament. See Temper v. t.

sn.def: Internal constitution; state with respect to the relative proportion of different qualities, or constituent parts.
sn.q: The common law . . . has reduced the kingdom to its just state and temperament.

sn.def: Due mixture of qualities; a condition brought about by mutual compromises or concessions.
sn.q: However, I forejudge not any probable expedient, any temperament that can be found in things of this nature, so disputable on their side.

sn.def: The act of tempering or modifying; adjustment, as of clashing rules, interests, passions, or the like; also, the means by which such adjustment is effected.
sn.q: Wholesome temperaments of the rashness of popular assemblies.

sn.def: Condition with regard to heat or cold; temperature.
sn.q: Bodies are denominated “hot” and “cold” in proportion to the present temperament of that part of our body to which they are applied.

sn.def: A system of compromises in the tuning of organs, pianofortes, and the like, whereby the tones generated with the vibrations of a ground tone are mutually modified and in part canceled, until their number reduced to the actual practicable scale of twelve tones to the octave. This scale, although in so far artificial, is yet closely suggestive of its origin in nature, and this system of tuning, although not mathematically true, yet satisfies the ear, while it has the convenience that the same twelve fixed tones answer for every key or scale, C♯ becoming identical with D♭, and so on.

The peculiar physical and mental character of an individual, in olden times erroneously supposed to be due to individual variation in the relations and proportions of the constituent parts of the body, especially of the fluids, as the bile, blood, lymph, etc. Hence the phrases, bilious or choleric temperament, sanguine temperament, etc., implying a predominance of one of these fluids and a corresponding influence on the temperament.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to temperament; constitutional.

cs.cd: an association formed for the purpose of diminishing or stopping the use of alcoholic liquors as a beverage.

entry.ety: L. temperantia: cf. F. tempérance. See Temper v. t.

sn.def: Habitual moderation in regard to the indulgence of the natural appetites and passions; restrained or moderate indulgence; moderation; as, temperance in eating and drinking; temperance in the indulgence of joy or mirth; specifically, moderation, and sometimes abstinence, in respect to using intoxicating liquors.
Moderation of passion; patience; calmness; sedateness.
sn.q: A gentleman of alltemperance.
He calmed his wrath with goodly temperance.

sn.def: State with regard to heat or cold; temperature.
sn.q: Tender and delicatetemperance.

entry.def: Temperance.

cs.cd: that part of the earth which lies between either tropic and the corresponding polar circle; -- so called because the heat is less than in the torrid zone, and the cold less than in the frigid zones.

entry.ety: L. temperatus, p. p. of temperare. See Temper v. t.

sn.def: Moderate; not excessive; as, temperate heat; a temperate climate.
Not marked with passion; not violent; cool; calm; as, temperate language.
sn.q: She is not hot, but temperate as the morn.
That sober freedom out of which there springs Our loyal passion for our temperate kings.

sn.def: Moderate in the indulgence of the natural appetites or passions; as, temperate in eating and drinking.
sn.q: Be sober and temperate, and you will be healthy.

sn.def: Proceeding from temperance.
sn.q: The temperate sleeps, and spirits light as air.
sn.syn: Abstemious; sober; calm; cool; sedate.

entry.def: To render temperate; to moderate; to soften; to temper.
entry.q: It inflames temperance, and temperates wrath.

entry.def: In a temperate manner.
The quality or state of being temperate; moderateness; temperance.

entry.ety: Cf. L. temperativus soothing
entry.def: Having power to temper.

entry.note: The temperature of a liquid or a solid body as measured by a thermometer is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the consituent atoms or molecules of the body. For other states of matter such as plasma, electromagnetic radiation, or subatomic particles, an analogous measure of the average kinetic energy may be expressed as a temperature, although it could never be measured by a traditional thermometer, let alone by sensing with the skin.
entry.cs: Absolute temperature. Physics See under Absolute. Animal temperature Physiol the nearly constant temperature maintained in the bodies of warm-blooded (homoiothermal) animals during life. The ultimate source of the heat is to be found in the potential energy of the food and the oxygen which is absorbed from the air during respiration. See Homoiothermal. Temperature sense Physiol the faculty of perceiving cold and warmth, and so of perceiving differences of temperature in external objects. H. N. Martin.
entry.ety: F. température, L. temperatura due measure, proportion, temper, temperament

sn.def: Constitution; state; degree of any quality.
sn.q: The best composition and temperature is, to have openness in fame and opinion, secrecy in habit, dissimulation in seasonable use, and a power to feign, if there be no remedy.
Memory depends upon the consistence and the temperature of the brain.

sn.def: Freedom from passion; moderation.
sn.q: In that proud port, which her so goodly graceth, Most goodly temperature you may descry.

sn.def: Condition with respect to heat or cold, especially as indicated by the sensation produced, or by the thermometer or pyrometer; degree of heat or cold; as, the temperature of the air; high temperature; low temperature; temperature of freezing or of boiling.
Mixture; compound.
sn.q: Made a temperature of brass and iron together.

sn.def: The degree of heat of the body of a living being, esp. of the human body; also Colloq, loosely, the excess of this over the normal (of the human body 98°-99.5° F., in the mouth of an adult about 98.4°).

entry.def: Brought to a proper temper; as, tempered steel; having (such) a temper; -- chiefly used in composition; as, a good-tempered or bad-tempered man; a well-tempered sword.
One who, or that which, tempers; specifically, a machine in which lime, cement, stone, etc., are mixed with water.

cs.cd: the shade of color that indicates the degree of temper in tempering steel, as pale straw yellow for lancets, razors, and tools for metal; dark straw yellow for penknives, screw taps, etc.; brown yellow for axes, chisels, and plane irons; yellow tinged with purple for table knives and shears; purple for swords and watch springs; blue for springs and saws; and very pale blue tinged with green, too soft for steel instruments.

entry.def: The process of giving the requisite degree of hardness or softness to a substance, as iron and steel; especially, the process of giving to steel the degree of hardness required for various purposes, consisting usually in first plunging the article, when heated to redness, in cold water or other liquid, to give an excess of hardness, and then reheating it gradually until the hardness is reduced or drawn down to the degree required, as indicated by the color produced on a polished portion, or by the burning of oil.

entries.entry:
Tem"per screw. A screw link, to which is attached the rope of a rope-drilling apparatus, for feeding and slightly turning the drill jar at each stroke.
A set screw used for adjusting.

entry.note: ☞ Tempest is sometimes used in the formation of self-explaining compounds; as, tempest-beaten, tempest-loving, tempest-tossed, tempest-winged, and the like.
entry.ety: OF. tempeste, F. tempête, (assumed) LL. tempesta, fr. L. tempestas a portion of time, a season, weather, storm, akin to tempus time. See Temporal of time

sn.def: An extensive current of wind, rushing with great velocity and violence, and commonly attended with rain, hail, or snow; a furious storm.
sn.q: We] caught in a fiery tempest, shall be hurled, Each on his rock transfixed.

sn.def: Fig.: Any violent tumult or commotion; as, a political tempest; a tempest of war, or of the passions.
A fashionable assembly; a drum. See the Note under Drum n., 4.
sn.syn: Storm; agitation; perturbation. See Storm.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. tempester, F. tempêter to rage
entry.def: To disturb as by a tempest.
entry.q: Part huge of bulk Wallowing unwieldy, enormous in their gait,Tempest the ocean.

entry.def: To storm.

entry.ety: L. tempestivus
entry.def: Seasonable; timely; as, tempestive showers.

entry.ety: L. tempestivitas
entry.def: The quality, or state, of being tempestive; seasonableness.

entry.ety: L. tempestuous: cf. OF. tempestueux, F. tempêtueux
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a tempest; involving or resembling a tempest; turbulent; violent; stormy; as, tempestuous weather; a tempestuous night; a tempestuous debate.
entry.q: They saw the Hebrew leader, Waiting, and clutching his tempestuous beard.

entry.note: ☞ The order was first limited in numbers, and its members were bound by vows of chastity and poverty. After the conquest of Palestine by the Saracens, the Templars spread over Europe, and, by reason of their reputation for valor and piety, they were enriched by numerous donations of money and lands. The extravagances and vices of the later Templars, however, finally led to the suppression of the order by the Council of Vienne in 1312.
entry.ety: OE. templere, F. templier, LL. templarius. See Temple a church

sn.def: One of a religious and military order first established at Jerusalem, in the early part of the 12th century, for the protection of pilgrims and of the Holy Sepulcher. These Knights Templars, or Knights of the Temple, were so named because they occupied an apartment of the palace of Bladwin II. in Jerusalem, near the Temple.
A student of law, so called from having apartments in the Temple at London, the original buildings having belonged to the Knights Templars. See Inner Temple, and Middle Temple, under Temple.
One belonged to a certain order or degree among the Freemasons, called Knights Templars. Also, one of an order among temperance men, styled Good Templars.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a temple.
entry.q: Solitary, family, and templar devotion.

entry.def: Same as Templet.

entry.ety: Cf. Templet
entry.def: A contrivence used in a loom for keeping the web stretched transversely.

entry.ety: OF. temple, F. tempe, from L. tempora tempus; perhaps originally, the right place, the fatal spot, supposed to be the same word as tempus temporis, the fitting or appointed time. See Temporal of time, and cf. Tempo Tense n.

sn.def: The space, on either side of the head, back of the eye and forehead, above the zygomatic arch and in front of the ear.
One of the side bars of a pair of spectacles, jointed to the bows, and passing one on either side of the head to hold the spectacles in place.

cs.cd: two buildings, or ranges of buildings, occupied by two inns of court in London, on the site of a monastic establishment of the Knights Templars, called the Temple.

entry.ety: AS. tempel, from L. templum a space marked out, sanctuary, temple; cf. Gr. � a piece of land marked off, land dedicated to a god: cf. F. témple, from the Latin. Cf. Contemplate

sn.def: A place or edifice dedicated to the worship of some deity; as, the temple of Jupiter at Athens, or of Juggernaut in India.
sn.q: Thetempleof mighty Mars.

sn.def: The edifice erected at Jerusalem for the worship of Jehovah.
sn.q: Jesus walked in the temple in Solomon's porch.

sn.def: Hence, among Christians, an edifice erected as a place of public worship; a church.
sn.q: Can he whose life is a perpetual insult to the authority of God enter with any pleasure a temple consecrated to devotion and sanctified by prayer?

sn.def: Fig.: Any place in which the divine presence specially resides.
sn.q: Thetempleof his body.
Know ye not that ye are the temple of God, and that the spirit of God dwelleth in you?
The groves were God's first temples.

sn.def: A building dedicated to the administration of ordinances.
A local organization of Odd Fellows.

entry.def: To build a temple for; to appropriate a temple to; as, to temple a god.
Supplied with a temple or temples, or with churches; inclosed in a temple.
entry.q: I love thy rocks and rills, Thy woods and templed hills.

entry.ety: LL. templatus vaulted, from L. templum a small timber

sn.def: A gauge, pattern, or mold, commonly a thin plate or board, used as a guide to the form of the work to be executed; as, a mason's or a wheelwright's templet .
A short piece of timber, iron, or stone, placed in a wall under a girder or other beam, to distribute the weight or pressure.

entry.cs: ‖A tempo giusto j�s"t� It in exact time; -- sometimes, directing a return to strict time after a tempo rubato. Tempo rubato. See under Rubato.
entry.ety: It., fr. L. tempus. See Tense n.
entry.def: The rate or degree of movement in time.

cs.cd: a very complex bone situated in the side of the skull of most mammals and containing the organ of hearing. It consists of an expanded squamosal portion above the ear, corresponding to the squamosal and zygoma of the lower vertebrates, and a thickened basal petrosal and mastoid portion, corresponding to the periotic and tympanic bones of the lower vertebrates.

entry.ety: L. temporalis, fr. tempora the temples: cf. F. temporal. See Temple a part of the head
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the temple or temples; as, the temporal bone; a temporal artery.

entry.cs:
Lords temporal. See under Lord n.
Temporal augment. See the Note under Augment n.
entry.ety: L. temporalis, fr. tempus temporis, time, portion of time, the fitting or appointed time: cf. F. temporel. Cf. Contemporaneous Extempore Temper v. t. Tempest Temple a part of the head, Tense n. Thing

sn.def: Of or pertaining to time, that is, to the present life, or this world; secular, as distinguished from sacred or eternal.
sn.q: The things which are seen are temporal, but the things which are not seen are eternal.
Is this an hour for temporal affairs?

sn.def: Civil or political, as distinguished from ecclesiastical; as, temporal power; temporal courts.
sn.syn: Transient; fleeting; transitory.

entry.def: Anything temporal or secular; a temporality; -- used chiefly in the plural.
entry.q: He assigns supremacy to the pope in spirituals, and to the emperor or temporals.

entries.entry:
Tem`po*ral"i*ty n.; pl.Temporalities #. L. temporalitas, in LL., possessions of the church: cf. F. temporalité
The state or quality of being temporary; -- opposed to perpetuity.
The laity; temporality. Obs
That which pertains to temporal welfare; material interests; especially, the revenue of an ecclesiastic proceeding from lands, tenements, or lay fees, tithes, and the like; -- chiefly used in the plural. Supreme head, . . . under God, of the spirituality and temporality of the same church.

entry.def: In a temporal manner; secularly.
Worldliness.

entry.ety: See Temporality

sn.def: The laity; secular people.
A secular possession; a temporality.

entry.ety: L. temporaneus happening at the right time, fr. tempus temporis, time
entry.def: Temporarity.
In a temporary manner; for a time.
The quality or state of being temporary; -- opposed to perpetuity.

entry.cs: Temporary star. Astron See under Star.
entry.ety: L. temporarius, fr. tempus temporis, time: cf. F. temporaire
entry.def: Lasting for a time only; existing or continuing for a limited time; not permanent; as, the patient has obtained temporary relief.
entry.q: Temporary government of the city.

entry.def: A temporizer.
entry.q: Why, turn a temporist, row with the tide.

entry.ety: Cf. F. temporisation
entry.def: The act of temporizing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Temporized; p. pr. & vb. n. Temporizing
entry.ety: F. temporiser. See Temporal of time

sn.def: To comply with the time or occasion; to humor, or yield to, the current of opinion or circumstances; also, to trim, as between two parties.
sn.q: They might their grievance inwardly complain, But outwardly they needs must temporize.

sn.def: To delay; to procrastinate.
To comply; to agree.

entry.def: One who temporizes; one who yields to the time, or complies with the prevailing opinions, fashions, or occasions; a trimmer.
entry.q: A sort of temporizers, ready to embrace and maintain all that is, or shall be, proposed, in hope of preferment.

entry.def: In a temporizing or yielding manner.

entries.entry: Tem"po*ro-. A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to the temple, or temporal bone; as, temporofacial.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to both the temple and the ear; as, the temporo-auricular nerve.
Of or pertaining to both the temple and the face.
Of or pertaining to both the temple and the region of the malar bone; as, the temporomalar nerve.
Of or pertaining to both the temple or the temporal bone and the maxilla.

entry.ety: OF. & F., fr. L. tempus. See Temporal of time
entry.def: Time.
See Temse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tempted; p. pr. & vb. n. Tempting
entry.ety: OE. tempten tenten, from OF. tempter tenter, F. tenter, fr. L. tentare temptare, to handle, feel, attack, to try, put to the test, urge, freq. from tendere tentum, and tensum, to stretch. See Thin, and cf. Attempt Tend Taunt Tent a pavilion, Tent to probe

sn.def: To put to trial; to prove; to test; to try.
sn.q: God did tempt Abraham.
Ye shall not tempt the Lord your God.

sn.def: To lead, or endeavor to lead, into evil; to entice to what is wrong; to seduce.
sn.q: Every man is tempted when he is drawn away of his own lust, and enticed.

sn.def: To endeavor to persuade; to induce; to invite; to incite; to provoke; to instigate.
sn.q: Tempt not the brave and needy to despair.
Nor tempt the wrath of heaven's avenging Sire.

sn.def: To endeavor to accomplish or reach; to attempt.
sn.q: Ere leave be given to tempt the nether skies.
sn.syn: To entice; allure; attract; decoy; seduce.

entry.def: The quality or state of being temptable; lability to temptation.
Capable of being tempted; liable to be tempted.

entry.ety: OF. temptation tentation, F. tentation, L. tentatio

sn.def: The act of tempting, or enticing to evil; seduction.
sn.q: When the devil had ended all the temptation, he departed from him for a season.

sn.def: The state of being tempted, or enticed to evil.
sn.q: Lead us not into temptation.

sn.def: That which tempts; an inducement; an allurement, especially to something evil.
sn.q: Dare to be great, without a guilty crown; View it, and lay the bright temptation down.

entry.def: Having no temptation or motive; as, a temptationless sin.
Tempting.
One who tempts or entices; especially, Satan, or the Devil, regarded as the great enticer to evil.
entry.q: Those who are bent to do wickedly will never wanttemptersto urge them on.
So glozed the Tempter, and his proem tuned.

entry.def: Adapted to entice or allure; attractive; alluring; seductive; enticing; as, tempting pleasures.
A woman who entices.
entry.q: She was my temptress, the foul provoker.

cs.cd: bread made of flour better sifted than common fluor.

entry.ety: F. tamis, or D. tems teems. Cf. Tamine
entry.def: A sieve.

entry.ety: L. temulentia
entry.def: Intoxication; inebriation; drunkenness.
entry.q: Theirtemulency.

entry.ety: L. temulentus
entry.def: Intoxicated; drunken.
Somewhat temulent; addicted to drink.

entry.note: ☞ Ten is often used, indefinitely, for several many, and other like words.
entry.ety: AS. tēn tién tȳn tēne; akin to OFries. tian, OS. tehan, D. tien, G. zehn, OHG. zehan, Icel. tīu, Sw. tio, Dan. ti, Goth. taíhun, Lith. deszimt, Russ. desiate, W. deg, Ir. & Gael. deich, L. decem, Gr. de`ka, Skr. daçan. √308. Cf. Dean Decade Decimal December Eighteen Eighty Teens Tithe
entry.def: One more than nine; twice five.
entry.q: With twice ten sail I crossed the Phrygian Sea.
There 's a proud modesty in merit, Averse from begging, and resolved to payTen times the gift it asks.

sn.def: The number greater by one than nine; the sum of five and five; ten units of objects.
sn.q: I will not destroy it for ten's sake.

sn.def: A symbol representing ten units, as 10, x, or X.

entry.def: The quality or state of being tenable; tenableness.

entry.ety: F. tenable, fr. tenir to hold, L. tenere. See Thin, and cf. Continue Continent Entertain Maintain Tenant Tent
entry.def: Capable of being held, maintained, or defended, as against an assailant or objector, or against attempts to take or process; as, a tenable fortress, a tenable argument.
entry.q: If you have hitherto concealed his sight, Let it be tenable in your silence still.
I would be the last man in the world to give up his cause when it was tenable.

entry.def: Same as Tenability.

entry.ety: F. tenace tenacious, demeurer tenace to hold the best and third best cards and take both tricks, the adversary having to lead. See Tenacious
entry.def: The holding by the fourth hand of the best and third best cards of a suit led; also, sometimes, the combination of best with third best card of a suit in any hand.

entry.ety: L. tenax -acis, from tenere to hold. See Tenable, and cf. Tenace

sn.def: Holding fast, or inclined to hold fast; inclined to retain what is in possession; as, men tenacious of their just rights.
Apt to retain; retentive; as, a tenacious memory.
Having parts apt to adhere to each other; cohesive; tough; as, steel is a tenacious metal; tar is more tenacious than oil.
Apt to adhere to another substance; glutinous; viscous; sticking; adhesive.
sn.q: Female feet, too weak to struggle withtenaciousclay.

sn.def: Niggardly; closefisted; miserly.
Holding stoutly to one's opinion or purpose; obstinate; stubborn.

entry.ety: L. tenacitas: cf. F. ténacité. See Tenacious

sn.def: The quality or state of being tenacious; as, tenacity, or retentiveness, of memory; tenacity, or persistency, of purpose.
That quality of bodies which keeps them from parting without considerable force; cohesiveness; the effect of attraction; -- as distinguished from brittleness fragility mobility, etc.
That quality of bodies which makes them adhere to other bodies; adhesiveness; viscosity.

The greatest longitudinal stress a substance can bear without tearing asunder, -- usually expressed with reference to a unit area of the cross section of the substance, as the number of pounds per square inch, or kilograms per square centimeter, necessary to produce rupture.

entries.entry:
Te*nac"u*lum Te*nac"u*lum n.; pl. L. Tenacula #; E. Tenaculums #. L., a holder, fr. tenere to hold. Cf. Tenaille
Surg An instrument consisting of a fine, sharp hook attached to a handle, and used mainly for taking up arteries, and the like.

entry.ety: L. tenacia obstinacy. See Tenacious
entry.def: Tenaciousness; obstinacy.

entry.ety: F., a pair of pincers or tongs, a tenaille, fr. L. tenaculum. See Tenaculum
entry.def: An outwork in the main ditch, in front of the curtain, between two bastions. See Illust. of Ravelin.

entry.ety: F. See Tenaille
entry.def: A work constructed on each side of the ravelins, to increase their strength, procure additional ground beyond the ditch, or cover the shoulders of the bastions.

entries.entry:
Ten"an*cy n.; pl.Tenacies #. Cf. OF. tenace, LL. tenentia. See Tenant
Law A holding, or a mode of holding, an estate; tenure; the temporary possession of what belongs to another. O. Eng. Law A house for habitation, or place to live in, held of another.

entry.cs:
Tenant in capite L. in in + capite, abl. of caput head, chieforTenant in chief
by the laws of England, one who holds immediately of the king. According to the feudal system, all lands in England are considered as held immediately or mediately of the king, who is styled lord paramount. Such tenants, however, are considered as having the fee of the lands and permanent possession. Blackstone. Tenant in common. See under Common.
entry.ety: F. tenant, p. pr. of tenir to hold. See Tenable, and cf. Lieutenant

sn.def: One who holds or possesses lands, or other real estate, by any kind of right, whether in fee simple, in common, in severalty, for life, for years, or at will; also, one who has the occupation or temporary possession of lands or tenements the title of which is in another; -- correlative to landlord. See Citation from Blackstone, under Tenement, 2.
One who has possession of any place; a dweller; an occupant.
sn.q: Sweettenantsof this grove.
The hhappy tenant of your shade.
The sister tenants of the middle deep.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tenanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Tenanting
entry.def: To hold, occupy, or possess as a tenant.
entry.q: Sir Roger's estate is tenanted by persons who have served him or his ancestors.

entry.def: Fit to be rented; in a condition suitable for a tenant.
Having no tenants; unoccupied; as, a tenantless mansion.

sn.def: The body of tenants; as, the tenantry of a manor or a kingdom.
Tenancy.

entries.entry: Ten"ant saw`. See Tenon saw, under Tenon.

entry.ety: OF. tenche, F. tanche, L. tinca
entry.def: A European fresh-water fish (Tinca tinca, or Tinca vulgaris) allied to the carp. It is noted for its tenacity of life.

entry.ety: See Tender to offer
entry.def: To make a tender of; to offer or tender.

cs.cd: to manage an anchored vessel when the tide turns, so that in swinging she shall not entangle the cable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tended; p. pr. & vb. n. Tending
entry.ety: Aphetic form of attend. See Attend Tend to move, and cf. Tender one that tends or attends

sn.def: To accompany as an assistant or protector; to care for the wants of; to look after; to watch; to guard; as, shepherds tend their flocks.
sn.q: And flaming ministers to watch and tend Their earthly charge.
There 's not a sparrow or a wren, There 's not a blade of autumn grain, Which the four seasons do not tend And tides of life and increase lend.

sn.def: To be attentive to; to note carefully; to attend to.
sn.q: Being to descend A ladder much in height, I did not tend My way well down.

sn.def: To wait, as attendants or servants; to serve; to attend; -- with on or upon.
sn.q: Was he not companion with the riotous knights That tend upon my father?

sn.def: To await; to expect.

entry.ety: F. tendre, L. tendere tensum and tentum, to stretch, extend, direct one's course, tend; akin to Gr. � to stretch, Skr. tan. See Thin, and cf. Tend to attend, Contend Intense Ostensible Portent Tempt Tender to offer, Tense a.

sn.def: To move in a certain direction; -- usually with to or towards.
sn.q: Two gentlemen tending towards that sight.
Thus will this latter, as the former world, Still tend from bad to worse.
The clouds above me to the white Alps tend.

sn.def: To be directed, as to any end, object, or purpose; to aim; to have or give a leaning; to exert activity or influence; to serve as a means; to contribute; as, our petitions, if granted, might tend to our destruction.
sn.q: The thoughts of the diligent tend only to plenteousness; but of every one that is hasty only to want.
The laws of our religion tend to the universal happiness of mankind.

entry.ety: See Tend to attend, and cf. Attendance

sn.def: The act of attending or waiting; attendance.
sn.q: The breath Of her sweet tendance hovering over him.

sn.def: Persons in attendance; attendants.

entry.def: Tendency.

entries.entry: Tend"en*cy n.; pl.Tendencies #. L. tendents -entis, p. pr. of tendere: cf. F. tendance. See Tend to move Direction or course toward any place, object, effect, or result; drift; causal or efficient influence to bring about an effect or result. Writings of this kind, if conducted with candor, have a more particular tendency to the good of their country. In every experimental science, there is a tendency toward perfection. Disposition; inclination; proneness; drift; scope; aim.

entry.ety: From Tend to attend. Cf. Attender

sn.def: One who tends; one who takes care of any person or thing; a nurse.
A vessel employed to attend other vessels, to supply them with provisions and other stores, to convey intelligence, or the like.
A car attached to a locomotive, for carrying a supply of fuel and water.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tendered; p. pr. & vb. n. Tendering
entry.ety: F. tendre to stretch, stretch out, reach, L. tendere. See Tend to move

sn.def: To offer in payment or satisfaction of a demand, in order to save a penalty or forfeiture; as, to tender the amount of rent or debt.
To offer in words; to present for acceptance.
sn.q: You see how all conditions, how all minds, . . . tender down Their services to Lord Timon.

entry.note: ☞ To constitute a legal tender, such money must be offered as the law prescribes. So also the tender must be at the time and place where the rent or debt ought to be paid, and it must be to the full amount due.
entry.cs: Legal tender. See under Legal. Tender of issue Law a form of words in a pleading, by which a party offers to refer the question raised upon it to the appropriate mode of decision. Burrill.

sn.def: An offer, either of money to pay a debt, or of service to be performed, in order to save a penalty or forfeiture, which would be incurred by nonpayment or nonperformance; as, the tender of rent due, or of the amount of a note, with interest.
Any offer or proposal made for acceptance; as, a tender of a loan, of service, or of friendship; a tender of a bid for a contract.
sn.q: A free, unlimited tender of the gospel.

sn.def: The thing offered; especially, money offered in payment of an obligation.

entry.note: ☞ Tender is sometimes used in the formation of self-explaining compounds; as, tender-footed, tender-looking, tender-minded, tender-mouthed, and the like.
entry.ety: F. tendre, L. tener; probably akin to tenuis thin. See Thin

sn.def: Easily impressed, broken, bruised, or injured; not firm or hard; delicate; as, tender plants; tender flesh; tender fruit.
Sensible to impression and pain; easily pained.
sn.q: Our bodies are not naturally more tender than our faces.

sn.def: Physically weak; not hardly or able to endure hardship; immature; effeminate.
sn.q: The tender and delicate woman among you.

sn.def: Susceptible of the softer passions, as love, compassion, kindness; compassionate; pitiful; anxious for another's good; easily excited to pity, forgiveness, or favor; sympathetic.
sn.q: The Lord is very pitiful, and of tender mercy.
I am choleric by my nature, and tender by my temper.

sn.def: Exciting kind concern; dear; precious.
sn.q: I love Valentine, Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!

sn.def: Careful to save inviolate, or not to injure; -- with of.
sn.q: Tenderof property.
The civil authority should be tender of the honor of God and religion.

sn.def: Unwilling to cause pain; gentle; mild.
sn.q: You, that are thus so tender o'er his follies, Will never do him good.

sn.def: Adapted to excite feeling or sympathy; expressive of the softer passions; pathetic; as, tender expressions; tender expostulations; a tender strain.
Apt to give pain; causing grief or pain; delicate; as, a tender subject.
sn.q: Things that aretenderand unpleasing.

sn.def: Heeling over too easily when under sail; -- said of a vessel.
sn.syn: Delicate; effeminate; soft; sensitive; compassionate; kind; humane; merciful; pitiful.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tendre
entry.def: Regard; care; kind concern.
To have a care of; to be tender toward; hence, to regard; to esteem; to value.
entry.q: For first, next after life, he tendered her good.
Tender yourself more dearly.
To see a prince in want would move a miser's charity. Our western princes tendered his case, which they counted might be their own.

sn.def: A delicate person; one not inured to the hardship and rudeness of pioneer life.
See Boy scout.

entry.def: Having great sensibility; susceptible of impressions or influence; affectionate; pitying; sensitive.
entry.q: Rehoboam was young and tender-hearted, and could not withstand them.
Be ye kind one to another, tender-hearted.

entry.def: Having great tenderness; easily moved.

sn.def: One made tender by too much kindness; a fondling.
One of the first antlers of a deer.
A strip of tender flesh on either side of the vertebral column under the short ribs, in the hind quarter of beef and pork. It consists of the psoas muscles.

In New York City, the region which is the center of the night life of fashionable amusement, including the majority of the theaters, etc., centering on Broadway. The term orig. designates the old twenty-ninth police precinct, in this region, which afforded the police great opportunities for profit through conniving at vice and lawbreaking, one captain being reported to have said on being transferred there that whereas he had been eating chuck steak he would now eat tenderlion. Hence, in some other cities, a district largely devoted to night amusement, or, sometimes, to vice.

entry.def: In a tender manner; with tenderness; mildly; gently; softly; in a manner not to injure or give pain; with pity or affection; kindly.
The quality or state of being tender (in any sense of the adjective).
entry.syn: Benignity; humanity; sensibility; benevolence; kindness; pity; clemency; mildness; mercy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tendineux

sn.def: Pertaining to a tendon; of the nature of tendon.
Full of tendons; sinewy; as, nervous and tendinous parts of the body.

entry.def: Attendance; care.

cs.cd: a kind of reflex act in which a muscle is made to contract by a blow upon its tendon. Its absence is generally a sign of disease. See Knee jerk, under Knee.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. tendere to stretch, extend. See Tend to move
entry.def: A tough insensible cord, bundle, or band of fibrous connective tissue uniting a muscle with some other part; a sinew.
Tendinous.

entry.ety: NL. See Tendon, and Synovitis
entry.def: See Tenosynovitis.

entry.ety: See Tenrec
entry.def: Any one of several species of small insectivores of the family Centetidæ, belonging to Ericulus Echinope, and related genera, native of Madagascar. They are more or less spinose and resemble the hedgehog in habits. The rice tendrac (Oryzorictes hora) is very injurious to rice crops. Some of the species are called also tenrec.

entries.entry: Ten"dre‖n. F Tender feeling or fondness; affection. You poor friendless creatures are always having some foolish tendre.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Tender feeling; fondness.
entry.mark: Obs., except as a French word

entry.note: ☞ Tendrils may represent the end of a stem, as in the grapevine; an axillary branch, as in the passion flower; stipules, as in the genus Smilax; or the end of a leaf, as in the pea.
entry.ety: Shortened fr. OF. tendrillon, fr. F. tendre tender; hence, properly, the tender branch or spring of a plant: cf. F. tendrille. See Tender a., and cf. Tendron
entry.def: A slender, leafless portion of a plant by which it becomes attached to a supporting body, after which the tendril usually contracts by coiling spirally.
Clasping; climbing as a tendril.
Furnished with tendrils, or with such or so many, tendrils.
entry.q: Thethousand tendriledvine.

entry.ety: F. Cf. Tendril
entry.def: A tendril.
A tender; an offer.
See 1st and 2d Teen.

entry.ety: L., pl., darkness
entry.def: The matins and lauds for the last three days of Holy Week, commemorating the sufferings and death of Christ, -- usually sung on the afternoon or evening of Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, instead of on the following days.

entry.ety: L. tenebricosus
entry.def: Tenebrous; dark; gloomy.

entry.ety: L. tenebrae darkness + facere to make
entry.def: Rendering dark or gloomy; tenebrous; gloomy.
entry.q: It lightens, it brightens, The tenebrific scene.
Where light Lay fitful in a tenebrific time.

entry.def: Tenebrific.
entry.q: Authors who are tenebrificous stars.

entry.def: Tenebrous.
Characterized by darkness or gloom; tenebrous.
The quality or state of being tenebrous; tenebrousness.

entry.ety: L. tenebrosus, fr. tenebrae darkness: cf. F. ténébreux
entry.def: Dark; gloomy; dusky; tenebrious.
entry.q: The most dark, tenebrous night.
The towering and tenebrous boughts of the cypress.

cs.cd: commonly, a dwelling house erected for the purpose of being rented, and divided into separate apartments or tenements for families. The term is often applied to apartment houses occupied by poor families, often overcrowded and in poor condition.

entry.usage: Tenement House. There may be many houses under one roof, but they are completely separated from each other by party walls. A tenement may be detached by itself, or it may be part of a house divided off for the use of a family. In modern usage, a tenement or tenement house most commonly refers to the meaning given for tenement house, above.
entry.ety: OF. tenement a holding, a fief, F. tènement, LL. tenementum, fr. L. tenere to hold. See Tenant

sn.def: That which is held of another by service; property which one holds of a lord or proprietor in consideration of some military or pecuniary service; fief; fee.

Any species of permanent property that may be held, so as to create a tenancy, as lands, houses, rents, commons, an office, an advowson, a franchise, a right of common, a peerage, and the like; -- called also free tenementsorfrank tenements.
sn.q: The thing held is a tenement, the possessor of it a “tenant,” and the manner of possession is called “tenure.”

sn.def: A dwelling house; a building for a habitation; also, an apartment, or suite of rooms, in a building, used by one family; often, a house erected to be rented.
Fig.: Dwelling; abode; habitation.
sn.q: Who has informed us that a rational soul can inhabit no tenement, unless it has just such a sort of frontispiece?

sn.def: A tenement house.
sn.syn: House; dwelling; habitation.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a tenement; capable of being held by tenants.
Capable of being leased; held by tenants.

entry.ety: L. tenent they hold, 3d pers. pl. pres. of tenere
entry.def: A tenet.

entry.ety: L. tener -eris, tender, delicate
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a condition assumed by the imago of certain Neuroptera, after exclusion from the pupa. In this state the insect is soft, and has not fully attained its mature coloring.
A white wine resembling Madeira in taste, but more tart, produced in Teneriffe, one of the Canary Islands; -- called also Vidonia.

entry.ety: L. teneritas. See Tender a.
entry.def: Tenderness.
Of or pertaining to tenesmus; characterized by tenesmus.

cs.cd: a similar sensation as to the evacuation of urine, referred to the region of the bladder.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to stretch: cf. L. tenesmos
entry.def: An urgent and distressing sensation, as if a discharge from the intestines must take place, although none can be effected; -- always referred to the lower extremity of the rectum.

entry.ety: L. tenet he holds, fr. tenere to hold. See Tenable
entry.def: Any opinion, principle, dogma, belief, or doctrine, which a person holds or maintains as true; as, the tenets of Plato or of Cicero.
entry.q: That al animals of the land are in their kind in the sea, . . . is a tenet very questionable.
The religious tenets of his family he had early renounced with contempt.
entry.syn: Dogma; doctrine; opinion; principle; position. See Dogma.

entry.def: In tens; consisting of ten in one; ten times repeated.
entry.q: The grisly Terror . . . grew tenfold More dreadful and deform.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Tænia.
See Tænoid.

entry.ety: Named after Smithson Tennant, an English chemist
entry.def: A blackish lead-gray mineral, closely related to tetrahedrite. It is essentially a sulphide of arsenic and copper.

entry.ety: Cf. Tawny
entry.def: A tincture, rarely employed, which is considered as an orange color or bright brown. It is represented by diagonal lines from sinister to dexter, crossed by vertical lines.

entry.cs:
Court tennis the old game of tennis as played within walled courts of peculiar construction; -- distinguished from lawn tennis. Lawn tennis. See under Lawn n.
Tennis court a place or court for playing the game of tennis. Shak.
entry.ety: OE. tennes tenies tenyse; of uncertain origin, perhaps fr. F. tenez hold or take it, fr. tenir to hold (see Tenable)
entry.def: A play in which a ball is driven to and fro, or kept in motion by striking it with a racket or with the open hand.
entry.q: His easy bow, his good stories, his style of dancing and playing tennis, . . . were familiar to all London.

entry.def: To drive backward and forward, as a ball in playing tennis.

entry.ety: Jap. tennō, fr. Chin. t'ien heaven + wang king
entry.def: Lit., King of Heaven; -- a title of the emperor of Japan as the head of the Shinto religion.
The tapir.
Of or pertaining to Alfred (Lord) Tennyson, the English poet (1809-92); resembling, or having some of the characteristics of, his poetry, as simplicity, pictorial quality, sensuousness, etc.
A plant, the star-of-Bethlehem. See under Star.

cs.cd: a saw with a thin blade, usually stiffened by a brass or steel back, for cutting tenons.

entry.ety: F., fr. tenir to hold. See Tenable
entry.def: A projecting member left by cutting away the wood around it, and made to insert into a mortise, and in this way secure together the parts of a frame; especially, such a member when it passes entirely through the thickness of the piece in which the mortise is cut, and shows on the other side. Cf. Tooth Tusk.
To cut or fit for insertion into a mortise, as the end of a piece of timber.

cs.cd: a lymphatic space inclosed by a delicate membrane or fascia (the fascia of Tenon) between the eyeball and the fat of the orbit; -- called also capsule of Tenon.

entry.def: Discovered or described by M. Tenon, a French anatomist.

entry.ety: NL., Gr. te`nwn tendon + -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of a tendon.

entry.ety: NL. See Tenonian -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of the Tenonian capsule.

cs.cd: different descriptions of paper money, issued at different periods, by the American colonial governments in the last century.

entry.ety: L., from tenere to hold; hence, properly, a holding on in a continued course: cf. F. teneur. See Tenable, and cf. Tenor a kind of voice

sn.def: A state of holding on in a continuous course; manner of continuity; constant mode; general tendency; course; career.
sn.q: Along the cool sequestered vale of life They kept the noiseless tenor of their away.

sn.def: That course of thought which holds on through a discourse; the general drift or course of thought; purport; intent; meaning; understanding.
sn.q: When it [the bond] is paid according to the tenor.
Does not the whole tenor of the divine law positively require humility and meekness to all men?

sn.def: Stamp; character; nature.
sn.q: This success would look like chance, if it were perpetual, and always of the same tenor.

sn.def: An exact copy of a writing, set forth in the words and figures of it. It differs from purport, which is only the substance or general import of the instrument.

sn.ety: F. ténor, L. tenor, properly, a holding; -- so called because the tenor was the voice which took and held the principal part, the plain song, air, or tune, to which the other voices supplied a harmony above and below: cf. It. tenore

sd.def: The higher of the two kinds of voices usually belonging to adult males; hence, the part in the harmony adapted to this voice; the second of the four parts in the scale of sounds, reckoning from the base, and originally the air, to which the other parts were auxillary.
A person who sings the tenor, or the instrument that play it.

entry.ety: Gr. te`nwn tendon + -rhaphy
entry.def: Suture of a tendon.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. te`nwn tendon + -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of a tendon.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. te`nwn a tendon + E. synovitis
entry.def: Inflammation of the synovial sheath of a tendon.
A slender knife for use in the operation of tenotomy.

entry.ety: Gr. te`nwn a tendon + te`mnein to cut
entry.def: The division of a tendon, or the act of dividing a tendon.
Valued or sold at ten pence; as, a tenpenny cake. See 2d Penny n.
Denoting a size of nails. See 1st Penny.
A game resembling ninepins, but played with ten pins. See Ninepins.
A large oceanic fish (Elops saurus) found in the tropical parts of all the oceans. It is used chiefly for bait.

entry.ety: From the native name: cf. F. tanrac tanrec tandrec
entry.def: A small insectivore (Centetes ecaudatus), native of Madagascar, but introduced also into the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius; -- called also tanrec. The name is applied to other allied genera. See Tendrac.

entry.note: ☞ The primary simple tenses are three: those which express time past present, and future; but these admit of modifications, which differ in different languages.
entry.ety: OF. tens, properly, time, F. temps time, tense. See Temporal of time, and cf. Thing
entry.def: One of the forms which a verb takes by inflection or by adding auxiliary words, so as to indicate the time of the action or event signified; the modification which verbs undergo for the indication of time.

entry.ety: L. tensus, p. p. of tendere to stretch. See Tend to move, and cf. Toise
entry.def: Stretched tightly; strained to stiffness; rigid; not lax; as, a tense fiber.
entry.q: The temples were sunk, her forehead was tense, and a fatal paleness was upon her.

entry.def: The quality or state of being tensible; tensility.

entry.ety: See Tense a.
entry.def: Capable of being extended or drawn out; ductile; tensible.
entry.q: Gold . . . is likewise the most flexible and tensible.

entry.ety: See Tense a.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to extension; as, tensile strength.
Capable of extension; ductile; tensible.

entry.def: Made tensile.
The quality or state of being tensile, or capable of extension; tensibility; as, the tensility of the muscles.

cs.cd: a brace or member designed to resist tension, or subjected to tension, in a structure.
an iron rod used as a tension member to strengthen timber or metal framework, roofs, or the like.

entry.ety: L. tensio, from tendere tensum, to stretch: cf. F. tension. See Tense a.

sn.def: The act of stretching or straining; the state of being stretched or strained to stiffness; the state of being bent strained; as, the tension of the muscles, tension of the larynx.
Fig.: Extreme strain of mind or excitement of feeling; intense effort.
The degree of stretching to which a wire, cord, piece of timber, or the like, is strained by drawing it in the direction of its length; strain.
The force by which a part is pulled when forming part of any system in equilibrium or in motion; as, the tension of a srting supporting a weight equals that weight.
A device for checking the delivery of the thread in a sewing machine, so as to give the stitch the required degree of tightness.

Expansive force; the force with which the particles of a body, as a gas, tend to recede from each other and occupy a larger space; elastic force; elasticity; as, the tension of vapor; the tension of air.

The quality in consequence of which an electric charge tends to discharge itself, as into the air by a spark, or to pass from a body of greater to one of less electrical potential. It varies as the quantity of electricity upon a given area.

entry.def: Extended or drawn out; subjected to tension.
entry.q: A highlytensionedstring.

entry.def: The quality or state of being tense, or strained to stiffness; tension; tenseness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tensif. See Tense a.
entry.def: Giving the sensation of tension, stiffness, or contraction.
entry.q: A tensive pain from distension of the parts.

entry.ety: NL. See Tension

sn.def: A muscle that stretches a part, or renders it tense.

The ratio of one vector to another in length, no regard being had to the direction of the two vectors; -- so called because considered as a stretching factor in changing one vector into another. See Versor.

A knocking down of all ten pins at one delivery of the ball
.
Any quick, decisive stroke or act.

entry.ety: L. tensura. See Tension
entry.def: Tension.

entry.ety: Sp. tinto, properly, deep-colored, fr. L. tinctus, p. p. of tingere to dye. See Tinge, and cf. Tint Tinto
entry.def: A kind of wine of a deep red color, chiefly from Galicia or Malaga in Spain; -- called also tent wine, and tinta.

entry.ety: Cf. Attent n.

sn.def: Attention; regard, care.
Intention; design.

entry.def: To attend to; to heed; hence, to guard; to hinder.

entry.ety: OF. tenter. See Tempt
entry.def: To probe or to search with a tent; to keep open with a tent; as, to tent a wound. Used also figuratively.
entry.q: I'll tent him to the quick.

entry.ety: F. tente. See Tent to probe
entry.def: A roll of lint or linen, or a conical or cylindrical piece of sponge or other absorbent, used chiefly to dilate a natural canal, to keep open the orifice of a wound, or to absorb discharges.
A probe for searching a wound.
entry.q: The tent that searches To the bottom of the worst.

cs.cd: a high-post bedstead curtained with a tentlike canopy.

any one of several species of gregarious caterpillars which construct on trees large silken webs into which they retreat when at rest. Some of the species are very destructive to fruit trees. The most common American species is the larva of a bombycid moth (Clisiocampa Americana). Called also lackery caterpillar, and webworm.

entry.ety: OE. tente, F. tente, LL. tenta, fr. L. tendere tentum, to stretch. See Tend to move, and cf. Tent a roll of lint

sn.def: A pavilion or portable lodge consisting of skins, canvas, or some strong cloth, stretched and sustained by poles, -- used for sheltering persons from the weather, especially soldiers in camp.
sn.q: Within his tent, large as is a barn.

sn.def: The representation of a tent used as a bearing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tented; p. pr. & vb. n. Tenting
entry.def: To lodge as a tent; to tabernacle.
entry.q: We 're tenting to-night on the old camp ground.

cs.cd: a sheathlike structure around the base of the tentacles of many mollusks.

entry.ety: NL. tentaculum, from L. tentare to handle, feel: cf. F. tentacule. See Tempt
entry.def: A more or less elongated process or organ, simple or branched, proceeding from the head or cephalic region of invertebrate animals, being either an organ of sense, prehension, or motion.
Having tentacles.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tentaculaire
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a tentacle or tentacles.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A division of Ctenophora including those which have two long tentacles.
Having tentacles, or organs like tentacles; tentacled.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Suctoria, 1.

entry.ety: Tentaculum + -ferous
entry.def: Producing or bearing tentacles.
Shaped like a tentacle.
Any one of numerous species of small, conical fossil shells found in Paleozoic rocks. They are supposed to be pteropods.

entry.ety: Tentaculum + cyst
entry.def: One of the auditory organs of certain medusæ; -- called also auditory tentacle.

entries.entry:
Ten*tac"u*lum Ten*tac"u*lum n.; pl.Tentacula #. NL. See Tentacle
Zoöl A tentacle.
Anat One of the stiff hairs situated about the mouth, or on the face, of many animals, and supposed to be tactile organs; a tactile hair.

entry.ety: From Tent a pavilion
entry.def: A collection of tents; an encampment.

entry.ety: L. tentatio: cf. F. tentation. See Temptation

sn.def: Trial; temptation.
A mode of adjusting or operating by repeated trials or experiments.

entry.ety: L. tentare to try: cf. F. tentatif. See Tempt
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a trial or trials; essaying; experimental.
entry.q: A slow,tentativemanner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tentative
entry.def: An essay; a trial; an experiment.
Covered with tents.

sn.def: One who takes care of, or tends, machines in a factory; a kind of assistant foreman.
A kind of governor.

cs.cd: a place where tenters are erected.
a sharp, hooked nail used for fastening cloth on a tenter.
cs.mcol: To be on the tenters To be on the tenter-hooksorTo be on tenterhooks
cs.cd: to be on the stretch; to be in distress, uneasiness, or suspense.

entry.ety: OE. tenture tentoure, OF. tenture a stretching, spreading, F. tenture hangings, tapestry, from L. tendere tentum, to stretch. See Tend to move
entry.def: A machine or frame for stretching cloth by means of hooks, called tenter-hooks, so that it may dry even and square.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tentered; p. pr. & vb. n. Tentering
entry.def: To admit extension.
entry.q: Woolen cloth will tenter, linen scarcely.

entry.def: To hang or stretch on, or as on, tenters.

entries.entry: Tent"ful n.; pl.Tentfuls. As much, or as many, as a tent will hold.

entry.ety: From Ten: cf. OE. tethe, AS. teó�a. See Ten, and cf. Tithe

sn.def: Next in order after the ninth; coming after nine others.
Constituting or being one of ten equal parts into which anything is divided.
The next in order after the ninth; one coming after nine others.
The quotient of a unit divided by ten; one of ten equal parts into which anything is divided.
The tenth part of annual produce, income, increase, or the like; a tithe.
The interval between any tone and the tone represented on the tenth degree of the staff above it, as between one of the scale and three of the octave above; the octave of the third.

sd.def: A temporary aid issuing out of personal property, and granted to the king by Parliament; formerly, the real tenth part of all the movables belonging to the subject.
The tenth part of the annual profit of every living in the kingdom, formerly paid to the pope, but afterward transferred to the crown. It now forms a part of the fund called Queen Anne's Bounty.

entry.def: In a tenth manner.
A unit for the measurement of many small lengths, such that 1010 of these units make one meter; the ten millionth part of a millimeter.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a kind of wasp
entry.def: A group of Hymneoptera comprising the sawflies.
Attentive.
Attentively.

entry.ety: L. tentigo -inis, a tension, lecherousness, fr. tendere tentum, to stretch

sn.def: Stiff; stretched; strained.
Lustful, or pertaining to lust.

entry.def: One whose occupation it is to make tents.

entry.ety: L., a tent
entry.def: A fold of the dura mater which separates the cerebellum from the cerebrum and often incloses a process or plate of the skull called the bony tentorium.

entry.ety: L. tentorium a tent
entry.def: The awning or covering of a tent.
A kind of small fern, the wall rue. See under Wall.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tenuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Tenuating
entry.ety: L. tenuatus, p. p. of tenuare to make thin, fr. tenuis thin. See Tenuous
entry.def: To make thin; to attenuate.

entry.ety: L. tenuis thin + folium a leaf
entry.def: Having thin or narrow leaves.

entry.ety: See Tenuous
entry.def: Rare or subtile; tenuous; -- opposed to dense.

entries.entry: Ten`u*i*ros"ter n.; pl.Tenuirosters #. NL., fr. L. tenuis thin + rostrum a beak Zoöl One of the Tenuirostres.

entry.def: Thin-billed; -- applied to birds with a slender bill, as the humming birds.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: An artificial group of passerine birds having slender bills, as the humming birds.

entries.entry:
Ten"u*is Ten"u*is n.; pl.Tenues #. NL., fr. L. tenuis fine, thin. See Tenuous
Gr. Gram One of the three surd mutes κ, π, τ; -- so called in relation to their respective middle letters, or medials, γ, β, δ, and their aspirates, χ, φ, θ. The term is also applied to the corresponding letters and articulate elements in other languages.

entry.ety: L. tenuitas, from tenuis thin: cf. F. ténuité. See Tenuous

sn.def: The quality or state of being tenuous; thinness, applied to a broad substance; slenderness, applied to anything that is long; as, the tenuity of a leaf; the tenuity of a hair.
Rarily; rareness; thinness, as of a fluid; as, the tenuity of the air; the tenuity of the blood.
Poverty; indigence.
Refinement; delicacy.

entry.ety: L. tenuis thin. See Thin, and cf. Tenuis

sn.def: Thin; slender; small; minute.
Rare; subtile; not dense; -- said of fluids.

entry.note: ☞ Tenure is inseparable from the idea of property in land, according to the theory of the English law; and this idea of tenure pervades, to a considerable extent, the law of real property in the United States, where the title to land is essentially allodial, and almost all lands are held in fee simple, not of a superior, but the whole right and title to the property being vested in the owner. Tenure, in general, then, is the particular manner of holding real estate, as by exclusive title or ownership, by fee simple, by fee tail, by courtesy, in dower, by copyhold, by lease, at will, etc.
entry.cs: Tenure by fee alms. Law See Frankalmoigne.
entry.ety: F. tenure, OF. teneure, fr. F. tenir to hold. See Tenable

sn.def: The act or right of holding, as property, especially real estate.
sn.q: That the tenure of estates might rest on equity, the Indian title to lands was in all cases to be quieted.

sn.def: The manner of holding lands and tenements of a superior.
The consideration, condition, or service which the occupier of land gives to his lord or superior for the use of his land.
Manner of holding, in general; as, in absolute governments, men hold their rights by a precarious tenure .
sn.q: All that seems thine own, Held by the tenure of his will alone.

entries.entry: Te`o*cal"li n.; pl.Teocallis #. Mexican Literally, God's house; a temple, usually of pyramidal form, such as were built by the aborigines of Mexico, Yucatan, etc. And Aztec priests upon their teocallis Beat the wild war-drums made of serpent's skin.

entry.def: A large grass (Euchlæna luxurians) closely related to maize. It is native of Mexico and Central America, but is now cultivated for fodder in the Southern United States and in many warm countries. Called also Guatemala grass.

entry.ety: F. tépale, fr. pétale, by transposition
entry.def: A division of a perianth.
An Indian wigwam or tent.
Act of tepefying.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tepefied; p. pr. & vb. n. Tepefying
entry.ety: L. tepere to be tepid + -fy; cf. L. tepefacere. See Tepid
entry.def: To make or become tepid, or moderately warm.

entry.ety: Gr. � ashes + -mancy
entry.def: Divination by the ashes of the altar on which a victim had been consumed in sacrifice.

entry.ety: Gr. � ashes
entry.def: An igneous rock consisting essentially of plagioclase and either leucite or nephelite, or both.

entry.ety: See Tephrosia
entry.def: A silicate of manganese of an ash-gray color.

entry.note: ☞ The Tephrosia toxicaria is used in the West Indies and in Polynesia for stupefying fish. T. purpurea is used medicinally in the East Indies. T. Virginia is the goat's rue of the United States.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � ash-colored, from � ashes
entry.def: A genus of leguminous shrubby plants and herbs, mostly found in tropical countries, a few herbaceous species being North American. The foliage is often ashy-pubescent, whence the name.

entry.ety: L. tepidus, fr. tepere to be warm; akin to Skr. tap to be warm, tapas heat
entry.def: Moderately warm; lukewarm; as, a tepid bath; tepid rays; tepid vapors.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tépidité
entry.def: The quality or state of being tepid; moderate warmth; lukewarmness; tepidness.

entry.ety: L., fr. tepere to be tepid
entry.def: Gentle heat; moderate warmth; tepidness.
An intoxicating liquor made from the maguey in the district of Tequila, Mexico.

entries.entry: Ter-. A combining form from L. ter signifying three times thrice. See Tri-, 2.

entry.ety: Terebic + citraconic
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the distillation of terebic acid, and homologous with citraconic acid.

entry.ety: Terpene + acrylic
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the acrylic series, obtained by the distillation of terpenylic acid, as an only substance having a peculiar cheesy odor.

entries.entry: Ter"aph n.; pl.Teraphs. See Teraphim.

entry.ety: Heb. terāphīm
entry.def: Images connected with the magical rites used by those Israelites who added corrupt practices to the patriarchal religion. Teraphim were consulted by the Israelites for oracular answers.
See Terrapin.

entry.ety: Gr. � a wonder
entry.def: Wonderful; ominous; prodigious.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, a wonder, monster + the root of � to be born
entry.def: The formation of monsters.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, monster + -oid
entry.def: Resembling a monster; abnormal; of a pathological growth, exceedingly complex or highly organized.
Of or pertaining to teratology; as, teratological changes.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, a wonder, monster + -logy: cf. Gr. � a telling of wonders, and F. tératologie

sn.def: That branch of biological science which treats of monstrosities, malformations, or deviations from the normal type of structure, either in plants or animals.
Affectation of sublimity; bombast.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, �, monster + -oma
entry.def: A tumor, sometimes found in newborn children, which is made up of a heterigenous mixture of tissues, as of bone, cartilage and muscle.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, terbium; also, designating certain of its compounds.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Ytterby, in Sweden. See Erbium
entry.def: A rare metallic element, found in certain minerals, as gadolinite and samarskite, with other rare earths such as ytterbium. Symbol Tb. Atomic number 65. Atomic weight 158.925.
See Tierce.
See Tiercel. Called also tarsel tassel.
A male hawk or eagle; a tiercelet.
A small male hawk.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to turpentine; consisting of turpentine, or partaking of its qualities.

entries.entry:
Ter"e*bra Ter"e*bra n.; pl. E. Terebras #, L. Terebræ #. L., a borer
Zoöl A genus of marine gastropods having a long, tapering spire. They belong to the Toxoglossa. Called also auger shell.
Zoöl The boring ovipositor of a hymenopterous insect.

entry.ety: L. terebrans -antis, p. pr
entry.def: Boring, or adapted for boring; -- said of certain Hymenoptera, as the sawflies.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A division of Hymenoptera including those which have an ovipositor adapted for perforating plants. It includes the sawflies.

entry.ety: L. terebratus, p. p. of terebrare, from terebra a borer, terere to rub
entry.def: To perforate; to bore; to pierce.

sn.def: Boring; perforating; -- applied to molluskas which form holes in rocks, wood, etc.
Boring; piercing; -- applied to certain kinds of pain, especially to those of locomotor ataxia.

entry.ety: L. terebratio
entry.def: The act of terebrating, or boring.

entries.entry: Ter`e*brat"u*la Ter`e*brat"u*la n.; pl.Terebratulæ #. Nl., dim. fr. terebratus, p. p., perforated Zoöl A genus of brachiopods which includes many living and some fossil species. The larger valve has a perforated beak, through which projects a short peduncle for attachment. Called also lamp shell.

entry.def: Any species of Terebratula or allied genera. Used also adjectively.
Having the general form of a terebratula shell.

entry.ety: F. térédine
entry.def: A borer; the teredo.

entries.entry: Te*re"do n.; pl. E. Teredos #, L. Teredines #. L., a worm that gnaws wood, clothes, etc.; akin to Gr. �, L. terere to rub Zoöl A genus of long, slender, wormlike bivalve mollusks which bore into submerged wood, such as the piles of wharves, bottoms of ships, etc.; -- called also shipworm. See Shipworm. See Illust. in Appendix.

entry.ety: Because found on the Terek River in the Caucasus
entry.def: A sandpiper (Terekia cinerea) of the Old World, breeding in the far north of eastern Europe and Asia and migrating to South Africa and Australia. It frequents rivers.
A salt of terephthalic acid.

entry.ety: Terebene + phthalic

Round; terete.

entry.ety: L. teres -etis, rounded off, properly, rubbed off, fr. terere to rub
entry.def: Cylindrical and slightly tapering; columnar, as some stems of plants.

entry.ety: See Terete
entry.def: Rounded; as, the teretial tracts in the floor of the fourth ventricle of the brain of some fishes.
Terete.

entry.ety: L. tergum the back
entry.def: Of or pertaining to back, or tergum. See Dorsal.
Showing the back; as, the eagle tergant .

entry.ety: See Tergeminous
entry.def: Thrice twin; having three pairs of leaflets.

entry.ety: L. tergeminus; ter thrice + geminus doubled at birth, twin-born. Cf. Trigeminous
entry.def: Threefold; thrice-paired.

cs.cd: plants which bear their seeds on the back of their leaves, as ferns.

entry.ety: L. tergum the back + -ferous
entry.def: Carrying or bearing upon the back.
The dorsal portion of an arthromere or somite of an articulate animal. See Illust. under Coleoptera.

entry.ety: L. tergiversatus, p. p. of tergiversari to turn one's back, to shift; tergum back + versare, freq. of vertere to turn. See Verse
entry.def: To shift; to practice evasion; to use subterfuges; to shuffle.

entry.ety: L. tergiversario: cf. F. tergiversation

sn.def: The act of tergiversating; a shifting; shift; subterfuge; evasion.
sn.q: Writing is to be preferred before verbal conferences, as being freer from passions and tergiversations.

sn.def: Fickleness of conduct; inconstancy; change.
sn.q: The colonel, after all his tergiversations, lost his life in the king's service.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who tergiversates; one who suffles, or practices evasion.

entries.entry: Ter"gum Ter"gum n.; pl.Terga #. L., the back Zoöl The back of an animal. The dorsal piece of a somite of an articulate animal. One of the dorsal plates of the operculum of a cirriped.

entry.ety: F. tarin, Prov. F. tairin térin, probably from the Picard tère tender
entry.def: A small yellow singing bird, with an ash-colored head; the European siskin. Called also tarin.

entry.note: ☞ In England, there were formerly four terms in the year, during which the superior courts were open: Hilary term, beginning on the 11th and ending on the 31st of January; Easter term, beginning on the 15th of April, and ending on the 8th of May; Trinity term, beginning on the 22d day of May, and ending on the 12th of June; Michaelmas term, beginning on the 2d and ending on the 25th day of November. The rest of the year was called vacation. But this division has been practically abolished by the Judicature Acts of 1873, 1875, which provide for the more convenient arrangement of the terms and vacations. In the United States, the terms to be observed by the tribunals of justice are prescribed by the statutes of Congress and of the several States.
☞ The pillar part frequently tapers downward, or is narrowest at the base. Terms rudely carved were formerly used for landmarks or boundaries. Gwilt.

☞ Terms legal and conventional in Scotland correspond to quarter days in England and Ireland. There are two legal termsWhitsunday, May 15, and Martinmas, Nov. 11; and two conventional termsCandlemas, Feb. 2, and Lammas day, Aug. 1. Mozley & W.

cs.cd: in set terms; in formal phrase.
cs.q: I can not speak in term.
cs.cd: a fee by the term, chargeable to a suitor, or by law fixed and taxable in the costs of a cause for each or any term it is in court.
the four members of which it is composed.
to compel (one) to agree, assent, or submit; to force (one) to come to terms.
to come to terms; to make an agreement: to agree.

entry.usage: Term Word. These are more frequently interchanged than almost any other vocables that occur of the language. There is, however, a difference between them which is worthy of being kept in mind. Word is generic; it denotes an utterance which represents or expresses our thoughts and feelings. Term originally denoted one of the two essential members of a proposition in logic, and hence signifies a word of specific meaning, and applicable to a definite class of objects. Thus, we may speak of a scientific or a technical term, and of stating things in distinct terms. Thus we say, “the term minister literally denotes servant;” “an exact definition of terms is essential to clearness of thought;” “no term of reproach can sufficiently express my indignation;” “every art has its peculiar and distinctive terms,” etc. So also we say, “purity of style depends on the choice of words, and precision of style on a clear understanding of the terms used.” Term is chiefly applied to verbs, nouns, and adjectives, these being capable of standing as terms in a logical proposition; while prepositions and conjunctions, which can never be so employed, are rarely spoken of as terms, but simply as words.
entry.ety: F. terme, L. termen -inis terminus, a boundary limit, end; akin to Gr. �, �. See Thrum a tuft, and cf. Terminus Determine Exterminate

sn.def: That which limits the extent of anything; limit; extremity; bound; boundary.
sn.q: Corruption is a reciprocal to generation, and they two are as nature's two terms, or boundaries.

sn.def: The time for which anything lasts; any limited time; as, a term of five years; the term of life.
In universities, schools, etc., a definite continuous period during which instruction is regularly given to students; as, the school year is divided into three terms .
A point, line, or superficies, that limits; as, a line is the term of a superficies, and a superficies is the term of a solid.

entry.sn:
Law A fixed period of time; a prescribed duration; as: The limitation of an estate; or rather, the whole time for which an estate is granted, as for the term of a life or lives, or for a term of years.
A space of time granted to a debtor for discharging his obligation.
The time in which a court is held or is open for the trial of causes.

sn.def: The subject or the predicate of a proposition; one of the three component parts of a syllogism, each one of which is used twice.
sn.q: The subject and predicate of a proposition are, after Aristotle, together called its terms or extremes.

sn.def: A word or expression; specifically, one that has a precisely limited meaning in certain relations and uses, or is peculiar to a science, art, profession, or the like; as, a technical term .
sn.q: Termsquaint of law.
In painting, the greatest beauties can not always be expressed for want of terms.

sn.def: A quadrangular pillar, adorned on the top with the figure of a head, as of a man, woman, or satyr; -- called also terminal figure. See Terminus n., 2 and 3.
A member of a compound quantity; as, a or b in a + b; ab or cd in ab - cd .
The menses.
Propositions or promises, as in contracts, which, when assented to or accepted by another, settle the contract and bind the parties; conditions.
In Scotland, the time fixed for the payment of rents.
A piece of carved work placed under each end of the taffrail.
sn.syn: Limit; bound; boundary; condition; stipulation; word; expression.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Termed; p. pr. & vb. n. Terming
entry.ety: See Term n., and cf. Terminate
entry.def: To apply a term to; to name; to call; to denominate.
entry.q: Men term what is beyond the limits of the universe “imaginary space.”

entry.ety: NL. See Term n.
entry.def: The terminal lamina, or thin ventral part, of the anterior wall of the third ventricle of the brain.
The quality or state of being termagant; turbulence; tumultuousness; as, a violent termagancy of temper.

entry.ety: OE. Trivigant Termagant, Termagant (in sense 1), OF. Tervagan; cf. It. Trivigante

sn.def: An imaginary being supposed by the Christians to be a Moslem deity or false god. He is represented in the ancient moralities, farces, and puppet shows as extremely vociferous and tumultous.
sn.q: And oftentimes byTermagantand Mahound [Mahomet] swore.
The lesser part on Christ believed well, On Termagant the more, and on Mahound.

sn.def: A boisterous, brawling, turbulent person; -- formerly applied to both sexes, now only to women.
sn.q: This terrible termagant, this Nero, this Pharaoh.

entry.def: Tumultuous; turbulent; boisterous; furious; quarrelsome; scolding.

entry.ety: NL. See Termes
entry.def: Any nest or dwelling of termes, or white ants.
Same as Termatarium.

entries.entry: Term day. A day which is a term (as for payment of rent), or is a day in a term, as of the sitting of a court; esp., one of a series of special days, designated by scientists of different nations or stations, for making synoptic magnetic, meteorological, or other physical observations.

sn.def: One who resorted to London during the law term only, in order to practice tricks, to carry on intrigues, or the like.
One who has an estate for a term of years or for life.

entries.entry:
Ter"mes Ter"mes tẽr"mēz n.; pl.Termites -mĭ*tēz. L. termes tarmes -itis, a woodworm. Cf. Termite
Zoöl A genus of Pseudoneuroptera including the white ants, or termites. See Termite.

cs.cd: an annuity for a stated, definite number of years; -- distinguished from life annuity, and perpetual annuity.

entry.ety: See Terminate

entry.cs: Terminal moraine. See the Note under Moraine. Terminal statue. See Terminus n., 2 and 3. Terminal velocity. The velocity acquired at the end of a body's motion. The limit toward which the velocity of a body approaches, as of a body falling through the air.
entry.ety: L. terminals: cf. F. terminal. See Term n.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the end or extremity; forming the extremity; as, a terminal edge.
