sn.def: A public acknowledgment or celebration of divine goodness; also, a day set apart for religious services, specially to acknowledge the goodness of God, either in any remarkable deliverance from calamities or danger, or in the ordinary dispensation of his bounties.

entry.def: The quality or state of being thankworthy.
Deserving thanks; worthy of gratitude; mreitorious.
entry.q: For this thankworthy, if a man, for conscience toward God, endure grief, suffering wrongfully.

entry.def: A goatlike animal (Capra Jemlaica) native of the Himalayas. It has small, flattened horns, curved directly backward. The hair of the neck, shoulders, and chest of the male is very long, reaching to the knees. Called also serow, and imo.

entry.ety: OE. thar þarf, AS. þearf, infin. þurfan to need; akin to OHG. durfan, G. dürfen to be allowed, Icel. þurfa to need, Goth. þaúrban
entry.def: It needs; need.
entry.q: What thar thee reck or care?

entry.ety: AS. þearm a gut; akin to D. & G. darm, Icel. þarmr, Sw. & Dan. tarm. √53
entry.def: Twisted guts.

A small American butterfly (Phycoides tharos) having the upper surface of the wings variegated with orange and black, the outer margins black with small white crescents; -- called also pearl crescent.

entry.note: ☞ That may refer to an entire sentence or paragraph, and not merely to a word. It usually follows, but sometimes precedes, the sentence referred to.

☞ That is often used in opposition to this, or by way of distinction, and in such cases this, like the Latin hic and French ceci, generally refers to that which is nearer, and that, like Latin ille and French cela, to that which is more remote. When they refer to foreign words or phrases, this generally refers to the latter, and that to the former.
☞ That was formerly sometimes used with the force of the article the, especially in the phrases that one that other, which were subsequently corrupted into th'tone th'tothernow written t'other).

☞ If the relative clause simply conveys an additional idea, and is not properly explanatory or restrictive, who or whichrarely that) is employed; as, the king thator who) rules well is generally popular; Victoria, whonot that) rules well, enjoys the confidence of her subjects. Ambiguity may in some cases be avoided in the use of thatwhich is restrictive) instead of who or which, likely to be understood in a coördinating sense. Bain. That was formerly used for that which, as what is now; but such use is now archaic.We speak that we do know, and testify that we have seen. John iii. 11.
That I have done it is thyself to wite [blame]. Chaucer. That, as a relative pronoun, cannot be governed by a preposition preceding it, but may be governed by one at the end of the sentence which it commences.The ship that somebody was sailing in. Sir W. Scott. In Old English, that was often used with the demonstratives he his him, etc., and the two together had the force of a relative pronoun; thus, that he = who; that his = whose; that him = whom.I saw to-day a corpse yborn to churchThat now on Monday last I saw him wirche [work]. Chaucer. Formerly, that was used, where we now commonly use which, as a relative pronoun with the demonstrative pronoun that as its antecedent.That that dieth, let it die; and that that is to cut off, let it be cut off. Zech. xi. 9.

☞ That was formerly added to other conjunctions or to adverbs to make them emphatic.To try if that our own be ours or no. Shak. That is sometimes used to connect a clause with a preceding conjunction on which it depends.When he had carried Rome and that we looked For no less spoil than glory. Shak.
entry.cs:
All that everything of that kind; all that sort. With singing, laughing, ogling, and all that. Pope. The rank is but the guinea's stamp, The man's the gowd [gold] for a'that. Burns. For that. See under For prep.
In that. See under In prep.
entry.ety: AS. ðæt, neuter nom. & acc. sing. of the article (originally a demonstrative pronoun). The nom. masc. sē, and the nom. fem. seó are from a different root. AS. ðæt is akin to D. dat, G. das, OHG. daz, Sw. & Dan. det, Icel. þatmasc. sā, fem. sō), Goth. þatamasc. sa, fem. sō), Gr. � (masc. �, fem. �), Skr. tatfor tad, masc. sas, fem. sā); cf. L. istud that. √184. Cf. The Their They Them This Than Since

sn.def: As a demonstrative pronoun (pl. Those), that usually points out, or refers to, a person or thing previously mentioned, or supposed to be understood. That, as a demonstrative, may precede the noun to which it refers; as, that which he has said is true; those in the basket are good apples.
sn.q: The early fame of Gratian was equal to that of the most celebrated princes.
That be far from thee, to do after this manner, to slay the righteous with the wicked.
And when Moses heard that, he was content.
I will know your business, Harry, that I will.
If the Lord will, we shall live, and do this or that.

sn.def: As an adjective, that has the same demonstrative force as the pronoun, but is followed by a noun.
sn.q: It shall be more tolerable for Sodom and Gomorrah in the day of judgment, than for that city.
The woman was made whole from that hour.
Upon a day out riden knightes two . . . That one of them came home, that other not.

sn.def: As a relative pronoun, that is equivalent to who or which, serving to point out, and make definite, a person or thing spoken of, or alluded to, before, and may be either singular or plural.
sn.q: He that reproveth a scorner getteth to himself shame.
A judgment that is equal and impartial must incline to the greater probabilities.

entry.sn:
As a conjunction, that retains much of its force as a demonstrative pronoun. It is used, specifically: To introduce a clause employed as the object of the preceding verb, or as the subject or predicate nominative of a verb. She tells them 't is a causeless fantasy, And childish error, that they are afraid. I have shewed before, that a mere possibility to the contrary, can by no means hinder a thing from being highly credible.
To introduce, a reason or cause; -- equivalent to for that in that for the reason that because. He does hear me; And that he does, I weep.
To introduce a purpose; -- usually followed by may, or might, and frequently preceded by so in order to the end, etc. These things I say, that ye might be saved. To the end that he may prolong his days.
To introduce a consequence, result, or effect; -- usually preceded by so or such, sometimes by that. The birds their notes renew, and bleating herds Attest their joy, that hill and valley rings. He gazed so longThat both his eyes were dazzled.
To introduce a clause denoting time; -- equivalent to in which time at which time when.So wept Duessa until eventide,That shining lamps in Jove's high course were lit. Is not this the dayThat Hermia should give answer of her choice?
In an elliptical sentence to introduce a dependent sentence expressing a wish, or a cause of surprise, indignation, or the like. Ha, cousin Silence, that thou hadst seen that that this knight and I have seen!
O God, that right should thus overcome might!

sn.def: As adverb: To such a degree; so; as, he was that frightened he could say nothing.

cs.cd: the house sparrow.

entry.ety: OE. thak, AS. þæc a roof; akin to þeccean to cover, D. dak a roof, dekken to cover, G. dach a roof, decken 8cover, Icel. þak a roof, Sw. tak, Dan. tag, Lith. stōgas, Ir. teagh a house, Gael. teach tigh, W. ty, L. tegere to cover, toga a toga, Gr. �, �, a roof, � to cover, Skr. sthag. Cf. Deck Integument Tile Toga

sn.def: Straw, rushes, or the like, used for making or covering the roofs of buildings, or of stacks of hay or grain.
A name in the West Indies for several kinds of palm, the leaves of which are used for thatching.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thatched; p. pr. & vb. n. Thatching
entry.ety: From Thatch n.: cf. OE. thecchen, AS. �eccean to cover
entry.def: To cover with, or with a roof of, straw, reeds, or some similar substance; as, to thatch a roof, a stable, or a stack of grain.
One who thatches.

sn.def: The act or art of covering buildings with thatch; so as to keep out rain, snow, etc.
The materials used for this purpose; thatch.

entry.def: See Thwart.

entry.ety: Gr. qay^ma qay`matos, a wonder + latrei`a worship
entry.def: Worship or undue admiration of wonderful or miraculous things.
entry.q: The thaumatolatry by which our theology has been debased for more than a century.

entry.note: ☞ It consists of a card having on its opposite faces figures of two different objects, or halves of the same object, as a bird and a cage, which, when the card is whirled rapidly round a diameter by the strings that hold it, appear to the eye combined in a single picture, as of a bird in its cage.
entry.ety: Gr. qay^ma a wonder + tre`pein to turn
entry.def: An optical instrument or toy for showing the persistence of an impression upon the eyes after the luminous object is withdrawn.

entry.ety: See thaumaturgus
entry.def: A magician; a wonder worker.
Of or pertaining to thaumaturgy; magical; wonderful.
Feats of legerdemain, or magical performances.
One who deals in wonders, or believes in them; a wonder worker; a thaumaturge.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. qaymatourgo`s wonder-working; qay^ma a wonder + 'e`rgon work
entry.def: A miracle worker; -- a title given by the Roman Catholics to some saints.

entry.ety: Gr. qaymatourgi`a
entry.def: The act or art of performing something wonderful; magic; legerdemain.
Same as theave.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thawed th�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Thawing
entry.ety: AS. þāwian þāwan; akin to D. dovijen, G. tauen thauencf. also verdauen to digest, OHG. douwen, firdouwen), Icel. þeyja, Sw. töa, Dan. töe, and perhaps to Gr. th`kein to melt. √56

sn.def: To melt, dissolve, or become fluid; to soften; -- said of that which is frozen; as, the ice thaws .
To become so warm as to melt ice and snow; -- said in reference to the weather, and used impersonally.
To grow gentle or genial. Compare cold4}, a. and hard6}, a.

entry.def: To cause (frozen things, as earth, snow, ice) to melt, soften, or dissolve.

The melting of ice, snow, or other congealed matter; the resolution of ice, or the like, into the state of a fluid; liquefaction by heat of anything congealed by frost; also, a warmth of weather sufficient to melt that which is congealed.
Liquefying by heat after having been frozen; thawing; melting.
See Thee.

entry.note: ☞ The was originally a demonstrative pronoun, being a weakened form of that. When placed before adjectives and participles, it converts them into abstract nouns; as, the sublime and the beautiful. Burke. The is used regularly before many proper names, as of rivers, oceans, ships, etc.; as, the Nile, the Atlantic, the Great Eastern, the West Indies, The Hague. The with an epithet or ordinal number often follows a proper name; as, Alexander the Great; Napoleon the Third. The may be employed to individualize a particular kind or species; as, the grasshopper shall be a burden. Eccl. xii. 5.
entry.pr: �ē, when emphatic or alone; ��, obscure before a vowel; ��, obscure before a consonant; 37
entry.ety: AS. ðē, a later form for earlier nom. sing. masc. sē, formed under the influence of the oblique cases. See That, pron
entry.def: A word placed before nouns to limit or individualize their meaning.

entry.ety: AS. ðē ðȳ, instrumental case of sē seó ðæt, the definite article. See 2d The
entry.def: By that; by how much; by so much; on that account; -- used before comparatives; as, the longer we continue in sin, the more difficult it is to reform.
entry.q: Yet notthemore cease I.
So much the rather thou, Celestial Light, Shine inward, and the mind through all her powers Irradiate.

entry.note: ☞ It is now commonly referred to the genus Camellia.
entry.ety: NL. See Tea
entry.def: A genus of plants found in China and Japan; the tea plant.

entry.ety: Gr. qeandriko`s; qeo`s god + anh`r andro`s, a man
entry.def: Relating to, or existing by, the union of divine and human operation in Christ, or the joint agency of the divine and human nature.
Partaking of, or combining, both divinity and humanity.
entry.q: The gorgeous and imposing figures of his [Homer'stheanthropic sytem.

entry.ety: Gr. � god + � man

sn.def: A state of being God and man.
The ascription of human atributes to the Deity, or to a polytheistic deity; anthropomorphism.

entry.def: One who advocates, or believes in, theanthropism.
Theanthropism.

entry.ety: Gr. �. See Thearchy
entry.def: Divinely sovereign or supreme.
entry.q: He [Jesus] is the thearchic Intelligence.

entry.ety: Gr. � god + -archy: cf. Gr. � the supreme deity
entry.def: Government by God; divine sovereignty; theocracy.

entry.ety: F. théâtre, L. theatrum, Gr. �, fr. � to see, view; cf. Skr. dhyā to meditate, think. Cf. Theory

sn.def: An edifice in which dramatic performances or spectacles are exhibited for the amusement of spectators; anciently uncovered, except the stage, but in modern times roofed.
Any room adapted to the exhibition of any performances before an assembly, as public lectures, scholastic exercises, anatomical demonstrations, surgical operations, etc.
That which resembles a theater in form, use, or the like; a place rising by steps or gradations, like the seats of a theater.
sn.q: Shade above shade, a woody theater Of stateliest view.

sn.def: A sphere or scheme of operation.
sn.q: For if a man can be partaker of God's theater, he shall likewise be partaker of God's rest.

sn.def: A place or region where great events are enacted; as, the theater of war.

entry.note: ☞ Their name is derived from Theate, or Chieti, a city of Naples, the archbishop of which was a principal founder of the order; but they bore various names; as, Regular Clerks of the Community Pauline Monks Apostolic Clerks, and Regular Clerks of the Divine Providence. The order never flourished much out of Italy.
entry.ety: F. théatin, It. theatino

sn.def: One of an order of Italian monks, established in 1524, expressly to oppose Reformation, and to raise the tone of piety among Roman Catholics. They hold no property, nor do they beg, but depend on what Providence sends. Their chief employment is preaching and giving religious instruction.
One of an order of nuns founded by Ursula Benincasa, who died in 1618.

entry.ety: L. theatralis: cf. F. théatral
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a theater; theatrical.
Theatrical.
entry.q: Woods over woods in gay, theatric pride.

entry.ety: L. theatricus, Gr. �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a theater, or to the scenic representations; resembling the manner of dramatic performers; histrionic; hence, artificial; as, theatrical performances; theatrical gestures.
entry.q: No meretricious aid whatever has been called in -- no trick, no illusion of the eye, nothing theatrical.

entry.def: Dramatic performances; especially, those produced by amateurs.
entry.q: Such fashionable cant terms as ‘theatricals,' and ‘musicals,' invented by the flippant Topham, still survive among his confraternity of frivolity.

entry.ety: Cf. W. dafad a sheep, ewe
entry.def: A ewe lamb of the first year; also, a sheep three years old.

entry.ety: L. thebaicus, Gr. �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thebes in Egypt; specifically, designating a version of the Bible preserved by the Copts, and esteemed of great value by biblical scholars. This version is also called the Sahidic version.

entry.ety: L. Thebais -idis
entry.def: A Latin epic poem by Statius about Thebes in Bœotia.

entry.ety: So called from a kind of Egyptian opium produced at Thebes
entry.def: A poisonous alkaloid, C19H21NO3, found in opium in small quantities, having a sharp, astringent taste, and a tetanic action resembling that of strychnine.

cs.cd: the Egyptian year of 365 days and 6 hours.

entry.ety: L. Thebanus
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thebes.
A native or inhabitant of Thebes; also, a wise man.
entry.q: I'll talk a word with this same learned Theban.

entries.entry:
The"ca The"ca n.; pl.Thecæ #. L., fr. Gr. � a case to put anything in. See Tick a cover
A sheath; a case; as, the theca, or cell, of an anther; the theca, or spore case, of a fungus; the theca of the spinal cord.
Zoöl
The chitinous cup which protects the hydranths of certain hydroids.
The more or less cuplike calicle of a coral.
The wall forming a calicle of a coral.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a theca; as, a thecal abscess.

entry.ety: Theca + Gr. fe`rein to bear: cf. F. thécaphore
entry.def: A surface or organ bearing a theca, or covered with thecæ.
See Basigynium.
Having the spores in thecæ, or cases.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � a case
entry.def: Same as Thecophora.
Any one of many species of small delicately colored butterflies belonging to Thecla and allied genera; -- called also hairstreak, and elfin.

entry.ety: � case + � finger
entry.def: Any one of a group of lizards of the Gecko tribe, having the toes broad, and furnished with a groove in which the claws can be concealed.

entry.ety: Gr. � a case + �, �, a tooth

sn.def: Having the teeth inserted in sockets in the alveoli of the jaws.
Of or pertaining to the thecodonts.

entry.def: One of the Thecodontia.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A group of fossil saurians having biconcave vertebræ and the teeth implanted in sockets.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � a case + fe`rein to bear
entry.def: A division of hydroids comprising those which have the hydranths in thecæ and the gonophores in capsules. The campanularians and sertularians are examples. Called also Thecata. See Illust. under Hydroidea.

entry.ety: NL. See Theca, and Soma
entry.def: An order of Pteropoda comprising those species which have a shell. See Pteropoda.

entry.ety: Thee to prosper + -dom
entry.def: Success; fortune; luck; chance.
entry.q: Evil thedom on his monk's snout.

entry.ety: AS. þeón; akin to OS. thīhan, D. gedijen, G. gedeihen, OHG. gidihan, Goth. þeihan, Lith. tekti to fall to the lot of. Cf. Tight a.
entry.def: To thrive; to prosper.
entry.q: He shall neverthee.
Well mote thee, as well can wish your thought.

entry.note: ☞ Thee is poetically used for thyself, as him for himself, etc.
entry.ety: AS. ðē, acc. & dat. of ðū thou. See Thou
entry.def: The objective case of thou. See Thou.
entry.q: This sword hath ended him; so shall it thee, Unless thou yield thee as my prisoner.

entry.note: ☞ To constitute theft there must be a taking without the owner's consent, and it must be unlawful or felonious; every part of the property stolen must be removed, however slightly, from its former position; and it must be, at least momentarily, in the complete possession of the thief. See Larceny, and the Note under Robbery.
entry.ety: OE. thefte, AS. þiéfðe þȳfðe þeófðe. See Thief

sn.def: The act of stealing; specifically, the felonious taking and removing of personal property, with an intent to deprive the rightful owner of the same; larceny.
The thing stolen.
sn.q: If the theft be certainly found in his hand alive, . . . he shall restore double.

entry.ety: Theft + bote compensation
entry.def: The receiving of a man's goods again from a thief, or a compensation for them, by way of composition, with the intent that the thief shall escape punishment.
Thane. See Thane.
Thanehood.

entry.ety: NL. thea tea, the tea plant + -form: cf. F. théiforme
entry.def: Having the form of tea.

entry.ety: F. théine, fr. NL. thea. See Theiform
entry.def: See Caffeine. Called also theina.

entry.note: ☞ The possessive takes the form theirs�) when the noun to which it refers is not expressed, but implied or understood; as, our land is richest, but theirs is best cultivated.
entry.ety: OE. thair, fr. Icel. þeirra þeira, of them, but properly gen. pl. of the definite article; akin to AS. ðāra ðǣra, gen. pl. of the definite article, or fr. AS. ðǣra, influenced by the Scandinavian use. See That
entry.def: The possessive case of the personal pronoun they; as, their houses; their country.
entry.q: Nothing but the name of zeal appears 'Twixt our best actions and the worst of theirs.

entry.ety: From Gr. � God; probably akin to � to pray for, � spoken by God, decreed: cf. F. théisme. Cf. Enthusiasm Pantheon Theology
entry.def: The belief or acknowledgment of the existence of a God, as opposed to atheism pantheism, or polytheism.

entry.ety: NL. & E. thea tea + -ism
entry.def: The morbid condition resulting from the excessive use of tea.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théiste. See Theism
entry.def: One who believes in the existence of a God; especially, one who believes in a personal God; -- opposed to atheist.
Of or pertaining to theism, or a theist; according to the doctrine of theists.

entry.ety: Gr. � nipple + � to blow, to puff
entry.def: One of a tribe of fresh-water crabs which live in or on the banks of rivers in tropical countries.

entry.ety: Gr. qh^lys female + to`kos a bringing forth
entry.def: Producing females only; -- said of certain female insects.

entry.note: ☞ Them is poetically used for themselves, as him for himself, etc.
entry.ety: AS. ðǣm, dat. pl. of the article, but influenced by the Scand. use of the corresponding form þeim as a personal pronoun. See They
entry.def: The objective case of they. See They.
entry.q: Go ye rather to them that sell, and buy for yourselves.
Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father.
Little stars may hide them when they list.

cs.cd: a catalogue of musical works which, besides the title and other particulars, gives in notes the theme, or first few measures, of the whole work or of its several movements.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. thématique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the theme of a word. See Theme n., 4.
Of or pertaining to a theme, or subject.

entry.ety: OE. teme, OF. teme, F. thème, L. thema, Gr. �, fr. � to set, place. See Do, and cf. Thesis

sn.def: A subject or topic on which a person writes or speaks; a proposition for discussion or argument; a text.
sn.q: My theme is alway one and ever was.
And when a soldier was the theme, my name Was not far off.

sn.def: Discourse on a certain subject.
sn.q: Then ran repentance and rehearsed his theme.
It was the subject of my theme.

sn.def: A composition or essay required of a pupil.
A noun or verb, not modified by inflections; also, that part of a noun or verb which remains unchanged (except by euphonic variations) in declension or conjugation; stem.
That by means of which a thing is done; means; instrument.
The leading subject of a composition or a movement.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � that which is laid down or established by usage, law, prob. fr. � to set, place
entry.def: The goddess of law and order; the patroness of existing rights.
The plural of himself herself, and itself. See Himself Herself Itself.

entry.cs: By then. By that time. By the time that. Obs

Now and then. See under Now adv.
Till then until that time; until the time mentioned. Milton.
entry.note: ☞ Then is often used elliptically, like an adjective, for then existing; as, the then administration.
entry.ety: Originally the same word as than. See Than

sn.def: At that time (referring to a time specified, either past or future).
sn.q: And the Canaanite was then in the land.
Now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I am known.

sn.def: Soon afterward, or immediately; next; afterward.
sn.q: First be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift.

sn.def: At another time; later; again.
sn.q: One while the master is not aware of what is done, and then in other cases it may fall out to be own act.
But that opinion, I trust, by then this following argument hath been well read, will be left for one of the mysteries of an indulgent Antichrist.

entry.usage: Then Therefore. Both these words are used in reasoning; but therefore takes the lead, while then is rather subordinate or incidental. Therefore states reasons and draws inferences in form; then, to a great extent, takes the point as proved, and passes on to the general conclusion. “Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God.” Rom. v. 1. “So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God.” Rom. x. 17.

sn.def: Than.
In that case; in consequence; as a consequence; therefore; for this reason.
sn.q: If all this be so, then man has a natural freedom.
Now, then, be all thy weighty cares away.
sn.syn: Therefore.

entry.def: At that time; then; in those days; -- correlative to nowadays.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the thenar; corresponding to thenar; palmar.
The palm of the hand.
The prominence of the palm above the base of the thumb; the thenar eminence; the ball of the thumb. Sometimes applied to the corresponding part of the foot.

entry.ety: Named after the French chemist, L. J. Thénard
entry.def: Anhydrous sodium sulphate, a mineral of a white or brown color and vitreous luster.

entry.note: ☞ It is not unusual, though pleonastic, to use from before thence. Cf. Hence Whence.
entry.ety: OE. thenne thanne, and (with the adverbal -s; see -wards thennes thanneshence thens, now written thence), AS. ðanon ðanan ðonan; akin to OHG. dannana dannān danān, and G. von dannen, E. that there. See That

sn.def: From that place.
sn.q: Bid himthencego.
When ye depart thence, shake off the dust under your feet for a testimony against them.
Then I will send, and fetch thee from thence.

sn.def: From that time; thenceforth; thereafter.
sn.q: There shall be no more thence an infant of days.

sn.def: For that reason; therefore.
sn.q: Not to sit idle with so great a gift Useless, and thence ridiculous, about him.

sn.def: Not there; elsewhere; absent.

entry.note: This word is sometimes preceded by from, -- a redundancy sanctioned by custom. Chaucer. John. xix. 12.
entry.def: From that time; thereafter.
entry.q: If the salt have lost his savor, wherewith shall it be salted? it is thenceforth good for nothing.

entry.def: From that time onward; thenceforth.
From that place.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a god + � food, fr. � to eat: cf. F. théobrome
entry.def: A genus of small trees. See Cacao.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid extracted from cacao butter (from the Theobroma Cacao), peanut oil (from Arachis hypogæa), etc., as a white waxy crystalline substance.

An alkaloidal ureide, C7H8N4O2, homologous with and resembling caffeine, produced artificially, and also extracted from cacao and chocolate (from Theobroma Cacao) as a bitter white crystalline substance; -- called also dimethyl xanthine.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � God + � anointed, fr. � to anoint
entry.def: Anointed by God.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � God + � to be strong, to rule, fr. � strength: cf. F. théocratie. See Theism, and cf. Democracy

sn.def: Government of a state by the immediate direction or administration of God; hence, the exercise of political authority by priests as representing the Deity.
The state thus governed, as the Hebrew commonwealth before it became a kingdom.

entry.ety: Gr. � union of the soul with God; � God + � a mixing, akin to � to mix

sn.def: A mixture of the worship of different gods, as of Jehovah and idols.
sn.q: This syncretistic theocracy by no means excludes in him [Solomon] the proper service of idols.

sn.def: An intimate union of the soul with God in contemplation, -- an ideal of the Neoplatonists and of some Oriental mystics.

entry.def: One who lives under a theocratic form of government; one who in civil affairs conforms to divine law.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théocratique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a theocracy; administred by the immediate direction of God; as, the theocratical state of the Israelites.

entry.ety: NL. theodicæa, fr. Gr. � God + � right, justice: cf. F. théodicée

sn.def: A vindication of the justice of God in ordaining or permitting natural and moral evil.
That department of philosophy which treats of the being, perfections, and government of God, and the immortality of the soul.

entry.note: ☞ The theodolite consists principally of a telescope, with cross wires in the focus of its object glass, clamped in Y's attached to a frame that is mounted so as to turn both on vertical and horizontal axes, the former carrying a vernier plate on a horizontal graduated plate or circle for azimuthal angles, and the latter a vertical graduated arc or semicircle for altitudes. The whole is furnished with levels and adjusting screws and mounted on a tripod.
entry.ety: Probably a corruption of the alidade. See Alidade
entry.def: An instrument used, especially in trigonometrical surveying, for the accurate measurement of horizontal angles, and also usually of vertical angles. It is variously constructed.
Of or pertaining to a theodolite; made by means of a theodolite; as, theodolitic observations.
Of or relating to theogony.
Theogony.
A writer on theogony.

entry.ety: L. theogonia, Gr. �; � a god + the root of � to be born. See Theism, and Genus
entry.def: The generation or genealogy of the gods; that branch of heathen theology which deals with the origin and descent of the deities; also, a poem treating of such genealogies; as, the Theogony of Hesiod.

entry.ety: Formed like poetaster: cf. F. théologastre
entry.def: A pretender or quack in theology.
A theologian.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théologien, L. theologus, Gr. �. See Theology
entry.def: A person well versed in theology; a professor of theology or divinity; a divine.
Theological.

entry.ety: L. theologicus, Gr. �: cf. F. théologique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to theology, or the science of God and of divine things; as, a theological treatise.
Theology.
A theologian.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Theologized; p. pr. & vb. n. Theologizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. théologiser
entry.def: To render theological; to apply to divinity; to reduce to a system of theology.
entry.q: School divinity was but Aristotle's philosophy theologized.

entry.def: To frame a system of theology; to theorize or speculate upon theological subjects.
One who theologizes; a theologian.

entry.ety: Cf. L. theologus, Gr. �, and E. philologue

sn.def: A theologian.
sn.q: Ye gentle theologues of calmer kind.
He [Jerome] was the theologueand the word is designation enough.

sn.def: A student in a theological seminary.

entries.entry:
The*ol"o*gy
Ascetic theology Natural theology . See Ascetic Natural. Moral theology that phase of theology which is concerned with moral character and conduct. Revealed theology theology which is to be learned only from revelation. Scholastic theology theology as taught by the scholastics, or as prosecuted after their principles and methods. Speculative theology theology as founded upon, or influenced by, speculation or metaphysical philosophy. Systematic theology that branch of theology of which the aim is to reduce all revealed truth to a series of statements that together shall constitute an organized whole. E. G. Robinson (Johnson's Cyc.).
n.; pl.Theologies #. L. theologia, Gr. �; � God + � discourse: cf. F. théologie. See Theism, and Logic
The science of God or of religion; the science which treats of the existence, character, and attributes of God, his laws and government, the doctrines we are to believe, and the duties we are to practice; divinity; (as more commonly understood) “the knowledge derivable from the Scriptures, the systematic exhibition of revealed truth, the science of Christian faith and life.” Many speak of theology as a science of religion [instead of “science of God”] because they disbelieve that there is any knowledge of God to be attained.
Theology is ordered knowledge; representing in the region of the intellect what religion represents in the heart and life of man.

entry.ety: Cf. Gr. �
entry.def: One who fights against the gods; one who resists God of the divine will.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � a god + � a battle

sn.def: A fighting against the gods, as the battle of the gaints with the gods.
A battle or strife among the gods.
Opposition to God or the divine will.

entry.ety: Gr. � a god + -mancy: cf. F. théomancie, Gr. � a spirit of prophecy,
entry.def: A kind of divination drawn from the responses of oracles among heathen nations.
Of or pertaining to a theopathy.

entry.ety: Gr. � God + �, �, to suffer, feel
entry.def: Capacity for religious affections or worship.
Of or pertaining to a theopany; appearing to man, as a god.

entries.entry: The*oph"a*ny n.; pl.-nies #. Gr. �; � God + � to appear A manifestation of God to man by actual appearance, usually as an incarnation.

entry.def: Pertaining to theophilanthropy or the theophilanthropists.
The doctrine of the theophilanthropists; theophilanthropy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théophilanthrope
entry.def: A member of a deistical society established at Paris during the French revolution.

entry.ety: Gr. � God + E. philanthropy
entry.def: Theophilanthropism.

entry.ety: Gr. � God + E. philosophic
entry.def: Combining theism and philosophy, or pertaining to the combination of theism and philosophy.
Divinely inspired; theopneustic.

entry.ety: Gr. � inspired of God; � God + � to blow, to breathe
entry.def: Given by the inspiration of the Spirit of God.

entry.ety: Gr. �
entry.def: Divine inspiration; the supernatural influence of the Divine Spirit in qualifying men to receive and communicate revealed truth.
One who plays on a theorbo.

entry.note: ☞ A larger form of theorbo was also called the archlute, and was used chiefly, if not only, as an accompaniment to the voice. Both have long fallen into disuse.
entry.ety: F. théorbe téorbe, formerly tuorbe tiorbe, It. tiorba
entry.def: An instrument made like large lute, but having two necks, with two sets of pegs, the lower set holding the strings governed by frets, while to the upper set were attached the long bass strings used as open notes.

entry.note: ☞ A theorem is something to be proved, and is thus distinguished from a problem, which is something to be solved. In analysis, the term is sometimes applied to a rule, especially a rule or statement of relations expressed in a formula or by symbols; as, the binomial theorem; Taylor's theorem . See the Note under Proposition n., 5.
entry.cs: Binomial theorem. Math See under Binomial. Negative theorem a theorem which expresses the impossibility of any assertion. Particular theorem Math a theorem which extends only to a particular quantity. Theorem of Pappus. Math See Centrobaric method, under Centrobaric. Universal theorem Math a theorem which extends to any quantity without restriction.
entry.ety: L. theorema, Gr. � a sight, speculation, theory, theorem, fr. � to look at, � a spectator: cf. F. théorème. See Theory

sn.def: That which is considered and established as a principle; hence, sometimes, a rule.
sn.q: Not theories, but theorems�), the intelligible products of contemplation, intellectual objects in the mind, and of and for the mind exclusively.
By the theorems, Which your polite and terser gallants practice, I re-refine the court, and civilize Their barbarous natures.

sn.def: A statement of a principle to be demonstrated.

entry.def: To formulate into a theorem.

entry.ety: Cf. Gr. �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a theorem or theorems; comprised in a theorem; consisting of theorems.
One who constructs theorems.
Theorematic.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. L. theoreticus, F. théorétique
entry.def: Pertaining to theory; depending on, or confined to, theory or speculation; speculative; terminating in theory or speculation: not practical; as, theoretical learning; theoretic sciences.
The speculative part of a science; speculation.
entry.q: At the very first, with our Lord himself, and his apostles, as represented to us in the New Testament, morals come before contemplation, ethics before theoretics.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théorique. See Theory

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the theorica.
Relating to, or skilled in, theory; theoretically skilled.
sn.q: A man but young, Yet old in judgment, theoric and practic In all humanity.

entry.ety: OF. theorique; cf. L. theorice
entry.def: Speculation; theory.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � (sc. �), fr. � belonging to � a public spectacle. See Theory
entry.def: Public moneys expended at Athens on festivals, sacrifices, and public entertainments (especially theatrical performances), and in gifts to the people; -- also called theoric fund.
Theoretic.
In a theoretic manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théoriste
entry.def: One who forms theories; one given to theory and speculation; a speculatist.
entry.q: The greatest theoretists have given the preference to such a government as that which obtains in this kingdom.

entry.def: The act or product of theorizing; the formation of a theory or theories; speculation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Theorized; p. pr. & vb. n. Theorizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. théoriser
entry.def: To form a theory or theories; to form opinions solely by theory; to speculate.
One who theorizes or speculates; a theorist.

entries.entry:
The"o*ry ☞ “This word is employed by English writers in a very loose and improper sense. It is with them usually convertible into hypothesis, and hypothesis is commonly used as another term for conjecture. The terms theory and theoretical are properly used in opposition to the terms practice and practical. In this sense, they were exclusively employed by the ancients; and in this sense, they are almost exclusively employed by the Continental philosophers.” Sir W. Hamilton.
Atomic theory Binary theory
etc. See under Atomic Binary, etc.
Theory Hypothesis. A theory is a scheme of the relations subsisting between the parts of a systematic whole; an hypothesis is a tentative conjecture respecting a cause of phenomena. n.; pl.Theories #. F. théorie, L. theoria, Gr. � a beholding, spectacle, contemplation, speculation, fr. � a spectator, � to see, view. See Theater
A doctrine, or scheme of things, which terminates in speculation or contemplation, without a view to practice; hypothesis; speculation.
An exposition of the general or abstract principles of any science; as, the theory of music.
The science, as distinguished from the art; as, the theory and practice of medicine.
The philosophical explanation of phenomena, either physical or moral; as, Lavoisier's theory of combustion; Adam Smith's theory of moral sentiments.
Hypothesis, speculation.

entry.def: A theosophist.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théosophique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to theosophy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théosophisme
entry.def: Belief in theosophy.
One addicted to theosophy.
entry.q: The theosophist is one who gives you a theory of God, or of the works of God, which has not reason, but an inspiration of his own, for its basis.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to theosophy; theosophical.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Theosophized; p. pr. & vb. n. Theosophizing
entry.def: To practice theosophy.

entry.ety: Gr. � knowledge of things divine, fr. � wise in the things of God; � God + � wise: cf. F. théosophie
entry.def: Any system of philosophy or mysticism which proposes to attain intercourse with God and superior spirits, and consequent superhuman knowledge, by physical processes, as by the theurgic operations of some ancient Platonists, or by the chemical processes of the German fire philosophers; also, a direct, as distinguished from a revealed, knowledge of God, supposed to be attained by extraordinary illumination; especially, a direct insight into the processes of the divine mind, and the interior relations of the divine nature.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � (pl. �) an attendant, servant, physician. See Therapeutic
entry.def: A name given to certain ascetics said to have anciently dwelt in the neighborhood of Alexandria. They are described in a work attributed to Philo, the genuineness and credibility of which are now much discredited.

entry.ety: F. thérapeutique, Gr. �, from � attendant, servant, � to serve, take care of, treat medically, � attendant, servant
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the healing art; concerned in discovering and applying remedies for diseases; curative.
entry.q: Therapeuticor curative physic.
Medicine is justly distributed into “prophylactic,” or the art of preserving health, and therapeutic, or the art of restoring it.

entry.def: One of the Therapeutæ.

entry.ety: Cf. F. thérapeutique
entry.def: That part of medical science which treats of the discovery and application of remedies for diseases.
One versed in therapeutics, or the discovery and application of remedies.

entry.ety: Gr. �
entry.def: Therapeutics.

entry.note: ☞ In distinction from here there usually signifies a place farther off. “Darkness there might well seem twilight here.” Milton.

☞ There is sometimes used by way of exclamation, calling the attention to something, especially to something distant; as, there there! see there! look there! There is often used as an expletive, and in this use, when it introduces a sentence or clause, the verb precedes its subject.
☞ There is much used in composition, and often has the sense of a pronoun. See Thereabout Thereafter Therefrom, etc.
☞ There was formerly used in the sense of where.

cs.cd: in one place and another.

entry.ety: OE. ther, AS. ðǣr; akin to D. daar, G. da, OHG. dār, Sw. & Dan. der, Icel. & Goth. þar, Skr. tarhi then, and E. that. √184. See That pron.

sn.def: In or at that place.
sn.q: Theythereleft me and my man, both bound together.
The Lord God planted a garden eastward in Eden; and there he put the man whom he had formed.

sn.def: In that matter, relation, etc.; at that point, stage, etc., regarded as a distinct place; as, he did not stop there, but continued his speech.
sn.q: The law that theaten'd death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile; there art thou happy.

sn.def: To or into that place; thither.
sn.q: The rarest that e'er came there.
A knight there was, and that a worthy man.
There is a path which no fowl knoweth.
Wherever there is a sense or perception, there some idea is actually produced.
There have been that have delivered themselves from their ills by their good fortune or virtue.
Spend their good there it is reasonable.
sn.syn: See Thither.

entry.ety: The latter spelling is less proper, but more commonly used

sn.def: Near that place.
Near that number, degree, or quantity; nearly; as, ten men, or thereabouts .
sn.q: Five or six thousand horse . . . or thereabouts.
Some three months since, or thereabout.

sn.def: Concerning that; about that.
sn.q: What will ye dine? I will go thereabout.
They were much perplexed thereabout.

entry.ety: AS. ðǣræfter after that. See There, and After

sn.def: After that; afterward.
According to that; accordingly.
sn.q: I deny not but that it is of greatest concernment in the church and commonwealth to have a vigilant eye how books demean themselves as well as men; and thereafter to confine, imprison, and do sharpest justice on them as malefactors.

sn.def: Of that sort.
sn.q: My audience is notthereafter.

entry.def: In opposition; against one's course.
entry.q: If that him list to stand thereagain.

entry.def: Concerning that.

sn.def: At that place; there.
sn.q: Wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat.

sn.def: At that occurrence or event; on that account.
sn.q: Every error is a stain to the beauty of nature; for which cause it blusheth thereat.

entry.def: Before that time; beforehand.
entry.q: Many a winter therebiforn.

sn.def: By that; by that means; in consequence of that.
sn.q: Acquaint now thyself with him, and be at peace; thereby good shall come unto thee.

sn.def: Annexed to that.
sn.q: Therebyhangs a tale.

sn.def: Thereabout; -- said of place, number, etc.

entry.ety: There + for. Cf. Therefore
entry.def: For that, or this; for it.
entry.q: With certain officers ordained therefore.

entry.ety: OE. therfore. See There, and Fore adv. For, and cf. Therefor

sn.def: For that or this reason, referring to something previously stated; for that.
sn.q: I have married a wife, and therefore I can not come.
Behold, we have forsaken all, and followed thee; what shall we have therefore?

sn.def: Consequently; by consequence.
sn.q: He blushes; therefore he is guilty.
sn.syn: See Then.

entry.def: From this or that.
entry.q: Turn not aside therefrom to the right hand or to the left.

entry.def: In that or this place, time, or thing; in that particular or respect.
entry.q: He pricketh through a fair forest,Therein is many a wild beast.
Bring forth abundantly in the earth, and multiply therein.
Therein our letters do not well agree.

entry.def: Into that or this, or into that place.
entry.q: Let not them . . . enter thereinto.

entry.def: Of that or this.
entry.q: In the day that thou eatest thereof, thou shalt surely die.

entry.def: Therapeutios.

entry.ety: AS. ��ron. See There, and On
entry.def: On that or this.
entry.q: Then the king said, Hang him thereon.

sn.def: Out of that or this.
sn.q: He shall take thereout his handful of the flour.

sn.def: On the outside; out of doors.
To that or this.
Besides; moreover.
sn.q: Her mouth full small, and thereto soft and red.

entry.def: Up to that time; before then; -- correlative with heretofore.
Under that or this.
Unto that or this; thereto; besides.

sn.def: Upon that or this; thereon.
sn.q: They shall feedthereupon.

sn.def: On account, or in consequence, of that; therefore.
sn.q: He] hopes to find you forward, . . . And thereupon he sends you this good news.

sn.def: Immediately; at once; without delay.

entry.def: At that time; at the same time.

sn.def: With that or this.
sn.q: I have learned in whatsoever state I am,therewithto be content.

sn.def: In addition; besides; moreover.
sn.q: To speak of strength and therewith hardiness.

sn.def: At the same time; forthwith.
Over and above; besides; moreover.
sn.q: And therewithal it was full poor and bad.

sn.def: With that or this; therewith; at the same time.
sn.q: Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal Remit thy other forfeits.
And therewithal one came and seized on her, And Enid started waking.

entry.ety: AS. �eorf; akin to OHG. derb, Icel. �jarfr
entry.def: Not fermented; unleavened; -- said of bread, loaves, etc.
entry.q: Pask and the feast of therf loaves.

entry.ety: L. theriaca an antidote against the bite of serpents, Gr. �: cf. F. thériaque. See Treacle

sn.def: An ancient composition esteemed efficacious against the effects of poison; especially, a certain compound of sixty-four drugs, prepared, pulverized, and reduced by means of honey to an electuary; -- called also theriaca Andromachi, and Venice treacle.
Treacle; molasses.

entry.ety: Cf. F. thériacal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to theriac; medicinal.
entry.q: Theriacalherbs.

entry.def: Theriac.
One of the Theriodontia. Used also adjectively.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Theriodontia.

entry.note: ☞ They had biconcave vertebræ, ambulatory limbs, and a well-developed pelvis and shoulder girdle. Some of the species had large maxillary teeth. The head somewhat resembled that of a turtle. The Dicynodont is one of the best-known examples. See Dicynodont.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � (dim. of � a beast) + �, �, a tooth
entry.def: An extinct order of reptiles found in the Permian and Triassic formations in South Africa. In some respects they resembled carnivorous mammals. Called also Theromorpha.

entry.ety: Gr. � wild beast + � to cut
entry.def: Zoötomy.
one of several units of heat, especially one equivalent to 1000 large calories, or 100,000 British thermal units.

entry.ety: L. See Thermal
entry.def: Springs or baths of warm or hot water.

entry.cs: Thermal conductivity Thermal spectrum . See under Conductivity, and Spectrum. Thermal unit Physics a unit chosen for the comparison or calculation of quantities of heat. The unit most commonly employed is the amount of heat necessary to raise the temperature of one gram or one pound of water from zero to one degree Centigrade. See Calorie, and under Unit.
entry.ety: L. thermae hot springs, fr. Gr. �, pl. of � heat, fr. � hot, warm, � to warm, make hot; perhaps akin to L. formus warm, and E. forceps

sn.def: Of or pertaining to heat; warm; hot; as, the thermal unit; thermal waters.
sn.q: The thermal condition of the earth.

sn.def: caused by or affected by heat; as, thermal springs.
designed to retain heat; as, thermal underwear.

entry.def: In a thermal manner.

entry.ety: Gr. � heat + E. antidote
entry.def: A device for circulating and cooling the air, consisting essentially of a kind of roasting fan fitted in a window and incased in wet tatties.
entry.q: Will you bring me to book on the mountains, or where the thermantidotes play?

entry.ety: Gr. � heat + � measure + -graph
entry.def: A self-registering thermometer, especially one that registers the maximum and minimum during long periods.

entry.cs: Thermic balance. See Bolometer. Thermic fever Med the condition of fever produced by sunstroke. See Sunstroke. Thermic weight. Mech Same as Heat weight, under Heat.
entry.ety: Gr. � heat
entry.def: Of or pertaining to heat; due to heat; thermal; as, thermic lines.

entry.ety: F., fr. Gr. � warm, hot
entry.def: The eleventh month of the French republican calendar, -- commencing July 19, and ending August 17. See the Note under Vendémiaire.

entry.ety: Gr. � heat + L. fugere to flee
entry.def: An artificial alkaloid of complex composition, resembling thalline and used as an antipyretic, -- whence its name.

entries.entry: Ther"mo-. A combining form from Gr. qe`rmh heat qermo`s hot warm; as in thermochemistry, thermodynamic.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Loss of power to distinguish heat or cold by touch.
An instrument for recording simultaneously the pressure and temperature of a gas; a combined thermograph and barograph.

entry.ety: Thermo- + barometer

sn.def: An instrument for determining altitudes by the boiling point of water.
A siphon barometer adapted to be used also as a thermometer.

entry.ety: Thermo- + battery
entry.def: A thermoelectric battery; a thermopile.

cs.cd: thermocautery by means of a hollow platinum point, which is kept constantly hot by the passage through it of benzine vapor.

entry.ety: Thermo- + cautery
entry.def: Cautery by the application of heat.
Of or pertaining to thermochemistry; obtained by, or employed in, thermochemistry.

entry.ety: Thermo- + chemistry
entry.def: That branch of chemical science which includes the investigation of the various relations existing between chemical action and that manifestation of force termed heat, or the determination of the heat evolved by, or employed in, chemical actions.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. �, �, color
entry.def: Pertaining to or designating heat rays that have undergone selective absorption and are therefore analogous to colored light rays.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. � coloring
entry.def: The property possessed by heat of being composed, like light, of rays of different degrees of refrangibility, which are unequal in rate or degree of transmission through diathermic substances.
A thermoelectric couple.

entry.ety: Thermo- + current
entry.def: A current developed or set in motion by heat; specif., an electric current, in a heterogeneous circuit, due to differences of temperature between the junctions of the substances of which the circuit is composed.

entry.ety: G., fr. Gr. � heat
entry.def: A white crystalline substance derived from urethane, used in medicine as an antipyretic, etc.

entry.cs: Thermodynamic function. See Heat weight, under Heat.
entry.ety: Thermo- + dynamic
entry.def: Relating to thermodynamics; caused or operated by force due to the application of heat.
The science which treats of the mechanical action or relations of heat.
Pertaining to thermoelectricity; as, thermoelectric currents.

entries.entry: Ther`mo*e*lec"tric coupleorTher`mo*e*lec"tric pair . Elec A union of two conductors, as bars or wires of dissimilar metals joined at their extremities, for producing a thermoelectric current.

entry.ety: Thermo- + electricity: cf. F. thermoélectricité
entry.def: Electricity developed in the action of heat. See the Note under Electricity.

entry.ety: Thermo- + electrometer
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the strength of an electric current in the heat which it produces, or for determining the heat developed by such a current.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -gen
entry.def: Caloric; heat; regarded as a material but imponderable substance.
Relating to heat, or to the production of heat; producing heat; thermogenous; as, the thermogenic tissues.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -genous
entry.def: Producing heat; thermogenic.
The trace or record made by means of a thermograph.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -graph
entry.def: An instrument for automatically recording indications of the variation of temperature.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -graphy
entry.def: Any process of writing involving the use of heat.
A junction of two dissimilar conductors used to produce a thermoelectric current, as in one form of pyrometer; a thermocouple.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -logy
entry.def: A discourse on, or an account of, heat.
Luminescence exhibited by a substance on being moderately heated. It is shown esp. by certain substances that have been exposed to the action of light or to X-rays.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. ly`ein to loose + -in
entry.def: a proteolytic enzyme obtained from the bacterium Bacillus thermoproteolyticus, which hydrolyses the N-terminal amide bonds of hydrophobic amino acid residues in proteins. It is used in studies of protein structure. It has a molecular weight of about 37,500 and contains zinc and calcium in its active configuration.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. ly`ein to loose
entry.def: The resolution of a compound into parts by heat; dissociation by heat.
Of or pertaining to thermolysis.
To subject to thermolysis; to dissociate by heat.

entry.ety: Thermo- + magnetism
entry.def: Magnetism as affected or caused by the action of heat; the relation of heat to magnetism.

entry.note: ☞ The thermometer usually consists of a glass tube of capillary bore, terminating in a bulb, and containing mercury or alcohol, which expanding or contracting according to the temperature to which it is exposed, indicates the degree of heat or cold by the amount of space occupied, as shown by the position of the top of the liquid column on a graduated scale. See Centigrade Fahrenheit, and Réaumur. To reduce degrees Fahrenheit to degrees Centigrade, substract 32° and multiply by 5/9; to reduce degrees Centigrade to degrees Fahrenheit, multiply by 9/5 and add 32°.

cs.cd: etc. See under Air Balance, etc.
a form of thermometer indicating changes of temperature by the expansion or contraction of rods or strips of metal.

a thermometer that registers the maximum and minimum of temperature occurring in the interval of time between two consecutive settings of the instrument. A common form contains a bit of steel wire to be pushed before the column and left at the point of maximum temperature, or a slide of enamel, which is drawn back by the liquid, and left within it at the point of minimum temperature.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -meter: cf. F. thermomètre. See Thermal
entry.def: An instrument for measuring temperature, founded on the principle that changes of temperature in bodies are accompanied by proportional changes in their volumes or dimensions.

entry.ety: Cf. F. thermométrique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a thermometer; as, the thermometrical scale or tube.
Made, or ascertained, by means of a thermometer; as, thermometrical observations.

entry.def: In a thermometrical manner; by means of a thermometer.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. � measure + -graph
entry.def: An instrument for recording graphically the variations of temperature, or the indications of a thermometer.
The estimation of temperature by the use of a thermometric apparatus.
A heat engine; a hot-air engine.

entry.ety: Thermo- + multiplier
entry.def: Same as Thermopile.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A neurosis caused by exposure to heat.
A neurosis causing a rise or fall of a body's temperature.
Neutrality as regards heat effects.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. � loving + -ic
entry.def: Heat-loving; -- applied especially to microorganisms such as certain bacteria, fungi and algae, which grow best at temperatures above 40° C (e.g. between 50° and 60°), and in some cases at temperatures that would kill ordinary microorganisms. They are found in naturally hot locations, such as at hot springs or the thermal vents at the ocean bottom.

entry.ety: Thermo- + phone

sn.def: A portable form of telethermometer, using a telephone in connection with a differential thermometer.
A telephone involving heat effects, as changes in temperature (hence in length) due to pulsations of the line current in a fine wire connected with the receiver diaphragm.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. � -bearing, fr. fe`rein to bear
entry.def: An apparatus for conveying heat, as a case containing material which retains its heat for a considerable period.

entry.ety: Thermo- + pile a heap
entry.def: An instrument of extreme sensibility, used to determine slight differences and degrees of heat. It is composed of alternate bars of antimony and bismuth, or any two metals having different capacities for the conduction of heat, connected with an astatic galvanometer, which is very sensibly affected by the electric current induced in the system of bars when exposed even to the feeblest degrees of heat.
A device for the automatic regulation of temperature; a thermostat.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -scope
entry.def: An instrument for indicating changes of temperature without indicating the degree of heat by which it is affected; especially, an instrument contrived by Count Rumford which, as modified by Professor Leslie, was afterward called the differential thermometer.
Of or pertaining to the thermoscope; made by means of the thermoscope; as, thermoscopic observations.
An arrangement of siphon tubes for assisting circulation in a liquid.

entry.ety: Thermo- + stable fixed
entry.def: Capable of being heated to or somewhat above 55° C. without loss of special properties; -- said of proteins, immune substances, etc.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. � to make to stand
entry.def: A device which automatically regulates temperature, or provides a signal used by another device to regulate temperature. The temperature-sensitive signal may be electronic, as that produced by a thermocouple. The signal may also be caused mechanically, as by the unequal expansion of different metals, liquids, or gases by heat, which can then cause the opening or closing of the damper of a stove, or the like, as the heat becomes greater or less than is desired.
Of or pertaining to the thermostat; made or effected by means of the thermostat.

entry.ety: Thermo- + systaltic
entry.def: Influenced in its contraction by heat or cold; -- said of a muscle.
Of or retaining to thermotaxis.

entry.ety: Thermo- + ank
entry.def: A tank containing pipes through which circulates steam, water, air, or the like, for heating or cooling; -- used in some heating and ventilation systems.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. � arrangement
entry.def: Pertaining to, or connected with, the regulation of temperature in the animal body; as, the thermotaxic nervous system.

entry.ety: NL.; thermo- + Gr. � an arranging
entry.def: The property possessed by protoplasm of moving under the influence of heat.
Determination of the direction of locomotion by heat.
Pertaining to the variation of tensile strength with the temperature.

entry.ety: Thermo- + tension
entry.def: A process of increasing the strength of wrought iron by heating it to a determinate temperature, and giving to it, while in that state, a mechanical strain or tension in the direction in which the strength is afterward to be exerted.

entry.ety: Thermo- + therapy
entry.def: Treatment of disease by heat, esp. by hot air.

entry.ety: Gr. � heat, fr. � hot
entry.def: Of or pertaining to heat; produced by heat; as, thermotical phenomena.
The science of heat.

entry.ety: NL.; thermo- + tonus
entry.def: A condition of tonicity with respect to temperature.
Manifesting thermotropism.

entry.ety: Thermo- + Gr. � to turn
entry.def: The phenomenon of turning towards a source of warmth, seen in the growing parts of some plants.

entry.ety: Thermo- + -type
entry.def: A picture (as of a slice of wood) obtained by first wetting the object slightly with hydrochloric or dilute sulphuric acid, then taking an impression with a press, and next strongly heating this impression.
The art or process of obtaining thermotypes.

entry.ety: Thermo- + voltaic
entry.def: Of or relating to heat and electricity; especially, relating to thermal effects produced by voltaic action.

entry.ety: Gr. qh`r qhro`s, wild beast + -oid
entry.def: Resembling a beast in nature or habit; marked by animal characteristics; as, theroid idiocy.

entry.ety: NL.: Gr. qh`r beast + morfh` form
entry.def: See Theriodonta.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. qh`r a beast + �, �, foot
entry.def: An order of carnivorous dinosaurs in which the feet are less birdlike, and hence more like those of an ordinary quadruped, than in the Ornithopoda. It includes the rapacious genera Megalosaurus Creosaurus, and their allies.

entries.entry:
The*sau"rus The*sau"rus n.; pl.Thesauri #. L. See Treasure
A treasury or storehouse; hence, a repository, especially of knowledge; -- often applied to a comprehensive work, like a dictionary or cyclopedia.

entry.ety: OE. þes þæs, a variant of þas, pl. of þes thes, this. See This, and cf. Those
entry.def: The plural of this. See This.

entry.ety: Dim. of thesis
entry.def: A little or subordinate thesis; a proposition.

entries.entry:
The"sis n.; pl.Theses #. L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to place, set. See Do, and cf. Anathema Apothecary Epithet Hypothesis Parenthesis Theme Tick a cover
A position or proposition which a person advances and offers to maintain, or which is actually maintained by argument.
Hence, an essay or dissertation written upon specific or definite theme; especially, an essay presented by a candidate for a diploma or degree. I told them of the grave, becoming, and sublime deportment they should assume upon this mystical occasion, and read them two homilies and a thesis of my own composing, to prepare them.
Logic An affirmation, or distinction from a supposition or hypothesis.
Mus The accented part of the measure, expressed by the downward beat; -- the opposite of arsis.
Pros
The depression of the voice in pronouncing the syllables of a word.
The part of the foot upon which such a depression falls.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � that which is established, a law (fr. � to set) + � a giver (also fr. �)
entry.def: A lawgiver; a legislator; one of the six junior archons at Athens.

entry.ety: From L. Thespis, Gr. �, the founder of the Greek drama
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thespis; hence, relating to the drama; dramatic; as, the Thespian art.

def2.def: An actor.

entry.ety: Cf. L. Thessalius
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thessaly in Greece.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Thessaly.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thessalonica, a city of Macedonia.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Thessalonica.

cs.cd: one of a group of functions used in developing the properties of elliptic functions.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. qh^ta, the Greek letter θ, Θ
entry.def: A letter of the Greek alphabet corresponding to th in English; -- sometimes called the unlucky letter, from being used by the judges on their ballots in passing condemnation on a prisoner, it being the first letter of the Greek qa`natos, death.

entry.ety: Gr. � fit for placing, fr. � to set, lay down. See Thesis
entry.def: Laid down; absolute or positive, as a law.

entry.ety: Thio + ether + sulphine
entry.def: Any one of a series of complex basic sulphur compounds analogous to the sulphines.

cs.cd: songs of incantation.

entry.ety: L. theurgicus, Gr. �: cf. F. théurgique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to theurgy; magical.

entry.ety: Cf. F. théurgiste
entry.def: One who pretends to, or is addicted to, theurgy.

entry.ety: L. theurgia, Gr. qeoyrgi`a, fr. qeoyrgo`s doing the works of God; qeo`s God + 'e`rgon work: cf. F. théurgie. See Theism, and Work

sn.def: A divine work; a miracle; hence, magic; sorcery.
A kind of magical science or art developed in Alexandria among the Neoplatonists, and supposed to enable man to influence the will of the gods by means of purification and other sacramental rites.
In later or modern magic, that species of magic in which effects are claimed to be produced by supernatural agency, in distinction from natural magic.

entry.note: Chiefly used in the plural Thews thūz
entry.ety: OE. thew þeau, manner, habit, strength, AS. þeáw manner, habit (cf. þȳwan to drive); akin to OS. thau custom, habit, OHG. dou. √56

sn.def: Manner; custom; habit; form of behavior; qualities of mind; disposition; specifically, good qualities; virtues.
sn.q: For her great light Of sapience, and for her thews clear.
Evil speeches destroy good thews.
To be upbrought in gentle thews and martial might.

sn.def: Muscle or strength; nerve; brawn; sinew.
sn.q: And I myself, who sat apart And watched them, waxed in every limb; I felt the thews of Anakim, The pules of a Titan's heart.

sn.def: Furnished with thews or muscles; as, a well-thewed limb.
Accustomed; mannered.
sn.q: Yet would not seem so rude and thewed ill.

entry.def: Having strong or large thews or muscles; muscular; sinewy; strong.

entries.entry:
They
poss. Theirs; obj. Them
☞ They is used indefinitely, as our ancestors used man, and as the French use on; as, they say (French on dit), that is, it is said by persons not specified. �ā pron. pl.; . Icel. þeir they, properly nom. pl. masc. of sā sū þat, a demonstrative pronoun, akin to the English definite article, AS. sē seó ðæt, nom. pl. ðā. See That
The plural of he she, or it. They is never used adjectively, but always as a pronoun proper, and sometimes refers to persons without an antecedent expressed. Jolif and glad they went unto heretheir] rest And casten hemthem] full early for to sail.
They of Italy salute you. Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness.

entry.ety: Thio- + aldehyde + -ine
entry.def: A weak nitrogenous sulphur base, C6H13NS2.

entry.ety: Thio- + alcohol + L. oleum oil
entry.def: A colorless oily liquid, C2H5)2S2, having a strong garlic odor; -- called also ethyl disulphide. By extension, any one of the series of related compounds.
Of or pertaining to Thibet.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Thibet.

entries.entry: Thib"et cloth`. A fabric made of coarse goat's hair; a kind of camlet. A kind of fine woolen cloth, used for dresses, cloaks, etc.

entry.def: Same as Thibetan.
A slice; a skimmer; a spatula; a pudding stick.

entry.note: ☞ Thick is often used in the formation of compounds, most of which are self-explaining; as, thick-barred, thick-bodied, thick-coming, thick-cut, thick-flying, thick-growing, thick-leaved, thick-lipped, thick-necked, thick-planted, thick-ribbed, thick-shelled, thick-woven, and the like.
entry.cs: Thick register. Phon See the Note under Register n., 7. Thick stuff Naut all plank that is more than four inches thick and less than twelve. J. Knowles.
entry.ety: OE. thicke, AS. þicce; akin to D. dik, OS. thikki, OHG. dicchi thick, dense, G. dick thick, Icel. þykkr þjökkr, and probably to Gael. & Ir. tiugh. Cf. Tight

sn.def: Measuring in the third dimension other than length and breadth, or in general dimension other than length; -- said of a solid body; as, a timber seven inches thick .
sn.q: Were it as thick as is a branched oak.
My little finger shall be thicker than my father's loins.

sn.def: Having more depth or extent from one surface to its opposite than usual; not thin or slender; as, a thick plank; thick cloth; thick paper; thick neck.
Dense; not thin; inspissated; as, thick vapors. Also used figuratively; as, thick darkness.
sn.q: Make the gruel thick and slab.

sn.def: Not transparent or clear; hence, turbid, muddy, or misty; as, the water of a river is apt to be thick after a rain.
sn.q: In athick, misty day.

sn.def: Abundant, close, or crowded in space; closely set; following in quick succession; frequently recurring.
sn.q: The people were gathered thick together.
Black was the forest; thick with beech it stood.

sn.def: Not having due distinction of syllables, or good articulation; indistinct; as, a thick utterance.
Deep; profound; as, thick sleep.
Dull; not quick; as, thick of fearing.
sn.q: His dimensions to any thick sight were invincible.

sn.def: Intimate; very friendly; familiar.
sn.q: We have been thick ever since.
sn.syn: Dense; close; compact; solid; gross; coarse.

cs.cd: a fiddle block. See under Fiddle.
through all obstacles and difficulties, both great and small.

sn.def: The thickest part, or the time when anything is thickest.
sn.q: In the thick of the dust and smoke.

sn.def: A thicket; as, gloomy thicks .
sn.q: Through the thick they heard one rudely rush.
He through a little window cast his sight Through thick of bars, that gave a scanty light.
Through thick and thin she followed him.
He became the panegyrist, through thick and thin, of a military frenzy.

cs.cd: in quick succession, or in great numbers.

entry.ety: AS. þicce

sn.def: Frequently; fast; quick.
Closely; as, a plat of ground thick sown.
To a great depth, or to a greater depth than usual; as, land covered thick with manure.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. þiccian
entry.def: To thicken.
entry.q: The nightmare Life-in-death was she, Who thicks man's blood with cold.

entry.def: The bullfinch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thickened; p. pr. & vb. n. Thickening
entry.def: To make thick (in any sense of the word).
To render dense; to inspissate; as, to thicken paint.
To make close; to fill up interstices in; as, to thicken cloth; to thicken ranks of trees or men.
To strengthen; to confirm.
entry.q: And this may to thicken other proofs.
entry.def: To make more frequent; as, to thicken blows.
To become thick.
entry.q: Thy lusterthickenswhen he shines by.
The press of people thickens to the court.
The combat thickens, like the storm that flies.

entry.def: Something put into a liquid or mass to make it thicker.

entry.ety: AS. þiccet. See Thick a.
entry.def: A wood or a collection of trees, shrubs, etc., closely set; as, a ram caught in a thicket .

sn.def: A thick-headed or stupid person.
Any one of several species of Australian singing birds of the genus Pachycephala. The males of some of the species are bright-colored. Some of the species are popularly called thrushes.

entry.def: Having a thick skull; stupid.
Somewhat thick.
A stone curlew. See under Stone.
In a thick manner; deeply; closely.

entry.ety: AS. �icnes
entry.def: The quality or state of being thick (in any of the senses of the adjective).

sn.def: Close planted; as, a thickset wood; a thickset hedge.
Having a short, thick body; stout.
A close or thick hedge.
A stout, twilled cotton cloth; a fustian corduroy, or velveteen.

entry.def: A coarse, gross person; a person void of sensibility or sinsitiveness; a dullard.
Having a thick skin; hence, not sensitive; dull; obtuse.
A dullard, or dull person; a blockhead; a numskull.
Having a thick skull; hence, dull; heavy; stupid; slow to learn.

entries.entry: Thick" wind`. Far A defect of respiration in a horse, that is unassociated with noise in breathing or with the signs of emphysema.

entry.def: Affected with thick wind.
Thither.
Thitherward.

entries.entry:
Thief
Thief catcher. Same as Thief taker. Thief leader one who leads or takes away a thief. L'Estrange. Thief taker one whose business is to find and capture thieves and bring them to justice. Thief tube a tube for withdrawing a sample of a liquid from a cask. Thieves' vinegar a kind of aromatic vinegar for the sick room, taking its name from the story that thieves, by using it, were enabled to plunder, with impunity to health, in the great plague at London. Eng
Thief Robber. A thief takes our property by stealth; a robber attacks us openly, and strips us by main force. thēf n.; pl.Thieves thēvz. OE. thef theef, AS. þeóf; akin to OFries. thiaf, OS. theof thiof, D. dief, G. dieb, OHG. diob, Icel. þjōfr, Sw. tjuf, Dan. tyv, Goth. þiufs þiubs, and perhaps to Lith. tupeti to squat or crouch down. Cf. Theft
One who steals; one who commits theft or larceny. See Theft. There came a privy thief, men clepeth death. Where thieves break through and steal.
A waster in the snuff of a candle. Robber; pilferer. Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night. Some roving robber calling to his fellows.

entry.def: Like a thief; thievish; thievishly.

entry.ety: Thiënyl + ketone
entry.def: A ketone derivative of thiophene obtained as a white crystalline substance, C4H3S)2.CO, by the action of aluminum chloride and carbonyl chloride on thiophene.

entry.ety: Thiophene + -yl
entry.def: The hypothetical radical C4H3S., regarded as the essential residue of thiophene and certain of its derivatives.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thieved; p. pr. & vb. n. Thieving
entry.ety: AS. geþeófian
entry.def: To practice theft; to steal.

sn.def: The practice of stealing; theft; thievishness.
sn.q: Among the Spartans, thievery was a practice morally good and honest.

sn.def: That which is stolen.
Given to stealing; addicted to theft; as, a thievish boy, a thievish magpie.
Like a thief; acting by stealth; sly; secret.
sn.q: Time's thievish progress to eternity.

sn.def: Partaking of the nature of theft; accomplished by stealing; dishonest; as, a thievish practice.
sn.q: Or with a base and biosterous sword enforce A thievish living on the common road.

cs.cd: the femur.

entry.ety: OE. thi þih þeh, AS. þeóh; akin to OFries. thiach, D. dij dije, OHG. dioh thioh, Icel. þjō thigh, rump, and probably to Lith. taukas fat of animals, tukti to become fat, Russ. tuke fat of animals. √56

sn.def: The proximal segment of the hind limb between the knee and the trunk. See Femur.
The coxa, or femur, of an insect.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to thigmotaxis.

entries.entry: Thig`mo*tax"is ☞ When the movement is away from the touching body, it is negative thigmotaxis; when towards it, positive thigmotaxis.‖n. NL., fr. Gr. � touch + � an arranging Physiol The property possessed by living protoplasm of contracting, and thus moving, when touched by a solid or fluid substance.

entry.ety: Cf. Ilk same
entry.def: That same; this; that.
entry.q: I lovethilklass.
Thou spake right now of thilke traitor death.

cs.cd: a device for connecting the thill of a vehicle to the axle.

entry.ety: OE. thille, AS. �ille a board, plank, beam, thill; akin to �el a plank, D. deel a plank, floor, G. diele, OHG. dili dilla, Icel. �ilja a plank, planking, a thwart, �ili a wainscot, plank; cf. Skr. tala a level surface. √236. Cf. Fill a thill, Deal a plank

sn.def: One of the two long pieces of wood, extending before a vehicle, between which a horse is hitched; a shaft.
The floor of a coal mine.

entry.def: The horse which goes between the thills, or shafts, and supports them; also, the last horse in a team; -- called also thill horse.

entry.ety: OE. thimbil, AS. ��mel, fr. ��ma a thumb. √56. See Thumb

sn.def: A kind of cap or cover, or sometimes a broad ring, for the end of the finger, used in sewing to protect the finger when pushing the needle through the material. It is usually made of metal, and has upon the outer surface numerous small pits to catch the head of the needle.

entry.sn:
Mech Any thimble-shaped appendage or fixure. Specifically: A tubular piece, generally a strut, through which a bolt or pin passes.
A fixed or movable ring, tube, or lining placed in a hole.
A tubular cone for expanding a flue; -- called ferrule in England.

sn.def: A ring of thin metal formed with a grooved circumference so as to fit within an eye-spice, or the like, and protect it from chafing.

entry.def: A kind of black raspberry (Rubus occidentalis), common in America.
The chub mackerel. See under Chub.

entries.entry: Thim"ble*ful n.; pl.Thimblefuls. As much as a thimble will hold; a very small quantity. For a thimbleful of golf, a thimbleful of love.

entry.def: A sleight-of-hand trick played with three small cups, shaped like thimbles, and a small ball or little pea.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thimblerigged; p. pr. & vb. n. Thimblerigging
entry.def: To swindle by means of small cups or thimbles, and a pea or small ball placed under one of them and quickly shifted to another, the victim laying a wager that he knows under which cup it is; hence, to cheat by any trick.
One who cheats by thimblerigging, or tricks of legerdemain.
Any plant of the composite genus Rudbeckia, coarse herbs somewhat resembling the sunflower; -- so called from their conical receptacles.

entry.note: ☞ Thin is used in the formation of compounds which are mostly self-explaining; as, thin-faced, thin-lipped, thin-peopled, thin-shelled, and the like.
entry.cs: Thin section. See under Section.
entry.ety: OE. thinne thenne thunne, AS. þynne; akin to D. dun, G. dünn, OHG. dunni, Icel. þunnr, Sw. tunn, Dan. tynd, Gael. & Ir. tana, W. teneu, L. tenuis, Gr. � (in comp.) stretched out, � stretched, stretched out, long, Skr. tanu thin, slender; also to AS. �enian to extend, G. dehnen, Icel. �enja, Goth. �anjanin comp.), L. tendere to stretch, tenere to hold, Gr. � to stretch, Skr. tan. √51 & 237. Cf. Attenuate Dance Tempt Tenable Tend to move, Tenous Thunder Tone

sn.def: Having little thickness or extent from one surface to its opposite; as, a thin plate of metal; thin paper; a thin board; a thin covering.
Rare; not dense or thick; -- applied to fluids or soft mixtures; as, thin blood; thin broth; thin air.
sn.q: In the day, when the air is more thin.
Satan, bowing low His gray dissimulation, disappeared, Into thin air diffused.

sn.def: Not close; not crowded; not filling the space; not having the individuals of which the thing is composed in a close or compact state; hence, not abundant; as, the trees of a forest are thin; the corn or grass is thin.
sn.q: Ferrara is very large, but extremely thin of people.

sn.def: Not full or well grown; wanting in plumpness.
sn.q: Seven thin ears . . . blasted with the east wind.

sn.def: Not stout; slim; slender; lean; gaunt; as, a person becomes thin by disease.
Wanting in body or volume; small; feeble; not full.
sn.q: Thin, hollow sounds, and lamentable screams.

sn.def: Slight; small; slender; flimsy; wanting substance or depth or force; superficial; inadequate; not sufficient for a covering; as, a thin disguise.
sn.q: My tale is done, for my wit is but thin.

entry.def: Not thickly or closely; in a seattered state; as, seed sown thin .
entry.q: Spain is thin sown of people.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thinned; p. pr. & vb. n. Thinning
entry.ety: Cf. AS. geþynnian
entry.def: To make thin (in any of the senses of the adjective).
To grow or become thin; -- used with some adverbs, as out away, etc.; as, geological strata thin out, i. e., gradually diminish in thickness until they disappear.

entry.note: ☞ In the old style, thine was commonly shortened to thi thy) when used attributively before words beginning with a consonant; now, thy is used also before vowels. Thine is often used absolutely, the thing possessed being understood.
entry.ety: OE. thin, AS. ðīn, originally gen. of ðu ðū, thou; akin to G. dein thine, Icel. þinn, possessive pron., þīn, gen. of þū thou, Goth. þeins, possessive pron., þeina, gen. of þu thou. See Thou, and cf. Thy
entry.def: A form of the possessive case of the pronoun thou, now superseded in common discourse by your, the possessive of you, but maintaining a place in solemn discourse, in poetry, and in the usual language of the Friends, or Quakers.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly, the singular was sometimes used in a plural or collective sense.
☞ Thing was used in a very general sense in Old English, and is still heard colloquially where some more definite term would be used in careful composition.
entry.cs: Things personal. Law Same as Personal property, under Personal. Things real. Same as Real property, under Real.
