entry.ety: AS. þing a thing, cause, assembly, judicial assembly; akin to þingan to negotiate, þingian to reconcile, conciliate, D. ding a thing, OS. thing thing, assembly, judicial assembly, G. ding a thing, formerly also, an assembly, court, Icel. þing a thing, assembly, court, Sw. & Dan. ting; perhaps originally used of the transaction of or before a popular assembly, or the time appointed for such an assembly; cf. G. dingen to bargain, hire, MHG. dingen to hold court, speak before a court, negotiate, Goth. þeihs time, perhaps akin to L. tempus time. Cf. Hustings, and Temporal of time

sn.def: Whatever exists, or is conceived to exist, as a separate entity, whether animate or inanimate; any separable or distinguishable object of thought.
sn.q: God made . . . every thing that creepeth upon the earth after his kind.
He sent after this manner; ten asses laden with the good things of Egypt.
A thing of beauty is a joy forever.

sn.def: An inanimate object, in distinction from a living being; any lifeless material.
sn.q: Ye meads and groves, unconscious things!

sn.def: A transaction or occurrence; an event; a deed.
sn.q: And Jacob said] All these things are against me.
Which if ye tell me, I in like wise will tell you by what authority I do these things.

sn.def: A portion or part; something.
sn.q: Wicked men who understand any thing of wisdom.

sn.def: A diminutive or slighted object; any object viewed as merely existing; -- often used in pity or contempt.
sn.q: See, sons, what things you are!
The poor thing sighed, and . . . turned from me.
I'll be this abject thing no more.
I have a thing in prose.

sn.def: Clothes; furniture; appurtenances; luggage; as, to pack or store one's things .
sn.q: And them she gave her moebles and her thing.
In the garden [he] walketh to and fro, And hath his thingsi. e., prayers, devotions] said full courteously.
Hearkening his minstrels their things play.

sn.def: Whatever may be possessed or owned; a property; -- distinguished from person.
In Scandinavian countries, a legislative or judicial assembly.

entry.ety: Dan. thing ting, Norw. ting, or Sw. ting
entry.def: In Scandinavian countries, a legislative or judicial assembly; -- used, esp. in composition, in titles of such bodies. See Legislature Norway.

entry.note: ☞ These are genuine Anglo-Saxon expressions, equivalent to it seems to me it seemed to me. In these expressions me is in the dative case.

☞ To think, in a philosophical use as yet somewhat limited, designates the higher intellectual acts, the acts preëminently rational; to judge; to compare; to reason. Thinking is employed by Hamilton as “comprehending all our collective energies.” It is defined by Mansel as “the act of knowing or judging by means of concepts,”by Lotze as “the reaction of the mind on the material supplied by external influences.” See Thought.
entry.cs:
To think better of. See under Better.
To think much oforTo think well of
to hold in esteem; to esteem highly.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thought; p. pr. & vb. n. Thinking
entry.ety: OE. thinken, properly, to seem, from AS. þynceancf. Methinks), but confounded with OE. thenken to think, fr. AS. þenceanimp. þōhte); akin to D. denken dunken, OS. thenkian thunkian, G. denken dünken, Icel. þekkja to perceive, to know, þykkja to seem, Goth. þagkjan þaggkjan, to think, þygkjan to think, to seem, OL. tongere to know. Cf. Thank Thought

sn.def: To seem or appear; -- used chiefly in the expressions methinketh or methinks, and methought.
To employ any of the intellectual powers except that of simple perception through the senses; to exercise the higher intellectual faculties.
sn.q: For that I am I know, because I think.

entry.sn:
Specifically: To call anything to mind; to remember; as, I would have sent the books, but I did not think of it. Well thought upon; I have it here.
To reflect upon any subject; to muse; to meditate; to ponder; to consider; to deliberate. And when he thought thereon, he wept. He thought within himself, saying, What shall I do, because I have no room where to bestow my fruits?
To form an opinion by reasoning; to judge; to conclude; to believe; as, I think it will rain to-morrow. Let them marry to whom they think best.
To purpose; to intend; to design; to mean. I thought to promote thee unto great honor. Thou thought'st to help me.
To presume; to venture.
Think not to say within yourselves, We have Abraham to our father. To expect; guess; cogitate; reflect; ponder; contemplate; meditate; muse; imagine; suppose; believe. See Expect Guess.

entry.cs: To think much to esteem a great matter; to grudge. Obs “[Hethought not much to clothe his enemies.” Milton. To think scorn. To disdain. Obs “He thought scorn to lay hands on Mordecai alone.” Esther iii. 6. To feel indignation. Obs

sn.def: To conceive; to imagine.
sn.q: Charity . . . thinketh no evil.

sn.def: To plan or design; to plot; to compass.
sn.q: So little womanhood And natural goodness, as to think the death Of her own son.

sn.def: To believe; to consider; to esteem.
sn.q: Nor think superfluous other's aid.

entry.def: Act of thinking; a thought.
entry.q: If you think that I'm finished, you've got anotherthinkcoming!

entry.def: Capable of being thought or conceived; cogitable.
One who thinks; especially and chiefly, one who thinks in a particular manner; as, a close thinker; a deep thinker; a coherent thinker.
Having the faculty of thought; cogitative; capable of a regular train of ideas; as, man is a thinking being.
The act of thinking; mode of thinking; imagination; cogitation; judgment.
entry.q: I heard a bird so sing, Whose music, to my thinking, pleased the king.

entry.def: In a thin manner; in a loose, scattered manner; scantily; not thickly; as, ground thinly planted with trees; a country thinly inhabited.
One who thins, or makes thinner.
The quality or state of being thin (in any of the senses of the word).
Somewhat thin.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, shore + -lite
entry.def: A calcareous tufa, in part crystalline, occurring on a large scale as a shore deposit about the Quaternary lake basins of Nevada.
Having a thin skin; hence, sensitive; irritable.

entries.entry: Thi"o-. Gr. � brimstone, sulphur Chem A combining form (also used adjectively) denoting the presence of sulphur. See Sulpho-.

entry.def: A sulphocarbonate.

entry.ety: Thio- + carbonic
entry.def: Same as Sulphocarbonic.
Same as Sulphocyanate.

entry.ety: Thio- + cyanic
entry.def: Same as Sulphocyanic.

entry.ety: Thiophene + naphthalene
entry.def: A double benzene and thiophene nucleus, C8H6S, analogous to naphthalene, and like it the base of a large series of derivatives.

entry.ety: Gr. � brimstone, sulphur
entry.def: Of or pertaining to sulphur; containing or resembling sulphur; specifically, designating certain of the thio compounds; as, the thionic acids. Cf. Dithionic Trithionic Tetrathionic, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. � brimstone, sulphur
entry.def: An artificial red or violet dyestuff consisting of a complex sulphur derivative of certain aromatic diamines, and obtained as a dark crystalline powder; -- called also phenylene violet.

entry.ety: Thionine + -ol
entry.def: A red or violet dyestuff having a greenish metallic luster. It is produced artificially, by the chemical dehydration of thionine, as a brown amorphous powder.
A beautiful fluorescent crystalline substance, intermediate in composition between thionol and thionine.

entry.ety: Thionic + -yl
entry.def: The hypothetical radical SO, regarded as an essential constituent of certain sulphurous compounds; as, thionyl chloride.

entry.ety: Thio- + phenyl + -ene
entry.def: A sulphur hydrocarbon, C4H4S, analogous to furfuran and benzene, and acting as the base of a large number of substances which closely resemble the corresponding aromatic derivatives.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, thiophene; specifically, designating a certain acid analogous to benzoic acid.

entry.ety: Thio- + phenol
entry.def: A colorless mobile liquid, C6H5.SH, of an offensive odor, and analogous to phenol; -- called also phenyl sulphydrate.

entry.ety: Abbreviated from thionaphthene
entry.def: A double thiophene nucleus, C6H4S2, analogous to thionaphthene, and the base of a large series of compounds.

entry.note: ☞ The sodium salt called in photography by the name sodium hyposulphite, being used as a solvent for the excess of unchanged silver chloride, bromide, and iodide on the sensitive plate.
entry.def: A salt of thiosulphuric acid; -- formerly called hyposulphite.

entry.ety: Thio- + sulphuric
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an unstable acid, H2S2O3, analogous to sulphuric acid, and formerly called hyposulphurous acid.

entry.ety: Thio- + toluene
entry.def: A colorless oily liquid, C4H3S.CH3, analogous to, and resembling, toluene; -- called also methyl thiophene.

entry.ety: Thiophene + xylene
entry.def: Any one of three possible metameric substances, which are dimethyl derivatives of thiophene, like the xylenes from benzene.

entry.cs: Third estate. In England, the commons, or the commonalty, who are represented in Parliament by the House of Commons. In France, the tiers état. See Tiers état. Third order R. C. Ch an order attached to a monastic order, and comprising men and women devoted to a rule of pious living, called the third rule, by a simple vow if they remain seculars, and by more solemn vows if they become regulars. See Tertiary n., 1. Third person Gram the person spoken of. See Person n., 7. Third sound. Mus See Third n., 3.
entry.ety: OE. thirde, AS. þridda, fr. þrī þreó, three; akin to D. derde third, G. dritte, Icel. þriði, Goth. þridja, L. tertius, Gr. tri`tos, Skr. tṛtīya. See Three, and cf. Riding a jurisdiction, Tierce

sn.def: Next after the second; coming after two others; -- the ordinal of three; as, the third hour in the day.
sn.q: Thethirdnight.

sn.def: Constituting or being one of three equal parts into which anything is divided; as, the third part of a day.

cs.cd: an interval of two tones.
an interval of a tone and a half.

sn.def: The quotient of a unit divided by three; one of three equal parts into which anything is divided.
The sixtieth part of a second of time.
The third tone of the scale; the mediant.
The third part of the estate of a deceased husband, which, by some local laws, the widow is entitled to enjoy during her life.

entry.def: An under constable.
The third part of the corn or grain growing on the ground at the tenant's death, due to the lord for a heriot, as within the manor of Turfat in Herefordshire.
In the third place.
A third part of the profits of fines and penalties imposed at the country court, which was among the perquisites enjoyed by the earl.

entries.entry: Third rail. Electric Railways The third rail used in the third-rail system. An electric railway using such a rail. Colloq

Third-rail system. Electric Railways A system in which a third rail is used for carrying the current for operating the motors, the rail being insulated from the ground and the current being taken off by means of contact brushes or other devices.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thirled; p. pr. & vb. n. Thirling
entry.ety: See Thrill
entry.def: To bore; to drill or thrill. See Thrill.
entry.q: That with a spear was thirled his breast bone.

entry.ety: Cf. Thrall
entry.def: The right which the owner of a mill possesses, by contract or law, to compel the tenants of a certain district, or of his sucken, to bring all their grain to his mill for grinding.

entry.ety: OE. thirst þurst, AS. þurst þyrst; akin to D. dorst, OS. thurst, G. durst, Icel. þorsti, Sw. & Dan. törst, Goth. þaúrstei thirst, þaúrsus dry, withered, þaúrsieþ mik I thirst, gaþaírsan to wither, L. torrere to parch, Gr. te`rsesqai to become dry, tesai`nein to dry up, Skr. tṛsh to thirst. √54. Cf. Torrid

sn.def: A sensation of dryness in the throat associated with a craving for liquids, produced by deprivation of drink, or by some other cause (as fear, excitement, etc.) which arrests the secretion of the pharyngeal mucous membrane; hence, the condition producing this sensation.
sn.q: Wherefore is this that thou hast brought us up out of Egypt, to kill us, and our children . . . with thirst?
With thirst, with cold, with hunger so confounded.

sn.def: Fig.: A want and eager desire after anything; a craving or longing; -- usually with for of, or after; as, the thirst for gold.
sn.q: Thirstof worldy good.
ThethirstI had of knowledge.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thirsted; p. pr. & vb. n. Thirsting
entry.ety: AS. þyrstan. See Thirst n.

sn.def: To feel thirst; to experience a painful or uneasy sensation of the throat or fauces, as for want of drink.
sn.q: The people thirsted there for water.

sn.def: To have a vehement desire.
sn.q: My soul thirsteth for . . . the living God.

entry.def: To have a thirst for.
entry.q: He seeks his keeper's flesh, and thirsts his blood.

entry.def: One who thirsts.
In a thirsty manner.
The state of being thirsty; thirst.
The throstle.

entry.ety: AS. �urstig. See Thirst n.

sn.def: Feeling thirst; having a painful or distressing sensation from want of drink; hence, having an eager desire.
sn.q: Give me, I pray thee, a little water to drink, for I am thirsty.

sn.def: Deficient in moisture; dry; parched.
sn.q: A dry and thirsty land, where no water is.
When in the sultry glebe I faint, Or on the thirsty mountain pant.

entry.ety: OE. threttene, AS. þreótēne þreótyne. See Three, and Ten, and cf. Thirty
entry.def: One more than twelve; ten and three; as, thirteen ounces or pounds.

sn.def: The number greater by one than twelve; the sum of ten and three; thirteen units or objects.
A symbol representing thirteen units, as 13 or xiii.

entry.ety: From Thirteen: cf. AS. þreóteóða

sn.def: Next in order after the twelfth; the third after the tenth; -- the ordinal of thirteen; as, the thirteenth day of the month.
Constituting or being one of thirteen equal parts into which anything is divided.
The quotient of a unit divided by thirteen; one of thirteen equal parts into which anything is divided.
The next in order after the twelfth.
The interval comprising an octave and a sixth.

entry.ety: From Thirty: cf. AS. þrītigōða

sn.def: Next in order after the twenty-ninth; the tenth after the twentieth; -- the ordinal of thirty; as, the thirtieth day of the month.
Constituting or being one of thirty equal parts into which anything is divided.

entry.def: The quotient of a unit divided by thirty; one of thirty equal parts.

entry.ety: OE. thritty, AS. þrītig þrittig; akin to D. dertig, G. dreissig, Icel. þrjātīu þrjātigi þrir teger, Goth. þreis tigjus, i.e., three tens. See Three, and Ten, and cf. Thirteen
entry.def: Being three times ten; consisting of one more than twenty-nine; twenty and ten; as, the month of June consists of thirty days.

entries.entry:
Thir"ty n.; pl.Thirties.
The sum of three tens, or twenty and ten; thirty units or objects.
A symbol expressing thirty, as 30, or XXX.

cs.cd: the thirty-second part of a whole note; a demi-semiquaver.

entry.def: Being one of thirty-two equal parts into which anything is divided.

entries.entry:
This ☞ This may be used as opposed or correlative to that, and sometimes as opposed to other or to a second this. See the Note under That, 1. ☞ This, like a every that, etc., may refer to a number, as of years, persons, etc., taken collectively or as a whole. �ĭs pron. & a.; pl.These �ēz. OE. this thes, AS. ðēs, masc., ðeós, fem., ðis, neut.; akin to OS. these, D. deze, G. dieser, OHG. diser deser, Icel. þessi; originally from the definite article + a particle -se -si; cf. Goth. sai behold. See The That, and cf. These Those
As a demonstrative pronoun, this denotes something that is present or near in place or time, or something just mentioned, or that is just about to be mentioned. When they heard this, they were pricked in their heart. But know this, that if the good man of the house had known in what watch the thief would come, he would have watched.
As an adjective, this has the same demonstrative force as the pronoun, but is followed by a noun; as, this book; this way to town.
This way and that wavering sails they bend. A body of this or that denomination is produced. Their judgment in this we may not, and in that we need not, follow. Consider the arguments which the author had to write this, or to design the other, before you arraign him. Thy crimes . . . soon by this or this will end.
This twenty years have I been with thee.. I have not wept this years; but now My mother comes afresh into my eyes.

entry.cs:
Blessed thistle
Carduus benedictus, so named because it was formerly considered an antidote to the bite of venomous creatures. Bull thistle
Cnicus lanceolatus, the common large thistle of neglected pastures. Canada thistle
Cnicus arvensis, a native of Europe, but introduced into the United States from Canada. Cotton thistle
Onopordon Acanthium. Fuller's thistle the teasel.
Globe thistle Melon thistle
etc. See under Globe Melon, etc. Pine thistle
Atractylis gummifera, a native of the Mediterranean region. A vicid gum resin flows from the involucre. Scotch thistle either the cotton thistle, or the musk thistle, or the spear thistle; -- all used national emblems of Scotland. Sow thistle
Sonchus oleraceus. Spear thistle. Same as Bull thistle. Star thistle a species of Centaurea. See Centaurea. Torch thistle a candelabra-shaped plant of the genus Cereus. See Cereus. Yellow thistle
Cincus horridulus.

cs.cd: the American goldfinch, or yellow-bird (Spinus tristis); -- so called on account of its feeding on the seeds of thistles. See Illust. under Goldfinch.
a handsomely colored American butterfly (Vanessa cardui) whose larva feeds upon thistles; -- called also painted lady.
the corn bunting (Emberiza militaria).
a gold coin of England of the reign of James I., worth four shillings.
the goldfinch; -- so called from its fondness for thistle seeds.
a funnel having a bulging body and flaring mouth.

entry.ety: OE. thistil, AS. þistel; akin to D. & G. distel, OHG. distila distil, Icel. þistill, Sw. tistel, Dan. tidsel; of uncertain origin
entry.def: Any one of several prickly composite plants, especially those of the genera Cnicus Craduus, and Onopordon. The name is often also applied to other prickly plants.

sn.def: Overgrown with thistles; as, thistly ground.
Fig.: Resembling a thistle or thistles; sharp; pricking.
sn.q: In such a world, so thorny, and where none Finds happiness unblighted, or, if found, Without some thistly sorrow at its side.

cs.cd: to this place and to that; one way and another.

entry.usage: Thither There. Thither properly denotes motion toward a place; there denotes rest in a place; as, I am going thither, and shall meet you there . But thither has now become obsolete, except in poetry, or a style purposely conformed to the past, and there is now used in both senses; as, I shall go there to-morrow; we shall go there together.
entry.ety: OE. thider, AS. ðider; akin to E. that; cf. Icel. þaðra there, Goth. þaþrō thence. See That, and The

sn.def: To that place; -- opposed to hither.
sn.q: This city is near; . . . O, let me escape thither.
Where I am, thither ye can not come.

sn.def: To that point, end, or result; as, the argument tended thither .
sn.syn: There.

sn.def: Being on the farther side from the person speaking; farther; -- a correlative of hither; as, on the thither side of the water.
Applied to time: On the thither side of, older than; of more years than. See Hither a.

entry.def: To that point; so far.
To ward that place; in that direction.
entry.q: They shall ask the way to Zion, with their faces thitherward.

entry.ety: Written also theesee, and thietsie

sn.def: The varnish tree of Burmah (Melanorrhœa usitatissima).
A black varnish obtained from the tree.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � pressure, fr. � to press
entry.def: Compression, especially constriction of vessels by an external cause.
The.
Those.
entry.q: This knowen tho that be to wives bound.

entry.ety: AS. þā
entry.def: Then.
entry.q: To do obsequies as was tho the guise.

entry.def: Though.

entry.cs: Thole pin. Same as Thole.
entry.ety: OE. thol, AS. þol; akin to D. dol, Icel. þollr a fir tree, a young fir, a tree, a thole

sn.def: A wooden or metal pin, set in the gunwale of a boat, to serve as a fulcrum for the oar in rowing.
The pin, or handle, of a scythe snath.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tholed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tholing
entry.ety: OE. þolen þolien, AS. þolian; akin to OS. tholōn, OHG. dolēn, G. geduld patience, dulden to endure, Icel. þola, Sw. tåla, Dan. taale, Goth. þulan, L. tolerate tulisse, to endure, bear, tollere to lift, bear, Gr. � to bear, Skr. tul to lift. √55. Cf. Tolerate
entry.def: To bear; to endure; to undergo.
entry.q: So much woe as I have with you tholed.
To thole the winter's steely dribble.

entry.def: To wait.
A member of the ancient church of Christians established on the Malabar coast of India, which some suppose to have been originally founded by the Apostle Thomas.

entries.entry: Thom"as phos"phateorThom"as slag . Same as Basic slag, above.
Thom"as proc"ess. Iron Metal Same as Basic process, above.

entry.def: The doctrine of Thomas Aquinas, esp. with respect to predestination and grace.
A follower of Thomas Aquinas. See Scotist.
A Thomæan.

entry.ety: Named after Dr. J. Thomsen of Copenhagen. See -lite
entry.def: A fluoride of aluminium, calcium, and sodium occurring with the cryolite of Greenland.

entries.entry: Thom"sen's dis*ease". From Thomsen, a physician of Sleswick Med An affection apparently congenital, consisting in tonic contraction and stiffness of the voluntary muscles occurring after a period of muscular inaction.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thomsonianism.

def2.def: A believer in Thomsonianism; one who practices Thomsonianism.

entry.def: An empirical system which assumes that the human body is composed of four elements, earth, air, fire, and water, and that vegetable medicines alone should be used; -- from the founder, Dr. Samuel Thomson, of Massachusetts.

entry.ety: From R. D. Thomson, of Glasgow
entry.def: A zeolitic mineral, occurring generally in masses of a radiated structure. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia, lime, and soda. Called also mesole, and comptonite.

entries.entry: Thomson process. After Elihu Thomson, American inventor A process of electric welding in which heat is developed by a large current passing through the metal.

cs.cd: the bearded seal. See the Note under Seal.

entry.ety: OE. thong þwong thwang, AS. þwang; akin to Icel. þvengr a thong, latchet. √57. Cf. Twinge
entry.def: A strap of leather; especially, one used for fastening anything.
entry.q: And nails for loosened spears, and thongs for shields, provide.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, the jacal + -oid
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a group of carnivores, including the wovels and the dogs.

entry.ety: Icel. þōrs. Cf. Thursday
entry.def: The god of thunder, and son of Odin.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � thorax + � pricking, from � to prick, stab
entry.def: The operation of puncturing the chest wall so as to let out liquids contained in the cavity of the chest.

cs.cd: the great trunk of the lymphatic vessels, situated on the ventral side of the vertebral column in the thorax and abdomen. See Illust. of Lacteal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. thoracique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the thorax, or chest.

entry.ety: Cf. F. thoracique
entry.def: One of a group of fishes having the ventral fins placed beneath the thorax or beneath the pectorial fins.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A division of cirripeds including those which have six thoracic segments, usually bearing six pairs of cirri. The common barnacles are examples.
Same as Stethometer.

entry.ety: Thorax + plasty
entry.def: A remodeling or reshaping of the thorax; especially, the operation of removing the ribs, so as to obliterate the pleural cavity in cases of empyema.

entry.ety: NL. See Thorax, and Ostracoid a.
entry.def: An extensive division of Crustacea, having a dorsal shield or carapec� ��niting all, or nearly all, of the thoracic somites to the head. It includes the crabs, lobsters, shrimps, and similar species.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, thorax + � to cut
entry.def: The operation of opening the pleural cavity by incision.

entry.ety: L. torus a couch, bed
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a bed.

entry.note: ☞ In mammals the thoracic cavity is completely separated from the abdominal by the diaphragm, but in birds and many reptiles the separation is incomplete, while in other reptiles, and in amphibians and fishes, there is no marked separation and no true thorax.
entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �

sn.def: The part of the trunk between the neck and the abdomen, containing that part of the body cavity the walls of which are supported by the dorsal vertebræ, the ribs, and the sternum, and which the heart and lungs are situated; the chest.

sd.def: The middle region of the body of an insect, or that region which bears the legs and wings. It is composed of three united somites, each of which is composed of several distinct parts. See Illust. in Appendix. and Illust. of Coleoptera.

The second, or middle, region of the body of a crustacean, arachnid, or other articulate animal. In the case of decapod Crustacea, some writers include under the term thorax only the three segments bearing the maxillipeds; others include also the five segments bearing the legs. See Illust. in Appendix.

sn.def: A breastplate, cuirass, or corselet; especially, the breastplate worn by the ancient Greeks.

entry.ety: NL. See Thorite
entry.def: A rare white earthy substance, consisting of the oxide of thorium; -- formerly called also thorina.
Of or pertaining to thorium; designating the compounds of thorium.

entry.ety: So called by Berzelius from the Scandinavian god Thor. See Thor
entry.def: A mineral of a brown to black color, or, as in the variety orangite, orange-yellow. It is essentially a silicate of thorium.

entry.ety: NL. See Thorite
entry.def: A metallic element found in certain rare minerals, as thorite, pyrochlore, monazite, etc., and isolated as an infusible gray metallic powder which burns in the air and forms thoria; -- formerly called also thorinum. Symbol Th. Atomic weight 232.0.

entry.cs: Thorn apple Bot Jamestown weed. Thorn broom Bot a shrub that produces thorns. Thorn hedge a hedge of thorn-bearing trees or bushes. Thorn devil. Zoöl See Moloch, 2. Thorn hopper Zoöl a tree hopper (Thelia cratægi) which lives on the thorn bush, apple tree, and allied trees.
entry.ety: AS. þorn; akin to OS. & OFries. thorn, D. doorn, G. dorn, Dan. torn, Sw. törne, Icel. þorn, Goth. þaúrnus; cf. Pol. tarn, Russ. tern' the blackthorn, ternie thorns, Skr. tṛṇa grass, blade of grass. √53

sn.def: A hard and sharp-pointed projection from a woody stem; usually, a branch so transformed; a spine.
Any shrub or small tree which bears thorns; especially, any species of the genus Cratægus, as the hawthorn, whitethorn, cockspur thorn.
Fig.: That which pricks or annoys as a thorn; anything troublesome; trouble; care.
sn.q: There was given to me a thorn in the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me.
The guilt of empire, all its thorns and cares, Be only mine.

sn.def: The name of the Anglo-Saxon letter �, capital form �. It was used to represent both of the sounds of English th, as in thin then. So called because it was the initial letter of thorn, a spine.

entry.def: To prick, as with a thorn.
entry.q: I am the only rose of all the stock That never thorn'd him.

sn.def: A European skate (Raia clavata) having thornlike spines on its back.
The large European spider crab or king crab (Maia squinado).

entry.def: Any one of several species of small, brilliantly colored American birds of the genus Rhamphomicron. They have a long, slender, sharp bill, and feed upon honey, insects, and the juice of the sugar cane.
A small South American bird (Anumbius anumbii) allied to the ovenbirds of the genus Furnarius). It builds a very large and complex nest of twigs and thorns in a bush or tree.

entry.ety: Thorn + -but as in halibut; cf. G. dornbutt
entry.def: The turbot.

cs.cd: any worm of the order Acanthocephala; -- called also thornhead.

entry.def: Having a head armed with thorns or spines.
Destitute of, or free from, thorns.
Set with thorns.
A beautiful South American humming bird (Gouldia Popelairii), having the six outer tail feathers long, slender, and pointed. The head is ornamented with a long, pointed crest.

cs.cd: rest-harrow.
a prickly plant of the genus Fagonia Fagonia Cretica, etc.).

entry.ety: Cf. AS. þorniht

sn.def: Full of thorns or spines; rough with thorns; spiny; as, a thorny wood; a thorny tree; a thorny crown.
Like a thorn or thorns; hence, figuratively, troublesome; vexatious; harassing; perplexing.
sn.q: Thethornypoint of bare distress.
The steep and thorny way to heaven.

entry.def: Thorough.

entry.ety: See Through
entry.def: Through.

sn.def: Passing through; as, thorough lights in a house.
Passing through or to the end; hence, complete; perfect; as, a thorough reformation; thorough work; a thorough translator; a thorough poet.
Thoroughly.
Through.

entry.def: A furrow between two ridges, to drain off the surface water.

entries.entry: Thor"ough bass`. Mus The representation of chords by figures placed under the base; figured bass; basso continuo; -- sometimes used as synonymous with harmony.

entry.def: A leather strap supporting the body of a carriage, and attached to springs, or serving as a spring. See Illust. of Chaise.
Bred from the best blood through a long line; pure-blooded; -- said of stock, as horses. Hence, having the characteristics of such breeding; mettlesome; courageous; of elegant form, or the like.

def2.def: A thoroughbred animal, especially a horse.

entry.ety: AS. þurhfaru

sn.def: A passage through; a passage from one street or opening to another; an unobstructed way open to the public; a public road; hence, a frequented street.
sn.q: A large and splendid thoroughfare.

sn.def: A passing or going through; passage.
sn.q: [Made] Hell and this world -- one realm, one continent Of easy thoroughfare.

sn.def: Going through, or to the end or bottom; very thorough; complete.
Going all lengths; extreme; thoroughplaced; -- less common in this sense.

entry.def: Provided with thorough lights or windows at opposite sides, as a room or building.
In a thorough manner; fully; entirely; completely.
The quality or state of being thorough; completeness.
Perfect in what is undertaken; complete; going all lengths; as, a thoroughplaced Tory or Whig.
entry.q: If she be a thoroughplaced impostor.

entry.def: A disease of the hock (sometimes of the knee) of a horse, caused by inflammation of the synovial membrane and a consequent excessive secretion of the synovial fluid; -- probably so called because there is usually an oval swelling on each side of the leg, appearing somewhat as if a pin had been thrust through.
Fully accomplished; thoroughplaced.
So as to go the whole length of any business; fully; completely.
entry.q: Preservance alone can carry us thoroughstitch.

entry.def: An umbelliferous plant (Bupleurum rotundifolium) with perfoliate leaves.
Thoroughwort.
Same as Boneset.
Through.
entry.q: Thorowbramble, pits, and floods.

entry.def: Thorough.

entry.ety: AS. þorp; akin to OS. & OFries. thorp, D. dorp, G. dorf, Icel. þorp, Dan. torp, Sw. torp a cottage, a little farm, Goth. þaúrp a field, and probably to Lith. troba a building, a house, W. tref a hamlet, Ir. treabh a farmed village, a tribe, clan, Gael. treabhair houses, and perhaps to L. turba a crowd, mult. Cf. Dorp
entry.def: A group of houses in the country; a small village; a hamlet; a dorp; -- now chiefly occurring in names of places and persons; as, Althorp, Mablethorpe .
entry.q: Within a littlethorpI staid.
Then thorpe and byre arose in fire.

entry.ety: OE. þos þas, AS. ðās, nom. and acc. pl. of ðēs this. See This, and cf. These
entry.def: The plural of that. See That.

sn.def: The god of eloquence and letters among the ancient Egyptians, and supposed to be the inventor of writing and philosophy. He corresponded to the Mercury of the Romans, and was usually represented as a human figure with the head of an ibis or a lamb.
The Egyptian sacred baboon.

entry.note: ☞ “In Old English, generally, thou is the language of a lord to a servant, of an equal to an equal, and expresses also companionship, love, permission, defiance, scorn, threatening: whilst ye is the language of a servant to a lord, and of compliment, and further expresses honor, submission, or entreaty.”
☞ Thou is now sometimes used by the Friends, or Quakers, in familiar discourse, though most of them corruptly say thee instead of thou.
entry.nmorph: Sing.: nom. Thou; poss. Thy �ī or Thine �īn; obj. Thee �ē. Pl.: nom. You y�; poss. Your y�r or Yours y�rz; obj. You
entry.ety: OE. thou þu, AS. ðū ðu; akin to OS. & OFries. thu, G., Dan. & Sw. du, Icel. þū, Goth. þu, Russ. tui, Ir. & Gael. tu, W. ti, L. tu, Gr. sy`, Dor. ty` , Skr. tvam. √185. Cf. Thee Thine Te Deum
entry.def: The second personal pronoun, in the singular number, denoting the person addressed; thyself; the pronoun which is used in addressing persons in the solemn or poetical style.
entry.q: Art thou he that should come?

entry.def: To address as thou, esp. to do so in order to treat with insolent familiarity or contempt.
entry.q: If thou thouest him some thrice, it shall not be amiss.

entry.def: To use the words thou and thee in discourse after the manner of the Friends.

entry.note: ☞ It is compounded with all in although. See Although.

cs.cd: as if.

entry.ety: OE. thogh þah, AS. ðeáh ðǣh ðēh; akin to OS. thōh, OFries. thach, D. & G. doch but, yet, OHG. doh but, yet though, Icel. þō yet, nevertheless, Sw. dock, Dan. dog, Goth. þáuh þáu, than, or, yet; of uncertain origin. √184
entry.def: Granting, admitting, or supposing that; notwithstanding that; if.
entry.q: Though he slay me, yet will I trust in him.
Not that I so affirm, though so it seem.
In the vine were three branches; and it was as though it budded.

entry.def: However; nevertheless; notwithstanding; -- used in familiar language, and in the middle or at the end of a sentence.
entry.q: I would not be as sick though for his place.
A good cause would do well, though.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Think.

entry.note: ☞ Thought, in philosophical usage now somewhat current, denotes the capacity for, or the exercise of, the very highest intellectual functions, especially those usually comprehended under judgment.
entry.ety: OE. þoght þouht, AS. þōht, geþōht, fr. þencean to think; akin to D. gedachte thought, MHG. dāht, gedāht, Icel. þōttr þōtti. See Think

sn.def: The act of thinking; the exercise of the mind in any of its higher forms; reflection; cogitation.
sn.q: Thought can not be superadded to matter, so as in any sense to render it true that matter can become cogitative.

sn.def: Meditation; serious consideration.
sn.q: Pride, of all others the most dangerous fault, Proceeds from want of sense or want of thought.

sn.def: That which is thought; an idea; a mental conception, whether an opinion, judgment, fancy, purpose, or intention.
sn.q: Thus Bethel spoke, who always speaks his thought.
Why do you keep alone, . . . Using those thoughts which should indeed have died With them they think on?
Thoughts come crowding in so fast upon me, that my only difficulty is to choose or to reject.
All their thoughts are against me for evil.

sn.def: Solicitude; anxious care; concern.
sn.q: Hawis was put in trouble, and died with thought and anguish before his business came to an end.
Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink.

sn.def: A small degree or quantity; a trifle; as, a thought longer; a thought better.
sn.q: If the hair were a thought browner.
This [faculty], to which I gave the name of the “elaborative faculty,” -- the faculty of relations or comparison, -- constitutes what is properly denominated thought.
sn.syn: Idea; conception; imagination; fancy; conceit; notion; supposition; reflection; consideration; meditation; contemplation; cogitation; deliberation.

entry.usage: Thoughtful Considerate. He who is habitually thoughtful rarely neglects his duty or his true interest; he who is considerate pauses to reflect and guard himself against error. One who is not thoughtful by nature, if he can be made considerate, will usually be guarded against serious mistakes. “He who is thoughtful does not forget his duty; he who is considerate pauses, and considers properly what is his duty. It is a recommendation to a subordinate person to be thoughtful in doing what is wished of him; it is the recommendation of a confidential person to be considerate, as he has often to judge according to his own discretion. Crabb.

sn.def: Full of thought; employed in meditation; contemplative; as, a man of thoughtful mind.
sn.q: War, horrid war, your thoughtful walks invades.

sn.def: Attentive; careful; exercising the judgment; having the mind directed to an object; as, thoughtful of gain; thoughtful in seeking truth.
Anxious; solicitous; concerned.
sn.q: Around her crowd distrust, and doubt, and fear, And thoughtful foresight, and tormenting care.
sn.syn: Considerate; deliberate; contemplative; attentive; careful; wary; circumspect; reflective; discreet.

sn.def: Lacking thought; careless; inconsiderate; rash; as, a thoughtless person, or act.
Giddy; gay; dissipated.
Deficient in reasoning power; stupid; dull.
sn.q: Thoughtless as monarch oaks that shade the plain.

entries.entry: Thought transference. Telepathy.

entry.note: ☞ The word thousand often takes a plural form. See the Note under Hundred.
entry.ety: OE. þousend þusend, AS. þūsend; akin to OS. thūsundig thūsind, OFries. thusend, D. duizend, G. tausend, OHG. tūsunt dūsunt, Icel. þūsund þūshund, Sw. tusen Dan. tusind, Goth. þūsundi, Lith. tukstantis, Russ. tuisiacha; of uncertain origin

sn.def: The number of ten hundred; a collection or sum consisting of ten times one hundred units or objects.
Hence, indefinitely, a great number.
sn.q: A thousand shall fall at thy side, and ten thousand at thy right hand.

sn.def: A symbol representing one thousand units; as, 1,000, M or CI�.
Consisting of ten hundred; being ten times one hundred.
Hence, consisting of a great number indefinitely.
sn.q: Perplexed with athousandcares.

entry.def: Multiplied by a thousand.

entries.entry: Thou"sand legs`. Zoöl A millepid, or galleyworm; -- called also thousand-legged worm.

sn.def: Next in order after nine hundred and ninty-nine; coming last of a thousand successive individuals or units; -- the ordinal of thousand; as, the thousandth part of a thing.
Constituting, or being one of, a thousand equal parts into which anything is divided; the tenth of a hundredth.
Occurring as being one of, or the last one of, a very great number; very small; minute; -- used hyperbolically; as, to do a thing for the thousandth time.

entry.def: The quotient of a unit divided by a thousand; one of a thousand equal parts into which a unit is divided.

entry.ety: See Thole
entry.def: A thole pin.
A rowlock.
entry.q: I would sit impatiently thinking with what an unusual amount of noise the oars worked in the thowels.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thrace, or its people.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Thrace.

entry.def: To load or burden; as, to thrack a man with property.
Metal still in the mine.

entry.ety: Icel. �rældōmr. See Thrall, and -dom
entry.def: The condition of a thrall; slavery; bondage; state of servitude.
entry.q: Women are born to thraldom and penance And to be under man's governance.
He shall rule, and she in thraldom live.

entry.ety: OE. thral þral, Icel. þræll, perhaps through AS. þrǣl; akin to Sw. träl, Dan. træl, and probably to AS. þrægian to run, Goth. þragjan, Gr. tre`chein; cf. OHG. dregil drigil, a servant

sn.def: A slave; a bondman.
sn.q: Gurth, the born thrall of Cedric.

sn.def: Slavery; bondage; servitude; thraldom.
sn.q: He still in thrall Of all-subdoing sleep.

sn.def: A shelf; a stand for barrels, etc.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a thrall; in the condition of a thrall; bond; enslaved.
entry.q: The fiend that would make you thrall and bond.

entry.def: To enslave.
Thraldom.
Having no thralls.
Not enslaved; not subject to bonds.
Resembling a thrall, or his condition, feelings, or the like; slavish.
entry.q: Servile and thrall-like fear.

entry.ety: Gr. �, from � a bench, form, especially the topmost of the three benches in a trireme
entry.def: One of the rowers on the topmost of the three benches in a trireme.

entry.ety: Also thropple, corrupted fr. throttle
entry.def: Windpipe; throttle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thrashed; p. pr. & vb. n. Thrashing
entry.ety: OE. þreschen þreshen, to beat, AS. þerscan þrescan; akin to D. dorschen, OD. derschen, G. dreschen, OHG. dreskan, Icel. þreskja, Sw. tröska, Dan. tærske, Goth. þriskan, Lith. traszketi to rattle, Russ. treskate to burst, crackle, tresk' a crash, OSlav. troska a stroke of lighting. Cf. Thresh

sn.def: To beat out grain from, as straw or husks; to beat the straw or husk of (grain) with a flail; to beat off, as the kernels of grain; as, to thrash wheat, rye, or oats; to thrash over the old straw.
sn.q: The wheat was reaped, thrashed, and winnowed by machines.

sn.def: To beat soundly, as with a stick or whip; to drub.
To practice thrashing grain or the like; to perform the business of beating grain from straw; as, a man who thrashes well.
Hence, to labor; to toil; also, to move violently.
sn.q: I rather would be Mævius, thrash for rhymes, Like his, the scorn and scandal of the times.

entry.def: An instrument to thrash with; a flail.

entry.cs: Sage thrasher. Zoöl See under Sage. Thrasher whale Zoöl the common killer of the Atlantic.

sn.def: One who, or that which, thrashes grain; a thrashing machine.

A large and voracious shark (Alopias vulpes), remarkable for the great length of the upper lobe of its tail, with which it beats, or thrashes, its prey. It is found both upon the American and the European coasts. Called also fox shark sea ape sea fox slasher swingle-tail, and thrasher shark.
A name given to the brown thrush and other allied species. See Brown thrush.

cs.cd: a floor or area on which grain is beaten out.
a machine for separating grain from the straw.

entry.def: a. & n. from Thrash v.

entry.ety: From Thrso, the name of a braggart soldier in Terence's “Eunuch:” cf. L. Thrasonianus
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Thraso; like, or becoming to, Thraso; bragging; boastful; vainglorious.
entry.q: Cæsar's thrasonical brag of 'I came, saw, and overcame.'

entry.vmorph: imp. Thraste; p. p. Thrast
entry.def: To thrust.

entry.ety: OE. þrave þreve, Icel. þrefi; akin to Dan. trave; cf. Icel. þrīfa to grasp

sn.def: Twenty-four (in some places, twelve) sheaves of wheat; a shock, or stook.
The number of two dozen; also, an indefinite number; a bunch; a company; a throng.
sn.q: The worst of athrave.
He sends forth thraves of ballads to the sale.

entry.def: See Throse.

cs.cd: the fine white filaments which are seen floating in the air in summer, the production of spiders; gossamer.
the good and bad together.
a lasso cell. See under Lasso.
the gizzard shad. See under Gizzard.
lace made of linen thread.
a game in which children stand in a row, joining hands, and in which the outer one, still holding his neighbor, runs between the others; -- called also thread the needle.

entry.ety: OE. threed þred, AS. þrǣd; akin to D. draad, G. draht wire, thread, OHG. drāt, Icel. þrāðr a thread, Sw. tråd, Dan. traad, and AS. þrāwan to twist. See Throw, and cf. Third

sn.def: A very small twist of flax, wool, cotton, silk, or other fibrous substance, drawn out to considerable length; a compound cord consisting of two or more single yarns doubled, or joined together, and twisted; also, one fiber of a cord composed of multiple fibers.
A filament of any substance, as of glass, gold or silver; a filamentous part of an object, such as a flower; a component fiber of any or of any fibrous substance, as of bark.
The prominent part of the spiral of a screw or nut; the rib. See Screw n., 1.
Something continued in a long course or tenor; a recurrent theme or related sequence of events in a larger story; as the thread of a story, or of life, or of a discourse.
Fig.: Composition; quality; fineness.
sn.q: A neat courtier, Of a most elegant thread.

sn.def: A related sequence of instructions or actions within a program that runs at least in part independent of other actions within the program; -- such threads are capable of being executed only in oprating systems permittnig multitasking.

A sequence of messages posted to an on-line newsgroup or discussion group, dealing with the same topic; -- messages in such a thread typically refer to a previous posting, thus allowing their identification as part of the thread. Some news-reading programs allow a user to follow a single such thread independent of the other postings to that newsgroup.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Threaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Threading

sn.def: To pass a thread through the eye of; as, to thread a needle.
To pass or pierce through as a narrow way; also, to effect or make, as one's way, through or between obstacles; to thrid.
sn.q: Heavy trading ships . . . threading the Bosphorus.
They would not thread the gates.

sn.def: To form a thread, or spiral rib, on or in; as, to thread a screw or nut.
Worn to the naked thread; having the nap worn off; threadbare clothes.
sn.q: Athreadbarecope.

sn.def: Fig.: Worn out; as, a threadbare subject; stale topics and threadbare quotations.

entry.def: The state of being threadbare.
Made of thread; as, threaden sails; a threaden fillet.

sn.def: A device for assisting in threading a needle.
A tool or machine for forming a thread on a screw or in a nut.

entry.def: Any one of several species of fishes belonging to Polynemus and allied genera. They have numerous long pectoral filaments.
The cutlass fish.
A carangoid fish (Caranx gallus, or Caranx crinitus) having the anterior rays of the soft dorsal and anal fins prolonged in the form of long threads.
Quality of being thready.
Clothes; clothing; as, he was wearing his new threads at the party.
Having the form of a thread; filiform.
Any long, slender nematode worm, especially the pinworm and filaria.

sn.def: Like thread or filaments; slender; as, the thready roots of a shrub.
Containing, or consisting of, thread.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Threaped; p. pr. & vb. n. Threaping
entry.ety: AS. þreápian to reprove

sn.def: To call; to name.
To maintain obstinately against denial or contradiction; also, to contend or argue against (another) with obstinacy; to chide; as, he threaped me down that it was so.
To beat, or thrash.
To cozen, or cheat.

entry.def: To contend obstinately; to be pertinacious.
entry.q: It's not for a man with a woman to threap.

entry.def: An obstinate decision or determination; a pertinacious affirmation.
entry.q: He was taken a threap that he would have it finished before the year was done.

entry.ety: AS. þreát, akin to āþreótan to vex, G. verdriessen, OHG. irdriozan, Icel. þrjōta to fail, want, lack, Goth. usþriutan to vex, to trouble, Russ. trudite to impose a task, irritate, vex, L. trudere to push. Cf. Abstruse Intrude Obstrude Protrude
entry.def: The expression of an intention to inflict evil or injury on another; the declaration of an evil, loss, or pain to come; menace; threatening; denunciation.
entry.q: There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats.

entry.ety: OE. þreten, AS. þreátian. See Threat n.
entry.def: To threaten.
entry.q: Of all his threating reck not a mite.
Our dreaded admiral from far they threat.

entry.usage: Threaten Menace. Threaten is Anglo-Saxon, and menace is Latin. As often happens, the former is the more familiar term; the latter is more employed in formal style. We are threatened with a drought; the country is menaced with war.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Threatened; p. pr. & vb. n. Threatening
entry.ety: OE. þretenen. See Threat v. t.

sn.def: To utter threats against; to menace; to inspire with apprehension; to alarm, or attempt to alarm, as with the promise of something evil or disagreeable; to warn.
sn.q: Let us straitly threaten them, that they speak henceforth to no man in this name.

sn.def: To exhibit the appearance of (something evil or unpleasant) as approaching; to indicate as impending; to announce the conditional infliction of; as, to threaten war; to threaten death.
sn.q: The skies look grimly And threaten present blusters.
sn.syn: To menace.
sn.q: By turns put on the suppliant and the lord:Threatened this moment, and the next implored.
Of the sharp ax Regardless, that o'er his devoted head Hangs menacing.

entry.def: To use threats, or menaces; also, to have a threatening appearance.
entry.q: Though the seas threaten, they are merciful.

entry.def: One who threatens.

cs.cd: letters containing threats, especially those designed to extort money, or to obtain other property, by menaces; blackmailing letters.

entry.def: a. & n. from Threaten v.
Full of threats; having a menacing appearance.
Same as Thrave.

entry.note: ☞ Three is often joined with other words, forming compounds signifying divided into composed of, or containing three parts portions organs, or the like; as, three-branched, three-capsuled, three-celled, three-cleft, three-edged, three-foot, three-footed, three-forked, three-grained, three-headed, three-legged, three-mouthed, three-nooked, three-petaled, three-pronged, three-ribbed, three-seeded, three-stringed, three-toed, and the like.
entry.ety: OE. þre þreo þri, AS. þrī, masc., þreó, fem. and neut.; akin to OFries. thre, OS. thria threa, D. drie, G. drei, OHG. drī, Icel. þrīr, Dan. & Sw. tre, Goth. þreis, Lith. trys, Ir., Gael. & W. tri, Russ. tri, L. tres, Gr. trei^s, Skr. tri. √301. Cf. 3d Drilling Tern a. Third Thirteen Thirty Tierce Trey Tri- Triad Trinity Tripod
entry.def: One more than two; two and one.
entry.q: I offer theethreethings.
Three solemn aisles approach the shrine.

entry.cs: Rule of three. Arith See under Rule n.

sn.def: The number greater by a unit than two; three units or objects.
A symbol representing three units, as 3 or iii.

entry.def: Having or consisting of three coats; -- applied to plastering which consists of pricking-up, floating, and a finishing coat; or, as called in the United States, a scratch coat, browning, and finishing coat.
Designating, or pert. to, a photomechanical process employing printings in three colors, as red, yellow, and blue.

sn.def: Having three corners, or angles; as, a three-cornered hat.
Having three prominent longitudinal angles; as, a three-cornered stem.

entry.def: A vessel of war carrying guns on three decks.
Bearing three flowers together, or only three flowers.

entry.ety: OE. þreofald; cf. AS. þrīfeald
entry.def: Consisting of three, or thrice repeated; triple; as, threefold justice.
entry.q: A threefold cord is not quickly broken.

entry.def: Said of games or contests where three persons play against each other, or two against one; as, a three-handed game of cards.

entry.cs: Three-leaved nightshade. See Trillium.
entry.def: Producing three leaves; as, three-leaved nightshade.
Consisting of three distinct leaflets; having the leaflets arranged in threes.

cs.cd: a leaf divided into three parts, the sinuses extending not more than half way to the middle, and either the parts of the sinuses being rounded.

entry.def: Having three lobes.

cs.cd: a leaf having three distinct and prominent ribs, or nerves, extending from the base.

entry.def: Having three nerves.

cs.cd: a leaf divided into three parts down to the base, but not entirely separate.

entry.def: Divided into, or consisting of, three parts; tripartite.
A small silver coin of three times the value of a penny.
Costing or worth three pence; hence, worth but little; poor; mean.
An old name for the finest and most costly kind of velvet, having a fine, thick pile.
entry.q: I have served Prince Florizel and in my time wore three-pile.

sn.def: Having the quality of three-pile; best; most costly.
sn.q: Thou art good velvet; thou 'rt three-piled piece.

sn.def: Fig.: Extravagant; exaggerated; high-flown.
sn.q: Three-piledhyperboles.

sn.def: Accustomed to wearing three-pile; hence, of high rank, or wealth.
sn.q: Three-piledpeople.

entry.def: Consisting of three distinct webs inwrought together in weaving, as cloth or carpeting; having three strands; threefold.
Having three acute or setigerous points; tricuspidate.
Having three ports; specif.: Designating a type of two-cycle internal-combustion engine in which the mixture enters the crank case through a port uncovered by the piston near the end of its stroke.

cs.cd: a portrait showing the figure to the hips only.

entry.def: Measuring thirty inches by twenty-five; -- said of portraitures.
Thrice twenty; sixty.
Having three sides, especially three plane sides; as, a three-sided stem, leaf, petiole, peduncle, scape, or pericarp.
Having a cross section in the form of an equilateral triangle; -- said especially of a kind of file.

entries.entry: Three"-torque` system of control. Aëronautics Any system of rudders by which the pilot can exert a turning moment about each of the three rectangular axes of an aëroplane or airship.

entry.def: Consisting of, or having, three valves; opening with three valves; as, a three-valved pericarp.
Connected with, or serving to connect, three channels or pipes; as, a three-way cock or valve.

entry.ety: L. threnus, Gr. �. Cf. Drone
entry.def: Lamentation; threnody; a dirge.
entry.q: The threns . . . of the prophet Jeremiah.

entry.ety: Gr. �. See Threne
entry.def: Pertaining to a threne; sorrowful; mournful.
A threne, or threnody; a dirge; a funeral song.
One who composes, delivers, or utters, a threnode, or threnody.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � a dirge + � a song. See Threne, and Ode
entry.def: A song of lamentation; a threnode.

entry.ety: See Threap
entry.def: To call; to term.
entry.q: Luna silver wethrepe.

entry.ety: Gr. � nourishment + -logy
entry.def: The doctrine of nutrition; a treatise on nutrition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Threshed; p. pr. & vb. n. Threshing
entry.def: Same as Thrash.
entry.q: He would thresh, and thereto dike and delve.

entry.def: Same as Thrasher.
Threshold.

entry.ety: OE. threswold þreshwold, AS. þrescwald þerscwald þerscold þrescold, fr. þrescan þerscan, to thresh; akin to Icel. þreskjöde þröskuldr, Sw. tröskel, Dan. tærskel. See Thrash

sn.def: The plank, stone, or piece of timber, which lies under a door, especially of a dwelling house, church, temple, or the like; the doorsill; hence, entrance; gate; door.
Fig.: The place or point of entering or beginning, entrance; outset; as, the threshold of life.

entry.def: Threshold.

entry.vmorph: imp. Threste; p. p. Threst
entry.def: To thrust.
Thirteen.
Thirty.
imp. of Throw.
Triple; treble; threefold.

entry.note: ☞ Thrice is often used, generally with an intensive force, to form compounds which are usually of obvious meaning; as, in thrice-blessed, thrice-favored, thrice-hallowed, thrice-happy, thrice-told, and the like.
entry.ety: OE. thries; thrie thrice (AS. þriga þriwa) + -s, the adverbal suffix. See Three, and -wards

sn.def: Three times.
sn.q: Thricein vain.
Verily I say unto thee. That this night, before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.

sn.def: In a threefold manner or degree; repeatedly; very.
sn.q: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you To pardon me.
Thrice is he armed that hath his quarrel just.

entry.def: The missel thrush.
Third.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thridded; p. pr. & vb. n. Thridding
entry.ety: A variant of thread

sn.def: To pass through in the manner of a thread or a needle; to make or find a course through; to thread.
sn.q: Some thrid the mazy ringlets of her hair.
And now he thrids the bramble bush.
I began To thrid the musky-circled mazes.

sn.def: To make or effect (a way or course) through something; as, to thrid one's way through a wood.

entry.def: Thread; continuous line.
entry.q: I resume the thrid of my discourse.

entry.def: See Thryfallow, and Trifallow.

cs.cd: Armeria vulgaris; -- also called sea pink.

entry.ety: Icel. þrift. See Thrive

sn.def: A thriving state; good husbandry; economical management in regard to property; frugality.
sn.q: The rest, . . . willing to fall to thrift, prove very good husbands.

sn.def: Success and advance in the acquisition of property; increase of worldly goods; gain; prosperity.
sn.q: Yourthriftis gone full clean.
I have a mind presages me such thrift.

sn.def: Vigorous growth, as of a plant.
One of several species of flowering plants of the genera Statice and Armeria.
sn.syn: Frugality; economy; prosperity; gain; profit.

sn.def: In a thrifty manner.
Carefully; properly; becomingly.
sn.q: A young clerk . . . in Latin thriftily them gret [greeted].

entry.def: The quality or state of being thrifty; thrift.
Without thrift; not prudent or prosperous in money affairs.

sn.def: Given to, or evincing, thrift; characterized by economy and good menegement of property; sparing; frugal.
sn.q: Her chaffer was so thrifty and so new.
I am glad he hath so much youth and vigor left, of which he hath not been thrifty.

sn.def: Thriving by industry and frugality; prosperous in the acquisition of worldly goods; increasing in wealth; as, a thrifty farmer or mechanic.
Growing rapidly or vigorously; thriving; as, a thrifty plant or colt.
Secured by thrift; well husbanded.
sn.q: I have five hundred crowns, The thrifty hire I saved under your father.

sn.def: Well appearing; looking or being in good condition; becoming.
sn.q: I sit at home, I have no thrifty cloth.
sn.syn: Frugal; sparing; economical; saving; careful.

entry.ety: See Trill
entry.def: A warbling; a trill.

entry.ety: AS. þyrel an aperture. See Thrill v. t.
entry.def: A breathing place or hole; a nostril, as of a bird.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thrilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Thrilling
entry.ety: OE. thrillen þirlen þurlen, to pierce; all probably fr. AS. þyrlian þyrelian, Fr. þyrel pierced; as a noun, a hole, fr. þurh through; probably akin to D. drillen to drill, to bore. √53. See Through, and cf. Drill to bore, Nostril Trill to trickle

sn.def: To perforate by a pointed instrument; to bore; to transfix; to drill.
sn.q: He pierced through his chafed chest With thrilling point of deadly iron brand.

sn.def: Hence, to affect, as if by something that pierces or pricks; to cause to have a shivering, throbbing, tingling, or exquisite sensation; to pierce; to penetrate.
sn.q: To bathe in flery floods, or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice.
Vivid and picturesque turns of expression which thrill the �eader with sudden delight.
The cruel word her tender heart so thrilled, That sudden cold did run through every vein.

sn.def: To hurl; to throw; to cast.
sn.q: I'll thrill my javelin.

sn.def: To pierce, as something sharp; to penetrate; especially, to cause a tingling sensation that runs through the system with a slight shivering; as, a sharp sound thrills through the whole frame.
sn.q: I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins.

sn.def: To feel a sharp, shivering, tingling, or exquisite sensation, running through the body.
sn.q: To seek sweet safety out In vaults and prisons, and to thrill and shake.

sn.def: A drill. See 3d Drill, 1.
A sensation as of being thrilled; a tremulous excitement; as, a thrill of horror; a thrill of joy.

entry.def: Piercing; sharp; thrilling.
entry.q: Histhrillantspear.

entry.def: Causing a thrill; causing tremulous excitement; deeply moving; as, a thrilling romance.

entry.ety: AS. þringan. See Throng
entry.def: To press, crowd, or throng.

entry.note: ☞ The term is also popularly applied to various other small injurious insects.
entry.ety: L., a woodworm, Gr. �
entry.def: Any one of numerous small species of Thysanoptera, especially those which attack useful plants, as the grain thrips (Thrips cerealium).
Thrist.
Thirteen.

entry.vmorph: imp. Throve thrōv or Thrived thrīvd; p. p. Thrived or Thriven thrĭv"'n; p. pr. & vb. n. Thriving
entry.ety: OE. þriven, Icel. þrīfask; probably originally, to grasp for one's self, from þrīfa to grasp; akin to Dan. trives to thrive, Sw. trifvas. Cf. Thrift

sn.def: To prosper by industry, economy, and good management of property; to increase in goods and estate; as, a farmer thrives by good husbandry.
sn.q: Diligence and humility is the way to thrive in the riches of the understanding, as well as in gold.

sn.def: To prosper in any business; to have increase or success.
sn.q: They by vicesthrive.
O son, why sit we here, each other viewing Idly, while Satan, our great author, thrives?
And so she throve and prospered.

sn.def: To increase in bulk or stature; to grow vigorously or luxuriantly, as a plant; to flourish; as, young cattle thrive in rich pastures; trees thrive in a good soil.

entry.def: p. p. of Thrive.
One who thrives, or prospers.
In a thriving manner.
The quality or condition of one who thrives; prosperity; growth; increase.

entries.entry: Thro'. A contraction of Through.

cs.cd: brails attached to the gaff close to the mast.
halyards that raise the throat of the gaff.
the windpipe, or trachea.
cs.col: To give one the lie in his throat
cs.cd: to accuse one pointedly of lying abominably.
to lie flatly or abominably.

entry.ety: OE. throte, AS. þrote þrotu; akin to OHG. drozza, G. drossel; cf. OFries. & D. stort. Cf. Throttle

sd.def: The part of the neck in front of, or ventral to, the vertebral column.
Hence, the passage through it to the stomach and lungs; the pharynx; -- sometimes restricted to the fauces.
sd.q: I can vent clamor from my throat.

sn.def: A contracted portion of a vessel, or of a passage way; as, the throat of a pitcher or vase.
The part of a chimney between the gathering, or portion of the funnel which contracts in ascending, and the flue.

sd.def: The upper fore corner of a boom-and-gaff sail, or of a staysail.
That end of a gaff which is next the mast.
The angle where the arm of an anchor is joined to the shank.

sn.def: The inside of a timber knee.
The orifice of a tubular organ; the outer end of the tube of a monopetalous corolla; the faux, or fauces.
To utter in the throat; to mutter; as, to throat threats.
To mow, as beans, in a direction against their bending.

entry.def: Same as Throatlatch.

entry.ety: Throat + boll a ball
entry.def: The Adam's apple in the neck.
entry.q: By the throatboll he caught Aleyn.

entry.def: A drip, or drip molding.
A strap of a bridle, halter, or the like, passing under a horse's throat.
A plant (Campanula Trachelium) formerly considered a remedy for sore throats because of its throat-shaped corolla.
Guttural; hoarse; having a guttural voice.
entry.q: Hard,throatywords.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Throbbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Throbbing
entry.ety: OE. þrobben; of uncertain origin; cf. Russ. trepete a trembling, and E. trepidation
entry.def: To beat, or pulsate, with more than usual force or rapidity; to beat in consequence of agitation; to palpitate; -- said of the heart, pulse, etc.
entry.q: My heartThrobs to know one thing.
Here may his head lie on my throbbing breast.

entry.def: A beat, or strong pulsation, as of the heart and arteries; a violent beating; a papitation:
entry.q: The impatient throbs and longings of a soul That pants and reaches after distant good.

entry.ety: Prov. E. throdden throddle, fat, thriving; cf. Icel. throask to grow
entry.def: To grow; to thrive.

entry.ety: OE. þrowe þrawe, AS. þreá a threatening, oppression, suffering, perhaps influenced by Icel. þrā a throe, a pang, a longing; cf. AS. þreowian to suffer

sn.def: Extreme pain; violent pang; anguish; agony; especially, one of the pangs of travail in childbirth, or purturition.
sn.q: Prodogious motion felt, and rueful throes.

sn.def: A tool for splitting wood into shingles; a frow.

entry.def: To struggle in extreme pain; to be in agony; to agonize.
To put in agony.

entry.ety: See Thrombus
entry.def: The enzyme which converts fibrinogen into fibrin.

entry.ety: NL. See Thrombus
entry.def: The obstruction of a blood vessel by a clot formed at the site of obstruction; -- distinguished from embolism, which is produced by a clot or foreign body brought from a distance.

entries.entry: Throm"bus Throm"bus n.; pl.Thrombi #. NL., fr. Gr. � a lump, a clot of blood Med A clot of blood formed of a passage of a vessel and remaining at the site of coagulation. A tumor produced by the escape of blood into the subcutaneous cellular tissue.

entry.ety: OE. trone, F. trône, L. thronus, Gr. �; cf. � a bench, � a footstool, � to set one's self, to sit, Skr. dharaṇa supporting, dhṛ to hold fast, carry, and E. firm, a

sn.def: A chair of state, commonly a royal seat, but sometimes the seat of a prince, bishop, or other high dignitary.
sn.q: The noble king is set up in his throne.
High on a throne of royal state.

sn.def: Hence, sovereign power and dignity; also, the one who occupies a throne, or is invested with sovereign authority; an exalted or dignified personage.
sn.q: Only in the throne will I be greater than thou.
To mold a mighty state's decrees, And shape the whisper of the throne.

sn.def: A high order of angels in the celestial hierarchy; -- a meaning given by the schoolmen.
sn.q: Great Sire! whom thrones celestial ceaseless sing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Throned; p. pr. & vb. n. Throning

sn.def: To place on a royal seat; to enthrone.
To place in an elevated position; to give sovereignty or dominion to; to exalt.
sn.q: True image of the Father, whether throned In the bosom of bliss, and light of light.

entry.def: To be in, or sit upon, a throne; to be placed as if upon a throne.
Having no throne.

entry.usage: Any great number of persons form a multitude; a throng is a large number of persons who are gathered or are moving together in a collective body; a crowd is composed of a large or small number of persons who press together so as to bring their bodies into immediate or inconvenient contact. A dispersed multitude; the throngs in the streets of a city; the crowd at a fair or a street fight. But these distinctions are not carefully observed.
entry.ety: OE. þrong þrang, AS. geþrang, fr. þringan to crowd, to press; akin to OS. thringan, D. & G. dringen, OHG. dringan, Icel. þryngva þröngva, Goth. þriehan, D. & G. drang a throng, press, Icel. þröng a throng, Lith. trenkti to jolt, tranksmas a tumult. Cf. Thring

sn.def: A multitude of persons or of living beings pressing or pressed into a close body or assemblage; a crowd.
A great multitude; as, the heavenly throng .
sn.syn: Throng Multitude Crowd.
sn.q: So, with this bold opposer rushes on This many-headed monster, multitude.
Not to know me argues yourselves unknown, The lowest of your throng.
I come from empty noise, and tasteless pomp, From crowds that hide a monarch from himself.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thronged; p. pr. & vb. n. Thronging
entry.def: To crowd together; to press together into a close body, as a multitude of persons; to gather or move in multitudes.
entry.q: I have seen the dumb men throng to see him.

sn.def: To crowd, or press, as persons; to oppress or annoy with a crowd of living beings.
sn.q: Much people followed him, and thronged him.

sn.def: To crowd into; to fill closely by crowding or pressing into, as a hall or a street.

entry.def: Thronged; crowded; also, much occupied; busy.
entry.q: To the intent the sick . . . should not lie too throng.

entry.def: In throngs or crowds.
A thorp.

entry.ety: Cf. Thrapple, and see Throttle
entry.def: The windpipe.
To throttle.

cs.cd: the missel thrush.

entry.ety: OE. throsel, AS. þrostle þrosle; akin to MHG. trostel, G. drossel, Icel. þröstr, Sw. trast, Lith. strazdas, L. turdus. √238. Cf. Thrush the bird

sn.def: The song thrush. See under Song.

A machine for spinning wool, cotton, etc., from the rove, consisting of a set of drawing rollers with bobbins and flyers, and differing from the mule in having the twisting apparatus stationary and the processes continuous; -- so called because it makes a singing noise.

entry.ety: Cf. Throttle
entry.def: A disease of bovine cattle, consisting of a swelling under the throat, which, unless checked, causes strangulation.

cs.cd: the hand lever by which a throttle valve is moved, especially in a locomotive.
a valve moved by hand or by a governor for regulating the supply of steam to the steam chest. In one form it consists of a disk turning on a transverse axis.

entry.ety: Dim. of throat. See Throat

sn.def: The windpipe, or trachea; the weasand.
The throttle valve.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Throttled; p. pr. & vb. n. Throttling

sn.def: To compress the throat of; to choke; to strangle.
sn.q: Grant him this, and the Parliament hath no more freedom than if it sat in his noose, which, when he pleases to draw together with one twitch of his negative, shall throttle a whole nation, to the wish of Caligula, in one neck.

sn.def: To utter with breaks and interruption, in the manner of a person half suffocated.
sn.q: Throttle their practiced accent in their fears.

sn.def: To shut off, or reduce flow of, as steam to an engine.
To have the throat obstructed so as to be in danger of suffocation; to choke; to suffocate.
To breathe hard, as when nearly suffocated.
One who, or that which, throttles, or chokes.
See Flasher, 3 .

entry.ety: OE. thurgh þurh þuruh þoruh, AS. þurh; akin to OS. thurh thuru, OFries. thruch, D. door, OHG. durh duruh, G. durch, Goth. þaírh; cf. Ir. tri tre, W. trwy. √53. Cf. Nostril Thorough Thrill

sn.def: From end to end of, or from side to side of; from one surface or limit of, to the opposite; into and out of at the opposite, or at another, point; as, to bore through a piece of timber, or through a board; a ball passes through the side of a ship.
Between the sides or walls of; within; as, to pass through a door; to go through an avenue.
sn.q: Through the gate of ivory he dismissed His valiant offspring.

sn.def: By means of; by the agency of.
sn.q: Through these hands this science has passed with great applause.
Material things are presented only through their senses.

sn.def: Over the whole surface or extent of; as, to ride through the country; to look through an account.
Among or in the midst of; -- used to denote passage; as, a fish swims through the water; the light glimmers through a thicket.
From the beginning to the end of; to the end or conclusion of; as, through life; through the year.

entry.note: ☞ Through was formerly used to form compound adjectives where we now use thorough; as, through-bred; through-lighted; through-placed, etc.
entry.cs: To drop through to fall through; to come to naught; to fail. To fall through. See under Fall v. i.

sn.def: From one end or side to the other; as, to pierce a thing through .
From beginning to end; as, to read a letter through .
To the end; to a conclusion; to the ultimate purpose; as, to carry a project through .

cs.cd: a bolt which passes through all the thickness or layers of that which it fastens, or in which it is fixed.
a bridge in which the floor is supported by the lower chords of the tissues instead of the upper, so that travel is between the trusses and not over them. Cf. Deck bridge, under Deck.
a deep-seated cold.
a flat gravestone.
a ticket for the whole journey.
a train which goes the whole length of a railway, or of a long route.

entry.def: Going or extending through; going, extending, or serving from the beginning to the end; thorough; complete; as, a through line; a through ticket; a through train. Also, admitting of passage through; as, a through bridge.
Thoroughly.
entry.q: Wash me throughly from mine iniquity.
To dare in fields is valor; but how few Dare to be throughly valiant to be true?

entry.def: Quite through; from one extremity to the other of; also, every part of; as, to search throughout the house.
entry.q: Nor to their idle orbs doth sight appear Of sun, or moon, or star, throughout the year.

entry.def: In every part; as, the cloth was of a piece throughout .
imp. of Thrive.

entry.ety: See Throe
entry.def: Pain; especially, pain of travail; throe.

entry.ety: AS. þrāh þrāg
entry.def: Time; while; space of time; moment; trice.
entry.q: I will with Thomas speak a little throw.

entry.cs:
To throw away. To lose by neglect or folly; to spend in vain; to bestow without a compensation; as, to throw away time; to throw away money. To reject; as, to throw away a good book, or a good offer. To throw back. To retort; to cast back, as a reply. To reject; to refuse. To reflect, as light. To throw by to lay aside; to discard; to neglect as useless; as, to throw by a garment. To throw down to subvert; to overthrow; to destroy; as, to throw down a fence or wall. To throw in. To inject, as a fluid. To put in; to deposit with others; to contribute; as, to throw in a few dollars to help make up a fund; to throw in an occasional comment. To add without enumeration or valuation, as something extra to clinch a bargain. To throw off. To expel; to free one's self from; as, to throw off a disease. To reject; to discard; to abandon; as, to throw off all sense of shame; to throw off a dependent. To make a start in a hunt or race. Eng
To throw on to cast on; to load. To throw one's self down to lie down neglectively or suddenly.
To throw one's self onorTo throw one's self upon . To fall upon. To resign one's self to the favor, clemency, or sustain power of (another); to repose upon. To throw out. To cast out; to reject or discard; to expel. “The other two, whom they had thrown out, they were content should enjoy their exile.” Swift. “The bill was thrown out.” Swift. To utter; to give utterance to; to speak; as, to throw out insinuation or observation. “She throws out thrilling shrieks.” Spenser. To distance; to leave behind. Addison. To cause to project; as, to throw out a pier or an abutment. To give forth; to emit; as, an electric lamp throws out a brilliant light. To put out; to confuse; as, a sudden question often throws out an orator. To throw over to abandon the cause of; to desert; to discard; as, to throw over a friend in difficulties. To throw up. To resign; to give up; to demit; as, to throw up a commission. “Experienced gamesters throw up their cards when they know that the game is in the enemy's hand.” Addison. To reject from the stomach; to vomit. To construct hastily; as, to throw up a breastwork of earth.
entry.vmorph: imp. Threw thrṳ; p. p. Thrown thrōn; p. pr. & vb. n. Throwing
entry.ety: OE. þrowen þrawen, to throw, to twist, AS. þrāwan to twist, to whirl; akin to D. draaijen, G. drehen, OHG. drājan, L. terebra an auger, gimlet, Gr. � to bore, to turn, � to pierce, � a hole. Cf. Thread Trite Turn v. t.

sn.def: To fling, cast, or hurl with a certain whirling motion of the arm, to throw a ball; -- distinguished from to toss, or to bowl.

To fling or cast in any manner; to drive to a distance from the hand or from an engine; to propel; to send; as, to throw stones or dust with the hand; a cannon throws a ball; a fire engine throws a stream of water to extinguish flames.
To drive by violence; as, a vessel or sailors may be thrown upon a rock.
To cause to take a strategic position; as, he threw a detachment of his army across the river.
To overturn; to prostrate in wrestling; as, a man throws his antagonist.
To cast, as dice; to venture at dice.
sn.q: Set less than thou throwest.

sn.def: To put on hastily; to spread carelessly.
sn.q: O'er his fair limbs a flowery vest he threw.

sn.def: To divest or strip one's self of; to put off.
sn.q: There the snake throws her enameled skin.

sn.def: To form or shape roughly on a throwing engine, or potter's wheel, as earthen vessels.
To give forcible utterance to; to cast; to vent.
sn.q: I have thrown A brave defiance in King Henry's teeth.

sn.def: To bring forth; to produce, as young; to bear; -- said especially of rabbits.

To twist two or more filaments of, as silk, so as to form one thread; to twist together, as singles, in a direction contrary to the twist of the singles themselves; -- sometimes applied to the whole class of operations by which silk is prepared for the weaver.

cs.cd: to cast about; to try expedients.

entry.def: To perform the act of throwing or casting; to cast; specifically, to cast dice.

sn.def: The act of hurling or flinging; a driving or propelling from the hand or an engine; a cast.
sn.q: He heaved a stone, and, rising to the throw, He sent it in a whirlwind at the foe.

sn.def: A stroke; a blow.
sn.q: Nor shield defend the thunder of his throws.

sn.def: The distance which a missile is, or may be, thrown; as, a stone's throw .
A cast of dice; the manner in which dice fall when cast; as, a good throw .
An effort; a violent sally.
sn.q: Your youth admires The throws and swellings of a Roman soul.

sn.def: The extreme movement given to a sliding or vibrating reciprocating piece by a cam, crank, eccentric, or the like; travel; stroke; as, the throw of a slide valve. Also, frequently, the length of the radius of a crank, or the eccentricity of an eccentric; as, the throw of the crank of a steam engine is equal to half the stroke of the piston.
A potter's wheel or table; a jigger. See 2d Jigger, 2 .
A turner's lathe; a throwe.
The amount of vertical displacement produced by a fault; -- according to the direction it is designated as an upthrow, or a downthrow.
to discard.
to waste or squander.
designed to be discarded after a single use; disposable.
spoken with deliberate underemphasis; as, a throwaway line in a play.
an advertisement (usually printed on a page or in a leaflet) intended for wide distribution.
sn.syn: circular, handbill, bill, broadside, broadsheet, flier, flyer

sn.def: words spoken in a casual way with conscious underemphasis.
the reappearance in an organism of characteristics of an earlier ancestral type; atavism.
an organisms having characteristics of an earlier ancestral type.

entry.def: to revert to an ancestral type or character.
entry.q: A large proportion of the steerage passengersthrow backto their Darwinian ancestry.

entry.def: An instrument used for twisting ropes out of straw.
A turning lathe.
One who throws. Specifically: One who throws or twists silk; a throwster. One who shapes vessels on a throwing engine.

cs.mcol: Throwing engine Throwing mill Throwing tableorThrowing wheel
cs.cd: a machine on which earthenware is first rudely shaped by the hand of the potter from a mass of clay revolving rapidly on a disk or table carried by a vertical spindle; a potter's wheel.

entry.def: a. & n. from Throw v.

entries.entry: Throw"ing stick`. Anthropol An instrument used by various savage races for throwing a spear; -- called also throw stick and spear thrower. One end of the stick receives the butt of the spear, as upon a hook or thong, and the other end is grasped with the hand, which also holds the spear, toward the middle, above it with the finger and thumb, the effect being to bring the place of support nearer the center of the spear, and practically lengthen the arm in the act of throwing. In Mexico, one such device is called the atlatl.

cs.cd: silk thread consisting of two or more singles twisted together like a rope, in a direction contrary to that in which the singles of which it is composed are twisted.

silk thread or cord made by three processes of twisting, first into singles, two or more of which are twisted together making dumb singles, and several of these twisted together to make thrown singles.

entry.def: a. & p. p. from Throw v.
A start in a hunt or a race.

entry.ety: Throw + -ster
entry.def: One who throws or twists silk; a thrower.
Through.

cs.cd: a knitted cap.
a hat made of coarse woolen cloth.
