entry.ety: OE. thrum throm; akin to OD. drom, D. dreum, G. trumm, lump, end, fragment, OHG. drum end, Icel. �römr edge, brim, and L. terminus a limit, term. Cf. Term

sn.def: One of the ends of weaver's threads; hence, any soft, short threads or tufts resembling these.
Any coarse yarn; an unraveled strand of rope.
A threadlike part of a flower; a stamen.
A shove out of place; a small displacement or fault along a seam.
A mat made of canvas and tufts of yarn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thrummed; p. pr. & vb. n. Thrumming

sn.def: To furnish with thrums; to insert tufts in; to fringe.
sn.q: Are we born to thrum caps or pick straw?

sn.def: To insert short pieces of rope-yarn or spun yarn in; as, to thrum a piece of canvas, or a mat, thus making a rough or tufted surface.

entry.ety: CF. Icel. �ruma to rattle, to thunder, and E. drum

sn.def: To play rudely or monotonously on a stringed instrument with the fingers; to strum.
Hence, to make a monotonous drumming noise; as, to thrum on a table.
To play, as a stringed instrument, in a rude or monotonous manner.
Hence, to drum on; to strike in a monotonous manner; to thrum the table.

entry.def: Having the anthers raised above the stigma, and visible at the throat of the corolla, as in long-stamened primroses; -- the reverse of pin-eyed.
Like thrums; made of, furnished with, or characterized by, thrums.
entry.q: On her head thrummy cap she had.

entry.def: A kind of amaranth (Amarantus caudatus).

entries.entry: Thru*out". Throughout. Ref. spelling

entry.note: ☞ Among the best-known European species are the song thrush or throstle (Turdus musicus), the missel thrush (see under Missel), the European redwing, and the blackbird. The most important American species are the wood thrush (Turdus mustelinus), Wilson's thrush (Turdus fuscescens), the hermit thrush (see under Hermit), Swainson's thrush (Turdus Aliciæ), and the migratory thrush, or American robin (see Robin).
entry.cs: Ant thrush. See Ant thrush Breve, and Pitta. Babbling thrush any one of numerous species of Asiatic timaline birds; -- called also babbler. Fruit thrush any species of bulbul. Shrike thrush. See under Shrike. Stone thrush the missel thrush; -- said to be so called from its marbled breast. Thrush nightingale. See Nightingale, 2. Thrush tit any one of several species of Asiatic singing birds of the genus Cochoa. They are beautifully colored birds allied to the tits, but resembling thrushes in size and habits. Water thrush. The European dipper. An American warbler (Seiurus Noveboracensis).
entry.ety: OE. þrusche, AS. þrysce; akin to OHG. drosca droscea droscela, and E. throstle. Cf. Throstle

sn.def: Any one of numerous species of singing birds belonging to Turdus and allied genera. They are noted for the sweetness of their songs.
Any one of numerous species of singing birds more or less resembling the true thrushes in appearance or habits; as the thunderbird and the American brown thrush (or thrasher). See Brown thrush.

entry.ety: Akin to Dan. tröske, Sw. trosk; cf. Dan. tör dry, Sw. torr, Icel. þurr, AS. þyrr, OE. thrust thrist, E. thrist

sn.def: An affection of the mouth, fauces, etc., common in newly born children, characterized by minute ulcers called aphthæ. See Aphthæ.
An inflammatory and suppurative affection of the feet in certain animals. In the horse it is in the frog.

entry.def: The song thrush.
The song thrush.
Thrist.

entry.cs:
To thrust awayorTo thrust from
to push away; to reject. To thrust in to push or drive in. To thrust off to push away. To thrust on to impel; to urge.
To thrust one's self inorTo thrust one's self into
to obtrude upon, to intrude, as into a room; to enter (a place) where one is not invited or not welcome. To thrust out to drive out or away; to expel. To thrust through to pierce; to stab. “I am eight times thrust through the doublet.” Shak. To thrust together to compress.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thrust; p. pr. & vb. n. Thrusting
entry.ety: OE. �rusten �risten �resten, Icel. �r�st� to thrust, press, force, compel; perhaps akin to E. threat

sn.def: To push or drive with force; to drive, force, or impel; to shove; as, to thrust anything with the hand or foot, or with an instrument.
sn.q: Into a dungeon thrust, to work with slaves.

sn.def: To stab; to pierce; -- usually with through.

cs.cd: to rush upon.

sn.def: To make a push; to attack with a pointed weapon; as, a fencer thrusts at his antagonist.
To enter by pushing; to squeeze in.
sn.q: And thrust between my father and the god.

sn.def: To push forward; to come with force; to press on; to intrude.
sn.q: Young, old,thrustthere in mighty concourse.
As doth an eager houndThrust to an hind within some covert glade.

cs.cd: a bearing arranged to receive the thrust or endwise pressure of the screw shaft.
the surface along which dislocation has taken place in the case of a reversed fault.

entry.usage: Thrust Push Shove. Push and shove usually imply the application of force by a body already in contact with the body to be impelled. Thrust, often, but not always, implies the impulse or application of force by a body which is in motion before it reaches the body to be impelled.

sn.def: A violent push or driving, as with a pointed weapon moved in the direction of its length, or with the hand or foot, or with any instrument; a stab; -- a word much used as a term of fencing.
sn.q: Polites] Pyrrhus with his lance pursues, And often reaches, and his thrusts renews.

sn.def: An attack; an assault.
sn.q: One thrust at your pure, pretended mechanism.

sn.def: The force or pressure of one part of a construction against other parts; especially Arch, a horizontal or diagonal outward pressure, as of an arch against its abutments, or of rafters against the wall which support them.
The breaking down of the roof of a gallery under its superincumbent weight.
sn.syn: Push; shove; assault; attack.

entry.def: One who thrusts or stabs.

cs.cd: the screw of a screw press, as for pressing curd in making cheese.

sn.def: The act of pushing with force.

sd.def: The act of squeezing curd with the hand, to expel the whey.
The white whey, or that which is last pressed out of the curd by the hand, and of which butter is sometimes made.

entry.def: The throstle, or song thrust.
entry.q: When he heard the thrustel sing.

entry.def: Thrice.

entry.ety: Perhaps fr. thrice + fallow. Cf. Trifallow
entry.def: To plow for the third time in summer; to trifallow.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. þōden a whirlwind, violent wind, or E. thump
entry.def: A dull sound without resonance, like that produced by striking with, or striking against, some comparatively soft substance; also, the stroke or blow producing such sound; as, the thrud of a cannon ball striking the earth.
entry.q: At every new thud of the blast, a sob arose.
At intervals there came some tremendous thud on the side of the steamer.

entry.def: To make, or strike so as to make, a dull sound, or thud.
entry.q: Hardly the softest thudding of velvety pads.
The waves break into spray, dash and rumble and thud below your feet.

entry.ety: Hind. thag a deceiver, robber

sn.def: One of an association of robbers and murderers in India who practiced murder by stealthy approaches, and from religious motives. They have been nearly exterminated by the British government.
An assassin; a ruffian; a rough.
sn.q: Thugsand midnight rounders.

entry.ety: Hind. ṭhagī
entry.def: The practice of secret or stealthy murder by Thugs.
entry.q: One of the suppressors ofThuggee.

entry.def: Thuggee.

entries.entry:
Thu"ja Thu"ja ☞ Thuja occidentalis is the Arbor vitæ of the Eastern and Northern United States. Thuja gigantea of North-waetern America is a very large tree, there called red cedar, and canoe cedar, and furnishes a useful timber. n. NL., from Gr. � an African tree with sweet-smelling wood Bot A genus of evergreen trees, thickly branched, remarkable for the distichous arrangement of their branches, and having scalelike, closely imbricated, or compressed leaves.
thuya See Thyine wood.

entry.ety: L. Thule Thyle, Gr. �, �
entry.def: The name given by ancient geographers to the northernmost part of the habitable world. According to some, this land was Norway, according to others, Iceland, or more probably Mainland, the largest of the Shetland islands; hence, the Latin phrase ultima Thule, farthest Thule.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Oxide of thulium.

entry.ety: NL. See Thule
entry.def: A rare metallic element of uncertain properties and identity, said to have been found in the mineral gadolinite.

entry.cs: Thumb band a twist of anything as thick as the thumb. Mortimer. Thumb blue indigo in the form of small balls or lumps, used by washerwomen to blue linen, and the like. Thumb latch a door latch having a lever formed to be pressed by the thumb. Thumb mark. The mark left by the impression of a thumb, as on the leaves of a book. Longfellow. The dark spot over each foot in finely bred black and tan terriers. Thumb nut a nut for a screw, having wings to grasp between the thumb and fingers in turning it; also, a nut with a knurled rim for the same perpose. Thumb ring a ring worn on the thumb. Shak. Thumb stall. A kind of thimble or ferrule of iron, or leather, for protecting the thumb in making sails, and in other work. Mil A buckskin cushion worn on the thumb, and used to close the vent of a cannon while it is sponged, or loaded. Under one's thumb completely under one's power or influence; in a condition of subservience. Colloq
entry.ety: OE. thombe thoumbe þume, AS. þūma; akin to OFries. thūma, D. duim, G. daumen, OHG. dūmo, Icel. þumall, Dan. tommelfinger, Sw. tumme, and perhaps to L. tumere to swell. √56. Cf. Thimble Tumid
entry.def: The short, thick first digit of the human hand, differing from the other fingers in having but two phalanges; the pollex. See Pollex.
entry.q: Upon his thumb he had of gold a ring.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thumbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Thumbing

sn.def: To handle awkwardly.
To play with the thumbs, or with the thumbs and fingers; as, to thumb over a tune.
To soil or wear with the thumb or the fingers; to soil, or wear out, by frequent handling; also, to cover with the thumb; as, to thumb the touch-hole of a cannon.
sn.q: He gravely informed the enemy that all his cards had been thumbed to pieces, and begged them to let him have a few more packs.

entry.def: To play with the thumb or thumbs; to play clumsily; to thrum.
The goldcrest.

sn.def: Having thumbs.
Soiled by handling.

entry.def: An instrument of torture for compressing the thumb; a thumbscrew.
Without a thumb.

sn.def: A screw having a flat-sided or knurled head, so that it may be turned by the thumb and forefinger.
An old instrument of torture for compressing the thumb by a screw; a thumbkin.

entry.def: The chiff-chaff.

entry.ety: Heb., pl. of thōm perfection
entry.def: A mysterious part or decoration of the breastplate of the Jewish high priest. See the note under Urim.

entry.ety: Probably of imitative origin; perhaps influenced by dump, v. t

sn.def: The sound made by the sudden fall or blow of a heavy body, as of a hammer, or the like.
sn.q: The distant forge's swinging thump profound.
With heavy thump, a lifeless lump, They dropped down, one by one.

sn.def: A blow or knock, as with something blunt or heavy; a heavy fall.
sn.q: The watchman gave so great a thump at my door, that I awaked at the knock.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thumped; p. pr. & vb. n. Thumping
entry.def: To strike or beat with something thick or heavy, or so as to cause a dull sound.
entry.q: These bastard Bretons; whom our hathers Have in their own land beaten, bobbed, and thumped.

entry.def: To give a thump or thumps; to strike or fall with a heavy blow; to pound.
entry.q: A watchman at midnight thumps with his pole.

entry.def: One who, or that which, thumps.
Heavy; large.

entry.cs: Thunder pumper. Zoöl The croaker (Haploidontus grunniens). The American bittern or stake-driver. Thunder rod a lightning rod. R Thunder snake. Zoöl The chicken, or milk, snake. A small reddish ground snake (Carphophis amœna syn. Celuta amœna) native to the Eastern United States; -- called also worm snake. Thunder tube a fulgurite. See Fulgurite.
entry.ety: OE. þunder þonder þoner, AS. þunor; akin to þunian to stretch, to thunder, D. donder thunder, G. donner, OHG. donar, Icel. þōrr Thor, L. tonare to thunder, tonitrus thunder, Gr. to`nos a stretching, straining, Skr. tan to stretch. √52. See Thin, and cf. Astonish Detonate Intone Thursday Tone

sn.def: The sound which follows a flash of lightning; the report of a discharge of atmospheric electricity.
The discharge of electricity; a thunderbolt.
sn.q: The revenging gods 'Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend.

sn.def: Any loud noise; as, the thunder of cannon.
An alarming or statrling threat or denunciation.
sn.q: The thunders of the Vatican could no longer strike into the heart of princes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thundered; p. pr. & vb. n. Thundering
entry.ety: AS. þunrian. See Thunder n.

sn.def: To produce thunder; to sound, rattle, or roar, as a discharge of atmospheric electricity; -- often used impersonally; as, it thundered continuously.
sn.q: Canst thou thunder with a voice like him?

sn.def: Fig.: To make a loud noise; esp. a heavy sound, of some continuance.
sn.q: His dreadful voice no more Would thunder in my ears.

sn.def: To utter violent denunciation.

entry.def: To emit with noise and terror; to utter vehemently; to publish, as a threat or denunciation.
entry.q: Oracles severe Were daily thundered in our general's ear.
An archdeacon, as being a prelate, may thunder out an ecclesiastical censure.

entry.def: An Australian insectivorous singing bird (Pachycephala gutturalis). The male is conspicuously marked with black and yellow, and has a black crescent on the breast. Called also white-throated thickhead orange-breasted thrust black-crowned thrush guttural thrush, and black-breasted flycatcher.

cs.cd: a long-horned beetle (Arhopalus fulminans) whose larva bores in the trunk of oak and chestnut trees. It is brownish and bluish-black, with W-shaped whitish or silvery markings on the elytra.

sn.def: A shaft of lightning; a brilliant stream of electricity passing from one part of the heavens to another, or from the clouds to the earth.
Something resembling lightning in suddenness and effectiveness.
sn.q: The Scipios' worth, those thunderbolts of war.

sn.def: Vehement threatening or censure; especially, ecclesiastical denunciation; fulmination.
sn.q: He severely threatens such with the thunderbolt of excommunication.

sn.def: A belemnite, or thunderstone.

entry.def: A burst of thunder.
A sharp burst of thunder; a sudden report of a discharge of atmospheric electricity.
entry.q: Thunderclapsthat make them quake.
When suddenly the thunderclap was heard.

entry.def: A cloud charged with electricity, and producing lightning and thunder.
One who thunders; -- used especially as a translation of L. tonans, an epithet applied by the Romans to several of their gods, esp. to Jupiter.
entry.q: That dreadful oath which binds the Thunderer.

entry.def: A large European loach (Misgurnus fossilis).
A rounded mass of cloud, with shining white edges; a cumulus, -- often appearing before a thunderstorm.

sn.def: Emitting thunder.
sn.q: Roll the thundering chariot o'er the ground.

sn.def: Very great; -- often adverbially.

entry.def: Thunder.
Without thunder or noise.

entry.ety: Written also thundrous

sn.def: Producing thunder.
sn.q: How he before the thunderous throne doth lie.

sn.def: Making a noise like thunder; sounding loud and deep; sonorous.

entry.def: Secure against the effects of thunder or lightning.
A shower accompanied with lightning and thunder.

sn.def: A thunderbolt, -- formerly believed to be a stone.
sn.q: Fear no more the lightning flash, Nor the all-dreaded thunderstone.

sn.def: A belemnite. See Belemnite.

entry.def: A storm accompanied with lightning and thunder.

entry.vmorph: imp. Thunderstruck; p. p. Thunderstruck -strucken; p. pr. & vb. n. Thunderstriking

sn.def: To strike, blast, or injure by, or as by, lightning.
To astonish, or strike dumb, as with something terrible; -- rarely used except in the past participle.
sn.q: drove before him, thunderstruck.

entry.def: A small, footless, burrowing, snakelike lizard (Rhineura Floridana) allied to Amphisbæna, native of Florida; -- so called because it leaves its burrows after a thundershower.
Accompanied with thunder; thunderous.
entry.q: Thunderyweather.

entry.def: Thunderous; sonorous.
entry.q: Scraps ofthunderousepic.

entry.def: The tunny.
Through.
Thoroughfare.
entry.q: This world is but a thurghfare full of woe.

entry.ety: L. thuribulum turibulum, from thus thuris, or better tus turis, frankincense, fr. Gr. � a sacrifice, an offering, from � to sacrifice
entry.def: A censer of metal, for burning incense, having various forms, held in the hand or suspended by chains; -- used especially at mass, vespers, and other solemn services.

entry.ety: L. thurifer turifer; thus frankincense + -ferre to bear
entry.def: Producing or bearing frankincense.

entry.ety: L. thus incense + -ficarein comp.) to make. See -fy
entry.def: The act of fuming with incense, or the act of burning incense.
Of or pertaining to Thuringia, a country in Germany, or its people.

def2.def: A native, or inhabitant of Thuringia.

entry.ety: From Thuringia, where it is found
entry.def: A mineral occurring as an aggregation of minute scales having an olive-green color and pearly luster. It is a hydrous silicate of aluminia and iron.

entry.ety: AS. þyrel a hole. √53. See Thirl Thrill

sn.def: A hole; an aperture.

sd.def: A short communication between adits in a mine.
A long adit in a coalpit.

entry.ety: See Thrill

sn.def: To cut through; to pierce.
To cut through, as a partition between one working and another.

entry.def: Same as Thurl n., 2 .

entry.ety: AS. þurruc a boat
entry.def: The hold of a ship; a sink.
entry.q: Small drops of water that enter through a little crevice into the thurrok and into the bottom of a ship.

entry.cs: Holy Thursday. See under Holy.
entry.ety: OE. þursdei þorsday, from the Scand. name Thor + E. day. Icel. þōrr Thor, the god of thunder, is akin to AS. þunor thunder; D. Donderdag Thursday, G. Donnerstag, Icel. þōrsdagr, Sw. & Dan. Torsdag. √52. See Thor Thunder, and Day
entry.def: The fifth day of the week, following Wednesday and preceding Friday.
The ruins of the fallen roof resulting from the removal of the pillars and stalls.

entry.ety: L. thus, better tus, frankincense. See Thurible
entry.def: The commoner kind of frankincense, or that obtained from the Norway spruce, the long-leaved pine, and other conifers.

entry.ety: OE. thus, AS. ðus; akin to OFries. & OS. thus, D. dus, and E. that; cf. OHG. sus. See That

sn.def: In this or that manner; on this wise.
sn.q: Thus did Noah; according to all that God commanded him, so did he.
Thus God the heaven created, thus the earth.

sn.def: To this degree or extent; so far; so; as, thus wise; thus peaceble; thus bold.
sn.q: Thus far extend, thus far thy bounds.

entry.def: See Tussock.
Same as Thuja.
A substance extracted from trees of the genus Thuja, or Thuya, and probably identical with quercitrin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thwacked; p. pr. & vb. n. Thwacking
entry.ety: Cf. OE. thakken to stroke, AS. þaccian, E. whack

sn.def: To strike with something flat or heavy; to bang, or thrash: to thump.
sn.q: A distantthwackingsound.

sn.def: To fill to overflow.

entry.def: A heavy blow with something flat or heavy; a thump.
entry.q: With many a stiff thwack, many a bang, Hard crab tree and old iron rang.

entry.def: The twaite.

entry.note: ☞ Thwaite occurs in composition as the last element in many names of places in the north of England; as, in Rosthwaite, Stonethwaite.
entry.ety: CF. Icel. þveit a piece of land, fr. þvīta to cut. See Thwite, and cf. Doit, and Twaite land cleared of woods
entry.def: Forest land cleared, and converted to tillage; an assart.

entry.ety: OE. þwart þwert, a. and adv., Icel. þvert, neut. of þverr athwart, transverse, across; akin to AS. þweorh perverse, transverse, cross, D. dwars, OHG. dwerah twerh, G. zwerch quer, Dan. & Sw. tver athwart, transverse, Sw. tvär cross, unfriendly, Goth. þwaírhs angry. Cf. Queer

sn.def: Situated or placed across something else; transverse; oblique.
sn.q: Moved contrary with thwart obliquities.

sn.def: Fig.: Perverse; crossgrained.

entry.ety: See Thwart a.
entry.def: Thwartly; obliquely; transversely; athwart.

entry.cs: Thwart ships. See Athwart ships, under Athwart.
entry.def: Across; athwart.
A seat in an open boat reaching from one side to the other, or athwart the boat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Thwarted; p. pr. & vb. n. Thwarting

sn.def: To move across or counter to; to cross; as, an arrow thwarts the air.
sn.q: Swift as a shooting star In autumn thwarts the night.

sn.def: To cross, as a purpose; to oppose; to run counter to; to contravene; hence, to frustrate or defeat.
sn.q: If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.
The proposals of the one never thwarted the inclinations of the other.

sn.def: To move or go in an oblique or crosswise manner.
Hence, to be in opposition; to clash.
sn.q: Any proposition . . . that shall at all thwart with internal oracles.

entry.def: A disease in sheep, indicated by shaking, trembling, or convulsive motions.
In a thwarting or obstructing manner; so as to thwart.
Transversely; obliquely.
The quality or state of being thwart; obliquity; perverseness.

entry.ety: AS. þwītan. See Whittle, and cf. Thwaite a piece of land
entry.def: To cut or clip with a knife; to whittle.

entry.ety: See Thwite, and Whittle
entry.def: To cut or whittle.
A small knife; a whittle.
entry.q: A Sheffieldthwittle.

entry.ety: OE. thi, shortened from thin. See Thine Thou
entry.def: Of thee, or belonging to thee; the more common form of thine, possessive case of thou; -- used always attributively, and chiefly in the solemn or grave style, and in poetry. Thine is used in the predicate; as, the knife is thine . See Thine.
entry.q: Our father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done.
These are thy glorious works, Parent of good.

entries.entry: Thy"ine wood`. Gr. � �, fr. �, adj., pertaining to the tree � or �, an African tree with sweet-smelling wood Bot The fragrant and beautiful wood of a North African tree (Callitris quadrivalvis), formerly called Thuja articulata. The tree is of the Cedar family, and furnishes a balsamic resin called sandarach.

entry.ety: Gr. � a sack
entry.def: The zebra wolf. See under Wolf.
A compound of thymol analogous to a salt; as, sodium thymate .

cs.cd: a labiate plant (Teucrium Marum) of the Mediterranean religion. Cats are said to be fond of rolling on it.
Thymus Serpyllum, common on banks and hillsides in Europe.

entry.ety: OE. tyme, L. thymum, Gr. qy`mon qy`mos; cf. qy`ein, to sacrifice, qy`os a sacrifice, offering, incense: cf. F. thym; -- perhaps so named because of its sweet smell. Cf. Fume n.
entry.def: Any plant of the labiate genus Thymus. The garden thyme (Thymus vulgaris) is a warm, pungent aromatic, much used to give a relish to seasoning and soups.
entry.q: Ankle deep in moss and flowery thyme.
I know a bank where the wild thyme blows.

entry.def: A liquid terpene obtained from oil of thyme.

entry.ety: Gr. � incense + te`chnh art
entry.def: The art of employing perfumes in medicine.
Of or pertaining to the thymus gland.
Pertaining to, or derived from, thyme; as, thymic acid.

entry.ety: Thyme + -ol
entry.def: A phenol derivative of cymene, C10H13.OH, isomeric with carvacrol, found in oil of thyme, and extracted as a white crystalline substance of a pleasant aromatic odor and strong antiseptic properties; -- called also hydroxy cymene.

cs.cd: a ductless gland in the throat, or in the neighboring region, of nearly all vertebrates. In man and other mammals it is the throat, or neck, sweetbread, which lies in the upper part of the thorax and lower part of the throat. It is largest in fetal and early life, and disappears or becomes rudimentary in the adult. The thymus gland functions as the site of maturation of T-lymphocytes (T-cells), which confer cell-mediated immunity on the host organism; thus, removal or malfunciton of the thymus can lead to absence of cell-mediated immunity, and a consequent loss of resistance to infection.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. qy`mos
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the thymus gland.

def2.def: The thymus gland.

entry.def: Abounding with thyme; fragrant; as, a thymy vale.
entry.q: Where'er a thymy bank he found, He rolled upon the fragrant ground.

entries.entry: Thy"ro-. A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to the thyroid body or the thyroid cartilage; as, thyrohyal.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to both the thyroid and arytenoid cartilages of the larynx.
One of the lower segments in the hyoid arch, often consolidated with the body of the hyoid bone and forming one of its great horns, as in man.
Of or pertaining to the thyroid cartilage of the larynx and the hyoid arch.

entry.cs:
Thyroid cartilage. See under Larynx.
Thyroid bodyorThyroid gland
Anat an endocrine gland having two lobes, located in the floor of the mouth or the region of the larynx, which secretes two hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine) that regulate the rates of growth and metabloism. In man and most mammals it is a highly vascular organ, partly surrounding the base of the larynx and the upper part of the trachea. Cases of hypothyroidism, where the gland is insufficiently active, can be treated by administration of thyroxine or a combination of thyroxine and triiodothyronine. Thyroid dislocation Surg dislocation of the thigh bone into the thyroid foramen. Thyroid foramen the obturator foramen.
entry.ety: Gr. qyreoeidh`s shield-shaped; qyreo`s a large, oblong shield (from qy`ra a door) + e'i^dos form: cf. F. thyroïde thyréoïde

sn.def: Shaped like an oblong shield; shield-shaped; as, the thyroid cartilage.
Of or pertaining to the thyroid body, thyroid cartilage, or thyroid artery; thyroideal.

entry.def: Thyroid.

entry.ety: Thyro- + Gr. � to cut
entry.def: The operation of cutting into the thyroid cartilage.

entry.ety: Cf. F. thyrse
entry.def: A thyrsus.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � thyrsus + e'i^dos form, shape: cf. F. thyrsoïde
entry.def: Having somewhat the form of a thyrsus.

entries.entry:
Thyr"sus Thyr"sus n.; pl.Thyrsi #. L., fr. Gr. �. Cf. Torso
A staff entwined with ivy, and surmounted by a pine cone, or by a bunch of vine or ivy leaves with grapes or berries. It is an attribute of Bacchus, and of the satyrs and others engaging in Bacchic rites. A good to grow on graves As twist about a thyrsus. In my hand I bear The thyrsus, tipped with fragrant cones of pine.
Bot A species of inflorescence; a dense panicle, as in the lilac and horse-chestnut.

entry.def: One of the Thysanoptera.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � a fringe + � a wing
entry.def: A division of insects, considered by some writers a distinct order, but regarded by others as belonging to the Hemiptera. They are all of small size, and have narrow, broadly fringed wings with rudimentary nervures. Most of the species feed upon the juices of plants, and some, as those which attack grain, are very injurious to crops. Called also Physopoda. See Thrips.
One of the Thysanoptera.
Of or pertaining to the Thysanoptera.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � fringe + � tail
entry.def: An order of wingless hexapod insects which have setiform caudal appendages, either bent beneath the body to form a spring, or projecting as bristles. It comprises the Cinura, or bristletails, and the Collembola, or springtails. Called also Thysanoura. See Lepisma, and Podura.
One of the Thysanura. Also used adjectively.
Of or pertaining to the Thysanura.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. Thisbe maiden beloved by Pyramus, Gr. �
entry.def: A common clearwing moth (Hemaris thysbe).

An emphasized form of the personal pronoun of the second person; -- used as a subject commonly with thou; as, thou thyself shalt go; that is, thou shalt go, and no other. It is sometimes used, especially in the predicate, without thou, and in the nominative as well as in the objective case.
entry.q: Thyself shalt see the act.
Ere I do thee, thou to thyself wast cruel.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tiare. See Tiara
entry.def: A tiara.

entry.ety: L., from Gr. �, �; of Persian origin

sn.def: A form of headdress worn by the ancient Persians. According to Xenophon, the royal tiara was encircled with a diadem, and was high and erect, while those of the people were flexible, or had rims turned over.
The pope's triple crown. It was at first a round, high cap, but was afterward encompassed with a crown, subsequently with a second, and finally with a third. Fig.: The papal dignity.

entry.def: Adorned with, or wearing, a tiara.
A female cat.

entries.entry:
Tib"i*a Tib"i*a n.; pl.Tibiæ #. L
Anat The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the two bones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
Zoöl The fourth joint of the leg of an insect. See Illust. under Coleoptera, and under Hexapoda.
Antiq A musical instrument of the flute kind, originally made of the leg bone of an animal.

cs.cd: a spine frequently borne on the tibia of insects. See Illust. under Coleoptera.

entry.ety: L. tibialis, fr. tibia the shin bone; also, a pipe or flute, originally made of a bone: cf. F. tibial

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a tibia.
Of or pertaining to a pipe or flute.

entry.def: A tibial bone; a tibiale.

entries.entry: Tib`i*a"le Tib`i*a"le n.; pl.Tibialia #. NL Anat The bone or cartilage of the tarsus which articulates with the tibia and corresponds to a part of the astragalus in man and most mammals.

entry.ety: L. tibicinare
entry.def: To play on a tibia, or pipe.

entries.entry: Tib"i*o-. A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with, or relation to the tibia; as, tibiotarsus, tibiofibular.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to both to the tibia and the tarsus; as, the tibiotarsal articulation.
Of or pertaining to the tibiotarsus.

entries.entry: Tib`i*o*tar"sus n.; pl.Tibiotarsi. Anat The large bone between the femur and tarsometatarsus in the leg of a bird. It is formed by the union of the proximal part of the tarsus with the tibia.

entry.def: The pollack.

entry.cs: Tic douloureux. F., fr. tic a knack, a twitching + douloureux painful Med Neuralgia in the face; face ague. See under Face.
entry.ety: F
entry.def: A local and habitual convulsive motion of certain muscles; especially, such a motion of some of the muscles of the face; twitching; velication; -- called also spasmodic tic.

sn.def: A bean-shaped coin of Siam, worth about sixty cents; also, a weight equal to 236 grains troy.
A money of account in China, reckoning at about $1.60; also, a weight of about four ounces avoirdupois.

entry.ety: Aphetic form of entice
entry.def: To entice.
A ball bowled to strike the ground about a bat's length in front of the wicket.
Enticement.

entry.ety: Gr. � a wall + �, �, the nose
entry.def: A fossil rhinoceros with a vertical bony medial septum supporting the nose; the hairy rhinoceros.

entry.ety: Abbrev. from ticket
entry.def: Credit; trust; as, to buy on, or upon, tick .

sn.def: To go on trust, or credit.
To give tick; to trust.

cs.cd: a small bean used for feeding horses and other animals.

a name given to many plants of the leguminous genus Desmodium, which have trifoliate leaves, and joined pods roughened with minute hooked hairs by which the joints adhere to clothing and to the fleece of sheep.

entry.ety: OE. tike teke; akin to D. teek, G. zecke. Cf. Tike a tick
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of large parasitic mites which attach themselves to, and suck the blood of, cattle, dogs, and many other animals. When filled with blood they become ovate, much swollen, and usually livid red in color. Some of the species often attach themselves to the human body. The young are active and have at first but six legs.
Any one of several species of dipterous insects having a flattened and usually wingless body, as the bird ticks (see under Bird) and sheep tick (see under Sheep).

entry.ety: LL. techa teca, L. theca case, Gr. �, fr. � to put. See Thesis

sn.def: The cover, or case, of a bed, mattress, etc., which contains the straw, feathers, hair, or other filling.
Ticking. See Ticking n.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ticked; p. pr. & vb. n. Ticking
entry.ety: Probably of imitative origin; cf. D. tikken, LG. ticken

sn.def: To make a small or repeating noise by beating or otherwise, as a watch does; to beat.
To strike gently; to pat.
sn.q: Stand not ticking and toying at the branches.

entry.cs: Death tick. Zoöl See Deathwatch.

sn.def: A quick, audible beat, as of a clock.
Any small mark intended to direct attention to something, or to serve as a check.
The whinchat; -- so called from its note.

entry.def: To check off by means of a tick or any small mark; to score.
entry.q: When I had got all my responsibilities down upon my list, I compared each with the bill and ticked it off.

entry.def: See Ticking.

entry.ety: See Tick

sn.def: One who, or that which, ticks, or produces a ticking sound, as a watch or clock, a telegraphic sounder, etc.

an electronic instrument receiving information by transmision from a remote source and displaying it in readable fashion, not necessarily on paper tape (e.g. on a video display terminal or moving ribbon of electronically controlled lights).
The heart.
sn.cd: Tape from or designed to be used in a stock ticker, usu. of paper and being narrow but long.

an electro-mechanical information receiving device connected by telegraphic wire to a stock exchange, and which prints out the latest transactions or news on stock exchanges, commonly found in the offices of stock brokers. By 1980 such devices were largely superseded by electronic stock quotation devices.

entry.def: A parade to honor a person or persons, held in New York City, during which people in the tall buildings of Manhattan throw large quantities of paper, confetti, paper ribbons, or the like onto the parading group. The name comes form the ticker tape originally thrown onto the parade when it passed stockbrokers' offices in lower Manhattan, before stock tickers became obsolete; in subsequent years other types of waste paper were used to serve the honorary function, as well as paper tape distributed specifically for the purpose of being thrown in such a parade.

entries.entry:
Tick"et ☞ Hence the phrase on ticket, on account; whence, by abbreviation, came the phrase on tick. See 1st Tick.
Scratched ticket a ticket from which the names of one or more of the candidates are scratched out. Split ticket a ticket representing different divisions of a party, or containing candidates selected from two or more parties. Straight ticket a ticket containing the regular nominations of a party, without change. Ticket day Com the day before the settling or pay day on the stock exchange, when the names of the actual purchasers are rendered in by one stockbroker to another. Eng Simmonds. Ticket of leave a license or permit given to a convict, or prisoner of the crown, to go at large, and to labor for himself before the expiration of his sentence, subject to certain specific conditions. Eng Simmonds. Ticket porter a licensed porter wearing a badge by which he may be identified. Eng
n. F. étiquette a label, ticket, fr. OF. estiquette, or OF. etiquet estiquet; both of Teutonic origin, and akin to E. stick. See Stick n. & v., and cf. Etiquette Tick credit A small piece of paper, cardboard, or the like, serving as a notice, certificate, or distinguishing token of something. Specifically:A little note or notice. Obs. or Local He constantly read his lectures twice a week for above forty years, giving notice of the time to his auditors in a ticket on the school doors. A tradesman's bill or account. Obs Your courtier is mad to take up silks and velvetsOn ticket for his mistress. A certificate or token of right of admission to a place of assembly, or of passage in a public conveyance; as, a theater ticket; a railroad or steamboat ticket . A label to show the character or price of goods. A certificate or token of a share in a lottery or other scheme for distributing money, goods, or the like. Politics A printed list of candidates to be voted for at an election; a set of nominations by one party for election; a ballot. U. S The old ticket forever! We have it by thirty-four votes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ticketed; p. pr. & vb. n. Ticketing

sn.def: To distinguish by a ticket; to put a ticket on; as, to ticket goods.
To furnish with a tickets; to book; as, to ticket passengers to California.

entry.def: A periodical sale of ore in the English mining districts; -- so called from the tickets upon which are written the bids of the buyers.

entry.ety: From Tick a bed cover. Cf. Ticken
entry.def: A strong, closely woven linen or cotton fabric, of which ticks for beds are made. It is usually twilled, and woven in stripes of different colors, as white and blue; -- called also ticken.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tickled; p. pr. & vb. n. Tickling
entry.ety: Perhaps freq. of tick to beat; pat; but cf. also AS. citelian to tickle, D. kittelen, G. kitzlen, OHG. chizzilōn chuzzilōn, Icel. kitla. Cf. Kittle v. t.

sn.def: To touch lightly, so as to produce a peculiar thrilling sensation, which commonly causes laughter, and a kind of spasm which become dengerous if too long protracted.
sn.q: If you tickle us, do we not laugh?

sn.def: To please; to gratify; to make joyous.
sn.q: Pleased with a rattle, tickled with a straw.
Such a natureTickled with good success, disdains the shadow Which he treads on at noon.

sn.def: To feel titillation.
sn.q: He with secret joy therefore Did tickle inwardly in every vein.

sn.def: To excite the sensation of titillation.
Ticklish; easily tickled.
Liable to change; uncertain; inconstant.
sn.q: The world is now full tickle, sikerly.
So tickle is the state of earthy things.

sn.def: Wavering, or liable to waver and fall at the slightest touch; unstable; easily overthrown.
sn.q: Thy head stands so tickle on thy shoulders, that a milkmaid, if she be in love, may sigh it off.

entry.def: Uncertain; inconstant; slippery.
A coarse, mixed linen fabric made to be sold in the West Indies.
Unsteadiness.
entry.q: For hoard hath hate, and climbing tickleness.

sn.def: One who, or that which, tickles.
Something puzzling or difficult.
A book containing a memorandum of notes and debts arranged in the order of their maturity.
A prong used by coopers to extract bungs from casks.
Sensible to slight touches; easily tickled; as, the sole of the foot is very ticklish; the hardened palm of the hand is not ticklish .
Standing so as to be liable to totter and fall at the slightest touch; unfixed; easily affected; unstable.
sn.q: Can any man with comfort lodge in a condition so dismally ticklish?

sn.def: Difficult; nice; critical; as, a ticklish business.
sn.q: Surely princes had need, in tender matters and ticklish times, to beware what they say.

entry.ety: Tick the insect + seed; cf. G. wanzensamen, literally, bug seed

sn.def: A seed or fruit resembling in shape an insect, as that of certain plants.

sd.def: Same as Coreopsis.
Any plant of the genus Corispermum, plants of the Goosefoot family.

entry.ety: See Tick to beat, to pat, and (for sense 2) cf. Tricktrack

sn.def: A noise like that made by a clock or a watch.
A kind of backgammon played both with men and pegs; tricktrack.
sn.q: A game at ticktack with words.

entry.def: With a ticking noise, like that of a watch.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A very venomous viper (Daboia Russellii), native of Ceylon and India; -- called also cobra monil.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. tedre tydere, weak, tender
entry.def: Tender; soft; nice; -- now only used in tidbit.

entry.cs: Tidal air Physiol the air which passes in and out of the lungs in ordinary breathing. It varies from twenty to thirty cubic inches. Tidal basin a dock that is filled at the rising of the tide. Tidal wave. See Tide wave, under Tide. Cf. 4th Bore. A vast, swift wave caused by an earthquake or some extraordinary combination of natural causes. It rises far above high-water mark and is often very destructive upon low-lying coasts.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to tides; caused by tides; having tides; periodically rising and falling, or following and ebbing; as, tidal waters.
entry.q: The tidal wave of deeper souls Into our inmost being rolls, And lifts us unawares Out of all meaner cares.

sn.def: an unusually high wave from the sea, sometimes reaching far inland and causing great destruction, and usually caused by some event, such as an earthquake, far from the shore. In Japan, such a wave is called a tsunami.
an unusually large quantity of items or events requiring attention and causing strain on the capacity to handle them; as, a tidal wave of orders for a new product; a tidal wave of tourists.

entry.ety: Tid + bit
entry.def: A delicate or tender piece of anything eatable; a delicious morsel.
imp. of Tide v. i.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. tyderian to grow tender. See Tid
entry.def: To use with tenderness; to fondle.
A game in which the object is to snap small disks of plastic, bone, ivory, or the like, from a flat surface, as of a table, into a small cup or basket; -- called also tiddlywinks.
Same as Tiddledywinks.

entry.note: ☞ The flow or rising of the water is called flood tide, and the reflux, ebb tide.
entry.cs:
Atmospheric tides tidal movements of the atmosphere similar to those of the ocean, and produced in the same manner by the attractive forces of the sun and moon. Inferior tide. See under Inferior a.
To work double tides. See under Work v. t. Tide day the interval between the occurrences of two consecutive maxima of the resultant wave at the same place. Its length varies as the components of sun and moon waves approach to, or recede from, one another. A retardation from this cause is called the lagging of the tide, while the acceleration of the recurrence of high water is termed the priming of the tide. See Lag of the tide, under 2d Lag. Tide dial a dial to exhibit the state of the tides at any time. Tide gate. An opening through which water may flow freely when the tide sets in one direction, but which closes automatically and prevents the water from flowing in the other direction. Naut A place where the tide runs with great velocity, as through a gate. Tide gauge a gauge for showing the height of the tide; especially, a contrivance for registering the state of the tide continuously at every instant of time. Brande & C. Tide lock a lock situated between an inclosed basin, or a canal, and the tide water of a harbor or river, when they are on different levels, so that craft can pass either way at all times of the tide; -- called also guard lock. Tide mill. a A mill operated by the tidal currents. A mill for clearing lands from tide water. Tide rip a body of water made rough by the conflict of opposing tides or currents. Tide table a table giving the time of the rise and fall of the tide at any place. Tide water water affected by the flow of the tide; hence, broadly, the seaboard.
Tide waveorTidal wave
the swell of water as the tide moves. That of the ocean is called primitive; that of bays or channels derivative. See also tidal wave in the vocabulary. Whewell. Tide wheel a water wheel so constructed as to be moved by the ebb or flow of the tide.
entry.ety: AS. tīd time; akin to OS. & OFries. tīd, D. tijd, G. zeit, OHG. zīt, Icel. tī�, Sw. & Dan. tid, and probably to Skr. aditi unlimited, endless, where a- is a negative prefix. √58. Cf. Tidings Tidy Till prep. Time

sn.def: Time; period; season.
sn.q: This lusty summer'stide.
And rest their weary limbs a tide.
Which, at the appointed tide, Each one did make his bride.
At the tide of Christ his birth.

sn.def: The alternate rising and falling of the waters of the ocean, and of bays, rivers, etc., connected therewith. The tide ebbs and flows twice in each lunar day, or the space of a little more than twenty-four hours. It is occasioned by the attraction of the sun and moon (the influence of the latter being three times that of the former), acting unequally on the waters in different parts of the earth, thus disturbing their equilibrium. A high tide upon one side of the earth is accompanied by a high tide upon the opposite side. Hence, when the sun and moon are in conjunction or opposition, as at new moon and full moon, their action is such as to produce a greater than the usual tide, called the spring tide, as represented in the cut. When the moon is in the first or third quarter, the sun's attraction in part counteracts the effect of the moon's attraction, thus producing under the moon a smaller tide than usual, called the neap tide.
A stream; current; flood; as, a tide of blood.
sn.q: Let in thetideof knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide.

sn.def: Tendency or direction of causes, influences, or events; course; current.
sn.q: There is a tide in the affairs of men, Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune.

sn.def: Violent confluence.
The period of twelve hours.

entry.def: To cause to float with the tide; to drive or carry with the tide or stream.
entry.q: They are tided down the stream.

entry.ety: AS. tīdan to happen. See Tide n.

sn.def: To betide; to happen.
sn.q: What should us tide of this new law?

sn.def: To pour a tide or flood.
To work into or out of a river or harbor by drifting with the tide and anchoring when it becomes adverse.

entry.def: Affected by the tide; having a tide.
entry.q: ThetidedThames.

entry.def: Land that is overflowed by tide water; hence, land near the sea.
Having no tide.

sn.def: a mark on a shore line indicating the normal level of the water at high tide, caused by the action of the flowing water; sometimes also used for the mark left at the point of the normal low tide; -- called also high water mark.
the maximum level which some activity has reached and from which it has declined; -- called also high water mark.

entry.def: Swung by the tide when at anchor; -- opposed to wind-rode.

entries.entry: Tides"man n.; pl.Tidesmen. A customhouse officer who goes on board of a merchant ship to secure payment of the duties; a tidewaiter.

entry.def: A customhouse officer who watches the landing of goods from merchant vessels, in order to secure payment of duties.
Channel in which the tide sets.

entry.note: ☞ The “tidif” mentioned in Chaucer is by some supposed to be the titmouse, by others the wren.
entry.def: The blue titmouse.
In a tidy manner.
The quality or state of being tidy.
Tidings.

entry.note: ☞ Although tidings is plural in form, it has been used also as a singular. By Shakespeare it was used indiscriminately as a singular or plural.
entry.usage: Tidings News. The term news denotes recent intelligence from any quarter; the term tidings denotes intelligence expected from a particular quarter, showing what has there betided. We may be indifferent as to news, but are always more or less interested in tidings. We read the news daily; we wait for tidings respecting an absent friend or an impending battle. We may be curious to hear the news; we are always anxious for tidings.
entry.ety: OE. tidinge ti�inge tidinde, from or influenced by Icel. tī�indi; akin to Dan. tidende, Sw. tidning, G. zeung, AS. tīdan to happen, E. betide tide. See Tide v. i. & n.
entry.def: Account of what has taken place, and was not before known; news.
entry.q: I shall make my master glad with these tidings.
Full well the busy whisper, circling round, Conveyed the dismal tidings when he frowned.
Now near the tidings of our comfort is.
Tidings to the contrary Are brought your eyes.
Evil news rides post, while good news baits.
What tidings dost thou bring?

entry.def: The wren.
The goldcrest.

entry.ety: Tide + -logy
entry.def: A discourse or treatise upon the tides; that part of science which treats of tides.

entry.note: ☞ This name is probably applied also to other small singing birds, as the goldcrest.
entry.def: The wren; -- called also tiddy.
entry.q: The tidy for her notes as delicate as they.

entry.ety: From Tide time, season; cf. D. tijdig timely, G. zeitig, Dan. & Sw. tidig

sn.def: Being in proper time; timely; seasonable; favorable; as, tidy weather.
sn.q: If weather be fair and tidy.

sn.def: Arranged in good order; orderly; appropriate; neat; kept in proper and becoming neatness, or habitually keeping things so; as, a tidy lass; their dress is tidy; the apartments are well furnished and tidy .
sn.q: A tidy man, that tened [injured] me never.

entries.entry:
Ti"dy n.; pl.Tidies.
A cover, often of tatting, drawn work, or other ornamental work, for the back of a chair, the arms of a sofa, or the like.
A child's pinafore. Prov. Eng

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tidied; p. pr. & vb. n. Tidying
entry.def: To put in proper order; to make neat; as, to tidy a room; to tidy one's dress.
To make things tidy.
entry.q: I have tidied and tidied over and over again.

entry.def: A California composite plant (Layia platyglossa), the flower of which has yellow rays tipped with white.

entries.entry:
Tie
Bale tie a fastening for the ends of a hoop for a bale.
n.; pl.Ties #. AS. tēge t�ge tīge. √64. See Tie v. t.
A knot; a fastening.
A bond; an obligation, moral or legal; as, the sacred ties of friendship or of duty; the ties of allegiance. No distance breaks the tie of blood.
A knot of hair, as at the back of a wig.
An equality in numbers, as of votes, scores, etc., which prevents either party from being victorious; equality in any contest, as a race.
Arch. & Engin A beam or rod for holding two parts together; in railways, one of the transverse timbers which support the track and keep it in place.
Mus A line, usually straight, drawn across the stems of notes, or a curved line written over or under the notes, signifying that they are to be slurred, or closely united in the performance, or that two notes of the same pitch are to be sounded as one; a bind; a ligature.
pl. Low shoes fastened with lacings.

entry.cs: To ride and tie. See under Ride. To tie down. To fasten so as to prevent from rising. To restrain; to confine; to hinder from action. To tie up to confine; to restrain; to hinder from motion or action.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tied Obs. Tight); p. pr. & vb. n. Tying
entry.ety: OE. ti�en teyen, AS. tīgan tiégan, fr. teág teáh, a rope; akin to Icel. taug, and AS. teón to draw, to pull. See Tug v. t., and cf. Tow to drag

sn.def: To fasten with a band or cord and knot; to bind.
sn.q: Tiethe kine to the cart.
My son, keep thy father's commandment, and forsake not the law of thy mother: bind them continually upon thine heart, and tie them about thy neck.

sn.def: To form, as a knot, by interlacing or complicating a cord; also, to interlace, or form a knot in; as, to tie a cord to a tree; to knit; to knot.
sn.q: We do nottiethis knot with an intention to puzzle the argument.

sn.def: To unite firmly; to fasten; to hold.
sn.q: In bond of virtuous love together tied.

sn.def: To hold or constrain by authority or moral influence, as by knotted cords; to oblige; to constrain; to restrain; to confine.
sn.q: Not tied to rules of policy, you find Revenge less sweet than a forgiving mind.

sn.def: To unite, as notes, by a cross line, or by a curved line, or slur, drawn over or under them.
To make an equal score with, in a contest; to be even with.

entry.def: To make a tie; to make an equal score.
A flat bar used as a tie.
A beam acting as a tie, as at the bottom of a pair of principal rafters, to prevent them from thrusting out the wall. See Illust. of Timbers, under Roof.

entry.ety: Chinese, square of heavenly peace
entry.def: a large plaza in Beijing, China.

entry.ety: Sp., prop., tent, awning
entry.def: In Cuba, Mexico, etc., a booth, stall, or shop where merchandise is sold.
One who, or that which, ties.

entry.ety: See Tire a headdress
entry.def: A chold's apron covering the upper part of the body, and tied with tape or cord; a pinafore.

cs.cd: the ranges of fakes, or windings, of a cable, laid one within another when coiled.

entry.ety: Perhaps fr. OF. tire, F. tire; probably of Teutonic origin; cf. OHG. ziarī ornament, G. zier, AS. tīr glory, tiér row, rank. But cf. also F. tirer to draw, pull; of Teutonic origin. Cf. Attire v. t. Tire a headdress, but also Tirade
entry.def: A row or rank, especially one of two or more rows placed one above, or higher than, another; as, a tier of seats in a theater.

entry.ety: F. tierce a third, from tiers tierce, third, fr. L. tertius the third; akin to tres three. See Third Three, and cf. Terce Tercet Tertiary

sn.def: A cask whose content is one third of a pipe; that is, forty-two wine gallons; also, a liquid measure of forty-two wine, or thirty-five imperial, gallons.
A cask larger than a barrel, and smaller than a hogshead or a puncheon, in which salt provisions, rice, etc., are packed for shipment.
The third tone of the scale. See Mediant.
A sequence of three playing cards of the same suit. Tierce of ace, king, queen, is called tierce-major.
A position in thrusting or parrying in which the wrist and nails are turned downward.
The third hour of the day, or nine a. m,; one of the canonical hours; also, the service appointed for that hour.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Divided into three equal parts of three different tinctures; -- said of an escutcheon.

entry.ety: OE. tercel tercelet, F. tiercelet, a dim. of (assumedtiercel, or LL. tertiolus, dim. fr. L. tertius the third; -- so called, according to some, because every third bird in the nest is a male, or, according to others, because the male is the third part less than female. Cf. Tercel
entry.def: The male of various falcons, esp. of the peregrine; also, the male of the goshawk.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tierce majeure
entry.def: See Tierce, 4.

entry.ety: F. tercet. See Tercet
entry.def: A triplet; three lines, or three lines rhyming together.
A rod used as a tie. See Tie.

entries.entry: Tiers` é`tat" Tiers` é`tat" ☞ The refusal of the clergy and nobility to give the tiers état a representation in the States-general proportioned to their actual numbers had an important influence in bringing on the French Revolution of 1789. Since that time the term has been purely historical.. F The third estate, or commonalty, in France, answering to the commons in Great Britain; -- so called in distinction from, and as inferior to, the nobles and clergy.
Tie"tick n. The meadow pipit. Prov. Eng.

entry.def: A wig having a tie or ties, or one having some of the curls tied up; also, a wig tied upon the head.

entry.ety: Originally, a sniff, sniffing; cf. Icel. �efr a smell, �efa to sniff, Norw. tev a drawing in of the breath, teva to sniff, smell, dial. Sw. tüv smell, scent, taste

sn.def: Liquor; especially, a small draught of liquor.
sn.q: Sipping histiffof brandy punch.

sn.def: A fit of anger or peevishness; a slight altercation or contention. See Tift.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tiffed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tiffing
entry.def: To be in a pet.
entry.q: She tiffed with Tim, she ran from Ralph.

entry.ety: OE. tiffen, OF. tiffer tifer, to bedizen; cf. D. tippen to clip the points or ends of the hair, E. tip, n
entry.def: To deck out; to dress.

entry.ety: OE. tiffenay; cf. OF. tiffe ornament, tiffer to adjust, adorn. See Tiff to dress
entry.def: A species of gause, or very silk.
entry.q: The smoke of sulphur . . . is commonly used by women to whiten tiffanies.

entry.ety: After Louis Comfort Tiffany

sn.def: made of stained glass by, or in the style of objects made by, Louis C. Tiffany ; as, a Tiffany lamp.
Made by or purchased from the Tiffany corporationwith headquarters in New York City); as, Tiffany jewelry.

entry.ety: Properly, tiffing a quaffing, a drinking. See Tiff n.
entry.def: A lunch, or slight repast between breakfast and dinner; -- originally, a Provincial English word, but introduced into India, and brought back to England in a special sense.
Inclined to tiffs; peevish; petulant.

entry.ety: Cf. Norw. teft a scent. See Tiff n.
entry.def: A fit of pettishness, or slight anger; a tiff.
entry.q: After all your fatigue you seem as ready for a tift with me as if you had newly come from church.

sn.def: A game among children. See Tag.
A capacious, flat-bottomed drinking cup, generally with four handles, formerly used for passing around the table at convivial entertainment.

entry.ety: NL., from F. tige stem or stock
entry.def: That part of an embryo which represents the young stem; the caulicle or radicle.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Same as Tigella.

entry.cs: American tiger. Zoöl The puma. The jaguar. Clouded tiger Zoöl a handsome striped and spotted carnivore (Felis macrocelis or Felis marmorata) native of the East Indies and Southern Asia. Its body is about three and a half feet long, and its tail about three feet long. Its ground color is brownish gray, and the dark markings are irregular stripes, spots, and rings, but there are always two dark bands on the face, one extending back from the eye, and one from the angle of the mouth. Called also tortoise-shell tiger. Mexican tiger Zoöl the jaguar. Tiger beetle Zoöl any one of numerous species of active carnivorous beetles of the family Cicindelidæ. They usually inhabit dry or sandy places, and fly rapidly. Tiger bittern. Zoöl See Sun bittern, under Sun. Tiger cat Zoöl any one of several species of wild cats of moderate size with dark transverse bars or stripes somewhat resembling those of the tiger. Tiger flower Bot an iridaceous plant of the genus Tigridiaas Tigridia conchiflora Tigridia grandiflora, etc.) having showy flowers, spotted or streaked somewhat like the skin of a tiger. Tiger grass Bot a low East Indian fan palm (Chamærops Ritchieana). It is used in many ways by the natives. J. Smith (Dict. Econ. Plants). Tiger lily. Bot See under Lily. Tiger moth Zoöl any one of numerous species of moths of the family Arctiadæ which are striped or barred with black and white or with other conspicuous colors. The larvæ are called woolly bears. Tiger shark Zoöl a voracious shark (Galeocerdo tigrinus syn. Galeocerdo maculatus) more or less barred or spotted with yellow. It is found in both the Atlantic and Indian Ocean. Called also zebra shark. Tiger shell Zoöl a large and conspicuously spotted cowrie (Cypræa tigris); -- so called from its fancied resemblance to a tiger in color and markings. Called also tiger cowrie. Tiger snake Zoöl either of two very venomous snakes of Tasmania and Australia, Notechis scutatis and Notechis ater, which grow up to 5 feet in length. Tiger wolf Zoöl the spotted hyena (Hyæna crocuta). Tiger wood the variegated heartwood of a tree (Machærium Schomburgkii) found in Guiana.
entry.ety: OE. tigre, F. tigre, L. tigris, Gr. ti`gris; probably of Persian origin; cf. Zend tighra pointed, tighri an arrow, Per. tīr; perhaps akin to E. stick, v. t.; -- probably so named from its quickness.]

sn.def: A very large and powerful carnivore (Felis tigris) native of Southern Asia and the East Indies. Its back and sides are tawny or rufous yellow, transversely striped with black, the tail is ringed with black, the throat and belly are nearly white. When full grown, it equals or exceeds the lion in size and strength. Called also royal tiger, and Bengal tiger.
Fig.: A ferocious, bloodthirsty person.
sn.q: As for heinous tiger, Tamora.

sn.def: A servant in livery, who rides with his master or mistress.
A kind of growl or screech, after cheering; as, three cheers and a tiger .
A pneumatic box or pan used in refining sugar.

entry.def: A siliceous stone of a yellow color and chatoyant luster, obtained in South Africa and much used for ornament. It is an altered form of the mineral crocidolite. See Crocidolite.
Same as Tiger's-foot.
Hastening to devour; furious.
Tigerish; tigrine.
Like a tiger; tigrish.
A name given to some species of morning-glory (Ipomœa) having the leaves lobed in pedate fashion.

entry.ety: Perhaps akin to tight
entry.def: A close, or inclosure; a croft.
p. p. of Tie.

entry.ety: OE. tight thiht; probably of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. þēttr, Dan. tæt, Sw. tät: akin to D. & G. dicht thick, tight, and perhaps to E. thee to thrive, or to thick. Cf. Taut

sn.def: Firmly held together; compact; not loose or open; as, tight cloth; a tight knot.

Close, so as not to admit the passage of a liquid or other fluid; not leaky; as, a tight ship; a tight cask; a tight room; -- often used in this sense as the second member of a compound; as, water-tight; air-tight.
Fitting close, or too close, to the body; as, a tight coat or other garment.
Not ragged; whole; neat; tidy.
sn.q: Clad very plain, but clean and tight.
I'll spin and card, and keep our children tight.

sn.def: Close; parsimonious; saving; as, a man tight in his dealings.
Not slack or loose; firmly stretched; taut; -- applied to a rope, chain, or the like, extended or stretched out.
Handy; adroit; brisk.
Somewhat intoxicated; tipsy.
Pressing; stringent; not easy; firmly held; dear; -- said of money or the money market. Cf. Easy, 7.

entry.def: To tighten.

cs.cd: a pulley which rests, or is forced, against a driving belt to tighten it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tightened; p. pr. & vb. n. Tightening
entry.def: To draw tighter; to straiten; to make more close in any manner.
entry.q: Just where I please, with tightened rein I'll urge thee round the dusty plain.

entry.def: That which tightens; specifically Mach, a tightening pulley.
A ribbon or string used to draw clothes closer.
In a tight manner; closely; nearly.
The quality or condition of being tight.
Close-fitting garments, especially for the lower part of the body and the legs.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C4H7CO2Hcalled also methyl crotonic acid), homologous with crotonic acid, and obtained from croton oil (from Croton Tiglium) as a white crystalline substance.

entry.ety: From Tiger: cf. F. tigresse
entry.def: The female of the tiger.

entry.ety: L. tigrinus, fr. tigris a tiger

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a tiger; like a tiger.
Resembling the tiger in color; as, the tigrine cat (Felis tigrina) of South America.

entry.def: Resembling a tiger; tigerish.
A tick. See 2d Tick.

entry.ety: Icel. tīk a bitch; akin to Sw. tik

sn.def: A dog; a cur.
sn.q: Bobtailtikeor trundle-tail.

sn.def: A countryman or clown; a boorish, clumsy, or eccentric person; -- also spelled tyke.
a small child; -- variant of tyke.

entry.ety: Hind. tikhur
entry.def: A starch or arrow-root made from the tubes of an East Indian zinziberaceous plant (Curcuma angustifolia); also, the plant itself.

entry.ety: Hind. tikūr
entry.def: An East Indian tree (Garcinia pedunculata) having a large yellow fleshy fruit with a pleasant acid flavor.
The bulau.
See Till.

entries.entry:
Til"bu*ry n.; pl.Tilburies #. Probably from Tilburyfort, in the Country of Essex, in England A kind of gig or two-wheeled carriage, without a top or cover.
tilburgh

entry.ety: Sp., fr. L. titulus a superscription, title, token, sign. See Title n.
entry.def: The accentual mark placed over n, and sometimes over l, in Spanish words [thus, ñ�], indicating that, in pronunciation, the sound of the following vowel is to be preceded by that of the initial, or consonantal, y.

entry.ety: See 2d Tiler
entry.def: To protect from the intrusion of the uninitiated; as, to tile a Masonic lodge.

cs.cd: a drain made of tiles.
a species of strong, clayey earth; stiff and stubborn land.
a kiln in which tiles are burnt; a tilery.
an earthy variety of cuprite.
light red like the color of tiles or bricks.
a kind of hard, flat brick tea. See Brick tea, under Brick.

entry.ety: OE. tile tigel, AS. tigel tigol, fr. L. tegula, from tegere to cover. See Thatch, and cf. Tegular

sn.def: A plate, or thin piece, of baked clay, used for covering the roofs of buildings, for floors, for drains, and often for ornamental mantel works.

sd.def: A small slab of marble or other material used for flooring.
A plate of metal used for roofing.

sn.def: A small, flat piece of dried earth or earthenware, used to cover vessels in which metals are fused.
A draintile.
A stiff hat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tiled; p. pr. & vb. n. Tiling

sn.def: To cover with tiles; as, to tile a house.
Fig.: To cover, as if with tiles.
sn.q: The muscle, sinew, and vein, Which tile this house, will come again.

entry.def: To drain by means of tiles; to furnish with a tile drain.

entry.note: ☞ It was discovered off the Eastern coast of the United States in 1880, and was abundant in 1881, but is believed to have become extinct in 1882.
entry.def: A large, edible, deep-water food fish (Lopholatilus chamæleonticeps) more or less thickly covered with large, round, yellow spots.
A man whose occupation is to cover buildings with tiles.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin, but probably from E. tile, n
entry.def: A doorkeeper or attendant at a lodge of Freemasons.

entries.entry:
Til"er*y n.; pl.Tileries #. From Tile; cf. F. tuilerie, fr. tuile a tile, L. tegula
A place where tiles are made or burned; a tile kiln.

entry.def: Any plant of the genus Geissois, having seeds overlapping like tiles on a roof.

sn.def: A kind of laminated shale or sandstone belonging to some of the layers of the Upper Silurian.
A tile of stone.

entry.ety: L., linden. Cf. Teil
entry.def: A genus of trees, the lindens, the type of the family Tiliaceæ, distinguished by the winglike bract coalescent with the peduncle, and by the indehiscent fruit having one or two seeds. There are about twenty species, natives of temperate regions. Many species are planted as ornamental shade trees, and the tough fibrous inner bark is a valuable article of commerce. Also, a plant of this genus.

entry.ety: OE. tilia the linden tree
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a natural family of plants (Tiliaceæ) of which the linden (Tilia) is the type. The family includes many plants which furnish a valuable fiber, as the jute.

sn.def: A surface covered with tiles, or composed of tiles.
sn.q: They . . . let him down through the tiling.

sn.def: Tiles, collectively.

entry.ety: Abbrev. from lentil
entry.def: A vetch; a tare.

entries.entry:
Till
Till alarm a device for sounding an alarm when a money drawer is opened or tampered with.
n. Properly, a drawer, from OE. tillen to draw. See Tiller the lever of a rudder A drawer. Specifically: A tray or drawer in a chest. A money drawer in a shop or store.

sn.def: A deposit of clay, sand, and gravel, without lamination, formed in a glacier valley by means of the waters derived from the melting glaciers; -- sometimes applied to alluvium of an upper river terrace, when not laminated, and appearing as if formed in the same manner.
A kind of coarse, obdurate land.

cs.cd: to the present time.
to that time.

entry.ety: OE. til, Icel. til; akin to Dan. til, Sw. till, OFries. til, also to AS. til good, excellent, G. ziel end, limit, object, OHG. zil, Goth. tils, gatils, fit, convenient, and E. till to cultivate. See Till v. t.
entry.def: To; unto; up to; as far as; until; -- now used only in respect to time, but formerly, also, of place, degree, etc., and still so used in Scotland and in parts of England and Ireland; as, I worked till four o'clock; I will wait till next week.
entry.q: He . . . came till an house.
Women, up till this Cramped under worse than South-sea-isle taboo.
Similar sentiments will recur to every one familiar with his writings -- all through them till the very end.

entry.note: ☞ This use may be explained by supposing an ellipsis of when, or the time when, the proper conjunction or conjunctive adverb begin when.
entry.def: As far as; up to the place or degree that; especially, up to the time that; that is, to the time specified in the sentence or clause following; until.
entry.q: And said unto them, Occupy till I come.
Mediate so long till you make some act of prayer to God.
There was no outbreak till the regiment arrived.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Tilling
entry.ety: OE. tilen tilien, AS. tilian teolian, to aim, strive for, till; akin to OS. tilian to get, D. telen to propagate, G. zielen to aim, ziel an end, object, and perhaps also to E. tide time, from the idea of something fixed or definite. Cf. Teal Till prep.

sn.def: To plow and prepare for seed, and to sow, dress, raise crops from, etc., to cultivate; as, to till the earth, a field, a farm.
sn.q: No field nolde [would nottilye.
the Lord God sent him forth from the garden of Eden, to till the ground from whence he was taken.

sn.def: To prepare; to get.

entry.def: To cultivate land.
Capable of being tilled; fit for the plow; arable.

sn.def: The operation, practice, or art of tilling or preparing land for seed, and keeping the ground in a proper state for the growth of crops.
A place tilled or cultivated; cultivated land.
sn.syn: Cultivation; culture; husbandry; farming; agriculture.

entry.note: Tillandsia usneoides, called Spanish moss long moss black moss, and Florida moss, has a very slender pendulous branching stem, and forms great hanging tufts on the branches of trees in the Southeastern United States and south to Argentina. It is often used for stuffing mattresses
entry.ety: NL., after Prof. Tillands, of Abo, in Finland
entry.def: An immense genus of epiphytic bromeliaceous plants confined to tropical and subtropical America. They usually bear a rosette of narrow overlapping basal leaves, which often hold a considerable quantity of water. The spicate or paniculate flowers have free perianth segments, and are often subtended by colored bracts. Also, a plant of this genus.

entry.ety: From Till v. t.
entry.def: One who tills; a husbandman; a cultivator; a plowman.

entry.ety: AS. telgor a small branch. Cf. Till to cultivate

sd.def: A shoot of a plant, springing from the root or bottom of the original stalk; a sucker.
A sprout or young tree that springs from a root or stump.

sn.def: A young timber tree.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tillered; p. pr. & vb. n. Tillering
entry.def: To put forth new shoots from the root, or round the bottom of the original stalk; as, wheat or rye tillers; some spread plants by tillering.

cs.cd: a rope for turning a tiller. In a large vessel it forms the connection between the fore end of the tiller and the steering wheel.

entry.ety: From OE. tillen tullen, to draw, pull; probably fr. AS. tyllan in fortyllan to lead astray; or cf. D. tillen to lift up. Cf. Till a drawer

sn.def: A lever of wood or metal fitted to the rudder head and used for turning side to side in steering. In small boats hand power is used; in large vessels, the tiller is moved by means of mechanical appliances. See Illust. of Rudder. Cf. 2d Helm, 1.
The stalk, or handle, of a crossbow; also, sometimes, the bow itself.
sn.q: You can shoot in a tiller.

sn.def: The handle of anything.
A small drawer; a till.

entries.entry:
Til"ley n.orTil"ley seed` . Bot The seeds of a small tree (Croton Pavana) common in the Malay Archipelago. These seeds furnish croton oil, like those of Croton Tiglium.
tilly
Till"man n.; pl.Tillmen. A man who tills the earth; a husbandman. Obs

entry.def: One of the Tillodontia.
An extinct group of Mammalia found fossil in the Eocene formation. The species are related to the carnivores, ungulates, and rodents. Called also Tillodonta.
A bag made of thin glazed muslin, used as a wrapper for dress goods.
See 3d Tiller.
A word of unknown origin and signification, formerly used as expressive of contempt, or when anything said was rejected as trifling or impertinent.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. tilmo`s, fr. ti`llein to pluck, pull
entry.def: Floccillation.

entries.entry: Til seed tĭl; tēl. The seed of sesame. The seed of an African asteraceous plant (Guizotia abyssinica), yielding a bland fixed oil used in medicine.

cs.cd: a boat covered with canvas or other cloth.
a round-headed roof, like the canopy of a wagon.

entry.ety: OE. teltperhaps from the Danish), teld, AS. teld, geteld; akin to OD. telde, G. zelt, Icel. tjald, Sw. tält tjäll, Dan. telt, and AS. beteldan to cover

sn.def: A covering overhead; especially, a tent.
The cloth covering of a cart or a wagon.
A cloth cover of a boat; a small canopy or awning extended over the sternsheets of a boat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tilted; p. pr. & vb. n. Tilting
entry.def: To cover with a tilt, or awning.

entry.ety: OE. tilten tulten, to totter, fall, AS. tealt unstable, precarious; akin to tealtrian to totter, to vacillate, D. tel amble, ambling pace, G. zelt, Icel. tölt an ambling pace, tölta to amble. Cf. Totter

sn.def: To incline; to tip; to raise one end of for discharging liquor; as, to tilt a barrel.
To point or thrust, as a lance.
sn.q: Sons against fathers tilt the fatal lance.

sn.def: To point or thrust a weapon at.
To hammer or forge with a tilt hammer; as, to tilt steel in order to render it more ductile.

To run or ride, and thrust with a lance; to practice the military game or exercise of thrusting with a lance, as a combatant on horseback; to joust; also, figuratively, to engage in any combat or movement resembling that of horsemen tilting with lances.
sn.q: He tilts With piercing steel at bold Mercutio's breast.
Swords out, and tilting one at other's breast.
But in this tournament can no man tilt.
The fleet, swift tilting, o'er the �urges flew.

sn.def: To lean; to fall partly over; to tip.
sn.q: The trunk of the body is kept from tilting forward by the muscles of the back.

cs.cd: with full force.

sn.def: A thrust, as with a lance.
A military exercise on horseback, in which the combatants attacked each other with lances; a tournament.
See Tilt hammer, in the Vocabulary.
Inclination forward; as, the tilt of a cask.
One who tilts, or jousts; hence, one who fights.
sn.q: Let me alone to match your tilter.

sn.def: One who operates a tilt hammer.

entry.ety: AS. til�, fr. tilian to till. See Till to cultivate

sn.def: The state of being tilled, or prepared for a crop; culture; as, land is good tilth .
sn.q: The tilth and rank fertility of its golden youth.

sn.def: That which is tilled; tillage ground.
sn.q: And so by tilth and grange . . . We gained the mother city.

entries.entry: Tilt" ham`mer. A tilted hammer; a heavy hammer, used in iron works, which is lifted or tilted by projections or wipers on a revolving shaft; a trip hammer.

cs.cd: a helmet of large size and unusual weight and strength, worn at tilts.

sn.def: The act of one who tilts; a tilt.
The process by which blister steel is rendered ductile by being forged with a tilt hammer.

entry.def: A mill where a tilt hammer is used, or where the process of tilting is carried on.

entries.entry: Til tree tĭl; tēl. Bot Var. of Teil tree. An ill-smelling lauraceous tree (Ocotea fœtens) of the Canary Islands; -- sometimes distinguished as Canary Island til tree.

entry.def: Same as Tip-up.
A yard or place for tilting.
entry.q: Thetilt-yardof Templestowe.

entry.def: The blue titmouse.
Of or pertaining to the genus Timalus or family Timalidæ, which includes the babblers thrushes, and bulbuls.
A kettledrum. See Tymbal.

entry.ety: [F., prop., a kettledrum; -- so named from the form of the mold used. Cf. Timbal
entry.def: A seasoned preparation, as of chicken, lobster, cheese, or fish, cooked in a drum-shaped mold; also, a pastry case, usually small, filled with a cooked mixture.

entry.ety: Probably the same word as timber sort of wood; cf. Sw. timber, LG. timmer, MHG. zimber, G. zimmer, F. timbre, LL. timbrium. Cf. Timmer
entry.def: A certain quantity of fur skins, as of martens, ermines, sables, etc., packed between boards; being in some cases forty skins, in others one hundred and twenty; -- called also timmer.

entry.ety: F. timbre. See Timbre
entry.def: The crest on a coat of arms.
To surmount as a timber does.

entry.cs: Timber and room. Shipbuilding Same as Room and space. See under Room. Timber beetle Zoöl any one of numerous species of beetles the larvæ of which bore in timber; as, the silky timber beetle Lymexylon sericeum . Timber doodle Zoöl the American woodcock. Local, U. S Timber grouse Zoöl any species of grouse that inhabits woods, as the ruffed grouse and spruce partridge; -- distinguished from prairie grouse. Timber hitch Naut a kind of hitch used for temporarily marking fast a rope to a spar. See Illust. under Hitch. Timber mare a kind of instrument upon which soldiers were formerly compelled to ride for punishment. Johnson. Timber scribe a metal tool or pointed instrument for marking timber. Simmonds. Timber sow. Zoöl Same as Timber worm, below. Bacon. Timber tree a tree suitable for timber. Timber worm Zoöl any larval insect which burrows in timber. Timber yard a yard or place where timber is deposited.
entry.ety: AS. timbor timber, wood, building; akin to OFries. timber, D. timmer a room, G. zimmer, OHG. zimbar timber, a dwelling, room, Icel. timbr timber, Sw. timmer, Dan. tömmer, Goth. timrjan to build, timrja a builder, L. domus a house, Gr. � house, � to build, Skr. dama a house. √62. Cf. Dome Domestic

sn.def: That sort of wood which is proper for buildings or for tools, utensils, furniture, carriages, fences, ships, and the like; -- usually said of felled trees, but sometimes of those standing. Cf. Lumber, 3.
sn.q: And ta'en my fiddle to the gate, . . . And fiddled in the timber!

sn.def: The body, stem, or trunk of a tree.
Fig.: Material for any structure.
sn.q: Such dispositions are the very errors of human nature; and yet they are the fittest timber to make politics of.

sn.def: A single piece or squared stick of wood intended for building, or already framed; collectively, the larger pieces or sticks of wood, forming the framework of a house, ship, or other structure, in distinction from the covering or boarding.
sn.q: So they prepared timber . . . to build the house.
Many of the timbers were decayed.

sn.def: Woods or forest; wooden land.
A rib, or a curving piece of wood, branching outward from the keel and bending upward in a vertical direction. One timber is composed of several pieces united.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Timbered; p. pr. & vb. n. Timbering
entry.def: To furnish with timber; -- chiefly used in the past participle.
entry.q: His bark is stoutly timbered.

sn.def: To light on a tree.
To make a nest.
Furnished with timber; -- often compounded; as, a well-timbered house; a low-timbered house.
Built; formed; contrived.
Massive, like timber.
sn.q: His timbered bones all broken, rudely rumbled.

sn.def: Covered with growth timber; wooden; as, well-timbered land.

entry.def: The top end of a timber, rising above the gunwale, and serving for belaying ropes, etc.; -- called also kevel head.
The act of furnishing with timber; also, timbers, collectively; timberwork; timber.

entry.ety: Timber + -ling
entry.def: A small tree.

entries.entry: Tim"ber*man n.; pl.Timbermen. Mining A man employed in placing supports of timber in a mine.

entry.def: Work made of timbers.
See 1st Timber.

entry.ety: F., a bell to be struck with a hammer, sound, tone, stamp, crest, in OF., a timbrel. Cf. Timbrel

sn.def: The crest on a coat of arms.
The quality or tone distinguishing voices or instruments; tone color; clang tint; as, the timbre of the voice; the timbre of a violin. See Tone, and Partial tones, under Partial.

entry.ety: Dim. of OE. timbre, OF. timbre; probably fr. L. typmanum, Gr. � a kettledrum, but influenced perhaps by Ar. tabl a drum; cf. Per. tambal a drum. See Tympanum, and cf. 2d Timbre Tymbal
entry.def: A kind of drum, tabor, or tabret, in use from the highest antiquity.
entry.q: Miriam . . . took a timbrel in her hand, and all the women went out after her with timbrels and with dances.
