sn.def: To stumble.
To rock or roll, as a curved body on a plane.

entry.ety: L. titubatio: cf. F. titubation
entry.def: The act of stumbling, rocking, or rolling; a reeling.

entry.cs: Titular bishop. See under Bishop.
entry.ety: F. titulaire, fr. L. titulus. See Title
entry.def: Existing in title or name only; nominal; having the title to an office or dignity without discharging its appropriate duties; as, a titular prince.
entry.q: If these magnificent titles yet remain Not merely titular.

entry.def: A titulary.
The quality or state of being titular.
In a titular manner; nominally; by title only.

entries.entry:
Tit"u*la*ry n.; pl.Titularies #. Cf. F. titulaire
A person invested with a title, in virtue of which he holds an office or benefice, whether he performs the duties of it or not.

sn.def: Consisting in a title; titular.
Of or pertaining to a title.

entry.def: Having a title.

entry.ety: AS. teáfor teáfur
entry.def: A kind of ocher which is used in some parts of England in marking sheep.
To mark with tiver.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. Tivoli in Italy, a pleasure resort not far from Rome
See Tantivy
entry.def: With great speed; -- a huntsman's word or sound.

entry.ety: CF. Sp. tiza whitening, a kind of chalk or pipe clay
entry.def: See Ulexite.

The Indians of a seafaring group of tribes of southern Alaska comprising the Koluschan stock. Previous to deterioration from contact with the whites they were the foremost traders of the northwest. They built substantial houses of cedar adorned with totem poles, and were expert stone carvers and copper workers. Slavery, the potlatch, and the use of immense labrets were characteristic. Many now work in the salmon industry.
Same as T cell.

entry.ety: L., from Gr. tmh^sis a cutting, fr. te`mnein to cut
entry.def: The separation of the parts of a compound word by the intervention of one or more words; as, in what place soever, for whatsoever place .

entry.ety: AS. to- asunder; akin to G. zer-, and perhaps to L. dis-, or Gr. �
entry.def: An obsolete intensive prefix used in the formation of compound verbs; as in to-beat, to-break, to-hew, to-rend, to-tear. See these words in the Vocabulary. See the Note on All to, or All-to, under All adv.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly, by omission of the verb denoting motion, to sometimes followed a form of be, with the sense of at, or in. “When the sun was [gone or declinedto rest.” Chaucer.
Such usage is now obsolete or illiterate. In colloquial usage, to often stands for, and supplies, an infinitive already mentioned; thus, he commands me to go with him, but I do not wish to.

☞ To in to-day to-night, and to-morrow has the sense or force of for or on; for, or on, (this) day, for, or on, (this) night, for, or on, (the) morrow. To-day to-night to-morrow may be considered as compounds, and usually as adverbs; but they are sometimes used as nouns; as, to-day is ours. To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow; Creeps in this petty pace from day to day. Shak.

cs.cd: to and fro.
forward and back. In this phrase, to is adverbial.
cs.q: There was great showing both to and fro.
cs.cd: a pacing backward and forward; as, to commence a to-and-fro.
in front of; in behind; hence, in the presence of.
to know; namely. See Wit v. i.

entry.note: ☞ To, without an object expressed, is used adverbially; as, put to the door, i. e., put the door to its frame, close it; and in the nautical expressions, to heave to, to come to, meaning to a certain position. To, like on, is sometimes used as a command, forward set to. “To, Achilles! to, Ajax! to!” Shak.
entry.pr: �, emphatic or alone, �, obscure or unemphatic
entry.ety: AS. tō; akin to OS. & OFries. tō, D. toe, G. zu, OHG. zuo zua zō, Russ. do, Ir. & Gael. do, OL. -do -du, as in endo indu, in, Gr. �, as in � homeward. √200. Cf. Too Tatoo a beat of drums

sn.def: The preposition to primarily indicates approach and arrival, motion made in the direction of a place or thing and attaining it, access; and also, motion or tendency without arrival; movement toward; -- opposed to from.
sn.q: ToCanterbury they wend.
Stay with us, go not to Wittenberg.
So to the sylvan lodge They came, that like Pomona's arbor smiled.
I'll to him again, . . . He'll tell me all his purpose. She stretched her arms to heaven.

sn.def: Hence, it indicates motion, course, or tendency toward a time, a state or condition, an aim, or anything capable of being regarded as a limit to a tendency, movement, or action; as, he is going to a trade; he is rising to wealth and honor.

In a very general way, and with innumerable varieties of application, to connects transitive verbs with their remoter or indirect object, and adjectives, nouns, and neuter or passive verbs with a following noun which limits their action. Its sphere verges upon that of for, but it contains less the idea of design or appropriation; as, these remarks were addressed to a large audience; let us keep this seat to ourselves; a substance sweet to the taste; an event painful to the mind; duty to God and to our parents; a dislike to spirituous liquor.
sn.q: Marks and points out each man of us to slaughter.
Whilst they, distilled Almost to jelly with the act of fear, Stand dumb and speak not to him.

Add to your faith virtue; and to virtue knowledge; and to knowledge temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience godliness; and to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness charity.
I have a king's oath to the contrary.
Numbers were crowded to death.
Fate and the dooming gods are deaf to tears.
Go, buckle to the law.

sn.def: As sign of the infinitive, to had originally the use of last defined, governing the infinitive as a verbal noun, and connecting it as indirect object with a preceding verb or adjective; thus, ready to go, i.e., ready unto going; good to eat, i.e., good for eating; I do my utmost to lead my life pleasantly. But it has come to be the almost constant prefix to the infinitive, even in situations where it has no prepositional meaning, as where the infinitive is direct object or subject; thus, I love to learn, i.e., I love learning; to die for one's country is noble, i.e., the dying for one's country. Where the infinitive denotes the design or purpose, good usage formerly allowed the prefixing of for to the to; as, what went ye out for see? (Matt. xi. 8 .
sn.q: Then longen folk to go on pilgrimages, And palmers for to seeken strange stranders.

entry.sn:
In many phrases, and in connection with many other words, to has a pregnant meaning, or is used elliptically. Thus, it denotes or implies: Extent; limit; degree of comprehension; inclusion as far as; as, they met us to the number of three hundred. We ready are to try our fortunesTo the last man. Few of the Esquimaux can count to ten.
Effect; end; consequence; as, the prince was flattered to his ruin; he engaged in a war to his cost; violent factions exist to the prejudice of the state.
Apposition; connection; antithesis; opposition; as, they engaged hand to hand. Now we see through a glass, darkly; but then face to face.
Accord; adaptation; as, an occupation to his taste; she has a husband to her mind. He to God's image, she to his was made.
Comparison; as, three is to nine as nine is to twenty-seven; it is ten to one that you will offend him. All that they did was piety to this.
Addition; union; accumulation. Wisdom he has, and to his wisdom, courage.
Accompaniment; as, she sang to his guitar; they danced to the music of a piano. Anon they move In perfect phalanx to the Dorian mood Of flutes and soft recorders.
Character; condition of being; purpose subserved or office filled. In this sense archaic I have a king heretomy flatterer. Made his masters and others . . . to consider him to a little wonder.

entry.note: ☞ The common toad (Bufo vulgaris) and the natterjack are familiar European species. The common American toad (Bufo lentiginosus) is similar to the European toad, but is less warty and is more active, moving chiefly by leaping.
entry.cs: Obstetrical toad. Zoöl See under Obstetrical. Surinam toad. Zoöl See Pita. Toad lizard Zoöl a horned toad. Toad pipe Bot a hollow-stemmed plant (Equisetum limosum) growing in muddy places. Dr. Prior. Toad rush Bot a low-growing kind of rush (Juncus bufonius). Toad snatcher Zoöl the reed bunting. Prov. Eng Toad spittle. Zoöl See Cuckoo spit, under Cuckoo. Tree toad. Zoöl See under Tree.
entry.ety: OE. tode tade, AS. tādie tādige; of unknown origin. Cf. Tadpole
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of batrachians belonging to the genus Bufo and allied genera, especially those of the family Bufonidæ. Toads are generally terrestrial in their habits except during the breeding season, when they seek the water. Most of the species burrow beneath the earth in the daytime and come forth to feed on insects at night. Most toads have a rough, warty skin in which are glands that secrete an acrid fluid.

entry.ety: Said to be so called in allusion to an old alleged practice among mountebanks' boys of eating toads (popularly supposed to be poisonous), in order that their masters might have an opportunity of pretending to effect a cure. The French equivalent expression is un avaleur de couleuvres. Cf. Toady
entry.def: A fawning, obsequious parasite; a mean sycophant; a flatterer; a toady.
entry.q: You had nearly imposed upon me, but you have lost your labor. You're too zealous a toadeater, and betray yourself.

entry.def: Any marine fish of the genus Batrachus, having a large, thick head and a wide mouth, and bearing some resemblance to a toad. The American species (Batrachus tau) is very common in shallow water. Called also oyster fish, and sapo.
The angler.
A swellfish.
An herb (Linaria vulgaris) of the Figwort family, having narrow leaves and showy orange and yellow flowers; -- called also butter and eggs flaxweed, and ramsted.
The golden plover.
Like a toad.
A small toad.

sn.def: A local name for the igneous rocks of Derbyshire, England; -- said by some to be derived from the German todter stein, meaning dead stone, that is, stone which contains no ores.
Bufonite, formerly regarded as a precious stone, and worn as a jewel. See Bufonite.

entry.def: A name given to many umbrella-shaped fungi, mostly of the genus Agaricus. The species are almost numberless. They grow on decaying organic matter.

entries.entry:
Toad"y n.; pl.Toadies #. Shortened from toadeater
A mean flatterer; a toadeater; a sycophant. Before I had been standing at the window five minutes, they somehow conveyed to me that they were all toadies and humbugs.
A coarse, rustic woman. R

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toadied; p. pr. & vb. n. Toadying
entry.def: To fawn upon with mean sycophancy.
The practice of meanly fawning on another; base sycophancy; servile adulation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Toasting
entry.ety: OF. toster to roast, toast, fr. L. torrere tostum, to parch, roast. See Torrid

sn.def: To dry and brown by the heat of a fire; as, to toast bread.
To warm thoroughly; as, to toast the feet.
To name when a health is proposed to be drunk; to drink to the health, or in honor, of; as, to toast a lady.

cs.cd: a small rack or stand for a table, having partitions for holding slices of dry toast.

entry.ety: OF. toste, or tostée, toasted bread. See Toast v.

sn.def: Bread dried and browned before a fire, usually in slices; also, a kind of food prepared by putting slices of toasted bread into milk, gravy, etc.
sn.q: My sober evening let the tankard bless, With toast embrowned, and fragrant nutmeg fraught.

sn.def: A lady in honor of whom persons or a company are invited to drink; -- so called because toasts were formerly put into the liquor, as a great delicacy.
sn.q: It now came to the time of Mr. Jones to give a toast . . . who could not refrain from mentioning his dear Sophia.

sn.def: Hence, any person, especially a person of distinction, in honor of whom a health is drunk; hence, also, anything so commemorated; a sentiment, as “The land we live in,” “The day we celebrate,” etc.
One who toasts.
A kitchen utensil for toasting bread, cheese, etc.

cs.cd: a long-handled fork for toasting bread, cheese, or the like, by the fire.

entry.def: a. & n. from Toast v.
A person who presides at a public dinner or banquet, and announces the toasts.
The handle of a joiner's plane.

entry.note: ☞ The name is extended to other species of the genus, and to some unrelated plants, as Indian tobacco (Nicotiana rustica, and also Lobelia inflata), mountain tobacco (Arnica montana), and Shiraz tobacco (Nicotiana Persica).
entry.cs: Tobacco box Zoöl the common American skate. Tobacco camphor. Chem See Nicotianine. Tobacco man a tobacconist. R Tobacco pipe. A pipe used for smoking, made of baked clay, wood, or other material. Bot Same as Indian pipe, under Indian. Tobacco-pipe clay Min a species of clay used in making tobacco pipes; -- called also cimolite. Tobacco-pipe fish. Zoöl See Pipemouth. Tobacco stopper a small plug for pressing down the tobacco in a pipe as it is smoked. Tobacco worm Zoöl the larva of a large hawk moth (Sphinx Carolina syn. Phlegethontius Carolina). It is dark green, with seven oblique white stripes bordered above with dark brown on each side of the body. It feeds upon the leaves of tobacco and tomato plants, and is often very injurious to the tobacco crop. See Illust. of Hawk moth.
entry.ety: Sp. tabaco, fr. the Indian tabaco the tube or pipe in which the Indians or Caribbees smoked this plant. Some derive the word from Tabaco, a province of Yucatan, where it was said to be first found by the Spaniards; others from the island of Tobago, one of the Caribbees. But these derivations are very doubtful

sn.def: An American plant (Nicotiana Tabacum) of the Nightshade family, much used for smoking and chewing, and as snuff. As a medicine, it is narcotic, emetic, and cathartic. Tobacco has a strong, peculiar smell, and an acrid taste.
The leaves of the plant prepared for smoking, chewing, etc., by being dried, cured, and manufactured in various ways.

entry.def: Smoking tobacco.
entry.q: Tobacconingis but a smoky play.

sn.def: A dealer in tobacco; also, a manufacturer of tobacco.
A smoker of tobacco.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + beat
entry.def: To beat thoroughly or severely.

entries.entry: To*bi"as fish`. See the Note under Asmodeus, in the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction Zoöl The lant, or sand eel.

entry.ety: Cf. Toby
entry.def: A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered at one end.

entry.ety: Cf. G. tobin, D. tabijn. See Tabby
entry.def: A stout twilled silk used for dresses.
A book of the Apocrypha.

entry.ety: Corruption of American Indian odabagan a sled
entry.def: A kind of sledge made of pliable board, turned up at one or both ends, used for coasting down hills or prepared inclined planes; also, a sleigh or sledge, to be drawn by dogs, or by hand, over soft and deep snow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tobogganed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tobogganing
entry.def: To slide down hill over the snow or ice on a toboggan.
One who practices tobogganing.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + break
entry.def: To break completely; to break in pieces.
entry.q: With nose and mouth to-broke.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + brest
entry.def: To burst or break in pieces.

entries.entry: To"by n.; pl. -bies # . Perh. from the proper name A small jug, pitcher, or mug, generally used for ale, shaped somewhat like a stout man, with a cocked hat forming the brim.

entry.ety: It., fr. toccare to touch. See Touch
entry.def: An old form of piece for the organ or harpsichord, somewhat in the free and brilliant style of the prelude fantasia, or capriccio.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: A short or simple toccata.

entry.ety: Gael. tochradh
entry.def: Dowry brought by a bride to her husband.
A spotted lizard native of India.
A toucan (Ramphastos toco) having a very large beak. See Illust. under Toucan.

entry.ety: Gr. � a birth + -logy
entry.def: The science of obstetrics, or midwifery; that department of medicine which treats of parturition.

entry.ety: Probably from the native name through the Spanish: cf. Sp. tocororo
entry.def: A cuban trogon (Priotelus temnurus) having a serrated bill and a tail concave at the end.

entry.ety: F., fr. OF. toquier to touch, F. toqueroriginally, a dialectic form of F. toucher) + seintfor sein) a bell, LL. signum, fr. L. signum a sign, signal. See Touch, and Sign
entry.def: An alarm bell, or the ringing of a bell for the purpose of alarm.
entry.q: The loud tocsin tolled their last alarm.

cs.cd: a close stove adapted for burning small round wood, twigs, etc.

entry.ety: Akin to D. todde a rag, G. zotte shag, rag, a tuft of hair, Icel. toddi a piece of a thing, a tod of wool

sn.def: A bush; a thick shrub; a bushy clump.
sn.q: An ivytodde.
The ivy tod is heavy with snow.

sn.def: An old weight used in weighing wool, being usually twenty-eight pounds.
A fox; -- probably so named from its bushy tail.
sn.q: The wolf, the tod, the brock.

entry.def: To weigh; to yield in tods.

entry.ety: AS. tō dæg. See To prep., and Day
entry.def: On this day; on the present day.
entry.q: Worcester's horse came but to-day.

entry.def: The present day.
entry.q: On to-day Is worth for me a thousand yesterdays.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toddled; p. pr. & vb. n. Toddling
entry.ety: Akin to tottle totter
entry.def: To walk with short, tottering steps, as a child.
A toddling walk.
One who toddles; especially, a young child.

entry.note: ☞ Toddy differs from grog in having a less proportion of spirit, and is being made hot and sweetened.

cs.cd: a weaver bird of the East Indies and India: -- so called from its fondness for the juice of the palm.
the common paradoxure; the palm cat.

entry.ety: Formed from Hind. tā�ī the juice of the palmyra tree, popularly, toddy, fr. tā� the palmyra tree, Skr. tāla

sn.def: A juice drawn from various kinds of palms in the East Indies; or, a spirituous liquor procured from it by fermentation.
A mixture of spirit and hot water sweetened.

entry.ety: To + do. Cf. Ado
entry.def: Bustle; stir; commotion; ado.

entries.entry:
To"dy n.; pl. Todies #. Cf. NL. todus, F. todier, G. todvogel
Zoöl Any one of several species of small insectivorous West Indian birds of the genus Todus. They are allied to the kingfishers.

cs.cd: a tadpole; a polliwig.
a morbid condition of the foot in which the toe is depressed and the heel elevated, as in talipes equinus. See Talipes.

entry.ety: OE. too taa, AS. tā; akin to D. teen, G. zehe, OHG. zēha, Icel. tā, Sw. tå, Dan. taa; of uncertain origin. √60

sn.def: One of the terminal members, or digits, of the foot of a man or an animal.
sn.q: Each one, tripping on histoe.

sn.def: The fore part of the hoof or foot of an animal.
Anything, or any part, corresponding to the toe of the foot; as, the toe of a boot; the toe of a skate.

sd.def: The journal, or pivot, at the lower end of a revolving shaft or spindle, which rests in a step.
A lateral projection at one end, or between the ends, of a piece, as a rod or bolt, by means of which it is moved.
A projection from the periphery of a revolving piece, acting as a cam to lift another piece.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toed; p. pr. & vb. n. Toeing
entry.def: To touch or reach with the toes; to come fully up to; as, to toe the mark.

cs.cd: to stand or carry the feet in such a way that the toes of either foot incline toward the other.
to have the toes of each foot, in standing or walking, incline from the other foot.

entry.def: To hold or carry the toes (in a certain way).

sn.def: Having (such or so many) toes; -- chiefly used in composition; as, narrow-toed, four-toed .
Having the end secured by nails driven obliquely, said of a board, plank, or joist serving as a brace, and in general of any part of a frame secured to other parts by diagonal nailing.

entries.entry: Toe drop. Med A morbid condition of the foot in which the toe is depressed and the heel elevated.
Toe hold. Wrestling A hold in which the agressor bends back his opponent's foot.

entry.def: A lean-to. See Lean-to.

entry.ety: Etym. uncertain
entry.def: A fop; a beau; a swell.
Taffy.

entry.ety: AS. tōforan. See To prep. Fore
entry.def: Before.
entry.q: Toforn him goeth the loud minstrelsy.
Would thou wert as thou tofore hast been!

entry.ety: OE. toft a knoll; akin to LG. toft a field hedged in, not far from a house, Icel. topt a green knoll, grassy place, place marked out for a house, Dan. toft

sn.def: A knoll or hill.
sn.q: A tower on atoft.

sn.def: A grove of trees; also, a plain.
A place where a messuage has once stood; the site of a burnt or decayed house.

entries.entry: Toft"man n.; pl.Toftmen. The owner of a toft. See Toft, 3.

entry.ety: L., tufa

sn.def: Tophus.
Tufa. See under Tufa, and Toph.

entry.def: To put toggery, or togs, on; to dress; -- usually with out, implying care, elaborateness, or the like.

entries.entry:
To"ga To"ga
‖Toga prætexta. L a toga with a broad purple border, worn by children of both sexes, by magistrates, and by persons engaged in sacred rites. ‖Toga virilis L the manly gown; the common toga. This was assumed by Roman boys about the time of completing their fourteenth year.
n.; pl. E. Togas #, L. Togæ #. L., akin to tegere to cover. See Thatch
Rom. Antiq The loose outer garment worn by the ancient Romans, consisting of a single broad piece of woolen cloth of a shape approaching a semicircle. It was of undyed wool, except the border of the toga prætexta.

entry.ety: L. togatus, from toga a toga
entry.def: Dressed in a toga or gown; wearing a gown; gowned.
Togated.

cs.cd: in union with; in company or mixture with; along with.

entry.ety: OE. togedere togidere, AS. tōgædere tōgædre tōgadere; tō to + gador together. √29. See To prep., and Gather

sn.def: In company or association with respect to place or time; as, to live together in one house; to live together in the same age; they walked together to the town.
sn.q: Soldiers can never stand idle long together.

sn.def: In or into union; into junction; as, to sew, knit, or fasten two things together; to mix things together.
sn.q: The king joined humanity and policy together.

sn.def: In concert; with mutual coöperation; as, the allies made war upon France together .
sn.q: Take the bad together with the good.

entry.ety: Cf. Togated
entry.def: Clothes; garments; dress; as, fishing toggery .

entry.ety: Cf. Tug

sn.def: A wooden pin tapering toward both ends with a groove around its middle, fixed transversely in the eye of a rope to be secured to any other loop or bight or ring; a kind of button or frog capable of being readily engaged and disengaged for temporary purposes.
Two rods or plates connected by a toggle joint.
A toggle switch.

cs.cd: a harpoon with a pivoted crosspiece in a mortise near the point to prevent it from being drawn out when a whale, shark, or other animal, is harpooned.

an elbow or knee joint, consisting of two bars so connected that they may be brought quite or nearly into a straight line, and made to produce great endwise pressure, when any force is applied to bring them into this position.

entry.def: To change the value of (a program variable) by activating a toggle switch; as, to toggle the view from character to graphic mode; to toggle the keyboard input from insert to overtype mode.

sn.def: an electrical switch operated by pushing a lever through a small angle of deflection. The lever has a spring which returns it to its original position after the pressure applied by the operator is released.

A mechanism for acquiring input from an operator, such that taking some action (such as pressing a function key on a keyboard) will cause a program variable to take a new value. The values are usually changed in cyclic fashion, so that a certain number of activations of the toggle returns the variable to its initial value. When there are two values to the variable, each activation of the toggle causes the variable to assume the alternate value.

entry.def: Taut.
Together.

entry.ety: See Toggery
entry.def: Clothes; garments; toggery.

entry.ety: From the American Indian name
entry.def: The namaycush.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + hew
entry.def: To hew in pieces.

entry.ety: F. tohu-bohu, fr. Heb. tohū wa bohū without form and void (Gen. i. 2)
entry.def: Chaos; confusion.
entry.q: Was ever such a tohubohu of people as there assembles?

entry.ety: F. toiles, pl., toils, nets, fr. toile cloth, canvas, spider web, fr. L. tela any woven stuff, a web, fr. texere to weave. See Text, and cf. Toilet
entry.def: A net or snare; any thread, web, or string spread for taking prey; -- usually in the plural.
entry.q: As a Numidian lion, when first caught, Endures the toil that holds him.
Then toils for beasts, and lime for birds, were found.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toiled; p. pr. & vb. n. Toiling
entry.ety: OE. toilen to pull about, to toil; of uncertain origin; cf. OD. teulen tuylen, to labor, till, or OF. tooillier toailler, to wash, rub (cf. Towel); or perhaps ultimately from the same root as E. tug
entry.def: To exert strength with pain and fatigue of body or mind, especially of the body, with efforts of some continuance or duration; to labor; to work.

sn.def: To weary; to overlabor.
sn.q: Toiledwith works of war.

sn.def: To labor; to work; -- often with out.
sn.q: Places well toiled and husbanded.
Itoiled out my uncouth passage.

entry.note: ☞ Toil is used in the formation of compounds which are generally of obvious signification; as, toil-strung, toil-wasted, toil-worn, and the like.
entry.usage: Toil Labor Drudgery. Labor implies strenuous exertion, but not necessary such as overtasks the faculties; toil denotes a severity of labor which is painful and exhausting; drudgery implies mean and degrading work, or, at least, work which wearies or disgusts from its minuteness or dull uniformity.
entry.ety: OE. toil turmoil, struggle; cf. OD. tuyl labor, work. See Toil v.
entry.def: Labor with pain and fatigue; labor that oppresses the body or mind, esp. the body.
entry.q: My task of servile toil.
After such bloody toil, we bid good night.
entry.syn: Labor; drudgery; work; exertion; occupation; employment; task; travail.
entry.q: You do not know the heavy grievances, The toils, the labors, weary drudgeries, Which they impose.
How often have I blessed the coming day, When toil remitting lent its turn to play.

entry.def: One who toils, or labors painfully.

cs.cd: a looking-glass for a toilet table or for a dressing room.
earthenware, glass, and other utensils for a dressing room.
a dressing table; a toilet. See def. 2 above.
to dress one's self; especially, to dress one's self carefully.

entry.ety: F. toilette, dim. of toile cloth. See Toil a net

sn.def: A covering of linen, silk, or tapestry, spread over a table in a chamber or a dressing room.
A dressing table.
Act or mode of dressing, or that which is arranged in dressing; attire; dress; as, her toilet is perfect.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Toilet, 3.
Producing or involving much toil; laborious; toilsome; as, toilful care.

entry.ety: F. toilinet. See Toil a net
entry.def: A cloth, the weft of which is of woolen yarn, and the warp of cotton and silk, -- used for waistcoats.
Free from toil.
Attended with toil, or fatigue and pain; laborious; wearisome; as, toilsome work.
entry.q: What can be toilsome in these pleasant walks?

entry.ety: F., fr. LL. tesa, fr. L. tensus, fem. tensa, p. p. of tendere to stretch, extend. See Tense a.
entry.def: An old measure of length in France, containing six French feet, or about 6.3946 French feet.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A sheep's fleece.

entries.entry: Toi`son" d'or" Toi`son" d'or" d�r". F Lit., the golden fleece; specif., the order of the Golden Fleece, or its jewel.

entry.ety: Named fr. Tokay in Hungary

sn.def: A grape of an oval shape and whitish color.
A rich Hungarian wine made from Tokay grapes.

entry.note: ☞ It is now made unlawful for private persons to issue tokens.

cs.cd: money which is lawfully current for more than its real value. See Token n., 4.
the last sheet of each token.

entry.ety: OE. token taken, AS. tācen; akin to OFries. tēken, OS. tēkan, D. teeken, G. zeichen, OHG. Zeihhan, Icel. tākan teiken, Sw. tecken, Dan. tegn, Goth. taikns sign, token, gateihan to tell, show, AS. teón to accuse, G. zeihen, OHG. zīhan, G. zeigen to show, OHG. zeigōn, Icel. tjā, L. dicere to say, Gr. deikny`nai to show, Skr. diç. Cf. Diction Teach

sn.def: Something intended or supposed to represent or indicate another thing or an event; a sign; a symbol; as, the rainbow is a token of God's covenant established with Noah.
A memorial of friendship; something by which the friendship of another person is to be kept in mind; a memento; a souvenir.
sn.q: This is some token from a never friend.

sn.def: Something given or shown as a symbol or guarantee of authority or right; a sign of authenticity, of power, good faith, etc.
sn.q: Say, by this token, I desire his company.

sn.def: A piece of metal intended for currency, and issued by a private party, usually bearing the name of the issuer, and redeemable in lawful money. Also, a coin issued by government, esp. when its use as lawful money is limited and its intrinsic value is much below its nominal value.
A livid spot upon the body, indicating, or supposed to indicate, the approach of death.
sn.q: Like the fearful tokens of the plague, Are mere forerunners of their ends.

sn.def: Ten and a half quires, or, commonly, 250 sheets, of paper printed on both sides; also, in some cases, the same number of sheets printed on one side, or half the number printed on both sides.
A piece of metal given beforehand to each person in the congregation who is permitted to partake of the Lord's Supper.
A bit of leather having a peculiar mark designating a particular miner. Each hewer sends one of these with each corf or tub he has hewn.
In a Jacquard loom, a colored signal to show the weaver which shuttle to use.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tokened; p. pr. & vb. n. Tokening
entry.ety: AS. tācnian, fr. tācen token. See Token n.
entry.def: To betoken.
Marked by tokens, or spots; as, the tokened pestilence.
Without a token.
A tocsin.
To take away. See Toll.

entry.ety: Hind., from Skr. tulā a balance
entry.def: A weight of British India. The standard tola is equal to 180 grains.

entry.ety: From Toluene
entry.def: A hydrocarbon, C14H10, related both to the acetylene and the aromatic series, and produced artificially as a white crystalline substance; -- called also diphenyl acetylene.
See Tollbooth.
imp. & p. p. of Tell.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toled; p. pr. & vb. n. Toling
entry.ety: OE. tollen to draw, to entice; of uncertain origin. Cf. Toll to ring a bell
entry.def: To draw, or cause to follow, by displaying something pleasing or desirable; to allure by some bait.
entry.q: Whatever you observe him to be more frighted at then he should, tole him on to by insensible degrees, till at last he masters the difficulty.

entry.def: A sword or sword blade made at Toledo in Spain, which city was famous in the 16th and 17th centuries for the excellence of its weapons.
The quality or state of being tolerable.

entry.ety: L. tolerabilis: cf. F. tolérable. See Tolerate

sn.def: Capable of being borne or endured; supportable, either physically or mentally.
sn.q: As may affect the earth with cold and heat Scarce tolerable.

sn.def: Moderately good or agreeable; not contemptible; not very excellent or pleasing, but such as can be borne or received without disgust, resentment, or opposition; passable; as, a tolerable administration; a tolerable entertainment; a tolerable translation.

entry.cs: Tolerance of the mint. Coinage Same as Remedy of the mint. See under Remedy.
entry.ety: L. tolerantia: cf. F. tolérance

sn.def: The power or capacity of enduring; the act of enduring; endurance.
sn.q: Diogenes, one frosty morning, came into the market place, shaking, to show his tolerance.

sn.def: The endurance of the presence or actions of objectionable persons, or of the expression of offensive opinions; toleration.
The power possessed or acquired by some persons of bearing doses of medicine which in ordinary cases would prove injurious or fatal.
Capability of growth in more or less shade.

the allowed amount of variation from the standard or from exact conformity to the specified dimensions, weight, hardness, voltage etc., in various mechanical or electrical devices or operations; -- caklled also allowance
The amount which coins, either singly or in lots, are legally allowed to vary above or below the standard of weight or fineness.
the capacity to resist the deleterious action of a chemical agent normally harmful to the organism; as, the acquired tolerance of bacteria to anitbiotics.

the acquired inability to respond with an immune reaction to an antigen to which the organism normally responds; -- called also immunotolerance immunological tolerance, or immune tolerance. Such tolerance may be induced by exposing an animal to the antigen at a very early stage of life, prior to maturation of the immune system, or, in adults, by exposing the animal to repeated low doses of a weak protein antigen (low-zone tolerance), or to a large amount of an antigen (high-zone tolerance).

entry.ety: L. tolerans, p. pr. of tolerare to tolerate: cf. F. tolérant. See Tolerate
entry.def: Inclined to tolerate; favoring toleration; forbearing; indulgent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tolerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Tolerating
entry.ety: L. toleratus, p. p. of tolerare, fr. the same root as tollere to lift up, tuli, used as perfect of ferre to bear, latusfor tlatus), used as p. p. of ferre to bear, and E. thole. See Thole, and cf. Atlas Collation Delay Elate Extol Legislate Oblate Prelate Relate Superlative Talent Toll to take away, Translate
entry.def: To suffer to be, or to be done, without prohibition or hindrance; to allow or permit negatively, by not preventing; not to restrain; to put up with; as, to tolerate doubtful practices.
entry.q: Crying should not be tolerated in children.
We tolerate them because property and liberty, to a degree, require that toleration.

entry.ety: L. toleratio: cf. OF. toleration

sn.def: The act of tolerating; the allowance of that which is not wholly approved.
Specifically, the allowance of religious opinions and modes of worship in a state when contrary to, or different from, those of the established church or belief.
Hence, freedom from bigotry and severity in judgment of the opinions or belief of others, especially in respect to religious matters.

entry.ety: L. tollere. See Tolerate
entry.def: To take away; to vacate; to annul.

entry.ety: See Tole

sn.def: To draw; to entice; to allure. See Tole.

sn.ety: Probably the same word as toll to draw, and at first meaning, to ring in order to draw people to church
sn.def: To cause to sound, as a bell, with strokes slowly and uniformly repeated; as, to toll the funeral bell.
sn.q: The sextontolledthe bell.

sn.def: To strike, or to indicate by striking, as the hour; to ring a toll for; as, to toll a departed friend.
sn.q: Slow tolls the village clock the drowsy hour.

sn.def: To call, summon, or notify, by tolling or ringing.
sn.q: When hollow murmurs of their evening bells Dismiss the sleepy swains, and toll them to their cells.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tolled; p. pr. & vb. n. Tolling
entry.def: To sound or ring, as a bell, with strokes uniformly repeated at intervals, as at funerals, or in calling assemblies, or to announce the death of a person.
entry.q: The country cocks do crow, the clocks do toll.
Now sink in sorrows with a tolling bell.

entry.def: The sound of a bell produced by strokes slowly and uniformly repeated.

cs.cd: the privilege of having a market, and jurisdiction of villeins.
a bar or beam used on a canal for stopping boats at the tollhouse, or on a road for stopping passengers.
a bridge where toll is paid for passing over it.
corn taken as pay for grinding at a mill.
a dish for measuring toll in mills.
a man who takes, or gathers, toll.
a toll dish.
toll taken by a town for beasts driven through it, or over a bridge or ferry maintained at its cost.
toll taken by an individual for beasts driven across his ground; toll paid by a person for passing over the private ground, bridge, ferry, or the like, of another.
a toll paid at the return of beasts from market, though they were not sold.

entry.ety: OE. tol, AS. toll; akin to OS. & D. tol, G. zoll, OHG. zol, Icel. tollr, Sw. tull, Dan. told, and also to E. tale; -- originally, that which is counted out in payment. See Tale number

sn.def: A tax paid for some liberty or privilege, particularly for the privilege of passing over a bridge or on a highway, or for that of vending goods in a fair, market, or the like.
A liberty to buy and sell within the bounds of a manor.
A portion of grain taken by a miller as a compensation for grinding.
sn.syn: Tax; custom; duty; impost.

sn.def: To pay toll or tallage.
To take toll; to raise a tax.
sn.q: Well could he [the miller] steal corn and toll thrice.
No Italian priest Shall tithe or toll in our dominions.

entry.def: To collect, as a toll.
Subject to the payment of toll; as, tollable goods.
Payment of toll; also, the amount or quantity paid as toll.

entry.ety: Toll a tax + booth
Written also tolbooth

sn.def: A place where goods are weighed to ascertain the duties or toll.
sn.q: He saw Levy . . . sitting at the tollbooth.

sn.def: In Scotland, a burgh jail; hence, any prison, especially a town jail.

entry.def: To imprison in a tollbooth.
entry.q: That they might tollbooth Oxford men.

entry.ety: AS. tollere

entry.q: Tollersin markets.

entry.def: One who tolls a bell.

entry.ety: L. Toletanus

entry.q: TablesTolletanes.

entries.entry: Toll"house` n.; pl.Tollhouses. A house occupied by a receiver of tolls.
Toll"man n.; pl.Tollmen. One who receives or collects toll; a toll gatherer.

entry.def: See Dolmen.

entry.ety: LL. tolsestrum. Cf. Toll a tax
entry.def: A toll or tribute of a sextary of ale, paid to the lords of some manors by their tenants, for liberty to brew and sell ale.
A tollbooth; also, a merchants' meeting place, or exchange.
Of or pertaining to Tolstoy1828-1910).

def2.def: A follower of Tolstoy, who advocates and practices manual labor, simplicity of living, nonresistance, etc., holds that possession of wealth and ownership of property are sinful, and in religion rejects all teachings not coming from Christ himself.

entry.ety: LL. tolta, fr. L. tollere to take away

One of a race which formerly occupied Mexico.

cs.cd: a large tree (Myroxylon toluiferum), the wood of which is red in the center, and has an aromatic rose odor. It affords the balsam called tolu.

entry.def: A fragrant balsam said to have been first brought from Santiago de Tolu, in New Granada. See Balsam of Tolu, under Balsam.
A salt of any one of the toluic acids.

entry.ety: Tolu + benzene
entry.def: A hydrocarbon, C6H5.CH3, of the aromatic series, homologous with benzene, and obtained as a light mobile colorless liquid, by distilling tolu balsam, coal tar, etc.; -- called also methyl benzene phenyl methane, etc.

entry.ety: Toluene + -yl
entry.def: Tolyl.

Pertaining to, or designating, one of three metameric acids, CH3.C6H4.CO2H, which are related to toluene and analogous to benzoic acids. They are white crystalline substances, and are called respectively orthotoluicacidmetatoluicacid, and paratoluicacid.
A complex double tolyl and toluidine derivative of glycocoll, obtained as a white crystalline substance.

entry.note: ☞ It is used in the aniline dye industry, and constitutes the essential nucleus or radical of those dyes.
entry.def: Any one of three metameric amido derivatives of toluene analogous to aniline, and called respectively orthtoluidine metatoluidine, and paratoluidine; especially, the commonest one, or paratoluidine, which is obtained as a white crystalline substance.

entry.ety: Tolu + benzol

entry.ety: Toluic + uric
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of three isomeric crystalline acids, C9H10ON.CO2H, which are toluyl derivatives of glycocoll.

entry.ety: L. tolutim on a trot, properly, lifting up the feet, akin to tollere to lift up
entry.def: A pacing or ambling.

entry.ety: Toluic + -yl
entry.def: Any one of the three hypothetical radicals corresponding to the three toluic acids.
Same as Stilbene.
Sometimes, but less properly, tolylene.

entry.ety: Toluic + -yl
entry.def: The hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C6H4, regarded as characteristic of certain compounds of the aromatic series related to toluene; as, tolyl carbinol.
A hydrocarbon radical, C6H4.(CH2)2, regarded as characteristic of certain toluene derivatives.
The apar.
The knave of trumps at gleek.

sn.def: A familiar contraction of Thomas, a proper name of a man.
The male of certain animals; -- often used adjectively or in composition; as, tom turkey, tomcat, etc.

entry.ety: Of American Indian origin; cf. Algonkin tomehagen, Mohegan tumnahegan, Delaware tamoihecan

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tomahawked; p. pr. & vb. n. Tomahawking

The liver of the lobster, which becomes green when boiled; -- called also tomalline.

entry.ety: Per. tōmān; from a Mongol word signifying, ten thousand
entry.def: A money of account in Persia, whose value varies greatly at different times and places. Its average value may be reckoned at about two and a half dollars.

entries.entry: Tom and Jerry. A hot sweetened drink of rum and water spiced with cinnamon, cloves, etc., and beaten up with eggs.

To*ma"to
Tomato gall Zoöl a large gall consisting of a mass of irregular swellings on the stems and leaves of grapevines. They are yellowish green, somewhat tinged with red, and produced by the larva of a small two-winged fly (Lasioptera vitis). Tomato sphinx Zoöl the adult or imago of the tomato worm. It closely resembles the tobacco hawk moth. Called also tomato hawk moth. See Illust. of Hawk moth. Tomato worm Zoöl the larva of a large hawk moth (Manduca quinquemaculata Protoparce quinquemaculata Sphinx quinquemaculata, or Macrosila quinquemaculata) which feeds upon the leaves of the tomato and potato plants, often doing considerable damage. Called also tomato hornworm and potato worm, and in the Southern U. S. tobacco fly.
n.; pl.Tomatoes #. Sp. or Pg. tomate, of American Indian origin; cf. Mexican tomail
Bot The fruit of a plant of the Nightshade family (Lycopersicum esculentun); also, the plant itself. The fruit, which is called also love apple, is usually of a rounded, flattened form, but often irregular in shape. It is of a bright red or yellow color, and is eaten either cooked or uncooked.

cs.cd: any one of species of Old World bats of the genus Taphozous which inhabit tombs, especially the Egyptian species (Taphozous perforatus).

entry.ety: OE. tombe toumbe, F. tombe, LL. tumba, fr. Gr. � a tomb, grave; perhaps akin to L. tumulus a mound. Cf. Tumulus

sn.def: A pit in which the dead body of a human being is deposited; a grave; a sepulcher.
sn.q: As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.

sn.def: A house or vault, formed wholly or partly in the earth, with walls and a roof, for the reception of the dead.
sn.q: Intombof marble stones.

sn.def: A monument erected to inclose the body and preserve the name and memory of the dead.
sn.q: Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb.

entries.entry:
Tomb,, v. t.
imp. & p. p. Tombed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tombing
To place in a tomb; to bury; to inter; to entomb. I tombed my brother that I might be blessed.

entry.ety: Pg. tambaca,tambaque, fr. Malay tambāga copper; cf. Skr. tāmraka; cf. F. tombac
entry.def: An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, and containing about 84 per cent of copper; -- called also German brassorDutch brass. It is very malleable and ductile, and when beaten into thin leaves is sometimes called Dutch metal. The addition of arsenic makes white tombac.

entry.ety: See Tumble, and -ster
entry.def: A female dancer.
Destitute of a tomb.

entry.ety: Tomfor Thomas, L. Thomas, fr. Gr. � )+ boy
entry.def: A romping girl; a hoiden.
A stone erected over a grave, to preserve the memory of the deceased.

entry.ety: Tomsee Tomboy) + cat
entry.def: A male cat, especially when full grown or of large size.

entry.ety: Tomsee Tomboy) + cod: cf. F. tacaud whiting pout, American Indian tacaud, literally, plenty fish
entry.def: A small edible American fish (Microgadus tomcod) of the Codfish family, very abundant in autumn on the Atlantic coast of the Northen United States; -- called also frostfish. See Illust. under Frostfish.
The kingfish. See Kingfish.
The jack. See 2d Jack, 8. .

entry.ety: F. tomecf. It., Sp., & Pg. tomo), L. tomus, fr. Gr. � a piece cut off, a part of a book, a volume, akin to � to cup, and perhaps to L. tondere to shear, E. tonsure. Cf. Anatomy Atom Entomology Epitome.
entry.def: As many writings as are bound in a volume, forming part of a larger work; a book; -- usually applied to a ponderous volume.
entry.q: Tomes of fable and of dream.
A more childish expedient than that to which he now resorted is not to be found in all the tomes of the casuists.

entry.def: All small tome, or volume.

entry.ety: L. tomentum a stuffing of wool, hair, or feathers: cf. F. tomenteux
entry.def: Covered with matted woolly hairs; as, a tomentose leaf; a tomentose leaf; a tomentose membrane.
Tomentose.

entries.entry: To*men"tum To*men"tum n.; pl.Tomenta #. L. See Tomentose. Bot The closely matted hair or downy nap covering the leaves or stems of some plants.

entry.ety: Tomsee Tomboy) + fool
entry.def: A great fool; a trifler.
Folly; trifling.

entries.entry:
To"mi*um To"mi*um tō"mĭ*ŭm n.; pl.Tomia tō"mĭ*ȧ
NL., fr. Gr. te`mnein to cut Zoöl The cutting edge of the bill of a bird.

entry.ety: Probably of East Indian origin
entry.def: A kind of open sedan used in Ceylon, carried by a single pole on men's shoulders.

entry.note: ☞ Tommy is used adjectively or in compounds; as, tommy master, tommy-store,tommy-shop,etc.

sn.def: Bread, -- generally a penny roll; the supply of food carried by workmen as their daily allowance.
A truck, or barter; the exchange of labor for goods, not money.
Same as Tommy Atkins; -- a shortened form.

entry.def: Any white regular soldier of the British army; also, such soldiers collectively; -- said to be fictitious name inserted in the models given to soldiers to guide them in filling out account blanks, etc.

entry.ety: Tomsee Tomboy) + noddy

sn.def: A sea bird, the puffin.
A fool; a dunce; a noddy.

entries.entry: Tom o' Bed"lam. Formerly, a wandering mendicant discharged as incurable from Bethlehem Hospital, England; hence, a wandering mendicant, either mad or feigning to be so; a madman; a bedlamite.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. to`mos a cut + ptero`n wing (but taken to mean, fin)
entry.def: A genus of transparent marine annelids which swim actively at the surface of the sea. They have deeply divided or forked finlike organs (parapodia). This genus is the type of the order, or suborder, Gymnocopa.

entry.ety: Prep. to + morn
entry.def: To-morrow.

entry.ety: Prep. to + morrow
entry.def: On the day after the present day; on the next day; on the morrow.

entry.def: The day after the present; the morrow.
entry.q: To-morrowis our wedding day.
One today is worth two to-morrows.

entry.ety: See Tampios

sn.def: A stopper of a cannon or a musket. See Tampion.
A plug in a flute or an organ pipe, to modulate the tone.
The iron bottom to which grapeshot are fixed.

entry.ety: F. tampon. See Tampion
entry.def: An inking pad used in lithographic printing.

entry.ety: Tomsee Tomboy) + rig.)
entry.def: A rude, wild, wanton girl; a hoiden; a tomboy.
A Florida and West Indian grunt (Bathystoma rimatororHæmulon rimator); also, any of various allied species.

entry.ety: Tomsee Tomboy) + tit the bird
entry.def: A titmouse, especially the blue titmouse.
The wren.
See Tam-tam.
pl. of Toe.

entry.ety: Cf. Tunny
entry.def: The common tunny, or horse mackerel.

entry.cs: Bon ton. See in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: F. See Tone
entry.def: The prevailing fashion or mode; vogue; as, things of ton .
entry.q: If our people of ton are selfish, at any rate they show they are selfish.

entries.entry:
Ton ☞ In England, the ton is 2,240 pounds. In the United States the ton is commonly estimated at 2,000 pounds, this being sometimes called the short ton, while that of 2,240 pounds is called the long ton. ☞ Ton and tun have the same etymology, and were formerly used interchangeably; but now ton generally designates the weight, and tun the cask. See Tun. tŭn n. OE. tonne tunne, a tun, AS. tunne a tun, tub, a large vessel; akin to G. & F. tonne a ton, tun, LL. tunna a tun; all perhaps of Celtic origin; cf. Ir. & Gael. tunna a tun. Cf. Tun,Tunnel
Com A measure of weight or quantity. Specifically:The weight of twenty hundredweight. Naut. & Com Forty cubic feet of space, being the unit of measurement of the burden, or carrying capacity, of a vessel; as a vessel of 300 tons burden. See the Note under Tonnage.Naut. & Com A certain weight or quantity of merchandise, with reference to transportation as freight; as, six hundred weight of ship bread in casks, seven hundred weight in bags, eight hundred weight in bulk; ten bushels of potatoes; eight sacks, or ten barrels, of flour; forty cubic feet of rough, or fifty cubic feet of hewn, timber, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tonalité
entry.def: The principle of key in music; the character which a composition has by virtue of the key in which it is written, or through the family relationship of all its tones and chords to the keynote, or tonic, of the whole.
entry.q: The predominance of the tonic as the link which connects all the tones of a piece, we may, with Fétis, term the principle of tonality.

entry.ety: prep. to + name
entry.def: A name added, for the sake of distinction, to one's surname, or used instead of it.

entries.entry: Ton"ca bean`. Bot See Tonka bean.

entry.note: ☞ The use of the word tone, both for a sound and for the interval between two sounds or tones, is confusing, but is common -- almost universal.

☞ Nearly every musical sound is composite, consisting of several simultaneous tones having different rates of vibration according to fixed laws, which depend upon the nature of the vibrating body and the mode of excitation. The components (of a composite sound) are called partial tones; that one having the lowest rate of vibration is the fundamental tone, and the other partial tones are called harmonics, or overtones. The vibration ratios of the partial tones composing any sound are expressed by all, or by a part, of the numbers in the series 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, etc.; and the quality of any sound (the tone color) is due in part to the presence or absence of overtones as represented in this series, and in part to the greater or less intensity of those present as compared with the fundamental tone and with one another. Resultant tones combination tones summation tones difference tones Tartini's tonesterms only in part synonymous) are produced by the simultaneous sounding of two or more primary (simple or composite) tones.
☞ In this sense, the word is metaphorically applied to character or faculties, intellectual and moral; as, his mind has lost its tone.
entry.cs: Tone color. Mus see the Note under def. 4, above. Tone syllable an accented syllable. M. Stuart.
entry.ety: F. ton, L. tonus a sound, tone, fr. Gr. to`nos a stretching, straining, raising of the voice, pitch, accent, measure or meter, in pl., modes or keys differing in pitch; akin to tei`nein to stretch or strain. See Thin, and cf. Monotonous Thunder Ton fashion, Tune

sn.def: Sound, or the character of a sound, or a sound considered as of this or that character; as, a low, high, loud, grave, acute, sweet, or harsh tone .
sn.q: Harmony divine] smooths her charming tones.
Tones that with seraph hymns might blend.

sn.def: Accent, or inflection or modulation of the voice, as adapted to express emotion or passion.
sn.q: Eager his tone, and ardent were his eyes.

sn.def: A whining style of speaking; a kind of mournful or artificial strain of voice; an affected speaking with a measured rhythm ahd a regular rise and fall of the voice; as, children often read with a tone .

sd.def: A sound considered as to pitch; as, the seven tones of the octave; she has good high tones.
The larger kind of interval between contiguous sounds in the diatonic scale, the smaller being called a semitone as, a whole tone too flat; raise it a tone.
The peculiar quality of sound in any voice or instrument; as, a rich tone a reedy tone .
A mode or tune or plain chant; as, the Gregorian tones .

sn.def: That state of a body, or of any of its organs or parts, in which the animal functions are healthy and performed with due vigor.
Tonicity; as, arterial tone .
State of mind; temper; mood.
sn.q: The strange situation I am in and the melancholy state of public affairs, . . . drag the mind down . . . from a philosophical tone or temper, to the drudgery of private and public business.
Their tone was dissatisfied, almost menacing.

sn.def: Tenor; character; spirit; drift; as, the tone of his remarks was commendatory.

General or prevailing character or style, as of morals, manners, or sentiment, in reference to a scale of high and low; as, a low tone of morals; a tone of elevated sentiment; a courtly tone of manners.
The general effect of a picture produced by the combination of light and shade, together with color in the case of a painting; -- commonly used in a favorable sense; as, this picture has tone .
Quality, with respect to attendant feeling; the more or less variable complex of emotion accompanying and characterizing a sensation or a conceptual state; as, feeling tone; color tone .
Color quality proper; -- called also hue. Also, a gradation of color, either a hue, or a tint or shade.
sn.q: She was dressed in a soft cloth of a gray tone.

sn.def: The condition of normal balance of a healthy plant in its relations to light, heat, and moisture.

entry.cs: To tone down. To cause to give lower tone or sound; to give a lower tone to. Paint To modify, as color, by making it less brilliant or less crude; to modify, as a composition of color, by making it more harmonius. Its thousand hues toned down harmoniusly. C. Kingsley. Fig.: To moderate or relax; to diminish or weaken the striking characteristics of; to soften.The best method for the purpose in hand was to employ some one of a character and position suited to get possession of their confidence, and then use it to tone down their religious strictures. Palfrey. To tone up to cause to give a higher tone or sound; to give a higher tone to; to make more intense; to heighten; to strengthen.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toned; p. pr. & vb. n. Toning

sn.def: To utter with an affected tone.
To give tone, or a particular tone, to; to tune. See Tune v. t.
To bring, as a print, to a certain required shade of color, as by chemical treatment.

cs.cd: paper having a slight tint, in distinction from paper which is quite white.

entry.def: Having (such) a tone; -- chiefly used in composition; as, high-toned; sweet-toned .
Having no tone; unmusical.
Tongue.

entry.ety: Chinese t'ang, lit., hall
entry.def: In China, an association, secret society, or organization of any kind; in the United States, usually, a secret association of Chinese such as that of the highbinders; in the U. S. the tongs have been frequently associated with criminal activity and gang warfare.
A drug useful in neuralgia, derived from a Fijian plant supposed to be of the aroid genus Epipremnum.

entry.ety: Hind. tāngā, Skr. tamaṅgaka
entry.def: A kind of light two-wheeled vehicle, usually for four persons, drawn by ponies or bullocks.
A kind of boat or junk used in the seas of the Malay Archipelago.
The mangrove; -- so called in the Pacific Islands.

entry.ety: OE. tonge tange, AS. tange; akin to D. tang, G. zanga, OHG. zanga, Don. tang, Sw. tång, Icel. töng, Gr. da`knein to bite, Skr. dañiç daç. √59. Cf. Tang a strong taste, anything projecting
entry.def: An instrument, usually of metal, consisting of two parts, or long shafts, jointed together at or near one end, or united by an elastic bow, used for handling things, especially hot coals or metals; -- often called a pair of tongs.

entry.note: ☞ The tongue is usually muscular, mobile, and free at one extremity, and in man other mammals is the principal organ of taste, aids in the prehension of food, in swallowing, and in modifying the voice as in speech.
entry.cs: To hold the tongue to be silent. Tongue bone Anat the hyoid bone. Tongue grafting. See under Grafting.
entry.ety: OE. tunge tonge, AS. tunge; akin to OFries. tunge, D. tong, OS. tunga, G. zunge, OHG. zunga, Icel. & Sw. tunga, Dan tunge, Goth. tuggō, OL. dingua, L. lingua. √243 Cf.Language Lingo.

sn.def: an organ situated in the floor of the mouth of most vertebrates and connected with the hyoid arch.
sn.q: To make his English sweet upon his tongue.

sn.def: The power of articulate utterance; speech.
sn.q: Parrots imitating human tongue.

sn.def: Discourse; fluency of speech or expression.
sn.q: Much tongue and much judgment seldom go together.

sn.def: Honorable discourse; eulogy.
sn.q: She was born noble; let that title find her a private grave, but neither tongue nor honor.

sn.def: A language; the whole sum of words used by a particular nation; as, the English tongue .
sn.q: Whose tongue thou shalt not understand.
To speak all tongues.

sn.def: Speech; words or declarations only; -- opposed to thoughts or actions.
sn.q: My little children, let us love in word, neither in tongue, but in deed and in truth.

sn.def: A people having a distinct language.

sd.def: The lingual ribbon, or odontophore, of a mollusk.
The proboscis of a moth or a butterfly.
The lingua of an insect.

sn.def: Any small sole.

entry.sn:
That which is considered as resembing an animal's tongue, in position or form. Specifically: A projection, or slender appendage or fixture; as, the tongue of a buckle, or of a balance.
A projection on the side, as of a board, which fits into a groove.
A point, or long, narrow strip of land, projecting from the mainland into a sea or a lake.
The pole of a vehicle; especially, the pole of an ox cart, to the end of which the oxen are yoked.
The clapper of a bell.
Naut A short piece of rope spliced into the upper part of standing backstays, etc.; also. the upper main piece of a mast composed of several pieces.
Mus Same as Reed n., 5. Language; speech; expression. See Language.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tongued; p. pr. & vb. n. Tonguing

sn.def: To speak; to utter.
sn.q: Such stuff as madmentongue.

sn.def: To chide; to scold.
sn.q: How might she tongue me.

sn.def: To modulate or modify with the tongue, as notes, in playing the flute and some other wind instruments.
To join means of a tongue and grove; as, to tongue boards together.
To talk; to prate.
To use the tongue in forming the notes, as in playing the flute and some other wind instruments.

entry.def: The wryneck.
Having a tongue.
entry.q: Tongued like the night crow.

entry.def: A flounder (Symphurus plagiusa) native of the southern coast of the United States.

sn.def: Having no tongue.
Hence, speechless; mute.
sn.q: Whattonguelessblocks were they! would they not speak?

sn.def: Unnamed; not spoken of.
sn.q: One good deed dying tongueless.

entry.def: A little tongue.
A great talker.
Shaped like a tongue; specifically Bot, linear or oblong, and fleshy, blunt at the end, and convex beneath; as, a tongue-shaped leaf.
Any species of Lingula.
One who uses his tongue; a talker; a story-teller; a gossip.
entry.q: Step by step we rose to greatness; through the tonguesters we may fall.

entry.def: Impeded motion of the tongue because of the shortness of the frænum, or of the adhesion of its margins to the gums.
To deprive of speech or the power of speech, or of distinct articulation.

sn.def: Destitute of the power of distinct articulation; having an impediment in the speech, esp. when caused by a short frænum.
Unable to speak freely, from whatever cause.
sn.q: Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity.

entry.def: Any species of Linguatulina.

Modification of tone for a rapid staccato effect by the performer's tongue, in playing a wind instrument, as a flute. In single tonguing only one kind of stroke is used, the tongue articulating a rapid “t;” in double tonguing, two strokes, as for “t” and “k,” are alternated; in triple tonguing, “t, k, t,” etc.
Ready or voluble in speaking; as, a tonguy speaker.

entry.cs: Tonic spasm. Med See the Note under Spasm.
entry.ety: Cf. F. tonigue, Gr. �. See Tone

sn.def: Of or relating to tones or sounds; specifically Phon, applied to, or distingshing, a speech sound made with tone unmixed and undimmed by obstruction, such sounds, namely, the vowels and diphthongs, being so called by Dr. James Rush (1833) “ from their forming the purest and most plastic material of intonation.”
Of or pertaining to tension; increasing tension; hence, increasing strength; as, tonic power.
Increasing strength, or the tone of the animal system; obviating the effects of debility, and restoring healthy functions.
Characterized by continuous muscular contraction; as, tonic convulsions.

cs.cd: the name of the most popular among letter systems of notation (at least in England), based on key relationship, and hence called “tonic.” Instead of the five lines, clefs, signature, etc., of the usual notation, it employs letters and the syllables do re mi, etc., variously modified, with other simple signs of duration, of upper or lower octave, etc. See Sol-fa.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tonique, NL. tonicum

sn.def: A tonic element or letter; a vowel or a diphthong.
The key tone, or first tone of any scale.
A medicine that increases the strength, and gives vigor of action to the system.

entry.def: Tonic.
The state of healthy tension or partial contraction of muscle fibers while at rest; tone; tonus.

entry.ety: Prep. to + night

sn.def: On this present or coming night.
On the last night past.

entry.def: The present or the coming night; the night after the present day.

entry.ety: Cf.L. tonare to thunder
entry.def: An explosive compound; a preparation of gun cotton.

entries.entry:
Ton"ka bean`. Cf. F. onca tonka
Bot The seed of a leguminous tree (Dipteryx odorata), native of Guiana. It has a peculiarly agreeable smell, and is employed in the scenting of snuff. Called also tonquin bean.
tonca bean tonga bean

Ton mile. Railroads A unit of measurement of the freight transportation performed by a railroad during a given period, usually a year, the total of which consists of the sum of the products obtained by multiplying the aggregate weight of each shipment in tons during the given period by the number of miles for which it is carried.
Ton mileage. Railroads Ton miles collectively; esp., the total ton miles performed by a railroad in a given period.

entry.note: ☞ There are in common use the following terms relating to tonnage: (a) Displacement. (b) Register tonnage, gross and net. (c) Freight tonnage. (d) Builders' measurement. (e) Yacht measurement. The first is mainly used for war vessels, where the total weight is likely to be nearly constant. The second is the most important, being that used for commercial purposes. The third and fourth are different rules for ascertaining the actual burden-carrying power of a vessel, and the fifth is for the proper classification of pleasure craft. Gross tonnage expresses the total cubical interior of a vessel; net tonnage, the cubical space actually available for freight-carrying purposes. Rules for ascertaining these measurements are established by law.
entry.ety: From Ton a measure

sn.def: The weight of goods carried in a boat or a ship.
The cubical content or burden of a vessel, or vessels, in tons; or, the amount of weight which one or several vessels may carry. See Ton n..
sn.q: A fleet . . . with an aggregate tonnage of 60,000 seemed sufficient to conquer the world.

sn.def: A duty or impost on vessels, estimated per ton, or, a duty, toll, or rate payable on goods per ton transported on canals.
The whole amount of shipping estimated by tons; as, the tonnage of the United States. See Ton.

entry.def: A tun.

entry.ety: F

In France, a light-wheeled vehicle with square or rounded body and rear entrance.
Automobiles Orig., the after part of the body with entrance at the rear (as in vehicle in def. 1); now, one with sides closing in the seat or seats and entered by a door usually at the side, also, the entire body of an automobile having such an after part.
same as Tonne.

entry.def: One of the two glandular organs situated in the throat at the sides of the fauces. The tonsils are sometimes called the almonds, from their shape.

entry.ety: Tonsil + Gr. te`mnein to cut
entry.def: An instrument for removing the tonsils.
The operation of removing the tonsils, or a portion thereof; -- called more commonly tonsillectomy.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A barber.

entry.ety: L. tonsorius, fr. tonsor a shearer, barber, fr. tondere tonsum, to shear. See Tonsure
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a barber, or shaving.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. tonsura a shearing, clipping, from tondere tonsum, to shear, shave; cf. Gr. � to gnaw; perhaps akin to Gr. � to cut, and E. tome

sn.def: The act of clipping the hair, or of shaving the crown of the head; also, the state of being shorn.

sd.def: The first ceremony used for devoting a person to the service of God and the church; the first degree of the clericate, given by a bishop, abbot, or cardinal priest, consisting in cutting off the hair from a circular space at the back of the head, with prayers and benedictions; hence, entrance or admission into minor orders.
The shaven corona, or crown, which priests wear as a mark of their order and of their rank.

entry.def: Having the tonsure; shaven; shorn; clipped; hence, bald.
entry.q: A tonsured head in middle age forlorn.

entry.ety: F., from It. tontina; -- so called from its inventor, Tonti, an Italian, of the 17th century
entry.def: An annuity, with the benefit of survivorship, or a loan raised on life annuities with the benefit of survivorship. Thus, an annuity is shared among a number, on the principle that the share of each, at his death, is enjoyed by the survivors, until at last the whole goes to the last survivor, or to the last two or three, according to the terms on which the money is advanced. Used also adjectively; as, tontine insurance.
entry.q: Too many of the financiers by professions are apt to see nothing in revenue but banks, and circulations, and annuities on lives, and tontines, and perpetual rents, and all the small wares of the shop.

entries.entry: Ton*tine" in*su"rance. Life Insurance Insurance in which the benefits of the insurance are distributed upon the tontine principle. Under the old, or full tontine, plan, all benefits were forfeited on lapsed policies, on the policies of those who died within the tontine period only the face of the policy was paid without any share of the surplus, and the survivor at the end of the tontine period received the entire surplus. This plan of tontine insurance has been replaced in the United States by the semitontine plan, in which the surplus is divided among the holders of policies in force at the termination of the tontine period, but the reverse for the paid-up value is paid on lapsed policies, and on the policies of those that have died the face is paid. Other modified forms are called free tontine deferred dividend, etc., according to the nature of the tontine arrangement.

entry.ety: L. a sound, tone. See Tone
entry.def: Tonicity, or tone; as, muscular tonus .

entries.entry:
To"ny n.; pl.Tonies #. Abbrev. from Anthony

sn.def: Over; more than enough; -- noting excess; as, a thing is too long, too short, or too wide; too high; too many; too much.

Such is not Charles his too too active age.
sn.syn: Also; likewise. See Also.

entry.def: imp. of Take.

entry.ety: OE. tol,tool. AS. tōl; akin to Icel. tōl, Goth. taijan to do, to make, taui deed, work, and perhaps to E. taw to dress leather. √64

sn.def: An instrument such as a hammer, saw, plane, file, and the like, used in the manual arts, to facilitate mechanical operations; any instrument used by a craftsman or laborer at his work; an implement; as, the tools of a joiner, smith, shoe-maker, etc.; also, a cutter, chisel, or other part of an instrument or machine that dresses work.
A machine for cutting or shaping materials; -- also called machine tool.
Hence, any instrument of use or service.

the part that supports a tool-post or a tool.

entries.entry: Tool"shed. a small closed structure in which tools are stored, often found in the back yard of a residence.
Tool steel. Hard steel, usually crucible steel, capable of being tempered so as to be suitable for tools.

entry.ety: OE. tom, fr. Icel. tōmr; akin to Dan. & Sw. tom, As. tōme, adv. Cf. Teem to pour

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tooted; p. pr. & vb. n. Tooting

entry.def: To blow or sound a horn; to make similar noise by contact of the tongue with the root of the upper teeth at the beginning and end of the sound; also, to give forth such a sound, as a horn when blown.

entry.def: To cause to sound, as a horn, the note being modified at the beginning and end as if by pronouncing the letter t; to blow; to sound.

entries.entry:
Tooth ☞ The hard parts of teeth are principally made up of dentine, or ivory, and a very hard substance called enamel. These are variously combined in different animals. Each tooth consist of three parts, a crown, or body, projecting above the gum, one or more fangs imbedded in the jaw, and the neck, or intermediate part. In some animals one or more of the teeth are modified into tusks which project from the mouth, as in both sexes of the elephant and of the walrus, and in the male narwhal. In adult man there are thirty-two teeth, composed largely of dentine, but the crowns are covered with enamel, and the fangs with a layer of bone called cementum. Of the eight teeth on each half of each jaw, the two in front are incisors, then come one canine, cuspid, or dog tooth, two bicuspids, or false molars, and three molars, or grinding teeth. The milk, or temporary, teeth are only twenty in number, there being two incisors, one canine, and two molars on each half of each jaw. The last molars, or wisdom teeth, usually appear long after the others, and occasionally do not appear above the jaw at all.
In spite of the teeth in defiance of opposition; in opposition to every effort. In the teeth directly; in direct opposition; in front. “Nor strive with all the tempest in my teeth.” Pope. To cast in the teeth to report reproachfully; to taunt or insult one with. Tooth and nail as if by biting and scratching; with one's utmost power; by all possible means. L'Estrange. “I shall fight tooth and nail for international copyright.” Charles Reade. Tooth coralline Zoöl any sertularian hydroid. Tooth edge the sensation excited in the teeth by grating sounds, and by the touch of certain substances, as keen acids. Tooth key an instrument used to extract teeth by a motion resembling that of turning a key. Tooth net a large fishing net anchored. Scot Jamieson. Tooth ornament. Arch Same as Dogtooth n., 2.
Tooth powder a powder for cleaning the teeth; a dentifrice. Tooth rash. Med See Red-gum, 1. To show the teeth to threaten. “When the Law shows her teeth, but dares not bite.” Young. To the teeth in open opposition; directly to one's face. “That I shall live, and tell him to his teeth .” Shak.
t�th n.; pl.Teeth tēth. OE. toth,tooth, AS. tōð; akin to OFries. tōth, OS. & D. tand, OHG. zang zan, G. zahn, Icel. tönn, Sw. & Dan. tand, Goth. tumpus, Lith. dantis, W. dant, L. dens dentis, Gr. 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, Skr. danta; probably originally the p. pr. of the verb to eat. √239. Cf. Eat Dandelion Dent the tooth of a wheel, Dental Dentist Indent Tine of a fork, Tusk.
Anat One of the hard, bony appendages which are borne on the jaws, or on other bones in the walls of the mouth or pharynx of most vertebrates, and which usually aid in the prehension and mastication of food. How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is To have a thankless child!
Fig.: Taste; palate. These are not dishes for thy dainty tooth.
Any projection corresponding to the tooth of an animal, in shape, position, or office; as, the teeth, or cogs, of a cogwheel; a tooth, prong, or tine, of a fork; a tooth, or the teeth, of a rake, a saw, a file, a card.
A projecting member resembling a tenon, but fitting into a mortise that is only sunk, not pierced through.
One of several steps, or offsets, in a tusk. See Tusk.
Nat. Hist An angular or prominence on any edge; as, a tooth on the scale of a fish, or on a leaf of a plant ; specifically Bot one of the appendages at the mouth of the capsule of a moss. See Peristome.
Zoöl Any hard calcareous or chitinous organ found in the mouth of various invertebrates and used in feeding or procuring food; as, the teeth of a mollusk or a starfish.

A peculiar fruit-eating ground pigeon (Didunculus strigiostris) native of the Samoan Islands, and noted for its resemblance, in several characteristics, to the extinct dodo. Its beak is stout and strongly hooked, and the mandible has two or three strong teeth toward the end. Its color is chocolate red. Called also toothbilled pigeon, and manu-mea.

a wheel with teeth or projections cut or set on its edge or circumference, for transmitting motion by their action on the engaging teeth of another wheel.

entry.note: ☞ Top is often used adjectively or as the first part of compound words, usually self-explaining; as, top stone, or topstone; top-boots, or top boots; top soil, or top-soil.

a small viviparous fresh-water fish (Gambusia patruelis) abundant in the Southern United States. Also applied to other similar species.
from head to foot; altogether.

entry.ety: AS. top; akin to OFries. top a tuft, D. top top, OHG. zopf end, tip, tuft of hair, G. zopf tuft of hair, pigtail, top of a tree, Icel. toppr a tuft of hair, crest, top, Dan. top, Sw. topp pinnacle, top; of uncertain origin. Cf. Tuft

sn.def: The highest part of anything; the upper end, edge, or extremity; the upper side or surface; summit; apex; vertex; cover; lid; as, the top of a spire; the top of a house; the top of a mountain; the top of the ground.

sn.def: The utmost degree; the acme; the summit.

sn.def: The highest rank; the most honorable position; the utmost attainable place; as, to be at the top of one's class, or at the top of the school.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Topped; p. pr. & vb. n. Topping

to completely fill (an almost full tank) by adding more of the liquid it already contains.

sn.def: To cover on the top; to tip; to cap; -- chiefly used in the past participle.

sn.def: To rise above; to excel; to outgo; to surpass.

sn.def: To rise to the top of; to go over the top of.
sn.q: But wind about till thou hast topped the hill.

sn.def: To take off the or upper part of; to crop.
sn.q: Top your rose trees a little with your knife.

sn.def: To perform eminently, or better than before.
sn.q: From endeavoring universally to top their parts, they will go universally beyond them.

sn.def: To raise one end of, as a yard, so that that end becomes higher than the other.
To cover with another dye; as, to top aniline black with methyl violet to prevent greening and crocking.
To put a stiffening piece or back on (a saw blade).
To arrange, as fruit, with the best on top.
To strike the top of, as a wall, with the hind feet, in jumping, so as to gain new impetus; -- said of a horse.
To improve (domestic animals, esp. sheep) by crossing certain individuals or breeds with other superior.
To raise one end of, as a yard, so that that end becomes higher than the other.
To cut, break, or otherwise take off the top of (a steel ingot) to remove unsound metal.
To strike (the ball) above the center; also, to make (as a stroke) by hitting the ball in this way.

entry.ety: L. toparcha, Gr. �; � a place + � to govern, to rule

entry.cs: False topaz. Min See the Note under Quartz.
entry.ety: OE. topas, F. topaze, L. topazos, or topazion, a kind of precious stone, Gr. to`pazos topa`zion; possibly akin to Skr. tap to glow (cf. Tepid). According to some, the name is from Topazos, a small island in the Red Sea, where the Romans obtained a stone which they called by this name, but which is the chrysolite of the moderns

sn.def: A mineral occurring in rhombic prisms, generally yellowish and pellucid, also colorless, and of greenesh, bluish, or brownish shades. It sometimes occurs massive and opaque. It is a fluosilicate of alumina, and is used as a gem.

entry.ety: Tamil tōppu

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toped tōpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Toping
entry.ety: F. tôper to cover a stake in playing at dice, to accept an offer, tôpe agreed!; -- perhaps imitative of the sound of striking hands on concluding a bargain. From being used in English as a drinking term, probably at first in accepting a toast.]

entry.q: If you tope in form, and treat.

entry.ety: Eskimo tupek
entry.def: An Eskimo house made of material other than snow, esp. one having walls of turf, driftwood, rock, or skin, and a roof of skins of the walrus or seal. In Alaska it is often partially underground and covered with timber and turf. Topeks are also used by Indians of the lower Yukon region.
One who topes, or drinks frequently or to excess; a drunkard; a sot.

entry.ety: F. toupet tuft. See Touper
entry.def: The European crested titmouse.

entries.entry: Top fermentation. An alcoholic fermentation during which the yeast cells are carried to the top of the fermenting liquid. It proceeds with some violence and requires a temperature of 14-30° C. (58-86° F.). It is used in the production of ale, porter, etc., and of wines high in alcohol, and in distilling.

entry.def: unexcelled; of the highest grade; of greatest skill; exhibiting excellence; a topflight performance.
Full to the top, ore brim; brimfull.

He] was so topful of himself, that he let it spill on all the company.
