entry.def: Having the top or upper part too heavy for the lower part.

entry.note: ☞ It seems to have been at first part of the royal garden, but it was afterwards defiled and polluted by the sacrifices of Baal and the fires of Moloch, and resounded with the cries of burning infants. At a later period, its altars and high places were thrown down, and all the filth of the city poured into it, until it became the abhorrence of Jerusalem, and, in symbol, the place where are wailing and gnashing of teeth.
entry.ety: Heb. tōphet, literally, a place to be spit upon, an abominable place, fr. tūph to spit out
entry.def: A place lying east or southeast of Jerusalem, in the valley of Hinnom.
entry.q: And he defiled Topheth, which is in the valley of the children of Hinnom.
The pleasant valley of Hinnom, Tophet thence And black Gehenna called, the type of hell.

entry.def: Same as Toph.

entries.entry:
To"phus n.; pl.Tophi #. NL.: cf. F. tophus a mineral concretion in the joint. See Toph
tofus
Med One of the mineral concretions about the joints, and in other situations, occurring chiefly in gouty persons. They consist usually of urate of sodium; when occurring in the internal organs they are also composed of phosphate of calcium.
Min Calcareous tufa.

entry.def: An antelope (Damaliscus corrigum jimela) having a glossy purplish brown coat. It is related to the blesbok and is native of East Africa. Also, any of various related varieties of other districts south of the Sahara.

entry.ety: See Toplary
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the ornamental cutting and trimming of trees, hedges, etc.; practicing ornamental gardening.
entry.q: Thetopiarianartist.
All the pedantries of the topiarian art.

cs.cd: arbors, shrubbery, hedges, or the like, cut and trimmed into fanciful forms, as of animals, buildings, etc.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to ornamental gardening; produced by cutting, trimming, etc.; topiarian.

entry.ety: F. topiques, pl., L. topica the title of a work of Aristotle, Gr. topika`, fr. topiko`s of or for place, concerning to`poi, or commonplaces, fr. to`pos a place
entry.def: One of the various general forms of argument employed in probable as distinguished from demonstrative reasoning, -- denominated by Aristotle to`poiliterally, places), as being the places or sources from which arguments may be derived, or to which they may be referred; also, a prepared form of argument, applicable to a great variety of cases, with a supply of which the ancient rhetoricians and orators provided themselves; a commonplace of argument or oratory.
A treatise on forms of argument; a system or scheme of forms or commonplaces of argument or oratory; as, the Topics of Aristotle.
entry.q: These topics, or loci, were no other than general ideas applicable to a great many different subjects, which the orator was directed to consult.
In this question by [reason] I do not mean a distinct topic, but a transcendent that runs through all topics.

sn.def: An argument or reason.
sn.q: Contumacious persons, who are not to be fixed by any principles, whom no topics can work upon.

sn.def: The subject of any distinct portion of a discourse, or argument, or literary composition; also, the general or main subject of the whole; a matter treated of; a subject, as of conversation or of thought; a matter; a point; a head.
An external local application or remedy, as a plaster, a blister, etc.

entry.def: Topical.

entry.ety: Cf. F. topique, LL. topicus, Gr. �. See Topic n.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a place; limited; logical application; as, a topical remedy; a topical claim or privilege.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, a topic or topics; according to topics.
Resembling a topic, or general maxim; hence, not demonstrative, but merely probable, as an argument.
sn.q: Evidences of fact can be no more than topical and probable.

entry.def: In a topical manner; with application to, or limitation of, a particular place or topic.

sn.def: A crest or knot of feathers upon the head or top, as of a bird; also, an ornamental knot worn on top of the head, as by women.
sn.q: A great, stout servant girl, with cheeks as red as her topknot.

sn.def: A small Europen flounder (Rhoumbus punctatus). The name is also applied to allied species.
Having no top, or no visble fop; hence, fig.: very lofty; supreme; unequaled.
sn.q: ThetoplessApennines.
Toplessfortunes.

sn.def: wearing no clothes above the waist, said especially of women.
featuring entertainment by women wearing no clothes above the waist; as, a topless go-go joint.

entry.def: A lantern or light on the top of a vessel.

entries.entry:
Top"man n.; pl.Topmem.
See Topsman, 2.
Naut A man stationed in the top.

entry.def: The second mast, or that which is next above the lower mast, and below the topgallant mast.
Highest; uppermost; as, the topmost cliff; the topmost branch of a tree.
entry.q: The nightngale may claim the topmost bough.

entry.ety: Cf. F. topographe, Cr. �
entry.def: One who is skilled in the science of topography; one who describes a particular place, town, city, or tract of land.
entry.q: Dante is the one authorized topographer of the mediæval hell.

entry.cs: Topographical map. See under Cadastral. -- Topographical surveying. See under Surveying.
entry.ety: Cf. F. topographique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to topography; descriptive of a place.
A topographer.

entry.note: ☞ Topography, as the description of particular places, is distinguished from chorography, the description of a region or a district, and for geography, the description of the earth or of countries.
entry.ety: F. topographie, Gr. �; � a place + � to write
entry.def: The description of a particular place, town, manor, parish, or tract of land; especially, the exact and scientific delineation and description in minute detail of any place or region.
a mathematician specializing in topology.
entry.q: Atopologistis someone who doesn't know the difference between a donut and a coffee cup.

entry.ety: Gr. � place + -logy
entry.def: The art of, or method for, assisting the memory by associating the thing or subject to be remembered with some place.

sn.def: a branch of mathematics which studies the properties of geometrical forms which retain their identity under certain transformations, such as stretching or twisting, which are homeomorphic. See also topologist.
configuration, especially in three dimensions; -- used, e. g. of the configurations taken by macromolecules, such as superhelical DNA.

entry.ety: Gr. � place + � to distribute
entry.def: The designation of position and direction.

sn.def: A name of a place.
a name, as in the binomial name of a plant, based on, or derived from, a place name, or based on the location of the thing named.

entry.def: A system of toponyms; the use of toponyms.

entry.ety: Gr. � place + Gr. � sound
entry.def: A double ear trumpet for estimating the direction from which sounds proceed, esp. for the use of navigators.

entries.entry: Top out. Building To top off; to finish by putting on a cap of top (uppermost) course (called a top`ping-out" course).

sn.def: One that tops, in any sense of the verb;

sd.def: A cover of a top layer or part.
One that excels, surpasses, or is extraordinary of its kind.
Any device for cutting off tops; as, a turnip topper .
One who tops steel ingots.
A three-square float (file) used by comb makers.

sn.def: A top hat.
Tobacco left in the bottom of a pipe bowl; -- so called from its being often taken out and placed on top of the newly filled bowl. Also, a cigar stump.

entry.def: A small wig for the top of the head; a toupee.

sn.def: Rising above; surpassing.
Hence, assuming superiority; proud.
sn.q: The great and flourishing condition of some of the topping sinners of the world.

sn.def: Fine; gallant.

cs.cd: a large, strong tackle employed to raise or top the end of a gaff, or of a boom.

sn.def: The act of one who tops; the act of cutting off the top.
The act of raising one extremity of a spar higher than the other.
That which comes from hemp in the process of hatcheling.
The tail of an artificial fly.
something placed on top of another thing, such as a sauce or garnish on food; as, a three-scoop banana split with three different toppings ; an ice-cream cone with chocolate fudge topping.

entry.def: In a topping or proud manner.
Same as Topping a., 3.
entry.q: Toppingquests.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toppled; p. pr. & vb. n. Toppling
entry.ety: From Top summit
entry.def: To fall forward; to pitch or tumble down.
entry.q: Though castles topple on their warders' heads.

entry.def: To throw down; to overturn.
entry.q: He topple crags from the precipice.

entry.def: Proud to the highest degree.
entry.q: Thistop-proudfellow.

entries.entry: Top rake. Mech The angle that the front edge of the point of a tool is set back from the normal to the surface being cut.

entry.def: A rope used for hoisting and lowering a topmast, and for other purposes.

entry.cs: Topsail schooner. Naut See Schooner, and Illustration in Appendix.
entry.def: In a square-rigged vessel, the sail next above the lowermost sail on a mast. This sail is the one most frequently reefed or furled in working the ship. In a fore-and-aft rigged vessel, the sail set upon and above the gaff. See Cutter Schooner Sail, and Ship.
Small rolls of dough, baked, cut in halves, and then browned in an oven, -- used as food for infants.
entry.q: 'T is said that her top-and-bottoms were gilt.

entry.note: The names of the higher levels of secrecy classification are themselves classified secrets.

sn.def: containing information whose disclosure could result in grave danger to the national security; -- the highest of the three commonly known levels of national security classification, the others being confidential and secret.
kept secret by very careful and strict rules for disclosure.

entry.def: same as First Sergeant.
Having the shape of a top;
cone-shaped, with the apex downward; turbinate.
Any one of numerous species of marine top-shaped shells of the genus Trochus, or family Trochidæ.

entries.entry:
Tops"man n.; pl.Topsmen.
The chief drover of those who drive a herd of cattle.
The uppermost sawyer in a saw pit; a topman.

entry.def: The upper layer of soil; surface soil.
The act or art of taking off the top soil of land before an excavation or embankment is begun.
A stone that is placed on the top, or which forms the top.

entry.ety: Earlier topside-turvey topsy-tervy; probably for top so turvy; that is, the top as turvy, as it were turvy; where turvy probably means, overturned, fr. AS. torfian to throw
entry.def: In an inverted posture; with the top or head downward; upside down; as, to turn a carriage topsy-turvy .
A tackle used in hoisting and lowering the topmast.
The highest timbers on the side of a vessel, being those above the futtocks.
A tool applied to the top of the work, in distinction from a tool inserted in the anvil and on which the work is placed.

entry.ety: F. toque; of Celtic origin; cf. W. toc

sn.def: A kind of cap worn in the 16th century, and copied in modern fashions; -- called also toquet.
sn.q: His velvet toque stuck as airily as ever upon the side of his head.

sn.def: A variety of the bonnet monkey.

entry.def: See Toque, 1.

entry.ety: AS. torr; cf. Gael. torr. Cf. Tower

sn.def: A tower; a turret.
High-pointed hill; a rocky pinnacle.
sn.q: A rolling range of dreary moors, unbroken by tor or tree.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + OE. r�sen to rage
entry.def: To scratch to pieces.

entries.entry:
‖To"rah, ‖To"ra
n.; pl. Toroth # . Heb. tōrāh
Jewish Lit A law; a precept. A considerable body of priestly Toroth. Divine instruction; revelation.
Tora, . . . before the time of Malachi, is generally used of the revelations of God's will made through the prophets. The Pentateuch or “Law of Moses.” The Hebrew Bible is divided into three parts: (1) The Torah, “Law,” or Pentateuch. (2) The Prophets (Nevi'im in Hebrew) . . . (3) The Kethubim, or the “Writings,” generally termed Hagiographa. From the first letters of these three parts, the word “Tanakh” is derived, and used by Jews as the name of their Bible, the Christian Old Testament.

entry.ety: Skr. tōraṇa an arch, a gate
entry.def: A gateway, commonly of wood, but sometimes of stone, consisting of two upright pillars carrying one to three transverse lintels. It is often minutely carved with symbolic sculpture, and serves as a monumental approach to a Buddhist temple.

entry.ety: So named after Torber Bergmann, a Swedish chemist
entry.def: A mineral occurring in emerald-green tabular crystals having a micaceous structure. It is a hydrous phosphate of uranium and copper. Called also copper uranite, and chalcolite.
Same as Torque, 1.

entry.cs: Torch thistle. Bot See under Thistle.
entry.ety: OE. torche, F. torche a torch, rag, wisp, pad; probably from a derivative of L. torquere tortum, to twist, because twisted like a rope; cf. F. torcher to rub, wipe, It. topcia a torch, torciare to wrap, twist, OF. torse a torse. Cf. Torture
entry.def: A light or luminary formed of some combustible substance, as of resinous wood; a large candle or flambeau, or a lamp giving a large, flaring flame.
entry.q: They light the nuptial torch.

entry.def: One whose office it is to carry a torch.
One who gives light with a torch, or as if with a torch.
The light of a torch, or of torches. Also adjectively; as, a torchlight procession.

entries.entry: Tor"chon lace`. F. torchon a kind of coarse napkin a simple thread lace worked upon a pillow with coarse thread; also, a similar lace made by machinery.

Tor"chon pa"per. F. papier torchon
Paper with a rough surface; esp., handmade paper of great hardness for the use of painters in water colors.
Torch race. A race by men carrying torches, as in ancient Greece.

entry.def: one who sings torch songs.
a popular song with a sentimental theme of unrequited love or other form of unhappiness.
The inflammable wood of certain trees (Amyris balsamifera Amyris Floridana, etc.); also, the trees themselves.
The common mullein, the stalks of which, dipped in suet, anciently served for torches. Called also torch, and hig-taper.
imp. of Tear.

entry.ety: Probably from the root of tear; cf. W. tór a break, cut, tóri to break, cut
entry.def: The dead grass that remains on mowing land in winter and spring.

entry.ety: See Torus

sn.def: Same as Torus.
same as torus.

entry.ety: Sp., fr. torear to fight bulls, fr.L. taurus a bull
entry.def: A bullfighter.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + rend
entry.def: To rend in pieces.
entry.q: The wolf hath many a sheep and lamb to-rent.

entry.ety: Probably dim. fr. tore torus
entry.def: A Turret.
A ring for fastening a hawk's leash to the jesses; also, a ring affixed to the collar of a dog, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, embossed work, work in relief (from � to bore through, to work in relief) + -graphy
entry.def: A description of sculpture such as bas-relief in metal.

entry.ety: Gr. � embossed work + -logy
entry.def: The art or the description of scupture such as bas-relief in metal; toreumatography.

entry.ety: Gr. � belonging to work in relief
entry.def: In relief; pertaining to sculpture in relief, especially of metal; also, pertaining to chasing such as surface ornamentation in metal.
The saibling.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. torillo a little bull
entry.def: A species of Turnix (Turnix sylvatica) native of Spain and Northen Africa.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Turin.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Turin; collectively, the people of Turin.

entry.ety: OF. torment, F. tourment, fr. L. tormentum an engine for hurling missiles, an instrument of torture, a rack, torture, fr. torquere to turn, to twist, hurl. See Turture

sn.def: An engine for casting stones.
Extreme pain; anguish; torture; the utmost degree of misery, either of body or mind.
sn.q: The more I see Pleasures about me, so much more I feelTorment within me.

sn.def: That which gives pain, vexation, or misery.
sn.q: They brought unto him all sick people that were taken with divers diseases and torments.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. tormented; p. pr. & vb. n. tormenting
entry.ety: OF. tormenter, F. tourmenter

sn.def: To put to extreme pain or anguish; to inflict excruciating misery upon, either of body or mind; to torture.
sn.q: Art thou come hither totormentus before our time?

sn.def: To pain; to distress; to afflict.
sn.q: Lord, my servant lieth at home sick of the palsy, grievously tormented.

sn.def: To tease; to vex; to harass; as, to be tormented with importunities, or with petty annoyances.
To put into great agitation.
sn.q: They], soaring on main wing,tormentedall the air.

sn.def: One who, or that which, torments; a tormentor.
An executioner.

entry.def: Full of torment; causing, or accompanied by, torment; excruciating.

entry.ety: F. tormentille; cf. Pr., It., & NL. tormentilla, Sp. tormentila; all fr. L. tormentum pain. So called because it is said to allay pain. See Torment
entry.def: A rosaceous herb (Potentilla Tormentilla), the root of which is used as a powerful astringent, and for alleviating gripes, or tormina, in diarrhea.
Causing torment; as, a tormenting dream.

entry.ety: See Torment
entry.def: Torture; torment.

sn.def: One who, or that which, torments; one who inflicts penal anguish or tortures.
sn.q: Thoughts, my tormentors, armed with deadly stings.

sn.def: An implement for reducing a stiff soil, resembling a harrow, but running upon wheels.

entry.def: A woman who torments.
entry.q: Fortune ordinarily cometh after to whip and punish them, as the scourge and tormentress of glory and honor.

entry.def: Anything producing torment, annoyance, or pain.

entry.ety: L., a griping in the belly
entry.def: acute, colicky pains; gripes.
Affected with tormina; griping.
p. p. of Tear.

entries.entry:
Tor*na"do n.; pl.Tornadoes #. From Sp. or Pg. tornar to turn, return, L. tornare to turn, hence, a whirling wind. The Sp. & Pg. tornada is a return. See Turn
A violent whirling wind; specifically Meteorol, a tempest distinguished by a rapid whirling and slow progressive motion, usually accompaned with severe thunder, lightning, and torrents of rain, and commonly of short duration and small breadth; a small cyclone
.
Tor*na"ri*a Tor*na"ri*a n.; pl.Tornariæ #. NL., fr. L. tornare to turn Zoöl The peculiar free swimming larva of Balanoglossus. See Illust. in Append.

entry.ety: L. torosus full of muscle, brawny, fleshy. See Torus
entry.def: Cylindrical with alternate swellings and contractions; having the surface covered with rounded prominences.
The quality or state of being torose.
Torose.
Of or pertaining to a torpedo; resembling a torpedo; exerting a benumbing influence; stupefying; dull; torpid.
entry.q: Fishy were his eyes; torpedinous was his manner.

entries.entry:
Tor*pe"do ☞ The common European torpedo (Torpedo vulgaris) and the American species (Torpedo occidentalis) are the best known.
Fish torpedo a spindle-shaped, or fish-shaped, self-propelling submarine torpedo. Spar torpedo a canister or other vessel containing an explosive charge, and attached to the end of a long spar which projects from a ship or boat and is thrust against an enemy's ship, exploding the torpedo. Torpedo boat a vessel adapted for carrying, launching, operating, or otherwise making use of, torpedoes against an enemy's ship., especially, a small, fast boat with tubes for launching torpedoes. Torpedo nettings nettings made of chains or bars, which can be suspended around a vessel and allowed to sink beneath the surface of the water, as a protection against torpedoes.
n.; pl.Torpedoes #. L. torpedo -inis, from torpere to be stiff, numb, or torpid. See Torpid
Zoöl Any one of numerous species of elasmobranch fishes belonging to Torpedo and allied genera. They are related to the rays, but have the power of giving electrical shocks. Called also crampfish, and numbfish. See Electrical fish, under Electrical.
An engine or machine for destroying ships by blowing them up; a mine{4}. Specifically: A quantity of explosives anchored in a channel, beneath the water, or set adrift in a current, and so designed that they will explode when touched or approached by a vessel, or when an electric circuit is closed by an operator on shore; now called marine mine. obsolete Damn the torpedoesfull speed ahead!
A kind of small submarine boat carrying an explosive charge, and projected from a ship against another ship at a distance, or made self-propelling, and otherwise automatic in its action against a distant ship.
Mil A kind of shell or cartridge buried in earth, to be exploded by electricity or by stepping on it; now called land mine. obsolete
Railroad A kind of detonating cartridge or shell placed on a rail, and exploded when crushed under the locomotive wheels, -- used as an alarm signal.
An explosive cartridge or shell lowered or dropped into a bored oil well, and there exploded, to clear the well of obstructions or to open communication with a source of supply of oil.
A kind of firework in the form of a small ball, or pellet, which explodes when thrown upon a hard object.
An automobile with a torpedo body. Archaic Cant

sn.def: to destroy by, or subject to the action of, a torpedo.
To destroy, cause to halt, or prevent from being accomplished; -- used esp. with reference to a plan or an enterprise, halted by some action before the plan is put into execution.

entries.entry: Tor*pe"do-boat` de*stroy"er. A larger, swifter, and more powerful armed type of torpedo boat, originally intended principally for the destruction of torpedo boats, but later used also as a more formidable torpedo boat.
Tor*pe"do body. An automobile body which is built so that the side surfaces are flush. Cant
Tor*pe"do boom. A spar formerly carried by men-of-war, having a torpedo on its end.
Tor*pe"do catch"er. A small fast vessel for pursuing and destroying torpedo boats.

entry.def: One skilled in the theory or use of torpedoes; also, one who favors the use of torpedoes.

entries.entry: Torpedo shell. Ordnance A shell longer than a deck-piercing shell, with thinner walls and a larger cavity for the bursting charge, which consists of about 130 pounds of high explosive. It has no soft cap, and is intended to effect its damage by the powerful explosion which follows on slight resistance. It is used chiefly in 12-inch mortars.

Torpedo station. A headquarters for torpedo vessels and their supplies, usually having facilities for repairs and for instruction and experiments. The principal torpedo station of the United States is at Newport, R.I.
Torpedo stern. A broad stern without overhang, flattened on the bottom, used in some torpedo and fast power boats. It prevents settling in the water at high speed.

Torpedo tube. Nav A tube fixed below or near the water line through which a torpedo is fired, usually by a small charge of gunpowder. On torpedo vessels the tubes are on deck and usually in broadside, on larger vessels usually submerged in broadside and fitted with a movable shield which is pushed out from the vessel's side to protect the torpedo until clear, but formerly sometimes in the bow. In submarine torpedo boats they are in the bow.

entry.ety: L. torpens, p. pr. of torpere to be numb
entry.def: Having no motion or activity; incapable of motion; benumbed; torpid.
The quality or state or being torpescent; torpidness; numbness; stupidity.

entry.ety: L. torpescens, p. pr. of torpescere to grow stiff, numb, or torpid, incho. fr. torpere. See Torpid
entry.def: Becoming torpid or numb.

entry.ety: L. torpidus, fr. torpere to be stiff, numb, or torpid; of uncertain origin

sn.def: Having lost motion, or the power of exertion and feeling; numb; benumbed; as, a torpid limb.
sn.q: Without heat all things would be torpid.

sn.def: Dull; stupid; sluggish; inactive.

entry.ety: See Torpid a.

sn.def: An inferior racing boat, or one who rows in such a boat.
The Lenten rowing races.

entry.def: Same as Torpidness.
In a torpid manner.
The qualityy or state of being torpid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Torpified; p. pr. & vb. n. Torpifying.
entry.ety: L. torpere to be torpid + -fy
entry.def: To make torpid; to numb, or benumb.
Torpidness.
entry.q: In a kind oftorpitude, or sleeping state.

entry.ety: L., from torpere, to be torpid

sn.def: Loss of motion, or of the motion; a state of inactivity with partial or total insensibility; numbness.
Dullness; sluggishness; inactivity; as, a torpor of the mental faculties.

entry.ety: L. torpor torpor + facere to make
entry.def: Tending to produce torpor.

entry.ety: L. torquatus wearing a collar
entry.def: Collared; having a torques, or distinct colored ring around the neck.

entry.ety: L. Torqyatus
entry.def: Having or wearing a torque, or neck chain.

entry.ety: L. torques a twisted neck chain, fr. torquere to twist

sn.def: A collar or neck chain, usually twisted, especially as worn by ancient barbaric nations, as the Gauls, Germans, and Britons.
That which tends to produce torsion; a couple of forces.
A turning or twisting; tendency to turn, or cause to turn, about an axis.

entry.ety: L. torquere to twist, to turn, to wind

sn.def: Wreathed; twisted.
Twisted; bent; -- said of a dolphin haurient, which forms a figure like the letter S.

entry.ety: L., a necklace. See Torque, 1
entry.def: A cervical ring of hair or feathers, distinguished by its color or structure; a collar.

entry.ety: L. torrefacere,torrefactum, to torrefy: cf. F. torréfaction. See Torrefy
entry.def: The act or process of torrefying, or the state of being torrefied.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Torrefied; p. pr. & vb. n. Torrefying
entry.ety: L. torrere to parch + -fy: cf. F. torréfier, L. torrefacere

sn.def: To dry by a fire.
To subject to scorching heat, so as to drive off volatile ingredients; to roast, as ores.
To dry or parch, as drugs, on a metallic plate till they are friable, or are reduced to the state desired.

entries.entry: Tor"rens sys`tem. A system of registration of titles to land (as distinct from registration of deeds) introduced into South Australia by the Real Property (or Torrens) Act (act 15 of 1857-58), drafted by Sir Robert Torrens (1814-84). Its essential feature is the guaranty by the government of properly registered titles. The system has been generally adopted in Australia and British Columbia, and in its original or a modified form in some other countries, including some States of the United States. Hence Torrens title, etc.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. torrens -entis, fr. torrens burning, roaring, boiling, p. pr. of torrere to dry by heat, to burn. See Torrid

sn.def: A violent stream, as of water, lava, or the like; a stream suddenly raised and running rapidly, as down a precipice.
sn.q: The roaring torrent is deep and wide.

sn.def: Fig.: A violent or rapid flow; a strong current; a flood; as, a torrent of vices; a torrent of eloquence.
sn.q: At length, Erasmus, that great injured name, . . . Stemmed the wild torrent of a barbarous age.

entry.ety: See Torrent n.
entry.def: Rolling or rushing in a rapid stream.
entry.q: Waves oftorrentfire.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a torrent; having the character of a torrent; caused by a torrent .

cs.cd: a glass tube thirty or more inches in length, open at the lower end and hermetically sealed at the upper, such as is used in the barometer.

a vacuum produced by filling with a fluid, as mercury, a tube hermetically closed at one end, and, after immersing the other end in a vessel of the same fluid, allowing the inclosed fluid to descend till it is counterbalanced by the pressure of the atmosphere, as in the barometer.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Torricelli, an Italian philosopher and mathematician, who, in 1643, discovered that the rise of a liquid in a tube, as in the barometer, is due to atmospheric pressure. See Barometer.

cs.cd: that space or board belt of the earth, included between the tropics, over which the sun is vertical at some period of every year, and the heat is always great.

entry.ety: L. torridus, fr. torrere to parch, to burn, akin to E. Thist: cf. F. torride. See Thirst

sn.def: Parched; dried with heat; as, a torrid plain or desert.
sn.q: Barca or Cyrene'storridsoil.

sn.def: Violenty hot; drying or scorching with heat; burning; parching.
sn.q: Torridheat.

entry.def: Torridness.
The quality or state of being torrid or parched.
A worthless woman; also, a worthless horse.
A gull.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A twisted cord; also, a molded or worked ornament of similar form.
entry.q: The crown decked with torsades of pearls.

entry.def: A torsel.

entry.ety: OF., fr. OF. & F. tors torse, twisted, wreathed, p. p. of tordre to twist, L. torquere. See Torture

sn.def: A wreath.
A developable surface. See under Developable.

entry.def: A plate of timber for the end of a beam or joist to rest on.
The tendency, as of a rope, to untwist after being twisted.

cs.cd: of a curveGeom, the indefinitely small angle between two consecutive osculating planes of a curve of double curvature.
the moment of a pair of equal and opposite couples which tend to twist a body.

an instrument for estimating very minute forces, as electric or magnetic attractions and repulsions, by the torsion of a very slender wire or fiber having at its lower extremity a horizontal bar or needle, upon which the forces act.
a scale for weighing in which the fulcra of the levers or beams are strained wires or strips acting by torsion.

entry.ety: F., fr. LL. torsio, fr. L. torquere tortum, to twist. See Torture

sn.def: The act of turning or twisting, or the state of being twisted; the twisting or wrenching of a body by the exertion of a lateral force tending to turn one end or part of it about a longitudinal axis, while the other is held fast or turned in the opposite direction.
That force with which a thread, wire, or rod of any material, returns, or tends to return, to a state of rest after it has been twisted; torsibility.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to torsion; resulting from torsion, or the force with which a thread or wire returns to a state of rest after having been twisted round its axis; as, torsional force.

entries.entry: Tor"sion e*lec*trom"e*ter. Elec A torsion balance used for measuring electric attraction or repulsion.
Torsion galvanometer. Elec A galvanometer in which current is measured by torsion.
Torsion head. That part of a torsion balance from which the wire or filament is suspended.
Torsion indicator. An autographic torsion meter.

Torsion meter. Mech An instrument for determining the torque on a shaft, and hence the horse power of an engine, esp. of a marine engine of high power, by measuring the amount of twist of a given length of the shaft. Called also torsimeter torsiometer torsometer.

entry.ety: Dan.; akin to Icel. þorskr a codfish, G. dorsch
entry.def: The cusk. See Cusk.
The codfish. Called also tusk.

entries.entry:
Tor"so n.; pl. E. Torsos #, It. Torsi #. It. torso, probably fr. L. thyrsus a stalk, stem, thyrsus, Gr. �; cf. OHG. torso turso, a stalk, stem, G. dorsche a cabbage stalk. Cf. Thyrsus Truss
The human body, as distinguished from the head and limbs; in sculpture, the trunk of a statue, mutilated of head and limbs; as, the torso of Hercules.

entry.cs: ‖Executor de son tort. See under Executor. Tort feasor Law a wrongdoer; a trespasser. Wharton.
entry.ety: F., from LL. tortum, fr. L. tortus twisted, crooked, p. p. of torqure to twist, bend. See Torture

sn.def: Mischief; injury; calamity.
sn.q: That had them long opprest with tort.

sn.def: Any civil wrong or injury; a wrongful act (not involving a breach of contract) for which an action will lie; a form of action, in some parts of the United States, for a wrong or injury.

entry.def: Stretched tight; taut.
entry.q: Yet holds he them with tortest rein.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. torta a cake
entry.def: a flat heap of moist, crushed silver ore, prepared for the patio process.

entries.entry:
Tor"teau n.; pl.Torteaus #. Of. torteau tortel, from L. tortus twisted. See Tort
Her A roundel of a red color.

entry.ety: F. toricolis; L. torquere tortum, to twist + collum the neck
entry.def: See Wryneck.

entry.ety: L. tortilis, fr. torquere tortum, to twist: cf. F. tortile
entry.def: Twisted; wreathed; coiled.
The quality or state of being tortile, twisted, or wreathed.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: An unleavened cake, as of maize flour, baked on a heated iron or stone.

entry.ety: LL. tortio. See Torsion
entry.def: Torment; pain.

entry.ety: From Tort

sn.def: Injurious; wrongful.
sn.q: Tortiouspower.

sn.def: Imploying tort, or privat injury for which the law gives damages; involing tort.

entry.def: In a tortous manner.

entry.ety: L. tortus, p. p. of torquere to twist, wind
entry.def: Twisted; wreathed.

entry.note: ☞ The term is applied especially to the land and fresh-water species, while the marine species are generally called turtles, but the terms tortoise and turtle are used synonymously by many writers. See Testudinata Terrapin, and Turtle.
entry.cs: Box tortoise Land tortoise, etc. See under Box Land, etc. Painted tortoise. Zoöl See Painted turtle, under Painted. Soft-shell tortoise. Zoöl See Trionyx. Spotted tortoise. Zoöl A small American fresh-water tortoise (Chelopus guttatus or Nanemys guttatus) having a blackish carapace on which are scattered round yellow spots. Tortoise beetle Zoöl any one of numerous species of small tortoise-shaped beetles. Many of them have a brilliant metallic luster. The larvæ feed upon the leaves of various plants, and protect themselves beneath a mass of dried excrement held over the back by means of the caudal spines. The golden tortoise beetle (Cassida aurichalcea) is found on the morning-glory vine and allied plants. Tortoise plant. Bot See Elephant's foot, under Elephant. Tortoise shell the substance of the shell or horny plates of several species of sea turtles, especially of the hawkbill turtle. It is used in inlaying and in the manufacture of various ornamental articles. Tortoise-shell butterfly Zoöl any one of several species of handsomely colored butterflies of the genus Aglais, as Aglais Milberti, and Aglais urticæ, both of which, in the larva state, feed upon nettles. Tortoise-shell turtle Zoöl the hawkbill turtle. See Hawkbill.
entry.ety: OE. tortuce, fr. OF. tortis crooked, fr. L. tortus twisted, crooked, contorted, p. p. of torquere tortum, to wind; cf. F. tortue tortoise, LL. tortuca tartuca, Pr. tortesa crookedness, tortis crooked. so called in allusion to its crooked feet. See Torture

sn.def: Any one of numerous species of reptiles of the order Testudinata.
Same as Testudo, 2.

entry.def: Having a color like that of a tortoise's shell, black with white and orange spots; -- used mostly to describe cats of that color.

def2.def: a tortoise-shell cat.

entry.ety: See Tortrix
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Tortix, or the family Tortricidæ.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. torquere tortum, to twist

sn.def: Any one of numerous species of small moths of the family Tortricidæ, the larvæ of which usually roll up the leaves of plants on which they live; -- also called leaf roller.
A genus of tropical short-tailed snakes, which are not venomous. One species (Tortrix scytalæ) is handsomely banded with black, and is sometimes worn alive by the natives of Brazil for a necklace.

entry.def: Swelled out at intervals like a knotted cord.

entry.ety: See Tortuous
entry.def: Wreathed; twisted; winding.

entry.ety: L. tortuositas: cf. F. tortuosite
entry.def: the quality or state of being tortuous.

entry.ety: OE. tortuos, L. tortuosus, fr. tortus a twisting, winding, fr. torquere tortum, to twist: cf. F. tortueux. See Torture

sn.def: Bent in different directions; wreathed; twisted; winding; as, a tortuous train; a tortuous leaf or corolla.
sn.q: The badger made his dark and tortuous hole on the side of every hill where the copsewood grew thick.

sn.def: Fig.: Deviating from rectitude; indirect; erroneous; deceitful.
sn.q: That course became somewhat lesstortuous, when the battle of the Boyne had cowed the spirit of the Jakobites.

sn.def: Injurious: tortious.
Oblique; -- applied to the six signs of the zodiac (from Capricorn to Gemini) which ascend most rapidly and obliquely.
sn.q: Infortunate ascendent tortuous.

entry.def: Capable of being tortured.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. tortura, fr. torquere tortum, to twist, rack, torture; probably akin to Gr. tre`pein to turn, G. drechseln to turn on a lathe, and perhaps to E. queer. Cf. Contort Distort Extort Retort Tart n. Torch Torment Tortion Tort Trope.

sn.def: Extreme pain; anguish of body or mind; pang; agony; torment; as, torture of mind.
sn.q: Ghastly spasm or racking torture.

sn.def: Especially, severe pain inflicted judicially, either as punishment for a crime, or for the purpose of extorting a confession from an accused person, as by water or fire, by the boot or thumbkin, or by the rack or wheel.
The act or process of torturing.
sn.q: Torture, which had always been deciared illegal, and which had recently been declared illegal even by the servile judges of that age, was inflicted for the last time in England in the month of May, 1640.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. tortured tôr"t�rd; 135; p. pr. & vb. n. tTorturing.
entry.ety: Cf. F. Torturer.

sn.def: To put to torture; to pain extremely; to harass; to vex.
To punish with torture; to put to the rack; as, to torture an accused person.
To wrest from the proper meaning; to distort.
To keep on the stretch, as a bow.
sn.q: The bow tortureth the string.

entry.def: One who tortures; a tormentor.
So as to torture.
Involving, or pertaining to, torture.
entry.q: The torturous crucifixion.

entries.entry:
Tor"u*la Tor"u*la n.; pl.Torulæ
NL., dim. of L. torus a semicircular molding Biol A chain of special bacteria. A genus of budding fungi. Same as Saccharomyces. Also used adjectively.

entry.def: Having the appearance of a torula; in the form of a little chain; as, a torulaform string of micrococci.

entry.ety: L. torulus, dim. of torus: cf. F. toruleux. See Torus
entry.def: Same as Torose.
Same as Torose.

entries.entry:
To"rus To"rus tō"rŭs n.; pl.Tori tō"rī. L., a round, swelling, or bulging place, an elevation. Cf. 3d Tore
Arch A large molding used in the bases of columns. Its profile is semicircular. See Illust. of Molding.
Zoöl One of the ventral parapodia of tubicolous annelids. It usually has the form of an oblong thickening or elevation of the integument with rows of uncini or hooks along the center. See Illust. under Tubicolæ.
Bot The receptacle, or part of the flower on which the carpels stand.
Geom
The surface described by the circumference of a circle revolving about a straight line in its own plane.
The solid inclosed by such a surface; -- sometimes called an anchor ring. 3d Tore{2}.

entry.def: Stern; grim. See Torvous.
entry.q: But yesterday his breath Awed Rome, and his least torved frown was death.

entry.ety: L. torvitas. See Torvous
entry.def: Sourness or severity of countenance; sternness.

entry.ety: L. torvus.
entry.def: Sour of aspect; of a severe countenance; stern; grim.
entry.q: That torvous, sour look produced by anger.

entries.entry:
To"ry ☞ The word Tory first occurs in English history in 1679, during the struggle in Parliament occasioned by the introduction of the bill for the exclusion of the duke of York from the line of succession, and was applied by the advocates of the bill to its opponents as a title of obloquy or contempt. The Tories subsequently took a broader ground, and their leading principle became the maintenance of things as they were. The name, however, has for several years ceased to designate an existing party, but is rather applied to certain traditional maxims of public policy. The political successors of the Tories are now commonly known as Conservatives. n.; pl.Tories #. Properly used of the Irish bogtrotters who robbed and plundered during the English civil wars, professing to be in sympathy with the royal cause; hence transferred to those who sought to maintain the extreme prerogatives of the crown; probably from Ir. toiridhe tor, a pursuer; akin to Ir. & Gael. toir a pursuit
Eng. Politics A member of the conservative party, as opposed to the progressive party which was formerly called the Whig, and is now called the Liberal, party; an earnest supporter of existing royal and ecclesiastical authority.
Amer. Hist One who, in the time of the Revolution, favored submitting to the claims of Great Britain against the colonies; an adherent to the crown.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Tories.
The principles of the Tories.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + scatter
entry.def: To scatter in pieces; to divide.

entry.ety: See Touse
entry.def: To tease, or comb, as wool.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. tonce shorn clipped, and E. tonsure
entry.def: Neat; trim.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + shred.
entry.def: To cut into shreds or pieces.

entry.cs: To toss off to drink hastily. to accomplish easily or quickly. to say in an offhand manner; as, to toss off a comment. to masturbate; -- British slang. To toss the cars.See under Oar, n.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tossed; (less properly Tost ); p. pr. & vb. n. Tossing
entry.ety: W. tosiaw tosio, to jerk, toss, snatch, tosa quick jerk, a toss, a snatch.

sn.def: To throw with the hand; especially, to throw with the palm of the hand upward, or to throw upward; as, to toss a ball.
To lift or throw up with a sudden or violent motion; as, to toss the head.
sn.q: He tossed his arm aloft, and proudly told me, He would not stay.

sn.def: To cause to rise and fall; as, a ship tossed on the waves in a storm.
sn.q: We being exceedingly tossed with a tempest.

sn.def: To agitate; to make restless.
sn.q: Calm region once, And full of peace, now tossed and turbulent.

sn.def: Hence, to try; to harass.
sn.q: Whom devils fly, thus is he tossed of men.

sn.def: To keep in play; to tumble over; as, to spend four years in tossing the rules of grammar.

cs.cd: to throw dice or a coin to determine the possession of; to gamble for.
to throw a coin into the air, and wager on which side it will fall, or determine a question by its fall.

sn.def: To roll and tumble; to be in violent commotion; to write; to fling.
sn.q: To toss and fling, and to be restless, only frets and enrages our pain.

sn.def: To be tossed, as a fleet on the ocean.
A throwing upward, or with a jerk; the act of tossing; as, the toss of a ball.
A throwing up of the head; a particular manner of raising the head with a jerk.

entry.def: See Tassel.
One who tosses.
In a tossy manner.

sn.def: The act of throwing upward; a rising and falling suddenly; a rolling and tumbling.

sd.def: A process which consists in washing ores by violent agitation in water, in order to separate the lighter or earthy particles; -- called also tozing, and treloobing, in Cornwall.
A process for refining tin by dropping it through the air while melted.

entry.def: A toper; one habitually given to strong drink; a drunkard.
Tossing the head, as in scorn or pride; hence, proud; contemptuous; scornful; affectedly indifferent; as, a tossy commonplace.
imp. & p. p. of Toss.

cs.cd: faster; more rapid.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Quick; rapid.

entry.ety: Pref. to- + swink
entry.def: To labor excessively.

entry.ety: Cf. Toddle Tottle Totter

sn.def: Anything small; -- frequently applied as a term of endearment to a little child.
A drinking cup of small size, holding about half a pint.
A foolish fellow.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Lit., so much; -- a term used in the English exchequer to indicate that a debt was good or collectible for the amount specified, and often written opposite the item.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Totted; p. pr. & vb. n. Totting

sn.def: To mark with the word “tot”; as, a totted debt. See Tot n.
To add; to count; to make up the sum of; to total; -- often with up.
sn.q: The last two tot up the bill.

entry.ety: From the native name in Egypt
entry.def: The grivet.

entry.cs: Total abstinence. See Abstinence n., 1. Total depravity. Theol See Original sin, under Original.
entry.ety: F., fr. LL. totalis, fr. L. tolus all,whole. Cf. Factotum Surtout Teetotum
entry.def: Whole; not divided; entire; full; complete; absolute; as, a total departure from the evidence; a total loss.
entry.q: Totaldarkness.
To undergo myself thetotalcrime.

entry.def: The whole; the whole sum or amount; as, these sums added make the grand total of five millions.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Totaled or Totalled; p. pr. & vb. n. Totaling or Totalling

sn.def: To bring to a total; also, to reach as a total; to amount to.
to determine the total of (a set of numbers); to add; -- often used with up; as, to total up the bill.
To damage beyond repair; -- used especially of vehicles damaged in an accident; as, he skid on an ice patch and totaled his Mercedes against a tree. From total loss.

entry.ety: See Total a.
entry.def: The total.
entry.q: I look on nothing but totalis.

entry.def: Same as Totalizator.

entry.ety: Cf. F. totalite, LL. totalitas

sn.def: The quality or state of being total; as, the totality of an eclipse.
The whole sum; the whole quantity or amount; the entirety; as, the totality of human knowledge.
sn.q: The totality of a sentence or passage.

entry.def: Act of totalizing, or state of being totalized.

entry.ety: From Totalize: cf. F. totalisateur
entry.def: A machine for registering and indicating the number and nature of bets made on horse races. Called also totalizer.
To make total, or complete; to reduce to completeness.
To use a totalizator.
Same as Totalizator.
In a total manner; wholly; entirely.
The quality or state of being total; entireness; totality.

entry.ety: Maori
entry.def: A coniferous tree (Podocarpus totara), next to the kauri the most valuable timber tree of New Zealand. Its hard reddish wood is used for furniture and building, esp. in wharves, bridges, etc. Also mahogany pine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toted; p. pr. & vb. n. Toting
entry.ety: Said to be of African origin
entry.def: To carry or bear; as, to tote a child over a stream; to tote a gun on one's hip; -- a colloquial word originating in the Southern States, and used there esp. by negroes, now common throughout the U. S.

entry.ety: L. totum, fr. totus all, whole
entry.def: The entire body, or all; as, the whole tote .

entry.ety: Pref. to- + tear.
entry.def: To tear or rend in pieces.

entry.ety: Massachusetts Indian wutohtimoin that to which a person or place belongs

sn.def: A rude picture, as of a bird, beast, or the like, used by the North American Indians as a symbolic designation, as of a family or a clan; also, the object or animal itself, considered as an symbol of the family.
sn.q: And they painted on the grave posts Of the graves, yet unforgotten, Each his own ancestral totem Each the symbol of his household; Figures of the bear and reindeer, Of the turtle, crane, and beaver.
The totem, the clan deity, the beast or bird who in some supernatural way attends to the clan and watches over it.

sn.def: Anything which serves as a venerated or mystic symbol or emblem.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a totem, or totemism.

sn.def: The system of distinguishing families, clans, etc., in a tribe by the totem.
Superstitious regard for a totem; the worship of any real or imaginary object; nature worship.

entry.def: One belonging to a clan or tribe having a totem.

entries.entry: To"tem poleorTo"tem post . A pole or pillar, carved and painted with a series of totemic symbols, set up before the house of certain Indian tribes of the northwest coast of North America, esp. Indians of the Koluschan stock.

entry.ety: See Tote to carry
entry.def: The stone roller. See Stone roller, under Stone.

entries.entry: T'oth"er. A colloquial contraction of the other, and formerly a contraction for that other. See the Note under That, 2. The tothir that was crucifield with him.

entry.ety: L. totus all, whole + E. palmate
entry.def: Having all four toes united by a web; -- said of certain sea birds, as the pelican and the gannet. See Illust. under Aves.

entry.ety: NL., from L. totus all, whole + palmus palm
entry.def: A division of swimming birds including those that have totipalmate feet.

entry.ety: L. totus all, whole + E. presence
entry.def: Omnipresence.

entry.ety: L. totus all, whole + E. present
entry.def: Omnipresent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tottered; p. pr. & vb. n. Tottering
entry.ety: Probably for older tolter; cf. AS. tealtrian to totter, vacillate. Cf.Tilt to incline, Toddle Tottle Totty

sn.def: To shake so as to threaten a fall; to vacillate; to be unsteady; to stagger; as, an old man totters with age.
sn.q: As a bowing wall shall ye be, and as atotteringfence.

sn.def: To shake; to reel; to lean; to waver.
sn.q: Troy nods from high, and totters to her fall.

entry.def: One who totters.
In a tottering manner.
Trembling or vaccilating, as if about to fall; unsteady; shaking.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tottled tŏt"t'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Tottling tŏt"tlĭng
entry.ety: See Toddle Totter
entry.def: To walk in a wavering, unsteady manner; to toddle; to topple.
Trembling or tottering, as if about to fall; unsteady.

entry.ety: OE. toti. Cf. Totter
entry.def: Unsteady; dizzy; tottery.
entry.q: For yet his noule [head] was totty of the must.

entry.def: Totty.
entry.q: My head is toty of my swink to-night.

entry.def: A sailor or fisherman; -- so called in some parts of the Pacific.

entry.ety: F., fr. Pg. tucano; from Brazilian name.

sn.def: Any one of numerous species of fruit-eating birds of tropical America belonging to Ramphastos Pteroglossus, and allied genera of the family Ramphastidæ. They have a very large, but light and thin, beak, often nearly as long as the body itself. Most of the species are brilliantly colored with red, yellow, white, and black in striking contrast.
A modern constellation of the southern hemisphere.

entry.def: A small toucan.

cs.cd: to bring it so close to the wind that its weather leech shakes.
to keep the ship as near the wind as possible.
to repair; to improve by touches or emendation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Touched; p. pr. & vb. n. Touching
entry.ety: F. toucher, OF. touchier tuchier; of Teutonic origin; cf. OHG. zucchen zukken, to twitch, pluck, draw, G. zukken zukken, v. intens. fr. OHG. ziohan to draw, G. ziehen, akin to E. tug. See Tuck v. t. Tug, and cf. Tocsin Toccata

sn.def: To come in contact with; to hit or strike lightly against; to extend the hand, foot, or the like, so as to reach or rest on.
sn.q: Him thus intent Ithuriel with his spearTouched lightly.

sn.def: To perceive by the sense of feeling.
sn.q: Nothing but body can be touched or touch.

sn.def: To come to; to reach; to attain to.
sn.q: The god, vindictive, doomed them never more- Ah, men unblessed! -- to touch their natal shore.

sn.def: To try; to prove, as with a touchstone.
sn.q: Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed.

sn.def: To relate to; to concern; to affect.
sn.q: The quarrel toucheth none but us alone.

sn.def: To handle, speak of, or deal with; to treat of.
sn.q: Storial thing that toucheth gentilesse.

sn.def: To meddle or interfere with; as, I have not touched the books.
To affect the senses or the sensibility of; to move; to melt; to soften; especially, to cause feelings of pity, compassion, sympathy, or gratitude in.
sn.q: What of sweet before Hath touched my sense, flat seems to this and harsh.
The tender sire was touched with what he said.

sn.def: To mark or delineate with touches; to add a slight stroke to with the pencil or brush.
sn.q: The lines, though touched but faintly, are drawn right.

sn.def: To infect; to affect slightly.
To make an impression on; to have effect upon.
sn.q: Its face . . . so hard that a file will not touch it.

sn.def: To strike; to manipulate; to play on; as, to touch an instrument of music.
sn.q: Theytouched their golden harps.

sn.def: To perform, as a tune; to play.
sn.q: A person is the royal retinue touched a light and lively air on the flageolet.

sn.def: To influence by impulse; to impel forcibly.
sn.q: No decree of mine, . . . [totouchwith lightest moment of impulse his free will,

sn.def: To harm, afflict, or distress.
sn.q: Let us make a covenant with thee, that thou wilt do us no hurt, as we have not touched thee.

sn.def: To affect with insanity, especially in a slight degree; to make partially insane; -- rarely used except in the past participle.
sn.q: She feared his head was a little touched.

sn.def: To be tangent to. See Tangent a.
To lay a hand upon for curing disease.
To compare with; to be equal to; -- usually with a negative; as, he held that for good cheer nothing could touch an open fire.
To induce to give or lend; to borrow from; as, to touch one for a loan; hence, to steal from.

cs.cd: to touch bottom lightly and without damage, as a vessel in motion.
to come or go to, without tarrying; as, the ship touched at Lisbon.
to come or go to for a short time.
cs.q: I made a little voyage round the lake, and touched on the several towns that lie on its coasts.
cs.cd: to discuss briefly, as only a small part of a discourse.

sn.def: To be in contact; to be in a state of junction, so that no space is between; as, two spheres touch only at points.
To fasten; to take effect; to make impression.
sn.q: Strong waters pierce metals, and will touch upon gold, that will not touch upon silver.

sn.def: To treat anything in discourse, especially in a slight or casual manner; -- often with on or upon.
sn.q: If the antiquaries have touched upon it, they immediately quitted it.

sn.def: To be brought, as a sail, so close to the wind that its weather leech shakes.

entry.note: ☞ Pure tactile feelings are necessarily rare, since temperature sensations and muscular sensations are more or less combined with them. The organs of touch are found chiefly in the epidermis of the skin and certain underlying nervous structures.
entry.cs: In touch Football outside of bounds. T. Hughes. in communication; communicating, once or repeatedly. To be in touch to be in contact, communication, or in sympathy. to be aware of current events. To keep touch. To be true or punctual to a promise or engagement Obs; hence, to fulfill duly a function. My mind and senses keep touch and time. Sir W. Scott. To keep in contact; to maintain connection or sympathy; -- with with or of. Also to keep in touch. Touch and go a phrase descriptive of a narrow escape. True as touchi. e.touchstone), quite true. Obs
entry.ety: Cf. F. touche. See Touch v.

sn.def: The act of touching, or the state of being touched; contact.
sn.q: Their touch affrights me as a serpent's sting.

sn.def: The sense by which pressure or traction exerted on the skin is recognized; the sense by which the properties of bodies are determined by contact; the tactile sense. See Tactile sense, under Tactile.
sn.q: The spider's touch, how exquisitely fine.

sn.def: Act or power of exciting emotion.
sn.q: Not alone The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, Do strongly speak to us.

sn.def: An emotion or affection.
sn.q: A true, natural, and a sensible touch of mercy.

sn.def: Personal reference or application.
sn.q: Speech of touch toward others should be sparingly used.

sn.def: A stroke; as, a touch of raillery; a satiric touch; hence, animadversion; censure; reproof.
sn.q: I never bare any touch of conscience with greater regret.

sn.def: A single stroke on a drawing or a picture.
sn.q: Never give the least touch with your pencil till you have well examined your design.

sn.def: Feature; lineament; trait.
sn.q: Of many faces, eyes, and hearts, To have the touches dearest prized.

sn.def: The act of the hand on a musical instrument; bence, in the plural, musical notes.
sn.q: Soft stillness and the night Become the touches of sweet harmony.

sn.def: A small quantity intermixed; a little; a dash.
sn.q: Eyes La touch of Sir Peter Lely in them.
Madam, I have a touch of your condition.

sn.def: A hint; a suggestion; slight notice.
sn.q: A small touch will put him in mind of them.

sn.def: A slight and brief essay.
sn.q: Print my preface in such form as, in the booksellers' phrase, will make a sixpenny touch.

sn.def: A touchstone; hence, stone of the sort used for touchstone.
sn.q: Now do I play thetouch.
A neat new monument of touch and alabaster.

sn.def: Hence, examination or trial by some decisive standard; test; proof; tried quality.
sn.q: Equity, the true touch of all laws.
Friends of noble touch .

sn.def: The particular or characteristic mode of action, or the resistance of the keys of an instrument to the fingers; as, a heavy touch, or a light touch ; also, the manner of touching, striking, or pressing the keys of a piano; as, a legato touch; a staccato touch .

The broadest part of a plank worked top and but (see Top and but, under Top n.), or of one worked anchor-stock fashion (that is, tapered from the middle to both ends); also, the angles of the stern timbers at the counters.
That part of the field which is beyond the line of flags on either side.
A boys' game; tag.
A set of changes less than the total possible on seven bells, that is, less than 5,040.
An act of borrowing or stealing.
Tallow; -- a plumber's term.

entry.def: Capable of being touched; tangible.
The act of touching the football down by a player behind his own goal line when it received its last impulse from an opponent; -- distinguished from safety touchdown.
A box containing lighted tinder, formerly carried by soldiers who used matchlocks, to kindle the match.

entry.cs: Safety touchdown. See under Safety.
entry.def: The act of touching the football down behind the opponents' goal; also the score (6 points) resulting from such a play.
The vent of a cannon or other firearm, by which fire is communicateed to the powder of the charge.
In a touchy manner.
The quality or state of being touchy; peevishness; irritability; irascibility.
Affecting; moving; pathetic; as, a touching tale.
Concerning; with respect to.
entry.q: Now, as touching things offered unto idols.

entry.def: The sense or act of feeling; touch.
See Impatiens.
Squirting cucumber. See under Cucumber.

A small bar of gold and silver, either pure, or alloyed in some known proportion with copper, for trying the purity of articles of gold or silver by comparison of the streaks made by the article and the bar on a touchstone.
Paper steeped in saltpeter, which burns slowly, and is used as a match for firing gunpowder, and the like.

cs.cd: basalt, the stone which composes the Giant's Causeway.

sn.def: Lydian stone; basanite; -- so called because used to test the purity of gold and silver by the streak which is left upon the stone when it is rubbed by the metal. See Basanite.

entry.sn: Fig.: Any test or criterion by which the qualities of a thing are tried. The foregoing doctrine affords us also a touchstone for the trial of spirits.

entry.def: To mention briefly, or in passing.
To make minor improvements in, especially in the appearance.
A paint applied to small areas of a painted surface, to cover small blemishes, especially on an automobile.

entry.ety: Probably for tachwood; OE. tache tinder (of uncertain origin) + wood

sn.def: Wood so decayed as to serve for tinder; spunk, or punk.
Dried fungi used as tinder; especially, the Polyporus igniarius.

entry.ety: For techy tetchy
entry.def: Peevish; irritable; irascible; techy; apt to take fire.
entry.q: It may be said of Dryden that he was at no time touchy about personal attacks.

cs.cd: to make it a matter of difficulty; to make it a hard matter.

entry.ety: OE. tough, AS. tōh, akin to D. taai, LG. taa tage tau, OHG. zāhi, G. zähe, and also to AS. getenge near to, close to, oppressive, OS. bitengi

sn.def: Having the quality of flexibility without brittleness; yielding to force without breaking; capable of resisting great strain; as, the ligaments of animals are remarkably tough .
sn.q: Toughroots and stubs.

sn.def: Not easily broken; able to endure hardship; firm; strong; -- of objects and people; as, tough sinews.
sn.q: A body made of brass, the crone demands, . . . Tough to the last, and with no toil to tire.
The basis of his character was caution combined with tough tenacity of purpose.

sn.def: Not easily separated; viscous; clammy; tenacious; as, tough phlegm.
Stiff; rigid; not flexible; stubborn; as, a tough bow.
sn.q: So tough a frame she could not bend.

sn.def: Severe; violent; as, a tough storm.
sn.q: Atoughdebate.

sn.def: Difficult to do, perform, or accomplish; as, a tough job.
Prone to aggressive or violent behavior; rowdyish; -- of people, or groups; as, a tough neighborhood; a tough character.

entry.def: A person who is tough{7}; a ruffian; a thug; as, a cluster of neighborhood toughs hanging out on the corner.
See Tough-pitch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toughened; p. pr. & vb. n. Toughening
entry.def: To grow or make tough, or tougher.
The ruddy duck.
Tough in a slight degree.
In a tough manner.
The quality or state of being tough.
The exact state or quality of texture and consistency of well reduced and refined copper.
Copper so reduced; -- called also tough-cake.
The wood warbler.

entry.ety: F. toupet, dim. of OF. top a tuft; of Teutonic origin, and akin to E. top. See Top apex, and cf. Topet

sn.def: A little tuft; a curl or artificial lock of hair.
A small wig, or a toppiece of a wig.
sn.q: Her powdered hair is turned backward over a toupee.

entry.ety: See Topet toupee
entry.def: The crested titmouse.

entry.ety: F. tour. See Tower
entry.def: A tower.

entry.ety: F. tour. See Turn v. t.

sn.def: A going round; a circuit; hence, a journey in a circuit; a prolonged circuitous journey; a comprehensive excursion; as, the tour of Europe; the tour of France or England.
sn.q: The bird of Jove stooped from his airy tour.

sn.def: A turn; a revolution; as, the tours of the heavenly bodies.
anything done successively, or by regular order; a turn; as, a tour of duty.
sn.syn: Journey; excursion. See Journey.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toured; p. pr. & vb. n. Touring
entry.def: To make a tourm; as, to tour throught a country.
Same as Turacou.

entry.ety: F. torbillion a whirlwind, tourbillion, fr. L. turbo, -inis, a whirl, whirlwind
entry.def: An ornamental firework which turns round, when in the air, so as to form a scroll of fire.

entries.entry: Tour"ing car. An automobile designed for touring; specif., a roomy car, not a limousine, for five or more passengers.

entry.def: One who makes a tour, or performs a journey, especially for pleasure.

entry.note: ☞ Crystals of tourmaline when heated exhibit electric polarity (see Pyroelectric n.). Tourmaline is also used in the form of a polariscope called tourmaline tongs.
entry.ety: F. tourmaline, cf. It. turmalina tormalina, NL. turmalina turmalinus; all fr. tournamal, a name given to this stone in Ceylon
entry.def: A mineral occurring usually in three-sided or six-sided prisms terminated by rhombohedral or scalenohedral planes. Black tourmaline (schorl) is the most common variety, but there are also other varieties, as the blue (indicolite), red (rubellite), also green, brown, and white. The red and green varieties when transparent are valued as jewels.

entry.ety: See Turn

sn.def: A spinning wheel.
The sheriff's turn, or court.

entry.note: ☞ It different from the joust, which was a trial of skill between one man and another.
entry.ety: OE. turnement tornement, OF. torneiement tornoiement, F. tournoiement a turning or wheeling round. See Tourney

sn.def: A mock fight, or warlike game, formerly in great favor, in which a number of combatants were engaged, as an exhibition of their address and bravery; hence, figuratively, a real battle.
sn.q: In battle and intourneyment.
With cruel tournament the squadrons join.

sn.def: Any contest of skill in which there are many contestents for championship; as, a chess tournament .

entry.def: Work turned on a lathe; turnery.

entry.ety: OF. tornei tornoi, F. tournoi, fr. OF. torneier tornoier tournoier, to tit, to tourney, F. tournoyer to turn round and round. See Turn v. t.
entry.def: A tournament.
entry.q: At tilt or tourney or like warlike game.
We hold a tourney here to-morrow morn, And there is scantly time for half the work.

entry.ety: Cf.OF. torneier. See Tourney n.
entry.def: To perform in tournaments; to tilt.
entry.q: Well could he tourney, and in lists debate.

entry.ety: F., fr. tourner to turn
entry.def: An instrument for arresting hemorrhage. It consists essentially of a pad or compress upon which pressure is made by a band which is tightened by a screw or other means.

entry.ety: F., belonging to Tours in France
entry.def: A former French money of account worth 20 sous, or a franc. It was thus called in distinction from the Paris livre, which contained 25 sous.

entry.ety: F., fr. tourner to turn

sn.def: Turn; contour; figure.
Any device used by women to expand the skirt of a dress below the waist; a bustle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Toused touzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Tousing
entry.ety: OE. tosen. √64. See tease, and cf. Tose Toze
entry.def: To pull; to haul; to tear; to worry.
entry.q: As a bear, whom angry curs have touzed.

entry.def: A pulling; a disturbance.
Same as Tousle.
One who touses.

entry.ety: Freq. of touse. Cf.Tossle
entry.def: To put into disorder; to tumble; to touse.

entry.ety: F., all the months, i. e., every month
entry.def: A kind of starch with very large, oval, flattened grains, often sold as arrowroot, and extensively used for adulterating cocoa. It is made from the rootstocks of a species of Canna, probably Canna edulis, the tubers of which are edible every month in the year.

entry.ety: See Touse n. & v.
entry.def: Tousled; tangled; rough; shaggy.

entry.ety: See 1st Toot

sn.def: To act as a tout. See 2d Tout.
To ply or seek for customers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Touted; p. pr. & vb. n. Touting

sn.def: To look narrowly; spy.

sd.def: To spy out the movements of race horses at their trials, or to get by stealth or other improper means the secrets of the stable, for betting purposes.
To act as a tout; to tout, or give a tip on, a race horse.

entry.def: One who secretly watches race horses which are in course of training, to get information about their capabilities, for use in betting.

sn.def: One who gives a tip on a race horses for an expected compensation, esp. in hopes of a share in any winnings; -- usually contemptuous.
One who solicits custom, as a runner for a hotel, cab, gambling place.
A spy for a smuggler, thief, or the like.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. F. tout all
entry.def: In the game of solo, a proposal to win all eight tricks.

entry.ety: See 3d Toot.
entry.def: To toot a horn.
To spy out information about, as a racing stable or horse.
To give a tip on (a race horse) to a better with the expectation of sharing in the latter's winnings.
The anus.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: All together; hence, in costume, the fine arts, etc., the general effect of a work as a whole, without regard to the execution of the separate perts.
One who seeks customers, as for an inn, a public conveyance, shops, and the like: hence, an obtrusive candidate for office.
entry.q: The prey of ring droppers, . . . duffers, touters, or any of those bloodless sharpers who are, perhaps, better known to the police.

entry.def: See Touse.

entry.ety: OE. tow, AS. tow, akin to OD. touw, Icel. tō a tuft of wool for spinning; cf. E. taw, v. t
entry.def: The coarse and broken part of flax or hemp, separated from the finer part by the hatchel or swingle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Towed tōd; p. pr. & vb. n. Towing
entry.ety: OE. towen, toȝen; akin to OFries. toga to pull about, OHG. zogōn, Icel. toga, AS. tohline a towline, and AS. teón to draw, p. p. getogen. See Tug
entry.def: To draw or pull through the water, as a vessel of any kind, by means of a rope.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. taug a rope, from the same root as E. tow v. t.

sn.def: A rope by which anything is towed; a towline, or towrope.
The act of towing, or the state of being towed; -- chiefly used in the phrase, to take in tow, that is to tow.
That which is towed, or drawn by a towline, as a barge, raft, collection of boats, ect.

entry.ety: From Tow v..cf. F. touage

sn.def: The act of towing.
The price paid for towing.

entry.def: A towel.

entry.ety: AS. � impending, imminent, future, toward, � towards. See To, and -ward wards

sn.def: In the direction of; to.
sn.q: He set his face toward the wilderness.
The waves make towards" the pebbled shore.

sn.def: With direction to, in a moral sense; with respect or reference to; regarding; concerning.
sn.q: His eye shall be evil toward his brother.
Herein do I exercise myself, to have always a conscience void of offense toward God, and toward men.

sn.def: Tending to; in the direction of; in behalf of.
sn.q: This was the first alarm England received towards any trouble.

sn.def: Near; about; approaching to.
sn.q: I am toward nine years older since I left you.

entry.def: Near; at hand; in state of preparation.
entry.q: Do you hear sught, sir, of a battle toward ?
We have a trifling foolish banquet Towards.

entry.ety: AS. �. See Toward prep.

sn.def: Approaching; coming near.
sn.q: Histowardperil.

sn.def: Readly to do or learn; compliant with duty; not froward; apt; docile; tractable; as, a toward youth.
Ready to act; forward; bold; valiant.
sn.q: Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.

entry.def: The quality or state of being towardly; docility; tractableness.
entry.q: The beauty and towardliness of these children moved her brethren to envy.

entry.def: Same as Toward a., 2.
entry.q: He's towardly and will come on apace.

entry.def: Quality or state of being toward.
See Toward.

sn.def: A vessel constructed for being towed, as a canal boat.
A steamer used for towing other vessels; a tug.

cs.cd: the fruit of the cucurbitaceous plant Luffa Ægyptiaca; also, the plant itself. The fruit is very fibrous, and, when separated from its rind and seeds, is used as a sponge or towel. Called also Egyptian bath sponge, and dishcloth.

entry.ety: OE. towaille towail, F. touaille, LL. toacula, of Teutonic origin; cf. OHG. dwahila swahilla, G. zwehle, fr. OHG. dwahan to wash; akin to D. dwaal a towel, AS. þweán to wash, OS. thwahan, Icel. þvā, Sw. två, Dan. toe, Goth. þwahan. Cf. Doily
entry.def: A cloth used for wiping, especially one used for drying anything wet, as the person after a bath.
To beat with a stick.
Cloth for towels, especially such as is woven in long pieces to be cut at will, as distinguished from that woven in towel lengths with borders, etc.

entry.cs:
Gay Lussac's tower Chem a large tower or chamber used in the sulphuric acid process, to absorb (by means of concentrated acid) the spent nitrous fumes that they may be returned to the Glover's tower to be reemployed. See Sulphuric acid, under Sulphuric, and Glover's tower, below. Glover's tower Chem a large tower or chamber used in the manufacture of sulphuric acid, to condense the crude acid and to deliver concentrated acid charged with nitrous fumes. These fumes, as a catalytic, effect the conversion of sulphurous to sulphuric acid. See Sulphuric acid, under Sulphuric, and Gay Lussac's tower, above. Round tower. See under Round a.
Shot tower. See under Shot. Tower bastion Fort a bastion of masonry, often with chambers beneath, built at an angle of the interior polygon of some works. Tower mustard Bot the cruciferous plant Arabis perfoliata. Tower of London a collection of buildings in the eastern part of London, formerly containing a state prison, and now used as an arsenal and repository of various objects of public interest.
entry.ety: OE. tour,tor,tur, F. tour, L. turris; akin to Gr. �; cf. W. twr a tower, Ir. tor a castle, Gael. torr a tower, castle. Cf. Tor Turret

sd.def: A mass of building standing alone and insulated, usually higher than its diameter, but when of great size not always of that proportion.
A projection from a line of wall, as a fortification, for purposes of defense, as a flanker, either or the same height as the curtain wall or higher.
A structure appended to a larger edifice for a special purpose, as for a belfry, and then usually high in proportion to its width and to the height of the rest of the edifice; as, a church tower .

sn.def: A citadel; a fortress; hence, a defense.
sn.q: Thou hast been a shelter for me, and a strong tower from the enemy.

sn.def: A headdress of a high or towerlike form, fashionable about the end of the seventeenth century and until 1715; also, any high headdress.
sn.q: Lay trains of amorous intrigues In towers, and curls, and periwigs.

sn.def: High flight; elevation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. towered; p. pr. & vb. n. towering
entry.def: To rise and overtop other objects; to be lofty or very high; hence, to soar.
entry.q: On the other side an high rock towered still.
My lord protector's hawks do tower so well.

entry.def: To soar into.
Adorned or defended by towers.
entry.q: Towered cities please us then.

sn.def: Very high; elevated; rising aloft; as, a towering height.
Hence, extreme; violent; surpassing.
sn.q: A man agitated by a towering passion.

entry.def: Having towers; adorned or defended by towers.
entry.q: Towery cities.

sn.def: An urchin who has soft, whitish hair.
The hooded merganser.
A low alluvial island or shoal in a river.

entry.def: The chewink.
The sanderling; -- so called from its cry.

entry.ety: AS. tohline. See Tow v. t. and Line.
entry.def: A line used to tow vessels; a towrope.

entry.note: ☞ The same form of expressions is used in regard to other populous towns.
☞ Town is often used adjectively or in combination with other words; as, town clerk, or town-clerk; town-crier, or town crier; townhall, town-hall, or town hall; townhouse, town house, or town-house.
entry.cs: Town clerk an office who keeps the records of a town, and enters its official proceedings. See Clerk. Town cress Bot the garden cress, or peppergrass. Dr. Prior. Town house. A house in town, in distinction from a house in the country. See Townhouse. Town meeting a legal meeting of the inhabitants of a town entitled to vote, for the transaction of public bisiness. U. S Town talk the common talk of a place; the subject or topic of common conversation.
entry.ety: OE. toun tun, AS. tun inclosure, fence, village, town; akin to D. tuin a garden, G. zaun a hadge, fence, OHG. zun, Icel. tun an inclosure, homestead, house, Ir. & Gael. dun a fortress, W. din. Cf. Down adv. & prep. Dune tine to inclose

sn.def: Formerly: An inclosure which surrounded the mere homestead or dwelling of the lord of the manor. Obs The whole of the land which constituted the domain. Obs A collection of houses inclosed by fences or walls.
Any number or collection of houses to which belongs a regular market, and which is not a city or the see of a bishop.

Any collection of houses larger than a village, and not incorporated as a city; also, loosely, any large, closely populated place, whether incorporated or not, in distinction from the country, or from rural communities.
sn.q: God made the country, and man made the town.

sn.def: The body of inhabitants resident in a town; as, the town voted to send two representatives to the legislature; the town voted to lay a tax for repairing the highways.
A township; the whole territory within certain limits, less than those of a country.
The court end of London; -- commonly with the.
The metropolis or its inhabitants; as, in winter the gentleman lives in town; in summer, in the country.
sn.q: Always hankering after the diversions of the town.
Stunned with his giddy larum half the town.

sn.def: A farm or farmstead; also, a court or farmyard.
sn.syn: Village; hamlet. See Village.

entry.def: A town officer who makes proclamations to the people; the public crier of a town.
Having towns; containing many towns.
A public hall or building, belonging to a town, where the public offices are established, the town council meets, the people assemble in town meeting, etc.
A building devoted to the public used of a town; a townhall.
Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of a town; like the town.
Having no town.
A small town.
The people of a town; especially, the inhabitants of a city, in distinction from country people; townspeople.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States, many of the States are divided into townships of five, six, seven, or perhaps ten miles square, and the inhabitants of such townships are invested with certain powers for regulating their own affairs, such as repairing roads and providing for the poor. The township is subordinate to the county.

sn.def: The district or territory of a town.
In surveys of the public land of the United States, a division of territory six miles square, containing 36 sections.
In Canada, one of the subdivisions of a county.

entries.entry:
Towns"man tounz"m�n n.; pl.Townsmen tounz"m�n.
An inhabitant of a town; one of the same town with another.
A selectman, in New England. See Selectman.

entry.def: The inhabitants of a town or city, especially in distinction from country people; townsfolk.
Toward a town.
A path traveled by men or animals in towing boats; -- called also towing path.
A rope used in towing vessels.

entry.ety: See Touse to pull about.
entry.def: A familiar name for a dog.
Composed of, or like, tow.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. toxiko`n poison + a"i^ma blood
entry.def: Blood poisoning. See under Blood.

entry.ety: See Toxic; Albumin
entry.def: Any of a class of toxic substances of protein nature; a toxin.

entry.ety: L. toxicum poison, originally, a poison in which arrows were dipped, Gr. toxiko`nsc. �) poison for smearing arrows with, fr. toxiko`s of or for the bow, from to`xon bow, arrow. Cf. Intoxicate
entry.def: Of or pertaining to poison; poisonous; as, toxic medicines.
A poisonous agent or drug, as opium; an intoxicant.

entry.ety: L. toxicum a poison: cf. toxicatus smeared with poison
entry.def: Poisoning.
The quality or state of being toxic or poisonous; poisonousness.

entry.ety: See Toxic, and -genic
entry.def: Producing toxic products; as, toxicogenic germs or bacteria.

entry.ety: Cf.F. toxicologique.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to toxicology.
One versed in toxicology; the writer of a treatise on poisons.

entry.ety: Gr. toxiko`n poison + -logy; cf. F. toxicologie. See Toxic.
entry.def: The science which treats of poisons, their effects, antidotes, and recognition; also, a discourse or treatise on the science.

entry.ety: See. Toxic, and Mania

sn.def: Toxiphobia.
An insane desire for intoxicating or poisonous drugs, as alcohol or opium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. to`xon a bow + L. ferre to bear
entry.def: Same as Toxoglossa.

entry.ety: Gr. toxiko`n. See Toxic.
entry.def: A poisonous product formed by an organism, such as a pathogenic bacterium, a plant or an animal, usually having a high molecular weight, often a protein or a polysaccharide, but occasionally a low-molecular weight agent such as tetrodotoxin.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. toxiko`n poison + fo`bos fear
entry.def: An insane or greatly exaggerated dread of poisons.

entry.ety: Gr. to`xon a bow + �, �, a tooth
entry.def: A gigantic extinct herbivorous mammal from South America, having teeth bent like a bow. It is the type of the order Toxodonta.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: An extinct order of Mammalia found in the South American Tertiary formation. The incisor teeth were long and curved and provided with a persistent pulp. They are supposed to be related both to the rodents and ungulates. Called also Toxodontia.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. to`xon a bow + � tongue
entry.def: A division of marine gastropod mollusks in which the radula are converted into poison fangs. The cone shells (Conus), Pleurotoma, and Terebra, are examples. See Illust. of Cone n., 4, Pleurotoma, and Terebra.

entry.ety: Toxin + -oid
entry.def: An altered form of a toxin, possessing little or no toxic power.

entry.ety: Gr. to`xon a bow + filei^n to love
