entry.def: A lover of archery; one devoted to archery.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � an archer
entry.def: A genus of fishes comprising the archer fishes. See Archer fish.

entry.ety: D. tuid tools, implements, stuff, trash, speeltuig playthings, toys; akin to G. zeug stuff, materials, MNG. ziuc, Icel. tygi gear; all ultimately from the root of E. tug, v. t.; cf. G. zeugen to beget, MHG. ziugen to beget, make ready, procure. See Tug v. t.

sn.def: A plaything for children; a bawble.
A thing for amusement, but of no real value; an article of trade of little value; a trifle.
sn.q: They exchange for knives, glasses, and such toys, great abundance of gold and pearl.

sn.def: A wild fancy; an odd conceit; idle sport; folly; trifling opinion.
sn.q: To fly about playing their wanton toys.
What if a toy take 'em in the heels now, and they all run away.
Nor light and idle toys my lines may vainly swell.

sn.def: Amorous dalliance; play; sport; pastime.
sn.q: To dally thus with death is no fit toy.

sn.def: An old story; a silly tale.
A headdress of linen or woolen, that hangs down over the shoulders, worn by old women of the lower classes; -- called also toy mutch.
sn.q: Having, moreover, put on her cleantoy, rokelay, and scarlet plaid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. toyed; p. pr. & vb. n. toying
entry.def: To dally amorously; to trifle; to play.
entry.q: To toy, to wanton, dally, smile and jest.

entry.def: To treat foolishly.

entry.ety: To, prep. + year.
entry.def: This year.
One who toys; one who is full of trifling tricks; a trifler.
Full of trifling play.
A house for children to play in or to play with; a playhouse.
In a toying manner.

sn.def: Sportive; trifling; wanton.
Resembling a toy.

entry.def: One who deals in toys.
A shop where toys are sold.
Disposed to toy; trifling; wanton.
To pull violently; to touse.

entry.ety: See Toze
entry.def: Soft, like wool that has been teased.

entries.entry: Tra"be*a Tra"be*a n.; pl.Trabeæ #. L Rom. Antiq A toga of purple, or ornamented with purple horizontal stripes. -- worn by kings, consuls, and augurs.

entry.def: Furnished with an entablature.

entry.ety: L. trabs trabis, a beam, a timber
entry.def: Same as Entablature.

entries.entry: Tra*bec"u*la Tra*bec"u*la n.; pl.Trabeculæ -lē. L., a little beam Anat A small bar, rod, bundle of fibers, or septal membrane, in the framework of an organ part.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a trabecula or trabeculæ; composed of trabeculæ.
Crossbarred, as the ducts in a banana stem.
Same as Trubu.

entry.ety: F. trais. pl. of trait. See Trait

sn.def: One of two straps, chains, or ropes of a harness, extending from the collar or breastplate to a whiffletree attached to a vehicle or thing to be drawn; a tug.

A connecting bar or rod, pivoted at each end to the end of another piece, for transmitting motion, esp. from one plane to another; specif., such a piece in an organ-stop action to transmit motion from the trundle to the lever actuating the stop slider.

entry.cs: Syn.-Vestige; mark; token. See Vestige.
entry.ety: F. trace. See Trace v. t.

sn.def: A mark left by anything passing; a track; a path; a course; a footprint; a vestige; as, the trace of a carriage or sled; the trace of a deer; a sinuous trace .

A very small quantity of an element or compound in a given substance, especially when so small that the amount is not quantitatively determined in an analysis; -- hence, in stating an analysis, often contracted to tr.
A mark, impression, or visible appearance of anything left when the thing itself no longer exists; remains; token; vestige.
sn.q: The shady empire shall retain no trace Of war or blood, but in the sylvan chase.

sn.def: The intersection of a plane of projection, or an original plane, with a coordinate plane.
The ground plan of a work or works.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. traced; p. pr. & vb. n. tracing
entry.ety: OF. tracier, F. tracer, from (assumed) LL. tractiare, fr.L. tractus, p. p. of trahere to draw. Cf. Abstract Attract Contract Portratt Tract Trail Train Treat.

sn.def: To mark out; to draw or delineate with marks; especially, to copy, as a drawing or engraving, by following the lines and marking them on a sheet superimposed, through which they appear; as, to trace a figure or an outline; a traced drawing.
sn.q: Some faintly traced features or outline of the mother and the child, slowly lading into the twilight of the woods.

sn.def: To follow by some mark that has been left by a person or thing which has preceded; to follow by footsteps, tracks, or tokens.
sn.q: You may trace the deluge quite round the globe.
I feel thy power . . . to trace the ways Of highest agents.

sn.def: Hence, to follow the trace or track of.
sn.q: How all the way the prince on footpace traced.

sn.def: To copy; to imitate.
sn.q: That servile path thou nobly dost decline, Of tracing word, and line by line.

sn.def: To walk over; to pass through; to traverse.
sn.q: We do tracethis alley up and down.

entry.def: To walk; to go; to travel.
entry.q: Not wont on foot with heavy arms to trace.

entry.def: Capable of being traced.

entry.note: Radioactive tracers are used, for example, to measure the retention or distribution of residues of drugs after administration to an animal, to determine the type and rate of metabolism; also, to measure the rate of motion of molecules in electrophoresis or the leakage of small quantities of material from a container. Small fluorescent tracers may be attached in many cases to macromolecules such as proteins or nucleic acids, allowing the motions of such macromolecules to be easily observed by their acquired fluorescence, without appreciably changing their properties. In biological and biochemial systems the common radioactive isotopes used in tracers are carbon-14, tritium (hydrogen-3), sulfur-35, phosphorus-32, and iodine-131; other isotopes are also used, including non-radioactive isotopes such as carbon-13.
entry.def: One who, or that which, traces.

sn.def: A person engaged (esp. in the express or railway service) in tracing, or searching out, missing articles, as packages or freight cars.
An inquiry sent out (esp. in transportation service) for a missing article, as a letter or an express package.

a type of ammunition that emits light or smoke as it moves toward its target, providing a visible path of the projectile in flight so that the point of impact may be observed; -- called also tracer ammunition.
the chemical substance used in tracer ammunition to cause it to be visible in flight.

a chemical substance with properties, such as radioactivity or fluorescence, which make it easily measurable, used to observe the movements of chemically related substances through a biological, physical, or chemical system; -- in biochemistry, also called labeled compounds.

entries.entry:
Tra"cer/y ☞ Window tracery is of two sorts, plate tracery and bar tracery. Plate tracery, common in Italy, consists of a series of ornamental patterns cut through a flat plate of stone. Bar tracery is a decorative pattern formed by the curves and intersections of the molded bars of the mullions. Window tracery is imitated in many decorative objects, as panels of wood or metal either pierced or in relief. See also Stump tracery under Stump, and Fan tracery under Fan. n.; pl.Traceries
Arch
Ornamental work with rambled lines. Especially:
The decorative head of a Gothic window.
A similar decoration in some styles of vaulting, the ribs of the vault giving off the minor bars of which the tracery is composed.
A tracing of lines; a system of lines produced by, or as if by, tracing, esp. when interweaving or branching out in ornamental or graceful figures. Knit with curioustracery.

Tra"che*a n.; pl.Tracheæ #. NL.,from L. trachia, Gr. trachei^asc. � windpipe), from � rough, rugged: cf. F. trachée
Anat The windpipe. See Illust. of Lung.
Zoöl One of the respiratory tubes of insects and arachnids.
Bot One of the large cells in woody tissue which have spiral, annular, or other markings, and are connected longitudinally so as to form continuous ducts.

entry.ety: Cf.F. tracheal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the trachea; like a trachea.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A division of Arachnida including those that breathe only by means of tracheæ. It includes the mites, ticks, false scorpions, and harvestmen.
Tracheal; breathing by means of tracheæ.

def2.def: One of the Trachearia.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: An extensive division of arthropods comprising all those which breathe by tracheæ, as distinguished from Crustacea, which breathe by means of branchiæ.
Breathing by means of tracheæ; of or pertaining to the Tracheata.
Any arthropod having tracheæ; one of the Tracheata.
A wood cell with spiral or other markings and closed throughout, as in pine wood.

entry.ety: NL. See Trachea; -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of the trachea, or windpipe.

entry.ety: Gr. � neck
entry.def: Any one of a tribe of beetles (Trachelides) which have the head supported on a pedicel. The oil beetles and the Cantharides are examples.

entry.ety: Gr.� neck + -pod:cf.F. trachelipode
entry.def: One of the Trachelipoda.

entry.ety: NL. See Trachelipod
entry.def: An extensive artificial group of gastropods comprising all those which have a spiral shell and the foot attached to the base of the neck.
Having the foot united with the neck; of or pertaining to the Trachelipoda.

entry.ety: Gr.� + E. tranchiate
entry.def: Having the gills situated upon the neck; -- said of certain mollusks.

entry.ety: Gr. � neck + � to sew
entry.def: The operation of sewing up a laceration of the neck of the uterus.

entry.ety: NL.,fr. trachea + -enchyma as in E. parenchyma
entry.def: A vegetable tissue consisting of tracheæ.

entries.entry:
Tra`che*o*bran"chi*a Tra`che*o*bran"chi*a n.; pl.Tracheobranchlae #. NL. See Trachea, and Branchia
Zoöl One of the gill-like breathing organs of certain aquatic insect larvæ. They contain tracheal tubes somewhat similar to those of other insects.

entry.def: Pertaining both to the tracheal and bronchial tubes, or to their junction; -- said of the syrinx of certain birds.

entry.ety: Gr. � the windpipe + � a tumor: cf.F. tracheocele.
entry.def: Goiter.
A tumor containing air and communicating with the trachea.

entry.ety: NL., from trachea + Gr. fonei^n to sound
entry.def: A group of passerine birds having the syrinx at the lower end of the trachea.

entry.ety: Trachea + -scopy
entry.def: Examination of the interior of the trachea by means of a mirror.

entry.ety: Trachea + Gr. � to cut: cf.F. tracheotomie
entry.def: The operation of making an opening into the windpipe.
Of, pertaining to, or like, Trachinus, a genus of fishes which includes the weevers. See Weever.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Tracheitis.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � roughness, fr. � rough
entry.def: a contagious granular conjunctivitis caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is a chronic inflammation of the conjunctiva

entry.ety: Gr. � rough + � fruit
entry.def: Rough-fruited.

entry.ety: NL., fr.Gr. � rough + medusa
entry.def: A division of acalephs in which the development is direct from the eggs, without a hydroid stage. Some of the species are parasitic on other medusæ.

entry.ety: Gr. � rough + � seed
entry.def: Rough-seeded.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � rough + stoma
entry.def: An order of tailed aquatic amphibians, including Siren and Pseudobranchus. They have anterior legs only, are eel-like in form, and have no teeth except a small patch on the palate. The external gills are persistent through life.

entry.ety: Gr. � rough, rugged: cg. F. trachyte
entry.def: An igneous rock, usually light gray in color and breaking with a rough surface. It consists chiefly of orthoclase feldspar with sometimes hornblende and mica.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trachytique
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, trachyte.

entry.ety: Trachyte + -oid
entry.def: Resembling trachyte; -- used to define the structure of certain rocks.

cs.cd: specially prepared transparent cloth or paper, which enables a drawing or print to be clearly seen through it, and so allows the use of a pen or pencil to produce a facsimile by following the lines of the original placed beneath.

sn.def: The act of one who traces; especially, the act of copying by marking on thin paper, or other transparent substance, the lines of a pattern placed beneath; also, the copy thus producted.
A regular path or track; a course.

cs.cd: a railway scale. See under Railway.

entry.ety: OF. trac track of horses, mules, trace of animals; of Teutonic origin; cf.D. trek a drawing, trekken to draw, travel, march, MHG. trechen, pret. trach. Cf. Trick

sn.def: A mark left by something that has passed along; as, the track, or wake, of a ship; the track of a meteor; the track of a sled or a wheel.
sn.q: The bright track of his fiery car.

sn.def: A mark or impression left by the foot, either of man or beast; trace; vestige; footprint.
sn.q: Far from track of men.

sn.def: The entire lower surface of the foot; -- said of birds, etc.
A road; a beaten path.
sn.q: Behold Torquatus the same track pursue.

sn.def: Course; way; as, the track of a comet.
A path or course laid out for a race, for exercise, etc.
The permanent way; the rails.
A tract or area, as of land.
sn.q: Smalltracksof ground.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. tracked; p. pr. & vb. n. tracking
entry.def: To follow the tracks or traces of; to pursue by following the marks of the feet; to trace; to trail; as, to track a deer in the snow.
entry.q: It was often found impossible to track the robbers to their retreats among the hills and morasses.

sn.def: To draw along continuously, as a vessel, by a line, men or animals on shore being the motive power; to tow.
The act of tracking, or towing, as a boat; towage.
Lines of track, collectively; as, an extensive trackage .
One who, or that which, tracks or pursues, as a man or dog that follows game.
sn.q: And of the trackers of the deer Scarce half the lessening pack was near.

sn.def: In the organ, a light strip of wood connecting (in path) a key and a pallet, to communicate motion by pulling.

entry.def: Any workman engaged in work involved in putting the track in place.
Having no track; marked by no footsteps; untrodden; as, a trackless desert.
entry.q: To climb the trackless mountain all unseen.

entries.entry: Track"man n.; pl. -men . Railroads One employed on work on the track; specif., a trackwalker.

entry.def: One who has charge of the track; -- called also roadmaster.
A towing path.
See Trackschuyt.
A person employed to walk over and inspect a section of tracks.
Any of two or more narrow paths, of steel, smooth stone, or the like, laid in a public roadway otherwise formed of an inferior pavement, as cobblestones, to provide an easy way for wheels.

entry.cs: Tracts for the Times. See Tractarian.
entry.ety: Abbrev.fr. tractate
entry.def: A written discourse or dissertation, generally of short extent; a short treatise, especially on practical religion.
entry.q: The church clergy at that time writ the best collection of tracts against popery that ever appeared.

entry.ety: L. tractus a drawing, train, track, course, tract of land, from trahere tractum, to draw. Senses 4 and 5 are perhaps due to confusion with track. See Trace,v., and cf. Tratt

sn.def: Something drawn out or extended; expanse.
sn.q: The deeptractof hell.

sn.def: A region or quantity of land or water, of indefinite extent; an area; as, an unexplored tract of sea.
sn.q: A very high mountain joined to the mainland by a narrow tract of earth.

sn.def: Traits; features; lineaments.
sn.q: The discovery of a man's self by the tracts of his countenance is a great weakness.

sn.def: The footprint of a wild beast.
Track; trace.
sn.q: Efface all tract of its traduction.
But flies an eagle flight, bold, and forthon, Leaving no tract behind.

sn.def: Treatment; exposition.
Continuity or extension of anything; as, the tract of speech.
Continued or protracted duration; length; extent.
sn.q: Improved bytractof time.

sn.def: Verses of Scripture sung at Mass, instead of the Alleluia, from Septuagesima Sunday till the Saturday befor Easter; -- so called because sung tractim, or without a break, by one voice, instead of by many as in the antiphons.
sn.syn: Region; district; quarter; essay; treatise; dissertation.

entry.def: To trace out; to track; also, to draw out; to protact.

entry.ety: L. tractabilitas: cf.F. tractabilite
entry.def: The quality or state of being tractable or docile; docility; tractableness.

entry.ety: L. tractabilis, fr, tractare to draw violently, to handle, treat. See Treat v. t.

sn.def: Capable of being easily led, taught, or managed; docile; manageable; governable; as, tractable children; a tractable learner.
sn.q: I shall find them tractable enough.

sn.def: Capable of being handled; palpable; practicable; feasible; as, tractable measures.

entry.def: One of the writers of the Oxford tracts, called “Tracts for the Times,” issued during the period 1833-1841, in which series of papers the sacramental system and authority of the Church, and the value of tradition, were brought into prominence. Also, a member of the High Church party, holding generally the principles of the Tractarian writers; a Puseyite.
Of or pertaining to the Tractarians, or their principles.
The principles of the Tractarians, or of those persons accepting the teachings of the “Tracts for the Times.”

entry.ety: L. tractatus a touching, handling, treatise. See Tractable, and Tract a treatise, Treaty
entry.def: A treatise; a tract; an essay.
entry.q: Agreeing in substance with Augustin's, from whose fourteenth Tractate on St. John the words are translated.

entry.ety: L. tractatio
entry.def: Treatment or handling of a subject; discussion.
entry.q: A full tractation of the points controverted.

entry.ety: L., a handler
entry.def: One who writes tracts; specif., a Tractarian.

entry.ety: L. trahere tractum, to draw
entry.def: Capable of being drawn out in length; ductile.
The quality of being tractile; ductility.

cs.cd: the angle made with a given plane by the line of direction in which a tractive force acts.
a locomotive for drawing vehicles on highways or in the fields.

entry.ety: L. trahere tractum, to draw: cf. F. traction

sn.def: The act of drawing, or the state of being drawn; as, the traction of a muscle.
Specifically, the act of drawing a body along a plane by motive power, as the drawing of a carriage by men or horses, the towing of a boat by a tug.
Attraction; a drawing toward.
The adhesive friction of a wheel on a rail, a rope on a pulley, or the like; as, the car is stuck in the snow because it can;t get any traction .

entry.def: Of or relating to traction.

entries.entry: Traction wheel. Mach A locomotive driving wheel which acts by friction adhesion to a smooth track. A smooth-rimmed friction wheel for giving motion to an endless link belt or the like.

entry.def: A Tractarian.

entry.ety: See Tractate
entry.def: Treating of; handling.
Serving to draw; pulling; attracting; as, tractive power.

entry.ety: NL., from L. trahere tractum, to draw

sn.def: That which draws, or is used for drawing.
Two small, pointed rods of metal, formerly used in the treatment called Perkinism.

a motor vehicle with a powerful engine and large wheels, used to pull farm equipment such as plows, harvesting machinery, etc., over farm land. Smaller forms of farm tractor are completely open, with only a seat for the driver.

a motor vehicle with a driver's cab and a powerful engine, fitted with a coupling at the rear, and designed to pull a large trailer or semi-trailer on the open highway; -- called also truck tractor. The combination of such a tractor with its trailer is called a tractor-trailer, and is a common form of truck used for commercial shipping of freight.
A propeller screw placed in front of the supporting planes of an aëroplane instead of behind them, so that it exerts a pull instead of a push; -- called also Tractor screw and Tractor propeller.
An airplane having one or more tractor propellers; -- called also tractor airplane.

entry.def: An airplane having one or more tractor propellers; -- called also tractor.
See Perkinism.

entries.entry: Tractor screworTractor propeller . Aviation A propeller screw placed in front of the supporting planes of an airplane instead of behind them, so that it exerts a pull instead of a push. Hence, Tractor monoplane Tractor biplane, etc. This is the most common arrangement for propellers on modern airplanes.

entry.def: a combination of a tractor{4} hooked up to a trailer, forming a common type of truck{7 used for carrying freight on highways.
entry.q: Traffic was backed up for miles by a jackknifedtractor-trailer.

entry.ety: L. tractorius of drawing, fr. trahere tractum, to draw
entry.def: A tractrix.

entry.ety: NL. See Tractor
entry.def: A curve such that the part of the tangent between the point of tangency and a given straight line is constant; -- so called because it was conceived as described by the motion of one end of a tangent line as the other end was drawn along the given line.
imp. of Tread.

entry.note: ☞ Trade comprehends every species of exchange or dealing, either in the produce of land, in manufactures, in bills, or in money; but it is chiefly used to denote the barter or purchase and sale of goods, wares, and merchandise, either by wholesale or retail. Trade is either foreign or domestic. Foreign trade consists in the exportation and importation of goods, or the exchange of the commodities of different countries. Domestic, or home, trade is the exchange, or buying and selling, of goods within a country. Trade is also by the wholesale, that is, by the package or in large quantities, generally to be sold again, or it is by retail, or in small parcels. The carrying trade is the business of transporting commodities from one country to another, or between places in the same country, by land or water.
entry.cs: Board of trade. See under Board. Trade dollar. See under Dollar. Trade price the price at which goods are sold to members of the same trade, or by wholesale dealers to retailers. Trade sale an auction by and for the trade, especially that of the booksellers. Trade wind a wind in the torrid zone, and often a little beyond at, which blows from the same quarter throughout the year, except when affected by local causes; -- so called because of its usefulness to navigators, and hence to trade.
entry.note: ☞ The general direction of the trade winds is from N. E. to S. W. on the north side of the equator, and from S. E. to N. W. on the south side of the equator. They are produced by the joint effect of the rotation of the earth and the movement of the air from the polar toward the equatorial regions, to supply the vacancy caused by heating, rarefaction, and consequent ascent of the air in the latter regions. The trade winds are principally limited to two belts in the tropical regions, one on each side of the equator, and separated by a belt which is characterized by calms or variable weather.
entry.ety: Formerly, a path, OE. tred a footmark. See Tread n. & v.

sn.def: A track; a trail; a way; a path; also, passage; travel; resort.
sn.q: A postern with a blind wicket there was, A common trade to pass through Priam's house.
Hath tracted forth some salvage beastes trade.
Or, I'll be buried in the king's highway, Some way of common trade, where subjects' feet May hourly trample on their sovereign's head.

sn.def: Course; custom; practice; occupation; employment.
sn.q: The righttradeof religion.
There those five sisters had continual trade.
Long did I love this lady, Long was my travel, long my trade to win her.
Thy sin's not accidental but a trade.

sn.def: Business of any kind; matter of mutual consideration; affair; dealing.
sn.q: Have you any further trade with us?

sn.def: Specifically: The act or business of exchanging commodities by barter, or by buying and selling for money; commerce; traffic; barter.

The business which a person has learned, and which he engages in, for procuring subsistence, or for profit; occupation; especially, mechanical employment as distinguished from the liberal arts, the learned professions, and agriculture; as, we speak of the trade of a smith, of a carpenter, or mason, but not now of the trade of a farmer, or a lawyer, or a physician.
sn.q: Accursed usury was all his trade.
The homely, slighted, shepherd's trade.
I will instruct thee in my trade.

sn.def: Instruments of any occupation.
sn.q: The house and household goods, his trade of war.

sn.def: A company of men engaged in the same occupation; thus, booksellers and publishers speak of the customs of the trade, and are collectively designated as the trade.
The trade winds.
Refuse or rubbish from a mine.
sn.syn: Profession; occupation; office; calling; avocation; employment; commerce; dealing; traffic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Traded; p. pr. & vb. n. Trading

sn.def: To barter, or to buy and sell; to be engaged in the exchange, purchase, or sale of goods, wares, merchandise, or anything else; to traffic; to bargain; to carry on commerce as a business.
sn.q: A free port, where nations . . . resorted with their goods and traded.

sn.def: To buy and sell or exchange property in a single instance.
To have dealings; to be concerned or associated; -- usually followed by with.
sn.q: How did you dare to trade and traffic with Macbeth?

entry.def: To sell or exchange in commerce; to barter.
entry.q: They traded the persons of men.
To dicker and to swop, to trade rifles and watches.

entry.def: imp. of Tread.
Professional; practiced.
Full of trade; busy in traffic; commercial.

sn.def: an item of property, such as an automobile, that is given in part payment for a new one.

entry.def: Having no trade or traffic.
A peculiar distinguishing mark or device affixed by a manufacturer or a merchant to his goods, the exclusive right of using which is recognized by law.

entries.entry:
Trade name.
The name by which an article is called among traders, etc.; as, tin spirits is a common trade name in the dyeing industry for various solutions of tin salts.
An invented or arbitrary adopted name given by a manufacturer or merchant to an article to distinguish it as produced or sold by him.
The name or style under which a concern or firm does business. This name becomes a part of the good will of a business; it is not protected by the registration acts, but a qualified common-law protection against its misuse exists, analogous to that existing in the case of trade-marks.

sn.def: the exchange of one thing (object, right, opportunity) for another of approximately equal value, so as to seal a bargain, or effect a compromise.

the giving up of one desired objective in order to attain another, when both cannot be achieved at the same time; as, the factory workers viewed the trade-off of air quality for jobs as a necessary evil.
One engaged in trade or commerce; one who makes a business of buying and selling or of barter; a merchant; a trafficker; as, a trader to the East Indies; a country trader.
A vessel engaged in the coasting or foreign trade.

entry.def: A genus including spiderwort and Wandering Jew.
People employed in trade; tradesmen.

entries.entry:
Trades"man n.; pl.Tradesmen.
One who trades; a shopkeeper.
A mechanic or artificer; esp., one whose livelihood depends upon the labor of his hands. U. S

entry.def: People engaged in trade; shopkeepers.

entries.entry: trades" un`ionorTrade" un`ion . An organized combination among workmen for the purpose of maintaining their rights, privileges, and interests with respect to wages, hours of labor, customs, etc.

entry.def: A member of a trades union, or a supporter of trades unions.

entries.entry: Trades"wom`an n.; pl.Tradeswomen. A woman who trades, or is skilled in trade.

sn.def: Carrying on trade or commerce; engaged in trade; as, a trading company.
Frequented by traders.
sn.q: They on thetradingflood.

sn.def: Venal; corrupt; jobbing; as, a trading politician.

cs.cd: Palm Sunday; -- so called because the creed was then taught to candidates for baptism at Easter.

entry.ety: OE. tradicioun, L. traditio, from tradere to give up, transmit. See Treason Traitor

sn.def: The act of delivering into the hands of another; delivery.
sn.q: A deed takes effect only from thetraditionor delivery.

sn.def: The unwritten or oral delivery of information, opinions, doctrines, practices, rites, and customs, from father to son, or from ancestors to posterity; the transmission of any knowledge, opinions, or practice, from forefathers to descendants by oral communication, without written memorials.
Hence, that which is transmitted orally from father to son, or from ancestors to posterity; knowledge or belief transmitted without the aid of written memorials; custom or practice long observed.
sn.q: Will you mock at an ancient tradition begun upon an honorable respect?
Naught but tradition remains of the beautiful village of Grand-Pré.

sd.def: An unwritten code of law represented to have been given by God to Moses on Sinai.
sd.q: Making the word of God of none effect through your tradition, which ye have delivered.

sd.def: That body of doctrine and discipline, or any article thereof, supposed to have been put forth by Christ or his apostles, and not committed to writing.
sd.q: Stand fast, and hold the traditions which ye have been taught, whether by word or our epistle.

entry.def: To transmit by way of tradition; to hand down.
entry.q: The following story is . . . traditioned with very much credit amongst our English Catholics.

entry.ety: Cf. F. traditionnel, LL. traditionalis

sn.def: Of or pertaining to tradition; derived from tradition; communicated from ancestors to descendants by word only; transmitted from age to age without writing; as, traditional opinions; traditional customs; traditional expositions of the Scriptures.
Observant of tradition; attached to old customs; old-fashioned.

entry.def: A system of faith founded on tradition; esp., the doctrine that all religious faith is to be based solely upon what is delivered from competent authority, exclusive of rational processes.
An advocate of, or believer in, traditionalism; a traditionist.
In a traditional manner.
By tradition.
Traditional.
entry.q: The reveries of the Talmud, a collection of Jewish traditionary interpolations.

entries.entry:
Tra*di"tion*a*ry n.; pl.Traditionaries. Cf. F. traditionnare
One, among the Jews, who acknowledges the authority of traditions, and explains the Scriptures by them.

entry.ety: Cf. F. traditionniste
entry.def: One who adheres to tradition.

entry.ety: L. tradere traditum, to transmit, give up: cf. F. traditif
entry.def: Transmitted or transmissible from father to son, or from age, by oral communication; traditional.
entry.q: Suppose we on things traditive divide.

entry.ety: L., fr. tradere traditum. See Traitor
entry.def: A deliverer; -- a name of infamy given to Christians who delivered the Scriptures, or the goods of the church, to their persecutors to save their lives.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Traduced; p. pr. & vb. n. Traducing
entry.ety: L. traducere traductum, to lead across, lead along, exhibit as a spectacle, disgrace, transfer, derive; trans across, over + ducere to lead: cf. F. traduire to transfer, translate, arraign, fr. L. traducere. See Duke

sn.def: To transfer; to transmit; to hand down; as, to traduce mental qualities to one's descendants.
To translate from one language to another; as, to traduce and compose works.
To increase or distribute by propagation.
sn.q: From these only the race of perfect animals were propagated and traduced over the earth.

sn.def: To draw away; to seduce.
sn.q: I can forget the weakness Of the traduced soldiers.

sn.def: To represent; to exhibit; to display; to expose; to make an example of.
To expose to contempt or shame; to represent as blamable; to calumniate; to vilify; to defame.
sn.q: The best stratagem that Satan hath . . . is by traducing the form and manner of them [prayers], to bring them into contempt.
He had the baseness . . . to traduce me in libel.
sn.syn: To calumniate; vilify; defame; disparage; detract; depreciate; decry; slander.

entry.def: The act of traducing; misrepresentation; ill-founded censure; defamation; calumny.

entry.ety: L. traducens, p. pr. of traducere. See Traduce
entry.def: Slanderous.

sn.def: One who traduces; a slanderer; a calumniator.
One who derives or deduces.

entry.def: A believer in traducianism.
The doctrine that human souls are produced by the act of generation; -- opposed to creationism, and infusionism.

sn.def: Capable of being derived or propagated.
Capable of being traduced or calumniated.

entry.def: In a traducing manner; by traduction; slanderously.

entry.ety: L. traducere traductum. See Traduce
entry.def: To derive or deduce; also, to transmit; to transfer.
That which is traducted; that which is transferred; a translation.

entry.ety: L. traductio a transferring: cf. F. traduction translation. See Traduce

sn.def: Transmission from one to another.
sn.q: Traditional communication and traduction of truths.

sn.def: Translation from one language to another.
Derivation by descent; propagation.
sn.q: If by traduction came thy mind, Our wonder is the less to find A soul so charming from a stock so good.

sn.def: The act of transferring; conveyance; transportation.
sn.q: Thetraductionof brutes.

sn.def: Transition.
A process of reasoning in which each conclusion applies to just such an object as each of the premises applies to.

entry.def: Capable of being deduced; derivable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trafficked; p. pr. & vb. n. Trafficking
entry.ety: F. trafiquer; cf. It. trafficare, Sp. traficar trafagar, Pg. traficar trafegar trafeguear, LL. traficare; of uncertain origin, perhaps fr. L. trans across, over + -ficare to make (see -fy, and cf. G. übermachen to transmit, send over, e. g., money, wares); or cf. Pg. trasfegar to pour out from one vessel into another, OPg. also, to traffic, perhaps fr. (assumed) LL. vicare to exchange, from L. vicis change (cf. Vicar)

sn.def: To pass goods and commodities from one person to another for an equivalent in goods or money; to buy or sell goods; to barter; to trade.
To trade meanly or mercenarily; to bargain.

entry.def: To exchange in traffic; to effect by a bargain or for a consideration.

entry.note: ☞ This word, like trade, comprehends every species of dealing in the exchange or passing of goods or merchandise from hand to hand for an equivalent, unless the business of relating may be excepted. It signifies appropriately foreign trade, but is not limited to that.

cs.cd: a periodical statement of the receipts for goods and passengers, as on a railway line.
a computer of the returns of traffic on a railway, steamboat line, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trafic, It. traffico, Sp. tráfico tráfago, Pg. tráfego, LL. traficum trafica. See Traffic v.

sn.def: Commerce, either by barter or by buying and selling; interchange of goods and commodities; trade.
sn.q: A merchant of great traffic through the world.
The traffic in honors, places, and pardons.

sn.def: Commodities of the market.
sn.q: You 'll see a draggled damsel From Billingsgate her fishy traffic bear.

sn.def: The business done upon a railway, steamboat line, etc., with reference to the number of passengers or the amount of freight carried.

entry.def: Capable of being disposed of in traffic; marketable.
One who traffics, or carries on commerce; a trader; a merchant.
Destitute of traffic, or trade.

entries.entry:
Traf"fic mile. Railroad Accounting Any unit of the total obtained by adding the passenger miles and ton miles in a railroad's transportation for a given period; -- a term and practice of restricted or erroneous usage.
Traffic mile is a term designed to furnish an excuse for the erroneous practice of adding together two things (ton miles and passenger miles) which, being of different kinds, cannot properly be added.

entry.ety: L. tragacanthum tragacanth, tragacantha the plant producing tragacanth, Gr. � � a he-goat + � a thorn: cf. F. tragacanthe
entry.def: A kind of gum procured from a spiny leguminous shrub (Astragalus gummifer) of Western Asia, and other species of Astragalus. It comes in hard whitish or yellowish flakes or filaments, and is nearly insoluble in water, but slowly swells into a mucilaginous mass, which is used as a substitute for gum arabic in medicine and the arts. Called also gum tragacanth.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tragédien

sn.def: A writer of tragedy.
sn.q: Thence what the lofty, grave, tragedians taught.

sn.def: An actor or player in tragedy.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A woman who plays in tragedy.
Like tragedy; tragical.
entry.q: Tragedioushistory.

entries.entry:
Trag"e*dy n.; pl.Tragedies #. OE. tragedie, OF. tragedie, F. tragédie, L. tragoedia, Gr. �, fr. � a tragic poet and singer, originally, a goat singer; � a goat (perhaps akin to � to gnaw, nibble, eat, and E. trout) + � to sing; from the oldest tragedies being exhibited when a goat was sacrificed, or because a goat was the prize, or because the actors were clothed in goatskins. See Ode
A dramatic poem, composed in elevated style, representing a signal action performed by some person or persons, and having a fatal issue; that species of drama which represents the sad or terrible phases of character and life.
Tragedy is to say a certain storie, As olde bookes maken us memorie, Of him that stood in great prosperitee And is yfallen out of high degree Into misery and endeth wretchedly. All our tragedies are of kings and princes.
tragedy is poetry in its deepest earnest; comedy is poetry in unlimited jest.
A fatal and mournful event; any event in which human lives are lost by human violence, more especially by unauthorized violence.

entry.ety: L. tragicus, Gr.�: cf. F. tragique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to tragedy; of the nature or character of tragedy; as, a tragic poem; a tragic play or representation.
Fatal to life; mournful; terrible; calamitous; as, the tragic scenes of the French revolution.
Mournful; expressive of tragedy, the loss of life, or of sorrow.
sn.q: Why look you still so stern and tragical ?

sn.def: A writer of tragedy.
A tragedy; a tragic drama.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tragicomédie, L. tragicocomoedia. See Tragic, and Comedy
entry.def: A kind of drama representing some action in which serious and comic scenes are blended; a composition partaking of the nature both of tragedy and comedy.
entry.q: The noble tragi-comedy of “Measure for Measure.”

entry.ety: Cf. F. tragi-comique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to tragi-comedy; partaking of grave and comic scenes.
entry.q: Julian felt toward him that tragi-comic sensation which makes us pity the object which excites it not the less that we are somewhat inclined to laugh amid our sympathy.

entry.def: Partaking of the nature of, or combining, tragedy, comedy, and pastoral poetry.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. tragopan a fabulous Ethiopian bird, Gr. �
entry.def: Any one of several species of Asiatic pheasants of the genus Ceriornis. They are brilliantly colored with a variety of tints, the back and breast are usually covered with white or buff ocelli, and the head is ornamented with two bright-colored, fleshy wattles. The crimson tragopan, or horned pheasant (Ceriornis satyra), of India is one of the best-known species.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a part of the inner ear
entry.def: The prominence in front of the external opening of the ear. See Illust. under Ear.

entries.entry: T" rail`. See under T.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Trailing
entry.ety: OE. trailen, OF. trailler to trail a deer, or hunt him upon a cold scent, also, to hunt or pursue him with a limehound, F. trailler to trail a fishing line; probably from a derivative of L. trahere to draw; cf. L. traha a drag, sledge, tragula a kind of drag net, a small sledge, Sp. trailla a leash, an instrument for leveling the ground, D. treilen to draw with a rope, to tow, treil a rope for drawing a boat. See Trace v. t.

sd.def: To hunt by the track; to track.
to follow behind.
To pursue.

sn.def: To draw or drag, as along the ground.
sn.q: And hung his head, and trailed his legs along.
They shall not trail me through their streets Like a wild beast.
Long behind he trails his pompous robe.

sn.def: To carry, as a firearm, with the breech near the ground and the upper part inclined forward, the piece being held by the right hand near the middle.
To tread down, as grass, by walking through it; to lay flat.
To take advantage of the ignorance of; to impose upon.
sn.q: I presently perceived she was (what is vernacularly termedtrailing Mrs. Dent; that is, playing on her ignorance.

sn.def: To be drawn out in length; to follow after.
sn.q: When his brother saw the red blood trail.

sn.def: To grow to great length, especially when slender and creeping upon the ground, as a plant; to run or climb.

cs.cd: the carved boards on both sides of the cutwater near the figurehead.
a net that is trailed or drawn behind a boat.

sn.def: A track left by man or beast; a track followed by the hunter; a scent on the ground by the animal pursued; as, a deer trail .
sn.q: They traveled in the bed of the brook, leaving no dangerous trail.
How cheerfully on the false trail they cry!

sn.def: A footpath or road track through a wilderness or wild region; as, an Indian trail over the plains.
Anything drawn out to a length; as, the trail of a meteor; a trail of smoke.
sn.q: When lightning shoots in glittering trails along.

sn.def: Anything drawn behind in long undulations; a train.
sn.q: A radianttrailof hair.

sn.def: Anything drawn along, as a vehicle.
A frame for trailing plants; a trellis.
The entrails of a fowl, especially of game, as the woodcock, and the like; -- applied also, sometimes, to the entrails of sheep.
sn.q: The woodcock is a favorite with epicures, and served with its trail in, is a delicious dish.

sn.def: That part of the stock of a gun carriage which rests on the ground when the piece is unlimbered. See Illust. of Gun carriage, under Gun.
The act of taking advantage of the ignorance of a person; an imposition.

entry.def: One who, or that which, trails.

entry.cs: trailer park. An area equipped to accommodate trailers{2}, often with outlets supplying electrical power and water. Called also trailer camp trailer court.

sn.def: a wheeled vehicle without a motor, designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle in front of it;

sd.def: such a vehicle used on street railroads. Called also trail car.
the large wheeled wagon or van pulled by a tractor in a tractor-trailer combination.
a vehicle equipped as a mobile dwelling unit, pulled by an automobile or other mtor vehicle, and used as a dwelling when parked; -- also called a mobile home.
A wheeled motorless open wagon designed to carry a heavy object, such as a boat trailer.

sn.def: A short blank segment of movie film attached to the end; -- used for convenient insertion of the film in a projector.
A short film consisting primarily of one or more short portions of a film, used in promotions or advertisements shortly before initial release of a film.
A part of an object which extends some distance beyond the main body of the object; as, the trailer of a plant.

entry.cs: Trailing arbutus. Bot See under Arbutus. Trailing spring a spring fixed in the axle box of the trailing wheels of a locomotive engine, and so placed as to assist in deadening any shock which may occur. Weale. Trailing wheel a hind wheel of a locomotive when it is not a driving wheel; also, one of the hind wheels of a carriage.
entry.def: a. & vb. n. from Trail.

entries.entry: Trail"ing edge. Aeronautics A following edge. See Advancing edge, above.
Trail rope. Aëronautics Same as Guide rope, above.

cs.cd: to point it at some object either forward or else abaft the beam, that is, not directly on the side.
to educate; to teach; to form by instruction or practice; to bring up.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trained; p. pr. & vb. n. Training
entry.ety: OF. trahiner traïner,F. traîner, LL. trahinare trainare, fr. L. trahere to draw. See Trail

sn.def: To draw along; to trail; to drag.
sn.q: In hollow cubeTraining his devilish enginery.

sn.def: To draw by persuasion, artifice, or the like; to attract by stratagem; to entice; to allure.
sn.q: If but a dozen French Were there in arms, they would be as a call To train ten thousand English to their side.
O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note.
This feast, I'll gage my life, Is but a plot to train you to your ruin.

sn.def: To teach and form by practice; to educate; to exercise; to discipline; as, to train the militia to the manual exercise; to train soldiers to the use of arms.
sn.q: Our trained bands, which are the trustiest and most proper strength of a free nation.
The warrior horse here bred he's taught to train.

sn.def: To break, tame, and accustom to draw, as oxen.
To lead or direct, and form to a wall or espalier; to form to a proper shape, by bending, lopping, or pruning; as, to train young trees.
sn.q: He trained the young branches to the right hand or to the left.

sn.def: To trace, as a lode or any mineral appearance, to its head.
sn.q: Train up a child in the way he should go; and when he is old, he will not depart from it.
The first Christians were, by great hardships, trained up for glory.

sn.def: To be drilled in military exercises; to do duty in a military company.
To prepare by exercise, diet, instruction, etc., for any physical contest; as, to train for a boat race.

cs.cd: a set of plain or grooved rolls for rolling metal into various forms by a series of consecutive operations.

a unit employed in estimating running expenses, etc., being one of the total number of miles run by all the trains of a road, or system of roads, as within a given time, or for a given expenditure; -- called also mile run.
any number of cannon, mortars, etc., with the attendants and carriages which follow them into the field.
a series of moving pieces, as wheels and pinions, each of which is follower to that which drives it, and driver to that which follows it.
a slight railway for small cars, -- used for construction, or in mining.
a tackle for running guns in and out.

entry.usage: Train Cars. At one time “train” meaning railroad train was also referred to in the U. S. by the phrase “the cars”. In the 1913 dictionary the usage was described thus: “Train is the word universally used in England with reference to railroad traveling; as, I came in the morning train . In the United States, the phrase the cars has been extensively introduced in the room of train; as, the cars are late; I came in the cars . The English expression is obviously more appropriate, and is prevailing more and more among Americans, to the exclusion of the cars.”
entry.ety: F. train, OF. traïn trahin; cf. (for some of the senses) F. traine. See Train v.

sn.def: That which draws along; especially, persuasion, artifice, or enticement; allurement.
sn.q: Now to my charms, and to my wilytrains.

sn.def: Hence, something tied to a lure to entice a hawk; also, a trap for an animal; a snare.
sn.q: With cunning trains him to entrap un wares.

entry.sn:
That which is drawn along in the rear of, or after, something; that which is in the hinder part or rear. Specifically : That part of a gown which trails behind the wearer.
Mil The after part of a gun carriage; the trail.
The tail of a bird. Thetrainsteers their flights, and turns their bodies, like the rudder of ship.

sn.def: A number of followers; a body of attendants; a retinue; a suite.
sn.q: The king's daughter with a lovely train.
My train are men of choice and rarest parts.

sn.def: A consecution or succession of connected things; a series.
sn.q: Atrainof happy sentiments.
The train of ills our love would draw behind it.
Rivers now Stream and perpetual draw their humid train.
Other truths require a train of ideas placed in order.

sn.def: Regular method; process; course; order; as, things now in a train for settlement.
sn.q: If things were once in this train, . . . our duty would take root in our nature.

sn.def: The number of beats of a watch in any certain time.
A line of gunpowder laid to lead fire to a charge, mine, or the like.
A connected line of cars or carriages on a railroad; -- called also railroad train.
A heavy, long sleigh used in Canada for the transportation of merchandise, wood, and the like.
A roll train; as, a 12-inch train .
The aggregation of men, animals, and vehicles which accompany an army or one of its subdivisions, and transport its baggage, ammunition, supplies, and reserve materials of all kinds.
sn.syn: Cars.

entry.def: Capable of being trained or educated; as, boys trainable to virtue.

entries.entry: Train"band` n.; pl.Trainbands. A band or company of an organized military force instituted by James I. and dissolved by Charles II.; -- afterwards applied to the London militia. Eng He felt that, without some better protection than that of the trainbands and Beefeaters, his palace and person would hardly be secure. A trainband captain eke was he Of famous London town.

entry.def: One who holds up a train, as of a robe.

entries.entry: Train dispatcher. An official who gives the orders on a railroad as to the running of trains and their right of way.

entry.ety: OF
entry.def: A dragnet.

sn.def: One who trains; an instructor; especially, one who trains or prepares men, horses, etc., for exercises requiring physical agility and strength.
A militiaman when called out for exercise or discipline.

entry.cs:
Fan training Hort the operation of training fruit trees, grapevines, etc., so that the branches shall radiate from the stem like a fan. Horizontal training Hort the operation of training fruit trees, grapevines, etc., so that the branches shall spread out laterally in a horizontal direction. Training college. See Normal school, under Normal a.
Training day a day on which a military company assembles for drill or parade. U. S Training ship a vessel on board of which boys are trained as sailors.
entry.def: The act of one who trains; the act or process of exercising, disciplining, etc.; education.

entries.entry: Train"ing wheels. a pair of small wheels attached to the rear of a bicycle to keep the bicycle upright; -- used to assist those, especially small children, learning how to ride a bicycle.
Train"man`. a member of the crew of a railroad train, often an assistant to a conductor.

Train" oil` oil`. D. or LG. traan train oil, blubber (cf. Dan. & Sw. tran, G. thran) + E. oil
Oil procured from the blubber or fat of whales, by boiling.

entry.def: Belonging to train oil.

entry.ety: Cf. G. trapsen trappsen trappen, to tread noisily, to walk stamping. See Trample Trape
entry.def: To walk or run about in a slatternly, careless, or thoughtless manner.
Traces.
entry.q: Four white bulls in the trays.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly pronounced trā, as in French, and still so pronounced to some extent in England.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. tractus, fr. trahere to draw. See Trace v., and cf. Tract a region, Trace a strap, Tret

sn.def: A stroke; a touch.
sn.q: By this single trait Homer makes an essential difference between the Iliad and Odyssey.

sn.def: A distinguishing or marked feature; a peculiarity; as, a trait of character.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The keeper of an eating house, or restaurant; a restaurateur.

entry.ety: OE. traitour, OF. traïtor traïteur, F. treître, L. traditor, fr. tradere traditum, to deliver, to give up or surrender treacherously, to betray; trans across, over + dare to give. See Date time, and cf. Betray,Tradition Traditor Treason

sn.def: One who violates his allegiance and betrays his country; one guilty of treason; one who, in breach of trust, delivers his country to an enemy, or yields up any fort or place intrusted to his defense, or surrenders an army or body of troops to the enemy, unless when vanquished; also, one who takes arms and levies war against his country; or one who aids an enemy in conquering his country. See Treason.
sn.q: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!

sn.def: Hence, one who betrays any confidence or trust; a betrayer.
sn.q: This falsetraitordeath.

entry.def: Traitorous.
To act the traitor toward; to betray; to deceive.
entry.q: But time, ittraitorsme.

entry.def: A traitress.
Like a traitor; treacherous; traitorous.
entry.q: Traitorlyrascals.

entry.ety: Cf. F. traîtreux

sn.def: Guilty of treason; treacherous; perfidious; faithless; as, a traitorous officer or subject.
Consisting in treason; partaking of treason; implying breach of allegiance; as, a traitorous scheme.

entry.def: Treachery.

entry.ety: F. traîtresse
entry.def: A woman who betrays her country or any trust; a traitoress.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trajected; p. pr. & vb. n. Trajecting
entry.ety: L. trajectus, p. p. of trajicere to throw across; trans across + jacere to throw. See Jet a shooting forth
entry.def: To throw or cast through, over, or across; as, to traject the sun's light through three or more cross prisms.

entry.ety: L. trajectus, fr. trajicere: cf. F. trajet, OF. traject. See Traject v. t.

sn.def: A place for passing across; a passage; a ferry.
The act of trajecting; trajection.
A trajectory.

entry.ety: L. trajectio a crossing over, transposition

sn.def: The act of trajecting; a throwing or casting through or across; also, emission.
Transposition.

entries.entry:
Tra*ject"o*ry n.; pl.Trajectories #. Cf. F. trajectoire
The curve which a body describes in space, as a planet or comet in its orbit, or stone thrown upward obliquely in the air.

entry.def: See Treget Tregetour, and Tregetry.

entry.ety: L. tralatio translatio.See Translation
entry.def: The use of a word in a figurative or extended sense; ametaphor; a trope.

entry.ety: See Tralatitious
entry.def: A change, as in the use of words; a metaphor.

entry.ety: L. tralatitius translatitius tralaticius translaticius. See Tralation

sn.def: Passed along; handed down; transmitted.
sn.q: Among biblical critics a tralatitious interpretation is one received by expositor from expositor.

sn.def: Metaphorical; figurative; not literal.

entry.def: In a tralatitious manner; metephorically.

entry.ety: L. trans across + linea a line: cf. It tralineare tralignare
entry.def: To deviate; to stray; to wander.
Translucency; as, the tralucency of a gem.

entry.ety: L. tralucens translucens, p. pr. See Translucent
entry.def: Translucent.
entry.q: The air's tralucent gallery.

cs.cd: a car made to run on a tramway, especially a street railway car.
a flat piece of iron laid down as a rail.
the step and support for the lower end of the spindle of a millstone.

entry.ety: Prov. E. tram a coal wagon, the shaft of a cart or carriage, a beam or bar; probably of Scand, origin; cf. OSw. tråm trum, a beam, OD. drom, Prov. & OHG. tram

sn.def: A four-wheeled truck running on rails, and used in a mine, as for carrying coal or ore.
The shaft of a cart.
One of the rails of a tramway.
A car on a horse railroad.

entry.ety: Sp. trama weft, or F. trame
entry.def: A silk thread formed of two or more threads twisted together, used especially for the weft, or cross threads, of the best quality of velvets and silk goods.
Same as Trammel n., 6.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trammed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tramming
entry.def: To convey or transport on a tramway or on a tram car.
To operate, or conduct the business of, a tramway; to travel by tramway.

entry.ety: L., woof
entry.def: The loosely woven substance which lines the chambers within the gleba in certain Gasteromycetes.
To wash, as tin ore, with a shovel in a frame fitted for the purpose.

entry.ety: F. tramail trémail, a net, LL. tremaculum tremacle, a kind of net for taking fish; L. tres three + macula a mesh. See Three, and Mail armor

sn.def: A kind of net for catching birds, fishes, or other prey.
A net for confining a woman's hair.
A kind of shackle used for regulating the motions of a horse and making him amble.
Fig.: Whatever impedes activity, progress, or freedom, as a net or shackle.
sn.q: They] disdain the trammels of any sordid contract.

sn.def: An iron hook of various forms and sizes, used for handing kettles and other vessels over the fire.

sd.def: An instrument for drawing ellipses, one part of which consists of a cross with two grooves at right angles to each other, the other being a beam carrying two pins (which slide in those grooves), and also the describing pencil.
A beam compass. See under Beam.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trammeled or Trammelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trammeling, or Trammelling

sn.def: To entangle, as in a net; to catch.
To confine; to hamper; to shackle.

entry.def: Having blazes, or white marks, on the fore and hind foot of one side, as if marked by trammels; -- said of a horse.

sn.def: One who uses a trammel net.
One who, or that which, trammels or restrains.

entries.entry: Tram"mel wheel`. Mach A circular plate or a cross, with two or more cross grooves intersecting at the center, used on the end of a shaft to transmit motion to another shaft not in line with the first.

entry.def: The act or process of forming trams. See 2d Tram.

entry.ety: It. See Tramontane
entry.def: A dry, cold, violent, northerly wind of the Adriatic.

entry.note: ☞ The Italians sometimes use this epithet for ultramontane, and apply it to the countries north of the Alps, as France and Germany, and especially to their ecclesiastics, jurists, painters, etc.; and a north wind is called a tramontane wind. The French lawyers call certain Italian canonists tramontane, or ultramontane, doctors; considering them as favoring too much the court of Rome. See Ultramontane.
entry.ety: OF. tramontain, It. tramontano, L. transmontanus; trans across, beyond + mons montis, mountain
entry.def: Lying or being beyond the mountains; coming from the other side of the mountains; hence, foreign; barbarous.
One living beyond the mountains; hence, a foreigner; a stranger.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tramped; p. pr. & vb. n. Tramping
entry.ety: OE. trampen; akin to LG. trampen, G. trampeln, LG. & D. trappen, Dan. trampe, Sw. & Icel. trampa, Goth. anatrimpan to press upon; also to D. trap a step, G. treppe steps, stairs. Cf. Trap a kind of rock, Trape Trip v. i. Tread

sn.def: To tread upon forcibly and repeatedly; to trample.
To travel or wander through; as, to tramp the country.
To cleanse, as clothes, by treading upon them in water.

entry.def: To travel; to wander; to stroll.

sn.def: A foot journey or excursion; as, to go on a tramp; a long tramp .
A foot traveler; a tramper; often used in a bad sense for a vagrant or wandering vagabond.
The sound of the foot, or of feet, on the earth, as in marching.
A tool for trimming hedges.
A plate of iron worn to protect the sole of the foot, or the shoe, when digging with a spade.

entry.def: One who tramps; a stroller; a vagrant or vagabond; a tramp.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trampled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trampling
entry.ety: OE. trampelen, freq. of trampen. See Tramp v. t.

sn.def: To tread under foot; to tread down; to prostrate by treading; as, to trample grass or flowers.
sn.q: Neither cast ye your pearls before swine, lest they trample them under their feet.

sn.def: Fig.: To treat with contempt and insult.
To tread with force and rapidity; to stamp.
To tread in contempt; -- with on or upon.
sn.q: Diogenes trampled on Plato's pride with greater of his own.

entry.def: The act of treading under foot; also, the sound produced by trampling.
entry.q: The huddling trample of a drove of sheep.

entry.def: One who tramples; one who treads down; as, a trampler on nature's law.

entry.ety: See Tramp Trample, and Traipse
entry.def: To walk with labor, or heavily; to tramp.
An overhead rail forming a track on which a trolley runs to convey a load, as in a shop.

entry.ety: Tram a coal wagon + road
entry.def: A road prepared for easy transit of trams or wagons, by forming the wheel tracks of smooth beams of wood, blocks of stone, or plates of iron.

sn.def: Same as Tramroad.

A street railway laid in the streets of a town or city, or an interurban railway for local traffic, on which cable cars, or trolley cars, etc., are used, in distinction from an extended railway line for trains drawn by steam or electric locomotives.

entry.ety: L. tranare transnare, to swim over; trans across, over + nare to swim
entry.def: The act of swimming over.

entry.ety: F. transe fright, in OF. also, trance or swoon, fr. transir to chill, benumb, to be chilled, to shiver, OF. also, to die, L. transire to pass over, go over, pass away, cease; trans across, over + ire to go; cf. L. transitus a passing over. See Issue, and cf. Transit

sn.def: A tedious journey.
A state in which the soul seems to have passed out of the body into another state of being, or to be rapt into visions; an ecstasy.
sn.q: And he became very hungry, and would have eaten; but while they made ready, he fell into a trance.
My soul was ravished quite as in a trance.

sn.def: A condition, often simulating death, in which there is a total suspension of the power of voluntary movement, with abolition of all evidences of mental activity and the reduction to a minimum of all the vital functions so that the patient lies still and apparently unconscious of surrounding objects, while the pulsation of the heart and the breathing, although still present, are almost or altogether imperceptible.
sn.q: He fell down in a trance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tranced; p. pr. & vb. n. Trancing

sn.def: To entrance.
sn.q: And three I left him tranced.

sn.def: To pass over or across; to traverse.
sn.q: Trance the world over.
When thickest dark did trance the sky.

entry.def: To pass; to travel.

entry.ety: Cf. Traject
entry.def: A ferry.

entry.ety: OE. trangrain a strange thing, trangame a toy. See Tangram
entry.def: Something intricately contrived; a contrived; a puzzle.
A treenail.

entry.ety: L. tranquillus; probably fr. trans across, over + a word akin to quietus quiet: cf. F. tranquille. See Quiet
entry.def: Quiet; calm; undisturbed; peaceful; not agitated; as, the atmosphere is tranquil; the condition of the country is tranquil .
entry.q: A style clear, tranquil, easy to follow.

entry.def: The act of tranquilizing, or the state of being tranquilized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tranquilized or Tranquilliized; p. pr. & vb. n. Tranquilizing or Tranquillizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. tranquilliser
entry.def: To render tranquil; to allay when agitated; to compose; to make calm and peaceful; as, to tranquilize a state disturbed by factions or civil commotions; to tranquilize the mind.
entry.syn: To quiet; compose; still; soothe; appease; calm; pacify.

entry.def: One who, or that which, tranquilizes.
Making tranquil; calming.
entry.q: Thetranquilizingpower of time.

entry.ety: F. tranquillité, L. tranquillitas
entry.def: The quality or state of being tranquil; calmness; composure.
In a tranquil manner; calmly.
Quality or state of being tranquil.

entries.entry: Trans-. L. trans across, over A prefix, signifying over beyond through and through on the other side, as in transalpine, beyond the Alps; transform, to form through and through, that is, anew, transfigure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transacted; p. pr. & vb. n. Transacting
entry.ety: L. transactus, p. p. of transigere. See Transaction
entry.def: To carry through; to do; perform; to manage; as, to transact commercial business; to transact business by an agent.
To conduct matters; to manage affairs.

cs.cd: the published record of what it has done or accomplished.

entry.usage: Transaction Proceeding. A transaction is something already done and completed; a proceeding is either something which is now going on, or, if ended, is still contemplated with reference to its progress or successive stages.
entry.note: ☞ “ We the word proceeding in application to an affray in the street, and the word transaction to some commercial negotiation that has been carried on between certain persons. The proceeding marks the manner of proceeding, as when we speak of the proceedings in a court of law. The transaction marks the business transacted; as, the transactions on the Exchange.”
entry.ety: L. transactio, fr. transigere transactum, to drive through, carry through, accomplish, transact; trans across, over + agere to drive; cf. F. transaction. See Act Agent

sn.def: The doing or performing of any business; management of any affair; performance.
That which is done; an affair; as, the transactions on the exchange.
An adjustment of a dispute between parties by mutual agreement.
sn.syn: Proceeding; action; process.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who transacts, performs, or conducts any business.

entry.ety: L. transalpinus; trans across, beyond + Alpinus Alpine, from Alpes the Alps: cf. F. transalpin
entry.def: Being on the farther side of the Alps in regard to Rome, that is, on the north or west side of the Alps; of or pertaining to the region or the people beyond the Alps; as, transalpine Gaul; -- opposed to cisalpine.
entry.q: Transalpinegarbs.

entry.def: A native or inhabitant of a country beyond the Alps, that is, out of Italy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transanimated trăns*ăn"ĭ*mā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Transanimating
entry.ety: Trans- + animate
entry.def: To animate with a soul conveyed from another body.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transanimation
entry.def: The conveyance of a soul from one body to another.

entry.note: ☞ When used by a person in Europe or Africa, transatlantic signifies being in America; when by a person in America, it denotes being or lying in Europe or Africa, especially the former.
entry.ety: Pref. trans- + Atlantic: cf. F. transatlantique

sn.def: Lying or being beyond the Atlantic Ocean.
Crossing the Atlantic Ocean; as, a transatlantic flight.

entry.ety: See Trans-, and Audient
entry.def: Permitting the passage of sound.
The quality or state of being transcalent.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. calens, p. pr. of calere to grow warm
entry.def: Pervious to, or permitting the passage of, heat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transcended; p. pr. & vb. n. Transcending
entry.ety: L. transcendere transcensum; trans beyond, over + scandere to climb. See Scan

sn.def: To rise above; to surmount; as, lights in the heavens transcending the region of the clouds.
To pass over; to go beyond; to exceed.
sn.q: Such popes as shall transcend their limits.

sn.def: To surpass; to outgo; to excel; to exceed.
sn.q: How much her worth transcended all her kind.

sn.def: To climb; to mount.
To be transcendent; to excel.

entry.ety: Cf. L. transcendentia, F. transcendance

sn.def: The quality or state of being transcendent; superior excellence; supereminence.
sn.q: The Augustinian theology rests upon the transcendence of Deity at its controlling principle.

sn.def: Elevation above truth; exaggeration.
sn.q: “Where transcendencies are more allowed.”

entry.ety: L. transcendens -entis, p. pr. of transcendere to transcend: cf. F. transcendant, G. transcendent

sn.def: Very excellent; superior or supreme in excellence; surpassing others; as, transcendent worth; transcendent valor.
sn.q: Clothed with transcendent brightness.

sn.def: Transcending, or reaching beyond, the limits of human knowledge; -- applied to affirmations and speculations concerning what lies beyond the reach of the human intellect.

entry.def: That which surpasses or is supereminent; that which is very excellent.

entry.note: ☞ In mathematics, a quantity is said to be transcendental relative to another quantity when it is expressed as a transcendental function of the latter; thus, ax, 102x, log x, sin x, tan x, etc., are transcendental relative to x.
entry.cs: Transcendental curve Math a curve in which one ordinate is a transcendental function of the other. Transcendental equation Math an equation into which a transcendental function of one of the unknown or variable quantities enters. Transcendental function. Math See under Function.
entry.usage: These terms, with the corresponding nouns, transcendentalism and empiricism, are of comparatively recent origin. Empirical refers to knowledge which is gained by the experience of actual phenomena, without reference to the principles or laws to which they are to be referred, or by which they are to be explained. Transcendental has reference to those beliefs or principles which are not derived from experience, and yet are absolutely necessary to make experience possible or useful. Such, in the better sense of the term, is the transcendental philosophy, or transcendentalism. Each of these words is also used in a bad sense, empiricism applying to that one-sided view of knowledge which neglects or loses sight of the truths or principles referred to above, and trusts to experience alone; transcendentalism, to the opposite extreme, which, in its deprecation of experience, loses sight of the relations which facts and phenomena sustain to principles, and hence to a kind of philosophy, or a use of language, which is vague, obscure, fantastic, or extravagant.
entry.ety: Cf. F. transcendantal, G. transcendental

sn.def: Supereminent; surpassing others; as, transcendental being or qualities.

In the Kantian system, of or pertaining to that which can be determined a priori in regard to the fundamental principles of all human knowledge. What is transcendental, therefore, transcends empiricism; but is does not transcend all human knowledge, or become transcendent. It simply signifies the a priori or necessary conditions of experience which, though affording the conditions of experience, transcend the sphere of that contingent knowledge which is acquired by experience.
Vaguely and ambitiously extravagant in speculation, imagery, or diction.
sn.syn: Transcendental Empirical.

entry.def: A transcendentalist.

entry.note: ☞ As Schelling and Hegel claim to have discovered the absolute identity of the objective and subjective in human knowledge, or of things and human conceptions of them, the Kantian distinction between transcendent and transcendental ideas can have no place in their philosophy; and hence, with them, transcendentalism claims to have a true knowledge of all things, material and immaterial, human and divine, so far as the mind is capable of knowing them. And in this sense the word transcendentalism is now most used. It is also sometimes used for that which is vague and illusive in philosophy.
entry.ety: Cf. F. transcendantalisme, G. transcendentalismus

sn.def: The transcending, or going beyond, empiricism, and ascertaining a priori the fundamental principles of human knowledge.
Ambitious and imaginative vagueness in thought, imagery, or diction.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transcendantaliste
entry.def: One who believes in transcendentalism.
The quality or state of being transcendental.
In a transcendental manner.
In a transcendent manner.
Same as Transcendence.

entry.ety: See Transcend
entry.def: The act of transcending, or surpassing; also, passage over.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transcolated; p. pr. & vb. n. Transcolating
entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. colare colatum, to filter, to strain
entry.def: To cause to pass through a sieve or colander; to strain, as through a sieve.
Act of transcolating, or state of being transcolated.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + continental
entry.def: Extending or going across a continent; as, a transcontinental railroad or journey.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + corporate
entry.def: To transmigrate.
A transcriber; -- used in contempt.
entry.q: He [Aristotle] has suffered vastly from the transcribblers, as all authors of great brevity necessarily must.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transcribed; p. pr. & vb. n. Transcribing
entry.ety: L. transcribere transcriptum; trans across, over + scribere to write. See Scribe
entry.def: To write over again, or in the same words; to copy; as, to transcribe Livy or Tacitus; to transcribe a letter.
One who transcribes, or writes from a copy; a copier; a copyist.

entry.ety: L. transcriptum, neut. of transcriptus, p. p. of transcribere. See Transcribe

sn.def: That which has been transcribed; a writing or composition consisting of the same words as the original; a written copy.
sn.q: The decalogue of Moses was but a transcript.

sn.def: A copy of any kind; an imitation.
sn.q: The Grecian learning was but a transcript of the Chaldean and Egyptian.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transcription, L. transcriptio a transfer

sn.def: The act or process of transcribing, or copying; as, corruptions creep into books by repeated transcriptions .
A copy; a transcript.

An arrangement of a composition for some other instrument or voice than that for which it was originally written, as the translating of a song, a vocal or instrumental quartet, or even an orchestral work, into a piece for the piano; an adaptation; an arrangement; -- a name applied by modern composers for the piano to a more or less fanciful and ornate reproduction on their own instrument of a song or other piece not originally intended for it; as, Liszt's transcriptions of songs by Schubert.

entry.def: Done as from a copy; having the style or appearance of a transcription.

entry.ety: L. transcurrere transcursum; trans across, over + currere to run
entry.def: To run or rove to and fro.

entry.ety: L. transcurrens, p. pr. of transcurrere
entry.def: A roving hither and thither.

entry.ety: Cf. L. transcursio a passing over. See Transcur
entry.def: A rambling or ramble; a passage over bounds; an excursion.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + dialect
entry.def: To change or translate from one dialect into another.

entry.ety: L. transducere traducere -dictum, to lead across or over. See Traduce
entry.def: The act of conveying over.
See Trance.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- element
entry.def: To change or transpose the elements of; to transubstantiate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transélémentation
entry.def: Transubstantiation.
A transom.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. septum an inclosure. See Septum
entry.def: The transversal part of a church, which crosses at right angles to the greatest length, and between the nave and choir. In the basilicas, this had often no projection at its two ends. In Gothic churches these project these project greatly, and should be called the arms of the transept. It is common, however, to speak of the arms themselves as the transepts.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. sexus sex
entry.def: Change of sex.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. femina woman
entry.def: To change into a woman, as a man.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transferred; p. pr. & vb. n. Transferring
entry.ety: L. transferre; trans across, over + ferre to bear: cf. F. transférer. See Bear to carry

sn.def: To convey from one place or person another; to transport, remove, or cause to pass, to another place or person; as, to transfer the laws of one country to another; to transfer suspicion.
To make over the possession or control of; to pass; to convey, as a right, from one person to another; to give; as, the title to land is transferred by deed.
To remove from one substance or surface to another; as, to transfer drawings or engravings to a lithographic stone.
sn.syn: To sell; give; alienate; estrange; sequester.

entry.cs: Transfer day one of the days fixed by the Bank of England for the transfer, free of charge, of bank stock and government funds. These days are the first five business days in the week before three o'clock. Transfers may be made on Saturdays on payment of a fee of 2s. 6d. Bithell. Transfer office an office or department where transfers of stocks, etc., are made. Transfer paper a prepared paper used by draughtsmen, engravers, lithographers, etc., for transferring impressions. Transfer table. Railroad Same as Traverse table. See under Traverse.

sn.def: The act of transferring, or the state of being transferred; the removal or conveyance of a thing from one place or person to another.
The conveyance of right, title, or property, either real or personal, from one person to another, whether by sale, by gift, or otherwise.
sn.q: I shall here only consider it as a transfer of property.

entry.sn:
That which is transferred. Specifically: A picture, or the like, removed from one body or ground to another, as from wood to canvas, or from one piece of canvas to another.
A drawing or writing printed off from one surface on another, as in ceramics and in many decorative arts.
Mil A soldier removed from one troop, or body of troops, and placed in another.

sn.def: A pathological process by virtue of which a unilateral morbid condition on being abolished on one side of the body makes its appearance in the corresponding region upon the other side.

entry.def: The quality or state of being transferable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transférable

sn.def: Capable of being transferred or conveyed from one place or person to another.

Negotiable, as a note, bill of exchange, or other evidence of property, that may be conveyed from one person to another by indorsement or other writing; capable of being transferred with no loss of value; as, the stocks of most public companies are transferable; some tickets are not transferable .

entry.def: The person to whom a transfer in made.
The act of transferring; conveyance; passage; transfer.

entry.ety: Transfer + -graphy
entry.def: The act or process of copying inscriptions, or the like, by making transfers.
See Transference.
One who makes a transfer or conveyance.
Capable of being transferred; transferable.
To transfigure; to transform.

entry.ety: L. transfiguratio: cf. transfiguration

sn.def: A change of form or appearance; especially, the supernatural change in the personal appearance of our Savior on the mount.
A feast held by some branches of the Christian church on the 6th of August, in commemoration of the miraculous change above mentioned.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transfigured; p. pr. & vb. n. Transfiguring
entry.ety: F. transfigurer, L. transfigurare transfiguratum; trans across, over + figurare to form, shape. See Figure v. t.

sn.def: To change the outward form or appearance of; to metamorphose; to transform.
Especially, to change to something exalted and glorious; to give an ideal form to.
sn.q: Jesus] was transfigured before them; and his face did shine as the sun, and his raiment was white as the light.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transfixed; p. pr. & vb. n. Transfixing
entry.ety: L. transfixus, p. p. of transfigure to transfix; trans across, through + figere to fix, fasten. See Fix
entry.def: To pierce through, as with a pointed weapon; to impale; as, to transfix one with a dart.
The act of transfixing, or the state of being transfixed, or pierced.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + fluent

sn.def: Flowing or running across or through; as, a transfluent stream.
Passing or flowing through a bridge; -- said of water.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + flux
entry.def: A flowing through, across, or beyond.

entry.ety: L. transforatus, p. p. of transforare to pierce through; trans through + forare to bore
entry.def: To bore through; to perforate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transformed; p. pr. & vb. n. Transforming
entry.ety: L. transformare transformatum; trans across, over + formare to from: cf. F. transformer. See Form v. t.

sn.def: To change the form of; to change in shape or appearance; to metamorphose; as, a caterpillar is ultimately transformed into a butterfly.
sn.q: Love may transform me to an oyster.

sn.def: To change into another substance; to transmute; as, the alchemists sought to transform lead into gold.
To change in nature, disposition, heart, character, or the like; to convert.
sn.q: Be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind.

sn.def: To change, as an algebraic expression or geometrical figure, into another from without altering its value.

entry.def: To be changed in form; to be metamorphosed.
entry.q: His hair transforms to down.
