entry.def: Capable of being transformed or changed.

entries.entry:
Trans`for*ma"tion n. L. transformatio: cf. transformation
The act of transforming, or the state of being transformed; change of form or condition. Specifically:Biol Any change in an organism which alters its general character and mode of life, as in the development of the germ into the embryo, the egg into the animal, the larva into the insect (metamorphosis), etc.; also, the change which the histological units of a tissue are prone to undergo. See Metamorphosis. Physiol Change of one from of material into another, as in assimilation; metabolism; metamorphosis. Alchemy The imagined possible or actual change of one metal into another; transmutation. Theol A change in disposition, heart, character, or the like; conversion. Math The change, as of an equation or quantity, into another form without altering the value.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transformatif
entry.def: Having power, or a tendency, to transform.

entry.cs: Multiple transformer. Elec A transformer connected in multiple or in parallel with the primary circuit. A transformer with more than one primary or more than one secondary coil. Parallel transformer Elec a transformer connected in parallel.

sn.def: One who, or that which, transforms. Specif. Elec, an apparatus for producing from a given electrical current another current of different voltage.

a toy consisting of a figure or representation of an object, constructed of interlocking parts in such a way that a series of turning or twisting motions of the parts can transform the object from one type of object to a different type of object, such as from an animal to an automobile.

entry.ety: F. transformisme
entry.def: The hypothesis, or doctrine, that living beings have originated by the modification of some other previously existing forms of living matter; -- opposed to abiogenesis.
To transfrete.

entry.ety: L. transfretatio. See Transfrete
entry.def: The act of passing over a strait or narrow sea.

entry.ety: L. transfretare; trans across, over + fretum a strait: cf. OF. transfreter
entry.def: To pass over a strait or narrow sea.

entry.ety: L. transfuga; trans across, over + fugere to flee
entry.def: One who flees from one side to another; hence, a deserter; a turncoat; an apostate.

entry.ety: L. transfundere; trans over, across + fundere to pour, pour out. See Found to cast, and cf. Transfuse
entry.def: To pour from one vessel into another; to transfuse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transfused; p. pr. & vb. n. Transfusing
entry.ety: L. transfusus, p. p. of transfundere: cf. F. transfuser. See Transfund

sn.def: To pour, as liquid, out of one vessel into another; to transfer by pouring.
To transfer, as blood, from the veins or arteries of one man or animal to those of another.
To cause to pass from to another; to cause to be instilled or imbibed; as, to transfuse a spirit of patriotism into a man; to transfuse a love of letters.
sn.q: Into thee such virtue and grace Immense I have transfused.

entry.def: Capable of being transfused; transferable by transfusion.

entry.ety: L. transfusio: cf. F. transfusion

sn.def: The act of transfusing, or pouring, as liquor, out of one vessel into another.

The act or operation of transferring the blood of one man or animal into the vascular system of another; also, the introduction of any fluid into the blood vessels, or into a cavity of the body from which it can readily be adsorbed into the vessels; intrafusion; as, the peritoneal transfusion of milk.

entry.def: Tending to transfuse; having power to transfuse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transgressed; p. pr. & vb. n. Transgressing
entry.ety: Cf. F. transgresser. See Transgression

sn.def: To pass over or beyond; to surpass.
sn.q: Surpassing common faith, transgressing nature's law.

sn.def: Hence, to overpass, as any prescribed as the �imit of duty; to break or violate, as a law, civil or moral.
sn.q: For man will hearken to his glozing lies, And easily transgress the sole command.

sn.def: To offend against; to vex.
sn.q: Why give you peace to this imperate beast That hath so long transgressed you ?

entry.def: To offend against the law; to sin.
entry.q: Who transgressed in the thing accursed.

entry.ety: L. transgressio a going across, going over, transgression of the law, from transgredi transgressus, to step across, go over; trans over, across + gradi to step, walk: cf. F. transgression. See Grade
entry.def: The act of transgressing, or of passing over or beyond any law, civil or moral; the violation of a law or known principle of rectitude; breach of command; fault; offense; crime; sin.
entry.q: Forgive thy people . . . all their transgressions wherein they have transgressed against thee.
What rests, but that the mortal sentence pass On his transgression, death denounced that day ?
The transgression is in the stealer.
entry.syn: Fault; offense; crime; infringement; misdemeanor; misdeed; affront; sin.

entry.def: Of pertaining to transgression; involving a transgression.

entry.ety: Cf. L. transgressivus passing over into another class. F. transgressif
entry.def: Disposed or tending to transgress; faulty; culpable. -

entry.q: Adam, perhaps, . . . from the transgressive infirmities of himself, might have erred alone.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. transgresseur
entry.def: One who transgresses; one who breaks a law, or violates a command; one who violates any known rule or principle of rectitude; a sinner.
entry.q: The way of transgressors is hard.

entry.def: To transshape.
Same as Transship.
Same as Transshipment.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + human
entry.def: More than human; superhuman.
entry.q: Words may not tell of that transhuman change.

entry.def: To make more than human; to purity; to elevate above humanity.
entry.q: Souls purified by sorrow and self-denial, transhumanized to the divine abstraction of pure contemplation.

entry.def: The quality of being transient; transientness.

entry.usage: Transient represents a thing as brief at the best; transitory, as liable at any moment to pass away. Fleeting goes further, and represents it as in the act of taking its flight. Life is transient; its joys are transitory; its hours are fleeting.
entry.ety: L. transiens -entis, p. pr. of transire transitum, to go or pass over. See Trance

sn.def: Passing before the sight or perception, or, as it were, moving over or across a space or scene viewed, and then disappearing; hence, of short duration; not permanent; not lasting or durable; not stationary; passing; fleeting; brief; transitory; as, transient pleasure.
sn.q: Measured thistransientworld.

sn.def: Hasty; momentary; imperfect; brief; as, a transient view of a landscape.
Staying for a short time; not regular or permanent; as, a transient guest; transient boarders.
sn.syn: Transient Transitory Fleeting.
sn.q: What is loose love? A transient gust.
If [we lovetransitory things, which soon decay, Age must be loveliest at the latest day.
O fleeting joys Of Paradise, dear bought with lasting woes.

entry.def: That which remains but for a brief time.

entry.ety: L. transiliens, p. pr. of transilire to leap across or over; trans across, over + salire to leap
entry.def: A leap across or from one thing to another.
entry.q: An unadvisedtransiliency.

entry.ety: L. transire to pass through or across, to pass
entry.def: A customhouse clearance for a coasting vessel; a permit.
Extending across an isthmus, as at Suez or Panama.

entry.note: Transistors are used in almost all modern electronic devices, having replaced the vacuum tube in most applications. Since they are based on the electronic characteristics of solids, they are called solid-state devices. Typically a transistor is composed of p, n, and p-type semiconductors in series, or of n, p, and n, with the center region being a thin layer between the two outer regions. An electronic signal input to the central layer may be substantially amplified by such a device. In integrated circuits, many thousands of transistors may be etched into a single small wafer of silicon.
entry.ety: transfer + resistor, from its ability to tranfer a current across a resistor
entry.def: a component used in electronic devices consisting of three regions of at least two types of a semiconducting material, such as doped silicon, connected to each other and to three electrodes in a conducting path so as to modify the current or voltage in an electronic circuit.

entry.note: ☞ The surveyor's transit differs from the theodolite in having the horizontal axis attached directly to the telescope which is not mounted in Y's and can be turned completely over about the axis.
entry.cs: Lower transit Astron the passage of a heavenly body across that part of the meridian which is below the polar axis. Surveyor's transit. See Transit, 5, above. Transit circle Astron a transit instrument with a graduated circle attached, used for observing the time of transit and the declination at one observation. See Circle n., 3. Transit compass. See Transit, 5, above. Transit duty a duty paid on goods that pass through a country. Transit instrument. Astron A telescope mounted at right angles to a horizontal axis, on which it revolves with its line of collimation in the plane of the meridian, -- used in connection with a clock for observing the time of transit of a heavenly body over the meridian of a place. Surv A surveyor's transit. See Transit, 5, above. Transit trade Com the business conected with the passage of goods through a country to their destination. Upper transit Astron the passage of a heavenly body across that part of the meridian which is above the polar axis.
entry.ety: L. transitus, from transire to go over: cf. F. transit. See Transient

sn.def: The act of passing; passage through or over.
sn.q: In France you are now . . . in the transit from one form of government to another.

sn.def: The act or process of causing to pass; conveyance; as, the transit of goods through a country.
A line or route of passage or conveyance; as, the Nicaragua transit .

sd.def: The passage of a heavenly body over the meridian of a place, or through the field of a telescope.
The passage of a smaller body across the disk of a larger, as of Venus across the sun's disk, or of a satellite or its shadow across the disk of its primary.

sn.def: An instrument resembling a theodolite, used by surveyors and engineers; -- called also transit compass, and surveyor's transit.

entry.def: To pass over the disk of (a heavenly body).

entry.note: ☞ This word is sometimes pronounced tran*sish"un; but according to Walker, Smart, and most other authorities, the customary and preferable pronunciation is tran*sizh"un, although this latter mode violates analogy. Other authorities say tran*zish"un.

cs.cd: a term formerly applied to the lowest uncrystalline stratified rocks (graywacke) supposed to contain no fossils, and so called because thought to have been formed when the earth was passing from an uninhabitable to a habitable state.

entry.ety: L. transitio: cf. F. transition. See Transient

sn.def: Passage from one place or state to another; charge; as, the transition of the weather from hot to cold.
sn.q: There is no death, what seems so is transition.

sn.def: A direct or indirect passing from one key to another; a modulation.
A passing from one subject to another.
sn.q: He] with transition sweet, new speech resumes.

sn.def: Change from one form to another.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to transition; involving or denoting transition; as, transitional changes; transitional stage.
Transitional.

entries.entry: Tran*si"tion zone. Biogeography The zone lying between the Boreal and Sonoran zones of North America. It includes an eastern or humid subdivision and a western arid one of corresponding temperature comprising the northern Great Plains and the lower slopes of the mountains of the western United States and Mexico. Called also Neutral zone.

entry.ety: L. transitivus: cf. F. transitif. See Transient

sn.def: Having the power of making a transit, or passage.
Effected by transference of signification.
sn.q: By far the greater part of the transitive or derivative applications of words depend on casual and unaccountable caprices of the feelings or the fancy.

sn.def: Passing over to an object; expressing an action which is not limited to the agent or subject, but which requires an object to complete the sense; as, a transitive verb, for example, he holds the book.

entry.def: In a transitory manner; with brief continuance.
The quality or state of being transitory; speedy passage or departure.

cs.cd: an action which may be brought in any county, as actions for debt, and the like; -- opposed to local action.

entry.ety: L. transitorius: cf. F. transitoire. See Transient
entry.def: Continuing only for a short time; not enduring; fleeting; evanescent.
entry.q: Comfort and succor all those who, in this transitory life, are in trouble.
It was not the transitory light of a comet, which shines and glows for a wile, and then . . . vanishes into nothing.

entry.def: Capable of being translated, or rendered into another language.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Translated; p. pr. & vb. n. Translating
entry.ety: f. translatus, used as p. p. of transferre to transfer, but from a different root. See Trans-, and Tolerate, and cf. Translation

sn.def: To bear, carry, or remove, from one place to another; to transfer; as, to translate a tree.
sn.q: In the chapel of St. Catharine of Sienna, they show her head- the rest of her body being translated to Rome.

sn.def: To change to another condition, position, place, or office; to transfer; hence, to remove as by death.
To remove to heaven without a natural death.
sn.q: By faith Enoch was translated, that he should not see death; and was not found, because God had translatedhim.

sn.def: To remove, as a bishop, from one see to another.
sn.q: Fisher, Bishop of Rochester, when the king would havetranslatedhim from that poor bishopric to a better, . . . refused.

sn.def: To render into another language; to express the sense of in the words of another language; to interpret; hence, to explain or recapitulate in other words.
sn.q: Translating into his own clear, pure, and flowing language, what he found in books well known to the world, but too bulky or too dry for boys and girls.

sn.def: To change into another form; to transform.
sn.q: Happy is your grace, That can translatethe stubbornness of fortune Into so quiet and so sweet a style.

sn.def: To cause to remove from one part of the body to another; as, to translate a disease.
To cause to lose senses or recollection; to entrance.

entry.def: To make a translation; to be engaged in translation.

entry.ety: F. translation, L. translatio a transferring, translation, version. See Translate, and cf. Tralation

sn.def: The act of translating, removing, or transferring; removal; also, the state of being translated or removed; as, the translation of Enoch; the translation of a bishop.
The act of rendering into another language; interpretation; as, the translation of idioms is difficult.
That which is obtained by translating something a version; as, a translation of the Scriptures.
A transfer of meaning in a word or phrase, a metaphor; a tralation.
Transfer of meaning by association; association of ideas.
Motion in which all the points of the moving body have at any instant the same velocity and direction of motion; -- opposed to rotation.

entry.ety: See Tralatitious
entry.def: Metaphorical; tralatitious; also, foreign; exotic.

entry.ety: L. translativus that is to be transferred: cf. F. translatif
entry.def: tropical; figurative; as, a translative sense.

entry.ety: L. translator: cf. F. translateur

sn.def: One who translates; esp., one who renders into another language; one who expresses the sense of words in one language by equivalent words in another.
A repeating instrument.

entry.def: The office or dignity of a translator.
Serving to translate; transferring.
A woman who translates.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. lavatio -onis, washing
entry.def: A laving or lading from one vessel to another.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. litera littera letter
entry.def: To express or represent in the characters of another alphabet; as, to transliterate Sanskrit words by means of English letters.
The act or product of transliterating, or of expressing words of a language by means of the characters of another alphabet.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + location
entry.def: removal of things from one place to another; substitution of one thing for another.
entry.q: There happened certain translocations at the deluge.

entry.def: The quality or state of being translucent; clearness; partial transparency.

entry.usage: A thing is translucent when it merely admits the passage of light, without enabling us to distinguish the color and outline of objects through it; it is transparent when we can clearly discern objects placed on the other side of it. Glass, water, etc., are transparent; ground glass is translucent; a translucent style.
entry.ety: L. translucens -entis, p. pr. of translucere to shine through; trans across, through = lucere to shine. See Lucid

sn.def: Transmitting rays of light without permitting objects to be distinctly seen; partially transparent.
Transparent; clear.
sn.q: Fountain or fresh current . . .translucent, pure.
Replenished from the cool, translucent springs.
sn.syn: Translucent Transparent.

entry.def: In a translucent manner.

entry.ety: L. translucidus; trans across, through + lucidus lucid: cf. F. translucide. See Translucent
entry.def: Translucent.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. luna moon
entry.def: Being or lying beyond the moon; hence, ethereal; -- opposed to sublunary.
entry.q: Marlowe, bathed in the Thespian springs, Had in him those brave, translunary things That the first poets had.

entry.ety: L. transmarinus; trans beyond + marinus marine: cf. F. transmarin. See Marine
entry.def: Lying or being beyond the sea.

entry.ety: L. transmeabilis
entry.def: Capable of being passed over or traversed; passable.

entry.ety: L. transmeatus, p. p. of transmeare to pass across; trans across, over + meare to go
entry.def: To pass over or beyond.
The act of transmeating; a passing through or beyond.

entry.ety: F. transmuer, L. transmutare. See Transmute
entry.def: To transmute; to transform; to metamorphose.
entry.q: To transmew thyself from a holy hermit into a sinful forester.

entry.ety: L. transmigrans, p. pr. See Transmigrate
entry.def: Migrating or passing from one place or state to another; passing from one residence to another.

def2.def: One who transmigrates.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transmigrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Transmigrating
entry.ety: L. transmigrare transmigratum; trans across + migrare to migrate. See Migrate

sn.def: To pass from one country or jurisdiction to another for the purpose of residence, as men or families; to migrate.
To pass from one body or condition into another.
sn.q: Their may transmigrate into each other.

entry.ety: F. transmigration, L. transmigratio

sn.def: The act of passing from one country to another; migration.
The passing of the soul at death into another mortal body; metempsychosis.

entry.def: One who transmigrates.
Passing from one body or state to another.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transmissibilité
entry.def: The quality of being transmissible.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transmissible
entry.def: Capable of being transmitted from one to another; capable of being passed through any body or substance.

entry.ety: L. transmissio; cf. F. transmission. See Transmit

sn.def: The act of transmitting, or the state of being transmitted; as, the transmission of letters, writings, papers, news, and the like, from one country to another; the transmission of rights, titles, or privileges, from father to son, or from one generation to another.

The right possessed by an heir or legatee of transmitting to his successor or successors any inheritance, legacy, right, or privilege, to which he is entitled, even if he should die without enjoying or exercising it.

The mechanism within a vehicle which transmits rotational power from the engine to the axle of the wheel propelling the vehicle; it includes the gears and gear-changing mechanism as well as the propeller shaft.
The process or event of sending signals by means of a radio-frequency wave from an electronic transmitter to a receiving device.

entries.entry: Trans*mis"sion dy`na*mom"e*ter. Mach A dynamometer in which power is measured, without being absorbed or used up, during transmission.

entry.def: An adherent of a theory, the transmission theory, that the brain serves to “transmit,” rather than to originate, conclusions, and hence that consciousness may exist independently of the brain.
Capable of being transmitted; derived, or handed down, from one to another.
entry.q: Itself a sun, it with transmissive light Enlivens worlds denied to human sight.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transmitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Transmitting
entry.ety: L. transmittere transmissum; trans across, over + mittere to send: cf. F. transmettre. See Missile

sn.def: To cause to pass over or through; to communicate by sending; to send from one person or place to another; to pass on or down as by inheritance; as, to transmit a memorial; to transmit dispatches; to transmit money, or bills of exchange, from one country to another.
sn.q: The ancientest fathers must be next removed, as Clement of Alexandria, and that Eusebian book of evangelic preparation, transmitting our ears through a hoard of heathenish obscenities to receive the gospel.
The scepter of that kingdom continued to be transmitted in the dynasty of Castile.

sn.def: To suffer to pass through; as, glass transmits light; metals transmit, or conduct, electricity.

entry.def: Transmission.
Transmission.
One who, or that which, transmits; specifically, that portion of a telegraphic or telephonic instrument by means of which a message is sent; -- opposed to receiver.
Capable of being transmitted; transmissible.
The act of transmogrifying, or the state of being transmogrified; transformation.
entry.q: Clive, who wrote me about the transmogrification of our schoolfellow, an attorney's son.

entry.ety: A humorous coinage
entry.def: To change into a different shape; to transform.

entry.ety: Pref. trans + move
entry.def: To move or change from one state into another; to transform.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transmutabilité
entry.def: The quality of being transmutable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transmutable. See Transmute
entry.def: Capable of being transmuted or changed into a different substance, or into into something of a different form a nature; transformable.
entry.q: The fluids and solids of an animal body are easily transmutable into one another.

cs.cd: the conversion of base metals into gold or silver, a process often attempted by the alchemists. See Alchemy, and Philosopher's stone, under Philosopher.

entry.ety: F. transmutation, L. transmutatio. See Transmute

sn.def: The act of transmuting, or the state of being transmuted; as, the transmutation of metals.
The change or reduction of one figure or body into another of the same area or solidity, but of a different form, as of a triangle into a square.
The change of one species into another, which is assumed to take place in any development theory of life; transformism.

entry.def: One who believes in the transmutation of metals or of species.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transmuted; p. pr. & vb. n. Transmuting
entry.ety: L. transmutare transmutatum; trans across + mutare to change. See Mutable, and cf. Transmew
entry.def: To change from one nature, form, or substance, into another; to transform.
entry.q: The caresses of parents and the blandishments of friends transmute us into idols.
Transmuting sorrow into golden joy Free from alloy.

entry.def: One who transmutes.

entry.ety: Pref. trans + mutual
entry.def: Reciprocal; commutual.

entry.ety: L. transnatare to swim over; trans across, over + natare to swim
entry.def: The act of swimming across, as a river.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + nature
entry.def: To transfer or transform the nature of.
entry.q: We are transelemented, or transnatured.

entry.cs: Transom knees Shipbuilding knees bolted to the transoms and after timbers. Transom window. Arch A window divided horizontally by a transom or transoms. A window over a door, with a transom between.
entry.ety: Probably fr. L. transtrum a crossbeam, transom, from trans across. Cf. Trestle

sn.def: A horizontal crossbar in a window, over a door, or between a door and a window above it. Transom is the horizontal, as mullion is the vertical, bar across an opening. See Illust. of Mullion.
One of the principal transverse timbers of the stern, bolted to the sternpost and giving shape to the stern structure; -- called also transsummer.
The piece of wood or iron connecting the cheeks of some gun carriages.
The vane of a cross-staff.
One of the crossbeams connecting the side frames of a truck with each other.

entry.ety: L. transpadanus; trans across + Padus the Po
entry.def: Lying or being on the further side of the river Po with reference to Rome, that is, on the north side; -- opposed to cispadane.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + palatine
entry.def: Situated beyond or outside the palatine bone; -- said of a bone in the skull of some reptiles.

entry.ety: See Transparent
entry.def: To be, or cause to be, transparent; to appear, or cause to appear, or be seen, through something.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transparence
entry.def: The quality or state of being transparent; transparency.

entries.entry:
Trans*par"en*cy n.; pl.Transparencies #. Cf. F. transparence
The quality or condition of being transparent; transparence.
That which is transparent; especially, a picture painted on thin cloth or glass, or impressed on porcelain, or the like, to be viewed by natural or artificial light, which shines through it.

entry.ety: F., from LL. transparens -entis, p. pr. of transparere to be transparent; L. trans across, through + parere to appear. See Appear

sn.def: Having the property of transmitting rays of light, so that bodies can be distinctly seen through; pervious to light; diaphanous; pellucid; as, transparent glass; a transparent diamond; -- opposed to opaque.
sn.q: Transparentelemental air.

sn.def: Admitting the passage of light; open; porous; as, a transparent veil.
sn.syn: Translucent; pellucid; clear; bright; limpid; lucid; diaphanous. See Translucent.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + pass: cf. LL. transpassare. Cf. Trespass
entry.def: To pass over; as, Alexander transpassed the river.
To pass by; to pass away.
Capable of being transpassed, or crossed over.

entry.ety: Trans- + patronize
entry.def: To transfer the patronage of.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. species form
entry.def: To change from one species to another; to transform.
entry.q: Power to transpeciate a man into a horse.

entry.ety: L. transpicere to see or look through + specere spicere, to see. Cf. Conspicuous
entry.def: Transparent; pervious to the sight.
entry.q: The wide,transpicuousair.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transpierced; p. pr. & vb. n. Transpiercing
entry.ety: Pref. trans- + pierce: cf. F. transpercer
entry.def: To pierce through; to penetrate; to permeate; to pass through.
entry.q: The sides transpierced return a rattling sound.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transpirable
entry.def: Capable of being transpired, or of transpiring.

entry.ety: F. transpiration

sn.def: The act or process of transpiring or excreting in the form of vapor; exhalation, as through the skin or other membranes of the body; as, pulmonary transpiration, or the excretion of aqueous vapor from the lungs. Perspiration is a form of transpiration.
The evaporation of water, or exhalation of aqueous vapor, from cells and masses of tissue.
The passing of gases through fine tubes, porous substances, or the like; as, transpiration through membranes.

entry.def: Of or relating to transpiration.

entry.note: ☞ This sense of the word, which is of comparatively recent introduction, is common in the United States, especially in the language of conversation and of newspaper writers, and is used to some extent in England. Its use, however, is censured by critics of both countries.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transpired; p. pr. & vb. n. Transpiring
entry.ety: F. transpirer; L. trans across, through + spirare to breathe. See Spirit

sn.def: To pass off in the form of vapor or insensible perspiration; to exhale.
To evaporate from living cells.
To escape from secrecy; to become public; as, the proceedings of the council soon transpired .
sn.q: The story of Paulina's and Maximilian's mutual attachment had transpired through many of the travelers.

sn.def: To happen or come to pass; to occur.
To excrete through the skin; to give off in the form of vapor; to exhale; to perspire.
To evaporate (moisture) from living cells.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transplaced; p. pr. & vb. n. Transplacing
entry.ety: Pref. trans- + place
entry.def: To remove across some space; to put in an opposite or another place.
entry.q: It [an obelisk] was transplaced . . . from the left side of the Vatican into a more eminent place.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transplanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Transplanting
entry.ety: F. transplanter, L. transplantare; trans across, over + plantare to plant. See Plant

sn.def: To remove, and plant in another place; as, to transplant trees.
To remove, and settle or establish for residence in another place; as, to transplant inhabitants.
sn.q: Being transplanted out of his cold, barren diocese of St. David into a warmer climate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transplantation

sn.def: The act of transplanting, or the state of being transplanted; also, removal.
sn.q: The transplantation of Ulysses to Sparta.

sn.def: The removal of tissues from a healthy part, and the insertion of them in another place where there is a lesion; as, the transplantation of tissues in autoplasty.

entry.def: One who transplants; also, a machine for transplanting trees.
Quality or state of being transplendent.

entry.ety: Trans- + splendent
entry.def: Resplendent in the highest degree.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transported; p. pr. & vb. n. Transporting
entry.ety: F. transporter, L. transportare; trans across + portare to carry. See Port bearing, demeanor

sn.def: To carry or bear from one place to another; to remove; to convey; as, to transport goods; to transport troops.
To carry, or cause to be carried, into banishment, as a criminal; to banish.
To carry away with vehement emotion, as joy, sorrow, complacency, anger, etc.; to ravish with pleasure or ecstasy; as, music transports the soul.
sn.q: They] laugh as if transported with some fit Of passion.
We shall then be transported with a nobler . . . wonder.

entry.ety: F. See Transport v.

sn.def: Transportation; carriage; conveyance.
sn.q: The Romans . . . stipulated with the Carthaginians to furnish them with ships for transport and war.

sn.def: A vessel employed for transporting, especially for carrying soldiers, warlike stores, or provisions, from one place to another, or to convey convicts to their destination; -- called also transport ship transport vessel.
Vehement emotion; passion; ecstasy; rapture.
sn.q: With transport views the airy rule his own, And swells on an imaginary throne.
Say not, in transports of despair, That all your hopes are fled.

sn.def: A convict transported, or sentenced to exile.

entry.def: The quality or state of being transportable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transportable

sn.def: Capable of being transported.
Incurring, or subject to, the punishment of transportation; as, a transportable offense.

entry.def: Transportation; the act of removing from one locality to another.
entry.q: Thetransportalof seeds in the wool or fur of quadrupeds.

entry.def: Transportation.
entry.q: Give me swifttransportance.

entry.def: Transporting; �avishing; as, transportant love.

entry.ety: L. transportatio: cf. F. transportation

sn.def: The act of transporting, or the state of being transported; carriage from one place to another; removal; conveyance.
sn.q: To provide a vessel for their transportation.

sn.def: Transport; ecstasy.

entry.def: Conveyed from one place to another; figuratively, carried away with passion or pleasure; entranced.
One who transports.
That transports; fig., ravishing.
entry.q: Your transporting chords ring out.

entry.def: So as to transport.
The act of transporting, or the state of being transported; transportation.
That may transposed; as, a transposable phrase.
The act of transposing, or the state of being transposed; transposition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transposed; p. pr. & vb. n. Transposing
entry.ety: F. transposer; pref. trans-L. trans across) + poser to put. See Pose

sn.def: To change the place or order of; to substitute one for the other of; to exchange, in respect of position; as, to transpose letters, words, or propositions.
To change; to transform; to invert.
sn.q: Things base and vile, holding no quantity, Love can transpose to form and dignity.

sn.def: To bring, as any term of an equation, from one side over to the other, without destroying the equation; thus, if a + b = c, and we make a = c - b, then b is said to be transposed.
To change the natural order of, as words.
To change the key of.

entry.def: One who transposes.

entries.entry:
Trans`po*si"tion n. F. transposition, from L. transponere transpositum, to set over, remove, transfer; trans across, over + ponere to place. See Position
The act of transposing, or the state of being transposed. Specifically:Alg The bringing of any term of an equation from one side over to the other without destroying the equation. Gram A change of the natural order of words in a sentence; as, the Latin and Greek languages admit transposition, without inconvenience, to a much greater extent than the English. Mus A change of a composition into another key.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to transposition; involving transposition.
Made by transposing; consisting in transposition; transposable.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + print
entry.def: To transfer to the wrong place in printing; to print out of place.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + prose
entry.def: To change from prose into verse; to versify; also, to change from verse into prose.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + region
entry.def: Foreign.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transshaped; p. pr. & vb. n. Transshaping
entry.ety: Pref. trans- + shape
entry.def: To change into another shape or form; to transform.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + ship
entry.def: To transfer from one ship or conveyance to another.
The act of transshipping, or transferring, as goods, from one ship or conveyance to another.
See Transom, 2.

entry.ety: LL. transubstantiatus, p. p. of transubstantiare to transubstantiate; L. trans across, over + substantia substance. See Substance

sn.def: To change into another substance.
sn.q: The spider love which transubstantiates all, And can convert manna to gall.

sn.def: To change, as the sacramental elements, bread and wine, into the flesh and blood of Christ.

entry.ety: LL. transubstantiatio: cf. F. transsubstantiation

sn.def: A change into another substance.
The doctrine held by Roman Catholics, that the bread and wine in the Mass is converted into the body and blood of Christ; -- distinguished from consubstantiation, and impanation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transsubstantiateur
entry.def: One who maintains the doctrine of transubstantiation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transsudation

sn.def: The act or process of transuding.
Same as Exosmose.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to transudation; passing by transudation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transuded; p. pr. & vb. n. Transuding
entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. sudare to sweat: cf. F. transsuder
entry.def: To pass, as perspirable matter does, through the pores or interstices of textures; as, liquor may transude through leather or wood.

entry.ety: L. transumere transsumere, to take from one to another; trans across + sumere to take
entry.def: To change; to convert.

entry.ety: L. transumere transumptum, to take from one to another, in LL., to transcribe. See Transume
entry.def: A copy or exemplification of a record; a transcript.

entry.ety: L. transumptio
entry.def: Act of taking from one place to another.

entry.ety: L. transumptivus
entry.def: Taking from one to another; metaphorical.
entry.q: Atransumptivekind of speech.
Fictive, descriptive, digressive, transumptive, and withal definitive.

entry.ety: See Transvasation
entry.def: To pour out of one vessel into another.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + L. vas vasis, vessel
entry.def: The act or process of pouring out of one vessel into another.

entry.ety: L. transvectio, from transvehere to carry across; trans across + vehere to carry
entry.def: The act of conveying or carrying over.

entry.ety: L. transverberatus, p. p. of transverberare to strike or pierce through
entry.def: To beat or strike through.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transversal. See Transverse
entry.def: Running or lying across; transverse; as, a transversal line.

entry.ety: Cf. F. transversale
entry.def: A straight line which traverses or intersects any system of other lines, as a line intersecting the three sides of a triangle or the sides produced.

entry.cs: Transverse axisof an ellipse or hyperbolaGeom that axis which passes through the foci. Transverse partition Bot a partition, as of a pericarp, at right angles with the valves, as in the siliques of mustard.
entry.ety: L. transversus, p. p. of transvertere to turn on direct across; trans across + vertere to turn: cf. F. transverse. See Verse, and cf. Traverse
entry.def: Lying or being across, or in a crosswise direction; athwart; -- often opposed to longitudinal.

sn.def: Anything that is transverse or athwart.
The longer, or transverse, axis of an ellipse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Transversed; p. pr. & vb. n. Transversing
entry.def: To overturn; to change.

entry.ety: Pref. trans- + verse, n. Cf.Transpose
entry.def: To change from prose into verse, or from verse into prose.
In a transverse manner.
The act of changing from prose into verse, or from verse into prose.

entry.ety: L. transvertere. See Transverse, a
entry.def: To cause to turn across; to transverse.
Capable of being transverted.

entry.ety: L. transvolare to fly over or across; trans across + volare to fly
entry.def: The act of flying beyond or across.

entry.ety: Cf. OD. tranten to walk slowly, LG. & D. trant walk, pace
entry.def: To traffic in an itinerary manner; to peddle.
One who trants; a peddler; a carrier.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trapped; p. pr. & vb. n. Trapping
entry.ety: Akin to OE. trappe trappings, and perhaps from an Old French word of the same origin as E. drab a kind of cloth
entry.def: To dress with ornaments; to adorn; -- said especially of horses.
entry.q: Steeds . . . that trapped were in steel all glittering.
To deck his hearse, and trap his tomb-black steed.
There she found her palfrey trapped In purple blazoned with armorial gold.

cs.cd: a kind of fragmental rock made up of fragments and earthy materials from trap rocks.

entry.ety: Sw. trapp; akin to trappa stairs, Dan. trappe, G. treppe, D. trap; -- so called because the rocks of this class often occur in large, tabular masses, rising above one another, like steps. See Tramp
entry.def: An old term rather loosely used to designate various dark-colored, heavy igneous rocks, including especially the feldspathic-augitic rocks, basalt, dolerite, amygdaloid, etc., but including also some kinds of diorite. Called also trap rock.
Of or pertaining to trap rock; as, a trap dike.

cs.cd: a staircase leading to a trapdoor.
the jack; -- so called because it furnishes a kind of birdlime. See 1st Jack.

entry.ety: OE. trappe, AS. treppe; akin to OD. trappe, OHG. trapo; probably fr. the root of E. tramp, as that which is trod upon: cf. F. trappe, which is trod upon: cf. F. trappe, which perhaps influenced the English word

sn.def: A machine or contrivance that shuts suddenly, as with a spring, used for taking game or other animals; as, a trap for foxes.
sn.q: She would weep if that she saw a mouse Caught in a trap.

sn.def: Fig.: A snare; an ambush; a stratagem; any device by which one may be caught unawares.
sn.q: Let their table be made a snare and a trap.
God and your majesty Protect mine innocence, or I fall into The trap is laid for me!

sn.def: A wooden instrument shaped somewhat like a shoe, used in the game of trapball. It consists of a pivoted arm on one end of which is placed the ball to be thrown into the air by striking the other end. Also, a machine for throwing into the air glass balls, clay pigeons, etc., to be shot at.
The game of trapball.
A bend, sag, or partitioned chamber, in a drain, soil pipe, sewer, etc., arranged so that the liquid contents form a seal which prevents passage of air or gas, but permits the flow of liquids.
A place in a water pipe, pump, etc., where air accumulates for want of an outlet.
A wagon, or other vehicle.
A kind of movable stepladder.

entry.ety: AS. treppan. See Trap a snare

sn.def: To catch in a trap or traps; as, to trap foxes.
Fig.: To insnare; to take by stratagem; to entrap.
sn.q: Itrappedthe foe.

sn.def: To provide with a trap; as, to trap a drain; to trap a sewer pipe. See 4th Trap, 5.

entry.def: To set traps for game; to make a business of trapping game; as, to trap for beaver.

entry.ety: OF. trappan. See Trap, and cf. Trepan a snare
entry.def: A snare; a stratagem; a trepan. See 3d Trepan.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trapanned; p. pr. & vb. n. Trapanning
entry.def: To insnare; to catch by stratagem; to entrap; to trepan.
entry.q: Having some of his people trapanned at Baldivia.

entry.def: One who trapans, or insnares.
An old game of ball played with a trap. See 4th Trap, 4.

cs.cd: any one of several species of large spiders which make a nest consisting of a vertical hole in the earth, lined with a hinged lid, like a trapdoor. Most of the species belong to the genus Cteniza, as the California species (Cteniza Californica).

sn.def: A lifting or sliding door covering an opening in a roof or floor.
A door in a level for regulating the ventilating current; -- called also weather door.

entry.ety: See Tramp, and cf. Traipse
entry.def: To walk or run about in an idle or slatternly manner; to traipse.

entry.ety: See Trape
entry.def: A slattern; an idle, sluttish, or untidy woman.
To go about in an idle or slatternly fashion; to trape; to traipse.

entry.ety: See Trapezium
entry.def: Having the form of a trapezium; trapeziform.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trapèze

sn.def: A trapezium. See Trapezium, 1.
A swinging horizontal bar, suspended at each end by a rope; -- used by gymnasts.

entry.ety: Trapezium + -form: cf. F. trapéziforme
entry.def: Having the form of a trapezium; trapezoid.

entries.entry:
Tra*pe"zi*um n.; pl. E. Trapeziums #, L. Trapezia #. NL., fr. Gr. � a little table, an irregular four-sided figure, dim. of � a table, for �; � (see Tetra-) + � foot, akin to � foot; hence, originally, a table with four feet. See Foot
Geom A plane figure bounded by four right lines, of which no two are parallel.
Anat
A bone of the carpus at the base of the first metacarpal, or thumb.
A region on the ventral side of the brain, either just back of the pons Varolii, or, as in man, covered by the posterior extension of its transverse fibers.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a trapezohedron.

entry.ety: NL., from trapezium + Gr. � seat, base, fr. � to sit
entry.def: A solid bounded by twenty-four equal and similar trapeziums; a tetragonal trisoctahedron. See the Note under Trisoctahedron.
A tetartohedral solid of the hexagonal system, bounded by six trapezoidal planes. The faces of this form are common on quartz crystals.

entry.ety: Gr. � trapezoid-shaped; � table + � shape, likeness: cf. F. trapézoïde. See Trapezium

sn.def: A plane four-sided figure, having two sides parallel to each other.
A bone of the carpus at the base of the second metacarpal, or index finger.
Having the form of a trapezoid; trapezoidal; as, the trapezoid ligament which connects the coracoid process and the clavicle.
Of or pertaining to the trapezoid ligament; as, the trapezoid line.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trapézoïdal

sn.def: Having the form of a trapezoid; trapezoid.
Trapezohedral.

entry.def: See Trou-de-loup.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trappéen. See Trap a kind of rock
entry.def: Of or pertaining to trap; being of the nature of trap.

entry.ety: From Trap to insnare

sn.def: One who traps animals; one who makes a business of trapping animals for their furs.
A boy who opens and shuts a trapdoor in a gallery or level.

entry.ety: From Trap to dress with ornaments

sn.def: That which serves to trap or adorn; ornaments; dress; superficial decorations.
sn.q: Trappings of life, for ornament, not use.
These but the trappings and the suits of woe.

sn.def: Specifically, ornaments to be put on horses.
sn.q: Caparisons and steeds, Bases and tinsel trappings.

entry.ety: F. trappiste
entry.def: A monk belonging to a branch of the Cistercian Order, which was established by Armand de Rancé in 1660 at the monastery of La Trappe in Normandy. Extreme austerity characterizes their discipline. They were introduced permanently into the United States in 1848, and have monasteries in Iowa and Kentucky.

entry.ety: From Trap a kind of rock
entry.def: Of or performance to trap; resembling trap, or partaking of its form or qualities; trappy.

entry.ety: See Trap to dress
entry.def: Trappings for a horse.
Same as Trappous.

entry.ety: See Trappings, and Trap to dress
entry.def: Small or portable articles for dress, furniture, or use; goods; luggage; things.

entries.entry:
Trap shooting
Trap shooter.. Sport Shooting at pigeons liberated, or glass balls or clay pigeons sprung into the air, from a trap.

entry.def: A stick used in playing the game of trapball; hence, fig., a slender leg.

entry.note: ☞ In the West Indies, the decayed leaves and stems of canes are called field trash; the bruised or macerated rind of canes is called cane trash; and both are called trash.

cs.cd: crumbled ice mixed with water.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. tros rubbish, leaves, and twigs picked up for fuel, trassi a slovenly fellow, Sw. trasa a rag, tatter

sn.def: That which is worthless or useless; rubbish; refuse.
sn.q: Who steals my purse steals trash.
A haunch of venison would be trash to a Brahmin.

sn.def: Especially, loppings and leaves of trees, bruised sugar cane, or the like.
A worthless person.
A collar, leash, or halter used to restrain a dog in pursuing game.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trashed; p. pr. & vb. n. Trashing

sn.def: To free from trash, or worthless matter; hence, to lop; to crop, as to trash the rattoons of sugar cane.
To treat as trash, or worthless matter; hence, to spurn, humiliate, or crush.
To hold back by a trash or leash, as a dog in pursuing game; hence, to retard, encumber, or restrain; to clog; to hinder vexatiously.

entry.def: To follow with violence and trampling.
In a trashy manner.
The quality or state of being trashy.
Like trash; containing much trash; waste; rejected; worthless; useless; as, a trashy novel.

entry.note: ☞ The Dutch trass is made by burning and grinding a soft grayish rock found on the lower Rhine.
entry.ety: D. tras or Gr. trass, probably fr. It. terrazzo terrace. See Terrace
entry.def: A white to gray volcanic tufa, formed of decomposed trachytic cinders; -- sometimes used as a cement. Hence, a coarse sort of plaster or mortar, durable in water, and used to line cisterns and other reservoirs of water.

entry.ety: Gr. � a lisping, fr. � to lisp, to mispronounce
entry.def: A stammering or stuttering.

entry.ety: L. traumaticus, Gr. �, from �, �, a wound: cf. F. traumatique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to wounds; applied to wounds.
Adapted to the cure of wounds; vulnerary.
Produced by wounds; as, traumatic tetanus.

def2.def: A traumatic medicine.

entry.def: A wound or injury directly produced by causes external to the body; also, violence producing a wound or injury; as, rupture of the stomach caused by traumatism .
See Trance.
Same as Trant.
Same as Tranter.

entry.ety: F. travail; cf. Pr. trabalh trebalh, toil, torment, torture; probably from LL. trepalium a place where criminals are tortured, instrument of torture. But the French word may be akin to L. trabs a beam, or have been influenced by a derivative from trabscf. Trave). Cf. Travel

sn.def: Labor with pain; severe toil or exertion.
sn.q: As everything of price, so this doth require travail.

sn.def: Parturition; labor; as, an easy travail .

entry.ety: Cf. F. travail, a frame for confining a horse, or OF. travail beam, and E. trave, n. Cf. Travail v. i.
entry.def: Same as Travois.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Travailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Travailing
entry.ety: F. travailler, OF. traveillier travaillier, to labor, toil, torment; cf. Pr. trebalhar to torment, agitate. See Travail n.

sn.def: To labor with pain; to toil.
sn.q: Slothful persons which will nottravailfor their livings.

sn.def: To suffer the pangs of childbirth; to be in labor.

entry.def: To harass; to tire.
entry.q: As if all these troubles had not been sufficient to travail the realm, a great division fell among the nobility.

entry.def: Causing travail; laborious.

entry.ety: Through French, fr. L. trabs trabis, a beam; cf. OF. tref a beam, also F. travail a frame to confine a horse, OE. trave trevys travise, It. travaglio, F. travée the space between two beams

sn.def: A crossbeam; a lay of joists.
A wooden frame to confine an unruly horse or ox while shoeing.
sn.q: She sprung as a colt doth in the trave.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Traveled or Travelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Traveling or Travelling
entry.ety: Properly, to labor, and the same word as travail

sn.def: To labor; to travail.
To go or march on foot; to walk; as, to travel over the city, or through the streets.
To pass by riding, or in any manner, to a distant place, or to many places; to journey; as, a man travels for his health; he is traveling in California.
To pass; to go; to move.
sn.q: Time travels in divers paces with divers persons.

sn.def: To journey over; to traverse; as, to travel the continent.
sn.q: Itravelthis profound.

sn.def: To force to journey.
sn.q: They shall not be traveled forth of their own franchises.

sn.def: The act of traveling, or journeying from place to place; a journey.
sn.q: With long travel I am stiff and weary.
His travels ended at his country seat.

sn.def: An account, by a traveler, of occurrences and observations during a journey; as, a book of travels ; -- often used as the title of a book; as, Travels in Italy.
The length of stroke of a reciprocating piece; as, the travel of a slide valve.
Labor; parturition; travail.

entry.def: Having made journeys; having gained knowledge or experience by traveling; hence, knowing; experienced.
entry.q: The traveled thane, Athenian Aberdeen.

entry.cs: Traveler's joy Bot the Clematis vitalba, a climbing plant with white flowers. Traveler's tree. Bot See Ravenala.
entry.ety: Written also traveler

sn.def: One who travels; one who has traveled much.
A commercial agent who travels for the purpose of receiving orders for merchants, making collections, etc.
A traveling crane. See under Crane.
The metal loop which travels around the ring surrounding the bobbin, in a ring spinner.
An iron encircling a rope, bar, spar, or the like, and sliding thereon.

entry.def: Harassed; fatigued with travel.

entry.ety: F. travers, breadth, extent from side, à travers en travers de travers, across, athwart. See Traverse a.
entry.def: Across; athwart.
entry.q: The earl . . . caused . . . high trees to be hewn down, and laid travers one over another.

sn.def: Capable of being traversed, or passed over; as, a traversable region.
Deniable; specifically Law, liable to legal objection; as, a traversable presentment.

cs.cd: a machine tool for drilling slots, in which the work or tool has a lateral motion back and forth; also, a drilling machine in which the spindle holder can be adjusted laterally.

entry.ety: OF. travers, L. transversus, p. p. of transvertere to turn or direct across. See Transverse, and cf. Travers
entry.def: Lying across; being in a direction across something else; as, paths cut with traverse trenches.
entry.q: Oak . . . being strong in all positions, may be better trusted in cross and traverse work.
The ridges of the fallow field traverse.

entry.def: Athwart; across; crosswise.

entry.cs:
To work a traverseorTo solve a traverse
Naut to reduce a series of courses or distances to an equivalent single one; to calculate the resultant of a traverse. Traverse board Naut a small board hung in the steerage, having the points of the compass marked on it, and for each point as many holes as there are half hours in a watch. It is used for recording the courses made by the ship in each half hour, by putting a peg in the corresponding hole. Traverse jury Law a jury that tries cases; a petit jury. Traverse sailing Naut a sailing by compound courses; the method or process of finding the resulting course and distance from a series of different shorter courses and distances actually passed over by a ship. Traverse table. Naut. & Surv A table by means of which the difference of latitude and departure corresponding to any given course and distance may be found by inspection. It contains the lengths of the two sides of a right-angled triangle, usually for every quarter of a degree of angle, and for lengths of the hypothenuse, from 1 to 100. Railroad A platform with one or more tracks, and arranged to move laterally on wheels, for shifting cars, etc., from one line of track to another.
entry.ety: F. traverse. See Traverse a.
entry.sn:
Anything that traverses, or crosses. Specifically: Something that thwarts, crosses, or obstructs; a cross accident; as, he would have succeeded, had it not been for unlucky traverses not under his control.
A barrier, sliding door, movable screen, curtain, or the like. Men drinken and the travers draw anon. And the entrance of the king, The first traverse was drawn.
Arch A gallery or loft of communication from side to side of a church or other large building.
Fort A work thrown up to intercept an enfilade, or reverse fire, along exposed passage, or line of work.
Law A formal denial of some matter of fact alleged by the opposite party in any stage of the pleadings. The technical words introducing a traverse are absque hoc, without this; that is, without this which follows.
Naut The zigzag course or courses made by a ship in passing from one place to another; a compound course.
Geom A line lying across a figure or other lines; a transversal.
Surv A line surveyed across a plot of ground.
Gun The turning of a gun so as to make it point in any desired direction.

sn.def: A turning; a trick; a subterfuge.

cs.cd: to brace it fore and aft.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Traversed; p. pr. & vb. n. Traversing
entry.ety: Cf. F. traverser. See Traverse a.

sn.def: To lay in a cross direction; to cross.
sn.q: The parts should be often traversed, or crossed, by the flowing of the folds.

sn.def: To cross by way of opposition; to thwart with obstacles; to obstruct; to bring to naught.
sn.q: I can not but . . . admit the force of this reasoning, which I yet hope to traverse.

sn.def: To wander over; to cross in traveling; as, to traverse the habitable globe.
sn.q: What seas you traversed, and what fields you fought.

sn.def: To pass over and view; to survey carefully.
sn.q: My purpose is to traverse the nature, principles, and properties of this detestable vice -- ingratitude.

sn.def: To turn to the one side or the other, in order to point in any direction; as, to traverse a cannon.
To plane in a direction across the grain of the wood; as, to traverse a board.

To deny formally, as what the opposite party has alleged. When the plaintiff or defendant advances new matter, he avers it to be true, and traverses what the other party has affirmed. To traverse an indictment or an office is to deny it.
sn.q: And save the expense of long litigious laws, Where suits are traversed, and so little won That he who conquers is but last undone.

sn.def: To use the posture or motions of opposition or counteraction, as in fencing.
sn.q: To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee traverse.

sn.def: To turn, as on a pivot; to move round; to swivel; as, the needle of a compass traverses; if it does not traverse well, it is an unsafe guide.
To tread or move crosswise, as a horse that throws his croup to one side and his head to the other.

entries.entry: Trav"erse drill. Mach A machine tool for drilling slots, in which the work or tool has a lateral motion back and forth; also, a drilling machine in which the spindle holder can be adjusted laterally.

sn.def: One who, or that which, traverses, or moves, as an index on a scale, and the like.
One who traverses, or denies.
A traverse table. See under Traverse n.

cs.cd: one of two thick iron plates at the hinder part of a gun carriage, where the handspike is applied in traversing the piece.
a platform for traversing guns.

entry.def: Adjustable laterally; having a lateral motion, or a swinging motion; adapted for giving lateral motion.

entry.ety: F. travertin, It. travertino tiburtino, L. lapis Tiburtinus, fr. Tibur an ancient town of Latium, now Tivoli
entry.def: A white concretionary form of calcium carbonate, usually hard and semicrystalline. It is deposited from the water of springs or streams holding lime in solution. Extensive deposits exist at Tivoli, near Rome.

entry.ety: F. travesti, p. p. of travestir to disguise, to travesty, It. travestire, fr. L. trans across, over + vestire to dress, clothe. See Vest
entry.def: Disguised by dress so as to be ridiculous; travestied; -- applied to a book or shorter composition.

entries.entry: Trav"es*ty n.; pl.Travesties. A burlesque translation or imitation of a work. The second edition is not a recast, but absolutely a travesty of the first.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Travestied; p. pr. & vb. n. Travesting
entry.def: To translate, imitate, or represent, so as to render ridiculous or ludicrous.
entry.q: I see poor Lucan travestied, not appareled in his Roman toga, but under the cruel shears of an English tailor.

entries.entry:
Tra`vois"‖n. Cf. Travail
A primitive vehicle, common among the North American Indians, usually two trailing poles serving as shafts and bearing a platform or net for a load. On the plains they will have horses dragging travoises; dogs with travoises, women and children loaded with impediments.
A logging sled. Northern U. S. & Canada

entry.ety: OF. trauler troller, F. trôter, to drag about, to stroll about; probably of Teutonic origin. Cf. Troll v. t.
entry.def: To take fish, or other marine animals, with a trawl.

sn.def: A fishing line, often extending a mile or more, having many short lines bearing hooks attached to it. It is used for catching cod, halibut, etc.; a boulter.
A large bag net attached to a beam with iron frames at its ends, and dragged at the bottom of the sea, -- used in fishing, and in gathering forms of marine life from the sea bottom.

entry.def: A boat used in fishing with trawls or trawlnets.

sn.def: One who, or that which, trawls.
A fishing vessel which trails a net behind it.

entries.entry: Trawl"er*man n.; pl.Trawlermen. A fisherman who used unlawful arts and engines to catch fish. Obs

entry.def: Same as Trawl n., 2.
A rope passing through a block, used in managing or dragging a trawlnet.

entry.ety: OF. traïr, F. trahir, L. tradere. See Traitor
entry.def: To betray; to deceive.

entries.entry:
Tray n.; pl.Trays #. OE. treye, AS. treg. Cf. Trough
A small trough or wooden vessel, sometimes scooped out of a block of wood, for various domestic uses, as in making bread, chopping meat, etc.
A flat, broad vessel on which dishes, glasses, etc., are carried; a waiter; a salver.
A shallow box, generally without a top, often used within a chest, trunk, box, etc., as a removable receptacle for small or light articles.
Tray"ful n.; pl.Trayfuls. As much as a tray will hold; enough to fill a tray.

entry.def: See Trais.

entry.ety: From Trey a three
entry.def: An old game played with dice.

entry.ety: OE. trichour trichur, OF. tricheor deceiver, traitor, F. tricheur a cheat at play, a trickster. See Treachery
entry.def: A traitor; a cheat.
entry.q: Treacher and coward both.

entry.ety: See Treacher
entry.def: Like a traitor; involving treachery; violating allegiance or faith pledged; traitorous to the state or sovereign; perfidious in private life; betraying a trust; faithless.
entry.q: Loyal father of a treacherous son.
The treacherous smile, a mask for secret hate.
entry.syn: Faithless; perfidious; traitorous; false; insidious; plotting.

entry.ety: OE. trecherïe trichere, OF. trecherie tricherie, F. tricherie trickery, from tricher to cheat, to trick, OF. trichier trechier; probably of Teutonic origin. See Trickery Trick
entry.def: Violation of allegiance or of faith and confidence; treasonable or perfidious conduct; perfidy; treason.
entry.q: Be ware, ye lords, of their treachery.
In the council chamber at Edinburgh, he had contracted a deep taint of treachery and corruption.

entry.ety: See Treacher
entry.def: A traitor.
entry.q: Treachourfull of false despite.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States molasses is the common name; in England, treacle.
entry.cs: Treacle mustard Bot a name given to several species of the cruciferous genus Erysimum, especially the Erysimum cheiranthoides, which was formerly used as an ingredient in Venice treacle, or theriac. Treacle water a compound cordial prepared in different ways from a variety of ingredients, as hartshorn, roots of various plants, flowers, juices of plants, wines, etc., distilled or digested with Venice treacle. It was formerly regarded as a medicine of great virtue. Nares. Venice treacle. Old Med Same as Theriac, 1.
entry.ety: OE. triacle a sovereign remedy, theriac, OF. triacle, F. thériaquecf. Pr. triacla tiriaca, Sp. & It. triaca teriaca), L. theriaca an antidote against the bite of poisonous animals, Gr. �, fr. � of wild or venomous beasts, fr. qhri`on a beast, a wild beast, dim. of qh`r a beast. Cf. Theriac

sn.def: A remedy against poison. See Theriac, 1.
sn.q: We kill the viper, and make treacle of him.

sn.def: A sovereign remedy; a cure.
sn.q: Christ which is to every harm treacle.

sn.def: Molasses; sometimes, specifically, the molasses which drains from the sugar-refining molds, and which is also called sugarhouse molasses.
A saccharine fluid, consisting of the inspissated juices or decoctions of certain vegetables, as the sap of the birch, sycamore, and the like.

entry.def: Like, or composed of, treacle.

entry.cs: To tread onorTo tread upon . To trample; to set the foot on in contempt. “Thou shalt tread upon their high places.” Deut. xxxiii. 29. to follow closely. “Year treads on year.” Wordsworth. To tread upon the heels of to follow close upon. “Dreadful consequences that tread upon the heels of those allowances to sin.” Milton.
entry.vmorph: imp. Trod; p. p. Trodden Trod; p. pr. & vb. n. Treading
entry.ety: OE. treden, AS. tredan; akin to OFries. treda, OS. tredan, D. & LG. treden, G. treten, OHG. tretan, Icel. tro�a, Sw. tråda träda, Dan. træde, Goth. trudan, and perhaps ultimately to F. tramp; cf. Gr. � a running, Skr. dram to run. Cf. Trade Tramp Trot

sn.def: To set the foot; to step.
sn.q: Where'er you tread, the blushing flowers shall rise.
Fools rush in where angels fear to tread.
The hard stone Under our feet, on which we tread and go.

sn.def: To walk or go; especially, to walk with a stately or a cautious step.
sn.q: Ye that . . . stately tread, or lowly creep.

sn.def: To copulate; said of birds, esp. the males.
sn.q: One woe doth tread upon another's heel.

cs.cd: to press out with the feet; to press out, as wine or wheat; as, to tread out grain with cattle or horses.
to act as a stageplayer; to perform a part in a drama.

sn.def: To step or walk on.
sn.q: Forbid to tread the promised land he saw.
Methought she trod the ground with greater grace.

sn.def: To beat or press with the feet; as, to tread a path; to tread land when too light; a well-trodden path.
To go through or accomplish by walking, dancing, or the like.
sn.q: I am resolved to forsake Malta,treada pilgrimage to fair Jerusalem.
They have measured many a mile, To tread a measure with you on this grass.

sn.def: To crush under the foot; to trample in contempt or hatred; to subdue.
sn.q: Through thy name will we tread them under that rise up against us.

sn.def: To copulate with; to feather; to cover; -- said of the male bird.
A step or stepping; pressure with the foot; a footstep; as, a nimble tread ; a cautious tread.
Manner or style of stepping; action; gait; as, the horse has a good tread .
Way; track; path.
The act of copulation in birds.
The upper horizontal part of a step, on which the foot is placed.
The top of the banquette, on which soldiers stand to fire over the parapet.

sd.def: The part of a wheel that bears upon the road or rail.
The part of a rail upon which car wheels bear.

sn.def: The chalaza of a bird's egg; the treadle.
A bruise or abrasion produced on the foot or ankle of a horse that interferes. See Interfere, 3.

entry.def: See Tread n., 5.
One who treads.
A cock.

entry.ety: OE. tredyl a step, AS. tredel. See Tread

sn.def: The part of a foot lathe, or other machine, which is pressed or moved by the foot.
The chalaza of a bird's egg; the tread.

entry.def: A mill worked by persons treading upon steps on the periphery of a wide wheel having a horizontal axis. It is used principally as a means of prison discipline. Also, a mill worked by horses, dogs, etc., treading an endless belt.
Spurge nettle. See under Nettle.
A wheel turned by persons or animals, by treading, climbing, or pushing with the feet, upon its periphery or face. See Treadmill.

entry.ety: It. tregua; of Teutonic origin, and akin to E. true
entry.def: A truce.

entry.note: ☞ In monarchies, the killing of the sovereign, or an attempt to take his life, is treason. In England, to imagine or compass the death of the king, or of the queen consort, or of the heir apparent to the crown, is high treason, as are many other offenses created by statute. In the United States, treason is confined to the actual levying of war against the United States, or to an adhering to their enemies, giving them aid and comfort.
entry.cs: Petit treason. See under Petit.
entry.ety: OE. tresun treisun traisoun, OF. traïson, F. trahison, L. traditio a giving up, a delivering up, fr. tradere to give up, betray. See Traitor, and cf. Tradition

sn.def: The offense of attempting to overthrow the government of the state to which the offender owes allegiance, or of betraying the state into the hands of a foreign power; disloyalty; treachery.
sn.q: The treason of the murthering in the bed.

sn.def: Loosely, the betrayal of any trust or confidence; treachery; perfidy.
sn.q: If he be false, she shall his treason see.

entry.def: Pertaining to treason; consisting of treason; involving the crime of treason, or partaking of its guilt.
entry.q: Most men's heads had been intoxicated with imaginations of plots and treasonable practices.

entry.def: Treasonable.
entry.q: The treasonous book of the Court of King James.

cs.cd: a city for stores and magazines.

entry.ety: OE. tresor tresour, F. trésor, L. thesaurus, Gr. � a stone laid up, treasure, probably from the root of � to put, place. See Thesis, and cf. Thesaurus

sn.def: Wealth accumulated; especially, a stock, or store of money in reserve.
sn.q: This treasure hath fortune unto us given.

sn.def: A great quantity of anything collected for future use; abundance; plenty.
sn.q: We have treasures in the field, of wheat and of barley, and of oil and of honey.

sn.def: That which is very much valued.
sn.q: Ye shall be peculiar treasure unto me.
From thy wardrobe bring thy chiefest treasure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Treasured; p. pr. & vb. n. Treasuring
entry.def: To collect and deposit, as money or other valuable things, for future use; to lay up; to hoard; usually with up; as, to treasure up gold.
A house or building where treasures and stores are kept.

cs.cd: formerly, the third great officer of the crown. His office is now executed by five persons styled the lords commissioners of the treasury, or treasury lords.

entry.ety: OE. tresourer, F. trésorier
entry.def: One who has the care of a treasure or treasure or treasury; an officer who receives the public money arising from taxes and duties, or other sources of revenue, takes charge of the same, and disburses it upon orders made by the proper authority; one who has charge of collected funds; as, the treasurer of a society or corporation.
The office of treasurer.
A woman who is a treasurer.

entry.ety: Treasure + OF. trové, F. trouvé, p. p. of OF. trover to find, F. trouver. See Trover
entry.def: Any money, bullion, or the like, found in the earth, or otherwise hidden, the owner of which is not known. In England such treasure belongs to the crown; whereas similar treasure found in the sea, or upon the surface of the land, belongs to the finder if no owner appears.

entries.entry:
Treas"ur*y
Board of treasury the board to which is intrusted the management of all matters relating to the sovereign's civil list or other revenues. Eng Brande & C. Treasury bench the first row of seats on the right hand of the Speaker in the House of Commons; -- so called because occupied by the first lord of the treasury and chief minister of the crown. Eng Treasury lord. See Lord high treasurer of England, under Treasurer. Eng Treasury note U. S. Finance a circulating note or bill issued by government authority from the Treasury Department, and receivable in payment of dues to the government.
n.; pl.Treasuries #. OE. tresorie, F. trésorerie
A place or building in which stores of wealth are deposited; especially, a place where public revenues are deposited and kept, and where money is disbursed to defray the expenses of government; hence, also, the place of deposit and disbursement of any collected funds.
That department of a government which has charge of the finances.
A repository of abundance; a storehouse.
Hence, a book or work containing much valuable knowledge, wisdom, wit, or the like; a thesaurus; as, “ Maunder's Treasury of Botany.”
A treasure. Obs
Treas"ur*y stock. Finance Issued stock of an incorporated company held by the company itself.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Treated; p. pr. & vb. n. Treating
entry.ety: OE. treten, OF. traitier, F. traiter, from L. tractare to draw violently, to handle, manage, treat, v. intens. from trahere tractum, to draw. See Trace v. t., and cf. Entreat Retreat Trait

sn.def: To handle; to manage; to use; to bear one's self toward; as, to treat prisoners cruelly; to treat children kindly.
To discourse on; to handle in a particular manner, in writing or speaking; as, to treat a subject diffusely.
To entertain with food or drink, especially the latter, as a compliment, or as an expression of friendship or regard; as, to treat the whole company.
To negotiate; to settle; to make terms for.
sn.q: To treat the peace, a hundred senators Shall be commissioned.

sn.def: To care for medicinally or surgically; to manage in the use of remedies or appliances; as, to treat a disease, a wound, or a patient.
To subject to some action; to apply something to; as, to treat a substance with sulphuric acid.
To entreat; to beseech.
To discourse; to handle a subject in writing or speaking; to make discussion; -- usually with of; as, Cicero treats of old age and of duties.
sn.q: And, shortly of this story for to treat.
Now of love they treat.

sn.def: To negotiate; to come to terms of accommodation; -- often followed by with; as, envoys were appointed to treat with France.
sn.q: Inform us, will the emperor treat!

sn.def: To give a gratuitous entertainment, esp. of food or drink, as a compliment.
A parley; a conference.
sn.q: Bid him battle without further treat.

sn.def: An entertainment given as an expression of regard.
That which affords entertainment; a gratification; a satisfaction; as, the concert was a rich treat .

entry.ety: OE. tretable, F. traitable, L. tractabilis. See Treat, and cf. Tractable
entry.def: Manageable; tractable; hence, moderate; not violent.
entry.q: Atreatabledisposition, a strong memory.
A kind of treatable dissolution.
The heats or the colds of seasons are less treatable than with us.

entry.def: In a treatable manner.
One who treats; one who handles, or discourses on, a subject; also, one who entertains.

entry.note: ☞ A treatise implies more form and method than an essay, but may fall short of the fullness and completeness of a systematic exposition.
entry.ety: OE. tretis, OF. treitis traitis, well made. See Treat

sn.def: A written composition on a particular subject, in which its principles are discussed or explained; a tract.
sn.q: He published a treatise in which he maintained that a marriage between a member of the Church of England and a dissenter was a nullity.

sn.def: Story; discourse.

entry.def: One who writes a treatise.

entry.ety: Cf. F. traitement. See Treat

sn.def: The act or manner of treating; management; manipulation; handling; usage; as, unkind treatment; medical treatment .
Entertainment; treat.
sn.q: Accept such treatment as a swain affords.

entry.def: Treatment.

entries.entry:
Trea"ty n.; pl.Treaties #. OE. tretee, F. traité, LL. tractatus; cf. L. tractatus a handling, treatment, consultation, tractate. See Treat, and cf. Tractate
The act of treating for the adjustment of differences, as for forming an agreement; negotiation. By sly and wisetreaty. He cast by treaty and by trains Her to persuade.
An agreement so made; specifically, an agreement, league, or contract between two or more nations or sovereigns, formally signed by commissioners properly authorized, and solemnly ratified by the several sovereigns, or the supreme power of each state; an agreement between two or more independent states; as, a treaty of peace; a treaty of alliance.
A proposal tending to an agreement. Obs
A treatise; a tract. Obs

entry.ety: OE. treble threefold, OF. treble treible, L. triplus. See Triple

sn.def: Threefold; triple.
sn.q: A lofty tower, and strong on every side With treble walls.

sd.def: Acute; sharp; as, a treble sound.
Playing or singing the highest part or most acute sounds; playing or singing the treble; as, a treble violin or voice.

entry.def: Trebly; triply.

entry.note: ☞ This is sometimes called the first treble, to distinguish it from the second treble, or alto, which is sung by lower female voices.
entry.ety: “ It has been said to be a corruption of triplumLat.], a third part, superadded to the altus and bassus (high and low).” Grove.
entry.def: The highest of the four principal parts in music; the part usually sung by boys or women; soprano.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trebled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trebling

sn.def: To make thrice as much; to make threefold.
sn.q: Lovetrebledlife.

sn.def: To utter in a treble key; to whine.
sn.q: He outrageouslyWhen I accused himtrebled his reply.

entry.def: To become threefold.
The quality or state of being treble; as, the trebleness of tones.
Same as Triblet.
In a treble manner; with a threefold number or quantity; triply.

entry.ety: OF. trebuchet trebukiet, an engine of war for hurling stones, F. trébuchet a gin, trap, a kind of balance, fr. OF. trebuchier trebuquier, to stumble, trip, F. trébucher

sn.def: A cucking stool; a tumbrel.

A military engine used in the Middle Ages for throwing stones, etc. It acted by means of a great weight fastened to the short arm of a lever, which, being let fall, raised the end of the long arm with great velocity, hurling stones with much force.
A kind of balance for weighing.

entry.def: A member of the trecento, or an imitator of its characteristics.

entry.ety: It., three hundred, abbr. for thirteen hundred
entry.def: The fourteenth century, when applied to Italian art, literature, etc. It marks the period of Dante, Petrarch, and boccaccio in literature, and of Giotto in painting.

entry.ety: Gr. � to run + -meter
entry.def: An odometer for vehicles.

entry.ety: D. trekschuit; trekken to draw + schuit a boat. Cf. Trackscout
entry.def: A covered boat for goods and passengers, used on the Dutch and Flemish canals.

entry.ety: See Treadle

sn.def: See Treadle.
A prostitute; a strumpet.
The dung of sheep or hares.

entry.def: A game at cards for three.

entry.note: ☞ The kind of tree referred to, in any particular case, is often indicated by a modifying word; as forest tree, fruit tree, palm tree, apple tree, pear tree, etc.
entry.cs: Tree bear Zoöl the raccoon. Local, U. S Tree beetle Zoöl any one of numerous species of beetles which feed on the leaves of trees and shrubs, as the May beetles, the rose beetle, the rose chafer, and the goldsmith beetle. Tree bug Zoöl any one of numerous species of hemipterous insects which live upon, and suck the sap of, trees and shrubs. They belong to Arma Pentatoma Rhaphigaster, and allied genera. Tree cat Zool the common paradoxure (Paradoxurus musang). Tree clover Bot a tall kind of melilot (Melilotus alba). See Melilot. Tree crab Zoöl the purse crab. See under Purse. Tree creeper Zoöl any one of numerous species of arboreal creepers belonging to Certhia Climacteris, and allied genera. See Creeper, 3. Tree cricket Zoöl a nearly white arboreal American cricket (Ecanthus nivœus) which is noted for its loud stridulation; -- called also white cricket. Tree crow Zoöl any one of several species of Old World crows belonging to Crypsirhina and allied genera, intermediate between the true crows and the jays. The tail is long, and the bill is curved and without a tooth. Tree dove Zoöl any one of several species of East Indian and Asiatic doves belonging to Macropygia and allied genera. They have long and broad tails, are chiefly arboreal in their habits, and feed mainly on fruit. Tree duck Zoöl any one of several species of ducks belonging to Dendrocygna and allied genera. These ducks have a long and slender neck and a long hind toe. They are arboreal in their habits, and are found in the tropical parts of America, Africa, Asia, and Australia. Tree fern Bot an arborescent fern having a straight trunk, sometimes twenty or twenty-five feet high, or even higher, and bearing a cluster of fronds at the top. Most of the existing species are tropical. Tree fish Zoöl a California market fish (Sebastichthys serriceps). Tree frog. Zoöl Same as Tree toad. Any one of numerous species of Old World frogs belonging to Chiromantis Rhacophorus, and allied genera of the family Ranidæ. Their toes are furnished with suckers for adhesion. The flying frog (see under Flying) is an example. Tree goose Zoöl the bernicle goose. Tree hopper Zoöl any one of numerous species of small leaping hemipterous insects which live chiefly on the branches and twigs of trees, and injure them by sucking the sap. Many of them are very odd in shape, the prothorax being often prolonged upward or forward in the form of a spine or crest. Tree jobber Zoöl a woodpecker. Obs Tree kangaroo. Zoöl See Kangaroo. Tree lark Zoöl the tree pipit. Prov. Eng Tree lizard Zoöl any one of a group of Old World arboreal lizards (Dendrosauria) comprising the chameleons. Tree lobster. Zoöl Same as Tree crab, above. Tree louse Zoöl any aphid; a plant louse. Tree moss. Bot Any moss or lichen growing on trees. Any species of moss in the form of a miniature tree. Tree mouse Zoöl any one of several species of African mice of the subfamily Dendromyinæ. They have long claws and habitually live in trees. Tree nymph a wood nymph. See Dryad.
