Tree of a saddle a saddle frame. Tree of heaven Bot an ornamental tree (Ailantus glandulosus) having long, handsome pinnate leaves, and greenish flowers of a disagreeable odor. Tree of life Bot a tree of the genus Thuja; arbor vitæ. Tree onion Bot a species of garlic (Allium proliferum) which produces bulbs in place of flowers, or among its flowers. Tree oyster Zoöl a small American oyster (Ostrea folium) which adheres to the roots of the mangrove tree; -- called also raccoon oyster. Tree pie Zoöl any species of Asiatic birds of the genus Dendrocitta. The tree pies are allied to the magpie. Tree pigeon Zoöl any one of numerous species of longwinged arboreal pigeons native of Asia, Africa, and Australia, and belonging to Megaloprepia Carpophaga, and allied genera. Tree pipit. Zoöl See under Pipit. Tree porcupine Zoöl any one of several species of Central and South American arboreal porcupines belonging to the genera Chætomys and Sphingurus. They have an elongated and somewhat prehensile tail, only four toes on the hind feet, and a body covered with short spines mixed with bristles. One South American species (Sphingurus villosus) is called also couiy; another (Sphingurus prehensilis) is called also cœndou. Tree rat Zoöl any one of several species of large ratlike West Indian rodents belonging to the genera Capromys and Plagiodon. They are allied to the porcupines. Tree serpent Zoöl a tree snake. Tree shrike Zoöl a bush shrike. Tree snake Zoöl any one of numerous species of snakes of the genus Dendrophis. They live chiefly among the branches of trees, and are not venomous. Tree sorrel Bot a kind of sorrel (Rumex Lunaria) which attains the stature of a small tree, and bears greenish flowers. It is found in the Canary Islands and Tenerife. Tree sparrow Zoöl any one of several species of small arboreal sparrows, especially the American tree sparrow (Spizella monticola), and the common European species (Passer montanus). Tree swallow Zoöl any one of several species of swallows of the genus Hylochelidon which lay their eggs in holes in dead trees. They inhabit Australia and adjacent regions. Called also martin in Australia. Tree swift Zoöl any one of several species of swifts of the genus Dendrochelidon which inhabit the East Indies and Southern Asia. Tree tiger Zoöl a leopard. Tree toad Zoöl any one of numerous species of amphibians belonging to Hyla and allied genera of the family Hylidæ. They are related to the common frogs and toads, but have the tips of the toes expanded into suckers by means of which they cling to the bark and leaves of trees. Only one species (Hyla arborea) is found in Europe, but numerous species occur in America and Australia. The common tree toad of the Northern United States (Hyla versicolor) is noted for the facility with which it changes its colors. Called also tree frog. See also Piping frog, under Piping, and Cricket frog, under Cricket. Tree warbler Zoöl any one of several species of arboreal warblers belonging to Phylloscopus and allied genera. Tree wool Bot a fine fiber obtained from the leaves of pine trees.
entry.ety: OE. tree tre treo, AS. treó treów, tree, wood; akin to OFries. trē, OS. treo trio, Icel. trē, Dan. træ, Sw. trä träd, Goth. triu, Russ. drevo, W. derw an oak, Ir. darag darog, Gr. dry^s a tree, oak, do`ry a beam, spear shaft, spear, Skr. dru tree, wood, dāru wood. √63, 241. Cf. Dryad Germander Tar n. Trough

sn.def: Any perennial woody plant of considerable size (usually over twenty feet high) and growing with a single trunk.
Something constructed in the form of, or considered as resembling, a tree, consisting of a stem, or stock, and branches; as, a genealogical tree .
A piece of timber, or something commonly made of timber; -- used in composition, as in axletree, boottree, chesstree, crosstree, whiffletree, and the like.
A cross or gallows; as Tyburn tree.
sn.q: Jesus] whom they slew and hanged on a tree.

sn.def: Wood; timber.
sn.q: In a great house ben not only vessels of gold and of silver but also of tree and of earth.

sn.def: A mass of crystals, aggregated in arborescent forms, obtained by precipitation of a metal from solution. See Lead tree, under Lead.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Treed; p. pr. & vb. n. Treeing

sn.def: To drive to a tree; to cause to ascend a tree; as, a dog trees a squirrel.
To place upon a tree; to fit with a tree; to stretch upon a tree; as, to tree a boot. See Tree n., 3.

entry.def: A pendulous branching lichen (Usnea barbata); -- so called from its resemblance to hair.

entries.entry: Tree burial. Disposal of the dead by placing the corpse among the branches of a tree or in a hollow trunk, a practice among many primitive peoples.
Tree calf. A bright brown polished calfskin binding of books, stained with a conventional treelike design.
Tree"ful n.; pl.Treefuls. The quantity or number which fills a tree.

entry.def: Destitute of trees.

entry.ety: AS. treówen

sn.def: Made of wood; wooden.
sn.q: Treencups.

sn.def: Relating to, or drawn from, trees.
sn.q: Treen liquors, especially that of the date.

entry.def: pl. of Tree.
entry.q: The shadytreen.

entry.ety: Tree + nail
entry.def: A long wooden pin used in fastening the planks of a vessel to the timbers or to each other.

entry.ety: Yiddish, fr. Heb. tĕrēphāh an animal torn by wild beasts
entry.def: Ceremonially unclean, according to the Jewish law; -- opposed to kosher.

entry.ety: F. tréfle. See Trefoil
entry.def: A species of time; -- so called from its resemblance in form to a trefoil.

entry.ety: F. tréflé. See Trefoil
entry.def: Having a three-lobed extremity or extremities, as a cross; also, more rarely, ornamented with trefoils projecting from the edges, as a bearing.

entry.ety: L. tres three + E. foil leaf; cf. F. frèfle, It. trifoglio, L. trifolium. See Tri- Foil leaf, and cf. Trifoly

sn.def: Any plant of the genus Trifolium, which includes the white clover, red clover, etc.; -- less properly, applied also to the nonesuch, or black medic. See Clover, and Medic.
An ornamental foliation consisting of three divisions, or foils.
A charge representing the clover leaf.

entry.def: Same as Tréflé.

entry.ety: See Tregetour
entry.def: Guile; trickery.

entry.ety: OE. tresgeteor. See Trans-, and Jet a shooting forth
entry.def: A juggler who produces illusions by the use of elaborate machinery.
entry.q: Divers appearances Such as these subtle tregetours play.

entry.def: Trickery; also, a trick.

An amorphous variety of manna obtained from the nests and cocoons of a Syrian coleopterous insect (Larinus maculatus Larinus nidificans, etc.) which feeds on the foliage of a variety of thistle. It is used as an article of food, and is called also nest sugar.
Mycose; -- so called because sometimes obtained from trehala.

entry.ety: F. treillage. See Trellis
entry.def: Latticework for supporting vines, etc.; an espalier; a trellis.
entry.q: I shall plant the roses against my treillage to-morrow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trekked; p. pr. & vb. n. Trekking
entry.ety: D. trekken. See Track n.

sn.def: To draw or haul a load, as oxen.
To travel, esp. by ox wagon; to go from place to place; to migrate.
sn.q: One of the motives which induced the Boers of 1836 to trek out of the Colony.

cs.cd: the great emigration of Boers from Cape Colony which began in 1836, and resulted in the founding of the South African Republic and Orange Free State.

entry.ety: D. Cf. Track n.
entry.def: The act of trekking; a drawing or a traveling; a journey; a migration.
entry.q: To the north a trek was projected, and some years later was nearly carried out, for the occupation of the Mashonaland.

entry.ety: D
entry.def: One that treks.

entry.ety: Cf. Trechometer
entry.def: A field range finger used in the British service.

entry.ety: OE. relis, F. treillis, fr. treille vine arbor, fr. L. tricla triclea triclia, a bower, arbor, summer house
entry.def: A structure or frame of crossbarred work, or latticework, used for various purposes, as for screens or for supporting plants.
Having a trellis or trellises.
entry.q: Cottages trellised over with exotic plants.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Trembling; -- used as a direction to perform a passage with a general shaking of the whole chord.
One of the Trematodea. Also used adjectively.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � having holes, from �, �, a hole
entry.def: An extensive order of parasitic worms. They are found in the internal cavities of animals belonging to all classes. Many species are found, also, on the gills and skin of fishes. A few species are parasitic on man, and some, of which the fluke is the most important, are injurious parasites of domestic animals. The trematodes usually have a flattened body covered with a chitinous skin, and are furnished with two or more suckers for adhesion. Most of the species are hermaphrodite. Called also Trematoda, and Trematoidea. See Fluke Tristoma, and Cercaria.

entry.ety: From Gr. �, �, a hole + e'i^dos form
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Trematodea. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trembled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trembling
entry.ety: F. trembler, fr. L. tremulus trembling, tremulous, fr. tremere to shake, tremble; akin to Gr. �, Lith. trimti. Cf. Tremulous Tremor

sn.def: To shake involuntarily, as with fear, cold, or weakness; to quake; to quiver; to shiver; to shudder; -- said of a person or an animal.
sn.q: I tremble still with fear.
Frighted Turnus trembled as he spoke.

sn.def: To totter; to shake; -- said of a thing.
sn.q: The Mount of Sinai, whose gray top Shall tremble.

sn.def: To quaver or shake, as sound; to be tremulous; as the voice trembles.

entry.def: An involuntary shaking or quivering.
entry.q: I am all of a tremble when I think of it.

entry.def: One who trembles.

sn.def: Any of certain West Indian birds of the genera Cinclocerthia and Rhamphocinclus, of the family Mimidæ.
The vibrating hammer, or spring contact piece of a hammer break, as of the electric ignition apparatus for an internal-combustion engine.

cs.cd: the aspen.

entry.def: Shaking; tottering; quivering.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. tremere, to tremble: cf. It. tremella, F. tremelle
entry.def: A genus of gelatinous fungi found in moist grounds.

entry.ety: L. tremendus that is to be trembled at, fearful, fr. tremere to tremble. See Tremble
entry.def: Fitted to excite fear or terror; such as may astonish or terrify by its magnitude, force, or violence; terrible; dreadful; as, a tremendous wind; a tremendous shower; a tremendous shock or fall.
entry.q: A tremendous mischief was a foot.
entry.syn: Terrible; dreadful; frightful; terrific; horrible; awful.

entry.note: ☞ The pigeon tremex (Tremex columba), a common American species, infests the elm, pear, and other trees.
entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of large hymenopterous insects allied to the sawflies. The female lays her eggs in holes which she bores in the trunks of trees with her large and long ovipositor, and the larva bores in the wood. See Illust. of Horntail.

entry.ety: F. trémie hopper
entry.def: An apparatus for depositing and consolidating concrete under water, essentially a tube of wood or sheet metal with a hooperlike top. It is usually handled by a crane.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Same as Tremando.

entry.ety: From Tremola, a valley in the Alps, where it was discovered
entry.def: A white variety of amphibole, or hornblende, occurring in long, bladelike crystals, and coarsely fibrous masses.

entry.ety: It. Cf. Tremulous
entry.def: The rapid reiteration of tones without any apparent cessation, so as to produce a tremulous effect.
A certain contrivance in an organ, which causes the notes to sound with rapid pulses or beats, producing a tremulous effect; -- called also tremolant, and tremulant.

entry.ety: L., from tremere to tremble. See Tremble v.
entry.def: A trembling; a shivering or shaking; a quivering or vibratory motion; as, the tremor of a person who is weak, infirm, or old.
entry.q: He fell into an universal tremor of all his joints.

entry.def: Tremulous; trembling; shaking.
entry.q: Withtremulentwhite rod.

entry.ety: L. tremulus, fr. tremere to tremble. See Tremble

sn.def: Shaking; shivering; quivering; as, a tremulous limb; a tremulous motion of the hand or the lips; the tremulous leaf of the poplar.
Affected with fear or timidity; trembling.
sn.q: The tender, tremulous Christian.

entry.ety: See Treen wooden
entry.def: A fish spear.
Same as Treenail.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trenched; p. pr. & vb. n. Trenching
entry.ety: OF. trenchier to cut, F. trancher; akin to Pr. trencar trenchar, Sp. trinchar, It. trinciare; of uncertain origin

sn.def: To cut; to form or shape by cutting; to make by incision, hewing, or the like.
sn.q: The wide wound that the boar had trenched In his soft flank.
This weak impress of love is as a figureTrenched in ice, which with an hour's heat Dissolves to water, and doth lose its form.

sn.def: To fortify by cutting a ditch, and raising a rampart or breastwork with the earth thrown out of the ditch; to intrench.
sn.q: No more shall trenching war channel her fields.

sn.def: To cut furrows or ditches in; as, to trench land for the purpose of draining it.
To dig or cultivate very deeply, usually by digging parallel contiguous trenches in succession, filling each from the next; as, to trench a garden for certain crops.

cs.cd: to make trenches against; to approach by trenches, as a town in besieging it.

sn.def: To encroach; to intrench.
sn.q: Does it not seem as if for a creature to challenge to itself a boundless attribute, were to trench upon the prerogative of the divine nature?

sn.def: To have direction; to aim or tend.
sn.q: Like powerful armies, trenching at a town By slow and silent, but resistless, sap.

cs.cd: to begin to dig or to form the lines of approach.
an elevation constructed (by a besieger) of gabions, fascines, earth, and the like, about half way up the glacis, in order to discover and enfilade the covered way.
a kind of plow for opening land to a greater depth than that of common furrows.

entry.ety: OE. trenche, F. tranchée. See Trench v. t.

sn.def: A long, narrow cut in the earth; a ditch; as, a trench for draining land.
An alley; a narrow path or walk cut through woods, shrubbery, or the like.
sn.q: In a trench, forth in the park, goeth she.

sn.def: An excavation made during a siege, for the purpose of covering the troops as they advance toward the besieged place. The term includes the parallels and the approaches.

entry.def: Trenchant.

entry.ety: OF. trenchant, F. tranchant, p. pr. See Trench v. t.

sn.def: Fitted to trench or cut; gutting; sharp.
sn.q: Trenchantwas the blade.

sn.def: Fig.: Keen; biting; severe; as, trenchant wit.

entry.def: In a trenchant, or sharp, manner; sharply; severely.

cs.cd: the cap worn by studens at Oxford and Cambridge Universities, having a stiff, flat, square appendage at top. A similar cap used in the United States is called Oxford cap mortar board, etc.
a person who haunts the tables of others; a parasite.
one who frequents the tables of others; a sponger.
a table companion; a parasite; a trencher fly.

entry.ety: OE. trencheoir, F. tranchoir, fr. trancher to cut, carve. See Trench v. t.

sn.def: One who trenches; esp., one who cuts or digs ditches.
A large wooden plate or platter, as for table use.
The table; hence, the pleasures of the table; food.
sn.q: It could be no ordinary declension of nature that could bring some men, after an ingenuous education, to place their “summum bonum” upon their trenchers.

entries.entry:
Trench"er-man n.; pl.Trencher-men.
A feeder; a great eater; a gormandizer.
A cook. Obs The skillfulest trencher-men of Media.
A table companion; a trencher mate.

entry.def: A kind of lively dance of a rude, boisterous character. Also, music in triple time appropriate to the dance.
entry.q: All the windows in the town dance new trenchmore.

entry.def: To dance the trenchmore.
To plow with deep furrows, for the purpose of loosening the land to a greater depth than usual.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trended; p. pr. & vb. n. Trending
entry.ety: OE. trenden to roll or turn about; akin to OFries. trind trund, round, Dan. & Sw. trind, AS. trendel a circle, ring, and E. trendle trundle
entry.def: To have a particular direction; to run; to stretch; to tend; as, the shore of the sea trends to the southwest.
To cause to turn; to bend.
entry.q: Not far beneath i' the valley as she trends Her silver stream.

entry.cs: Trend of an anchor. Naut The lower end of the shank of an anchor, being the same distance on the shank from the throat that the arm measures from the throat to the bill. R. H. Dana, Jr. The angle made by the line of a vessel's keel and the direction of the anchor cable, when she is swinging at anchor.
entry.def: Inclination in a particular direction; tendency; general direction; as, the trend of a coast.

entry.ety: Cf. G. & OD. trennen to separate
entry.def: To cleanse, as wool.
Clean wool.
One whose business is to free wool from its filth.

entry.ety: AS. trendel tryndel, circle, ring. See Trend v. i., and cf. Trundle
entry.def: A wheel, spindle, or the like; a trundle.
entry.q: The shaft the wheel, the wheel, the trendle turns.

entry.def: Corrupt form of Treenail.

entry.ety: LL. trentale, fr. L. triginta thirty; akin to tres three: cf. OF. trentel. See Three, and cf. Trigintal

sn.def: An office and mass for the dead on the thirtieth day after death or burial.
sn.q: Theirtrentalsand their shrifts.

sn.def: Hence, a dirge; an elegy.

entries.entry: Trente" et` qua`rante" Trente" et` qua`rante". F., lit., thirty and forty Same as Rouge et noir, under Rouge.

Tren"ton pe"ri*od. Geol A subdivision in the lower Silurian system of America; -- so named from Trenton Falls, in New York. The rocks are mostly limestones, and the period is divided into the Trenton Utica, and Cincinnati epochs. See the Chart of Geology.

entry.ety: F. trépancf. Sp. trépano, It. trepano trapano), LL. trepanum, fr. Gr. � a borer, auger, trepan, fr. � to bore, � a hole. Cf. Trephine

sn.def: A crown-saw or cylindrical saw for perforating the skull, turned, when used, like a bit or gimlet. See Trephine.
A kind of broad chisel for sinking shafts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trepanned; p. pr. & vb. n. Trepanning
entry.ety: Cf. F. trépaner. See Trepan a saw
entry.def: To perforate (the skull) with a trepan, so as to remove a portion of the bone, and thus relieve the brain from pressure or irritation; to perform an operation with the trepan.

entry.ety: See Trapan

sn.def: A snare; a trapan.
sn.q: Snares and trepans that common life lays in its way.

sn.def: a deceiver; a cheat.
sn.q: He had been from the beginning a spy and a trepan.

entry.def: To insnare; to trap; to trapan.
entry.q: Guards even of a dozen men were silently trepanned from their stations.

entry.note: ☞ The edible trepangs are mostly large species of Holothuria, especially Holothuria edulis. They are taken in vast quantities in the East Indies, where they are dried and smoked, and then shipped to China. They are used as an ingredient in certain kinds of soup.
entry.ety: Malay trīpang
entry.def: Any one of several species of large holothurians, some of which are dried and extensively used as food in China; -- called also bêche de mer sea cucumber, and sea slug.
To trepan.
entry.q: Bytrepanizingthe skull.

entry.def: One who trepans.
entry.q: Pitifultrepannersand impostors.

entry.def: A trebuchet.

entry.ety: A dim. of 1st trepan: cf. F. tréphine
entry.def: An instrument for trepanning, being an improvement on the trepan. It is a circular or cylindrical saw, with a handle like that of a gimlet, and a little sharp perforator called the center pin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trephined; p. pr. & vb. n. Trephining
entry.def: To perforate with a trephine; to trepan.

entry.ety: L. trepidus
entry.def: Trembling; quaking.

entry.ety: F. trépidation, L. trepidatio, fr. trepidare to hurry with alarm, to tremble, from trepidus agitated, disturbed, alarmed; cf. trepit he turns, Gr. � to turn, E. torture

sn.def: An involuntary trembling, sometimes an effect of paralysis, but usually caused by terror or fear; quaking; quivering.
Hence, a state of terror or alarm; fear; confusion; fright; as, the men were in great trepidation .
A libration of the starry sphere in the Ptolemaic system; a motion ascribed to the firmament, to account for certain small changes in the position of the ecliptic and of the stars.
sn.syn: Tremor; agitation; disturbance; fear.

entry.def: Trepidation.

cs.cd: a writ which lay for a man claiming as heir to his grandfather's grandfather, to recover lands of which he had been deprived by an abatement happening on the ancestor's death.

entry.ety: F. trisaïeul, from L. tris tres, three + F. aïeul grandfather. Cf. Besaiel, and see Ayle
entry.def: A grandfather's grandfather.
Treasure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trespassed; p. pr. & vb. n. Trespassing
entry.ety: OF. trespasser to go across or over, transgress, F. trépasser to die; pref. tres-L. trans across, over) + passer to pass. See Pass v. i., and cf. Transpass

sn.def: To pass beyond a limit or boundary; hence, to depart; to go.
sn.q: Soon after this, noble Robert de Bruce . . . trespassed out of this uncertain world.

sn.def: To commit a trespass; esp., to enter unlawfully upon the land of another.
To go too far; to put any one to inconvenience by demand or importunity; to intrude; as, to trespass upon the time or patience of another.

To commit any offense, or to do any act that injures or annoys another; to violate any rule of rectitude, to the injury of another; hence, in a moral sense, to transgress voluntarily any divine law or command; to violate any known rule of duty; to sin; -- often followed by against.
sn.q: In the time of his distress did he trespass yet more against the Lord.

entry.cs: Trespass offering Jewish Antiq an offering in expiation of a trespass. Trespass on the case. Law See Action on the case, under Case.
entry.ety: OF. trespas, F. trépas death. See Trespass v.

sn.def: Any injury or offence done to another.
sn.q: I you forgive all wholly this trespass.
If ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses.

sn.def: Any voluntary transgression of the moral law; any violation of a known rule of duty; sin.
sn.q: The fatal trespass done by Eve.
You . . . who were dead in trespasses and sins.

sd.def: An unlawful act committed with force and violence (vi et armis) on the person, property, or relative rights of another.
An action for injuries accompanied with force.
sd.syn: Offense; breach; infringement; transgression; misdemeanor; misdeed.

entries.entry: Tres"pass*er n. One who commits a trespass; as: Law One who enters upon another's land, or violates his rights. A transgressor of the moral law; an offender; a sinner.

entry.ety: OE. tresse, OF. trece, F. tresse, LL. tricia, fr. Gr. tri`cha threefold, because a tress is usually formed by interlacing three pieces; akin to trei^s three. See Three

sn.def: A braid, knot, or curl, of hair; a ringlet.
sn.q: Her yellow hair was braided in a tress.
Fair tresses man's imperial race insnare.

sn.def: Fig.: A knot or festoon, as of flowers.
Having tresses.
Formed into ringlets or braided; braided; curled.

entry.def: A trestle.
Tressy.

entry.ety: F. tresser to twist, plait. See Tress n.
entry.def: A kind of border similar to the orle, but of only half the breadth of the latter.
Provided or bound with a tressure; arranged in the form of a tressure.
entry.q: The tressured fleur-de-lis he claims To wreathe his shield.

entry.def: Abounding in tresses.

entry.ety: Cf. L. tris tres, three, and E. tyne tine, a prong
entry.def: The third tine above the base of a stag's antler; the royal antler.

entry.cs: Trestle board a board used by architects, draughtsmen, and the like, for drawing designs upon; -- so called because commonly supported by trestles. Trestle bridge. See under Bridge n.
entry.ety: OF. trestel tresteay, F. tréteau; probably from L. transtillum a little crossbeam, dim. of transtrum a crossbeam. Cf. Transom

sn.def: A movable frame or support for anything, as scaffolding, consisting of three or four legs secured to a top piece, and forming a sort of stool or horse, used by carpenters, masons, and other workmen; also, a kind of framework of strong posts or piles, and crossbeams, for supporting a bridge, the track of a railway, or the like.
The frame of a table.

entry.def: One of two strong bars of timber, fixed horizontally on the opposite sides of the masthead, to support the crosstrees and the frame of the top; -- generally used in the plural.
A viaduct, pier, scaffold, or the like, resting on trestles connected together.

entry.ety: L. tris tres, three + E. tyne
entry.def: In the antler of a stag, the third tyne above the base. This tyne appears in the third year. In those deer in which the brow tyne does not divide, the tres-tyne is the second tyne above the base. See Illust. under Rucervine, and under Rusine.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Tread, for treadeth.

entry.ety: F. traite a drawing, trading, journey, tax on wares in transit, anything diminishing the value of coins, fr. OF. traire to draw, L. trahere. See Trait
entry.def: An allowance to purchasers, for waste or refuse matter, of four pounds on every 104 pounds of suttle weight, or weight after the tare deducted.

entry.ety: See Treatable
entry.def: Tractable; moderate.
entry.q: By nature debonaire and tretable.

entry.ety: W. treth an allowance, contribution, tribute, or tax, trethu to rate or tax
entry.def: A tax; an impost.

entry.ety: See Treatise
entry.def: A treatise; also, a treaty.

entry.ety: OF. traitis
entry.def: Long and well-proportioned; nicely made; pretty.
entry.q: Her nosetretys.

entry.def: A weaver's cutting instrument; for severing the loops of the pile threads of velvet.

entry.ety: See Trivet
entry.def: A stool or other thing supported by three legs; a trivet.
True.
Trowsers; especially, those of the Scotch Highlanders.
entry.q: He wore thetrews, or close trowsers, made of tartan.

entry.def: Truth.

entry.ety: OF. treis three, F. trois, L. tres. See Three, and cf. Tray-trip
entry.def: Three, at cards, dice, or dominoes; a card, die, or domino of three spots or pips.
entry.q: Seven is my chance and thine is cinq and trey.

entries.entry:
Tri-. Gr. tri- or L. tri-, sometimes through French; akin to L. tres three, and E. three. See Three
A prefix meaning three thrice threefold; as in tricolored, tridentate.
Chem A prefix (also used adjectively) denoting three proportional or combining part, or the third degree of that to the name of which it is prefixed; as in trisulphide, trioxide, trichloride.

entry.ety: From Try

sn.def: Fit or possible to be tried; liable to be subjected to trial or test.
sn.q: Experimentstriable.

sn.def: Liable to undergo a judicial examination; properly coming under the cognizance of a court; as, a cause may be triable before one court which is not triable in another.

entry.def: Quality or state of being triable.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + acid
entry.def: Capable of neutralizing three molecules of a monobasic acid or the equivalent; having three hydrogen atoms which may be acid radicals; -- said of certain bases; thus, glycerin is a triacid base.
See Treacle.

entry.ety: Gr. � thirty + � seat, base
entry.def: Having thirty sides.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � thirty
entry.def: A vessel with thirty banks of oars, or, as some say, thirty ranks of rowers.

entry.cs: Triads of the Welsh bards poetical histories, in which the facts recorded are grouped by threes, three things or circumstances of a kind being mentioned together. Hindu triad. See Trimurti.
entry.ety: L. trias -adis, Gr. �, �, fr.�, �, three: cf. F. triade. See Three, and cf. Trias Trio

sn.def: A union of three; three objects treated as one; a ternary; a trinity; as, a triad of deities.

sd.def: A chord of three notes.
The common chord, consisting of a tone with its third and fifth, with or without the octave.

sn.def: An element or radical whose valence is three.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � brother
entry.def: Having stamens joined by filaments into three bundles. See Illust. under Adelphous.
Having the characteristics of a triad; as, boron is triadic .

entry.ety: Gr. � thrice + E. octahedron
entry.def: A trigonal trisoctahedron.

entry.ety: From Try
entry.sn:
The act of trying or testing in any manner. Specifically: Any effort or exertion of strength for the purpose of ascertaining what can be done or effected. I] defy thee to the trial of mortal fight.
The act of testing by experience; proof; test. Repeated trials of the issues and events of actions.
Examination by a test; experiment, as in chemistry, metallurgy, etc.

sn.def: The state of being tried or tempted; exposure to suffering that tests strength, patience, faith, or the like; affliction or temptation that exercises and proves the graces or virtues of men.
sn.q: Others had trial of cruel mockings and scourgings.

sn.def: That which tries or afflicts; that which harasses; that which tries the character or principles; that which tempts to evil; as, his child's conduct was a sore trial .
sn.q: Every station is exposed to some trials.

sn.def: The formal examination of the matter in issue in a cause before a competent tribunal; the mode of determining a question of fact in a court of law; the examination, in legal form, of the facts in issue in a cause pending before a competent tribunal, for the purpose of determining such issue.
sn.syn: Test; attempt; endeavor; effort; experiment; proof; essay. See Test, and Attempt.

entry.def: The method of discovering something desirable by trying many different things until one works; as, the traditional method of finding new drugs is by trial and error .
entry.q: And millions miss for one that hits.

entries.entry: Tri"al bal`ance. Bookkeeping The testing of a ledger to discover whether the debits and credits balance, by finding whether the sum of the personal credits increased by the difference between the debit and credit sums in the merchandise and other impersonal accounts equals the sum of personal debits. The equality would not show that the items were all correctly posted.

entry.ety: L. tres tria, three
entry.def: Three united; state of being three.

entry.ety: LL. trialogus; tri-see Tri-) + -logus as, in L. dialogus, E. dialogue
entry.def: A discourse or colloquy by three persons.

entry.ety: tri- + amine
entry.def: An amide containing three amido groups.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + amine
entry.def: An amine containing three amido groups.
Any one of the Triandria.

entry.ety: NL. See Tri-, and -androus
entry.def: A Linnæan class of plants having three distinct and equal stamens.

entry.ety: Cf. F. triandre
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Triandria; having three distinct and equal stamens in the same flower.

entry.note: ☞ A triangle is either plane spherical or curvilinear, according as its sides are straight lines, or arcs of great circles of a sphere, or any curved lines whatever. A plane triangle is designated as scalene isosceles or equilateral, according as it has no two sides equal, two sides equal, or all sides equal; and also as right-angled, or oblique-angled, according as it has one right angle, or none; and oblique-angled triangle is either acute-angled, or obtuse-angled, according as all the angles are acute, or one of them obtuse. The terms scalene isosceles equilateral right-angled acute-angled, and obtuse-angled, are applied to spherical triangles in the same sense as to plane triangles.

cs.cd: a small American spider (Hyptiotes Americanus) of the family Ciniflonidæ, living among the dead branches of evergreen trees. It constructs a triangular web, or net, usually composed of four radii crossed by a double elastic fiber. The spider holds the thread at the apex of the web and stretches it tight, but lets go and springs the net when an insect comes in contact with it.

entry.ety: L. triangulum, fr. triangulus triangular; tri-see Tri-) + angulus angle: cf. F. triangle. See Angle a corner

sn.def: A figure bounded by three lines, and containing three angles.
An instrument of percussion, usually made of a rod of steel, bent into the form of a triangle, open at one angle, and sounded by being struck with a small metallic rod.
A draughtsman's square in the form of a right-angled triangle.
A kind of frame formed of three poles stuck in the ground and united at the top, to which soldiers were bound when undergoing corporal punishment, -- now disused.

sd.def: A small constellation situated between Aries and Andromeda.
A small constellation near the South Pole, containing three bright stars.

entry.def: Having three angles; triangular.

cs.cd: compasses with three legs for taking off the angular points of a triangle, or any three points at the same time.
any maioid crab; -- so called because the carapace is usually triangular.
the series of numbers formed by the successive sums of the terms of an arithmetical progression, of which the first term and the common difference are 1. See Figurate numbers, under Figurate.

entry.ety: L. triangularis: cf. F. triangulaire

sn.def: Having three angles; having the form of a triangle.
Oblong or elongated, and having three lateral angles; as, a triangular seed, leaf, or stem.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: The triangular, or maioid, crabs. See Illust. under Maioid, and Illust. of Spider crab, under Spider.
The quality or state of being triangular.
In a triangular manner; in the form of a triangle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Triangulated; p. pr. & vb. n. Triangulating

sn.def: To divide into triangles; specifically, to survey by means of a series of triangles properly laid down and measured.
To make triangular, or three-cornered.

entry.ety: Cf. F. triangulation
entry.def: The series or network of triangles into which the face of a country, or any portion of it, is divided in a trigonometrical survey; the operation of measuring the elements necessary to determine the triangles into which the country to be surveyed is supposed to be divided, and thus to fix the positions and distances of the several points connected by them.

entries.entry: Tri"ar*chy n.; pl.Triarchies #. Gr. �; � (see Tri-) + � to rule Government by three persons; a triumvirate; also, a country under three rulers.

entry.ety: L. triarii pl., a class of Roman soldiers who formed the third rank from the front, fr. tres tria, three
entry.def: Occupying the third post or rank.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + articulate
entry.def: Having three joints.

entry.ety: L., triad. See Triad
entry.def: The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and so named by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata, which are called in German the Bunter sandstein Muschelkalk, and Keuper.
Of the age of, or pertaining to, the Trias.

def2.def: The Triassic formation.

entry.def: A term used in the phrase triatic stay. See under Stay.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + atomic
entry.def: Having three atoms; -- said of certain elements or radicals.
Having a valence of three; trivalent; sometimes, in a specific sense, having three hydroxyl groups, whether acid or basic; thus, glycerin, glyceric acid, and tartronic acid are each triatomic .
Of or pertaining to a tribe or tribes; as, a tribal scepter.
The state of existing in tribes; also, tribal feeling; tribal prejudice or exclusiveness; tribal peculiarities or characteristics.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + basic
entry.def: Capable of neutralizing three molecules of a monacid base, or their equivalent; having three hydrogen atoms capable of replacement by basic elements on radicals; -- said of certain acids; thus, citric acid is a tribasic acid.
A frame on which paper is dried.

entry.note: ☞ By many recent naturalists, tribe has been used for a group of animals or plants intermediate between order and genus.
entry.ety: L. tribus, originally, a third part of the Roman people, afterwards, a division of the people, a tribe; of uncertain origin: cf. F. tribu

sn.def: A family, race, or series of generations, descending from the same progenitor, and kept distinct, as in the case of the twelve tribes of Israel, descended from the twelve sons of Jacob.
sn.q: The Lion of thetribeof Juda.
A wealthy Hebrew of my tribe.

sn.def: A number of species or genera having certain structural characteristics in common; as, a tribe of plants; a tribe of animals.
A nation of savages or uncivilized people; a body of rude people united under one leader or government; as, the tribes of the Six Nations; the Seneca tribe .
A division, class, or distinct portion of a people, from whatever cause that distinction may have originated; as, the city of Athens was divided into ten tribes .
A family of animals descended from some particular female progenitor, through the female line; as, the Duchess tribe of shorthorns.

entry.def: To distribute into tribes or classes.
entry.q: Our fowl, fish, and quadruped are well tribed.

entry.ety: F. triboulet

sn.def: A goldsmith's tool used in making rings.
A steel cylinder round which metal is drawn in the process of forming tubes.
A tapering mandrel.

entry.ety: Gr. tri`bein to rub
entry.def: a combining form relating to friction.

entry.ety: tribo- + electricity
entry.def: electrical charge developed by rubbing objects together, suc as amber on cat fur.

entry.ety: tribo- + -ology
entry.def: the study of the effects of friction on parts of machinery moving in contact with each other, and of methods, such as lubrication, to counteract negative effects such as wear.

entry.ety: Gr. tri`bein to rub + -meter: cf. F. tribomètre
entry.def: An instrument to ascertain the degree of friction in rubbing surfaces.

entry.ety: L. tribrachys, Gr. � consisting of three short syllables; � (see Tri-) + � short
entry.def: A poetic foot of three short syllables, as, mĕlĭŭs .

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + bracteate
entry.def: Having three bracts.
A colorless crystalline substance (C6H3OBr3) prepared by the reaction of carbolic acid with bromine. The predominant isomer is 2,4,6-tribromophenol; -- called also bromol.
Of or relating to a tribe; tribal; as, a tribual characteristic; tribular worship.
entry.q: The tribual lispings of the Ephraimites.

entry.ety: OE. tribulacium, F. tribulation, L. tribulatio, from tribulare to press, afflict, fr. tribulum a thrashing sledge, akin to terere tritum, to rub. See Trite
entry.def: That which occasions distress, trouble, or vexation; severe affliction.
entry.q: When tribulation or persecution ariseth because of the word, by and by he is offended.
In the world ye shall have tribulation.

entry.ety: L. tribunal, fr. tribunus a tribune who administered justice: cf. F. tribunal. See Tribune

sn.def: The seat of a judge; the bench on which a judge and his associates sit for administering justice.
Hence, a court or forum; as, the House of Lords, in England, is the highest tribunal in the kingdom.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: In villages of the Philippine Islands, a kind of townhall. At the tribunal the head men of the village met to transact business, prisoners were confined, and troops and travelers were often quartered.
Of or pertaining to tribunes; as, tribunary powers or authority.

entry.ety: L. tribunatus: cf. F. tribunat
entry.def: The state or office of a tribune; tribuneship.

entry.note: ☞ The tribunes were at first two, but their number was increased ultimately to ten. There were also military tribunes, officers of the army, of whom there were from four to six in each legion. Other officers were also called tribunes; as, tribunes of the treasury, etc.
entry.ety: L. tribunus, properly, the chief of a tribe, fr. tribus tribe: cf. F. tribun. See Tribe

sn.def: An officer or magistrate chosen by the people, to protect them from the oppression of the patricians, or nobles, and to defend their liberties against any attempts that might be made upon them by the senate and consuls.

Anciently, a bench or elevated place, from which speeches were delivered; in France, a kind of pulpit in the hall of the legislative assembly, where a member stands while making an address; any place occupied by a public orator.

entry.def: The office or power of a tribune.

entry.ety: L. tribunicius tribunitius: cf. F. tribunitien
entry.def: Of or pertaining to tribunes; befitting a tribune; as, tribunitial power or authority.
entry.q: A kind of tribunician veto, forbidding that which is recognized to be wrong.

entry.def: Tribunician; tribunitial.
In a tributary manner.
The quality or state of being tributary.

entry.ety: OE. tributaire, F. tributaire, L. tributarius. See Tribute

sn.def: Paying tribute to another, either from compulsion, as an acknowledgment of submission, or to secure protection, or for the purpose of purchasing peace.
sn.q: Julius] unto Rome made them tributary.

sn.def: Hence, subject; subordinate; inferior.
sn.q: He to grace his tributary gods.

sn.def: Paid in tribute.
sn.q: Tributarytears.

sn.def: Yielding supplies of any kind; serving to form or make up, a greater object of the same kind, as a part, branch, etc.; contributing; as, the Ohio has many tributary streams, and is itself tributary to the Mississippi.

entries.entry:
Trib"u*ta*ry n.; pl.Tributaries.
A ruler or state that pays tribute, or a stated sum, to a conquering power, for the purpose of securing peace and protection, or as an acknowledgment of submission, or for the purchase of security.
A stream or river flowing into a larger river or into a lake; an affluent.

entry.cs: Tribute money money paid as a tribute or tax. Tribute pitch. Mining See under Tributer. Eng
entry.ety: OE. tribut, L. tributum, fr. tribuere tributum, to bestow, grant, pay, allot, assign, originally, to a tribe, from tribus tribe; cf. F. tribut. See Tribe, and cf. Attribute Contribute

sn.def: An annual or stated sum of money or other valuable thing, paid by one ruler or nation to another, either as an acknowledgment of submission, or as the price of peace and protection, or by virtue of some treaty; as, the Romans made their conquered countries pay tribute .
sn.q: Millions for defense, but not one cent for tribute.

sn.def: A personal contribution, as of money, praise, service, etc., made in token of services rendered, or as that which is due or deserved; as, a tribute of affection.
sn.q: Implores the passing tribute of a sigh.

sn.def: A certain proportion of the ore raised, or of its value, given to the miner as his recompense.
sn.syn: See Subsidy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tributed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tributing
entry.def: To pay as tribute.

entry.note: ☞ Tributers generally work in gangs, and have a limited portion of a lode set them, called a tribute pitch, beyond which they are not permitted to work, and for which they receive a certain portion of the ore, or so much per pound, as agreed upon, of the value of what they raise.
entry.def: One who works for a certain portion of the ore, or its value.

entries.entry: Tri"ca Tri"ca n.; pl.Tricæ #. NL Bot An apothecium in certain lichens, having a spherical surface marked with spiral or concentric ridges and furrows.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + carboxyl + allyl + -ic
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex tribasic organic acid, C3H5.(CO2H)3 occurring naturally in unripe beet roots, and produced artificially from glycerin as a white crystalline substance.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + carbimide
entry.def: See under Cyanuric.

entry.ety: OE. trisen; of Scand. or Low German origin; cf. Sw. trissa a sheave, pulley, triss a spritsail brace, Dan. tridse a pulley, tridse to haul by means of a pulley, to trice, LG. trisse a pulley, D. trijsen to hoist

sn.def: To pull; to haul; to drag; to pull away.
sn.q: Out of his seat I will him trice.

sn.def: To haul and tie up by means of a rope.

entry.ety: Sp. tris the noise made by the breaking of glass, an instant, en un tris in an instant; probably of imitative origin
entry.def: A very short time; an instant; a moment; -- now used only in the phrase in a trice.
entry.q: With atrice.
On atrice.
A man shall make his fortune in a trice.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to thirty years; tricennial.

entry.ety: L. tricennium thirty years; triginta thirty + annus year: cf. L. tricennalis
entry.def: Of or pertaining to thirty years; consisting of thirty years; occurring once in every thirty years.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + centenary
entry.def: Including, or relating to, the interval of three hundred years; tercentenary.

def2.def: A period of three centuries, or three hundred years, also, the three-hundredth anniversary of any event; a tercentenary.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. triceps, having three beads; tres tria, three + caput head: cf. F. triceps. See Three, and Chief
entry.def: A muscle having three heads; specif., the great extensor of the forearm, arising by three heads and inserted into the olecranon at the elbow.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. tri`x tricho`s, hair
entry.def: A disease of the eye, in which the eyelashes, being turned in upon the eyeball, produce constant irritation by the motion of the lids.

entries.entry: Tri*chi"na Tri*chi"na -nȧ n.; pl.Trichinæ #. NL., fr. Gr. � hairy, made of hair, fr. tri`x tricho`s, hair Zoöl A small, slender nematoid worm (Trichina spiralis) which, in the larval state, is parasitic, often in immense numbers, in the voluntary muscles of man, the hog, and many other animals. When insufficiently cooked meat containing the larvæ is swallowed by man, they are liberated and rapidly become adult, pair, and the ovoviviparous females produce in a short time large numbers of young which find their way into the muscles, either directly, or indirectly by means of the blood. Their presence in the muscles and the intestines in large numbers produces trichinosis.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Trichinosis.
To render trichinous; to affect with trichinæ; -- chiefly used in the past participle; as, trichinized pork.

entry.ety: Trichina + -scope
entry.def: An apparatus for the detection of trichinæ in the flesh of animals, as of swine.

entry.ety: NL. See Trichina
entry.def: The disease produced by the presence of trichinæ in the muscles and intestinal track. It is marked by fever, muscular pains, and symptoms resembling those of typhoid fever, and is frequently fatal.
Of or pertaining to trichinæ or trichinosis; affected with, or containing, trichinæ; as, trichinous meat.

cs.cd: one of the small sheaflike fascicles of slender setæ characteristic of certain sponges. See Illust. under Spicule.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, hair

sn.def: A kind of crystallite resembling a bunch of hairs, common in obsidian. See Illust. of Crystallite.
A delicate, hairlike siliceous spicule, found in certain sponges.

entry.def: Like or pertaining to the genus Trichiurus or family Trichiuridæ, comprising the scabbard fishes and hairtails.

entry.ety: Trichiurus + -oid
entry.def: Of, like, or pertaining to, Trichiurus.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. tri`x tricho`s, a hair + o'yra` tail
entry.def: A genus of fishes comprising the hairtails. See Hairtail.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + chloride
entry.def: A chloride having three atoms of chlorine in the molecule.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. tri`x tricho`s, hair + branchia
entry.def: The gill of a crustacean in which the branchial filaments are slender and cylindrical, as in the crawfishes.

entry.ety: Gr. tri`x tricho`s, a hair + � bag
entry.def: A lasso cell.

entry.ety: F., fr. Gr. tri`x tricho`s, hair + � woman, female
entry.def: The slender, hairlike cell which receives the fertilizing particles, or antherozoids, in red seaweeds.

entry.ety: L., a kind of plant, from Gr. �
entry.def: Any fern of the genus Trichomanes. The fronds are very delicate and often translucent, and the sporangia are borne on threadlike receptacles rising from the middle of cup-shaped marginal involucres. Several species are common in conservatories; two are native in the United States.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, a growth of hair
entry.def: Affected with a disease which causes agglutination and matting together; -- said of the hair when affected with plica. See Plica, 1.

entry.ety: See Trichomatose
entry.def: A hair on the surface of leaf or stem, or any modification of a hair, as a minute scale, or star, or gland. The sporangia of ferns are believed to be of the nature of trichomes.

entry.ety: Gr. tri`x tricho`s, hair + fe`rein to bear

sn.def: The special cell in red algæ which produces or bears a trichogyne. See Illust. of Trichogyne.
One of the saclike organs from which the setæ of annelids arise.

entry.def: One of the Trichoptera.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. tri`x tricho`s, a hair + � wing
entry.def: A suborder of Neuroptera usually having the wings covered with minute hairs. It comprises the caddice flies, and is considered by some to be a distinct order.
One of the Trichoptera.
Of, pertaining to, or characterizing, the Trichoptera.

entry.ety: Gr. � three stringed; � (see Tri-) + � chord, or string
entry.def: An instrument, as a lyre or harp, having three strings.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. tri`x tricho`s, hair + skw`lhx a worm
entry.def: An extensive group of wormlike animals characterized by being more or less covered with cilia.

entry.ety: See Trichotomy
entry.def: Divided into three parts, or into threes; three-forked; as, a trichotomous stem.

entry.ety: Gr. tri`cha threefold, in three parts + te`mnein to cut or divide: cf. F. trichotomie
entry.def: Division into three parts.
Exhibiting trichroism; pleochroic; pleochroism.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � color: cf. F. trichroïsme
entry.def: The quality possessed by some crystals of presenting different colors in three different directions.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + chromatic
entry.def: Having or existing in three different phases of color; having three distinct color varieties; -- said of certain birds and insects.
The quality, state, or phenomenon of being trichromatic.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � color
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or consisting of, three colors or color sensations.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + chromic
entry.def: Containing three atoms of chromium.

entry.ety: See Triceps
entry.def: Having three heads, or three origins; as, a tricipital muscle.

entry.ety: D. trek a pull, or drawing, a trick, trekken to draw; akin to LG. trekken, MHG. trecken trechen, Dan. trække, and OFries. trekka. Cf. Track Trachery Trig a. Trigger

sn.def: An artifice or stratagem; a cunning contrivance; a sly procedure, usually with a dishonest intent; as, a trick in trade.
sn.q: He comes to me for counsel, and I show him a trick.
I know a trick worth two of that.

sn.def: A sly, dexterous, or ingenious procedure fitted to puzzle or amuse; as, a bear's tricks; a juggler's tricks .
Mischievous or annoying behavior; a prank; as, the tricks of boys.
A particular habit or manner; a peculiarity; a trait; as, a trick of drumming with the fingers; a trick of frowning.
sn.q: The trick of that voice I do well remember.
He hath a trick of Cœur de Lion's face.

sn.def: A knot, braid, or plait of hair.
The whole number of cards played in one round, and consisting of as many cards as there are players.
sn.q: On one nice trick depends the general fate.

sn.def: A turn; specifically, the spell of a sailor at the helm, -- usually two hours.
A toy; a trifle; a plaything.
sn.syn: Stratagem; wile; fraud; cheat; juggle; finesse; sleight; deception; imposture; delusion; imposition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tricked; p. pr. & vb. n. Tricking

sn.def: To deceive by cunning or artifice; to impose on; to defraud; to cheat; as, to trick another in the sale of a horse.
To dress; to decorate; to set off; to adorn fantastically; -- often followed by up off, or out.
sn.q: Trickher off in air.
People lavish it profusely in tricking up their children in fine clothes, and yet starve their minds.
They are simple, but majestic, records of the feelings of the poet; as little tricked out for the public eye as his diary would have been.

sn.def: To draw in outline, as with a pen; to delineate or distinguish without color, as arms, etc., in heraldry.
sn.q: They forget that they are in the statutes: . . . there they are tricked, they and their pedigrees.

entry.def: One who tricks; a trickster.
A trigger.
The art of dressing up; artifice; stratagem; fraud; imposture.
The quality of being tricky.
Given to tricks; tricky.
Dress; ornament.
Given to tricks; artful in making bargains; given to deception and cheating; knavish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trickled trĭk"k'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Trickling trĭk"klĭng
entry.ety: OE. triklen, probably for striklen, freq. of striken to flow, AS. strīcan. See Strike v. t.
entry.def: To flow in a small, gentle stream; to run in drops.
entry.q: His salt tears trickled down as rain.
Fast beside there trickled softly down A gentle stream.

entry.def: The act or state of trickling; also, that which trickles; a small stream; drip.
entry.q: Streams that . . . are short and rapid torrents after a storm, but at other times dwindle to feeble trickles of mud.

entry.def: Decoration.
entry.q: Notrickmentsbut my tears.

entry.def: The quality or state of being tricksy; trickiness.
One who tricks; a deceiver; a tricker; a cheat.

entry.ety: From Trick
entry.def: Exhibiting artfulness; trickish.
entry.q: Mytricksyspirit!
he tricksy policy which in the seventeenth century passed for state wisdom.

entry.ety: F. trictrac. Cf. Ticktack backgammon
entry.def: An old game resembling backgammon.
Given to tricks; practicing deception; trickish; knavish.
Triclinic.

entry.ety: L. tricliniaris. See Triclinium
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a triclinium, or to the ancient mode of reclining at table.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � to incline
entry.def: Having, or characterized by, three unequal axes intersecting at oblique angles. See the Note under crystallization.

entries.entry: Tri*clin"i*um Tri*clin"i*um n.; pl.Triclinia #. L., from Gr. �, �; � (see Tri-) + � a couch Rom. Antiq A couch for reclining at meals, extending round three sides of a table, and usually in three parts. A dining room furnished with such a triple couch.

entry.ety: Gr. tri`kokkos with three grains or berries; � (see Tri-) + ko`kkos grain, seed
entry.def: Having three cocci, or roundish carpels.

entry.ety: F. tricolore, drapeau tricolore a tricolored flag, fr. tricolore three-colored; trisee Tri-) + L. color color

sn.def: The national French banner, of three colors, blue, white, and red, adopted at the first revolution.
Hence, any three-colored flag.

entry.def: Having three colors.

entry.ety: L. tricorniger; tricornis three-horned (see Tri-, and Horn) + -gerere to bear
entry.def: Having three horns.

entry.ety: L. tricorpor; tri-see Tri-) + corpus -oris, body
entry.def: Represented with three bodies conjoined to one head, as a lion.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + costate
entry.def: Three-ribbed; having three ribs from the base.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A fabric of woolen, silk, or cotton knitted, or women to resemble knitted work.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � to beat
entry.def: Of or pertaining to tricrotism; characterized by tricrotism.

That condition of the arterial pulse in which there is a triple beat. The pulse curve obtained in the sphygmographic tracing characteristic of tricrotism shows two secondary crests in addition to the primary.
Tricrotic.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + curvate
entry.def: Curved in three directions; as, a tricurvate spiculesee Illust. of Spicule).

cs.cd: the valve, consisting of three triangular membranous flaps, at the opening of the right auricle into the right ventricle in the heart of most mammals; -- sometimes called the tricuspid valves, each flap being regarded as a valve.

entry.ety: L. tricuspis -idis; tri-see Tri-) + cuspis a point: cf. F. tricuspide

sn.def: Having three cusps, or points; tricuspidate; as, a tricuspid molar.
Of or pertaining to the tricuspid valves; as, tricuspid obstruction.

entry.def: Three-pointed; ending in three points; as, a tricuspidate leaf.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + cycle as inbicycle
entry.def: A three-wheeled velocipede. See Illust. under Velocipede. Cf. Bicycle.

entry.ety: L., pl., a kind of oysters, fr. Gr. � eaten at three bites, � tri- + � to bite
entry.def: A genus of very large marine bivalve shells found on the coral reefs of the Indian and Pacific Oceans. One species (Tridacna gigas) often weighs four or five hundred pounds, and is sometimes used for baptismal fonts. Called also paw shell, and fountain shell.

entry.ety: Gr. �: � (see Tri-) + � digit: cf. F. tridactyle
entry.def: Having three fingers or toes, or composed of three movable parts attached to a common base.
Tridactyl.
The jacksnipe.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tride lively, quick
entry.def: Short and ready; fleet; as, a tride pace; -- a term used by sportsmen.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � ten. So called from the number of carbon atoms in the molecule
entry.def: A hydrocarbon, C13H28, of the methane series, which is a probable ingredient both of crude petroleum and of kerosene, and is produced artificially as a light colorless liquid.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. de`katos tenth
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, that acid of the fatty acids heterologous with tridecane. It is a white crystalline substance.

entry.ety: Pref. tri-+ Gr. de`katos tenth + E. ethylene
entry.def: A hydrocarbon, C13H26, of the ethylene series, corresponding to tridecane, and obtained from Burmah petroleum as a light colorless liquid; -- called also tridecylene, and tridecene.

cs.cd: an Asiatic rhinolophid bat (Triænops Persicus), having the nose membrane in the shape of a trident.

entry.ety: L. tridens -entis; tri-see Tri-) + dens tooth: cf. F. trident. See Tooth

sn.def: A kind of scepter or spear with three prongs, -- the common attribute of Neptune.
A three-pronged spear or goad, used for urging horses; also, the weapon used by one class of gladiators.
A three-pronged fish spear.
A curve of third order, having three infinite branches in one direction and a fourth infinite branch in the opposite direction.

entry.ety: L. tridens
entry.def: Having three teeth or prongs; tridentate.

entry.ety: NL. tridentatus. See Trident
entry.def: Having three teeth; three-toothed.
Having three prongs; trident; tridentate; as, a tridented mace.

entry.ety: L. tridentifer; tridens trident + ferre to bear
entry.def: Bearing a trident.

entry.ety: From L. Tridentum Trent
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Trent, or the general church council held in that city.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + diaposon
entry.def: A triple octave, or twenty-second.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + dimensional
entry.def: Having three dimensions; extended in three different directions.
A riding. See Trithing.

entry.ety: L. triduanus, fr. triduum space of three days; tri- + dies day
entry.def: Lasting three lays; also, happening every third day.

entry.ety: Gr. � threefold. So called in allusion to the supposed threefold nature of the twin crystals
entry.def: Pure silica, like quartz, but crystallizing in hexagonal tables. It is found in trachyte and similar rocks.
imp. & p. p. of Try.
entry.def2: Also adj. Proved; tested; faithful; trustworthy; as, a tried friend.

entry.def: See Trihedral.

entry.ety: L. triennium the space of three years; tri-see Tri-) + annus year. See Annual

sn.def: Continuing three years; as, triennial parliaments; a triennial reign.
Happening, coming about, or appearing once in every three years; as, triennial elections; a triennial catalogue; a triennial visitation.

entry.def: Something which takes place or appears once in three years.
Once in three years.

entry.ety: L., from tres tria, three
entry.def: A Roman copper coin, equal to one third of the as. See 3d As, 2.

entry.ety: From Try

sn.def: One who tries; one who makes experiments; one who examines anything by a test or standard.
One who tries judicially.
A person appointed according to law to try challenges of jurors; a trior.
That which tries or approves; a test.

entry.ety: L. trierarchus, Gr. �; � a trireme + � a leader, a chief
entry.def: The commander of a trireme.
At Athens, one who (singly, or jointly with other citizens) had to fit out a trireme for the public service.

entries.entry: Tri"er*arch`y n.; pl.Trierarchises #. Gr. � The office duty of a trierarch.

entry.ety: L. trietericus, Gr. �, fr. � (sc. �) a triennial festival; � (see Tri-.) + � a year
entry.def: Kept or occurring once in three years; triennial.

entry.ety: L. trieterica, pl., fr. Gr. � of a triennial festival
entry.def: Festival games celebrated once in three years.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + ethylamine
entry.def: A tertiary amine analogous to trimethylamine.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + facial
entry.def: See Trigeminal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trifallowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Trifallowing
entry.ety: Pref. tri- + fallow. Cf. Thryfallow
entry.def: To plow the third time before sowing, as land.

entry.ety: L. trifarius of three sorts or ways, threefold; cf. Gr. �. Cf. Bifarious
entry.def: Facing three ways; arranged in three vertical ranks, as the leaves of veratrum.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + fasciated
entry.def: Having, or surrounded by, three fasciæ, or bands.

entry.ety: L. trifidus; tri- (see Tri-) + the root of findere to split: cf. F. trifide
entry.def: Cleft to the middle, or slightly beyond the middle, into three parts; three-cleft.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + fistula fistular
entry.def: Having three pipes.

entry.ety: OE. trifle trufle, OF. trufle mockery, raillery, trifle, probably the same word as F. truffe truffle, the word being applied to any small or worthless object. See Truffle

sn.def: A thing of very little value or importance; a paltry, or trivial, affair.
sn.q: With such poor trifles playing.
Trifles light as air Are to the jealous confirmation strong As proofs of holy writ.
Small sands the mountain, moments make year, And frifles life.

sn.def: A dish composed of sweetmeats, fruits, cake, wine, etc., with syllabub poured over it.

cs.cd: to play the fool with; to treat without respect or seriousness; to mock; as, to trifle with one's feelings, or with sacred things.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trifled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trifling
entry.ety: OE. trifelen truflen. See Trifle n.
entry.def: To act or talk without seriousness, gravity, weight, or dignity; to act or talk with levity; to indulge in light or trivial amusements.
entry.q: They trifle, and they beat the air about nothing which toucheth us.

sn.def: To make of no importance; to treat as a trifle.
To spend in vanity; to fritter away; to waste; as, to trifle away money.
sn.q: Wetrifletime.

entry.def: One who trifles.
Being of small value or importance; trivial; paltry; as, a trifling debt; a trifling affair.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. flos floris, flower
entry.def: Three-flowered; having or bearing three flowers; as, a triflorous peduncle.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + fluctuation
entry.def: A concurrence of three waves.
entry.q: Atrifluctuationof evils.

entry.ety: Tri- + foliate. Cf. Trefoil
entry.def: Having three leaves or leaflets, as clover. See Illust. of Shamrock.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + foliolate
entry.def: Having three leaflets.

entry.ety: L., clover
entry.def: A genus of leguminous herbs with densely spiked flowers and usually trifoliate leaves; trefoil. There are many species, all of which are called clover. See Clover.

entry.ety: L. trifolium. See Trifoliate Trefoil
entry.def: Sweet trefoil.
entry.q: She was crowned with a chaplet of trifoly.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. tri-see Tri-) + foris, pl. fores, a door
entry.def: The gallery or open space between the vaulting and the roof of the aisles of a church, often forming a rich arcade in the interior of the church, above the nave arches and below the clearstory windows.

entry.ety: L. triformis; tri-see Tri-) + forma form
entry.def: Having a triple form or character.
entry.q: Thistriformantagonism.
Goddess Triform, I own thy triple spell.

entry.ety: L. triformitas
entry.def: The state of being triform, or of having a threefold shape.

entry.ety: L. trifurcus; tri-see Tri-) + furca fork
entry.def: Having three branches or forks; trichotomous.

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. trykke to press, Sw. trycka
entry.def: To fill; to stuff; to cram.

entry.ety: Formerly written trick, akin to trick to dress
entry.def: Full; also, trim; neat.
entry.q: To sit on a horse square and trig.

entry.ety: See Trigger
entry.def: To stop, as a wheel, by placing something under it; to scotch; to skid.

entry.ety: See Trigger
entry.def: A stone, block of wood, or anything else, placed under a wheel or barrel to prevent motion; a scotch; a skid.

entry.ety: See Trigamy
entry.def: One who has been married three times; also, one who has three husbands or three wives at the same time.

entry.ety: L. trigamus a thrice-married man, Gr. � thrice married; � (see Tri-) + � marriage: cf. F. trigame
entry.def: Having three sorts of flowers in the same head, -- male, female, and hermaphrodite, or perfect, flowers.

entry.ety: L. trigamia,Gr. �: cf. F. trigamie. See Trigamous
entry.def: The act of marrying, or the state of being married, three times; also, the offense of having three husbands or three wives at the same time.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � belly
entry.def: Having three bellies; -- said of a muscle.

entry.ety: See Trigeminous
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the fifth pair of cranial nerves, which divide on each side of the head into three main branches distributed to the orbits, jaws, and parts of the mouth; trifacial.

entry.ety: L. trigeminus born three together; tri-see Tri-) + geminus twin. Cf. Tergeminous
entry.def: Born three together; being one of three born at the same birth; also, threefold.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + gen- + -ic. So named in reference to its composition, it being supposed to contain the radicals of three molecules of cyanic acid
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid, C4H7N3O2, obtained, by the action of the vapor of cyanic acid on cold aldehyde, as a white crystalline substance having a slightly acid taste and faint smell; -- called also ethidene-biuretorethylidene-biuret.

entries.entry: Tri`ger proc"ess. After M. Triger, French engineer Engin. & Mining A method of sinking through water-bearing ground, in which the shaft is lined with tubbing and provided with an air lock, work being proceeded with under air pressure.

entry.ety: L. in trigesimo-secundo in the thirty-second
entry.def: Having thirty-two leaves to a sheet; as, a trigesimo-secundo form, book, leaf, size, etc.
A book composed of sheets so folded that each one makes thirty-two leaves; hence, indicating, more or less definitely, a size of book; -- usually written 32mo, or 32°, and called thirty-twomo.

cs.cd: a large plectognath fish (Balistes Carolinensis or Balistes capriscus) common on the southern coast of the United States, and valued as a food fish in some localities. Its rough skin is used for scouring and polishing in the place of sandpaper. Called also leather jacket, and turbot.

entry.ety: For older tricker, from D. trekker, fr. trekken to draw, pull. See Trick n.

sn.def: A catch to hold the wheel of a carriage on a declivity.

A piece, as a lever, which is connected with a catch or detent as a means of releasing it; especially Firearms, the part of a lock which is moved by the finger to release the cock and discharge the piece.

entry.ety: LL. trigintate, fr. L. triginta thirty. See Trental
entry.def: A trental.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + glyceride
entry.def: A glyceride formed by the replacement of three hydrogen atoms in glycerin by acid radicals.

entry.ety: L. triglyphus, Gr. �; � (see Tri-) + � to carve: cf. F. triglyphe
entry.def: An ornament in the frieze of the Doric order, repeated at equal intervals. Each triglyph consists of a rectangular tablet, slightly projecting, and divided nearly to the top by two parallel and perpendicular gutters, or channels, called glyphs, into three parts, or spaces, called femora. A half channel, or glyph, is also cut upon each of the perpendicular edges of the tablet. See Illust. of Entablature.

sn.def: Consisting of, or pertaining to, triglyphs.
Containing three sets of characters or sculptures.

entry.ety: See Trig trim, neat
entry.def: The quality or state of being trig; smartness; neatness.
entry.q: Their spars had no man-of-war trigness.

entry.ety: L. trigonum, Gr. �; � (see Tri-) + � a corner, angle: cf. F. trigone

sn.def: A figure having three angles; a triangle.

sd.def: A division consisting of three signs.
Trine, an aspect of two planets distant 120 degrees from each other.
A kind of triangular lyre or harp.
A kind of game at ball played by three persons standing at the angular points of a triangle.

sn.def: The cutting region of the crown of an upper molar, usually the anterior part. That of a lower molar is the Tri"go*nid.

entry.def: Having three angles, or corners; triangular; as, a trigonal stem, one having tree prominent longitudinal angles.

entry.ety: F., literally, a trigon
entry.def: A smooth triangular area on the inner surface of the bladder, limited by the apertures of the ureters and urethra.

entry.ety: NL. See Trigon. So called in allusion to the triangular shape of some species
entry.def: A genus of pearly bivalve shells, numerous extinct species of which are characteristic of the Mesozoic rocks. A few living species exist on the coast of Australia.

entry.ety: Gr. � triangle + � horn
entry.def: Having horns with three angles, like those of some species of goats.

entry.ety: See Trigon; Odonto
entry.def: See Trituberculy.

entry.cs: Trigonometrical curve a curve one of whose coördinates is a trigonometric function of the other. Trigonometrical function. See under Function. Trigonometrical lines lines which are employed in solving the different cases of plane and spherical trigonometry, as sines, tangents, secants, and the like. These lines, or the lengths of them, are trigonometrical functions of the arcs and angles to which they belong. Trigonometrical survey. See under Survey.
entry.ety: Cf. F. trigonométrique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to trigonometry; performed by the rules of trigonometry.

entries.entry:
Trig`o*nom"e*try
Analytical trigonometry that branch of trigonometry which treats of the relations and properties of the trigonometrical functions.
Plane trigonometryandSpherical trigonometry
those branches of trigonometry in which its principles are applied to plane triangles and spherical triangles respectively.
n.; pl.-tries #. Gr. � a triangle + -metry: cf. F. trigonométrie. See Trigon
That branch of mathematics which treats of the relations of the sides and angles of triangles, which the methods of deducing from certain given parts other required parts, and also of the general relations which exist between the trigonometrical functions of arcs or angles.
A treatise in this science.

entry.ety: L. trigonus, Gr. �. See Trigon
entry.def: Same as Trigonal.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + -gram
entry.def: Same as Trigraph.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � + � a letter
entry.def: Containing three letters or characters, or three sets of letters or characters.

entry.ety: Gr. �. See Trigrammatic
entry.def: Same as Trigrammatic.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + -graph
entry.def: Three letters united in pronunciation so as to have but one sound, or to form but one syllable, as -ieu in adieu; a triphthong.
Any one of the Trigynia.

entry.ety: NL., Gr. � (see Tri-) + � a woman, a female
entry.def: A Linnæan order of plants having three pistils or styles.
Having three pistils or styles; of or pertaining to the Trigynia.

entry.ety: See Trihedron
entry.def: Having three sides or faces; thus, a trihedral angle is a solid angle bounded by three plane angles.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � a seat, base
entry.def: A figure having three sides.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + horal
entry.def: Occurring once in every three hours.
A hybrid whose parents differ by three pairs of contrasting Mendelian characters.

entry.ety: See Trijugous
entry.def: In three pairs; as, a trijugate leaf, or a pinnate leaf with three pairs of leaflets.

entry.ety: L. trijugus threefold; tri- + jugum a yoke
entry.def: Same as Trijugate.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � twenty
entry.def: A hydrocarbon, C23H48, of the methane series, resembling paraffin; -- so called because it has twenty-three atoms of carbon in the molecule.

entry.ety: L. trilaterus; tri-see Tri-) + latus lateris, side: cf. F. trilatéral. See Lateral
entry.def: Having three sides; being three-sided; as, a trilateral triangle.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � (see Tri-) + � any thing received, in logic, an assumption. Cf. Dilemma

sn.def: A syllogism with three conditional propositions, the major premises of which are disjunctively affirmed in the minor. See Dilemma.
A state of things in which it is difficult to determine which one of three courses to pursue.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or included by, three lines; as, trilinear coördinates.

entry.ety: L. trilinguis; tri-see Tri-) + lingua tongue, language. See Lingual
entry.def: Containing, or consisting of, three languages; expressed in three languages.
entry.q: The much-noted Rosetta stone . . . bears upon its surface a trilingual inscription.

entry.def: See Trilingual.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + literal
entry.def: Consisting of three letters; trigrammic; as, a triliteral root or word.

def2.def: A triliteral word.

entry.def: Same as Triliterality.
The quality of being triliteral; as, the triliterality of Hebrew roots.
Same as Trilithon.
Pertaining to a trilith.

entries.entry: Tril"i*thon trĭl"ĭ*thŏn n.; pl.Trilithons #. NL., fr. Gr.� of or with three stones; � (see Tri-) + � stone Archæol A monument consisting of three stones; especially, such a monument forming a kind of doorway, as among the ancient Celts.

entry.ety: OE. trillen to roll, turn round; of Scand. origin; cf. Sw. trilla to roll, Dan. trilde, Icel. þyrla to whirl, and E. thrill. Cf. Thrill
entry.def: To flow in a small stream, or in drops rapidly succeeding each other; to trickle.
entry.q: And now and then an ample tear trilled down Her delicate cheek.
Whispered sounds Of waters, trilling from the riven stone.

entry.ety: OE. trillen; cf. Sw. trilla to roll
entry.def: To turn round; to twirl.
entry.q: Bid him descend and trill another pin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trilling
entry.ety: It. trillare; probably of imitative origin
entry.def: To impart the quality of a trill to; to utter as, or with, a trill; as, to trill the r; to trill a note.
entry.q: The sober-suited songstress trills her lay.

entry.def: To utter trills or a trill; to play or sing in tremulous vibrations of sound; to have a trembling sound; to quaver.
entry.q: To judge of trilling notes and tripping feet.

entry.ety: It. trillo, fr. trillare. See Trill to shake

sn.def: A sound, of consonantal character, made with a rapid succession of partial or entire intermissions, by the vibration of some one part of the organs in the mouth -- tongue, uvula, epiglottis, or lip -- against another part; as, the r is a trill in most languages.
The action of the organs in producing such sounds; as, to give a trill to the tongue. d
A shake or quaver of the voice in singing, or of the sound of an instrument, produced by the rapid alternation of two contiguous tones of the scale; as, to give a trill on the high C. See Shake.

entry.def: The oyster catcher.

entry.ety: Cf. G. drilling

sn.def: One of tree children born at the same birth.
A compound crystal, consisting of three individuals.

entry.ety: F. trillion, formed from the pref. tri- in imitation of million a million. Cf. Billion
entry.def: According to the French notation, which is used upon the Continent generally and in the United States, the number expressed by a unit with twelve ciphers annexed; a million millions; according to the English notation, the number produced by involving a million to the third power, or the number represented by a unit with eighteen ciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.

entry.ety: NL.; cf. L. trilix triple-woven, triple
entry.def: A genus of liliaceous plants; the three-leaved nightshade; -- so called because all the parts of the plant are in threes.

entry.ety: It. See Trill
entry.def: A trill or shake. See Trill.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + lobate
entry.def: Having three lobes.
The state of being trilobate.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + lobe
entry.def: Same as Trilobate.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: An extinct order of arthropods comprising the trilobites.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trilobite. See Trilobate
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of extinct arthropods belonging to the order Trilobita. Trilobites were very common in the Silurian and Devonian periods, but became extinct at the close of the Paleozoic. So named from the three lobes usually seen on each segment.
Of, pertaining to or containing, trilobites; as, trilobitic rocks.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + locular: cf. F. triloculaire
entry.def: Having three cells or cavities; as, a trilocular capsule; a trilocular heart.

entry.ety: Gr. trilogi`a; pref. tri-see Tri-) + lo`gos speech, discourse: cf. F. trilogie
entry.def: A series of three dramas which, although each of them is in one sense complete, have a close mutual relation, and form one historical and poetical picture. Shakespeare's “ Henry VI.” is an example.
entry.q: On the Greek stage, a drama, or acted story, consisted in reality of three dramas, called together a trilogy, and performed consecutively in the course of one day.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. lumen luminis, light
entry.def: Having three lights

cs.cd: to fit, as a piece of timber, into other work.
to dress; to put in order.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trimmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Trimming
entry.ety: OE. trimen trumen, AS. trymian trymman, to prepare, dispose, make strong, fr. trum firm, strong; of uncertain origin

sn.def: To make trim; to put in due order for any purpose; to make right, neat, or pleasing; to adjust.
sn.q: The hermit trimmed his little fire.

sn.def: To dress; to decorate; to adorn; to invest; to embellish; as, to trim a hat.
sn.q: A rotten building newly trimmed over.
I was trimmed in Julia's gown.

sn.def: To make ready or right by cutting or shortening; to clip or lop; to curtail; as, to trim the hair; to trim a tree.
sn.q: Andtrimmedthe cheerful lamp.

sn.def: To dress, as timber; to make smooth.

sd.def: To adjust, as a ship, by arranging the cargo, or disposing the weight of persons or goods, so equally on each side of the center and at each end, that she shall sit well on the water and sail well; as, to trim a ship, or a boat.
To arrange in due order for sailing; as, to trim the sails.

sn.def: To rebuke; to reprove; also, to beat.
sn.q: I found her trimming up the diadem On her dead mistress.

entry.def: To balance; to fluctuate between parties, so as to appear to favor each.

cs.cd: having only ballast on board.
their position in regard to the ship and to each other, as near or distant, far forward or much aft, erect or raking.
that adjustment, with reference to the wind, witch is best adapted to impel the ship forward.

sn.def: Dress; gear; ornaments.
sn.q: Seeing him just pass the window in his woodland trim.

sn.def: Order; disposition; condition; as, to be in good trim .
sn.q: Thetrimof an encounter.

sn.def: The state of a ship or her cargo, ballast, masts, etc., by which she is well prepared for sailing.
The lighter woodwork in the interior of a building; especially, that used around openings, generally in the form of a molded architrave, to protect the plastering at those points.

entry.ety: See Trim v. t.
