entry.def: Fitly adjusted; being in good order., or made ready for service or use; firm; compact; snug; neat; fair; as, the ship is trim, or trim built; everything about the man is trim; a person is trim when his body is well shaped and firm; his dress is trim when it fits closely to his body, and appears tight and snug; a man or a soldier is trim when he stands erect.
entry.q: With comely carriage of her countenance trim.
So deemed I till I viewed their trim array Of boats last night.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + maculated
entry.def: Marked with three spots, or maculæ.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. mel, gen. mellis, honey
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a certain tribasic acid (called also trimellitic acid) metameric with trimesitic acid.

entry.ety: L. trimembris triplemembered. See Tri-, and Member
entry.def: Having, or consisting of, three members.

entry.ety: NL. See Tri-, and -mere
entry.def: A division of Coleoptera including those which have but three joints in the tarsi.
One of the Trimera. Also used adjectively.

entry.ety: See Trimera
entry.def: Having the parts in threes.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + mesitylene + -ic
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a tribasic acid, C6H3.(CO2)3, of the aromatic series, obtained, by the oxidation of mesitylene, as a white crystalline substance.

entry.ety: L. trimestris of three months; tri-see Tri-) + mensis month: cf. F. trimestre
entry.def: A term or period of three months.
Trimestrial.
Of or pertaining to a trimester, or period of three months; occurring once in every three months; quarterly.

entry.ety: L. trimetrus, Gr. �; � (see Tri-) + � measure. See Meter measure
entry.def: Consisting of three poetical measures.

def2.def: A poetical division of verse, consisting of three measures.

entries.entry: Tri*meth"yl. Chem A prefix or combining form (also used adjectively) indicating the presence of three methyl groups.

entry.ety: Trimethyl- + amine
entry.def: A colorless volatile alkaline liquid, N.(CH3)3, obtained from herring brine, beet roots, etc., with a characteristic herringlike odor. It is regarded as a substituted ammonia containing three methyl groups.
A gaseous hydrocarbon, C3H6, isomeric with propylene and obtained from it indirectly. It is the base of a series of compounds analogous to the aromatic hydrocarbons.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � measure
entry.def: Same as Orthorhombic.
Same as Trimeter.
In a trim manner; nicely.

sn.def: One who trims, arranges, fits, or ornaments.
One who does not adopt extreme opinions in politics, or the like; one who fluctuates between parties, so as to appear to favor each; a timeserver.
sn.q: Thus Halifax was a trimmer on principle.

sn.def: An instrument with which trimming is done.
A beam, into which are framed the ends of headers in floor framing, as when a hole is to be left for stairs, or to avoid bringing joists near chimneys, and the like. See Illust. of Header.
An apparatus used for piling the coal in gradually increasing piles made by building up at the point of the cone or top of the prism.

cs.cd: a joist into which timber trimmers are framed; a header. See Header.

entry.def: a. from Trim v.
entry.q: The Whigs are, essentially, an inefficient, trimming, halfway sort of a party.

sn.def: The act of one who trims.

That which serves to trim, make right or fitting, adjust, ornament, or the like; especially, the necessary or the ornamental appendages, as of a garment; hence, sometimes, the concomitants of a dish; a relish; -- usually in the plural
.
The act of reprimanding or chastisting; as, to give a boy a trimming .

entry.def: In a trimming manner.
The quality or state of being trim; orderliness; compactness; snugness; neatness.

entry.ety: See Trimorphous
entry.def: A substance which crystallizes in three distinct forms, or which has three distinct physical states; also, any one of these distinct forms. See Trimorphism, 1.

entry.ety: Gr. � three-formed; � (see Tri-) + morfh` form
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or characterized by, trimorphism; -- contrasted with monomorphic dimorphic, and polymorphic.

cs.cd: that condition in which flowers of plants of the same species have three different lengths of stamens, short, medium, and long, the blossoms of one individual plant having short and medium stamens and a long style, those of another having short and long stamens and a style of medium length, and those of a third having medium and long stamens and a short style, the style of each blossom thus being of a length not represented by its stamens.

entry.ety: See Trimorphic

sn.def: The property of crystallizing in three forms fundamentally distinct, as is the case with titanium dioxide, which crystallizes in the forms of rutile octahedrite, and brookite. See Pleomorphism.

The coëxistence among individuals of the same species of three distinct forms, not connected, as a rule, by intermediate gradations; the condition among individuals of the same species of having three different shapes or proportions of corresponding parts; -- contrasted with polymorphism, and dimorphism.

entry.ety: Skr. trimūrti; tri three + mūrti body
entry.def: The triad, or trinity, of Hindu gods, consisting of Brahma, the Creator, Vishnu, the Preserver, and Siva, the Destroyer.

entry.ety: Pref. tri + Gr. �, �, a muscle
entry.def: A lamellibranch which has three muscular scars on each valve.

entry.ety: L. trinus triple, trini three each, fr. tres tria, three. See Three, and cf. Trine a. & n. Tern a.
entry.def: Threefold.
entry.q: Trinalunity.
In their trinal triplicities on high.

entry.def: See Trundle.

entry.ety: See Trinal
entry.def: Threefold; triple; as, trine dimensions, or length, breadth, and thickness.

entry.ety: F. trine trin. See Trinal

sn.def: The aspect of planets distant from each other 120 degrees, or one third of the zodiac; trigon.
sn.q: In sextile, square, and trine.

sn.def: A triad; trinity.
sn.q: A single trine of brazen tortoises.
Eternal One, Almighty Trine!

entry.def: To put in the aspect of a trine.
entry.q: By fortune he [Saturn] was now to Venus trined.

entry.ety: NL. trinervatus; pref. tri- + L. nervus nerve
entry.def: Having three ribs or nerves extending unbranched from the base to the apex; -- said of a leaf.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + nerve
entry.def: Same as Trinervate.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of limicoline birds including many species of sandpipers. See Dunlin Knot, and Sandpiper.

entry.ety: F. tringle
entry.def: A curtain rod for a bedstead.

entry.ety: Tringa + -oid
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Tringa, or the Sandpiper family.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trinitaire. See Trinity
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Trinity, the doctrine of the Trinity, or believers in that doctrine.

sn.def: One who believes in the doctrine of the Trinity.
One of a monastic order founded in Rome in 1198 by St. John of Matha, and an old French hermit, Felix of Valois, for the purpose of redeeming Christian captives from the Moslems.

entry.def: The doctrine of the Trinity; the doctrine that there are three distinct persons in the Godhead.
Gun cotton; -- so called because regarded as containing three nitro groups.
Picric acid.

entry.cs: Trinity House an institution in London for promoting commerce and navigation, by licensing pilots, ordering and erecting beacons, and the like. Trinity Sunday the Sunday next after Whitsunday; -- so called from the feast held on that day in honor of the Holy Trinity. Trinity term. Law See the Note under Term n., 5.
entry.ety: OE. trinitee, F. trinité, L. trinitas, fr. trini three each. See Trinal

sn.def: The union of three persons (the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost) in one Godhead, so that all the three are one God as to substance, but three persons as to individuality.
Any union of three in one; three units treated as one; a triad, as the Hindu trinity, or Trimurti.
Any symbol of the Trinity employed in Christian art, especially the triangle.

entry.ety: See Trinity, and Unity
entry.def: Triunity; trinity.
entry.q: As for terms of trinity, triniunity, . . . and the like, they reject them as scholastic notions.

entry.def: A kind of fishing net.

entry.ety: F. trinquet foremast, also, a certain sail, trinquette a triangular sail, or Sp. trinquete triangular
entry.def: A three-cornered sail formerly carried on a ship's foremast, probably on a lateen yard.
entry.q: Sailing always with the sheets of mainsail and trinket warily in our hands.

entry.ety: OE. trenket a sort of knife, hence, probably, a toy knife worn as an ornament; probably from an Old French dialectic form of trenchier to cut. Cf. Trench v. t.

sn.def: A knife; a cutting tool.
A small ornament, as a jewel, ring, or the like.
A thing of little value; a trifle; a toy.

entry.def: To give trinkets; hence, to court favor; to intrigue.
One who trinkets.
Ornaments of dress; trinkets, collectively.
entry.q: No trinketry on front, or neck, or breast.

entry.def: To act secretly, or in an underhand way; to tamper.

entry.ety: L. trinoctialis for three nights; tri-see Tri-) + nox noctis, night
entry.def: Lasting during three nights; comprising three nights.

entry.ety: L. trinodis three-knotted; tri-see Tri-) + nodus knot

sn.def: Having three knots or nodes; having three points from which a leaf may shoot; as, a trinodal stem.
Having three nodal points.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + -nomial as in binomial: cf. F. trinôme
entry.def:
A quantity consisting of three terms, connected by the sign + or -; as, x + y + z, or ax + 2b - c2
.

sn.def: Consisting of three terms; of or pertaining to trinomials; as, a trinomial root.
Consisting of, or involving the use of, three terms; as, a trinomial systematic name specifying the genus, species, and variety.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. nomen nominis, name: cf. L. trinominis three-named
entry.def: Trinomial.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + nucleus
entry.def: A genus of Lower Silurian trilobites in which the glabella and cheeks form three rounded elevations on the head.

entry.ety: It., fr. L. tres tria, three: cf. F. trio, from the Italian. See Three

sn.def: Three, considered collectively; three in company or acting together; a set of three; three united.
sn.q: The trio were well accustomed to act together, and were linked to each other by ties of mutual interest.

sd.def: A composition for three parts or three instruments.
The secondary, or episodical, movement of a minuet or scherzo, as in a sonata or symphony, or of a march, or of various dance forms; -- not limited to three parts or instruments.

entry.ety: LL. triobolaris, fr. L. triobolus a piece of three oboli, Gr. �. See Tri-, and Obolus
entry.def: Of the value of three oboli; hence, mean; worthless.
entry.q: It may pass current . . . for a triobolar ballad.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + octile
entry.def: An aspect of two planets with regard to the earth when they are three octants, or three eighths of a circle, that is, 135 degrees, distant from each other.

entry.ety: NL. See Triœcious
entry.def: The third order of the Linnæan class Polygamia.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � house
entry.def: Having three sorts of flowers on the same or on different plants, some of the flowers being staminate, others pistillate, and others both staminate and pistillate; belonging to the order Triœcia.

entry.ety: See Triolet
entry.def: Same as Triplet.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + olein
entry.def: See Olein.

entry.ety: F. triolet. See Trio
entry.def: A short poem or stanza of eight lines, in which the first line is repeated as the fourth and again as the seventh line, the second being, repeated as the eighth.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + sulphonal; -- so called because it contains three ethyls.]
entry.def: A compound similar to sulphonal, used as a hypnotic in medicine.

entry.ety: NL. See Trionyx, and -old
entry.def: A division of chelonians which comprises Trionyx and allied genera; -- called also Trionychoides, and Trionychina.

entry.note: ☞ The common American species (Trionyx ferox syn. Aspidonectus ferox) becomes over a foot in length and is very voracious. Similar species are found in Asia and Africa.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � (see Tri-) + � a claw
entry.def: A genus of fresh-water or river turtles which have the shell imperfectly developed and covered with a soft leathery skin. They are noted for their agility and rapacity. Called also soft tortoise soft-shell tortoise, and mud turtle.
Same as Trier, 2 and 3.

entries.entry:
Tri"ose n.
Tri- + -ose
Chem A sugar derived from a trihydric alcohol. A trisaccharide.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + oxide
entry.def: An oxide containing three atoms of oxygen; as, sulphur trioxide SO3 ; -- formerly called tritoxide.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tripped trĭpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Tripping
entry.ety: OE. trippen; akin to D. trippen, Dan. trippe, and E. tramp. See Tramp

sn.def: To move with light, quick steps; to walk or move lightly; to skip; to move the feet nimbly; -- sometimes followed by it. See It, 5.
sn.q: This horse anon began to trip and dance.
Come, and trip it, as you go, On the light fantastic toe.
She bounded by, and tripped so light They had not time to take a steady sight.

sn.def: To make a brief journey or pleasure excursion; as, to trip to Europe.
To take a quick step, as when in danger of losing one's balance; hence, to make a false step; to catch the foot; to lose footing; to stumble.
Fig.: To be guilty of a misstep; to commit an offense against morality, propriety, or rule; to err; to mistake; to fail.
sn.q: Till his tonguetrip.
A blind will thereupon comes to be led by a blind understanding; there is no remedy, but it must trip and stumble.
Virgil is so exact in every word that none can be changed but for a worse; he pretends sometimes to trip, but it is to make you think him in danger when most secure.
What? dost thou verily trip upon a word?

sn.def: To cause to stumble, or take a false step; to cause to lose the footing, by striking the feet from under; to cause to fall; to throw off the balance; to supplant; -- often followed by up; as, to trip up a man in wrestling.
sn.q: The words of Hobbes's defense trip up the heels of his cause.

entry.sn: Fig: To overthrow by depriving of support; to put an obstacle in the way of; to obstruct; to cause to fail. To trip the course of law, and blunt the sword.

sn.def: To detect in a misstep; to catch; to convict; also called trip up.
sn.q: These her women can trip me if I err.

sd.def: To raise (an anchor) from the bottom, by its cable or buoy rope, so that it hangs free.
To pull (a yard) into a perpendicular position for lowering it.

sn.def: To release, let fall, or set free, as a weight or compressed spring, as by removing a latch or detent; to activate by moving a release mechanism, often unintentionally; as, to trip an alarm.
A quick, light step; a lively movement of the feet; a skip.
sn.q: His heart bounded as he sometimes could hear the trip of a light female step glide to or from the door.

sn.def: A brief or rapid journey; an excursion or jaunt.
sn.q: I took a trip to London on the death of the queen.

sn.def: A false step; a stumble; a misstep; a loss of footing or balance. Fig.: An error; a failure; a mistake.
sn.q: Imperfect words, with childish trips.
Each seeming trip, and each digressive start.

sn.def: A small piece; a morsel; a bit.
sn.q: Atripof cheese.

sn.def: A stroke, or catch, by which a wrestler causes his antagonist to lose footing.
sn.q: And watches with a trip his foe to foil.
It is the sudden trip in wrestling that fetches a man to the ground.

sn.def: A single board, or tack, in plying, or beating, to windward.
A herd or flock, as of sheep, goats, etc.
A troop of men; a host.
A flock of widgeons.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + palmitate
entry.def: A palmitate derived from three molecules of palmitic acid.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + palmitin
entry.def: See Palmitin.
See Trepang.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + parted

sn.def: Parted into three piece; having three parts or pieces; -- said of the field or of a bearing; as, a cross triparted .
Divided nearly to the base into three segments or lobes.

entry.def: Divisible into three parts.

entry.ety: See Tripartite
entry.def: Dividing into three parts; -- said of a number which exactly divides another into three parts.

entry.ety: L. tripartitus; tri-see Tri-) + partitus, p. p. of partiri to part, to divide. See Part v. i.

sn.def: Divided into three parts; triparted; as, a tripartite leaf.
Having three corresponding parts or copies; as, to make indentures tripartite .
Made between three parties; as, a tripartite treaty.

entry.def: In a tripartite manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tripartition
entry.def: A division by threes, or into three parts; the taking of a third part of any number or quantity.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + paschal
entry.def: Including three passovers.

entry.ety: OE. tripe, F. tripe; of uncertain origin; cf. Sp. & Pg. tripa, It. trippa, OD. tripe, W. tripa, Armor. stripen

sn.def: The large stomach of ruminating animals, when prepared for food.
sn.q: How say you to a fat tripe finely broiled ?

sn.def: The entrails; hence, humorously or in contempt, the belly; -- generally used in the plural.

entry.ety: L. tripedalis; tri-see Tri-) + pes pedis, a foot
entry.def: Having three feet.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Same as Rock tripe, under Rock.
Same as Tripoli.

entries.entry: Tripe"man n.; pl.-men. A man who prepares or sells tripe.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + pennate
entry.def: Same as Tripinnate.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + personal
entry.def: Consisting of three persons.
A Trinitarian.
The state of existing as three persons in one Godhead; trinity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. triperie
entry.def: A place where tripe is prepared or sold.
A variety of anhydrite composed of contorted plates fancied to resemble pieces of tripe.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + petaloid
entry.def: Having the form or appearance of three petals; appearing as if furnished with three petals.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + petalous: cf. F. tripétale
entry.def: Having three petals, or flower leaves; three-petaled.

entries.entry: Trip" ham`mer. A tilt hammer.

entry.ety: Gr. � appearing three-fold; � (see Tri-) + � to appear cf. F. triphane
entry.def: Spodumene.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + -phthong, as in diphthong: cf. F. triphthonque
entry.def: A combination of three vowel sounds in a single syllable, forming a simple or compound sound; also, a union of three vowel characters, representing together a single sound; a trigraph; as, eye -ieu in adieu -eau in beau, are examples of triphthongs .
Of or pertaining to a triphthong; consisting of three vowel sounds pronounced together in a single syllable.
Triphylite.

entry.note: ☞ A salmon-colored or clove-brown variety containing but little iron is known as lithiophilite.
entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � a family, class. So called in allusion to its containing three phosphates
entry.def: A mineral of a grayish-green or bluish color, consisting of the phosphates of iron, manganese, and lithia.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � (see Tri-) + � a leaf: cf. F. triphylle
entry.def: Having three leaves; three-leaved.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + pinnate
entry.def: Having bipinnate leaflets arranged on each side of a rhachis.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + pinnatifid
entry.def: Thrice pinnately cleft; -- said of a pinnatifid leaf when its segments are pinnatifid, and the subdivisions of these also are pinnatifid.

entry.ety: Skr. tripiṭaka
entry.def: The three divisions, or “baskets” (pitakas), of buddhist scriptures, -- the Vinayapitaka Skr. Vinayapiṭaka , or Basket of Discipline; Suttapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Discourses; and Abhidhammapitaka [Pali] , or Basket of Metaphysics.

entry.ety: Gr. � thrice as many
entry.def: Three-fold; triple; treble.

cs.cd: the crown, or tiara, of the pope. See Tiara, 2.
a compound steam engine in which the same steam performs work in three cylinders successively.
a measure of tree beats of which first only is accented.
a ratio which is equal to 3.
a salt containing three distinct basic atoms as radicals; thus, microcosmic salt is a triple salt.
a system of three stars in close proximity.
that time in which each measure is divided into three equal parts.
in an automatic air brake for railroad cars, the valve under each car, by means of which the brake is controlled by a change of pressure in the air pipe leading from the locomotive.

entry.ety: L. triplus; tri-see Tri-) + -plus, as in duplus double: cf. F. triple. See Double, and cf. Treble

sn.def: Consisting of three united; multiplied by three; threefold; as, a triple knot; a triple tie.
sn.q: By thy triple shape as thou art seen.

sn.def: Three times repeated; treble. See Treble.
One of three; third.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tripled; p. pr. & vb. n. Tripling
entry.ety: Cf. F. tripler. See Triple a.
entry.def: To make threefold, or thrice as much or as many; to treble; as, to triple the tax on coffee.
Having three crowns; wearing the triple crown, as the pope.
Having three heads; three-headed; as, the triple-headed dog Cerberus.

entry.ety: From Triple

sn.def: A collection or combination of three of a kind; three united.
Three verses rhyming together.
A group of three notes sung or played in the tree of two.
Three children or offspring born at one birth.

entry.def: An edible fish (Lobotes Surinamensis) found in the warmer parts of all the oceans, and common on the southern and middle coasts of the United States. When living it is silvery gray, and becomes brown or blackish when dead. Its dorsal and anal fins are long, and extend back on each side of the tail. It has large silvery scales which are used in the manufacture of fancy work. Called also, locally, black perch grouper, and flasher.
Having three principal operative parts or motions, so as to produce a three-fold effect.

cs.cd: the ratio of the cubes of two quantities; thus, the triplicate ratio of a to b is a3: b3 .

entry.ety: L. triplicatus, p. p. of triplicare to triple, treble; tri-see Tri-) + plicare to fold. See Ply v. t.
entry.def: Made thrice as much; threefold; tripled.
A third thing corresponding to two others of the same kind.
Triternate.

entry.ety: L. triplicatio: cf. F. triplication

sn.def: The act of tripling, or making threefold, or adding three together.
Same as Surrejoinder.

entry.ety: Cf. F. triplicité, fr. L. triplex triplicis, threefold. See Triplicate a.
entry.def: The quality or state of being triple, or threefold; trebleness.
entry.q: In their trinal triplicities on high.

entry.ety: Triple + costate
entry.def: Three-ribbed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. triplite. See Triple
entry.def: A mineral of a dark brown color, generally with a fibrous, massive structure. It is a fluophosphate of iron and manganese.

entry.ety: Gr. � threefold + -blast + -ic
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, that condition of the ovum in which there are three primary germinal layers, or in which the blastoderm splits into three layers.
A manganese phosphate near triplite, but containing hydroxyl instead of fluorine.
In a triple manner.

entry.ety: F. tripe-madame trique-madame
entry.def: Same as Prickmadam.

entry.note: ☞ On such, a stool, in the temple of Apollo at Delphi, the Pythian priestess sat while giving responses to those consulting the Delphic oracle.

cs.cd: the three organs, the heart, lungs, and brain; -- so called because their united action is necessary to the maintenance of life.

entry.ety: L. tripus -odis, Gr. �; � (see Tri-) + �, �, foot. See Foot, and cf. Tripos Trivet

sn.def: Any utensil or vessel, as a stool, table, altar, caldron, etc., supported on three feet.
A three-legged frame or stand, usually jointed at top, for supporting a theodolite, compass, telescope, camera, or other instrument.

entry.def: An ancient stringed instrument; -- so called because, in form, it resembled the Delphic tripod.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + -pody, as in dipody
entry.def: Three metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.
An earthy substance originally brought from Tripoli, used in polishing stones and metals. It consists almost wholly of the siliceous shells of diatoms.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Tripoli or its inhabitants; Tripolitan.
Of or pertaining to tripoli, the mineral.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Tripoli or its inhabitants; Tripoline.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Tripoli.

entries.entry:
Tri"pos
Classical tripos examination the final university examination for classical honors, optional to all who have taken the mathematical honors. C. A. Bristed. Tripos paper a printed list of the successful candidates for mathematical honors, accompanied by a piece in Latin verse. There are two of these, designed to commemorate the two tripos days. The first contains the names of the wranglers and senior optimes, and the second the names of the junior optimes. The word tripos is supposed to refer to the three-legged stool formerly used at the examinations for these honors, though some derive it from the three brackets formerly printed on the back of the paper. C. A. Bristed.
n.; pl.Triposes #. Gr. � a tripod. See Tripod
A tripod. Obs
A university examination of questionists, for honors; also, a tripos paper; one who prepares a tripos paper. Cambridge University, Eng

entry.def: See Tripping a., 2.

sn.def: One who trips or supplants; also, one who walks or trips nimbly; a dancer.
An excursionist.

entry.def: A cam, wiper, or projecting piece which strikes another piece repeatedly.

sn.def: Quick; nimble; stepping lightly and quickly.
Having the right forefoot lifted, the others remaining on the ground, as if he were trotting; trippant; -- said of an animal, as a hart, buck, and the like, used as a bearing.

cs.cd: a small rope attached to the topgallant or royal yard, used to trip the yard, and in lowering it to the deck; also, a line used in letting go the anchor.

sn.def: Act of one who, or that which, trips.
A light dance.
sn.q: Other trippings to be trod of lighter toes.

sn.def: The loosing of an anchor from the ground by means of its cable or buoy rope.

entry.def: In a tripping manner; with a light, nimble, quick step; with agility; nimbly.
entry.q: Sing, and dance it trippingly.
Speak the speech . . . trippingly on the tongue.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to rub
entry.def: Trituration.
Shampoo.

entry.ety: L. triptotum, Gr. � with three cases; � (see Tri-) + � falling, fr. � to fall
entry.def: A noun having three cases only.

entries.entry: Trip"tych n. Gr. � consisting of three layers or plates; � (see Tri-) + �, �, a fold, layer Anything in three parts or leaves. Specifically:A writing tablet in three parts, two of which fold over on the middle part. A picture or altarpiece in three compartments.

entry.ety: L. tripudium a measured stamping, a leaping, a solemn religious dance
entry.def: Of or pertaining to dancing; performed by dancing.
entry.q: Tripudiaryaugurations.

entry.ety: L. tripudiare tripudiatum
entry.def: To dance.

entry.ety: L. tripudiatio
entry.def: The act of dancing.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + quadrantal
entry.def: Having three quadrants; thus, a triquadrantal triangle is one whose three sides are quadrants, and whose three angles are consequently right angles.
Triquetrous.

entry.ety: L. triquetrus
entry.def: Three sided, the sides being plane or concave; having three salient angles or edges; trigonal.

entries.entry: Tri*que"trum n.; pl.Triquetra #. NL Anat One of the bones of the carpus; the cuneiform. See Cuneiform.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + radiate
entry.def: Having three rays.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + rectangular
entry.def: Having three right angles. See Triquadrantal.

entry.ety: L. triremis; tri-see Tri-) + remus an oar, akin to E. row. See Row to propel with an oar
entry.def: An ancient galley or vessel with tree banks, or tiers, of oars.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + rhomboidal
entry.def: Having three rhombic faces or sides.

entries.entry: Tri*sac"cha*ride n. Also -rid . Chem A complex sugar, as raffinose, yielding by hydrolysis three simple sugar molecules.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + sacramentarian
entry.def: One who recognizes three sacraments, and no more; -- namely, baptism, the Lord's Supper, and penance. See Sacrament.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � thrice holy; � thrice + � holy
entry.def: An ancient anthem, -- usually known by its Latin name tersanctus.See Tersanctus.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trisected; p. pr. & vb. n. Trisecting
entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. sectus, p. p. of secare to cut. See Section

sn.def: To cut or divide into three parts.
To cut or divide into three equal parts.

entry.def: Divided into three parts or segments by incisions extending to the midrib or to the base; -- said of leaves.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trisection
entry.def: The division of a thing into three parts, Specifically: Geom the division of an angle into three equal parts.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + sepal
entry.def: Having three sepals, or calyx leaves.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + serial seriate

entry.ety: NL., form Gr. � gnashing of the teeth

entry.ety: Gr. � thrice + E. nitrate

cs.cd: a trisoctahedron each face of which is a quadrilateral; called also trapezohedron and icositetrahedron.
a trisoctahedron each face of which is an isosceles triangle.

entry.ety: Gr. � thrice + FE. octahedron
entry.def: A solid of the isometric system bounded by twenty-four equal faces, three corresponding to each face of an octahedron.

entry.ety: NL. trispaston, fr. Gr. � drawn threefold; � (see Tri-) + � to draw
entry.def: A machine with three pulleys which act together for raising great weights.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � seed
entry.def: Containing three seeds; three-seeded; as, a trispermous capsule.

entry.ety: Tri- + splanchnic
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the three great splanchnic cavities, namely, that of the head, the chest, and the abdomen; -- applied to the sympathetic nervous system.
To trust.

entry.ety: See Tryst

sn.def: Trust.
A post, or station, in hunting.
A secret meeting, or the place of such meeting; a tryst. See Tryst.
sn.q: George Douglas caused a trist to be set between him and the cardinal and four lords; at the which trist he and the cardinal agreed finally.

entry.ety: F. triste, L. tristis
entry.def: Sad; sorrowful; gloomy.
A cattle fair.
Tristearin.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + stearin
entry.def: See Stearin.
Sad; sorrowful; gloomy.
entry.q: Eyes so tristful, eyes so tristful, Heart so full of care and cumber.

entry.def: In a tristful manner; sadly.

entry.ety: Gr. � in three rows; � (see Tri-) + � a row
entry.def: Arranged in three vertical rows.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + stigma
entry.def: Having, or consisting of, three stigmas.

entry.ety: L. tristitia sadness, fr. tristis sad
entry.def: To make sad.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. tri-see Tri-) + sto`ma mouth
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of trematode worms belonging to Tristoma and allied genera having a large posterior sucker and two small anterior ones. They usually have broad, thin, and disklike bodies, and are parasite on the gills and skin of fishes.
See Trist a.

entry.ety: L. trisulcus; tri-see Tri-) + sulcus a furrow
entry.def: Something having three forks or prongs, as a trident.
entry.q: Jupiter'strisulc.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + sulcate
entry.def: Having three furrows, forks, or prongs; having three grooves or sulci; three-grooved.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + sulphide
entry.def: A sulphide containing three atoms of sulphur.

entry.ety: L. trisyllabus, Gr. �; � (see Tri-) + � a syllable: cf. F. trissyllabique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a trisyllable; consisting of three syllables; as, “syllable” is a trisyllabic word.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + syllable
entry.def: A word consisting of three syllables only; as, a-ven-ger .

entry.ety: L. tritus, p. p. of terere to rub, to wear out; probably akin to E. throw. See Throw, and cf. Contrite Detriment Tribulation Try
entry.def: Worn out; common; used until so common as to have lost novelty and interest; hackneyed; stale; as, a trite remark; a trite subject.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + ternate
entry.def: Three times ternate; -- applied to a leaf whose petiole separates into three branches, each of which divides into three parts which each bear three leafiets.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + Gr. � God: cf. F. trithéisme
entry.def: The opinion or doctrine that the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are three distinct Gods.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trithéiste
entry.def: One who believes in tritheism.
Of or pertaining to tritheism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trithéite
entry.def: A tritheist.

entry.ety: See Ist Riding
entry.def: One of three ancient divisions of a county in England; -- now called riding.
A salt of trithionic acid.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + thionic
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or designating, a certain thionic acid, H2S3O6 which is obtained as a colorless, odorless liquid.

entry.note: Compounds which are tritiated are, as a consequence, radioactive, and may be used as tracers in biochemical or chemical analysis.
entry.def: containing tritium; -- of chemical compounds; as, tritiated thymine.
Trite.
A carbohydrate isomeric with dextrin, obtained from quitch grass (Agropyrum repens, formerly Triticum repens) as a white amorphous substance.

entry.ety: L., perhaps fr. tritus, p. p. of terere to grind
entry.def: A genus of grasses including the various species of wheat.

A radioactive isotope of hydrogen having one proton and two neutrons in the nucleus. It decays spontaneously to Helium-3 by the emission of an electron (beta ray), with a half-life of 12.3 years. Symbol 1H3. Atomic weight 3.01605 (C-12 = 12.0000). It is one of the radioisotopes commonly used to label chemical compounds for use as tracers in biochemistry and chemistry. It is also used as one of the fusionable components of a hydrogen bomb.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. Tri`twn
entry.def: A fabled sea demigod, the son of Neptune and Amphitrite, and the trumpeter of Neptune. He is represented by poets and painters as having the upper part of his body like that of a man, and the lower part like that of a fish. He often has a trumpet made of a shell.
entry.q: Have sight of Proteus rising from the sea, Or hear old Triton blow his wreathed horn.

sn.def: Any one of many species of marine gastropods belonging to Triton and allied genera, having a stout spiral shell, often handsomely colored and ornamented with prominent varices. Some of the species are among the largest of all gastropods. Called also trumpet shell, and sea trumpet.

Any one of numerous species of aquatic salamanders. The common European species are Hemisalamandra cristata Molge palmata, and Molge alpestris, a red-bellied species common in Switzerland. The most common species of the United States is Diemyctylus viridescens. See Illust. under Salamander.

entry.ety: Gr. tri`tonos of three tones; tri- tri- + to`nos a tone
entry.def: A superfluous or augmented fourth.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Triturium.

entries.entry: Tri*to"vum Tri*to"vum n.; pl.Tritova #. NL., fr. Gr. � third + L. ovum egg Zoöl An embryonic insect which has twice cast its skin previous to hatching from the egg.

entry.ety: Gr. � third + zo^,on an animal
entry.def: A zooid of the third generation in asexual reproduction.
Having or designating teeth with three cusps or tubercles; tricuspid.
Pertaining to trituberculy.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. tuberculum tubercle
entry.def: A theory of the development of mammalian molar teeth. The primitive stage is that of simple cones, as in reptiles. The simple cone then developed a smaller cone in front and another behind. Next, a cingulum was developed, and the three cones became arranged in a triangle, the two smaller cusps having moved to the outer side in upper and to the inner in lower molars. This primitive triangle is called the trigon or trigonid and this stage the tritubercular or trigonodont. The trigon being a cutting apparatus, an extension of the posterior part of the crown was developed in lower molars for crushing, and a smaller corresponding part appeared in upper molars. Another large cone then arose, usually from the cingulum. In more complex forms, smaller intermediate cusps appeared.

entry.ety: Cf. F. triturable
entry.def: Capable of being triturated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Triturated; p. pr. & vb. n. Triturating
entry.ety: L. trituratus, p. p. of triturate to thrash (grain), fr. terere tritum, to rub, rub to pieces. See Trite

sn.def: To rub, grind, bruise, or thrash.
To rub or grind to a very fine or impalpable powder; to pulverize and comminute thoroughly.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trituration, L. trituratio a thrashing of grain
entry.def: The act of triturating, or reducing to a fine or impalpable powder by grinding, rubbing, bruising, etc.

entry.ety: L. tritura, from terere tritum, to rub, rub to pieces
entry.def: A rubbing or grinding; trituration.

entry.ety: NL.; cf. L. terere tritum to rub
entry.def: A vessel for separating liquids of different densities.

entry.ety: Gr. � third + -yl
entry.def: Propyl.
Propylene.

entry.note: ☞ The general was allowed to enter the city crowned with a wreath of laurel, bearing a scepter in one hand, and a branch of laurel in the other, riding in a circular chariot, of a peculiar form, drawn by four horses. He was preceded by the senate and magistrates, musicians, the spoils, the captives in fetters, etc., and followed by his army on foot in marching order. The procession advanced in this manner to the Capitoline Hill, where sacrifices were offered, and victorious commander entertained with a public feast.
entry.ety: L. triumphus, OL. triumpus; of uncertain origin; cf. Gr. � a procession in honor of Bacchus: cf. F. triomphe. Cf. Trump at cards

sn.def: A magnificent and imposing ceremonial performed in honor of a general who had gained a decisive victory over a foreign enemy.
Hence, any triumphal procession; a pompous exhibition; a stately show or pageant.
sn.q: Our daughter, In honor of whose birth these triumphs are, Sits here, like beauty's child.

sn.def: A state of joy or exultation for success.
sn.q: Great triumph and rejoicing was in heaven.
Hercules from Spain Arrived in triumph, from Geryon slain.

sn.def: Success causing exultation; victory; conquest; as, the triumph of knowledge.
A trump card; also, an old game at cards.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Triumphed; p. pr. & vb. n. Triumphing
entry.ety: L. triumphare: cf. F. triompher. See Triumph n.

sn.def: To celebrate victory with pomp; to rejoice over success; to exult in an advantage gained; to exhibit exultation.
sn.q: How long shall the wicked triumph?
Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you That triumph thus upon my misery!

sn.def: To obtain victory; to be successful; to prevail.
sn.q: Triumphing over death, and chance, and thee, O Time.
On this occasion, however, genius triumphed.

sn.def: To be prosperous; to flourish.
sn.q: Where commerce triumphed on the favoring gales.

sn.def: To play a trump card.

entry.def: To obtain a victory over; to prevail over; to conquer. Also, to cause to triumph.
entry.q: Two and thirty legions that awe All nations of the triumphed word.

entry.ety: L. triumphalis: cf. F. triomphal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to triumph; used in a triumph; indicating, or in honor of, a triumph or victory; as, a triumphal crown; a triumphal arch.
entry.q: Messiah his triumphal chariot turned.

entry.def: A token of victory.
entry.q: Joyless triumphals of his hoped success.

cs.cd: the church in heaven, enjoying a state of triumph, her warfare with evil being over; -- distinguished from church militant. See under Militant.

entry.ety: L. triumphans, p. pr. of triumphare: cf. F. triomphant. See Triumph v. i.

sn.def: Rejoicing for victory; triumphing; exultant.
sn.q: Successful beyond hope to lead ye forthTriumphant out of this infernal pit.

sn.def: Celebrating victory; expressive of joy for success; as, a triumphant song or ode.
Graced with conquest; victorious.
sn.q: Athena, war's triumphant maid.
So shall it be in the church triumphant.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to triumph; triumphal.
sn.q: Captives bound to a triumphant car.

entry.def: In a triumphant manner.

sn.def: One who was honored with a triumph; a victor.
One who triumphs or rejoices for victory.

entry.def: Having or celebrating a triumph; victorious; triumphant.

entries.entry:
Tri*um"vir Tri*um"vir ☞ In later times the triumvirs of Rome were three men who jointly exercised sovereign power. Julius Cæsar, Crassus, and Pompey were the first triumvirs; Octavianus (Augustus), Antony, and Lepidus were the second and last. n.; pl. L. Triumviri #, E. Triumvirs #. L., fr. res, gen. trium, three + vir a man. See Three, and Virile
Rom. Antiq One of tree men united in public office or authority.

entry.ety: L. triumviratus: cf. F. triumvirat

sn.def: Government by three in coalition or association; the term of such a government.
A coalition or association of three in office or authority; especially, the union of three men who obtained the government of the Roman empire.

entry.def: A triumvirate.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. unus one. See One
entry.def: Being three in one; -- an epithet used to express the unity of a trinity of persons in the Godhead.

entries.entry:
Tri*un"gu*lus Tri*un"gu*lus n.; pl.Triunguli #. NL. See Tri-, and Ungulate
Zoöl The active young larva of any oil beetle. It has feet armed with three claws, and is parasitic on bees. See Illust. of Oil beetle, under Oil.

entry.def: The quality or state of being triune; trinity.
The quality or state of being trivalent.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. valens -entis, p. pr. See Valence
entry.def: Having a valence of three; capable of being combined with, substituted for, or compared with, three atoms of hydrogen; -- said of triad atoms or radicals; thus, nitrogen is trivalent in ammonia.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + valve
entry.def: Anything having three valves, especially a shell.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + valvular
entry.def: Having three valves; three-valved.
A truant.

entry.ety: Pref. tri- + L. verbum a word
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, certain days allowed to the pretor for hearing causes, when be might speak the three characteristic words of his office, do dico addico. They were called dies fasti.

cs.cd: a table supported by three legs.

entry.ety: Probably through French fr. L. tripes -edis, three-footed; tri-see Tri-)+ pes pedis, foot: cf. F. trépied. See Foot, and cf. Tripod

sn.def: A tree-legged stool, table, or other support; especially, a stand to hold a kettle or similar vessel near the fire; a tripod.
A weaver's knife. See Trevat.

cs.cd: the specific name.

entry.ety: L. trivialis, properly, that is in, or belongs to, the crossroads or public streets; hence, that may be found everywhere, common, fr. trivium a place where three roads meet, a crossroad, the public street; tri-see Tri-) + via a way: cf. F. trivial. See Voyage

sn.def: Found anywhere; common.
Ordinary; commonplace; trifling; vulgar.
sn.q: As a scholar, meantime, he was trivial, and incapable of labor.

sn.def: Of little worth or importance; inconsiderable; trifling; petty; paltry; as, a trivial subject or affair.
sn.q: The trivial round, the common task.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the trivium.

entry.def: One of the three liberal arts forming the trivium.
A trivial matter or method; a triviality.

entries.entry:
Triv`i*al"i*ty n.; pl.Trivialities #. Cf. F. trivialité
The quality or state of being trivial; trivialness.
That which is trivial; a trifle. The philosophy of our times does not expend itself in furious discussions on mere scholastic trivialities.

entry.def: In a trivial manner.
Quality or state of being trivial.

entry.note: ☞ The trivium and quadrivium together made up the seven liberal arts. See Quadrivium.
entry.ety: LL. See Trivial

sn.def: The three “ liberal” arts, grammar, logic, and rhetoric; -- being a triple way, as it were, to eloquence.
The three anterior ambulacra of echinoderms, collectively.

entry.note: ☞ This is a convenient word, but is not legitimately formed. It should mean occurring once in three weeks, as triennial means once in three years. Cf. Biweekly.
entry.ety: Pref. tri- + weekly
entry.def: Occurring or appearing three times a week; thriceweekly; as, a triweekly newspaper.

def2.def: Three times a week.
A triweekly publication.

entry.def: See Trode.

entry.ety: Either onomatopoetic, or akin to throat
entry.def: To cry, as a buck in rutting time.
The cry of a buck in rutting time.

entry.ety: F. trocartor trois-quarts, i. e., three quarters); trois three (L. tres) + carre the side of a sword blade; -- so called from its triangular point.]
entry.def: A stylet, usually with a triangular point, used for exploring tissues or for inserting drainage tubes, as in dropsy.

entry.ety: Sp., bypath, crossroad
entry.def: A line of fortifications, usually rough, constructed to prevent the passage of an enemy across a region.
A trochaic verse or measure.

entry.ety: L. trochaïcus, Gr. � or �. See Trochee
entry.def: Of or pertaining to trochees; consisting of trochees; as, trochaic measure or verse.

cs.cd: the cephalic disk of a rotifer. It is usually surrounded by a fringe of cilia.

entry.ety: From Gr. � a wheel
entry.def: Resembling a wheel.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �

sn.def: One of two processes near the head of the femur, the outer being called the great trochanter, and the inner the small trochanter.
The third joint of the leg of an insect, or the second when the trochantine is united with the coxa.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to one or both of the trochanters.
The second joint of the leg of an insect, -- often united with the coxa.
See Trocar.

entry.ety: Gr. trocho`s anything round or circular, a wheel, properly, a runner, fr. tre`chein to run. Cf. Trochee
entry.def: A medicinal tablet or lozenge; strictly, one of circular form.

entry.ety: L. trochaeus, Gr. � (sc.�), from � running, from � to run. Cf. Troche Truck a wheel
entry.def: A foot of two syllables, the first long and the second short, as in the Latin word ante, or the first accented and the second unaccented, as in the English word motion; a choreus.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trochile. See Trochilus
entry.def: The crocodile bird.
entry.q: The crocodile . . . opens his chaps to let the trochil in to pick his teeth, which gives it the usual feeding.

entry.ety: NL. See Trochilus
entry.def: A division of birds comprising the humming birds.

entry.ety: See Trochilics
entry.def: OF or pertaining to rotary motion; having power to draw out or turn round.
entry.q: By arttrochilic.

entry.ety: Gr. � the sheaf of a pulley, roller of a windlass, from � to run
entry.def: The science of rotary motion, or of wheel work.

entry.ety: See Trochilus
entry.def: One who studies, or is versed in, the nature and habits of humming birds, or the Trochilidæ.

entry.ety: NL. See Trochilus
entry.def: The crocodile bird, or trochil.

entries.entry:
Troch"i*lus Troch"i*lus n.; pl.Trochili #. L. trochilus a kind of small bird. Gr. �, fr. � to run
Zoöl
A genus of humming birds. It Formerly included all the known species.
Any one of several species of wrens and kinglets. Obs
The crocodile bird.
Arch An annular molding whose section is concave, like the edge of a pulley; -- called also scotia.

entry.ety: OF. troche cluster, group; cf. F. trochure a surantler, trochée branches of a seedling, trochet cluster of flowers or fruits
entry.def: One of the small branches of a stag's antler.

entries.entry:
Tro*chis"cus Tro*chis"cus n.; pl.Trochisci #. L., fr. Gr. � a small ball, dim. of � a wheel. See Troche
Pharm A kind of tablet or lozenge; a troche.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trochisque
entry.def: See Trochiscus.

entry.ety: Gr. � a wheel
entry.def: A wheel-like joint of the stem of a fossil crinoid.

entry.ety: L., a case or sheaf containing one or more pulleys, Gr. �. See Trochilics

sn.def: A pulley.

A pulley, or a structure resembling a pulley; as, the trochlea, or pulleylike end, of the humerus, which articulates with the ulna; or the trochlea, or fibrous ring, in the upper part of the orbit, through which the superior oblique, or trochlear, muscle of the eye passes.

entry.cs: Trochlear nerve. See Pathetic nerve, under Pathetic.
entry.ety: L. trochlea block or pulley
entry.def: Shaped like, or resembling, a pulley; pertaining to, or connected with, a trochlea; as, a trochlear articular surface; the trochlear muscle of the eye.
Pertaining to, or connected with, a trochlea; trochlear; as, the trochleary, or trochlear, nerve.

entry.ety: Gr. � a wheel + -oid; cf. F. trochoïde. See Troche
entry.def: The curve described by any point in a wheel rolling on a line; a cycloid; a roulette; in general, the curve described by any point fixedly connected with a moving curve while the moving curve rolls without slipping on a second fixed curve, the curves all being in one plane. Cycloids, epicycloids, hypocycloids, cardioids, etc., are all trochoids.

sn.def: Admitting of rotation on an axis; -- sometimes applied to a pivot joint like that between the atlas and axis in the vertebral column.
Top-shaped; having a flat base and conical spire; -- said of certain shells.
Of or pertaining to the genus Trochus or family Trochidæ.
Of or pertaining to a trochoid; having the properties of a trochoid.
See Trochoid a.

entry.ety: Gr. � a wheel + -meter
entry.def: A contrivance for computing the revolutions of a wheel; an odometer.

entry.ety: Gr. � a wheel + sphere
entry.def: A young larval form of many annelids, mollusks, and bryozoans, in which a circle of cilia is developed around the anterior end.

entries.entry: Tro"chus Tro"chus n.; pl.Trochi #. NL., fr. Gr. � a wheel Zoöl Any one of numerous species of marine univalve shells belonging to Trochus and many allied genera of the family Trochidæ. Some of the species are called also topshells.

entry.def: An old English game; -- called also lawn billiards.
imp. & p. p. of Tread.
p. p. of Tread.
imp. of Tread.
entry.q: On burnished hooves his war-horse trode.

entry.ety: AS. trod, fr. tredan to tread. See Tread
entry.def: Tread; footing.

entry.ety: L. troglodytae, pl., Gr. � one who creeps into holes; � a hole, cavern (fr. � to gnaw) + � enter: cf. F. troglodyte

sn.def: One of any savage race that dwells in caves, instead of constructing dwellings; a cave dweller, or cave man. Most of the primitive races of man were troglodytes.
sn.q: In the troglodytes' country there is a lake, for the hurtful water it beareth called the “mad lake.”

sn.def: An anthropoid ape, as the chimpanzee.
The wren.

entry.note: The chimpanzee is now named Pan troglodytes.
entry.ety: NL. See Troglodyte
entry.sn: Zoöl A genus of apes including the chimpanzee., and its genus is Pan.

sn.def: A genus of singing birds including the common wrens.

entry.ety: L. troglodyticus, Gr. �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a troglodyte, or dweller in caves.

entry.note: ☞ Some of the species have a train of long brilliant feathers lying over the tail and consisting of the upper tail coverts. Unlike other birds having two toes directed forward and two backward, they have the inner toe turned backward. A few species are found in Africa and India, but the greater number, including the most brilliant species, are found in tropical America. See Illust. of Quesal.
entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of beautiful tropical birds belonging to the family Trogonidæ. They are noted for the brilliant colors and the resplendent luster of their plumage.

entry.ety: Trogon + -oid
entry.def: Like or pertaining to the trogons.

entry.ety: Cf. G. trog trough, E. trough
entry.def: A wooden trough, forming a drain.

entry.ety: L. Troicus, Gr. �, fr. �. See Trojan
entry.def: Pertaining to Troy; Trojan.

entry.ety: Named after Dominico Troili, an Italian of the 18th century
entry.def: Native iron protosulphide, FeS. It is known only in meteoric irons, and is usually in imbedded nodular masses of a bronze color.

entries.entry: Tro"i*lus n.; pl. L. Troili #, E. Troiluses #. NL., fr. L. Troilus, Gr. �, the son of Priam Zoöl A large, handsome American butterfly (Euphœades troilusorPapilio troilus). It is black, with yellow marginal spots on the front wings, and blue spots on the rear wings; -- also called troilus butterfly.
Tro"i*lus butterfly. A large American butterfly (Papilio troilus). It is black, with yellow marginal spots on the front wings, and blue on the rear; -- also called troilus.
Trois` point" Trois` point". F. trois three Backgammon The third point from the outer edge on each player's home table.

entry.ety: L. Trojanus, fr. Troja Troia, Troy, from Tros, Gr. Trw`s Trwo`s, Tros, the mythical founder of Troy

sn.def: Of or pertaining to ancient Troy or its inhabitants.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Troy.

sn.def: One who shows the pluck, endurance, determined energy, strength, or the like, attributed to the defenders of Troy; -- used chiefly or only in the phrase like a Trojan; as, he endured the pain like a Trojan; he studies like a Trojan .
sn.q: Tim jumped like a Trojan from the bed.

entry.ety: from the incident described in Homer's Iliad

sn.def: a large hollow wooden horse built by Greek soldiers besieging Troy during the Trojan War, and left as a “gift” when they pretended to abandon their seige. It was taken into the city by the Trojans, and Greek soldiers concealed inside came out and opened the gates to the city, enabling the capture of the city by the Greeks.
Hence, any thing or person which appears harmless but is designed to destroy or attack from within. It may sometimes refer to a group; -- see also fifth column.

A computer program designed to evade the security precautions within a computer system and perform illicit operations, or to do malicious damage, and often designed to look like a different kind of program, such as a game, archiver, or directory lister. This term is not applied to a program that replicates itself, such as a virus.

entry.cs: Troll flower. Bot Same as Globeflower.
entry.ety: Icel. troll. Cf. Droll Trull
entry.def: A supernatural being, often represented as of diminutive size, but sometimes as a giant, and fabled to inhabit caves, hills, and like places; a witch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trolled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trolling
entry.ety: OE. trollen to roll, F. trôler, Of. troller to drag about, to ramble; probably of Teutonic origin; cf. G. trollen to roll, ramble, sich trollen to be gone; or perhaps for trotler, fr. F. trotter to trot (cf. Trot.). Cf. Trawl

sn.def: To move circularly or volubly; to roll; to turn.
sn.q: To dress and troll the tongue, and roll the eye.

sn.def: To send about; to circulate, as a vessel in drinking.
sn.q: Then doth she troll to the bowl.
Troll the brown bowl.

sn.def: To sing the parts of in succession, as of a round, a catch, and the like; also, to sing loudly or freely.
sn.q: Will you troll the catch ?
His sonnets charmed the attentive crowd, By wide-mouthed mortaltrolled aloud.

sn.def: To angle for with a trolling line, or with a book drawn along the surface of the water; hence, to allure.
To fish in; to seek to catch fish from.
sn.q: With patient angle trolls the finny deep.

sn.def: To roll; to run about; to move around; as, to troll in a coach and six.
To move rapidly; to wag.
To take part in trolling a song.
To fish with a rod whose line runs on a reel; also, to fish by drawing the hook through the water.
sn.q: Their young men . . . trolled along the brooks that abounded in fish.

cs.cd: a rotative disk with spiral ribs or grooves, by which several pieces, as the jaws of a chuck, can be brought together or spread radially.

sn.def: The act of moving round; routine; repetition.
A song the parts of which are sung in succession; a catch; a round.
sn.q: Thence the catch and troll, while “Laughter, holding both his sides,” sheds tears to song and ballad pathetic on the woes of married life.

sn.def: A trolley.

entry.def: One who trolls.
A form of truck which can be tilted, for carrying railroad materials, or the like.
A narrow cart that is pushed by hand or drawn by an animal.
A truck from which the load is suspended in some kinds of cranes.
A truck which travels along the fixed conductors, and forms a means of connection between them and a railway car.

entries.entry: Trol"ley car. Elec A motor car powered by electricity drawn from a trolley, and thus constrained to follow the trolley lines. Trolley line A trolley . The path along which a trolley car runs.
Trolley wire. A heavy conducting wire on which the trolley car runs and from which it receives the current.

entry.ety: F. trou-madame pigeon holes
entry.def: The game of nineholes.

entry.ety: From Troll to roll, to stroll; but cf. also Trull
entry.def: A stroller; a loiterer; esp., an idle, untidy woman; a slattern; a slut; a whore.
A kind of loose dress for women.

entry.ety: It., aug. of tromba a trumpet: cf. F. trombone. See Trump a trumpet

sn.def: A powerful brass instrument of the trumpet kind, thought by some to be the ancient sackbut, consisting of a tube in three parts, bent twice upon itself and ending in a bell. The middle part, bent double, slips into the outer parts, as in a telescope, so that by change of the vibrating length any tone within the compass of the instrument (which may be bass or tenor or alto or even, in rare instances, soprano) is commanded. It is the only member of the family of wind instruments whose scale, both diatonic and chromatic, is complete without the aid of keys or pistons, and which can slide from note to note as smoothly as the human voice or a violin. Softly blown, it has a rich and mellow sound, which becomes harsh and blatant when the tones are forced; used with discretion, its effect is often solemn and majestic.
The common European bittern.

entry.ety: Cf. G. trommel a drum
entry.def: A revolving buddle or sieve for separating, or sizing, ores.

entry.ety: F. trombe trompe, a waterspout, a water-blowing machine. Cf. Trump a trumpet
entry.def: A blowing apparatus, in which air, drawn into the upper part of a vertical tube through side holes by a stream of water within, is carried down with the water into a box or chamber below which it is led to a furnace.

entry.ety: See Trump a trumpet
entry.def: A trumpet; a trump.

entry.ety: OF. trompille, equiv. to F. trompette a trumpet
entry.def: An aperture in a tromp.
See 3d Trone, 2.

entry.ety: Of Egyptian or North African origin
entry.def: A native double salt, consisting of a combination of neutral and acid sodium carbonate, Na2CO3.2HNaCO3.2H2O, occurring as a white crystalline fibrous deposit from certain soda brine springs and lakes; -- called also urao, and by the ancients nitrum.

entry.ety: From Trone a steelyard
entry.def: A toll or duty paid for weighing wool; also, the act of weighing wool.

entry.ety: LL. See Tronage
entry.def: An officer in London whose duty was to weigh wool.
A throne.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. F. trogne a belly
entry.def: A small drain.

cs.cd: a weight equivalent to nineteen and a half pounds.
a weight formerly used in Scotland, in which a pound varied from 21 to 28 ounces avoirdupois.

entry.ety: LL. trona, fr. L. trutina a balance; cf. Gr. �

sn.def: A steelyard.
A form of weighing machine for heavy wares, consisting of two horizontal bars crossing each other, beaked at the extremities, and supported by a wooden pillar. It is now mostly disused.

entry.ety: F. troupe, OF. trope trupe, LL. troppus; of uncertain origin; cf. Icel. þorp a hamlet, village, G. dorf a village, dial. G. dorf a meeting. Norw. torp a little farm, a crowd, E. thorp. Cf. Troupe

sn.def: A collection of people; a company; a number; a multitude.
sn.q: That which should accompany old age As honor, love, obedience, troops of friends I must not look to have.

sn.def: Soldiers, collectively; an army; -- now generally used in the plural.
sn.q: Farewell the plumed troop, and the big wars.
His troops moved to victory with the precision of machines.

sn.def: Specifically, a small body of cavalry, light horse, or dragoons, consisting usually of about sixty men, commanded by a captain; the unit of formation of cavalry, corresponding to the company in infantry. Formerly, also, a company of horse artillery; a battery.
A company of stageplayers; a troupe.
A particular roll of the drum; a quick march.
See Boy scout, above.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trooped; p. pr. & vb. n. Trooping

sn.def: To move in numbers; to come or gather in crowds or troops.
sn.q: Armies . . .troopto their standard.

sn.def: To march on; to go forward in haste.
sn.q: Nor do I, as an enemy to peace,Troop in the throngs of military men.

cs.mcol: To troop the colorsorTo troop the colours
cs.cd: in the British army, to perform a ceremony consisting essentially in carrying the colors, accompanied by the band and escort, slowly before the troops drawn up in single file and usually in a hollow square, as in London on the sovereign's birthday.

entry.def: Any troupial.

entry.note: The black troopers of Queensland are a regiment of aboriginal police, employed chiefly for dispersing wild aborigines who encroach on sheep runs.

cs.cd: with energy, endurance, or enthusiasm; as, to work like a trooper .

sn.def: A soldier in a body of cavalry; a cavalryman; also, the horse of a cavalryman.
A state police officer; -- also called state trooper.
A mounted policeman.
Trouper.

entry.def: The American scaup duck.
Same as Troupial.

entry.ety: Troop + -meal as in piecemeal
entry.def: By troops; in crowds.
entry.q: So, troopmeal, Troy pursued a while, laying on with swords and darts.

entry.def: A vessel built or fitted for the conveyance of troops; a transport.

entry.ety: So named after Dr. Gerard Troost, of Nashville, Tenn
entry.def: Willemite.

A name given to any one of a series of orange-red dyestuffs produced artificially from certain complex sulphonic acid derivatives of azo and diazo hydrocarbons of the aromatic series; -- so called because of the general resemblance to the shades of nasturtium (Tropæolum).

entry.note: ☞ Tropes are chiefly of four kinds: metaphor metonymy synecdoche, and irony. Some authors make figures the genus, of which trope is a species; others make them different things, defining trope to be a change of sense, and figure to be any ornament, except what becomes so by such change.
entry.ety: L. tropus, Gr. �, fr. � to turn. See Torture, and cf. Trophy Tropic Troubadour Trover
entry.def: The use of a word or expression in a different sense from that which properly belongs to it; the use of a word or expression as changed from the original signification to another, for the sake of giving life or emphasis to an idea; a figure of speech.
The word or expression so used.
entry.q: In his frequent, long, and tedious speeches, it has been said that a trope never passed his lips.

entry.def: Any one of a series of artificial ethereal salts derived from the alkaloidal base tropine.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a feeder, fr. � to feed
entry.def: The mouth parts of an insect, collectively, including the labrum, labium, maxillæ, mandibles, and lingua, with their appendages.

entry.ety: Gr. � nursing. See Trophi
entry.def: Of or connected with nutrition; nitritional; nourishing; as, the so-called trophic nerves, which have a direct influence on nutrition.
Adorned with trophies.
entry.q: The trophied arches, storied halls, invade.

entry.ety: L. Trophonianus, fr. Trophonius, Gr. �, a Grecian architect, fabled to have been the builder of the first temple of Apollo at Delphi. He was worshiped after death, and had a celebrated oracle in a cave in Bœotia
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Trophonius, his architecture, or his cave and oracle.

entry.ety: Gr. � a feeder + -some body
entry.def: The nutritive zooids of a hydroid, collectively, as distinguished from the gonosome, or reproductive zooids.

entry.ety: Gr. � a feeder + � seed: cf. F. trophosperme. See Trophi
entry.def: The placenta.

entries.entry:
Tro"phy ☞ A trophy consisted originally of some of the armor, weapons, etc., of the defeated enemy fixed to the trunk of a tree or to a post erected on an elevated site, with an inscription, and a dedication to a divinity. The Romans often erected their trophies in the Capitol.
Trophy money a duty paid formerly in England, annually, by housekeepers, toward providing harness, drums, colors, and the like, for the militia.
n.; pl.Trophies #. F. trophéecf. It. & Sp. trofeo), L. tropaeum trophaeum, Gr. �, strictly, a monument of the enemy's defeat, fr.� a turn, especially, a turning about of the enemy, a putting to flight or routing him, fr. � to turn. See Trope
Gr. & Rom. Antiq A sign or memorial of a victory raised on the field of battle, or, in case of a naval victory, on the nearest land. Sometimes trophies were erected in the chief city of the conquered people.
The representation of such a memorial, as on a medal; esp. Arch, an ornament representing a group of arms and military weapons, offensive and defensive.
Anything taken from an enemy and preserved as a memorial of victory, as arms, flags, standards, etc. Around the posts hung helmets, darts, and spears, And captive chariots, axes, shields, and bars, And broken beaks of ships, the trophies of their wars.
Any evidence or memorial of victory or conquest; as, every redeemed soul is a trophy of grace.

entry.ety: Atropine + -ic
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from atropine and certain other alkaloids, as a white crystalline substance slightly soluble in water.

entry.ety: F. tropique, L. tropicus of or belonging to a turn, i. e., of the sun, Gr. � of the solstice, � (sc. �) the tropic or solstice, fr. � to turn. See Trope

sn.def: One of the two small circles of the celestial sphere, situated on each side of the equator, at a distance of 23° 28′, and parallel to it, which the sun just reaches at its greatest declination north or south, and from which it turns again toward the equator, the northern circle being called the Tropic of Cancer, and the southern the Tropic of Capricorn, from the names of the two signs at which they touch the ecliptic.

sd.def: One of the two parallels of terrestrial latitude corresponding to the celestial tropics, and called by the same names.
The region lying between these parallels of latitude, or near them on either side.
sd.q: The brilliant flowers of the tropics bloom from the windows of the greenhouse and the saloon.

cs.cd: any one of three species of oceanic belonging to the genus Phaëthon, found chiefly in tropical seas. They are mostly white, and have two central tail feathers very long and slender. The yellow-billed tropic bird. Phaëthon flavirostriscalled also boatswain), is found on the Atlantic coast of America, and is common at the Bermudas, where it breeds.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the tropics; tropical.

entry.cs: Tropic month. See Lunar month, under Month. Tropic year the solar year; the period occupied by the sun in passing from one tropic or one equinox to the same again, having a mean length of 365 days, 5 hours, 48 minutes, 46.0 seconds, which is 20 minutes, 23.3 seconds shorter than the sidereal year, on account of the precession of the equinoxes.
entry.ety: Cf. L. tropicus of turning, Gr. �. See Tropic n.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the tropics; characteristic of, or incident to, the tropics; being within the tropics; as, tropical climate; tropical latitudes; tropical heat; tropical diseases.
Rhetorically changed from its exact original sense; being of the nature of a trope; figurative; metaphorical.
sn.q: The foundation of all parables is some analogy or similitude between the tropical or allusive part of the parable and the thing intended by it.

entry.def: In a tropical manner; figuratively; metaphorically.

entry.ety: See Tropine
entry.def: An alkaloid, C8H13N, obtained by the chemical dehydration of tropine, as an oily liquid having a coninelike odor.

entry.ety: See Tropine
entry.def: A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the dry distillation of tropine with quicklime. It is regarded as being homologous with dipropargyl.

entry.ety: From Atropine
entry.def: A white crystalline alkaloid, C8H15NO, produced by decomposing atropine.

entry.ety: Gr. troph` a turning, tre`pein to turn + -ism
entry.def: Modification of the direction of growth, caused by some external influence, such as light; -- sometimes used for motion of an organism toward or away from an external stimulus, more properly called taxis.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tropiste. See Trope
entry.def: One who deals in tropes;
one who avoids the literal sense of the language of Scripture by explaining it as mere tropes and figures of speech.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. tropologique. See Tropology
entry.def: Characterized by tropes; varied by tropes; tropical.
To use in a tropological sense, as a word; to make a trope of.
entry.q: If . . . Minerva be tropologized into prudence.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � a trope + � discourse: cf. F. tropologie
entry.def: A rhetorical mode of speech, including tropes, or changes from the original import of the word.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Too much; as, allegro ma non troppo, brisk but not too much so.
Trousers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trotted; p. pr. & vb. n. Trotting
entry.ety: OE. trotten, OF. troter, F. trotter; probably of Teutonic origin, and akin to E. tread; cf. OHG. trott�n to tread. See Tread

sn.def: To proceed by a certain gait peculiar to quadrupeds; to ride or drive at a trot. See Trot n.
Fig.: To run; to jog; to hurry.
sn.q: He that rises late must trot all day, and will scarcely overtake his business at night.

cs.cd: to lead or bring out, as a horse, to show his paces; hence, to bring forward, as for exhibition.

entry.def: To cause to move, as a horse or other animal, in the pace called a trot; to cause to run without galloping or cantering.

entry.ety: F. See Trot v. i.

sn.def: The pace of a horse or other quadruped, more rapid than a walk, but of various degrees of swiftness, in which one fore foot and the hind foot of the opposite side are lifted at the same time.
sn.q: The limbs move diagonally in pairs in thetrot.

sn.def: Fig.: A jogging pace, as of a person hurrying.
One who trots; a child; a woman.
sn.q: An old trot with ne'er a tooth.

entry.ety: A variant of truth. See Truth

sn.def: Belief; faith; fidelity.
sn.q: Bid her alight And hertroth plight.

sn.def: Truth; verity; veracity; as, by my troth .
sn.q: In troth, thou art able to instruct gray hairs.

sn.def: Betrothal.

entry.def: Faitless; false; treacherous.
entry.q: Thrall to the faithless waves and trothless sky.

entry.def: To betroth.
Betrothed; espoused; affianced.
The act of betrothing, or plighting faith; betrothing.
Having fidelity pledged.

sn.def: One that trots; especially, a horse trained to be driven in trotting matches.
The foot of an animal, especially that of a sheep; also, humorously, the human foot.

entry.ety: F., from trotter to trot. See Trot
entry.def: Footpath; pavement; sidewalk.
entry.q: Headless bodies trailed along the trottoirs.

entry.ety: F. troubadour, fr. Pr. trobador, (assumed) LL. tropator a singer, tropare to sing, fr. tropus a kind of singing, a melody, song, L. tropus a trope, a song, Gr. � a turn, way, manner, particular mode in music, a trope. See Trope, and cf. Trouv�re
entry.def: One of a school of poets who flourished from the eleventh to the thirteenth century, principally in Provence, in the south of France, and also in the north of Italy. They invented, and especially cultivated, a kind of lyrical poetry characterized by intricacy of meter and rhyme, and usually of a romantic, amatory strain.
Causing trouble; troublesome.
entry.q: troublableire.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Troubled; p. pr. & vb. n. Troubling
entry.ety: F. troubler, OF. trobler trubler tourbler,fr. (assumed) LL. turbulare, L. turbare to disorderly group, a little crowd; both from turba a disorder, tumult, crowd; akin to Gr. �, and perhaps to E. thorp; cf. Skr. tvar tur,o hasten. Cf. Turbid

sn.def: To put into confused motion; to disturb; to agitate.
sn.q: An angel went down at a certain season into the pool, and troubled the water.
God looking forth will trouble all his host.

sn.def: To disturb; to perplex; to afflict; to distress; to grieve; to fret; to annoy; to vex.
sn.q: Now is my soul troubled.
Take the boy to you; he so troubles me 'T is past enduring.
Never trouble yourself about those faults which age will cure.

sn.def: To give occasion for labor to; -- used in polite phraseology; as, I will not trouble you to deliver the letter.
sn.syn: To disturb; perplex; afflict; distress; grieve; harass; annoy; tease; vex; molest.

entry.def: Troubled; dark; gloomy.
entry.q: With fulltroublecheer.

cs.cd: to get into difficulty or danger.
to be at the pains; to exert one's self; to give one's self inconvenience.
cs.q: She never took the trouble to close them.

entry.ety: F. trouble, OF. troble truble. See Trouble v. t.

sn.def: The state of being troubled; disturbance; agitation; uneasiness; vexation; calamity.
sn.q: Lest the fiend . . . some new trouble raise.
Foul whisperings are abroad; unnatural deeds Do breed unnatural troubles.

sn.def: That which gives disturbance, annoyance, or vexation; that which afflicts.
A fault or interruption in a stratum.
sn.syn: Affliction; disturbance; perplexity; annoyance; molestation; vexation; inconvenience; calamity; misfortune; adversity; embarrassment; anxiety; sorrow; misery.

entry.def: One who troubles or disturbs; one who afflicts or molests; a disturber; as, a troubler of the peace.
entry.q: The rich troublers of the world's repose.

entry.def: Giving trouble or anxiety; vexatious; burdensome; wearisome.
entry.q: This troublesome world.
These troublesome disguises that we wear.
My mother will never be troublesome to me.
entry.syn: Uneasy; vexatious; perplexing; harassing; annoying; disgusting; irksome; afflictive; burdensome; tiresome; wearisome; importunate.

entry.def: Full of trouble; causing trouble.
entry.q: In doubtful time oftroublousneed.
A tall ship tossed in troublous seas.

entries.entry: Trou"-de-loup" Trou"-de-loup" n.; pl.Trous-de-loup. F. trou hole + de of + loup wolf Mil A pit in the form of an inverted cone or pyramid, constructed as an obstacle to the approach of an enemy, and having a pointed stake in the middle. The pits are called also trapholes.

cs.cd: a rectangular or V-shaped gutter, usually hung below the eaves of a house.
the depression between two waves.

entry.ety: OE. trough trogh, AS. trog troh; akin to D., G., & Icel. trog, Sw. tråg, Dan. trug; probably originally meaning, made of wood, and akin to E. tree. √63 & 241. See Tree, and cf. Trug

sn.def: A long, hollow vessel, generally for holding water or other liquid, especially one formed by excavating a log longitudinally on one side; a long tray; also, a wooden channel for conveying water, as to a mill wheel.
Any channel, receptacle, or depression, of a long and narrow shape; as, trough between two ridges, etc.
The transverse section of a cyclonic area where the barometric pressure, neither rising nor falling, has reached its lowest point.

entry.def: Any bivalve shell of the genus Mactra. See Mactra.
See Troll.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trounced; p. pr. & vb. n. Trouncing
entry.ety: F. tronce tronche, a stump, piece of wood. See Truncheon
entry.def: To punish or beat severely; to whip smartly; to flog; to castigate.

entry.ety: F., troop. See Troop
entry.def: A company or troop, especially the company pf performers in a play or an opera.

entry.ety: F. troupiale
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of bright-colored American birds belonging to Icterus and allied genera, especially Icterus icterus, a native of the West Indies and South America. Many of the species are called orioles in America.
Trousers.
Cloth or material for making trousers.

entry.ety: OF. trousses breeches worn by pages, from trousse trosse, a bundle, a truss. See Truss, and cf. Trossers Trouse
entry.def: A garment worn by men and boys, extending from the waist to the knee or to the ankle, and covering each leg separately.

entry.ety: F. See Truss; cf. Trousseau
entry.def: A case for small implements; as, a surgeon's trousse .

entry.ety: F., fr. OF. trossel, dim. of trousse a bundle, truss. See Truss
entry.def: The collective lighter equipments or outfit of a bride, including clothes, jewelry, and the like; especially, that which is provided for her by her family.

entry.note: ☞ The most important European species are the river, or brown, trout (Salmo fario), the salmon trout, and the sewen. The most important American species are the brook, speckled, or red-spotted, trout (Salvelinus fontinalis) of the Northern United States and Canada; the red-spotted trout, or Dolly Varden (see Malma); the lake trout (see Namaycush); the black-spotted, mountain, or silver, trout (Salmo purpuratus); the golden, or rainbow, trout (see under Rainbow); the blueback trout (see Oquassa); and the salmon trout (see under Salmon.) The European trout has been introduced into America.

cs.cd: a small fresh-water American fish (Percopsis guttatus), allied to the trout, but resembling a perch in its scales and mouth.

entry.ety: AS. truht, L. tructa tructus; akin to Gr. trw`kths a sea fish with sharp teeth, fr. trw`gein to gnaw

sn.def: Any one of numerous species of fishes belonging to Salmo Salvelinus, and allied genera of the family Salmonidæ. They are highly esteemed as game fishes and for the quality of their flesh. All the species breed in fresh water, but after spawning many of them descend to the sea if they have an opportunity.

Any one of several species of marine fishes more or less resembling a trout in appearance or habits, but not belonging to the same family, especially the California rock trouts, the common squeteague, and the southern, or spotted, squeteague; -- called also salt-water trout sea trout shad trout, and gray trout. See Squeteague, and Rock trout under Rock.

entry.def: The American golden plover.
White, with spots of black, bay, or sorrel; as, a trout-colored horse.
A little trout; a troutling.
A little trout; a troutlet.

entry.ety: F. trouveur trouvère. See Troubadour
entry.def: One of a school of poets who flourished in Northern France from the eleventh to the fourteenth century.

entry.ety: OF. trover truver, to find, F. trouver; probably originally, to invent or compose (melodies), fr. (assumed) LL. tropare. See Troubadour Trope, and cf. Contrive Reirieve Trouveur
entry.def: The gaining possession of any goods, whether by finding or by other means.

An action to recover damages against one who found goods, and would not deliver them to the owner on demand; an action which lies in any case to recover the value of goods wrongfully converted by another to his own use. In this case the finding, though alleged, is an immaterial fact; the injury lies in the conversion.
A boat with an open well amidships. It is used in spearing fish.

entry.note: ☞ I trow, or trow alone, was formerly sometimes added to questions to express contemptuous or indignant surprise.
entry.ety: OE. trowen, AS. treówan to trust, believe, fr. treów trust, treówe true, faithful. See True
entry.def: To believe; to trust; to think or suppose.
entry.q: So that ye trow in Christ, and you baptize.
A better priest, I trow, there nowhere none is.
It never yet was worn, I trow.
What tempest, I trow, threw this whale . . . ashore?
What is the matter, trow?

entry.cs: Trowel bayonet. See Spade bayonet, under Spade. Fish trowel. See Fish slice, under Fish.
entry.ety: OE. truel, OF. truele, F. truelle, LL. truella, L. trulla, dim. of trua a ladle; probably akin to Gr. � a stirrer, ladle, G. quirl a stirrer, MHG. twirel, OHG. dwiril, Icel. þvara, AS. þwiril. Cf. Twirl

sn.def: A mason's tool, used in spreading and dressing mortar, and breaking bricks to shape them.
A gardener's tool, somewhat like a scoop, used in taking up plants, stirring the earth, etc.
A tool used for smoothing a mold.

entries.entry:
