Trow"eled. Formed with a trowel; smoothed with a trowel; as, troweled stucco, that is, stucco laid on and ready for the reception of paint.
trowelled
Trow"el*ful n.; pl.Trowelfuls. As much as a trowel will hold; enough to fill a trowel.

entry.def: See Troll.
Wearing trousers.
Same as Trousers.

cs.cd: the weight which gold and silver, jewels, and the like, are weighed. It was so named from Troyes, in France, where it was first adopted in Europe. The troy ounce is supposed to have been brought from Cairo during the crusades. In this weight the pound is divided into 12 ounces, the ounce into 20 pennyweights, and the pennyweight into 24 grains; hence, the troy ounce contains 480 grains, and the troy pound contains 5760 grains. The avoirdupois pound contains 7000 troy grains; so that 175 pounds troy equal 144 pounds avoirdupois, or 1 pound troy = 0.82286 of a pound avoirdupois, and 1 ounce troy = 117/175 or 1.09714 ounce avoirdupois. Troy weight when divided, the pound into 12 ounces, the ounce into 8 drams, the dram into 3 scruples, and the scruple into 20 grains, is called apothecaries' weight, used in weighing medicines, etc. In the standard weights of the United States, the troy ounce is divided decimally down to the 1/10000 part.

entry.def: Troy weight.
See Troy ounce, under Troy weight, above, and under Ounce.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. truage a tax. See True

sn.def: A pledge of truth or peace made on payment of a tax.
A tax or impost; tribute.

entry.def: The act of playing truant, or the state of being truant; as, addicted to truancy .
See Truant.

cs.cd: to stray away; to loiter; especially, to stay out of school without leave.

entry.ety: F. truand, OF. truant, a vagrant, beggar; of Celtic origin; cf. W. tru truan, wretched, miserable, truan a wretch, Ir. trogha miserable, Gael. truaghan a poor, distressed, or wretched creature, truagh wretched
entry.def: One who stays away from business or any duty; especially, one who stays out of school without leave; an idler; a loiterer; a shirk.
entry.q: I have a truant been to chivalry.

entry.def: Wandering from business or duty; loitering; idle, and shirking duty; as, a truant boy.
entry.q: While truant Jove, in infant pride, Played barefoot on Olympus' side.

entry.ety: Cf. F. truander
entry.def: To idle away time; to loiter, or wander; to play the truant.
entry.q: By this means they lost their time and truanted on the fundamental grounds of saving knowledge.

entry.def: To idle away; to waste.
entry.q: I dare not be the author Of truanting the time.

entry.def: Like a truant; in idleness.
The conduct of a truant; neglect of employment; idleness; truancy.

entry.ety: Cf. Truffle
entry.def: A truffle.

entry.ety: Prov. E. trub slut; cf. Sw. trubbig stumpy
entry.def: A short, squat woman.
An East India herring (Clupea toli) which is extensively caught for the sake of its roe and for its flesh.

cs.cd: a white flag carried or exhibited by one of the hostile parties, during the flying of which hostilities are suspended.
a suspension of arms promulgated by the church, which occasionally took place in the Middle Ages, putting a stop to private hostilities at or within certain periods.

entry.ety: OE. trewes triwes treowes, pl. of trewe a truce, properly, pledge of fidelity, truth, AS. treów fidelity, faith, troth. See True

sn.def: A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposing forces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation or other purpose; an armistice.
Hence, intermission of action, pain, or contest; temporary cessation; short quiet.
sn.q: Where he may likeliest findTruce to his restless thoughts.

entry.def: One who violates a truce, covenant, or engagement.
Without a truce; unforbearing.
entry.q: Two minds in one, and each a truceless guest.

entry.ety: Cf. F. trucheman. See Dragoman
entry.def: An interpreter. See Dragoman.
entry.q: And after, by the tongue, Her truchman, she reports the mind's each throw.

entry.ety: L. trucidatio, fr. trucidare to slaughter
entry.def: The act of killing.

entry.ety: L. trochus an iron hoop, Gr. � a wheel, fr. � to run. See Trochee, and cf. Truckle v. i.

sn.def: A small wheel, as of a vehicle; specifically Ord, a small strong wheel, as of wood or iron, for a gun carriage.
A low, wheeled vehicle or barrow for carrying goods, stone, and other heavy articles.
sn.q: Goods were conveyed about the town almost exclusively in trucks drawn by dogs.

sn.def: A swiveling carriage, consisting of a frame with one or more pairs of wheels and the necessary boxes, springs, etc., to carry and guide one end of a locomotive or a car; -- sometimes called bogie in England. Trucks usually have four or six wheels.

sd.def: A small wooden cap at the summit of a flagstaff or a masthead, having holes in it for reeving halyards through.
A small piece of wood, usually cylindrical or disk-shaped, used for various purposes.

sn.def: A freight car.
A frame on low wheels or rollers; -- used for various purposes, as for a movable support for heavy bodies.
a motorized vehicle larger than an automobile with a compartment in front for the driver, behind which is a separate compartment for freight;

sd.def: such a vehicle with an inflexible body.
A vehicle with a short body and a support for attaching a trailer; -- also called a tractor{4.
the combination of tractor and trailer, also called a tractor-trailera form of articulated vehicle); it is a common form of truck, and is used primarily for hauling freight on a highway.
a tractor with more than one trailer attached in a series. In Australia, often referred to as a road train.

entry.def: To transport on a truck or trucks.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trucked; p. pr. & vb. n. trucking
entry.ety: OE. trukken,F. troquer; akin to Sp. & Pg. trocar; of uncertain origin
entry.def: To exchange; to give in exchange; to barter; as, to truck knives for gold dust.
entry.q: We will begin by supposing the international trade to be in form, what it always is in reality, an actual trucking of one commodity against another.

entry.def: To exchange commodities; to barter; to trade; to deal.
entry.q: A master of a ship, who deceived them under color of trucking with them.
Despotism itself is obliged to truck and huckster.
To truck and higgle for a private good.

cs.cd: vegetables raised for market. Colloq U. S Truck farming, raising vegetables for market: market gardening.

entry.ety: Cf. F. troc

sn.def: Exchange of commodities; barter.
Commodities appropriate for barter, or for small trade; small commodities; esp., in the United States, garden vegetables raised for the market.
The practice of paying wages in goods instead of money; -- called also truck system.

entry.def: The practice of bartering goods; exchange; barter; truck.
entry.q: The truckage of perishing coin.

entry.def: Money paid for the conveyance of goods on a truck; freight.
One who trucks; a trafficker.
entry.q: No man having ever yet driven a saving bargain with this great trucker for souls.

entry.def: The business of conveying goods on trucks.

entry.ety: Dim. of truck a wheel; or from the kindred L. trochlea a block, sheaf containing one or more pulleys. See Truck a wheel
entry.def: A small wheel or caster.

entry.ety: From truckle in truckle-bed, in allusion to the fact that the truckle-bed on which the pupil slept was rolled under the large bed of the master
entry.def: To yield or bend obsequiously to the will of another; to submit; to creep.
entry.q: Small,truckingstates.
Religion itself is forced to truckle to worldly poliey.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Truckled; p. pr. & vb. n. Truckling
entry.def: To roll or move upon truckles, or casters; to trundle.
A low bed on wheels, that may be pushed under another bed; a trundle-bed.
entry.q: His standing bed andtruckle-bed.

entry.def: One who truckles, or yields servilely to the will of another.

entries.entry:
Truck"man n.; pl.Truckmen #.
From Truck barter One who does business in the way of barter or exchange.
From Truck a carriage One who drives a truck, or whose business is the conveyance of goods on trucks.

entry.ety: L. truculentia
entry.def: The quality or state of being truculent; savageness of manners; ferociousness.

entry.ety: L. truculentus, fr. trux, gen. trucis, wild, fierce: cf. F. truculent

sn.def: Fierce; savage; ferocious; barbarous; as, the truculent inhabitants of Scythia.
Cruel; destructive; ruthless.
sn.q: More or less truculent plagues.

entry.def: In a truculent manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trudged; p. pr. & vb. n. Trudging
entry.ety: Perhaps of Scand. origin, and originally meaning, to walk on snowshoes; cf. dial. Sw. truga trudja, a snowshoe, Norw. truga, Icel. þrūga
entry.def: To walk or march with labor; to jog along; to move wearily.
entry.q: And trudged to Rome upon my naked feet.

entry.def: A truchman.

entries.entry: Trudg"en stroke. Swimming A racing stroke in which a double over-arm motion is used; -- so called from its use by an amateur named Trudgen, but often erroneously written trudgeon.

entry.note: ☞ True is sometimes used elliptically for It is true.
entry.cs: Out of true varying from correct mechanical form, alignment, adjustment, etc.; -- said of a wall that is not perpendicular, of a wheel whose circumference is not in the same plane, and the like. Colloq A true bill Law a bill of indictment which is returned by the grand jury so indorsed, signifying that the charges to be true. True time. See under Time.
entry.ety: OE. trewe, AS. treówe faithful, true, from treów fidelity, faith, troth; akin to OFries. triuwe, adj., treuwa, n., OS. triuwi, adj., trewa, n., D. trouw, adj. & n., G. treu, adj., treue, n., OHG. gitriuwi, adj., triuwa n., Icel. tryggr, adj., Dan. tro, adj. & n., Sw. trogen, adj., tro, n., Goth. triggws, adj., triggwa, n., trauan to trust, OPruss druwis faith. Cf. Trow Trust Truth

sn.def: Conformable to fact; in accordance with the actual state of things; correct; not false, erroneous, inaccurate, or the like; as, a true relation or narration; a true history; a declaration is true when it states the facts.
Right to precision; conformable to a rule or pattern; exact; accurate; as, a true copy; a true likeness of the original.
sn.q: Making his eye, foot, and hand keep true time.

sn.def: Steady in adhering to friends, to promises, to a prince, or the like; unwavering; faithful; loyal; not false, fickle, or perfidious; as, a true friend; a wife true to her husband; an officer true to his charge.
sn.q: Thy so true, So faithful, love unequaled.
Dare to be true: nothing can need a lie.

sn.def: Actual; not counterfeit, adulterated, or pretended; genuine; pure; real; as, true balsam; true love of country; a true Christian.
sn.q: The true light which lighteth every man that cometh into the world.
True ease in writing comes from art, not chance.

sn.def: Genuine; real; not deviating from the essential characters of a class; as, a lizard is a true reptile; a whale is a true, but not a typical, mammal.

entry.def: In accordance with truth; truly.
Of inflexible honesty and fidelity; -- a term derived from the true, or Coventry blue, formerly celebrated for its unchanging color. See True blue, under Blue.
A person of inflexible integrity or fidelity.
Of genuine birth; having a right by birth to any title; as, a true-born Englishman.

sn.def: Of a genuine or right breed; as, a true-bred beast.
Being of real breeding or education; as, a true-bred gentleman.

entry.def: Of a faithful heart; honest; sincere; not faithless or deceitful; as, a truhearted friend.

cs.cd: a complicated, involved knot that does not readily untie; the emblem of interwoven affection or engagement; -- called also true-lover's knot.

sn.def: One really beloved.
A plant. See Paris.
An unexplained word occurring in Chaucer, meaning, perhaps, an aromatic sweetmeat for sweetening the breath.
sn.q: Under his tongue a truelove he bore.

entry.def: The quality of being true; reality; genuineness; faithfulness; sincerity; exactness; truth.
An honest fellow.

cs.cd: the larva of a fly of the genus Leiodes, injurious to truffles.

entry.ety: OF. trufle, F. truffe; akin to Sp. trufa tartufo; of uncertain origin; perhaps from L. tuber a tumor, knob, truffle. Cf. Tuber Trifle
entry.def: Any one of several kinds of roundish, subterranean fungi, usually of a blackish color. The French truffle (Tuber melanosporum) and the English truffle (Tuber æstivum) are much esteemed as articles of food.
Provided or cooked with truffles; stuffed with truffles; as, a truffled turkey.

entry.ety: Cf. Trough
entry.sn:
A trough, or tray. Specifically: A hod for mortar.
An old measure of wheat equal to two thirds of a bushel.

sn.def: A concubine; a harlot.

entry.ety: See Trug n., 2
entry.def: A brothel.

entry.ety: From True
entry.def: An undoubted or self-evident truth; a statement which is pliantly true; a proposition needing no proof or argument; -- opposed to falsism.
entry.q: Trifling truisms clothed in great, swelling words.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to truisms; consisting of truisms.

entry.ety: F., fr. truite trout
entry.def: Having a delicately crackled surface; -- applied to porcelian, etc.

entry.ety: G. trolle trulle; cf. OD. drol a jester, Dan. trold an elf, imp, Sw. troll a goblin, Icel. troll tröll, a giant, fiend, demon. Cf. Droll Troll

sn.def: A drab; a strumpet; a harlot; a trollop.
A girl; a wench; a lass.

entry.ety: L. trullissatio, from trullissare to trowel, to plaster, fr. trulla a trowel
entry.def: The act of laying on coats of plaster with a trowel.

entry.ety: From True

sn.def: In a true manner; according to truth; in agreement with fact; as, to state things truly; the facts are truly represented.
sn.q: I can not truly say how I came here.

sn.def: Exactly; justly; precisely; accurately; as, to estimate truly the weight of evidence.
Sincerely; honestly; really; faithfully; as, to be truly attached to a lover; the citizens are truly loyal to their prince or their country.
Conformably to law; legally; legitimately.
sn.q: His innocent babe [istruly begotten.

sn.def: In fact; in deed; in reality; in truth.
sn.q: Beauty is excelled by manly grace And wisdom, which alone is truly fair.

entry.ety: OE. trumpe trompe, F. trompe; probably fr. L. triumphare to triumph, to exult, hence, probably, to make a joyous sound or noise. See Triumph v. i. & n., and cf. Trombone Tromp Trump at cards, Trumpery Trumpet Trunk a proboscis
entry.def: A wind instrument of music; a trumpet, or sound of a trumpet; -- used chiefly in Scripture and poetry.
entry.q: We shall all be changed, in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump.
The wakeful trump of doom.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. tromper. See Trump a trumpet
entry.def: To blow a trumpet.

cs.mcol: To put to one's trumpsorTo put on one's trumps
cs.cd: to force to the last expedient, or to the utmost exertion.

entry.ety: A corruption of triumph, F. triomphe. See Triumph, and cf. Trump a trumpet

sn.def: A winning card; one of a particular suit (usually determined by chance for each deal) any card of which takes any card of the other suits.
An old game with cards, nearly the same as whist; -- called also ruff.
A good fellow; an excellent person.
sn.q: Alfred is a trump, I think you say.
But when kings come so low as to fawn upon philosophy, which before they neither valued nor understood, it is a sign that fails not, they are then put to their last trump.
Put the housekeeper to her trumps to accommodate them.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trumped; p. pr. & vb. n. Trumping
entry.def: To play a trump card when one of another suit has been led.
To play a trump card upon; to take with a trump card; as, she trumped the first trick.

cs.cd: to devise; to collect with unfairness; to fabricate; as, to trump up a charge.

entry.ety: F. tromper to deceive, in OF., to blow a trumpet, se tromper de to mock. See Trump a trumpet

sn.def: To trick, or impose on; to deceive.
sn.q: To trick ortrumpmankind.

sn.def: To impose unfairly; to palm off.
sn.q: Authors have been trumped upon us.

entry.ety: F. tromperie deceit, fr. tromper to deceive. See Trump to trick

sn.def: Deceit; fraud.
Something serving to deceive by false show or pretense; falsehood; deceit; worthless but showy matter; hence, things worn out and of no value; rubbish.
sn.q: The trumpery in my house, go bring it hither, for state to catch these thieves.
Upon the coming of Christ, very much, though not all, of this idolatrous trumpery and superstition was driven out of the world.

entry.def: Worthless or deceptive in character.
entry.q: Atrumperylittle ring.

entry.cs: Ear trumpet. See under Ear. Sea trumpet Bot a great seaweed (Ecklonia buccinalis) of the Southern Ocean. It has a long, hollow stem, enlarging upwards, which may be made into a kind of trumpet, and is used for many purposes. Speaking trumpet an instrument for conveying articulate sounds with increased force. Trumpet animalcule Zoöl any infusorian belonging to Stentor and allied genera, in which the body is trumpet-shaped. See Stentor. Trumpet ash Bot the trumpet creeper. Eng Trumpet conch Zoöl a trumpet shell, or triton. Trumpet creeper Bot an American climbing plant (Tecoma radicans) bearing clusters of large red trumpet-shaped flowers; -- called also trumpet flower, and in England trumpet ash. Trumpet fish. Zoöl The bellows fish. The fistularia. Trumpet flower. Bot The trumpet creeper; also, its blossom. The trumpet honeysuckle. A West Indian name for several plants with trumpet-shaped flowers. Trumpet fly Zoöl a botfly. Trumpet honeysuckle Bot a twining plant (Lonicera sempervirens) with red and yellow trumpet-shaped flowers; -- called also trumpet flower. Trumpet leaf Bot a name of several plants of the genus Sarracenia. Trumpet major Mil the chief trumpeter of a band or regiment. Trumpet marine Mus a monochord, having a thick string, sounded with a bow, and stopped with the thumb so as to produce the harmonic tones; -- said to be the oldest bowed instrument known, and in form the archetype of all others. It probably owes its name to “its external resemblance to the large speaking trumpet used on board Italian vessels, which is of the same length and tapering shape.” Grove. Trumpet shell Zoöl any species of large marine univalve shells belonging to Triton and allied genera. See Triton, 2. Trumpet tree. Bot See Trumpetwood.
entry.ety: F. trompette, dim. of trompe. See Trump a trumpet

sn.def: A wind instrument of great antiquity, much used in war and military exercises, and of great value in the orchestra. In consists of a long metallic tube, curved (once or twice) into a convenient shape, and ending in a bell. Its scale in the lower octaves is limited to the first natural harmonics; but there are modern trumpets capable, by means of valves or pistons, of producing every tone within their compass, although at the expense of the true ringing quality of tone.
sn.q: The trumpet's loud clangor Excites us to arms.

sn.def: A trumpeter.
One who praises, or propagates praise, or is the instrument of propagating it.
sn.q: That great politician was pleased to have the greatest wit of those times . . . to be the trumpet of his praises.

sn.def: A funnel, or short, fiaring pipe, used as a guide or conductor, as for yarn in a knitting machine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trumpeted; p. pr. & vb. n. Trumpeting
entry.ety: Cf. F. trompeter
entry.def: To publish by, or as by, sound of trumpet; to noise abroad; to proclaim; as, to trumpet good tidings.
entry.q: They did nothing but publish and trumpet all the reproaches they could devise against the Irish.

entry.def: To sound loudly, or with a tone like a trumpet; to utter a trumplike cry.

sn.def: One who sounds a trumpet.
One who proclaims, publishes, or denounces.
sn.q: These men are good trumpeters.

sd.def: Any one of several species of long-legged South American birds of the genus Psophia, especially Psophia crepitans, which is abundant, and often domesticated and kept with other poultry by the natives. They are allied to the cranes. So called from their loud cry. Called also agami, and yakamik.
A variety of the domestic pigeon.
An American swan (Olor buccinator) which has a very loud note.

sn.def: A large edible fish (Latris hecateia) of the family Cirrhitidæ, native of Tasmania and New Zealand. It sometimes weighs as much as fifty or sixty pounds, and is highly esteemed as a food fish.

entry.def: A channel cut behind the brick lining of a shaft.
A plant (Sarracenia flava) with long, hollow leaves.
Tubular with one end dilated, as the flower of the trumpet creeper.
Having a powerful, far-reaching voice or speech.
An herbaceous composite plant (Eupatorium purpureum), often having hollow stems, and bearing purplish flowers in small corymbed heads.
The sea trumpet.
A tropical American tree (Cecropia peltata) of the Breadfruit family, having hollow stems, which are used for wind instruments; -- called also snakewood, and trumpet tree.
The Richardson's skua (Stercorarius parasiticus).
Resembling a trumpet, esp. in sound; as, a trumplike voice.
Of or pertaining to the trunk, or body.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Truncated; p. pr. & vb. n. Truncating
entry.ety: L. truncatus, p. p. of truncare to cut off, mutilate, fr. truncus maimed, mutilated, cut short. See Trunk
entry.def: To cut off; to lop; to maim.

entry.ety: L. truncatus, p. p.
entry.def: Appearing as if cut off at the tip; as, a truncate leaf or feather.

cs.cd: a cone or pyramid whose vertex is cut off by a plane, the plane being usually parallel to the base.

sn.def: Cut off; cut short; maimed.
Replaced, or cut off, by a plane, especially when equally inclined to the adjoining faces; as, a truncated edge.
Lacking the apex; -- said of certain spiral shells in which the apex naturally drops off.

entry.ety: L. truncatio

sn.def: The act of truncating, lopping, or cutting off.
The state of being truncated.
The replacement of an edge or solid angle by a plane, especially when the plane is equally inclined to the adjoining faces.

entry.ety: See Truncheon
entry.def: A stake; a small post.

entry.ety: OE. tronchoun the shaft of a broken spear, broken piece, OF. tronchon tron�on, F. tron�on, fr. OF. & F. tronce tronche, a piece of wood; cf. OF. trons tros trois; all perhaps from L. thyrsus a stalk, stem, staff. See Thyrsus, and cf. Trounce

sn.def: A short staff, a club; a cudgel; a shaft of a spear.
sn.q: With his truncheon he so rudely struck.

sn.def: A baton, or military staff of command.
sn.q: The marshal's truncheon nor the judges robe.

sn.def: A stout stem, as of a tree, with the branches lopped off, to produce rapid growth.

entry.def: To beat with a truncheon.
Having a truncheon.
A person armed with a truncheon.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: The thorax of an insect. See Trunk n., 5.

entry.ety: AS. tryndel a little shield. See Trend v. i.

sn.def: A round body; a little wheel.
A lind of low-wheeled cart; a truck.
A motion as of something moving upon little wheels or rollers; a rolling motion.

sd.def: A lantern wheel. See under Lantern.
One of the bars of a lantern wheel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trundled; p. pr. & vb. n. Trundling

sn.def: To roll (a thing) on little wheels; as, to trundle a bed or a gun carriage.
To cause to roll or revolve; to roll along; as, to trundle a hoop or a ball.
To go or move on small wheels; as, a bed trundles under another.
To roll, or go by revolving, as a hoop.

entry.def: A low bed that is moved on trundles, or little wheels, so that it can be pushed under a higher bed; a truckle-bed; also, sometimes, a simiral bed without wheels.

sn.def: One of the disks forming the ends of a lantern wheel or pinion.
The drumhead of a capstan; especially, the drumhead of the lower of two capstans on the sane axis.

entry.def: A round or curled-up tail; also, a dog with such a tail.

cs.cd: a marine engine, the piston rod of which is a trunk. See Trunk, 10.
large breeches formerly worn, reaching to the knees.
the main line of a railway, canal, or route of conveyance.
the leatherback.

entry.ety: F. tronc, L. truncus, fr. truncus maimed, mutilated; perhaps akin to torquere to twist wrench, and E. torture. Trunk in the sense of proboscis is fr. F. trompethe same word as trompe a trumpet), but has been confused in English with trunk the stem of a tree (see Trump a trumpet). Cf. Truncate

sn.def: The stem, or body, of a tree, apart from its limbs and roots; the main stem, without the branches; stock; stalk.
sn.q: About the mossy trunk I wound me soon, For, high from ground, the branches would require Thy utmost reach.

sn.def: The body of an animal, apart from the head and limbs.
The main body of anything; as, the trunk of a vein or of an artery, as distinct from the branches.
That part of a pilaster which is between the base and the capital, corresponding to the shaft of a column.
That segment of the body of an insect which is between the head and abdomen, and bears the wings and legs; the thorax; the truncus.

sd.def: The proboscis of an elephant.
The proboscis of an insect.

sn.def: A long tube through which pellets of clay, p�as, etc., are driven by the force of the breath.
sn.q: He shot sugarplums them out of a trunk.

sn.def: A box or chest usually covered with leather, metal, or cloth, or sometimes made of leather, hide, or metal, for containing clothes or other goods; especially, one used to convey the effects of a traveler.
sn.q: Locked up in chests and trunks.

sn.def: A flume or sluice in which ores are separated from the slimes in which they are contained.

A large pipe forming the piston rod of a steam engine, of sufficient diameter to allow one end of the connecting rod to be attached to the crank, and the other end to pass within the pipe directly to the piston, thus making the engine more compact.
A long, large box, pipe, or conductor, made of plank or metal plates, for various uses, as for conveying air to a mine or to a furnace, water to a mill, grain to an elevator, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tronquer. See Truncate

sn.def: To lop off; to curtail; to truncate; to maim.
sn.q: Out of thetrunkedstock.

sn.def: To extract (ores) from the slimes in which they are contained, by means of a trunk. See Trunk n., 9.

entry.def: The leatherback.
Having (such) a trunk.
entry.q: Thickset with strong and well-trunked trees.

entries.entry: Trunk engine. An engine having a trunk piston, as most internal combustion engines.

entry.def: Any one of several species of plectognath fishes, belonging to the genus Ostracion, or the family Ostraciontidæ, having an angular body covered with a rigid integument consisting of bony scales. Some of the species are called also coffer fish, and boxfish.

entries.entry: Trunk"ful n.; pl.Trunkfuls. As much as a trunk will hold; enough to fill a trunk.

Trunk piston. In a single-acting engine, an elongated hollow piston, open at the end, in which the end of the connecting rod is pivoted. The piston rod, crosshead and stuffing box are thus dispensed with.
Trunk steamer. A freight steamer having a high hatch coaming extending almost continuously fore and aft, but not of whaleback form at the sides.

entry.def: Work or devices suitable to be concealed; a secret stratagem.
A trundle.
See Treenail.

cs.cd: a plate in the carriage of a gun, mortar, or howitzer, which covers the upper part of the cheek, and forms a bearing under the trunnion.
a ring on a cannon next before the trunnions.

entry.ety: OF. trognon the stock, stump, or truck of a tree, F. trognon a core, stalk, fr. tron a trunk, stem. Cf. Trunk

sn.def: A cylindrical projection on each side of a piece, whether gun, mortar, or howitzer, serving to support it on the cheeks of the carriage. See Illust. of Cannon.
A gudgeon on each side of an oscillating steam cylinder, to support it. It is usually tubular, to convey steam.

entry.def: Provided with trunnions; as, the trunnioned cylinder of an oscillating steam engine.

entry.ety: L. trudere trusum, to thrust, shove: cf. F. trusion
entry.def: The act of pushing or thrusting.

entry.note: ☞ A truss of hay in England is 56 lbs. of old and 60 lbs. of new hay; a truss of straw is 36 lbs.

cs.cd: a rod which forms the tension member of a trussed beam, or a tie rod in a truss.

entry.ety: OE. trusse, F. trousse, OF. also tourse; perhaps fr. L. tryrsus stalk, stem. Cf. Thyrsus Torso Trousers Trousseau

sn.def: A bundle; a package; as, a truss of grass.
sn.q: Bearing a truss of trifles at his back.

sn.def: A padded jacket or dress worn under armor, to protect the body from the effects of friction; also, a part of a woman's dress; a stomacher.
sn.q: Puts off his palmer's weed unto his truss, which bore The stains of ancient arms.

sn.def: A bandage or apparatus used in cases of hernia, to keep up the reduced parts and hinder further protrusion, and for other purposes.
A tuft of flowers formed at the top of the main stalk, or stem, of certain plants.
The rope or iron used to keep the center of a yard to the mast.

An assemblage of members of wood or metal, supported at two points, and arranged to transmit pressure vertically to those points, with the least possible strain across the length of any member. Architectural trusses when left visible, as in open timber roofs, often contain members not needed for construction, or are built with greater massiveness than is requisite, or are composed in unscientific ways in accordance with the exigencies of style.

entry.cs:
To truss a personorTo truss one's self
to adjust and fasten the clothing of; especially, to draw tight and tie the laces of garments. Obs “Enter Honeysuckle, in his nightcap, trussing himself.” J. Webster (1607). To truss up to strain; to make close or tight. Trussed beam a beam which is stiffened by a system of braces constituting a truss of which the beam is a chord.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trussed; p. pr. & vb. n. Trussing
entry.ety: F. trousser. See Truss n.

sn.def: To bind or pack close; to tie up tightly; to make into a truss.
sn.q: It [his hood] was trussed up in his wallet.

sn.def: To take fast hold of; to seize and hold firmly; to pounce upon.
sn.q: Who trussing me as eagle doth his prey.

sn.def: To strengthen or stiffen, as a beam or girder, by means of a brace or braces.
To skewer; to make fast, as the wings of a fowl to the body in cooking it.
To execute by hanging; to hang; -- usually with up.
The timbers, etc., which form a truss, taken collectively.
The art of stiffening or bracing a set of timbers, or the like, by putting in struts, ties, etc., till it has something of the character of a truss.
The act of a hawk, or other bird of prey, in seizing its quarry, and soaring with it into air.

cs.cd: a deed conveying property to a trustee, for some specific use.

entry.ety: OE. trust trost, Icel. traust confidence, security; akin to Dan. & Sw. tröst comfort, consolation, G. trost, Goth. trausti a convention, covenant, and E. true. See True, and cf. Tryst

sn.def: Assured resting of the mind on the integrity, veracity, justice, friendship, or other sound principle, of another person; confidence; reliance; reliance.
sn.q: O ever-failingtrustin mortal strength!
Most take things upon trust.

sn.def: Credit given; especially, delivery of property or merchandise in reliance upon future payment; exchange without immediate receipt of an equivalent; as, to sell or buy goods on trust .
Assured anticipation; dependence upon something future or contingent, as if present or actual; hope; belief.
sn.q: Suchtrusthave we through Christ.
His trust was with the Eternal to be deemed Equal in strength.

sn.def: That which is committed or intrusted to one; something received in confidence; charge; deposit.
The condition or obligation of one to whom anything is confided; responsible charge or office.
sn.q: I] serve him truly that will put me in trust.
Reward them well, if they observe their trust.

sn.def: That upon which confidence is reposed; ground of reliance; hope.
sn.q: O Lord God, thou art my trust from my youth.

sn.def: An estate devised or granted in confidence that the devisee or grantee shall convey it, or dispose of the profits, at the will, or for the benefit, of another; an estate held for the use of another; a confidence respecting property reposed in one person, who is termed the trustee, for the benefit of another, who is called the cestui que trust.

An equitable right or interest in property distinct from the legal ownership thereof; a use (as it existed before the Statute of Uses); also, a property interest held by one person for the benefit of another. Trusts are active, or special express implied constructive, etc. In a passive trust the trustee simply has title to the trust property, while its control and management are in the beneficiary.

A business organization or combination consisting of a number of firms or corporations operating, and often united, under an agreement creating a trust (in sense 1), esp. one formed mainly for the purpose of regulating the supply and price of commodities, etc.; often, opprobriously, a combination formed for the purpose of controlling or monopolizing a trade, industry, or business, by doing acts in restraint or trade; as, a sugar trust . A trust may take the form of a corporation or of a body of persons or corporations acting together by mutual arrangement, as under a contract or a so-called gentlemen's agreement. When it consists of corporations it may be effected by putting a majority of their stock either in the hands of a board of trustees (whence the name trust for the combination) or by transferring a majority to a holding company. The advantages of a trust are partly due to the economies made possible in carrying on a large business, as well as the doing away with competition. In the United States severe statutes against trusts have been passed by the Federal government and in many States, with elaborate statutory definitions.
sn.syn: Confidence; belief; faith; hope; expectation.

entry.def: Held in trust; as, trust property; trustmoney.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Trusted; p. pr. & vb. n. Trusting
entry.ety: OE. trusten trosten. See Trust n.

sn.def: To place confidence in; to rely on, to confide, or repose faith, in; as, we can not trust those who have deceived us.
sn.q: I will never trust his word after.
He that trusts every one without reserve will at last be deceived.

sn.def: To give credence to; to believe; to credit.
sn.q: Trust me, you look well.

sn.def: To hope confidently; to believe; -- usually with a phrase or infinitive clause as the object.
sn.q: I trust to come unto you, and speak face to face.
We trustwe have a good conscience.

sn.def: to show confidence in a person by intrusting (him) with something.
sn.q: Whom, with your power and fortune, sir, you trust, Now to suspect is vain.

sn.def: To commit, as to one's care; to intrust.
sn.q: Merchants were not willing to trust precious cargoes to any custody but that of a man-of-war.

sn.def: To give credit to; to sell to upon credit, or in confidence of future payment; as, merchants and manufacturers trust their customers annually with goods.
To risk; to venture confidently.
sn.q: Beguiled] by thee to trust thee from my side.

entry.cs:
To trust in To trust on
to place confidence in,; to rely on; to depend. “Trust in the Lord, and do good.” Ps. xxxvii. 3. “A priest . . . on whom we trust.” Chaucer. Her widening streets on new foundations trust. Dryden.
To trust toorTo trust unto
to depend on; to have confidence in; to rely on; as, to trust to luck. They trusted unto the liers in wait. Judges xx. 36.

sn.def: To have trust; to be credulous; to be won to confidence; to confide.
sn.q: More to know could not be more to trust.

sn.def: To be confident, as of something future; to hope.
sn.q: I will trust and not be afraid.

sn.def: To sell or deliver anything in reliance upon a promise of payment; to give credit.
sn.q: It is happier sometimes to be cheated than not to trust.

entries.entry: Trust company. Any corporation formed for the purpose of acting as trustee. Such companies usually do more or less of a banking business.

cs.cd: a process by which a creditor may attach his debtor's goods, effects, and credits, in the hands of a third person; -- called, in some States, the process of foreign attachment garnishment, or factorizing process.

entry.def: A person to whom property is legally committed in trust, to be applied either for the benefit of specified individuals, or for public uses; one who is intrusted with property for the benefit of another; also, a person in whose hands the effects of another are attached in a trustee process.

sn.def: To commit (property) to the care of a trustee; as, to trustee an estate.
To attach (a debtor's wages, credits, or property in the hands of a third person) in the interest of the creditor.

entries.entry: Trus*tee" proc"ess. Law The process of attachment by garnishment. U. S

entry.def: The office or duty of a trustee.

entries.entry: Trustee stock. Finance High-grade stock in which trust funds may be legally invested. Colloq

sn.def: One who trusts, or credits.
One who makes a trust; -- the correlative of trustee.
Full of trust; trusting.
Worthy of trust; faithful; trusty; trustworthy.

entry.def: In a trusty manner.
The quality or state of being trusty.
Having or exercising trust; confiding; unsuspecting; trustful.
That may not be trusted; not worthy of trust; unfaithful.
Worthy of trust or confidence; trusty.

sn.def: Admitting of being safely trusted; justly deserving confidence; fit to be confided in; trustworthy; reliable.
sn.q: Your trusty and most valiant servitor.

sn.def: Hence, not liable to fail; strong; firm.
sn.q: His trusty sword he called to his aid.

sn.def: Involving trust; as, a trusty business.

entries.entry:
Truth
In truth in reality; in fact. Of a truth in reality; certainly. To do truth to practice what God commands.
n.; pl.Truths #. OE. treuthe trouthe treowpe, AS. treów�. See True; cf. Troth Betroth
The quality or being true; as: Conformity to fact or reality; exact accordance with that which is, or has been; or shall be.
Conformity to rule; exactness; close correspondence with an example, mood, object of imitation, or the like. Plows, to go true, depend much on the truth of the ironwork.
Fidelity; constancy; steadfastness; faithfulness. Alas! they had been friends in youth, But whispering tongues can poison truth.
The practice of speaking what is true; freedom from falsehood; veracity. If this will not suffice, it must appear That malice bears down truth.
That which is true or certain concerning any matter or subject, or generally on all subjects; real state of things; fact; verity; reality. Speak ye every man the truth to his neighbor. I long to know the truth here of at large. The truth depends on, or is only arrived at by, a legitimate deduction from all the facts which are truly material.
A true thing; a verified fact; a true statement or proposition; an established principle, fixed law, or the like; as, the great truths of morals. Even so our boasting . . . is found a truth.
Righteousness; true religion. Grace and truth came by Jesus Christ. Sanctify them through thy truth; thy word is truth. He that doeth truth cometh to the light.

entry.def: To assert as true; to declare.
entry.q: Had they [the ancients] dreamt this, they would have truthed it heaven.

entry.def: Full of truth; veracious; reliable.
Devoid of truth; dishonest; dishonest; spurious; faithless.
One who loves the truth.
entry.q: Truth-lover was our English Duke.

entry.def: Truth.
One who tells the truth.
entry.q: Truth-teller was our England's Alfred named.

entry.def: Truthful; likely; probable.
entry.q: A moretruthyimport.

entry.ety: L. trutinari to weigh, from trutina a balance. See Trone a steelyard
entry.def: The act of weighing.

entry.ety: LL. trutta a trout, L. tructa. See Trout
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a trout; as, fish of the truttaceous kind.

entry.cs: To try on. To put on, as a garment, to ascertain whether it fits the person. To attempt; to undertake. Slang Dickens.
entry.usage: Try Attempt. To try is the generic, to attempt is the specific, term. When we try, we are usually uncertain as to success; when we attempt, we have always some definite object in view which we seek to accomplish. We may be indifferent as to the result of a trial, but we rarely attempt anything without a desire to succeed.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. tried; p. pr. & vb. n. Trying
entry.ety: OE. trien to select, pick out, F. trier to cull, to out, LL. tritare to triturate (hence the sense of, to thresh, to separate the grain from the straw, to select), L. terere tritum, to rub, bruise, grind, thresh. See Trite

sn.def: To divide or separate, as one sort from another; to winnow; to sift; to pick out; -- frequently followed by out; as, to try out the wild corn from the good.
To purify or refine, as metals; to melt out, and procure in a pure state, as oil, tallow, lard, etc.
sn.q: The words of the Lord are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times.
For thou, O God, hast proved us: thou hast tried us, as silver is tried.

sn.def: To prove by experiment; to apply a test to, for the purpose of determining the quality; to examine; to prove; to test; as, to try weights or measures by a standard; to try a man's opinions.
sn.q: Let the end try the man.

sn.def: To subject to severe trial; to put to the test; to cause suffering or trouble to.
sn.q: Thus far to try thee, Adam, I was pleased.
These are the times that try men's souls.

sn.def: To experiment with; to test by use; as, to try a remedy for disease; to try a horse.
sn.q: Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.
To ease her cares the force of sleep she tries.

sn.def: To strain; to subject to excessive tests; as, the light tries his eyes; repeated disappointments try one's patience.
To examine or investigate judicially; to examine by witnesses or other judicial evidence and the principles of law; as, to try a cause, or a criminal.
To settle; to decide; to determine; specifically, to decide by an appeal to arms; as, to try rival claims by a duel; to try conclusions.
sn.q: Left I the court, to see this quarrel tried.

sn.def: To experience; to have or gain knowledge of by experience.
sn.q: Or try the Libyan heat or Scythian cold.

sn.def: To essay; to attempt; to endeavor.
sn.q: Let us try . . . to found a path.
sn.syn: To attempt; endeavor; strive; aim; examine.
sn.q: He first deceased: she for a little tried To live without him; liked it not, and died.
Alack, I am afraid they have a waked, And 't is not done. The attempt, and not the deed, Confounds us.

sn.def: To exert strength; to endeavor; to make an effort or an attempt; as, you must try hard if you wish to learn.
To do; to fare; as, how do you try !
A screen, or sieve, for grain.
Act of trying; attempt; experiment; trial.
sn.q: This breaking of his has been but a try for his friends.

sn.def: In Rugby and Northern Union football, a score (counting three points) made by grounding the ball on or behind the opponent's goal line; -- so called because it entitles the side making it to a place kick for a goal (counting two points more if successful).

entry.ety: Cf. Try v. t.
entry.def: Refined; select; excellent; choice.
entry.q: Sugar that istry.

entries.entry: Try cock. A cock for withdrawing a small quantity of liquid, as for testing.

entry.ety: L., a sting ray, from Gr.� a kind of fish with a prickle in the tail
entry.def: Any one of several species of large sting rays belonging to Trygon and allied genera.
Adapted to try, or put to severe trial; severe; afflictive; as, a trying occasion or position.

sn.def: a test of the performance capability of a person, to ascertain fitness for a particular task; in sports, a test by which the fitness of a player or contestant to remain in a certain class is determined.

one or more performances of a play prior to the official opening, held at a location outside of the city where it is to be formally presented, conducted for the purpose of determining audience response or ascertaining weaknesses needing correction.

entry.def: to compete for a postition, as on a sports team or in a theatrical presentation.
to use (something not previously used) to determine its fitness for a particular purpose; also, to attempt (a deed) to determine if it will accomplish a particular purpose.

entry.ety: Gr. � a rubbing, fr. � to rub, grind. So called because it causes protein to break up or to fall apart
entry.def: A proteolytic enzyme present in the pancreatic juice. Unlike the pepsin of the gastric juice, it acts in a neutral or alkaline fluid, and not only converts the albuminous matter of the food into soluble peptones, but also, in part, into leucin and tyrosin.

entry.ety: Trypsin + -gen
entry.def: The antecedent of trypsin, a substance which is contained in the cells of the pancreas and gives rise to the trypsin.
Relating to trypsin or to its action; produced by trypsin; as, trypsin digestion.
The peptone formed by pancreatic digestion; -- so called because it is formed through the agency of the ferment trypsin.
A fore-and-aft sail, bent to a gaff, and hoisted on a lower mast or on a small mast, called the trysail mast, close abaft a lower mast; -- used chiefly as a storm sail. Called also spencer.
An instrument used by carpenters, joiners, etc., for laying off right angles off right angles, and testing whether work is square.

cs.cd: to wait, at the appointed time, for one with whom a tryst or engagement is made; to keep an engagement or appointment.

entry.ety: OE. trist tryst, a variant of trust; cf. Icel. treysta to make trusty, fr. traust confidence, security. See Trust n.

sn.def: Trust.
An appointment to meet; also, an appointed place or time of meeting; as, to keep tryst; to break tryst .
sn.q: The tenderest-hearted maid That ever bided tryst at village stile.

entry.ety: OE. tristen trysten. See Tryst n.

sn.def: To trust.
To agree with to meet at a certain place; to make an appointment with.

entry.def: To mutually agree to meet at a certain place.
One who makes an appointment, or tryst; one who meets with another.

cs.cd: an arranged day of meeting or assembling, as of soldiers, friends, and the like.
cs.q: And named a trysting day, And bade his messengers ride forth East and west and south and north, To summon his array.
cs.cd: a place designated for the assembling of soldiers, the meeting of parties for an interview, or the like; a rendezvous.

entry.def: An appointment; a tryst.
The title of the emperor of Russia. See Czar.

entry.ety: Russ. tsaritsa. Cf. Czarina
entry.def: The title of the empress of Russia. See Czarina.
The chameck.

entry.ety: From a native name
entry.def: A West African anthropoid ape allied to the gorilla and chimpanzee, and by some considered only a variety of the chimpanzee. It is noted for building large, umbrella-shaped nests in trees. Called also tscheigo tschiego nschego nscheigo.
The springbok.

A venomous two-winged African fly (Glossina morsitans) whose bite is very poisonous, and even fatal, to horses and cattle, but harmless to men. It renders extensive districts in which it abounds uninhabitable during certain seasons of the year.

entries.entry: T" square`. See under T.

Tsung"-li Ya"men Tsung"-li Ya"men. Tsung-li-Yamen Tsungli Yamen
Chin The board or department of foreign affairs in the Chinese government. See Yamen.
Tsung" tu` Tsung" tu`. A viceroy or governor-general, the highest provincial official in China, with civil and military authority over one or more provinces.

entry.ety: Maori tuatàra; tua on the farther side (the back) + tara spine
entry.def: A large iguanalike reptile (Sphenodon punctatum) formerly common in New Zealand, but by 1900 confined to certain islets near the coast. It reaches a length of two and a half feet, is dark olive-green with small white or yellowish specks on the sides, and has yellow spines along the back, except on the neck. It is the only surviving member of the order Rhyncocephala. Also called tuatera and hatteria.
Same as tuatara.

cs.cd: an old mode of treatment for the venereal disease, by sweating in a close place, or tub, and fasting.

a horizontal water wheel, usually in the form of a short cylinder, to the circumference of which spiral vanes or floats, placed radially, are attached, turned by the impact of one or more streams of water, conducted so as to strike against the floats in the direction of a tangent to the cylinder.

entry.ety: OE. tubbe; of Dutch or Low German origin; cf. LG. tubbe, D. tobbe

sn.def: An open wooden vessel formed with staves, bottom, and hoops; a kind of short cask, half barrel, or firkin, usually with but one head, -- used for various purposes.
The amount which a tub contains, as a measure of quantity; as, a tub of butter; a tub of camphor, which is about 1 cwt., etc.
Any structure shaped like a tub: as, a certain old form of pulpit; a short, broad boat, etc., -- often used jocosely or opprobriously.
sn.q: All being took up and busied, some in pulpits and some in tubs, in the grand work of preaching and holding forth.

sn.def: A sweating in a tub; a tub fast.
A small cask; as, a tub of gin.
A box or bucket in which coal or ore is sent up a shaft; -- so called by miners.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tubbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tubbing
entry.def: To plant or set in a tub; as, to tub a plant.
To make use of a bathing tub; to lie or be in a bath; to bathe.
entry.q: Don't we all tub in England ?

entry.ety: L., trumpet
entry.def: An ancient trumpet.
A sax-tuba. See Sax-tuba.
Of or pertaining to a tube; specifically, of or pertaining to one of the Fallopian tubes; as, tubal pregnancy.

sn.def: The forming of a tub; also, collectively, materials for tubs.

A lining of timber or metal around the shaft of a mine; especially, a series of cast-iron cylinders bolted together, used to enable those who sink a shaft to penetrate quicksand, water, etc., with safety.

entry.def: Resembling a tub; specifically sounding dull and without resonance, like a tub; wanting elasticity or freedom of sound; as, a tubby violin.

entry.note: In the New York area, the subways running under the Hudson River are sometimes referred to as the tube.
entry.cs:
Capillary tube a tube of very fine bore. See Capillary. Fire tube Steam Boilers a tube which forms a flue. Tube coral. Zoöl Same as Tubipore. Tube foot Zoöl one of the ambulacral suckers of an echinoderm.
Tube plateorTube sheet
Steam Boilers a flue plate. See under Flue. Tube pouch Mil a pouch containing priming tubes. Tube spinner Zoöl any one of various species of spiders that construct tubelike webs. They belong to Tegenaria Agelena, and allied genera. Water tube Steam Boilers a tube containing water and surrounded by flame or hot gases.
entry.ety: L. tubus; akin to tuba a trumpet: cf F. tube

sn.def: A hollow cylinder, of any material, used for the conveyance of fluids, and for various other purposes; a pipe.
A telescope.
sn.q: Glazed optictube.

sn.def: A vessel in animal bodies or plants, which conveys a fluid or other substance.
The narrow, hollow part of a gamopetalous corolla.
A priming tube, or friction primer. See under Priming, and Friction.
A small pipe forming part of the boiler, containing water and surrounded by flame or hot gases, or else surrounded by water and forming a flue for the gases to pass through.

sd.def: A more or less cylindrical, and often spiral, case secreted or constructed by many annelids, crustaceans, insects, and other animals, for protection or concealment. See Illust. of Tubeworm.
One of the siphons of a bivalve mollusk.

sn.def: A tunnel for a tube railway; also Colloq, a tube railway; a subway.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tubed; p. pr. & vb. n. Tubing
entry.def: To furnish with a tube; as, to tube a well.
In the form of a tube; tubular; tubiform.
Having the nostrils prolonged in the form of horny tubes along the sides of the beak; -- said of certain sea birds.
Belonging to the Tubinares.

entry.ety: L., a hump. knob; probably akin to tumere to swell. Cf. Tumid

sd.def: A fleshy, rounded stem or root, usually containing starchy matter, as the potato or arrowroot; a thickened root-stock. See Illust. of Tuberous.
A genus of fungi. See Truffle.

sn.def: A tuberosity; a tubercle.

entry.def: an electrically powered railroad with tracks running through a tunnel underground; a subway.

cs.cd: a minute vegetable organism (Mycobacterium tuberculosis, formerly Bacillus tuberculosis, and also called Koch's bacillus) discovered by Koch, a German physician, in the sputum of consumptive patients and in tuberculous tissue. It is the causative agent of tuberculosis.

entry.ety: L. tuberculum, dim. of tuber: cf. F. tubercule, OF. also tubercle. See Tuber

sn.def: A small knoblike prominence or excrescence, whether natural or morbid; as, a tubercle on a plant; a tubercle on a bone; the tubercles appearing on the body in leprosy.

A small mass or aggregation of morbid matter; especially, the deposit which accompanies scrofula or phthisis. This is composed of a hard, grayish, or yellowish, translucent or opaque matter, which gradually softens, and excites suppuration in its vicinity. It is most frequently found in the lungs, causing consumption.

entry.def: Having tubercles; affected with, tubercles; tuberculate; as, a tubercled lung or stalk.

sn.def: Having tubercles; affected with tubercles; tubercled; tuberculate.
Like a tubercle; as, a tubercular excrescence.
Characterized by the development of tubercles; as, tubercular diathesis.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. -ized; p. pr. & vb. n. i-zing
entry.ety: Tubercular + -ize
entry.def: To infect with tuberculosis.

entry.ety: NL. tuberculatus: cf. F. tuberculé
entry.def: Tubercled; tubercular.

entry.ety: See Tubercle
entry.def: A fluid containing the products formed by the growth of the tubercle bacillus in a suitable culture medium.

entries.entry: Tu*ber"cu*lin test In humans, a previous or acive infection with tuberculosis will cause a distinct reaction to the injection of tuberculin. The test is thus used to screen populations to discover those who may harbor an active tuberculosis infection, and more definitive tests are performed on those showing a positive reaction, to determine if the infection is active. In cattle there is little or no effect of the injection of tuberculin on healthy animals, but there is a marked rise in temperature in tuberculous animals.. The hypodermic injection of tuberculin, used as a test for past or present infection with tuberculosis. It is used both for humans and cattle.

entry.def: The development of tubercles; the condition of one who is affected with tubercles.

entry.ety: Tuberculum + root of L. caedere to kill
entry.def: able to kill Mycobacterum tuberculosis.

entry.ety: Tuberculum + root of L. caedere to kill
entry.def: A special substance contained in tuberculin, supposed to be the active agent of the latter freed from various impurities.

entry.ety: Tuberculum + -oid
entry.def: Resembling a tubercle.
Having tubercles; affected with, or characterized by, tubercles; tubercular.
Affected with tuberculosis.

entry.ety: NL. See Tubercle
entry.def: A constitutional disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosisalso called the Tubercle bacillus), characterized by the production of tubercles in the internal organs, and especially in the lungs, where it constitutes the most common variety of pulmonary phthisis (consumption). The Mycobacteria are slow-growing and without cell walls, and are thus not affected by the beta-lactam antibiotics; treatment is difficult, usually requiring simultaneous administration of multiple antibiotics to effect a cure. Prior to availability of antibiotic treatment, the cure required extensive rest, for which special sanatoriums were constructed.
Pertaining to, or affected with, a tuberculosis.

entries.entry: Tu*ber"cu*lum Tu*ber"cu*lum n.; pl.Tubercula #. L., dim. of tuber a swelling Zoöl A tubercle.

entry.ety: Tuber + -ferous
entry.def: Producing or bearing tubers.

entry.ety: Cf. G. tuberose, F. tubéreuse, NL. Polianthes tuberosa. See Tuberous
entry.def: A plant (Polianthes tuberosa) with a tuberous root and a liliaceous flower. It is much cultivated for its beautiful and fragrant white blossoms.
Tuberous.

entries.entry:
Tu`ber*os"i*ty n.; pl.Tuberosities #. Cf. F. tubérosité
The state of being tuberous.
An obtuse or knoblike prominence; a protuberance.

entry.ety: L. tuberosus: cf. F. tubéreux. See Tuber, and cf. also Tuberose

sn.def: Covered with knobby or wartlike prominences; knobbed.
Consisting of, or bearing, tubers; resembling a tuber.

entry.def: Any bivalve mollusk which secretes a shelly tube around its siphon, as the watering-shell.
Any annelid which constructs a tube; one of the Tubicolæ.
The sapphirine gurnard (Trigla hirundo). See Illust. under Gurnard.

entries.entry: Tub"ful n.; pl.Tubfuls. As much as a tub will hold; enough to fill a tub.

entry.ety: L. tubicen trumpeter
entry.def: To blow a trumpet.

entry.ety: L. tubus a tube + colere to inhabit
entry.def: A division of annelids including those which construct, and habitually live in, tubes. The head or anterior segments usually bear gills and cirri. Called also Sedentaria, and Capitibranchiata. See Serpula, and Sabella.
Tubicolous.
One of the Tubicolæ.

entry.ety: See Tubicolæ
entry.def: Inhabiting a tube; as, tubicolous worms.

entry.ety: L. tubus tube + cornu horn: cf. F. tubicorne
entry.def: Any ruminant having horns composed of a bony axis covered with a horny sheath; a hollow-horned ruminant.
Having hollow horns.
Having the form of a tube; tubeform.
entry.q: Tubiformcells.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. tubus tube + nares the nostrils
entry.def: A tribe of sea birds comprising the petrels, shearwaters, albatrosses, hagdons, and allied birds having tubular horny nostrils.

sn.def: The act of making tubes.
A series of tubes; tubes, collectively; a length or piece of a tube; material for tubes; as, leather tubing .

entry.ety: NL., from L. tubus tube + porus passage, pore
entry.def: A genus of halcyonoids in which the skeleton, or coral (called organ-pipe coral), consists of a mass of parallel cylindrical tubes united at intervals by transverse plates. These corals are usually red or purple and form large masses. They are natives of the tropical parts of the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tubipore
entry.def: Any species of the genus Tubipora.
Any fossil coral of the genus Syringopora consisting of a cluster of upright tubes united together by small transverse tubules.

entry.ety: See Tube Valve
entry.def: A shell or tube formed by an annelid, as a serpula.

entries.entry: Tub"man n.; pl.Tubmen. Eng. Law One of the two most experienced barristers in the Court of Exchequer. Cf. Postman, 2.

entry.cs: Tubular boiler. See under Boiler. Tubular breathing Med a variety of respiratory sound, heard on auscultation over the lungs in certain cases of disease, resembling that produced by the air passing through the trachea. Tubular bridge a bridge in the form of a hollow trunk or tube, made of iron plates riveted together, as the Victoria bridge over the St. Lawrence, at Montreal, Canada, and the Britannia bridge over the Menai Straits. Tubular girder a plate girder having two or more vertical webs with a space between them.
entry.ety: L. tubulus, dim. of tubus a tube, or pipe. See Tube
entry.def: Having the form of a tube, or pipe; consisting of a pipe; fistular; as, a tubular snout; a tubular calyx. Also, containing, or provided with, tubes.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of hydroids having large, naked, flowerlike hydranths at the summits of long, slender, usually simple, stems. The gonophores are small, and form clusters at the bases of the outer tentacles.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Tubularida.

entry.note: ☞ These hydroids usually form tufts of delicate tubes, and both gonophores and hydranths are naked. The gonophores of many of the species become free jellyfishes; those of other species remain permanently attached as medusoid buds or sporosacs. See Illust. under Gonosome, and Cymnoblastea.
entry.def: Any hydroid belonging to the suborder Tubularida.
Of or pertaining to the tubularians.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: An extensive division of Hydroidea; the tubularians; -- called also Athecata Gymnoblastea, and Tubulariæ.

entry.ety: L. tubulatus. See Tubular
entry.def: Tubular; tubulated; tubulous.

cs.cd: a bottle or retort having a stoppered opening for the introduction or removal of materials.

entry.def: Made in the form of a small tube; provided with a tube, or elongated opening.
The act of shaping or making a tube, or of providing with a tube; also, a tube or tubulure; as, the tubulation of a retort.
A tubulure.

entry.ety: F. tubule, or L. tubulus, dim. of tubus a tube, a pipe

sn.def: A small pipe or fistular body; a little tube.
A minute tube lined with glandular epithelium; as, the uriniferous tubules of the kidney.

entry.def: One of the Tubulibranchiata.

entry.ety: NL., from L. tubulus a little tube + branchia a gill
entry.def: A group of gastropod mollusks having a tubular shell. Vermetus is an example.

entry.ety: L. tubulus little tube + colere to inhabit
entry.def: Any hydroid which has tubular chitinous stems.

entry.ety: Tubule + dentate
entry.def: Having teeth traversed by canals; -- said of certain edentates.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tubuliforme
entry.def: Having the form of a small tube.
Any one of numerous species of Bryozoa belonging to Tubulipora and allied genera, having tubular calcareous calicles.

cs.cd: a steam boiler composed chiefly of tubes containing water and surrounded by flame and hot gases; -- sometimes distinguished from tubular boiler.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tubuleux. See Tubule

sn.def: Resembling, or in the form of, a tube; longitudinally hollow; specifically Bot, having a hollow cylindrical corolla, often expanded or toothed at the border; as, a tubulose flower.
Containing, or consisting of, small tubes; specifically Bot, composed wholly of tubulous florets; as, a tubulous compound flower.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tubulure
entry.def: A short tubular opening at the top of a retort, or at the top or side of a bottle; a tubulation.
The Mexican pocket gopher (Geomys Mexicanus). It resembles the common pocket gopher of the Western United States, but is larger. Called also tugan, and tuza.
See Tucket, a steak.

entry.ety: See Touchstone
entry.def: A dark-colored kind of marble; touchstone.

entry.ety: F. estoc; cf. It. stocco; both of German origin, and akin to E. stock. See Stock
entry.def: A long, narrow sword; a rapier.
entry.q: He wore large hose, and a tuck, as it was then called, or rapier, of tremendous length.

entry.ety: Cf. Tocsin
entry.def: The beat of a drum.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tucked; p. pr. & vb. n. Tucking
entry.ety: OE. tukken, LG. tukken to pull up, tuck up, entice; akin to OD. tocken to entice, G. zucken to draw with a short and quick motion, and E. tug. See Tug

sn.def: To draw up; to shorten; to fold under; to press into a narrower compass; as, to tuck the bedclothes in; to tuck up one's sleeves.
To make a tuck or tucks in; as, to tuck a dress.
To inclose; to put within; to press into a close place; as, to tuck a child into a bed; to tuck a book under one's arm, or into a pocket.

sn.ety: Perhaps originally, to strike, beat: cf. F. toquer to touch. Cf. Tocsin
sn.def: To full, as cloth.

entry.def: To contract; to draw together.

sn.def: A horizontal sewed fold, such as is made in a garment, to shorten it; a plait.
A small net used for taking fish from a larger one; -- called also tuck-net.
A pull; a lugging.
The part of a vessel where the ends of the bottom planks meet under the stern.
Food; pastry; sweetmeats.

entry.ety: North American Indian, bread
entry.def: A curious vegetable production of the Southern Atlantic United States, growing under ground like a truffle and often attaining immense size. The real nature is unknown. Called also Indian bread, and Indian loaf.

sn.def: One who, or that which, tucks; specifically, an instrument with which tuck are made.
A narrow piece of linen or the like, folded across the breast, or attached to the gown at the neck, forming a part of a woman's dress in the 17th century and later.
A fuller.
Daily food; meals; also, food in general.
sn.q: Tobacco, matches, and tucker, the latter comprising almost anything within the province of food.

entry.def: To tire; to weary; -- usually with out.

cs.cd: the sound of the tucket.

entry.ety: It toccata a prelude, fr. toccare to touch. See Toccata Touch
entry.def: A slight flourish on a trumpet; a fanfare.
entry.q: Let the trumpets sound The tucket sonance and the note to mount.

entry.ety: Cf. It. tocchetto a ragout of fish, meat, fr. tocco a bit, morsel, LL. tucetum tuccetum, a thick gravy
entry.def: A steak; a collop.
See Tuck n., 2.

entries.entry: Tuck pointing. Masonry The finishing of joints along the center lines with a narrow ridge of putty or fine lime mortar.

entry.ety: So called by the Indians of Brazil
entry.def: A fine, strong fiber obtained from the young leaves of a Brazilian palm (Astrocaryum vulgare), used for cordage, bowstrings, etc.; also, the plant yielding this fiber. Called also tecum, and tecum fiber.
A Brazilian palm (Astrocaryum Tucuma) which furnishes an edible fruit.

cs.cd: the latest development of Gothic architecture in England, under the Tudors, characterized by flat four-centered arches, shallow moldings, and a profusion of paneling on the walls.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a royal line of England, descended from Owen Tudor of Wales, who married the widowed queen of Henry V. The first reigning Tudor was Henry VII.; the last, Elizabeth.
The parson bird.
See To-fall.
See Tuyère.
A pair of blacksmith's tongs.

entry.ety: OE. Tewesday, AS. Tiwes dæg the day of Tiw the god of war; akin to OHG. Zio, Icel. Tȳr, L. Jupiter, Gr. Zey`s;, cf. OHG. Ziostac Tuesday, G. Dienstag, Icel. Tȳsdagr. √244. See Deity Day, and cf. Jovial
entry.def: The third day of the week, following Monday and preceding Wednesday.
The lapwing.

entry.ety: It. fufo soft, sandy stone, L. tofus tophus. Cf. Tofus Toph, and Tophin
entry.def: A soft or porous stone formed by depositions from water, usually calcareous; -- called also calcareous tufa.
A friable volcanic rock or conglomerate, formed of consolidated cinders, or scoria.

entry.ety: Cf. It. tufaceo, L. tofaceus tofacius. See Tufa
entry.def: Pertaining to tufa; consisting of, or resembling, tufa.
Same as Tufa.
See Typhoon.

entry.ety: Prov. E. tuff, F. touffe; of German origin; cf. G. zopf a weft of hair, pigtail, top of a tree. See Top summit

sn.def: A collection of small, flexible, or soft things in a knot or bunch; a waving or bending and spreading cluster; as, a tuft of flowers or feathers.
A cluster; a clump; as, a tuft of plants.
sn.q: Under a tuft of shade.
Green lake, and cedar fuft, and spicy glade.

sn.def: A nobleman, or person of quality, especially in the English universities; -- so called from the tuft, or gold tassel, on the cap worn by them.
sn.q: Several young tufts, and others of the faster men.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tufted; p. pr. & vb. n. Tufting

sn.def: To separate into tufts.
To adorn with tufts or with a tuft.

entry.def: To grow in, or form, a tuft or tufts.
A silk fabric formerly in use, having a nap or pile.

cs.cd: the ring-necked duck.

sn.def: Adorned with a tuft; as, the tufted duck.
Growing in tufts or clusters; tufty.
sn.q: The tufted crowtoe, and pale jessamine.
Tufted trees and springing corn.

entry.def: A hanger-on to noblemen, or persons of quality, especially in English universities; a toady. See 1st Tuft, 3.
The practice of seeking after, and hanging on, noblemen, or persons of quality, especially in English universities.

sn.def: Abounding with tufts.
sn.q: Both in the tufty frith and in the mossy fell.

sn.def: Growing in tufts or clusters.
sn.q: Where tufty daisies nod at every gale.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tugged; p. pr. & vb. n. Tugging
entry.ety: OE. toggen; akin to OD. tocken to entice, G. zucken to jerk, draw, Icel. toga to draw, AS. téon, p. p. togen, to draw, G. ziehen, OHG. ziohan, Goth. tiuhan, L. ducere to lead, draw. Cf. Duke Team Tie v. t. Touch Tow v. t. Tuck to press in, Toy a plaything

sn.def: To pull or draw with great effort; to draw along with continued exertion; to haul along; to tow; as, to tug a loaded cart; to tug a ship into port.
sn.q: There sweat, there strain, tug the laborious oar.

sn.def: To pull; to pluck.
sn.q: To ease the pain, His tugged cars suffered with a strain.

sn.def: To pull with great effort; to strain in labor; as, to tug at the oar; to tug against the stream.
sn.q: He tugged, he shook, till down they came.

sn.def: To labor; to strive; to struggle.
sn.q: England now is left To tug and scamble and to part by the teeth The unowed interest of proud-swelling state.

cs.cd: an iron hook or button to which a tug or trace may be attached, as on the shaft of a wagon.

sn.def: A pull with the utmost effort, as in the athletic contest called tug of war; a supreme effort.
sn.q: At the tug he falls, Vast ruins come along, rent from the smoking walls.

sn.def: A sort of vehicle, used for conveying timber and heavy articles.
A small, powerful steamboat used to tow vessels; -- called also steam tug tugboat, and towboat.
A trace, or drawing strap, of a harness.
An iron hook of a hoisting tub, to which a tackle is affixed.

entry.def: Same as Tucan.
See Tug n., 3.
One who tugs.
In a tugging manner; with laborious pulling.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tuile a tile
entry.def: In plate armor, a suspended plate in from of the thigh. See Illust. of Tasses.

entry.ety: L. tuitio protection, guarding, from tueri, p. p. tuitus, to see, watch, protect: cf. F. tuition. Cf. Tutor

sn.def: Superintending care over a young person; the particular watch and care of a tutor or guardian over his pupil or ward; guardianship.
Especially, the act, art, or business of teaching; instruction; as, children are sent to school for tuition; his tuition was thorough.
The money paid for instruction; the price or payment for instruction; as, tuition must be paid in full before graduation.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to tuition.

entry.ety: From the native name
entry.def: A burrowing South American rodent (Ctenomys Braziliensis). It has small eyes and ears and a short tail. It resembles the pocket gopher in size, form, and habits, but is more nearly allied to the porcupines.

entries.entry:
Tu"la met`al. An alloy of silver, copper, and lead made at Tula in Russia.
toola metal

entry.ety: Mex
entry.def: A large bulrush (Scirpus lacustris, and Scirpus Tatora) growing abundantly on overflowed land in California and elsewhere.

entry.cs: Tulip tree. A large American tree bearing tuliplike flowers. See Liriodendron. A West Indian malvaceous tree (Paritium tiliaceum syn. Hibiscus tiliaceum).
entry.ety: F. tulipe, OF. also tulipan, It. tulipano tulipa, from Turk. tulbend dulbend, literally, a turban, Per. dulband; -- so called from the resemblance of the form of this flower to a turban. See Turban
entry.def: Any plant of the liliaceous genus Tulipa. Many varieties are cultivated for their beautiful, often variegated flowers.
Having erect, pointed ears; prick-eared; -- said of certain dogs.
A person who is especially devoted to the cultivation of tulips.

entry.note: ☞ In Holland, in the first half of the 17th century, the cultivation of tulips became a mania. It began about the year 1634, and, like a violent epidemic, seized upon all classes of the community, leading to disasters and misery such as the records of commerce or of bankruptcies can scarcely parallel. In 1636, tulip marts had been established in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, Haarlem, Leyden, and various other towns, where tulip bulbs were sold and resold in the same manner as stocks are on the Stock Exchange of London.
entry.ety: Tulip + mania
entry.def: A violent passion for the acquisition or cultivation of tulips; -- a word said by Beckman to have been coined by Menage.
One who is affected with tulipomania.
A large, handsomely colored, marine univalve shell (Fasciolaria tulipa) native of the Southern United States. The name is sometimes applied also to other species of Fasciolaria.

cs.cd: the variegated wood of an Australian sapindaceous tree (Harpullia pendula).

entry.def: The beautiful rose-colored striped wood of a Brazilian tree (Physocalymna floribunda), much used by cabinetmakers for inlaying.

entry.ety: OE. tullen. See Tole
entry.def: To allure; to tole.
entry.q: With empty hands men may no hawkes tull.

entry.ety: [F.; -- so called from the town of Tulle, in France
entry.def: A kind of silk lace or light netting, used for veils, etc.

entry.ety: L. Tullianus, from Tullius, the name of a Roman gens
entry.def: Belonging to, or in the style of, Tully Marcus Tullius Cicero).
A whitefish (Coregonus tullibee) found in the Great Lakes of North America; -- called also mongrel whitefish.

cs.cd: to incline inward, as the sides of a vessel, above the bends or extreme breadth; -- used esp. in the phrase tumbling home. Cf. Wall-sided.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tumbled tŭm"b'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Tumbling tŭm"blĭng
entry.ety: OE. tumblen, AS. tumbian to turn heels over head, to dance violently; akin to D. tuimelen to fall, Sw. tumla, Dan. tumle, Icel. tumba; and cf. G. taumeln to reel, to stagger

sn.def: To roll over, or to and fro; to throw one's self about; as, a person in pain tumbles and tosses.
To roll down; to fall suddenly and violently; to be precipitated; as, to tumble from a scaffold.
sn.q: He who tumbles from a tower surely has a greater blow than he who slides from a molehill.

sn.def: To play tricks by various movements and contortions of the body; to perform the feats of an acrobat.

To turn over; to turn or throw about, as for examination or search; to roll or move in a rough, coarse, or unceremonious manner; to throw down or headlong; to precipitate; -- sometimes with over about, etc.; as, to tumble books or papers.
To disturb; to rumple; as, to tumble a bed.

entry.def: Act of tumbling, or rolling over; a fall.
See Tumbledung.
Ready to fall; dilapidated; ruinous; as, a tumble-down house.

Any one of numerous species of scaraboid beetles belonging to Scarabæus Copris Phanæus, and allied genera. The female lays her eggs in a globular mass of dung which she rolls by means of her hind legs to a burrow excavated in the earth in which she buries it.

sn.def: One who tumbles; one who plays tricks by various motions of the body; an acrobat.

A movable obstruction in a lock, consisting of a lever, latch, wheel, slide, or the like, which must be adjusted to a particular position by a key or other means before the bolt can be thrown in locking or unlocking.
A piece attached to, or forming part of, the hammer of a gunlock, upon which the mainspring acts and in which are the notches for the sear point to enter.

A drinking glass, without a foot or stem; -- so called because originally it had a pointed or convex base, and could not be set down with any liquor in it, thus compelling the drinker to finish his measure.
A variety of the domestic pigeon remarkable for its habit of tumbling, or turning somersaults, during its flight.
A breed of dogs that tumble when pursuing game. They were formerly used in hunting rabbits.
A kind of cart; a tumbrel.

entries.entry: Tum"bler*ful n.; pl.Tumblerfuls. As much as a tumbler will hold; enough to fill a tumbler.

entry.def: Any plant which habitually breaks away from its roots in the autumn, and is driven by the wind, as a light, rolling mass, over the fields and prairies; such as witch grass, wild indigo, Amarantus albus, etc.

entry.cs: Tumbling barrel. Same as Rumble n., 4. Tumbling bay an overfall, or weir, in a canal.
entry.def: a. & vb. n. from Tumble v.

entry.ety: OF. tomberel, F. tombereau, fr. tomber to fall, to tumble; of Teutonic origin. Cf. Tumble

sn.def: A cucking stool for the punishment of scolds.
A rough cart.
A cart or carriage with two wheels, which accompanies troops or artillery, to convey the tools of pioneers, cartridges, and the like.
A kind of basket or cage of osiers, willows, or the like, to hold hay and other food for sheep.

entry.ety: L. tumefaciens -entis, p. pr. of tumefacere to tumefy; tumere to swell + facere to make
entry.def: Producing swelling; tumefying.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tuméfaction
entry.def: The act or process of tumefying, swelling, or rising into a tumor; a tumor; a swelling.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tumefied tū"m�*fīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Tumefying
entry.ety: F. tuméfier, fr. L. tumere to swell + -ficarein comp.) to make; cf. L. tumefacere to tumefy. See Tumid, and -fy
entry.def: To swell; to cause to swell, or puff up.
entry.q: To swell, tumefy, stiffen, not the diction only, but the tenor of the thought.

entry.def: To rise in a tumor; to swell.

entry.ety: L. tumescens -entis, p.pr. of tumescere to swell up, v. incho. fr. tumere to swell
entry.def: The act of becoming tumid; the state of being swollen; intumescence; -- applied especially to the state of swelling of the vascular tissue in the male and female sex organs when they have been stimulated to readiness for sexual intercourse.
Slightly tumid; swollen, as certain moss capsules.

entry.ety: L. tumidus, fr. tumere to swell; cf. Skr. tumra strong, fat. Cf. Thumb

sn.def: Swelled, enlarged, or distended; as, a tumid leg; tumid flesh.
Rising above the level; protuberant.
sn.q: So high as heaved the tumid hills.

sn.def: Swelling in sound or sense; pompous; puffy; inflated; bombastic; falsely sublime; turgid; as, a tumid expression; a tumid style.

entry.def: The quality or state of being tumid.
A great quantity or heap.

entry.cs:
Encysted tumor a tumor which is inclosed in a membrane called a cyst, connected with the surrounding parts by the neighboring cellular substance. Fatty tumor. See under Fatty.
Innocent tumororBenign tumor
one which does not of itself threaten life, and does not usually tend to recur after extirpation; a tumor which has not metastesized. Malignant tumor a tumor which tends continually to spread, to become generalized in different parts of the body, and to recur after extirpation, and which, if left to itself, causes death.
entry.ety: L., fr. tumere to swell: cf. F. tumeúr. See Tumid

sn.def: A morbid swelling, prominence, or growth, on any part of the body; especially, a growth produced by deposition of new tissue; a neoplasm.
Affected pomp; bombast; swelling words or expressions; false magnificence or sublimity.
sn.q: Better, however, to be a flippant, than, by a revolting form of tumor and perplexity, to lead men into habits of intellect such as result from the modern vice of English style.

entry.def: Distended; swelled.
entry.q: Histumoredbreast.

entry.ety: L. tumorosus inflated

sn.def: Swelling; protuberant.
Inflated; bombastic.

entry.ety: W. twmp twm, a round mass or heap, a hillock
entry.def: A little hillock; a knoll.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tumped tŭmt; 215; p. pr. & vb. n. Tumping

sn.def: To form a mass of earth or a hillock about; as, to tump teasel.
To draw or drag, as a deer or other animal after it has been killed.

entry.def: A strap placed across a man's forehead to assist him in carrying a pack on his back.
A dish made in the West Indies by beating boiled plantain quite soft in a wooden mortar.

entry.ety: L. tumulus a mound: cf. F. tumulaire. See Tumulus
entry.def: Consisting in a heap; formed or being in a heap or hillock.

entry.ety: L. tumulatus, p. p. of tumulare to tumulate. See Tumulus
entry.def: To cover, as a corpse, with a mound or tomb; to bury.
To swell.
Tumulous.
The quality or state of being tumulous; hilliness.

entry.ety: L. tumulosus, fr. tumulus a mound
