entry.def: Full of small hills or mounds; hilly; tumulose.

entry.ety: L. tumultus; probably akin to Skr. tumula noise, noisy, and perhaps to L. tumere to swell, E. tumid: cf. F. tumulte

sn.def: The commotion or agitation of a multitude, usually accompanied with great noise, uproar, and confusion of voices; hurly-burly; noisy confusion.
sn.q: What meaneth the noise of this tumult ?
Till in loud tumult all the Greeks arose.

sn.def: Violent commotion or agitation, with confusion of sounds; as, the tumult of the elements.
Irregular or confused motion; agitation; high excitement; as, the tumult of the spirits or passions.
sn.syn: Uproar; ferment; disturbance; turbulence; disorder; confusion; noise; bluster; hubbub; bustle; stir; brawl; riot.

entry.def: To make a tumult; to be in great commotion.
entry.q: Importuning and tumulting even to the fear of a revolt.

entry.def: A maker of tumults.
entry.q: He severely punished the tumulters.

entry.def: In a tumultuary manner.
The quality or state of being tumultuary.

entry.ety: L. tumultuarius: cf. F. tumultuaire

sn.def: Attended by, or producing, a tumult; disorderly; promiscuous; confused; tumultuous.
sn.q: Atumultuaryconflict.
A tumultuary attack of the Celtic peasantry.
Sudden flight or tumultuary skirmish.

sn.def: Restless; agitated; unquiet.
sn.q: Men who live without religion live always in a tumultuary and restless state.

entry.ety: L. tumultuatus, p. p. of tumultuari to make a tumult
entry.def: To make a tumult.
entry.q: He will murmur andtumultuate.

entry.ety: L. tumultuatio
entry.def: Irregular or disorderly movement; commotion; as, the tumultuation of the parts of a fluid.

entry.ety: L. tumultuosus: cf. F. tumultueux

sn.def: Full of tumult; characterized by tumult; disorderly; turbulent.
sn.q: The flight became wild and tumultuous.

sn.def: Conducted with disorder; noisy; confused; boisterous; disorderly; as, a tumultuous assembly or meeting.
Agitated, as with conflicting passions; disturbed.
sn.q: His dire attempt, which, nigh the birth Now rolling, boils in his tumultuous breast.

sn.def: Turbulent; violent; as, a tumultuous speech.
sn.syn: Disorderly; irregular; noisy; confused; turbulent; violent; agitated; disturbed; boisterous; lawless; riotous; seditious.

entries.entry:
Tu"mu*lus Tu"mu*lus n.; pl.Tumuli #. L., a mound, a sepulchral mound, probably from tumere to swell. Cf. Tumid
An artificial hillock, especially one raised over a grave, particularly over the graves of persons buried in ancient times; a barrow.

entry.ety: AS. tunne. See Ton a weight

sn.def: A large cask; an oblong vessel bulging in the middle, like a pipe or puncheon, and girt with hoops; a wine cask.
A fermenting vat.
A certain measure for liquids, as for wine, equal to two pipes, four hogsheads, or 252 gallons. In different countries, the tun differs in quantity.
A weight of 2,240 pounds. See Ton.
An indefinite large quantity.
sn.q: A tun of man in thy large bulk is writ.

sn.def: A drunkard; -- so called humorously, or in contempt.
Any shell belonging to Dolium and allied genera; -- called also tun-shell.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tunned; p. pr. & vb. n. Tunning
entry.def: To put into tuns, or casks.
The Opuntia Tuna. See Prickly pear, under Prickly.

entry.note: The little tunny (Gymnosarda alletterata) of the Mediterranean and North Atlantic, and the long-finned tunny, or albacore (Thunnus alalunga) (see Albacore), are related species of smaller size.
entry.ety: Cf. Tunny

sn.def: Any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging to the mackerel family Scombridae, especially the bluefin tuna Thunnus thynnus, formerly Orcynus thynnusorAlbacora thynnus), called also the common tunny or great tunny, a native of the Mediterranean Sea and of temperate parts of the Atlantic Ocean. It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and is caught commercially in large quantity for use as food; -- also called, especially in Britain, tunny. It is also one of the favorite fishes used by the Japanese in preparing sushi. On the American coast, especially in New England, it is sometimes called the horse mackerel. Another well-known species is the yellowfin tuna Thunnus albacares) of warm seas. the See Illust. of Horse mackerel, under Horse.
The bonito, 2.
the meat of the tuna, used as food; -- also called tuna fish.

entry.def: Capable of being tuned, or made harmonious; hence, harmonious; musical; tuneful.
entry.q: And tunable as sylvan pipe or song.

entry.def: Having a large, protuberant belly, or one shaped like a tun; pot-bellied.
A tunnel.

entry.ety: Russ
entry.def: One of the level or undulating treeless plains characteristic of northern arctic regions in both hemispheres; the term is most commony associated with the arctic plains of Siberia. The tundras mark the limit of arborescent vegetation; they consist of black mucky soil with a permanently frozen subsoil, but support a dense growth of mosses and lichens, and dwarf herbs and shrubs, often showy-flowered.

entry.ety: A variant of tone

sn.def: A sound; a note; a tone.
sn.q: Thetuneof your voices.

sd.def: A rhythmical, melodious, symmetrical series of tones for one voice or instrument, or for any number of voices or instruments in unison, or two or more such series forming parts in harmony; a melody; an air; as, a merry tune; a mournful tune; a slow tune; a psalm tune. See Air.

The state of giving the proper sound or sounds; just intonation; harmonious accordance; pitch of the voice or an instrument; adjustment of the parts of an instrument so as to harmonize with itself or with others; as, the piano, or the organ, is not in tune .
sd.q: Like sweet bells jangled, out of tune and harsh.

sn.def: Order; harmony; concord; fit disposition, temper, or humor; right mood.
sn.q: A child will learn three times as much when he is in tune, as when he . . . is dragged unwillingly to [his task].

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tuned tūnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Tuning

sn.def: To put into a state adapted to produce the proper sounds; to harmonize, to cause to be in tune; to correct the tone of; as, to tune a piano or a violin.
sn.q: Tuneyour harps.

sn.def: To give tone to; to attune; to adapt in style of music; to make harmonious.
sn.q: For now to sorrow must I tune my song.

sn.def: To sing with melody or harmony.
sn.q: Fountains, and ye, that warble, as ye flow, Melodious murmurs, warbling tune his praise.

sn.def: To put into a proper state or disposition.
To form one sound to another; to form accordant musical sounds.
sn.q: Whilst tuning to the water's fall, The small birds sang to her.

sn.def: To utter inarticulate harmony with the voice; to sing without pronouncing words; to hum.

entry.def: Harmonious; melodious; musical; as, tuneful notes.
entry.q: Tunefulbirds.

sn.def: Without tune; inharmonious; unmusical.
sn.q: Thytunelessserenade.
How often have I led thy sportive choir, With tuneless pipe, beside the murmuring Loire!

sn.def: Not employed in making music; as, tuneless harps.
Not expressed in music or poetry; unsung.

entry.def: One who tunes; especially, one whose occupation is to tune musical instruments.
Having the circumference of a tun.

entry.ety: Cf. F. tungstate
entry.def: A salt of tungstic acid; a wolframate.

cs.cd: tungstite.

entry.ety: Sw. tungstencf. Dan. tungsteen, G. tungstein); tung heavy (akin to Dan. tung, Icel. þungr) + sten stone. See Stone

sn.def: A rare element of the chromium group found in certain minerals, as wolfram and scheelite, and isolated as a heavy steel-gray metal which is very hard and infusible. It has both acid and basic properties. When alloyed in small quantities with steel, it greatly increases its hardness. Symbol W (Wolframium). Atomic weight, 183.6. Specific gravity, 18.
Scheelite, or calcium tungstate.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to tungsten; containing tungsten; as, tungstenic ores.

entries.entry: Tung"sten lamp. An electric glow lamp having filaments of metallic tungsten, and contained in a glass bulb which is evacuated or has an inert gas, to avoid oxidation of the tungsten; a common form of light bulb. Such lamps, owing to the refractory nature of the metal, may be maintained at a very high temperature and require an expenditure of only about 1.25 watts per candle power, depending on the total wattage and the design of the bulb. By mid-20th century tungsten lamps became the most common type of incandescent (as contrasted with fluorescent) lamp; thus the phrase incandescent lamp or incandescent light typically refers to a tungsten lamp.

Tungsten steel. Metal A steel containing a small amount of tungsten, noted for tenacity and hardness, even under a considerable degree of heat. Magnets made of it are said to be highly permanent. It often contains manganese.

cs.cd: an acid of tungsten, H2WO4, analogous to sulphuric and chromic acids.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to tungsten; derived from, or resembling, tungsten; wolframic; as, tungstic oxide.
The oxide of tungsten, a yellow mineral occurring in a pulverulent form. It is often associated with wolfram.
A group of roving Turanian tribes occupying Eastern Siberia and the Amur valley. They resemble the Mongols.
Of or pertaining to the Tunguses; as, the Tungusic dialects.

entry.ety: Cf. Alehoof
entry.def: Ground ivy; alehoof.

entry.ety: L. tunica: cf. F. tunique

sn.def: An under-garment worn by the ancient Romans of both sexes. It was made with or without sleeves, reached to or below the knees, and was confined at the waist by a girdle.
Any similar garment worn by ancient or Oriental peoples; also, a common name for various styles of loose-fitting under-garments and over-garments worn in modern times by Europeans and others.
Same as Tunicle.
A membrane, or layer of tissue, especially when enveloping an organ or part, as the eye.
A natural covering; an integument; as, the tunic of a seed.
See Mantle n., 3 .

entries.entry: Tu"ni*ca*ry n.; pl.Tunicaries #. L. tunica a tunic Zoöl One of the Tunicata.

entry.note: ☞ Most of the species when mature are firmly attached to foreign substances, but have free-swimming larvæ which are furnished with an elongated tail and somewhat resemble a tadpole. In this state the larva has a urochord and certain other structures resembling some embryonic vertebrates. See Ascidian Doliolum Salpa Urochord, and Illust. of Social ascidian, under Social.
entry.ety: NL. See Tunicate
entry.def: A grand division of the animal kingdom, intermediate, in some respects, between the invertebrates and vertebrates, and in modern classifications considered a subphylum of the vertebrates; called also urochordata. They were formerly classed with acephalous mollusks. The body is usually covered with a firm external tunic, consisting in part of cellulose, and having two openings, one for the entrance and one for the exit of water. The pharynx is usually dilated in the form of a sac, pierced by several series of ciliated slits, and serves as a gill.

entry.ety: L. tunicatus, p. p. of tunicare to clothe with a tunic, fr. tunica a tunic

sn.def: Covered with a tunic; covered or coated with layers; as, a tunicated bulb.

sd.def: Having a tunic, or mantle; of or pertaining to the Tunicata.
Having each joint buried in the preceding funnel-shaped one, as in certain antennæ of insects.

entry.def: One of the Tunicata.
Animal cellulose; a substance present in the mantle, or tunic, of the Tunicates, which resembles, or is identical with, the cellulose of the vegetable kingdom.

entry.ety: L. tunicula a little tunic, coat, or membrane, dim. of tunica a tunic: cf. OF. tunicle

sn.def: A slight natural covering; an integument.
sn.q: The tunicles that make the ball or apple of the eye.

sn.def: A short, close-fitting vestment worn by bishops under the dalmatic, and by subdeacons.

cs.cd: a steel instrument consisting of two prongs and a handle, which, being struck, gives a certain fixed tone. It is used for tuning instruments, or for ascertaining the pitch of tunes.

entry.def: a. & n. from Tune v.
A sharp blow; a thump.
entry.mark: Prov. Eng. or Colloq. U. S

entry.def: Same as Dunker.

entry.ety: From Tun; cf. Tonnage
entry.def: See Tonnage.

cs.cd: the top of a smelting furnace where the materials are put in.
a limekiln in which coal is burned, as distinguished from a flame kiln, in which wood or peat is used.
a net with a wide mouth at one end and narrow at the other.
a pit or shaft sunk from the top of the ground to the level of a tunnel, for drawing up the earth and stones, for ventilation, lighting, and the like.

entry.ety: F. tonnelle a semicircular, wagon-headed vault, a tunnel net, an arbor, OF. also tonnel; dim. of tonne a tun; -- so named from its resemblance to a tun in shape. See Ton

sn.def: A vessel with a broad mouth at one end, and a pipe or tube at the other, for conveying liquor, fluids, etc., into casks, bottles, or other vessels; a funnel.
The opening of a chimney for the passage of smoke; a flue; a funnel.
sn.q: And one great chimney, whose long tunnel thence The smoke forth threw.

sn.def: An artificial passage or archway for conducting canals, roads, or railroads under elevated ground, for the formation of roads under rivers or canals, and the construction of sewers, drains, and the like.

A level passage driven across the measures, or at right angles to veins which it is desired to reach; -- distinguished from the drift, or gangway, which is led along the vein when reached by the tunnel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Tunneled tŭn"nĕld or Tunnelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Tunneling or Tunnelling

sn.def: To form into a tunnel, or funnel, or to form like a tunnel; as, to tunnel fibrous plants into nests.
To catch in a tunnel net.
To make an opening, or a passageway, through or under; as, to tunnel a mountain; to tunnel a river.

entry.def: To make a tunnel; as, to tunnel under a river.

entries.entry: Tun"nel stern. A design of motor-boat stern, for use in shallow waters, in which the propeller is housed in a tunnel and does not extend below the greatest draft.

Tun"ny ☞ The little tunny (Gymnosarda alletterata) of the Mediterranean and North Atlantic, and the long-finned tunny, or albicore (Thunnus alalunga, see Albacore), are related species of smaller size. tŭn"n� n.; pl.Tunnies #. L. thunnus thynnus, Gr. qy`nnos qy^nos: cf. It. tonno, F. & Pr. thon
Zoöl The chiefly British equivalent of tuna; any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging to the Mackerel family, especially the common or great tunny (Thunnus thynnus syn. Albacora thynnus, formerly Orcynus thynnus) native of the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and is extensively caught in the Mediterranean. On the American coast it is called horse mackerel. See Illust. of Horse mackerel, under Horse.
thynny

entry.ety: Probably akin to top summit, head

sn.def: To butt, as a ram does.
To cover; -- said of a ram.

entry.def: A ram.
Any one of the tupaiids.
Any one of several species of East Indian and Asiatic insectivores of the family Tupaiidæ, somewhat resembling squirrels in size and arboreal habits. The nose is long and pointed.

cs.cd: an American tree (Nyssa uniflora) with softer wood than the tupelo.
the Ogeechee lime.

entry.ety: Tupelo, or tupebo, the native American Indian name
entry.def: A North American tree (Nyssa multiflora) of the Dogwood family, having brilliant, glossy foliage and acid red berries. The wood is crossgrained and very difficult to split. Called also black gum sour gum, and pepperidge.

An Indian of the tribe from which the Tupian stock takes its name, dwelling, at the advent of the Portuguese, about the mouth of the Amazon. Also, their language, which is the basis of the Indian trade language of the Amazon.

Designating, or pertaining to, a linguistic stock of South American Indians comprising the most important Brazilian tribes. Agriculture, pottery, and stone working were practiced by them at the time of the conquest. The Tupi and the Guarani were originally the most powerful of the stock, which is hence also called Tupi-Guaranian.

entries.entry: Tup"man n.; pl.Tupmen. A man who breeds, or deals in tups. Prov. Eng

sn.def: A former U.K. silver coin; a U.K. bronze decimal coin worth two pennies.
sn.syn: twopence

entry.ety: Trade name

sn.def: the collective trade name for a type of plastic food-storage container with a translucent bottom and a close-fitting lid designed to seal the container tightly. It is in common use in the late 20th century and early 21st century in the U. S. It comes in a variety of shapes and sizes, suitable for storing a variety of items. Also used attributively.
sn.illu: She saved the leftovers in a couple of Tupperware containers.

entry.def: a social gathering at which the host (or more typically hostess) entertains the guests, and provides them with an opportunity to order Tupperware. This was used as an effective sales strategy by the Tupperware manufacturer, and provided income to the host(ess) from commissions on sales.

entry.ety: Canadian F. See Toque
entry.def: A kind of warm cap winter wear, made from a knit bag with closed tapered ends by pushing one end within the other, thus making a conical cap of double thickness.
entry.q: Picturesque fellow with tuques, red sashes, and fur coats.

entry.ety: Pol
entry.def: The urus.
A red or crimson pigment obtained from certain feathers of several species of turacou; whence the name. It contains nearly six per cent of copper.

entry.ety: Cf. F. touraco
entry.def: Any one of several species of large brightly crested birds of the genus Turacus, native of Africa. They eat plantain and are remarkable for the peculiar green and red pigments found in their feathers.

entry.ety: See Turacou, and Verdant
entry.def: A green pigment found in the feathers of the turacou. See Turacin.

entry.ety: From Tur, the name, in Persian legendary history, of one of the three brothers from whom sprang the races of mankind
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an extensive family of languages of simple structure and low grade (called also Altaic Ural-Altaic, and Scythian), spoken in the northern parts of Europe and Asia and in Central Asia; of pertaining to, or designating, the people who speak these languages.
One of the Turanians.
An extensive division of mankind including the Mongols and allied races of Asia, together with the Malays and Polynesians.
A group of races or tribes inhabiting Asia and closely related to the Mongols.
The hare kangaroo.

entry.ety: OE. turband turbant tolibant, F. turban, It. turbante, Turk. tulbend dulbend, fr. Per. dulband. Cf. Tulip

sn.def: A headdress worn by men in the Levant and by many Muslims of the male sex, consisting of a cap, and a sash, scarf, or shawl, usually of cotton or linen, wound about the cap, and sometimes hanging down the neck.
A kind of headdress worn by women.
The whole set of whorls of a spiral shell.

entry.def: A turban.
Wearing a turban.
entry.q: A malignant and aturbanedTurk.

entry.def: A sea urchin when deprived of its spines; -- popularly so called from a fancied resemblance to a turban.
A turban.
entry.q: I see the Turk nodding with his turbant.

entry.def: A kind of fungus with an irregularly wrinkled, somewhat globular pileus (Helvella esculenta syn. Gyromitra esculenta.).

entries.entry:
Tur"ba*ry n.; pl.Turbaries #. LL. turbaria a place for digging peat, from turba peat. See Turf
Eng. Law A right of digging turf on another man's land; also, the ground where turf is dug.

entry.ety: NL., dim. fr. L. turbo a whirling
entry.def: An extensive group of worms which have the body covered externally with vibrating cilia. It includes the Rhabdocœla and Dendrocœla. Formerly, the nemerteans were also included in this group.
One of the Turbellaria. Also used adjectively.
See Turpeth.

entry.ety: L. turbidus, from turba tumult, disturbance, akin to turbare to disturb. See Trouble, and cf. Disturb Perturb

sn.def: Not clear; having suspended matter that scatters light passing through; having the lees or sediment disturbed; roiled; muddy; thick; -- used of liquids of any kind; as, turbid water; turbid wine.
sn.q: On that strong, turbid water, a small boat, Guided by one weak hand, was seen to float.

sn.def: Disturbed; confused; disordered.
sn.q: Suchturbidintervals that use to attend close prisoners.

entry.def: Turbidness.

sn.def: In a turbid manner; with muddiness or confusion.
Proudly; haughtily.
sn.q: One of great merit turbidly resents them.

entry.def: The quality or state of being turbid; muddiness; foulness.

entry.ety: F. tourbillon, from L. turbo a whirl
entry.def: A whirl; a vortex.

entry.ety: See Turbary
entry.def: Of or pertaining to peat, or turf; of the nature of peat, or turf; peaty; turfy.

entry.note: ☞ There are usually several of these plates in each nasal chamber. The upper ones, connected directly with the ethmoid bone, are called ethmoturbinals, and the lower, connected with the maxillæ, maxillo-turbinals. Incurved portions of the wall of the nasal chamber are sometimes called pseudoturbinals, to distinguish them from the true turbinals which are free outgrowths into the chambers.
entry.ety: L. turbo turben -inis, a top, whirl
entry.def: Rolled in a spiral; scroll-like; turbinate; -- applied to the thin, plicated, bony or cartilaginous plates which support the olfactory and mucous membranes of the nasal chambers.
A turbinal bone or cartilage.
To revolve or spin like a top; to whirl.

entry.ety: L. turbinatus, fr. turbo turben turbinis, a whirl, top

sn.def: Whirling in the manner of a top.
sn.q: A spiral and turbinated motion of the whole.

sn.def: Shaped like a top, or inverted cone; narrow at the base, and broad at the apex; as, a turbinated ovary, pericarp, or root.
Turbinal.
Spiral with the whorls decreasing rapidly from a large base to a pointed apex; -- said of certain shells.

entry.ety: Cf. L. tirbinatio a pointing in the form of a cone. See Turbinate
entry.def: The act of spinning or whirling, as a top.

entry.note: ☞ In some turbines, the water is supplied to the wheel from below, instead of above. Turbines in which the water flows in a direction parallel to the axis are called parallel-flow turbines.

In the 1913 dictionary, the turbine was further decribed thus: “There are practically only two distinct kinds, and they are typified in the de Laval and the Parsons and Curtis turbines. The de Laval turbine is an impulse turbine, in which steam impinges upon revolving blades from a flared nozzle. The flare of the nozzle causes expansion of the steam, and hence changes its pressure energy into kinetic energy. An enormous velocity (30,000 revolutions per minute in the 5 H. P. size) is requisite for high efficiency, and the machine has therefore to be geared down to be of practical use. Some recent development of this type include turbines formed of several de Laval elements compounded as in the ordinary expansion engine. The Parsons turbine is an impulse-and-reaction turbine, usually of the axial type. The steam is constrained to pass successively through alternate rows of fixed and moving blades, being expanded down to a condenser pressure of about 1 lb. per square inch absolute. The Curtis turbine is somewhat simpler than the Parsons, and consists of elements each of which has at least two rows of moving blades and one row of stationary. The bucket velocity is lowered by fractional velocity reduction. Both the Parsons and Curtis turbines are suitable for driving dynamos and steamships directly. In efficiency, lightness, and bulk for a given power, they compare favorably with reciprocating engines.”
entry.ety: L. turbo -inis, that which spins or whirls round, whirl

sn.def: A water wheel, commonly horizontal, variously constructed, but usually having a series of curved floats or buckets, against which the water acts by its impulse or reaction in flowing either outward from a central chamber, inward from an external casing, or from above downward, etc.; -- also called turbine wheel.

A type of rotary engine with a set of rotating vanes, diagonally inclined and often curved, attached to a central spindle, and obtaining its motive force from the passage of a fluid, as water, steam, combusted gases, or air, over the vanes. Water turbines are frequently used for generating power at hydroelectric power stations, and steam turbines are used for generating power from coal- or oil-fired electric power stations. Turbines are also found in jet engines, and in some automobile engines.

entry.ety: NL., dim. fr. L. turbo -inis, a top
entry.def: A genus of large marine gastropods having a thick heavy shell with conspicuous folds on the columella.

entry.ety: NL. Turbo, the generic name, fr. L. turbo a whirl, top: cf. F. turbinite
entry.def: A petrified shell resembling a member of the genus Turbo.

entry.ety: See Turbo, and -oid
entry.def: Like or pertaining to Turbo or the family Turbinidæ.

entry.ety: Cf. Turbot

sn.def: The turbot.
A variety of the domestic pigeon, remarkable for its short beak.

entry.def: A fossil turbo.

entry.ety: F., fr. Per. See Turpeth
entry.def: See Turpeth.

entry.ety: L. turbo -inis, a top. See Turbine
entry.def: Any one of numerous marine gastropods of the genus Turbo or family Turbinidæ, usually having a turbinate shell, pearly on the inside, and a calcareous operculum.
Sontaining or using a turbine; -- a combining form; as, turbojet.

entry.ety: See Turbine, and Generator
entry.def: An electric generator or dynamo which is combined on one frame with a turbomotor, by which it is driven.

entry.cs: Spotted turbot. See Windowpane.
entry.ety: [F.; -- probably so named from its shape, and from L. turbo a top, a whirl
entry.def: A large European flounder (Rhombus maximus) highly esteemed as a food fish. It often weighs from thirty to forty pounds. Its color on the upper side is brownish with small roundish tubercles scattered over the surface. The lower, or blind, side is white. Called also bannock fluke.

Any one of numerous species of flounders more or less related to the true turbots, as the American plaice, or summer flounder (see Flounder), the halibut, and the diamond flounder (Hypsopsetta guttulata) of California.
The filefish; -- so called in Bermuda.
The trigger fish.

entry.ety: L. turbulentia: cf. F. turbulence
entry.def: The quality or state of being turbulent; a disturbed state; tumult; disorder; agitation.
entry.q: The years of . . . warfare and turbulence which ensued.
entry.syn: Agitation; commotion; tumult; tumultuousness; termagance; unruliness; insubordination; rioting.

entry.def: Turbulence.
entry.q: What a tale of terror now its turbulency tells!

entry.ety: L. turbulentus, fr. turba disorder, tumult: cf. F. turbulent. See Turbid

sn.def: Disturbed; agitated; tumultuous; roused to violent commotion; as, the turbulent ocean.
sn.q: Calm region once, And full of peace, now tossed and turbulent.

sn.def: Disposed to insubordination and disorder; restless; unquiet; refractory; as, turbulent spirits.
sn.q: Sagacious, bold, and turbulent of wit.

sn.def: Producing commotion; disturbing; exciting.
sn.q: Whose heads that turbulent liquor fills with fumes.
sn.syn: Disturbed; agitated; tumultuous; riotous; seditious; insubordinate; refractory; unquiet.

entry.def: In a turbulent manner.
A mode of speech peculiar to the Turks; a Turkish idiom or expression; also, in general, a Turkish mode or custom. Same as Turkism.

a kind of carpet or rug supposed to be made by the Turcomans.
pr. n.; pl.Turcomans.
A member of a tribe of Turanians inhabiting a region east of the Caspian Sea.
A Turcoman carpet.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. turdus a thrush + forma form
entry.def: A division of singing birds including the thrushes and allied kinds.

entry.ety: L., a thrush
entry.def: A genus of singing birds including the true thrushes.

entry.ety: F. terrine, L. terra earth. See Terrace
entry.def: A large, deep vessel for holding soup, or other liquid food, at the table.

entries.entry: Tu*reen"ful n.; pl.Tureenfuls. As much as a tureen can hold; enough to fill a tureen.

Turf ☞ Turf is often used adjectively, or to form compounds which are generally self-explaining; as, turf ashes, turf cutter or turf-cutter, turf pit or turf-pit, turf-built, turf-clad, turf-covered, etc.
Turf ant Zoöl a small European ant (Formica flava) which makes small ant-hills on heaths and commons. Turf drain a drain made with turf or peat. Turf hedge a hedge or fence formed with turf and plants of different kinds. Turf house a house or shed formed of turf, common in the northern parts of Europe. Turf moss a tract of turfy, mossy, or boggy land. Turf spade a spade for cutting and digging turf, longer and narrower than the common spade.
tûrf n.; pl.Turfs tûrfs Obs. Turves tûrvz. AS. turf; akin to D. turf peat, G. torf, OHG. zurba turf, Sw. & Icel. torf turf, peat, Dan. törv, Skr. darbha a kind of grass, a tuft of grass. √242
That upper stratum of earth and vegetable mold which is filled with the roots of grass and other small plants, so as to adhere and form a kind of mat; sward; sod. At his head a grass-green turf. The Greek historian sets her in the field on a high heap of turves.
Peat, especially when prepared for fuel. See Peat.
Race course; horse racing; -- preceded by the. We . . . claim the honors of theturf.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Turfed; p. pr. & vb. n. Turfing
entry.def: To cover with turf or sod; as, to turf a bank, or the border of a terrace.
Made of turf; covered with turf.
Quality or state of being turfy.

cs.cd: an implement for cutting, and paring off, turf.

entry.def: The act or process of providing or covering with turf.
A votary of the turf, or race course; hence, sometimes, a blackleg.
Destitute of turf.

entries.entry: Turf"man tûrf"m�n n.; pl.Turfmen tûrf"m�n. A turfite; a votary of the turf, or race course. Colloq

sn.def: Abounding with turf; made of, or covered with, turf.
sn.q: Theturfymountains.

sn.def: Having the nature or appearance of turf.
Of or pertaining to the turf, or horse racing.

entry.ety: L. turgens -entis, p. pr. of turgere to swell

sn.def: Rising into a tumor, or a puffy state; swelling; tumid; as, turgent humors.
Inflated; bombastic; turgid; pompous.
sn.q: Recompensed with turgent titles.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Turgesced; p. pr. & vb. n. Turgescing
entry.ety: L. turgescere, v. incho. fr. turgere to swell
entry.def: To become turgid; to swell or be inflated.

entry.ety: Cf. F. turgescence. See Turgescent

sn.def: The act of swelling, or the state of being swollen, or turgescent.
Empty magnificence or pompousness; inflation; bombast; turgidity.

entry.ety: L. turgescens -entis, p. pr. of turgescere: cf. F. turgescent. See Turgesce
entry.def: Becoming turgid or inflated; swelling; growing big.

entry.ety: L. turgidus, from turgere to swell

sn.def: Distended beyond the natural state by some internal agent or expansive force; swelled; swollen; bloated; inflated; tumid; -- especially applied to an enlarged part of the body; as, a turgid limb; turgid fruit.
sn.q: A bladder . . . held near the fire grew turgid.

sn.def: Swelling in style or language; vainly ostentatious; bombastic; pompous; as, a turgid style of speaking.

entry.def: The quality or state of being turgid.
Turgid.

entry.def: The golden oriole.
Same as Turio.

entry.ety: L. turio a sprout + -ferous
